fields.headline: God's gift to women
fields.standfirst:
She's our greatest living novelist, the first woman with the gift to write like Shakespeare, with exuberance and passion. Who says so? She does. And her next book is due out very soon

Books Unlimited
fields.trailText: She's our greatest living novelist, the first woman with the gift to write like Shakespeare, with exuberance and passion. Who says so? She does. And her next book is due out very soon
fields.body:
In the beginning was the book. It came to her in 1983, when she was 24 not long out of Oxford but already disenchanted with London. Desperate not to follow her old classmates into banking or advertising or indeed any job that came with routine hours, she was considering a move to the country when suddenly she found herself writing. 'It was not an accident, or an experiment, or a whim,' she later recalled, 'it was a downstream force by a high wind. It was as though the book was already written, such was the speed and certainty of its being. How had this thing overtaken me? I realised that I was not going to start a smallholding.'

The heroine of this book is a girl named Jeanette whose story bears a close resemblance her creator's. Born near Manchester, adopted by Pentecostalists as an infant and raised to become a missionary, the fictitious Jeanette is ejected from her church in her teens after her adoptive mother denounces her publicly for a lesbian affair. But as in life, it turns out to be a blessing in disguise.

When it was done, the real Jeanette looked at her work and was very, very pleased. It was, she later wrote, quite unlike any book ever written. Not only was it deeply threatening to the status quo: it was also a deeply comforting narrative with universal appeal. What's more, it was technically brilliant, partly because it was shaped like a spiral. This, she felt, gave it a fluidity that allowed 'infinite movement'.

Having packed all that into a mere 170 or so pages, she took Oranges Are Not the Only Fruit , for that was its name, to Phillippa Brewster at Pandora. Catching this editor's eye was not too difficult as Jeanette happened to be working in her office at the time. It was love at first sight for Phillippa, but she had to fight like hell to convince her bosses that the book had potential. In the end she could only get them to do it in paperback. When it went on to win the 1985 Whitbread Prize for best first novel, no one was less surprised than the author.

There followed a brief literary honeymoon. Everyone was calling her a breath of fresh air. In describing her style, they used the same words she did: scintillating, fluid, radiant, humming, daring, formidable, brilliant, biblical, head and shoulders above her contemporaries. The only spoilsports at this point were a handful of her peers from St Catherine's College, Oxford. They spoke darkly of megalomania and hubris: this woman did not just act like God, they said, she actually thought she was God. But most of these naysayers were just starting out in publishing, they didn't have much clout, and no one listened to them.

By now Jeanette had an agent who loved her dearly, and through this agent she had met Ruth and Don Rendell, who were so taken with her that they offered Jeanette their garden shed as a study. She also had a new editor, Liz Calder at Bloomsbury, and a new novel called The Passion that everyone at Bloomsbury was just over the moon about. They loved the next novel, Sexing the Cherry, even more. So did the critics. But it was a pity, more people began to say, about the author.

My first brush with her was at a reading at the ICA. It was the first event on a national publicity tour with two other women authors. At the ICA they had equal billing, but at the last minute Jeanette announced that she was having none of that. She took over as chair, which turned out to be an even more laughable figure of speech than usual. Not once did she sit down. Instead she stood at the front of the stage, pontificating away, and only occasionally looking down at her stage companions to invite them to speak.

The publishers had organised a dinner. Jeanette, I was later told, declined to attend. She also declined to travel by train with the other authors during their national tour. Instead she insisted on, and apparently got, her own chauffeur-driven car.

The refrain among gossips now became: 'Who does she think she is?' We soon found out. Her first truly outrageous public act was on a special film the Late Show did in connection with her fourth novel, Written on the Body. The film ended with a sequence of Jeanette tramping across a park looking intensely into the camera while sporting her famous impish grin, and reminding us of the passage in A Room of One's Own in which Virginia Woolf expresses the hope that one day, perhaps 50 years on, there would be a woman writing in English whose gifts were equal to Shakespeare's. She then went on to announce that she was that woman.

She went on to tell a tabloid interviewer that the novel (about an unnamed, sexually ambiguous narrator's affair with a married woman) was based on her own stormy lesbian affair with her agent. Who was no longer her agent. She didn't need an agent, she said, as she now had a coven (her term for the tight network of close female friends who help run her household) and a wife. If Peggy Reynolds, the distinguished academic and broadcaster, took issue with Jeanette for talking about her like this, she did not let on.

Unchecked, Jeanette went on to fly even closer to the sun. Not only did she name her own novel as Book of the Year: in 1995, when she was asked to name her favourite living author, she chose herself. 'No one working in the English language now comes close to my exuberance, my passion, and my fidelity to words.'

But the tide was turning. Reviews for Written on the Body were mixed. Art and Lies got a mostly negative reception. The cut that seems to have hurt the most came from Nicci Gerrard, a longtime friend and admirer who had published Jeanette in the mid-Eighties when she was an editor at Women's Review.

In a painstakingly balanced profile she did for The Observer, Nicci said that she thought Jeanette had gone off the boil, and suggested that this could be because she was cutting herself off from the outside world and surrounding herself with yes-women. Late one night not long after this profile was published, Jeanette and Peggy fitted themselves out in their biker leathers (so the story goes) and went out to settle scores.

But their timing could not have been worse. It was only after they had barged into Nicci Gerrard's north London home that they saw there was a dinner party in full swing. They would not have known, but they ought to have guessed, that almost all the people round the table would be journalists. And who could blame those journalists for telling everyone they ran into what happened when they went back to their offices?

The backlash was vicious and went on for years. Although no one could say that she didn't ask for it, there was still something ugly about the way the press boys went after her, ridiculing her not just for her bad behaviour and her mad claims, but also for being a lesbian, living an unusual life, daring to take herself as seriously in public as, let's be honest, almost all novelists do when hiding in the safety of their own closets.

The difference between Jeanette Winterson and most of her contemporaries is that she doesn't know where to stop. She doesn't know because she didn't grow up in a nice middle-class please-and-thank-you sort of family. In spite of the fun she's made of the weird evangelists who had brought her up, she's still very much their daughter, and she's embraced her new art-for-art's sake creed with the same passion she had once embraced God.

She belongs to another age. Paris in the Twenties would have suited her perfectly. Gertrude Stein would have found her manner and her way of life almost too acceptable to mention.

Arthur Miller and Anais Nïn would not have criticised her for her lack of irony. Scott Fitzgerald would have called her the new Oscar Wilde and Zelda would have kept it from going to her head. No one would have been too upset about her bad behaviour, because wasn't that what writers were put on Earth to do?

But the bohemian age is over. Today, if you want to survive in the writing game, you have to learn to think and act corporate. If you don't, it's headline news and then the cold shoulder. It is not surprising that Jeanette Winterson became more of a recluse after the papers gave her the treatment. But even after Gut Symmetries, which got a truly hostile press, her books did not stop selling, and she did not stop writing.

Now she has a new book, which she and her publishers have gone out of their way to encourage readers to judge by its cover. It's called The PowerBook, and it looks an awful lot like a Mac. Advance readers who were not put off by this gimmick say that it's as good as her best-loved early novels, even though it has all of the excesses that put so many readers off the later ones.

Their descriptions of the book are confusing, because they use the same words people use to describe Jeanette herself: audacious, funny and humourless, clever but infuriating, stagey, authoritative, crazily overstretched and overblown, bullying but at the same time curiously defenceless. A true romantic, they say. Utterly ruthless, but utterly obsessed with love.

How can it all add up into one person? Perhaps it doesn't matter how they do their sums, so long as they can find it in themselves to let her be.

Jeanette Winterson

DoB: 27 August 1959

Educated: St Catherine's College, Oxford (BA Hons English)

Partner: Dr M. Reynolds

Books: Oranges Are Not the Only Fruit (1985); The Passion (1987); Sexing the Cherry (1989); Written on the Body (1992); Art and Lies (1994); Gut Symmetries (1997); PowerBook (2000)

Passions: Opera, ballet, champagne

webTitle: Gore gives America a stark choice

fields.headline: Gore gives America a stark choice
fields.standfirst:
It was trailed as the most important speech the Vice-President would ever make - the reaction to Gore's pledge to shake off the past and be his own man

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: It was trailed as the most important speech the Vice-President would ever make - the reaction to Gore's pledge to shake off the past and be his own man
fields.body:
Down in the mosh pit, while Al Gore was midway through his coming-out speech, two of his aides slapped a high five; his young and idealistic speechwriter, Eli Attie, and seasoned, cynical 'message guru', Carter Eskew.

'I stand here tonight,' Gore had just told the electrified crowd, 'as my own man'. It was the moment of the passing of the torch, the handover of the leadership of the Democrat Party - and maybe the White House - by the President who had stolen the show on Monday night. His deputy and political 'son' was now delivering the most important speech of his life.

To the delight of Gore's audience and the surprise of many, he rose to the occasion with a declaration of war in a time of peace; with impatience at a time of prosperity and content. Naomi Wolf's 'Alpha Male' had broken free.

The speech was unabashedly populist, a class-conscious battle-cry crafted to forge an abyss between himself and his opponent, George W. Bush, who next day accused Gore of 'class warfare'. Gore cast Bush as a defender of 'powerful interests', while he would champion the 'working families of America'.

It is a high-risk strategy, which enlivens the struggle against Bush. This now becomes - issue for issue, brick by brick - the most politically polarised election since Ronald Reagan's.

'The presidency,' said Gore, 'is more than a popularity contest' - a dig at Bush and, in its way, at Clinton too - 'it is a day-to-day fight for people. There are big choices ahead and a shopping list of reforms in education, health-care, social security, law and order, and our whole future is at stake ... We have got to win this election.' This was not a 'new' Al Gore, but it was - as one of his close aides said - 'as good as he gets', when it mattered most.

Gore took a big gamble last week in Los Angeles. He was forced into it not so much by his own convictions as by the most contorted and complex heredity ever bestowed on a politician - a miasma of personal and political relationships.

Talking to The Observer after the speech, one of Gore's closest aides said: 'It's been so incredibly complicated - like a family fraught with relationships and loyalties pulling and pushing him in all directions. Clinton, Hillary, Monica, the whole White House thing.'

Foremost among those relationships is that with the President, out of whose long shadow Gore had to emerge if he was to live up to the declaration of independence that Attie and Eskew (among others) enjoyed so much.

Last week Clinton cast two contradictory shadows over his protégé: his lambent valediction on Monday night, and the news, leaked on the day of Gore's speech that Special Prosecutor Kenneth Starr's successor is considering re-opening the Monica Lewinsky wound.

The President had promised not to step into Gore's spotlight, but he could hardly help being himself. Everyone agreed that Clinton's farewell address was a star performance.

Far from setting the stage for Gore, Clinton staked his own personal claim of credit for America's good times. This is something Clinton has always felt he was due, but not granted, as his obsession with his legacy swings between three moods: contrition, whimsical melancholia and Monday's charismatic self-satisfaction. The mood swings are fast and frequent. Last week Clinton went before the cameras to clutch the hand of a tele-evangelist, describe his embarkation upon a 'new life', beg forgiveness for his 'terrible mistakes' and implore the public not to blame Al Gore.

Meanwhile, staff in the West Wing talk about Clinton's 'dark moods', which often permeate his speeches in lines that resemble those of an emperor who has seen through his own game of power play - such as, 'in 200 years' time, all of us will have been forgotten'.

Then came Monday: Clinton's contrived but effective gladiatorial walk down a tunnel leading to the stage, his shining smile and defiant response to what he took to be a personal affront from George Bush - the notion that he had somehow 'squandered' economic opportunities. It takes that kind of wound - coupled with a sense of occasion - to bring out the magic in Bill Clinton.

All three moods in the Clinton bequest created different and complex challenges for Gore last week. Gore had to maintain his distance from the Lewinsky scandal, but needed also to claim some reward for his part in Clinton's roll-call of achievement. On the other hand, he had to do this in a way that enables him to appear as a leader, not a perennial number two.

He also needed to find his own manifesto - it would not be enough to promise more of the same - especially because Bush thinks that is his line.

There were other pressures too, not least from an even longer shadow across American politics than that of Clinton, and an even more illustrious name - Kennedy. The note sounded by that name was a loud one in Los Angeles last week: it was exactly 40 years ago in LA that John F. Kennedy was nominated by the Democratic convention, announcing the 'New Frontier' in an epic speech which defined the politics and aspirations of a generation.

In the year 2000, the bridge between Clinton's big night and that of Gore's began with the remarkable appearance of four Kennedys during Tuesday, notably the secretive Caroline - sole survivor of JFK's immediate family. Her rare, elegant address was a high water mark of the convention, recalling her father's life and death, and saying: 'Now we are the New Frontier, and now that many of us are doing so well, it is time once again to ask more of ourselves. Much as we need a prosperous economy, we also need a prosperity of kindness and decency.'

The leader of the clan, Senator Ted, followed with a coded manifesto for everything that he - as guardian of the party's left wing - believes the Clinton administration should have done but did not, mainly in healthcare and social security.

In an interview with The Observer , the heir to Camelot - Patrick Kennedy, son of Bobby - said he found it 'surreal' to have his relatives take the stage in this way. 'This is not the real world here,' he said. Now in charge of the Democrats' fundraising, Congressman Kennedy added that 'politics is not about the kind of charisma that my father and uncle had; it is about hard work, everyday hard work'.

But all these Kennedy conversations and addresses had one striking feature in common: Clinton was not mentioned. Four decades on, the name Kennedy represented the liberal ideals that Clinton is thought, by the party's left, to have abandoned, or at least sidelined, and which now lodged their claim - from among the party base, at least - with his successor.

The challenge to Gore was to balance this claim - and the need to secure his own, still not conquered, party base - against the battle for the centre-ground votes and the 'undecideds', among whom he trails Bush.

Faced with this labyrinth of complex and contradictory challenges, the stakes were higher than the expectations when Gore took the podium on Thursday to take President Clinton's baton. In the event, Gore took a gamble.

He forged what may emerge as his own brand of unashamed populism, which combined some of Clinton's centrism with a decisive step to the left of the President he has served.

At a time when a largely contented electorate shows little taste for political confrontation, Gore laced Clinton's 'New Democrat' vision with more than a touch of the 'Old'. He blasted big oil, big insurance, big tobacco and big everything in bellicose language that belonged more to Franklin Roosevelt's party of the Thirties than that which Clinton returned to the presidential office eight years ago.

Gore focused not on what the Clinton administration has done, but what it left undone in the lives of those whom pundits call the 'K-Mart voter', whom Gore promised to champion and characterised as 'people trying to make house payments and car payments, working overtime to pay for college and do right by their kids'. Out of the 5,100 words in his speech, only one of them was 'Clinton'. Twenty were 'fight'.

At times, Gore's description of the political landscape even felt like a speech from opposition, rather than from the deputy leader who had painted it.

Indeed, George Bush was quick to spot this on Friday, saying that the 'laundry list' of Gore's proposed reforms 'seems like a reflection on past failures'.

In his best lines, Gore conceded that he appears 'a bit of a policy wonk' and 'won't always be the most exciting politician', but offered a stark contrast to Clinton with a pledge that: 'I will never let you down.'

The list of commitments on children, health insurance, education, guns, abortion and crime was a strident and often ambitious one, and, echoing Caroline Kennedy, Gore promised to 'challenge a culture with too much meanness and not enough meaning'.

In the aftermath of the speech, those around Gore were happy, but wary of the electoral task to which this rhetoric now commits them, and those on the left were pleasantly surprised.

Harold Ickes is the Democrats' left-wing Svengali figure and a long-time foe of Gore (he privately believes Gore cost him the post of Chief of Staff). He conceded to The Observer: 'It was good. The last quarter, very good.'

George Stephanopoulos, a key strategist in both Clinton presidential campaigns, who left Clinton's White House disappointed, told The Observer he thought 'Gore did a good job. Great speech. It's what we've been waiting to hear from him'.

The early polls suggest that America broadly agrees, but the test will come over the next few days. One source close to Gore said that the team felt the 'springboard effect of the convention has to bring Gore within three points of Bush, otherwise we're in big trouble'.

The style file: Gore and Clinton

William Jefferson Blythe Clinton IV

Born: 19 August, 1946, three months after his father died. His mother married Roger Clinton four years later.

Education: BA in Foreign Service Georgetown University (1968); Rhodes Scholar to Oxford (1968-70); law degree from Yale (1973); taught law at the University of Arkansas.

Experience: No military experience, he was a Vietnam draft-dodger. Defeated in campaign for Congress in Arkansas (1974). Elected Arkansas attorney-general (1976). Governor of Arkansas (1978) - defeated when he ran for second term. Re-elected Governor four years later and remained in office until 1992, when he became President.

Family: Wife, Hillary Rodham Clinton; Daughter, Chelsea, born 1980.

Brushes with the law: When he leaves office, may be charged with a criminal offence, when a grand jury would hear evidence to decide if Clinton committed a criminal offence by lying under oath about his affair with Monica Lewinsky.

Albert Arnold Gore Jr

Born: 31 March, 1948, to an affluent, political family. His father was Tennessee's Senator Albert Gore.

Education: B.A. in government, Harvard University (1969); Vanderbilt School of Religion (1971-72); Vanderbilt Law School (1974-1976).

Experience: US Army (1969-71), Journalist (1973-76); Congressman from Tennessee (1977-1985); Senator from Tennessee (1985-1993); Vice-President (1993-present). Gore ran for President in 1988 - when he asked for Bill Clinton's support, he was turned down. Clinton became President in 1993 - a quashed Gore had to make do with being 'Veep'.

Last week Gore moved a step to the left of Clinton on welfare and social security policy.

Family: Wife: Mary Elizabeth 'Tipper'. Four children: Karenna, 25; Kristin, 22; Sarah, 20; Albert III, 16.

Brushes with the law: Confessed to 'rare and infrequent use' of soft drugs in his youth.

This is something Clinton has always felt he was due, but not granted, as his obsession with his legacy swings between three moods: contrition, whimsical melancholia and Monday's charismatic self-satisfaction. The mood swings are fast and frequent. Last week Clinton went before the cameras to clutch the hand of a tele-evangelist, describe his embarkation upon a 'new life', beg forgiveness for his 'terrible mistakes' and implore the public not to blame Al Gore. Meanwhile, staff in the West Wing talk about Clinton's 'dark moods', which often permeate his speeches in lines that resemble those of an emperor who has seen through his own game of power play - such as, 'in 200 years' time, all of us will have been forgotten'. Then came Monday: Clinton's contrived but effective gladiatorial walk down a tunnel leading to the stage, his shining smile and defiant response to what he took to be a personal affront from George Bush - the notion that he had somehow 'squandered' economic opportunities. It takes that kind of wound - coupled with a sense of occasion - to bring out the magic in Bill Clinton. All three moods in the Clinton bequest created different and complex challenges for Gore last week. Gore had to maintain his distance from the Lewinsky scandal, but needed also to claim some reward for his part in Clinton's roll-call of achievement. On the other hand, he had to do this in a way that enables him to appear as a leader, not a perennial number two. He also needed to find his own manifesto - it would not be enough to promise more of the same - especially because Bush thinks that is his line. There were other pressures too, not least from an even longer shadow across American politics than that of Clinton, and an even more illustrious name - Kennedy. The note sounded by that name was a loud one in Los Angeles last week: it was exactly 40 years ago in LA that John F. Kennedy was nominated by the Democratic convention, announcing the 'New Frontier' in an epic speech which defined the politics and aspirations of a generation. In the year 2000, the bridge between Clinton's big night and that of Gore's began with the remarkable appearance of four Kennedys during Tuesday, notably the secretive Caroline - sole survivor of JFK's immediate family. Her rare, elegant address was a high water mark of the convention, recalling her father's life and death, and saying: 'Now we are the New Frontier, and now that many of us are doing so well, it is time once again to ask more of ourselves. Much as we need a prosperous economy, we also need a prosperity of kindness and decency.' The leader of the clan, Senator Ted, followed with a coded manifesto for everything that he - as guardian of the party's left wing - believes the Clinton administration should have done but did not, mainly in healthcare and social security. In an interview with The Observer , the heir to Camelot - Patrick Kennedy, son of Bobby - said he found it 'surreal' to have his relatives take the stage in this way. 'This is not the real world here,' he said. Now in charge of the Democrats' fundraising, Congressman Kennedy added that 'politics is not about the kind of charisma that my father and uncle had; it is about hard work, everyday hard work'. But all these Kennedy conversations and addresses had one striking feature in common: Clinton was not mentioned. Four decades on, the name Kennedy represented the liberal ideals that Clinton is thought, by the party's left, to have abandoned, or at least sidelined, and which now lodged their claim - from among the party base, at least - with his successor. The challenge to Gore was to balance this claim - and the need to secure his own, still not conquered, party base - against the battle for the centre-ground votes and the 'undecideds', among whom he trails Bush. Faced with this labyrinth of complex and contradictory challenges, the stakes were higher than the expectations when Gore took the podium on Thursday to take President Clinton's baton. In the event, Gore took a gamble. He forged what may emerge as his own brand of unashamed populism, which combined some of Clinton's centrism with a decisive step to the left of the President he has served. At a time when a largely contented electorate shows little taste for political confrontation, Gore laced Clinton's 'New Democrat' vision with more than a touch of the 'Old'. He blasted big oil, big insurance, big tobacco and big everything in bellicose language that belonged more to Franklin Roosevelt's party of the Thirties than that which Clinton returned to the presidential office eight years ago. Gore focused not on what the Clinton administration has done, but what it left undone in the lives of those whom pundits call the 'K-Mart voter', whom Gore promised to champion and characterised as 'people trying to make house payments and car payments, working overtime to pay for college and do right by their kids'. Out of the 5,100 words in his speech, only one of them was 'Clinton'. Twenty were 'fight'. At times, Gore's description of the political landscape even felt like a speech from opposition, rather than from the deputy leader who had painted it. Indeed, George Bush was quick to spot this on Friday, saying that the 'laundry list' of Gore's proposed reforms 'seems like a reflection on past failures'. In his best lines, Gore conceded that he appears 'a bit of a policy wonk' and 'won't always be the most exciting politician', but offered a stark contrast to Clinton with a pledge that: 'I will never let you down.' The list of commitments on children, health insurance, education, guns, abortion and crime was a strident and often ambitious one, and, echoing Caroline Kennedy, Gore promised to 'challenge a culture with too much meanness and not enough meaning'. In the aftermath of the speech, those around Gore were happy, but wary of the electoral task to which this rhetoric now commits them, and those on the left were pleasantly surprised. Harold Ickes is the Democrats' left-wing Svengali figure and a long-time foe of Gore (he privately believes Gore cost him the post of Chief of Staff). He conceded to The Observer: 'It was good. The last quarter, very good.' George Stephanopoulos, a key strategist in both Clinton presidential campaigns, who left Clinton's White House disappointed, told The Observer he thought 'Gore did a good job. Great speech. It's what we've been waiting to hear from him'. The early polls suggest that America broadly agrees, but the test will come over the next few days. One source close to Gore said that the team felt the 'springboard effect of the convention has to bring Gore within three points of Bush, otherwise we're in big trouble'. The style file: Gore and Clinton William Jefferson Blythe Clinton IV Born: 19 August, 1946, three months after his father died. His mother married Roger Clinton four years later. Education: BA in Foreign Service Georgetown University (1968); Rhodes Scholar to Oxford (1968-70); law degree from Yale (1973); taught law at the University of Arkansas. Experience: No military experience, he was a Vietnam draft-dodger. Defeated in campaign for Congress in Arkansas (1974). Elected Arkansas attorney-general (1976). Governor of Arkansas (1978) - defeated when he ran for second term. Re-elected Governor four years later and remained in office until 1992, when he became President. Family: Wife, Hillary Rodham Clinton; Daughter, Chelsea, born 1980. Brushes with the law: When he leaves office, may be charged with a criminal offence, when a grand jury would hear evidence to decide if Clinton committed a criminal offence by lying under oath about his affair with Monica Lewinsky. Albert Arnold Gore Jr Born: 31 March, 1948, to an affluent, political family. His father was Tennessee's Senator Albert Gore. Education: B.A. in government, Harvard University (1969); Vanderbilt School of Religion (1971-72); Vanderbilt Law School (1974-1976). Experience: US Army (1969-71), Journalist (1973-76); Congressman from Tennessee (1977-1985); Senator from Tennessee (1985-1993); Vice-President (1993-present). Gore ran for President in 1988 - when he asked for Bill Clinton's support, he was turned down. Clinton became President in 1993 - a quashed Gore had to make do with being 'Veep'. Last week Gore moved a step to the left of Clinton on welfare and social security policy. Family: Wife: Mary Elizabeth 'Tipper'. Four children: Karenna, 25; Kristin, 22; Sarah, 20; Albert III, 16. Brushes with the law: Confessed to 'rare and infrequent use' of soft drugs in his youth.

fields.headline: Woes for Wenger
fields.trailText: Arsene Wenger was spoilt for choice as he lined up the targets for his after-match verbal assault. Referee Steve Dunn's dismissal of Patrick Vieira, Sunderland's uncompromising approach and the woeful finishing of his players were all fuel for the fury of the Arsenal manager.
fields.byline: John Wardle at the Stadium of Light
fields.body:
Arsene Wenger was spoilt for choice as he lined up the targets for his after-match verbal assault. Referee Steve Dunn's dismissal of Patrick Vieira, Sunderland's uncompromising approach and the woeful finishing of his players were all fuel for the fury of the Arsenal manager.

Vieira's assault on Darren Williams and keeper David Seaman's leaden-footed part in Niall Quinn's goal somehow escaped Wenger's critical eye, although he may be less inclined to absolve them after studying video evidence.

Wenger's comments made for a fascinating inquest into a one-sided match that Arsenal should have wrapped up by half-time and won with several goals to spare. Peter Reid's reaction was more succinct. 'Mr Wenger is a very intelligent man and is entitled to his opinion,' said the Sunderland manager. 'I just think it's a load of crap. I don't comment on his players and he shouldn't comment on mine.'

Wenger certainly had plenty to say about Sunderland, deprived of several influential players through injuries and suspensions and forced to play four others - including Kevin Phillips - who were patently not fit.

Reid accepted the best, option for his patched-up team was to mark Kanu and show the commitment and resilience personified by his new signing Stanislav Varga, whose £650,000 price tag shows the Sunderland manager retains an eye for a bargain.

Wenger was not impressed by Sunderland's approach, which frustrated Arsenal and was a factor in the 90th minute red card for Vieira, who lashed out after being pulled back by Williams.

The Sunderland substitute was booked, but that wasn't enough for Wenger. He said: 'Vieira lost his temper, but every time you tried to attack, you had people pulling shirts and 10 men behind the ball.

'I would have sent off the Sunderland player as well for repeatedly pulling his shirt. When Williams came off I didn't see anything on his face, but he was down for two minutes, got Patrick sent off and gave his team some time.'

Even Reid had sympathy for Vieira. 'The ref's job is very difficult, but I thought Patrick was desperately unlucky because his arm wasn't raised maliciously,' he said.

Vieira has been sent off five times in England, prompting Wenger to say: 'I wouldn't like to think that his reputation is affecting referees. He tried to play football today, some players didn't.' Wenger's final point was valid. The vast majority of the football was undoubtedly played by Arsenal, who quickly settled into a familiar fluent vein, but - with Dennis Bergkamp on the bench - failed to accept any of 10 clear-cut opportunities.

Ray Parlour, Thierry Henry, Fredrik Ljungberg, Kanu ... the list of culprits in the first-half was a long one, although the goalkeeping of Thomas Sorensen was a factor in their failings.

Arsenal paid the price for their errant shooting seven minutes into the second half and, on the day Phillips received the Golden Boot for finishing as the Premiership's top scorer last season, it was the Golden Bonce of Niall Quinn that despatched his former club.

Quinn headed in Michael Gray's 52nd minute cross after an ill-timed challenge by Seaman which will add substance to the doubts surrounding the keeper. The goal heralded even more frantic attacks by Arsenal, by now faced by keeper Jurgen Macho, a half-time substitute for Sorensen. The Austrian under-21 international took his cue from the Dane, saved superbly from Robert Pires and Henry and saw Kanu place the best opportunity wide in the 72nd minute.

'We showed a terrific will to win,' said Reid. 'It was pure character and I'm delighted with my players. We played against a very good side and hung in there.'

Wenger was equally encouraged by his team's performance. 'I feel sorry for my players,' he said. 'We will win the championship if we dominate games like that for the rest of the season.

'The big regret is that we didn't take our chances. We had seven or eight one-on-ones and still lost. I have not lost a game like that in England before.'

fields.headline: Sutton rules roost
fields.trailText: Martin O'Neill, sensible man that he is, refused to make promises when he became manager of Celtic, but he did venture a prediction; namely that, given a break from injury, Chris Sutton would be 'a huge contributor' to the team. The striker made O'Neill look like a seer, with the goals which set Celtic in motion towards an emphatic victory in a fixture that has traditionally proved very troublesome.
fields.body:
Martin O'Neill, sensible man that he is, refused to make promises when he became manager of Celtic, but he did venture a prediction; namely that, given a break from injury, Chris Sutton would be 'a huge contributor' to the team. The striker made O'Neill look like a seer, with the goals which set Celtic in motion towards an emphatic victory in a fixture that has traditionally proved very troublesome.

The kind of productive burst produced by Sutton during that extraordinary first half is the short route to canonisation by a Celtic support eager to receive anyone who can respond to their supplications with small miracles. What was significant about the big Englishman's contribution was that he was able to give the Parkhead side a two-goal lead during a period in which the recognised redeemer, Henrik Larsson, had been unable to make an impact. It is extremely rare for Celtic to be able to boast a distinct advantage without the Swede's name on the credits.

Even when Larsson scored the third close to the interval, his lack of characteristic sharpness and finesse remained noticeable. The forward's energy and commitment remain beyond question, but he has yet to recover the quick control that marked his endeavours prior to the leg fracture he sustained last October.

Yet the prospect of Larsson returning to his most formidable may be bad news for opponents, as Sutton has already appeared to be a sound piece of business by O'Neill, even at £6 million from Chelsea.

He looked dangerous from the start, bothering the Hearts defence with powerful running and a lightness of touch with foot and head which created openings for team-mates. Yet his first goal was the result of a miscalculation by Gary Naysmith, the Hearts full-back.

Antti Niemi, the home goalkeeper, seemed to have the ball virtually in his hands on his six-yard line when the defender came in to knock it out, but only managed to get it as far as Bobby Petta on the Celtic left. The Dutchman whipped the centre straight to Sutton and the striker headed it to the left of Niemi from eight yards.

Hearts had busied themselves around the Celtic goal before this, although they tended to find Jonathan Gould in good form. He had to dive low to his right to prevent Scott Severin's low drive, from a short free-kick, from giving the home side an equaliser in the short time between Sutton's first and second goals.

The one which doubled the advantage could not have been more orthodox, Sutton cleanly heading a corner kick from Petta on the right into Niemi's right corner from six yards.

Hearts' resurgence was prompted by the appearance of Juanjo and Kris O'Neill in place of Lee Makel and Darren Jackson, the substitutes bringing a youthful liveliness to an attack in particular and a team in general who had seemed discouraged. The new self-belief was strengthened when Severin scored with another fierce low drive from a short free-kick by Colin Cameron.

Even when Moravcik restored Celtic's three-goal advantage with a high drive from Sutton's pass, the home side retained enough spirit to continue to give their visitors bother.

This was brilliantly illustrated by their second goal. Naysmith released O'Neill down the left, a quick shimmy took the youngster clear of McNamara and his precise centre was bulleted past Gould on the volley from Juanjo, coming in from the right.

fields.headline: Royle's poor return
fields.trailText: Kevin Keegan tipped Manchester City as his outside tip for a successful season on their return to the top flight after four years in the wilderness. Ever the optimist, no doubt the England manager will say that City have time to recover, but he has been wrong before.
fields.body:
Kevin Keegan tipped Manchester City as his outside tip for a successful season on their return to the top flight after four years in the wilderness. Ever the optimist, no doubt the England manager will say that City have time to recover, but he has been wrong before.

City were as woeful as Charlton were wonderful as last season's First Division Champions suggested that they might have what it takes to stay up this time. Then again, maybe they were just made to look good.

City manager Joe Royle was spot-on when he said: 'There was no cohesion in our play and we were very poor in the first half. Paulo Wanchope had only trained for one day with us and they did look like strangers out there. But we lost the first game last season and won promotion so it is too soon to panic.'

Goalkeeper Nicky Weaver may have had a feeling he was in for a busy Premiership debut trying to protect the City net when Claus Jensen cracked a free-kick towards the top right-hand corner of his goal in the first minute.

Weaver superbly clawed the ball away and went on to have a great game, but he was left far too exposed by his team-mates to stand a chance of keeping City in the game.

It was no surprise when Andy Hunt gave Charlton a 10th-minute lead. Collecting a Jensen through-pass, Hunt worked the ball on to his right foot and drilled a fairly unstoppable shot inside the near post.

The City midfield was continually outplayed and overrun and Charlton's inevitable second came through John Robinson three minutes before half-time.

Lisbie cut through the City defence with a powerful 20-yard run and scuffed a shot as Weaver came out to block. The ball broke to Robinson who took two touches before scoring with the help of a deflection off Steve Howey.

'Considering we had five strikers out injured I'm delighted with the start,' said Charlton manager Alan Cur bishley. 'I'm delighted with the performance for the opening game of the season and we really took advantage when City threw caution to the wind in the second half.'

City's new strike partnership of George Weah and Wanchope had barely seen the ball by the time the teams emerged for the second half and Charlton soon gained even more control of the match with new signing Jensen running the show. The home fans even had the foresight to get in an early cry of 'We are top of the League' as the next two goals flew in.

Mark Kinsella scored Charlton's third in the 72nd minute after good approach work and an unselfish pass from Graham Stuart gave him the chance to finish from just inside the penalty area.

Kinsella repaid the offering when he burst into the penalty area six minutes later and was blatantly tripped by Weaver. The City keeper escaped with a booking, but was further punished when Stuart sent him the wrong way from the penalty spot for Charlton's fourth.

fields.headline: Rebrov calms the fans
fields.trailText: The two most obvious questions before kick-off were whether Ipswich can survive in the Premiership and if there is life for Spurs in 2000AD (after 'Daveed').
fields.byline: Gerry Cox at White Hart Lane
fields.body:
The two most obvious questions before kick-off were whether Ipswich can survive in the Premiership and if there is life for Spurs in 2000AD (after 'Daveed').

The answer to the first was inconclusive, with Ipswich showing enough quality at times to suggest they will not be effectively relegated by Christmas, as they were five years ago. And on the thorny question of David Ginola, sold to Aston Villa last month, there was hardly a murmur of complaint from Tottenham fans who saw the first of what may turn out to be many memorable displays from Sergei Rebrov.

The little Ukranian, signed from Dynamo Kiev for a club record £11 million in the summer, showed that not only will he be a goalscorer, but he can provide a few Ginola-esque flashes of brilliance in setting up his team-mates.

One moment in particular had the home supporters on their feet, when he played a one-two with Steffen Freund and, from an unlikely position outside the penalty area, curled a shot with the outside of his right boot that swerved, dipped over goalkeeper Richard Wright and then rebounded off the crossbar.

'That showed the class he has,' said his delighted manager, George Graham. 'But what excites me most about him is that he is a team player who sets up goals as well as scores them.'

He certainly did that. After Ipswich had taken an eighth-minute lead when a Mark Venus free-kick took a huge deflection off the defensive wall, Rebrov helped Spurs back into the game by setting up two goals in as many minutes on the half-hour.

First, his lofted through-ball allowed Steve Carr to get behind the Ipswich defence, and although the full-back let the ball run too far ahead, he won a penalty when Wright sent him flying. Darren Anderton made no mistake from the penalty spot. A minute later, Carr played a one-two with Rebrov before running to the goal-line and squeezing the ball inside Wright's near post from the tightest of angles.

Les Ferdinand then completed an ultimately comfortable win with a goal in the closing minutes, heading home Anderton's cross from close range after replacing Steffen Iversen in attack. It was Ferdinand's first goal in almost a year that was disrupted by injury, and showed the attacking options available to Graham. 'It was a good start to the season for us,' he said. 'But Ipswich played very well at times and gave us a tough game. It's far too early to say whether they will survive, but they certainly pass the ball well.'

His counterpart, George Burley, was less happy, particularly with the defensive mistakes that led to goals. 'Two errors cost us the game and we cannot afford that,' he said. 'Players have to learn and if they don't we will have to bring people in.'

First, his lofted through-ball allowed Steve Carr to get behind the Ipswich defence, and although the full-back let the ball run too far ahead, he won a penalty when Wright sent him flying. Darren Anderton made no mistake from the penalty spot. A minute later, Carr played a one-two with Rebrov before running to the goal-line and squeezing the ball inside Wright's near post from the tightest of angles. Les Ferdinand then completed an ultimately comfortable win with a goal in the closing minutes, heading home Anderton's cross from close range after replacing Steffen Iversen in attack. It was Ferdinand's first goal in almost a year that was disrupted by injury, and showed the attacking options available to Graham. 'It was a good start to the season for us,' he said. 'But Ipswich played very well at times and gave us a tough game. It's far too early to say whether they will survive, but they certainly pass the ball well.' His counterpart, George Burley, was less happy, particularly with the defensive mistakes that led to goals. 'Two errors cost us the game and we cannot afford that,' he said. 'Players have to learn and if they don't we will have to bring people in.'

fields.headline: Rangers flex muscles
fields.trailText: Three goals in the first 30 minutes ensured Rangers' perfect Premier League record remained intact.
fields.body:
Three goals in the first 30 minutes ensured Rangers' perfect Premier League record remained intact.

Rangers had taken little time in showing the visitors their pedigree with three corners within the first five minutes. But, after 10 minutes, they had drawn first blood.

Jason Dair had already been feeling the pace against Neil McCann and had little option but to haul back the winger in the area after a great ball by Billy Dodds.

Jorg Albertz stroked the ball to Marco Ruitenbeek's right and, although the goalkeeper got a hand to it, there was too much power.

The visitors were not prepared to lie down and Boyle rose above the defence to guide home Rob Matthaei's cross.

Rangers nipped the challenge in the bud after 17 minutes with clever play between McCann and Dodds to give van Bronckhorst space and time in the area and he drilled the ball into the roof of the net for a 2-1 advantage.

Worse was to follow for the visitors after 25 minutes when Boyle was carried from the field after clashing with Fernando Ricksen.

The striker was replaced by Owen Coyle but he had been on the pitch for a matter of seconds when Rangers went further ahead. Tugay played a smart ball into Dodds who turned to drive the ball past Ruitenbeek.

Dunfermline were still trying to make a game of it but Van Bronckhorst and McCann were constant dangers while Dodds was desperate to prove his worth ahead of the Champions League tie against Herfolge on Wednesday.

Scott Thomson could have given the visitors a lifeline two minutes before the break but his shot from Barry Nicholson's corner was comfortably held by Klos.

A nifty one-two between Dair and Stevie Crawford saw the full-back unleash a drive from the edge of the box which flew just wide.

But just three minutes after the break, Rangers' win was secured. Tugay played the ball to McCann on the right side of the area and the winger skipped to the by-line before playing a perfect cross for unmarked Wallace who nodded home Rangers' fourth.

Ibrox captain Lorenzo Amoruso almost grabbed the fifth with a strong header from van Bronckhorst's corner but Ruitenbeek managed to scramble the ball clear.

By now the game was won and the play drifted into the mundane with Rangers barely stretching themselves as Dunfermline attempted to move out of their own half.

Albertz was given a standing ovation when he left the field with Wallace to be replaced by Claudio Reyna and Andrei Kanchelskis respectively.

fields.headline: Preston go marching on
fields.trailText: As sleeping giants go, Preston North End are certainly in the big five, especially with huge mosaics of Sir Tom Finney and Bill Shankly on Deepdale's two new stands acting as permanent reminders of the past.
fields.body:
As sleeping giants go, Preston North End are certainly in the big five, especially with huge mosaics of Sir Tom Finney and Bill Shankly on Deepdale's two new stands acting as permanent reminders of the past.

It is 19 years since the ground has tasted league football at this level, 30 years since they dropped out of the top division, so joint top of the table on maximum points after two games is more than anyone could surely have expected, especially as the performance here against a very experienced and by no means unskilful United side matched the emphatic scoreline.

But no one is getting carried away. The club have a long way to go before contemplating the Premiership - starting with another new stand planned for the New Year - and the playing squad are virtually the same as gained promotion from Division Two.

Survival has always been the target this year, and so far the signs are good. As pleasing as the goals were - and two inside six minutes was surely beyond the stuff of dreams - manager David Moyes was most satisfied with the way the team defended.

'Three goals without reply in our first game in Division One for 19 years, I'll take that every time,' he said. 'But after the two goals early on, we had to defend well because they threw everything at us in that first half. We're still learning at this level. We don't really know what to expect. If we're still in this position in twenty games, then I'll be really happy.'

Jonathan Macken, the former Manchester United trainee who notched 25 goals last year, scored twice to add to his opening day goal, and was denied a hat-trick only when a late effort came back off the crossbar. The 22-year-old looks assured, strong and quick, and with finishing like this, is rightly attracting scouts from the big clubs.

Deepdale was in raptures after just 64 seconds, when Michael Appleton exchanged a neat one-two with Steve Basham on the edge of the box before shooting low to Simon Tracey's right.

Worse was to follow for United, when Macken shrugged off the attentions of Gus Uhlenbeek eight yards out, swivelled and despatched an unstoppable shot to Tracey's left.

Having been two down before even drawing breath, the visitors understandably took a while to get into their stride, but could quite easily have gone in at the break level.

Wayne Quinn brilliantly headed Paul Devlin's dipping cross just over, before his curling 20-yard free-kick struck the post, and David Kelly narrowly failed to get to the rebound. Kelly saw another great header saved before Marcus Bent's audacious lob from the edge of the box went inches over.

Had United converted even one of those chances, it might have been very different, but Preston went from strength to strength in the second half.

United skipper Shaun Murphy had already denied Macken with two superb last-ditch tackles. But when the striker was first to a poor clearance and lobbed the ball over Tracey, Murphy could only deflect the ball into the roof of the net.

United lost their discipline late on when Devlin was sent off after kicking out at Paul McKenna, and manager Neil Warnock was ordered out of the dug-out for protesting. Warnock later declined to attend the post-match press conference.

fields.headline: Late strike saves Potters
fields.trailText: Everything went embarrassingly wrong for Bristol's new manager, Danny Wilson, in the closing minutes of the game that had offered so much for him.
fields.body:
Everything went embarrassingly wrong for Bristol's new manager, Danny Wilson, in the closing minutes of the game that had offered so much for him.

Wilson, who had survived the bruising experiences at Sheffield Wednesday after the acclaim at Barnsley, has wasted no time putting players on offer and shaking up the West Country club. But this was nullified as the defence donated the game to Stoke, themselves a strong, tough, direct team who ironically beat their opponents at Wembley in the last Auto Windscreen final. The home side had the bonus of Thomas's mistake to give them the lead that had proved so elusive against tight marking opponents. Then they lost organisation and composure in defence - and Stoke capitalised with a lethal opportunism.

The visitors equalised a quarter of an hour from time when substitute Graham Fenton crossed from the left for Bjarni Gudjonsson to score from a relatively unmarked position. If that was abysmal marking by Bristol, they compounded their indecision in the 87th minute and this time it was James O'Connor who snatched the winner with relative ease. In injury time Scott Murray cracked his shot against the post for Bristol; it was an optimistic gesture on a day when the defence, so compact for most of the time, suddenly and inexplicably lost its way. Wilson will be rethinking his defensive formation.

As early as the third minute Lee Peacock, Bristol's £650,000 signing from Manchester City was making the kind of impact that impressed the Ashton Gate crowd.

He leapt to head just wide from Brian Tinnion's corner. And he was searching and at times finding an encouraging combination with fellow striker Tony Thorpe, appointed captain by the new manager.

He almost scored as he surged forward and just failed to control the final short pass in a five-man move on the edge of the Stoke box.

But Stoke's solid three central defenders covered tightly, while Bristol's alert midfielders were apt to be curbed by close marking in a competitive, often attractive match, which indicated that both these teams could be promotion candidates.

Alan Miller, an emergency loan signing from Blackburn Rovers - Bristol's two goalkeepers are both injured - looked commanding, not least when he tipped Stefan Thordarson's dipping free-kick over the bar.

The tempo increased and at times the good nature deteriorated after the interval. Wayne Thomas earned ironic cheers after going down in a clash with Thorpe. Then the combative James O'Connor was booked after one too many skirmishes with Darren Dunning, another loan signing from Blackburn, and a teenager with a look of real maturity.

After 64 minutes the home team were rewarded. Mickey Bell crossed from the left and Thomas, headed into his own net.

fields.headline: Heskey has the answer
fields.trailText: Complete strangers thrown together in conditions of extreme stress for weeks on end in front of an omni-present media, engrossed millions, and tens of thousands of pounds at stake. Yes, Big Brother may be the pop culture cause celebre of the moment, but for real intrigue, passion, drama - not to mention a healthy sprinkling of insecurity and personal conflict - there is nothing quite like a Premiership season.
fields.body:
Complete strangers thrown together in conditions of extreme stress for weeks on end in front of an omni-present media, engrossed millions, and tens of thousands of pounds at stake. Yes, Big Brother may be the pop culture cause celebre of the moment, but for real intrigue, passion, drama - not to mention a healthy sprinkling of insecurity and personal conflict - there is nothing quite like a Premiership season.

Emile Heskey, 22, went through the treatment yesterday, the Anfield crowd growing increasingly impatient with the £11 million striker, the odd boo and groan enhancing the frustration, before he scored a wonderful individual goal that settled the encounter.

'Sometimes against a packed defence you need a piece of individual brilliance and Heskey gave us that,' said his manager, Gerard Houllier. 'I'm pleased for him because he is a player who needs support. He is very young and sometimes you forget that even good strikers looked a bit awkward when they started out.

'The best of Emile is yet to come. We will back him and support him and I hope the fans understand that. When he decides to turn and go for goal he is practically unstoppable, he shows that often in training and has got to show that in games. He just needs more self-belief.'

The same could be said of his entire team. With seven foreign players and three debutants, Liverpool played for long periods like the cast of Big Brother: a group of strangers thrown together in a dressing room an hour before kick-off. To add to Houllier's concerns, the victory came at a cost. Heskey twisted a knee, which makes him doubtful for tomorrow's visit to Arsenal while his 82nd minute replacement, Patrik Berger, will miss two months after suffering an injury to his lateral knee ligaments.

'The downside of the win is the injury factor,' observed Houllier. 'And I don't see why we have to travel and play a game like Arsenal two days after a game like this.'

But if the three points were hard-earned and costly, the sheer individual genius of Heskey's decisive contribution lifted some of the gloom, not to mention the pressure mounting on a player who had not previously scored at Anfield. Winning a challenge some 35 yards from goal, he casually brushed past Ian Nolan and David Hopkin before delivering an unstoppable shot into Matt Clarke's goal from a wide angle just inside the area.

The goal had been threatened after Liverpool opened the second half in much more determined and incisive fashion, only Clarke stalling the inevitable with a series of excellent blocks. A Steven Gerrard shot was tipped over acrobatically, Nick Barmby headed directly at the keeper, Vladimir Smicer was denied, Michael Owen too, and a goalbound Sammy Hyypia header struck team-mate Dietmar Hamann on the line after a corner following another good Clarke save.

It was a dramatic transformation from the first half in which honours belonged to a Bradford team with Benito Carbone on the bench and Dean Windass as a lone striker. Still, it took the legs of Liverpool's keeper, Sander Westerveld, to prevent Windass giving the visitors the lead late in the first half after Lee Sharpe had cleverly played him through.

'We got beat and I don't like getting beat,' said new manager Chris Hutchings. 'We were undone by a moment of individual brilliance. In the first half we had created the best two chances but if you don't put them away at this level you get punished and that is what happened.'

Arguably, there were more grounds for the visitors to be optimistic than their hosts. Even serial dissident Carbone apparently took his reduced role in good grace. Hutchings said: 'Benito Carbone is a couple of weeks behind in his fitness levels and we always planned on him being on the bench. We discussed it with him and he was fine. He'll train again tonight and on Sunday and we'll take it from there and see how he goes for our next game on Tuesday.'

Still, if television producers are looking for a new fly-on-the-wall documentary topic, the Bradford dressing room round about the turn of the year could be a good starting place.

fields.headline: Ginola suffers same old fate
fields.trailText: The ingredients were all there: on the one hand, Peter Taylor's first game as manager of Leicester City and Stan Collymore's comeback from a broken leg - against the team he left so acrimoniously; on the other, David Ginola's debut for Aston Villa. You can follow the recipe all you like, though, but sometimes, sometimes the dish doesn't taste as good as the picture looks in the cook book.
fields.body:
The ingredients were all there: on the one hand, Peter Taylor's first game as manager of Leicester City and Stan Collymore's comeback from a broken leg - against the team he left so acrimoniously; on the other, David Ginola's debut for Aston Villa. You can follow the recipe all you like, though, but sometimes, sometimes the dish doesn't taste as good as the picture looks in the cook book.

Such is the modern Premiership in fact. Very glossy, but insubstantial and unsatisfying at times. Neither side at Filbert Street passed the ball with any sustained quality and both lacked a cutting edge for all the millions of pounds worth on view. To be generous, let us say it was start-of-season stuff.

Leicester just shaded it, with their £5 million signing from Wolves, Ade Akinbiyi, forcing David James to show that his reflexes at least have not been undermined by that FA Cup final gaffe last May. Otherwise Villa's own £5m signing, the Turk Alpay Olazan, was not unduly tested on an efficient introduction to the English game.

Part of Taylor's nouvelle cuisine looks to be edging Leicester from Martin O'Neill's time-honoured 3-5-2 towards 4-4-2. Against Villa he could afford to; they lack the pace in attack that makes a third defender tempting and the absence with a groin strain of Luc Nilis only made it more obvious. Ginola was at his most maddening, sleight of foot mixed with wastage of the possession he mostly held for too long, and he was dragged off on the hour. 'He needs a bit of match fitness,' said the Villa manager, John Gregory.

By contrast, in Collymore and Akinbiyi, who looked raw but promising, Leicester these days have the speed in attack so necessary now at the top level. 'Ade has got a chance of doing very well at this level,' said Taylor. 'He's got the pace and power.'

It was Collymore, subsequently well subdued by Gareth Southgate, who sounded a rallying cry right from the kick-off, carrying the ball deep into the visitors' defence before a wayward cross. It certainly roused Filbert Street though it was a while before they were cheered again. It took a misplaced back-heel by Ginola to get them going, Akinbiyi seizing on to it to streak past a wrong-footed Barry on the right and get in a low cross that Collymore met, only for James to parry at his feet. At least it sparked the game into life, even if inappropriately.

Neil Lennon was booked for a foul on George Boateng, who was himself cautioned after responding angrily to a remark from Robbie Savage. The not-so-noble Savage was then shown the yellow card for a late challenge on Southgate.To the home crowd's delight, Ginola evened up the score after a 'dive' for a penalty. 'He deserved it,' said Gregory.

Leicester also went close either side of half-time, Andy Impey curling a shot just wide and James saving from Akinbiyi before Villa at last conjured up some meaningful attempts on goal.

And though Ginola forced Tim Flowers into a low save with a 25-yard shot, Lee Hendrie hit a volley that the goalkeeper dived on and Dion Dublin headed a chance over the bar, Villa rarely looked like finding the net. Only Barry and a persevering Paul Merson really lived up to the club motto: 'Prepared'. Much ado about nothing - nothing indeed.

fields.headline: Busy Boksic boon for Boro
fields.trailText: Alen Boksic, it is said, earns £63,000 a week, making him the highest-paid player in the Premiership. After claiming two goals and an assist on his first game for Middlesbrough, he may be knocking on the chairman's door tomorrow asking for a pay rise. He may have been half-fit, but he was still superb.
fields.body:
Alen Boksic, it is said, earns £63,000 a week, making him the highest-paid player in the Premiership. After claiming two goals and an assist on his first game for Middlesbrough, he may be knocking on the chairman's door tomorrow asking for a pay rise. He may have been half-fit, but he was still superb.

In 1996 Middlesbrough witnessed another highly paid import, a certain Fabrizio Ravanelli, score a hat-trick against Liverpool on the first day of the season. Relegation swiftly followed. They know something about false dawns on Teesside, but yesterday's performance promised better.

Coventry, apart from a 20-minute spell towards the end of the first half, were simply outplayed. The game's first chance, after 15 minutes, came when Coventry simply ignored a loose ball, allowing Joseph-Desiré Job to set up Brian Deane for an astonishing miss. And when Middlesbrough eventually scored, they were in disarray. Hendry ventured forward for a free-kick, but was stranded in Middlesbrough's area, appealing for a penalty, as Karembeu released Boksic down the left wing. His cross found Job unmarked six yards from goal, and his header was emphatic.

Coventry's goal, scored by John Eustace from David Thompson's free-kick late in the first half, briefly suggested that they could turn the red tide, but five blistering second-half minutes proved enough for Middlesbrough to win the game. Boksic's first, on 59 minutes, came when the home defence misjudged Gary Pallister's chipped free-kick allowing the Croatian to score stab the ball past Magnus Hedman at the second time of asking. The second, four minutes later, was again created by Pallister, who collected the ball on the halfway line and strode forward unchallenged, drawing the defence before slipping Boksic through for a delightful chipped finish. 'He should do that more often,' said Robson of his big defender.

'It was very nearly a perfect performance,' Robson concluded. 'No one's getting carried away, we're just hoping it will continue.'

fields.headline: Burton rescues Rams
fields.trailText: Substitute Deon Burton rescued Derby from an acute case of déjà vu with his first touch of the ball.
fields.body:
Substitute Deon Burton rescued Derby from an acute case of déjà vu with his first touch of the ball.

The striker had only been on the field for three minutes when his 48th-minute finish earned Jim Smith's side a point. Prior to that, the ramshackle Rams had looked like picking up the new season where they had left off the previous one - utterly shocking at home.

Trailing to two delightful Hassan Kachloul goals - both courtesy of the lively Kevin Davies - Derby had looked dead and buried. They did, however, claw their way back thanks to a stunning Branko Strupar free-kick and Burton's far-post finish immediately after the break.

Southampton manager Glenn Hoddle was less than satisfied. 'There was only one team in it for the first 45 minutes,' he said. 'We are disappointed not to have won it. Hassan scored two good goals, but could have had two more. We should have shut the door at half-time.'

Smith was more grateful. 'At half past three, I would have settled for the draw,' he said. 'You can make excuses about players not being fit, but I also thought some of our lads who were making their debuts looked a little nervous.'

Derby, minus nine first teamers, took 45 minutes to realise that the season had actually started. Sadly for their £2 million signing from Manchester United, Danny Higginbotham, he was introduced to the harsh realities of Pride Park life within a quarter of an hour. Kevin Davies left the full back for dead with a surging run wide on the right. To be fair to Higginbotham, he did make up some ground. By then, however, Davies had scurried his way into the penalty area and his magnificently slick delivery was dispatched from eight yards with aplomb by Kachloul.

Six minutes later, the Moroccan struck a second time. Davies was again the provider and Kachloul calmly steered his right-wing cross wide of goalkeeper Mart Poom.

Derby promptly hit back with a stunning goal of their own on the half hour when Strupar's 20-yard free-kick flew in.

Amazingly, Derby found themselves level within thee minutes of the restart. Smith withdrew Lee Morris at half-time and replaced him with Burton. The tactic paid off immediately. The result was touch number one for Burton and goal number two for Derby. Stefano Eranio produced a low, menacing cross from the right and Burton did the rest with a clinical finish.

fields.headline: Chelsea reap dividends
fields.trailText: It looks like £25 million well spent. What more rewarding portents for greater things ahead than Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink off the mark, a goal to make you swoon from Mario Stanic and - Ken's your uncle - even a bogey team laid to rest.
fields.body:
It looks like £25 million well spent. What more rewarding portents for greater things ahead than Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink off the mark, a goal to make you swoon from Mario Stanic and - Ken's your uncle - even a bogey team laid to rest.

Never mind the Bradfords, dropping points against awkward customers like West Ham has been equally detrimental to Chelsea's championship credentials in the past. After 45 years in the title wilderness, Gianluca Vialli's new improved selection could be nine months away from a summit last reached when players were slaves to the maximum wage and travelled to matches on public transport.

A cutting edge in front of goal had been Chelsea's achilles heel last season and the manager believes his expensive acquisitions will make a difference. In Hasselbaink, whose debut was solid if not spectacular, they possess a player who is instinctive and decisive when he sees the whites of the goal posts. The purposeful Stanic, who adds impressive balance as well as flashes of spectacular technique, looks a snip.

'Hopefully we can be better attacking-wise because we have more options,' said Vialli. 'Jimmy has pace, can shoot from long range and is a predator, and Mario gives us an aerial threat.' Add Gianfranco Zola's wizardry and the eternally patient and effective Tore Andre Flo and you can see why Vialli feels the need to talk down his team's chances in a vague attempt to deflect an unbearable level of expectation.

Optimism pulsed through the air. But Harry Redknapp's team were in no mood to allow their London rivals to stride out in style. They pressed and created, and Davor Suker soon carved the first opening. Ed De Goey clawed back his shot and Christian Panucci, partnering Marcel Desailly in the centre of defence, helped the ball to safety. The Italian was chosen ahead of the ostracised Frank Leboeuf and Vialli was content with his contribution too.

West Ham have ambitions of their own, too, and a three-pronged attack comprising Suker, Paolo Di Canio and Frederic Kanoute brimmed with opportunity. 'Chelsea are an outstanding team but I think we matched them today,' reckoned Redknapp.

It took Chelsea a while to find their rhythm and range. Cometh the half-hour, cometh the man. Hasselbaink surged forward to meet Di Matteo's pass. He bore down on goal and Hislop greeted him with a thudding challenge. It looked suspiciously outside the area but referee Graham Barber ordered the penalty. Hasselbaink duly marched to the spot. It was cool, it was crisp, it bore the mark of an instant hero.

It's hard to imagine anyone in blue spared a thought for Chris Sutton. Hasselbaink, with all his swaggering confidence, comes from a different school entirely.

Fortunately for West Ham, they too possess a forward with similar character. Two minutes after the interval, Di Canio shocked Stamford Bridge with a stylish finish from Kanoute's shrewd approach work, although Chelsea had only themselves to blame for slack defending.

It needed renewed resolve for Chelsea to wrestle back control of the game, and the presence of Gus Poyet, drifting dangerously towards the edge of the box, achieved precisely that. He was bodychecked by Igor Stimac. Gianfranco Zola sized up the free-kick and promptly delivered a delightful goal.

If that was to be relished, Chelsea's third was to be truly cherished. With breathtaking panache, Stanic juggled to tee himself up before unleashing a dipping volley from 25 yards.

The sight of Kanoute pulling one back from close range couldn't break the euphoric spell, and the irrepressible Croat reinforced the sense of wonder with a second in the last minute. The challenge now, is whether the magic can be sustained for 37 more games.

fields.headline: Techno-agents cast their net
fields.trailText: The rumours circulating within football that some computerised 'transfer' systems have fallen foul of the Data Protection Act show that while the march of progress is inevitable, it is not without problems. It may seem laughable now, but there was a time when a manager looking for a new player would simply thumb through the Rothmans Yearbook and then get on the phone to his fellow managers.
fields.body:
The rumours circulating within football that some computerised 'transfer' systems have fallen foul of the Data Protection Act show that while the march of progress is inevitable, it is not without problems. It may seem laughable now, but there was a time when a manager looking for a new player would simply thumb through the Rothmans Yearbook and then get on the phone to his fellow managers.

Even as recently as three or four years ago that was still the most common way of doing business, and although the annual is still the best book of its kind, it has all changed now.

Networking between managers has been replaced by the high-tech sort of network that allows you to boot up a laptop and find the inside leg measurement of almost any player on the planet. These bespoke systems are not totally comprehensive, of course, and they are not without drawbacks, as today's story proves, but this is how it is in the computer age.

The whole system is driven by agents, inevitably, but that is not to say it is necessarily a bad thing. What surprised me most when I returned to management with Crystal Palace last month was the number of agents ringing me to offer players - and not always their own ones.

They are now the main source of getting players, and the number of licensed agents has increased enormously - I think there are around 140 in Britain alone, which is clearly too many for the number of footballers over here. Some of them effectively act for clubs in conjunction with the manager and chief scout, identifying players and facilitating negotiations between clubs in return for a retainer fee or commission.

It is amazing how much knowledge some of them have of players throughout the world, and how organised that information is. If you are looking for a left-back, for example, you can switch on your laptop - or with many managers have someone switch it on for you - and enter a few key words.

You will then be given a number of players who fit your criteria, with details of their contracts, salaries and so on. I can understand why players are not happy with this, and I think someone needs to draw up proper guidelines about how information is handled.

The PFA are in an interesting position, and I still think they are the best people to act for players. Their commissions for negotiating contracts and transfers are often hundreds rather than thousands of pounds, and they can be tough negotiators because they have details of every players' salary through their pension plans.

So if, for example, you say you cannot afford the wages they are asking for a player they represent, they can easily find out whether you are telling the truth by looking up the salaries of other players at your club. I wonder if this information is sometimes given out too freely. I have my own database, which I am constantly building here in tandem with my coaching staff and the IT manager.

We log player details every time we speak to an agent or manager, and in a few weeks have built up a database of almost 250 who might be available or suit our needs. Information regarding salaries helps you build up a picture of wages today, but I keep it confidential and will discuss it only with the chairman.

Most of that information has come from agents - I have spoken to only four or five managers about players, whereas I have around 10 agents with whom I have a good working relationship and have spoken to dozens more. The whole way we go about finding players and negotiating transfers has changed dramatically in the past few years, and of course the influx of overseas players has played a large part.

I do not have to leave my office to find out about a player - I can get that information from many different sources instantly. You don't even have to go to watch them in action if they are featured on television regularly.

None of this comes for free, of course, but I still wonder why some clubs are so reluctant to invest in anything that makes this sort of thing more efficient, when they are prepared to spend huge sums of money on players who may or may not improve the team's fortunes.

Even though we are slowly moving into the computer age in football, much of the thinking is struggling to catch up with the new century.

fields.headline: Sky-high price for going down
fields.trailText: Sky will pay £3 million in rights fees alone for their first live broadcast of the new Premiership season, Manchester United v Newcastle, this afternoon.
fields.body:
Sky will pay £3 million in rights fees alone for their first live broadcast of the new Premiership season, Manchester United v Newcastle, this afternoon. The other 59 League matches they will show during 2000-01 will cost the same sum each time.

It is the most they have ever had to fork out, this, the final season of their present four-year deal, having been valued at £180 million, a rise of £20 million on a year ago under a pricing system that is ratcheted up on an annual basis.

But they may be reflecting that it is cheap at the price, the three-year contract that starts next season towering over the present one. In place of the £670 million Sky paid for the four seasons from 1997, they have agreed to part with £1.11 billion for the three that follow from next August.

They will get more matches under this new deal - 66 per season - but even so the average cost for a game comes out at £5.6 million, a price hike of nearly 90 per cent.

All of which supports the concern of those who fear that a damaging rift is opening between the plutocrats of the Premiership and the Football League clubs. The Football League's deal with ITV and ONdigital for 2001-04 amounts to a mere £315 million - in other words, more than three times as many clubs making do with less than a third of what the Premier League will receive over the same period.

It makes you realise why promotion to the Premiership is becoming an ever more coveted prize for First Division sides - and why relegation to the same division is such a disaster.

A final word on the match at Old Trafford this afternoon - it will be the first home game that Man U fan Bert Foulds has missed since 1979. He'll be at the Sky studios in London performing for the Fanzone, Sky Digital's latest offering that involves a fan from each of the competing clubs teaming up to provide an alternative commentary.

England's World Cup qualifier in Greece next June is now likely to end up on Sky after Octagon CSI won the right to market the match.

The Octagon deal almost certainly ends the possibility of the fixture being shown on pay-per-view, the fate of England's qualifier in Finland in October. Global Sportnet, who were responsible for the pay-per-view company u>direct scooping the Finland game, pitched unsuccessfully for the match in Athens, which is the last of England's World Cup qualifiers to find a TV broadcaster.

jon.henderson@observer.co.uk
