fields.headline: Tales from the Tabs
fields.trailText: WRIGHT WILL GO Ipswich keeper Richard Wright has been told he can talk to Arsène Wenger about replacing David Seaman at Arsenal. Wright's new contract at Portman Road has a one-year release clause - the possible £10m deal will mean the end for wantaway Highbury understudy Alex Manninger.
fields.body:
WRIGHT WILL GO Ipswich keeper Richard Wright has been told he can talk to Arsène Wenger about replacing David Seaman at Arsenal. Wright's new contract at Portman Road has a one-year release clause - the possible £10m deal will mean the end for wantaway Highbury understudy Alex Manninger.

FERGIE: SELL & DIE Alex Ferguson has told Manchester United's board to forget about selling his stars. 'If we had allowed Roy Keane to leave last summer it would have been a disaster for my ambitions, for the fans and for the rest of the squad. Next summer David Beckham and Ryan Giggs will be in the same situation.'

FRANK'S NEW BLAST Frank Leboeuf has again slammed Chelsea and France - and threatened to quit both unless he gets his way. 'If I'm not in the France starting line-up in September that's it,' he told French paper L'Equipe . 'And in England my coach Vialli isn't confident in me. Everything suggests I'm not certain to stay.'

Arsène Wenger has told Bordeaux he'll look elsewhere unless they drop their £15m demand for Sylvain Wiltord by £3m - closer to Arsenal's valuation: 'Their offers have been poor,' says president Jean-Louis Triaud, 'but we're still talking'

Ugo Ehiogu's proposed move from Aston Villa to Middlesbrough could be off after Bryan Robson began chasing Manchester United pair Henning Berg and David May

Winston Bogarde's agent has offered Bradford the chance to pay him £50,000 a week - Chris Hutchings is more likely to land Russian international Vladimir Bestchasthykh of Racing Santander

Charlton have pulled out of a bid for controversial French international Patrice Loco

Gianluca Vialli has told his Chelsea players to 'behave' after Frank Leboeuf called him socially inept: 'They are the soldiers and I am the general. If they make mistakes I will punish them'

Gordon Strachan will keep buying British after landing Craig Bellamy for Coventry: 'I'll bring top draw players to this club' - he hasn't given up on Rangers' Neil McCann

Derby boss Jim Smith says reports that he wants Sunderland's Nicky Sumerbee are 'rubbish, absolute rubbish'

Wimbledon are to bid again for Everton's Richard Dunne

Hermann Hreidarsson says he feels 'no pressure' about the responsibility of keeping Ipswich up

Harry Kewell says he's 'so pleased' to have signed a new four-year Leeds contract, but that he'd also 'like to play abroad'

Tony Cottee is pressing for a move to London from Leicester

Christian Ziege's move to Liverpool is being held up by solicitors: 'We're no further forward' says Bryan Robson

Joe Royle says Manchester City are aiming for Europe: 'you've got to have targets' - he'll sign Paul Ritchie tomorrow for £500,000

Manchester United's Henning Berg says he's ready to leave: 'I've a long way to go before I get in United's first team, so I have to look at other options' - Paul Scholes, though, says he's staying: 'me and Becks think the same'

Crystal Palace are set to move again for Middlesbrough's Alun Armstrong - but Armstrong isn't keen

Newcastle's Bobby Robson says Alan Shearer has four seasons left in him

SK Brann are stalling on a bid for Southampton's Trond Soltvedt

Michael Gray wants the Sunderland captaincy full-time

Sergei Rebrov says Tottenham will win the Premiership, 'or at least get in the Champions League'

West Ham are set to appeal against the decision not to give Hayden Foxe a work permit.

david.hills@observer.co.uk

1. Peter Shilton The England goalkeeping veteran ended up mired in financial problems caused by betting on horse racing

2. Roy Keane Manchester United's £52,000-a-week captain admitted to difficulties with drink and is reported to have recently attended AA meetings

3. Alex Rae Sunderland's Scottish midfielder has recovered from alcoholism and depression after treatment in the Priory

4. Diego Maradona Argentinian hero is in a rehabilitation centre in Cuba for drug addiction. Rumoured to be off narcotics but now drinking heavily instead

5. Paul McGrath Irish international who was part of a hard-drinking 'wild bunch' of Man Utd players broken up by manager Alex Ferguson

6. Jimmy Greaves One of football's first high-profile alcoholics. Regularly uses his Sun column to warn about temptations still open to players

7. Paul Merson Confessed to triple addiction to drink, drugs and gambling. Has fallen off the wagon at least once since going teetotal. Arsenal teammate and drinking partner of Tony Adams

8. Paul Gascoigne Self-confessed alcoholic and wife-beater who is widely thought to have wasted his magical talent through drink, indiscipline and misbehaviour

9. Jim Baxter Scotland and Rangers striker from the 1970s who has had two liver transplants on the NHS because of his heavy drinking

10. George Best The ultimate self-destructive football star ended up in countless drink-fuelled scrapes. Now 'dry', he has been warned that even one more drink could kill him

11. Stan Collymore Spent time in the Priory. Tempestuous off-field career, including attacking girlfriend Ulrika Jonsson and fire-extinguisher 'prank' during team night out

webTitle: Old Firm exit is not the end of the world

fields.headline: Old Firm exit is not the end of the world
fields.standfirst: Glenn Gibbons on a new era in Scottish football
fields.trailText: Glenn Gibbons on a new era in Scottish football.
fields.body:
Reflecting on a week that contained such projections as the Old Firm's departure from the Scottish Premier League and the abolition of transfer fees, it seems impossible to escape the conclusion that we are now in a position to approximate the date upon which Scottish football will be visited by the apocalypse, some time in the summer of 2002.

In common with all those other end-of-the-world-is-nigh predictions which have been a feature of man's insecurity since biblical times, a colossal amount of circumstances, most of them unlikely, will have to conspire in order to achieve their fulfilment.

It is not difficult to imagine that the European courts will inevitably end the practice of trading footballers like livestock, but it is hard to agree with the argument that this will have a devastating effect on those smaller clubs for whom semi-regular sales are essential to their existence.

In the five years since the Bosman judgment, this route to comparative prosperity has been virtually closed to traffic, with only a trickle of movement between middle-to-lower order Scottish clubs and those uptown members with the disposable income. Total removal of the facility is unlikely to make a significant difference; clubs who have had to survive since the 19th century through prudent husbanding of extremely limited resources have had enough practice not to allow the scrapping of transfer fees to bring them down.

The loss of Celtic and Rangers from the top league would be very serious, bringing the possibility of the Scottish game descending to a level comparable with that of Northern Ireland. There was a time when the primary reasons for the Old Firm's indispensability to domestic football were their ability to fill away grounds and the possibility that they would spend bundles on players from their neighbours.

Those benefits have long since ceased to be imperative. Celtic and Rangers rarely shop in the home market - Dick Advocaat's recent acquisition of Kenny Miller from Hibs for £2 million notwithstanding - and the compulsory segregation of fans in the past two decades has so severely reduced the ticket allocation to the Glasgow giants' followers that two home matches annually against each of them can no longer be considered a bonanza.

The most precious element of the modern game the Old Firm would take with them if the proposed northern European league materialised would be the interest of TV company executives. Even if the amount currently paid to the SPL - around £10m a year - seems like a pittance when set beside the mountain of money about to be disbursed to the Premiership in England, it is, when combined with other forms of sponsorship, of more value to the clubs than the revenue they receive through the gates.

Without the promotional worth of the Old Firm, it is possible that a company such as BSkyB would not stop at merely making a reduced offer to Scottish football when renewal of the present agreement is due, but withdraw their interest entirely.

The significance of the broadcasters' millions cannot be overstated. The possibility of attracting the purchase of transmission rights on a scale that compares with countries such as England, Italy, Germany, France and Spain is, indeed, the only reason why Celtic and Rangers are enthusiastic about joining a league comprising clubs from Scotland, Portugal, Holland, Belgium and Scandinavia.

When Allan MacDonald, the Celtic chief executive, first proposed what he called the Atlantic League, it was because he realised soon after his appointment by Fergus McCann in the spring of 1999 that even regular attendances of 60,000 and global merchandising would not allow the Parkhead club to compete with those from countries enjoying the real television money.

Rangers, whose chairman, David Murray, had claimed insistently that his club would never desert Scottish football, have been persuaded of the feasibility of a project which, if completed, would have a catchment area with a population of around 59,000,000. Murray admitted last week that he had changed his opinion.

It has been obvious for some time that the Old Firm had come to the realisation that they would never be able to rival clubs from the big countries without having what they already had. They had watched enviously as much smaller clubs in the English Premiership were handed at the start of each season a TV share-out four times greater than their own.

They are also concerned with the difficulties of attracting a certain quality of player because of the widespread perception of the Scottish Premier League as a backwater. Advocaat has recently been lamenting his failure to persuade a succession of expensive strikers to come to Ibrox to strengthen his squad for the Champions league, the group phase of which they will enter on Wednesday, when they complete the formality of eliminating Herfolge of Denmark from the final qualifying round.

Whether or not the project comes into being is difficult to forecast. The architects - who include Ajax, Feyenoord, PSV, Benfica, Porto and Sporting Club as well as the Old Firm - require the sanction of their local associations as well as of Uefa and will doubtless have to pay compensation to those clubs they leave behind in their domestic leagues.

They will also, presumably, need promissory notes from television companies for enough money to make the upheaval worthwhile. That may be the most difficult aspect of the exercise. What does seem clear is that they are willing to risk their present guarantee of European football every year through their home leagues by participating in a competition in which qualification should be much more difficult to achieve.

This is a mute declaration of their belief that even regular participation in the Champions League does not render the kind of money available from television. In this context, the attempted secession can hardly be regarded as treason.

fields.headline: News in Brief
fields.trailText: One man, many minds
fields.body:
One man, many minds

In the week that Tony Adams opened his sanctuary for football's most unstable players, former Danish international Lars Elstrup was making a strong case for inaugural membership.

Eight years ago, Elstrup - who remains Luton's record signing at £850,000 - scored the Euro 92 semi-final winner against France. A year later he quit the game to join a religious sect and last week was arrested for slapping a schoolboy while flashing for money in a Copenhagen shopping centre. Now the sect have confiscated his dog.

Elstrup - a striker at Brondby and Odense before Luton - joined 'The Wild Goose' commune on the island of Funen in 1993 under his new name, Darando. 'I feel here that I am seen for who I really am. They understand me better than I do myself, actually, and can really help me,' he explained.

Since then, Danish tabloids have kept a close eye on the island, reporting rampant free sex, and the alleged efforts of Wild Goose leaders to relieve Elstrup of his career earnings. At the start of this year, he attempted to resume his salaried career with a comeback for Odense, only to walk out when they refused to pay him during a trial.

Most recently he was spotted in the middle of the busiest pedestrian shopping street in Copenhagen circled by a rope, waving his penis at passersby.

'In some respects,' he explained, 'I do this to provoke people. I like experiencing people's reactions. Some might take my message to be "sod off" and others an offer of sex. I am very aware of people's reactions and I love the fact that people recognise me as Lars Elstrup.' He placed a scarf on the pavement for contributions, and made 27 Danish Kroner (£ 2.25) in one afternoon.

'I have mainly come to Copenhagen to have a good time. I have not had sex for three months: it is not possible in Odense where women are dead, stuck-up and introverted.' When he tested the theory by repeating the act for the female shoppers of Odense, he was heckled, lost his temper, slapped a laughing schoolboy, wrestled a police officer, was arrested and finally expelled by the Geese.

Now, having told police that 'he should have hit the boy harder' and that 'the kid deserved a fist', Elstrup has filed a complaint with the public prosecutor of Funen. 'They are inhuman and the sect even stole Devi, my dachshund. I am now ready to go to the European Court of Human Rights.' He's also, it seems, more than ready to lead the charge to Adamsville. Move over, David Icke.

Happy shopper

Former Wolves manager Mark McGhee - currently underemployed as a scout for Coventry - has launched his own internet business. 'Thecarbootsale.com' features virtual car boots full of unwanted items, including several of McGhee's own cast-offs. Top among the bargains are 30 mousemats for £5, a Flymo for £9.99, 500 sheets of wrapping paper and a porcelain doll with feathers ('a doll of distinction') being sold by 'fatman' for £5. 'If you want to buy a fishing rod for under £5, and within a mile of your front door, we'll tell you where you can get it,' McGhee boasted at the launch, overlooking the lack of fishing rods on the site. Nevertheless, Warren Barton, for one, was inspired: the Newcastle midfielder has added another business to his restaurant in Hammersmith: a pricey new travel agency for a better class of footballer.

Fab gets heavy

Fabien Barthez has attacked the English press for fabricating stories about him before his Premiership debut this afternoon. Speaking in Paris last week, United's new keeper - who has banned team-mates from kissing his head during today's game - revealed he moved to Manchester on the advice of Eric Cantona but can't believe the reception he's been given. 'The English press: you can't beat it,' he told reporters. 'It's tiptop isn't it? It is amazing the amount of rubbish they publish. It's not just one thing, it's 20.

'Just the other day I read an article that said I was a sad, unhappy child who didn't talk. It's insane. Another article said that I would no longer be able to eat in a restaurant in Monaco where I spent FF50,000 a meal. They really are just delirious.'

Online diaries: excerpt of the week

THIS WEEK, Vegard Heggem, Liverpool.

'...While I was doing my 2 x 20 minutes on the course in the wind and rain accompanied by an overworked pulse monitor, there were two boys hanging over the brick wall topped with barbed wire who beat me hands down as far as endurance is concerned. They couldn't have been more than 16-17 years old - in total, mind you - and with impressive lung capacity they shouted for the full 2 x 20 minutes (+ extra time) "Veeeegard Heggem is a wanker, is a wanker!" I only hope they weren't Liverpool supporters.'

'The English press: you can't beat it,' he told reporters. 'It's tiptop isn't it? It is amazing the amount of rubbish they publish. It's not just one thing, it's 20. 'Just the other day I read an article that said I was a sad, unhappy child who didn't talk. It's insane. Another article said that I would no longer be able to eat in a restaurant in Monaco where I spent FF50,000 a meal. They really are just delirious.' Online diaries: excerpt of the week THIS WEEK, Vegard Heggem, Liverpool. '...While I was doing my 2 x 20 minutes on the course in the wind and rain accompanied by an overworked pulse monitor, there were two boys hanging over the brick wall topped with barbed wire who beat me hands down as far as endurance is concerned. They couldn't have been more than 16-17 years old - in total, mind you - and with impressive lung capacity they shouted for the full 2 x 20 minutes (+ extra time) "Veeeegard Heggem is a wanker, is a wanker!" I only hope they weren't Liverpool supporters.'

We at The Observer sports desk football investments department would love to take him up, in view of the fact that the odds for such an eventuality are about 10-1. But we can't afford the £50,000 and are resigned in this new column to investing a mere £1,000 (and a mythical £1,000, at that) on short-term and long-term ventures at the start of every month.

We kick off by staking a pre-season grand for long-term gain. When we rang around to ask about the Man City odds we also asked Hill's for a price about our long-range World Cup fancy: Cameroon to reach the quarter-finals in 2002. The African champions will breeze through qualifying and when you've seen Lauren and Joseph Desire Job in Premiership action you'll soon have an idea why we're staking £300 of our stash at the 12-1 offered by Hill's. Get on if you can.

We hope to collect a year earlier on our second big investment, £500 on Chelsea to win the title at 5-1. We simply have to put the money down because Paul Wilson picked them, and The Observer's football correspondent is so good he recently helped a reader pay off his mortgage by persuading him that France would win Euro 2000 and England would finish third in their group. He also tipped France in the 1998 World Cup and even predicted the month in which Roy Evans would be sacked by Liverpool. Get on now. They were 6-1 last week, before Wilson went public.

The last £200 goes on the Premiership's top scorer. Viduka at 20-1 looks tempting, and there's plenty of money for Hasselbaink, but we want a player with a proven record who will be untroubled by international call-ups. That man is Alan Shearer, available at 10-1 with Heathorns and 9-1 in the High Street with Tote and Coral's.

If you're looking for a quick return, you could try an accumulator in next week's Champions League return legs: Inter, Valencia, Galatasaray, Rosenborg, Panathinaikos and Dynamo Kiev. That should pay about 10-1.

Apart from the mythical money, the sports investment department has persuaded everyone from the editor down to lump on a Sporting Index spread bet for the season: Everton to amass more than 49 points. Looks almost risk-free... but you never can tell. See you in a couple of weeks with our September advice.

Mr Prospector's investments can go down as well as up. Your home could be at risk if you overdo it.

fields.headline: There's a brown girl in the ring - boxing
fields.trailText: Burhan Wazir on the pick of the Edinburgh Festival
fields.body:
Only five minutes into Karyn Kusama's directorial debut, Girlfight, Michelle Rodriguez establishes herself as the most gifted young Hispanic actress to emerge from the US since Rosie Perez. Caught fighting in the school corridor, she is hauled before her headmistress. 'This is the fourth time this semester,' exclaims the teacher. Rodriguez sits silently, scowling from behind hooded eyes.

Girlfight is a towering and sympathetic portrayal of female boxing - made all the more authentic by the recent rise of the sport in the wake of fights by Laila Ali, Muhammad Ali's daughter. Unable to fit into any clique at school, Rodriguez gravitates towards a neighbourhood boxing gym visited by her younger brother. Set in the Brooklyn projects, Girlfight is an assured debut - boxing stripped bare of all the machismo that has usually characterised its transferral to the screen - and Rodriguez is a smouldering presence.

The film festival this year has been marked by a renaissance in low-budget alternative ventures. Another US independent filmmaker, Neil LaBute, scores highly with Nurse Betty - a wry, blackly funny road movie. Renée Zellweger excels as Betty, the diner waitress infatuated with Dr David Ravell, a hospital soap star.

When Betty's husband is killed by Morgan Freeman and comedian Chris Rock, she falls into a trance and heads out West, determined to woo the fictional Dr Ravell as a husband. Nurse Betty is marked by some wonderfully dark moments of humour. And Freeman gives a moving portrayal of a small-time crook hobbled by unfortunate circumstances.

Teamed up with Chris Rock, the pair's performances are played out with all the tragic consequences of Perry Smith and Richard Hickock, the low-down and vengeful killers from Truman Capote's 1967 masterpiece, In Cold Blood. Freeman - always an accomplished character actor - revels in the chance to play a human being peeling off any last hope at redemption.

Brooklyn crops up again in Our Song, a vibrant look at adolescence, with themes similar to those explored in director Jim McKay's debut last year, Girl Town . Our Song - set against the backdrop of the famous Jackie Robinson Steppers Marching Band - examines the fraying friendship between Jocelyn, Lanisha and Maria, all band members. The Jackie Robinson Steppers Marching Band has become an institution in the US - an inner-city project that aims to keep unruly teenagers off the streets.

The marching band, with its bombastic drumming that updates old standards as well as recreating hip-hop anthems, is juxtaposed with the girls' changing relationships with each other. But at heart, Our Song is an age-old tale of growing pains set against a slightly more energetic canvas. And while sometimes self-indulgent in its attempts to re-create teenage humour, McKay's film is characterised by an empathy usually missing from the work of that other great diarist of Brooklyn - Spike Lee.

webTitle: How Halle beat the odds to be the perfect Storm

fields.headline: How Halle beat the odds to be the perfect Storm
fields.standfirst: With the success of X-Men, Halle Berry is on the brink of major stardom. She tells  Adam Smith about the stress of her recent hit-and-run incident, turning down the lead role in Speed and her unlikely Liverpudlian roots
fields.trailText: With the success of X-Men, Halle Berry is on the brink of major stardom. She tells Adam Smith about the stress of her recent hit-and-run incident, turning down the lead role in Speed and her unlikely Liverpudlian roots
fields.body:
Halle Berry is, she reveals, sometimes afflicted with nerves. It's not that in a few hours' time she will have to attend the London premiere of her latest movie, X-Men . Or that she is having, as she puts it, a 'bad hair day' - many women would kill for 'bad' hair like hers. The problem is that, owing to her burgeoning fame, she has attracted that most unwelcome of celebrity accoutrements, a stalker.

'There's some guy in Louisiana who's been doing this to me for two years now,' she says, toying with a half-drunk Diet Coke. 'He shows up in LA, comes to my house, my manager's office - scares the shit out of everybody. Then we have to get the police stalking force involved. But until he tries to do something there's nothing we can do. For the most part I put those feelings in their box. But when he does show up, I worry.'

Berry might console herself with the thought that the presence of the Louisiana loon is an encouraging sign, professionally at least. What self-respecting Hollywood superstar would be without a personal trainer, personal publicist and personal lunatic fan? It's all part of the star deal these days.

For Berry it's been a while coming - X Men is her first copper-bottomed commercial hit. It broke box-office records on its release in the States and looks set to repeat the lucrative trick on this side of the Atlantic. Berry admits: 'I hadn't even heard of the comic books before. Comics are more a boy thing.'

Berry plays Storm, a futuristic mutant super-hero whose special power is manipulating the weather, but the role is far from being her cinema debut. She has been working in film for more than a decade, since giving up her career as a model - she was crowned Miss America in the late Eighties - for the more respectable role of a jobbing actress.

After her acting debut in TV soaps such as Knot's Landing, the Bruce Willis/Damon Wyans vehicle The Last Boy Scout (1991) introduced Berry to mainstream movie audiences. In the same year she starred as a crack addict in Spike Lee's Jungle Fever and people started to notice her.

'I wanted, in a major way, to make a statement,' she says. 'To come out swinging and hopefully have people see me for something other than what was on my resumé at the time, which was modelling.'

It almost worked. Her performance was critically lauded, yet decent roles weren't forthcoming. Not that her choices were bad - on paper, at least. There was The Flintstones , a summer family caper that arrived at the box office virtually extinct. Then there was the Kurt Russell action movie Executive Decision in 1996, an underrated crowd pleaser which nevertheless performed poorly. Even a re-match with Spike Lee in the form of a cameo in his telephone sex yarn Girl 6 turned out to be ill-starred.

And then there was the small matter of turning down the female lead in Speed opposite Keanu Reeves. The role made Sandra Bullock a star, but Berry has no regrets. 'Of all the things I've done so far, nothing has changed my career into Sandra Bullock's, so why would I think that would have? It would have been different for me and I don't have any regrets about not doing it.'

Her greatest success hasn't even been seen in Britain. Last year she produced and starred in Introducing Dorothy Dandridge , a TV biopic of the first black actress to be nominated for an Academy Award. It gained Berry herself the TV equivalent, a Golden Globe, and remains her favourite work. 'It took me seven years to get it on screen but I finally did it. It is absolutely my favourite project. I first saw her in Carmen Jones when I was 12 or 13 and I remember thinking just how beautiful she was and how I'd love to grow up and do what she does. I went to the school library to find out all I could about her. All I found was that she was nominated for an Oscar and that she died aged 42.'

What's surprising about this is not the adolescent Berry's dedication to Dandridge, but that at 13 she had time to visit the school library. Even as an adolescent she was already on the beauty pageant treadmill and was eventually voted Miss Teen USA, the first time a black girl had won the award. 'I knew it was important because it opened a door for an entire group of people,' she says. 'But it weirded my friends out. All of a sudden you get pushed into the spotlight. People are judging you for all these superficial reasons.'

That consciousness of being a black female actor is something that has informed her career. Hollywood might have a variety of prejudices, but, she thinks, things are getting better. 'Wow,' she murmurs when I ask which is the more tricky, in work terms, being a woman or being black. She puts her hands out like a pair of scales. 'Black, woman, woman, black. Any day it could go either way. But I feel that every year little advancements are made.'

There's a third prejudice she faces - the stigma of being a 'model-turned-actress', of people seeing only an ex-Miss Ohio. 'I haven't modelled for 12 years,' she says. 'But whatever your path into this business is, that's just your path. I've gotten away from it I hope. And I'm fortunate to get roles and seek roles that allow me to be anything but that.'

On 23 February this year Berry's somewhat charmed life took a wrong turn. In the small hours of the morning her rented car collided with a Pontiac Sunbird driven by one Hetal Raythatha. Both women were injured, Berry suffering a head injury that would eventually require 20 stitches. But, suffering from concussion and amnesia, she fled the scene of the accident and was charged with hit-and-run. Predictably the tabloids went berserk. 'It was a very scary time for me,' she remembers. 'The papers go wild on bits of information told to them by ... who? Or they take a tiny piece of information and make it bigger than it is. I've never felt so helpless. Every day of it was a particularly low point. It felt as though I'd been just dropped off in hell and left to burn.'

Eventually she was fined and received 200 hours community service. Surprisingly, she says she wouldn't change the events of the last few months. 'What doesn't kill you definitely makes you stronger,' she says. 'You find out who your friends are. And who they're not.'

One disappointment she'll take back home from her trip to Britain is being unable to visit Liverpool - for though it's assumed that Berry is all-American, she was born in the city, the daughter of a white English woman and black American. (The Liverpool birthplace has provoked a group of Everton FC fans to send an invitation, asking Berry to consider becoming the club's American 'mascot'!) Soon after Berry's birth, her family moved to America. 'I've always wanted to go there,' she says of Liverpool. 'To see what it's like. I'm aware it's kind of a blue collar town...'

Berry says she doesn't believe in grand plans. 'I can't tell you where I'll be in five years. I can tell you what I'm going to have for lunch and that I'll be going to the premiere tonight. Apart from that I'm looking forward to a family and children. Another reason to get up in the morning. Another reason to work.'

X-Men is now on general release

The Hollywood whitewash

In the beginning Hollywood only used black actresses to play 'motherly' servants, like Hattie MacDaniel, who became the first black actor or actress to win an Oscar, for Gone With The Wind . MGM debated 'passing' the light-skinned Lena Horne as a non-specific exotic; after she rejected that, the studio never gave her roles that would make her as big a star as her beauty and fame as a singer warranted.Other black singer-actresses such as Diana Ross, Whitney Houston, Aaliyah and TLC's T-Boz - followed her precedent .

By the Fifties, Hollywood knew it had to create some decent roles for African-Americans. The female counterpart to the Poitiers and Belafontes was Dorothy Danbridge, who made a huge impact in Carmen Jones (1954), but died broke 11 years later. The similarly promising career of the brainy, cosmopolitan Diahann Carroll, best seen in Paris Blues (1961), just seemed to stall, at least until Dynasty . Likewise, Pam Grier and Tamara Dobson were doing fine as long as blaxploitation lasted, and then vanished. Even Diana Ross and Whitney Houston only enjoyed temporary screen careers. In recent years Halle Berry, Angela Bassett and more recently Nia Long have built more solid careers, although none has breached the Hollywood A-list. Whoopi Goldberg, a true one-off, has become a casting category of her own.

fields.headline: Lucy Liu
fields.standfirst: The Charlie's Angel who kissed Ally
fields.trailText: Some people just don't know how to keep a low profile and Lucy Liu seems to be one of them.
fields.body:
Some people just don't know how to keep a low profile and Lucy Liu seems to be one of them. In recent times, the Ally McBeal star has been reported as having seduced George Clooney with oysters, set her heart on Matt Damon at all costs, and caused havoc on the set of Charlie's Angels . How much of it is true remains unclear, but it certainly suggests a talent for grabbing headlines.

There's a chance to work out whether she has an equal knack for her day job, acting, in Shanghai Noon . It is an extremely likeable martial arts/western/comedy starring Jackie Chan and Owen Wilson, probably better known for writing Rushmore than for his acting. Liu plays a kidnapped Chinese princess, but she's rather tougher than the damsels in distress of old.

For Liu, though, Shanghai Noon is just a prelude to Charlie's Angels , the real test of whether she can thrive in the movies. As one of the three Angels, she gets equal status with the infinitely more famous Drew Barrymore and Cameron Diaz; improbable for a woman who was still billed as 'Toy Store Girl' as recently as last year in True Crime .

It was Ally McBeal that turned it around for her. Liu was already aged 29 when she auditioned for a role in the second season of the eccentric legal drama. She didn't get that part, but series supremo David E. Kelley liked her enough to a write a role specifically for her to play in a couple of episodes.

And before long, the bitchy, aggressive Ling Woo was one of the most popular characters in the show, the antithesis of Calista Flockhart's dithering eponymous character. Which made it all the more notorious when the two kissed in one episode. 'I'm as honest as Ling,' Liu claims, 'but a little nicer.'

She was born in New York City's least glamorous borough, Queens, in 1968.

After dropping out of New York University, she ended up doing Asian culture and languages at the University of Michigan and then tried to make a name for herself both as an actress and photographer/ multimedia artist. For a while, she seemed to be doing better at the latter. Her first television appearance was in Beverly Hills 90210 in 1991, her first movie was as an unnamed hooker in Bang in 1995 .

It was slow progress until the Ally McBeal audition.

In recent times, the Ally McBeal star has been reported as having seduced George Clooney with oysters, set her heart on Matt Damon at all costs, and caused havoc on the set of Charlie's Angels . How much of it is true remains unclear, but it certainly suggests a talent for grabbing headlines. There's a chance to work out whether she has an equal knack for her day job, acting, in Shanghai Noon . It is an extremely likeable martial arts/western/comedy starring Jackie Chan and Owen Wilson, probably better known for writing Rushmore than for his acting. Liu plays a kidnapped Chinese princess, but she's rather tougher than the damsels in distress of old. For Liu, though, Shanghai Noon is just a prelude to Charlie's Angels , the real test of whether she can thrive in the movies. As one of the three Angels, she gets equal status with the infinitely more famous Drew Barrymore and Cameron Diaz; improbable for a woman who was still billed as 'Toy Store Girl' as recently as last year in True Crime . fields.headline: Mocking the public
fields.standfirst: Rapper launches new acting career
fields.trailText: You might think that Hip hop star and music mogul Sean 'Puffy Daddy' Combs would keep a discreet profile as he awaits trial for possessing weapons. But you would be wrong. The notorious rapper is to launch his movie career with a role, which will further whip up the media storm that surrounds him.
fields.body:
You might think that Hip hop star and music mogul Sean 'Puffy Daddy' Combs would keep a discreet profile as he awaits trial for possessing weapons. But you would be wrong. The notorious rapper is to launch his movie career with a role, which will further whip up the media storm that surrounds him.

The star who, rightly or wrongly, has the image of a pistol-packing maverick will portray a New York gangster boss in Made , a thriller set in the boxing world. The film is bound to send typewriters and tongues into overdrive when it is released in the US later this year. Is he living up to his image or trying to have fun with it? It's the latter according to director Jon Favreau. 'If he took himself too seriously, he'd come off as Vanilla Ice,' he says. After missing out on the chance to play the lead in Oliver Stone's kinetic and well-received gridiron drama Any Given Sunday, Combs has decided to aim high and forgo a few million dollars - not that he needs them.

Made is a low-budget independent film, which is unlikely to herald his arrival as a celluloid player equal to his girlfriend Jennifer Lopez. But the same team behind indie hit Swingers made the film. That will carry kudos among fans who have yet to appreciate Combs's musical mastery. Combs hasn't done a Will Smith. He won't be on the soundtrack although he offered. That could be a wise move. Combs's profile as a serious rapper lies between Richard Blackwood and Smith himself. If he can't hold his own against the bad boys on vinyl, at least he can do it on screen. Like fellow rappers including Ice Cube and LL Cool J, he wants to be both mainstream and edgy. Both the above artists have recently turned in solid performances in marquee movies - Ice Cube ( Three Kings ) and LL Cool J (Any Given Sunday) and their careers are developing. Combs's case won't reach the courts until next year. The public will have reached its verdict by then.

webTitle: A Titanic mistake, a Jurassic error and other  great continuity blunders

fields.headline: A Titanic mistake, a Jurassic error and other  great continuity blunders
fields.standfirst: True cinephiles scour important films to get a cerebral buzz, but not all movie obsessives have their minds on higher things. On movie-mistakes.com, dedicated film anoraks dissect movies to find those moments when filmmakers blundered. Movies are ranked not by artistic merit but by how many errors, mostly continuity, that have been spotted. Here's a selection of goofs from the Top 10.
fields.trailText: True cinephiles scour important films to get a cerebral buzz, but not all movie obsessives have their minds on higher things...
fields.body:
1. Titanic

'There is a beautiful sunset in the background of the scene where Jack and Rose are enjoying their 'flying', but the sun is setting in the south instead of the west. As the Titanic was headed from Britian to New York, it would have been travelling west, but the sunset in this scene is off the port (left) of the ship, and is therefore sinking into the south.'

2. Jurassic Park

'In an early scene, Samuel L Jackson's character is struggling to get the computers up, and he is smoking away. A full cigarette, then half, then full, all without lighting a new smoke.'

3. Saving Private Ryan

'Toward the end of the movie Private Ryan tells the soldiers who came to save him that the last time he and his brothers were together was before they went off to boot camp. But in the pan shot of the interior of the farmhouse, you see a picture of all four brothers in their uniforms.'

4. The Matrix

'In the scene with Laurence Fishburne fighting the agent in the bathroom of the building they were trapped in, the agent punches through a brick wall, yet next time we see the wall there is no damage.'

5. Independence Day

'When Jeff Goldblum and Judd Hirsch are playing chess, the radio next to them says it's 97 degrees outside. Yet the two men are both dressed as if it were winter.'

6. Star Wars

'After Luke destroys the Death Star and is getting out of his fighter, Leia runs over and he shouts 'Carrie!' not Leia.'

7. Star Wars: Episode I - The Phantom Menace

'Obi-Wan's braided hair keeps changing sides and getting longer and shorter, most noticeably in the scenes around the underwater city.'

8. The Wizard of Oz

'During the sequence where Dorothy first meets the Scarecrow, Dorothy's pigtails are short at first (above her shoulders) and as the song progresses her hair gets longer (below her shoulders), then short, and then long again. Magic indeed.'

9. Scream

'At the very end, when Sidney is seen wrestling around on the floor with the killer, she has black sneakers on - but she obviously finds time for a quick change: the next minute she's wearing her boots when she walks through the door.'

10. Mission: Impossible 2

'When Ethan Hunt is attacked by the two guys on motorcycles he shoots one of them off. As a result, the bike comes crashing to the ground and one of the side mirrors gets broken. When Dougray Scott's character is later riding the same red motorcycle, the mirror is in perfect condition.'

fields.headline: The Hollywood hitman
fields.standfirst: Tinseltown's icons  are flayed alive by Basic Instinct's Joe Eszterhas in his incendiary new novel, which has caused uproar in the States. Here, he reveals why he has it in for Gere,  Stone, Beatty et al
fields.trailText: Tinseltown's icons are flayed alive by Basic Instinct's Joe Eszterhas in his incendiary new novel, which has caused uproar in the States. Here, he reveals why he has it in for Gere, Stone, Beatty et al
fields.body:
Two words were not being spoken much at the Democrat's convention in Los Angeles: 'Monica' and 'Willard'. Monica needs neither introduction nor explanation, but Willard maybe does; it's the name Bill Clinton gave to his penis, according to another of his women, Gennifer Flowers. Clinton's reasoning: 'It's longer than Willie.'

Meanwhile, in Malibu, a few miles up the Californian coast, Willard has been on the mind of one of Hollywood's most intriguing stars. Indeed, Willard is the protagonist in Joe Eszterhas's latest book, American Rhapsody , America's current number four bestseller.

Eszterhas is the only movie screenwriter to attain and equal the superstardom of Tinseltown's actors and directors. He has had many famous and infamous ideas during his career walking in and out of Hollywood's portals, looking inside out and outside in. The best known is the 'pussy shot' of Sharon Stone crossing her legs while wearing no knickers in Basic Instinct .

But even this was unambitious compared to American Rhapsody , which had political and movie-making circles holding their breath during the months before it was published. It's a hilarious and scandalous book, part-fact, part-fantasy, about a serious subject: Washington observed through the prism of Hollywood and vice versa.

The Sharon Stone episode is there in full, along with a string of other fantasies that portray the actress as a dope-smoking, power-obsessed manipulator. Almost the entire Hollywood establishment is treated in the same way: Richard Gere, Michael Douglas, Warren Beatty, Gina Gershon, Glenn Close; many more are named and shamed as vain and self-obsessed.

Writs were expected to fly as soon as the book was published and although no one has sued, Stone's agent, for one, has not ruled out action. At Knopf, the book's American publisher, the lawyers were sufficiently concerned to write a 30-page memo. In Britain two publishers have turned it down after taking legal advice.

At the heart of American Rhapsody is an outrageous but astute portrait of Bill Clinton as America's 'first rock'n'roll President'; the man who ran the White House as a Hollywood mogul.

'Politics has become entertainment,' says Eszterhas, 'and entertainment has become politics. Betty Thomas, who made Private Parts and Dr Dolittle, said that comedy in Hollywood was now "funny moments with liberal inserts", and that is right, because Sixties liberals and political correctness have taken over the industry. And the inner dynamics of Hollywood are like politics. Say you give a script to a group of executives - they all sit around, afraid to voice an opinion, saying nothing, waiting to know what the consensus is. Just like focus groups, opinion polls or a cabinet. Meanwhile, politics is about getting a candidate in front of the public as a star, politics as rock'n'roll, politics as a movie.'

These mutually reflective prisms are a product of the cult of rock'n'roll, as epitomised by Eszterhas's own progression from Rolling Stone to Hollywood and now the innards of the Clinton scandal. 'I always wanted to be a rock'n'roll star,' admits Hollywood's highest-paid scriptwriter, 'and so did we all. So did Bill Clinton. Fact is we went on to do other things. But we still wanted to do our success like rock'n'roll stars.'

That's why Bill should come to Hollywood, as he is urged to do in the pivotal chapter of American Rhapsody , 'Bubba in Pig Heaven'. 'You've got to move out here, Bubba - Hollywood is the place for you - this place reeks sex from its cellular pores. A townful of sluts on the make, Willard-friendly and experimental, bored with ham-and-egg, Al Gore orgasms.'

Eszterhas's point is best illustrated by the knotty problem that dominated a year of American politics: the status of oral sex. Blow jobs were central to the Lewinsky scandal. Bill Clinton insisted that blow jobs do not count as sex; much of America agreed. Eszterhas assures the President that oral sex is what manicure girls offer in Hollywood as a matter of routine; they are 'a little break in a busy afternoon', just as they were for Bill in the Oval Office. Same for rock stars in between make-up and the stage. And that's the whole point: 'This is the permeation of rock'n'roll into everything,' says Eszterhas.

He was born in Hungary in 1944, the year the country's Jews were rounded up and sent to Auschwitz. 'I've studied the Holocaust extensively,' he says. 'It's my lifelong obsession.' His family fled when the Red Army cut a swathe across the country, as far as Austria, where the boy and his parents were moved from camp to camp by British and American military authorities.

After the war, they moved to the rust-belt town of Cleveland, Ohio, where his father edited a Catholic-Hungarian newspaper. Young Joe knew little English, but learned quickly enough to graduate and get a job on the Cleveland Plain Dealer , for which he interviewed Jimi Hendrix. He was obliged to leave the paper, however, after causing it to lose a libel suit to the tune of $16,000, a colossal sum in 1971. At that time, there was only one magazine that would give a home to a man who had developed a lifestyle propelled by a mix of drugs, booze and his Willard (by his own admission). He joined Jan Wenner's Rolling Stone and from there made the move to Hollywood.

'I remembered what Hemingway said,' recalls Eszterhas. 'He said, "Stop at the California state line, don't do it; it'll break your heart". I decided not to stop and not to let it break my heart.'

His first script, which got him into an immediate fight with Sylvester Stallone, was 'Fist' . 'It was 300 pages long. A page a minute - that's a long movie, and that's how little I knew.' At the time, Eszterhas said: 'I have always been fascinated by the corruption of power.'

Eszterhas lives in a house on the ocean-front of the Malibu Riviera. Bob Dylan is a neighbour. The greeting is warm and relaxed; his kids charge around covered in sand and seawater. The sofas are decorated with Native American designs and the walls are a shrine to the Sixties: a picture of the Beatles signed by George Harrison; Muhammad Ali; Robert Kennedy. His own scripts - Jagged Edge , Music Box , Telling Lies in Hollywood , Sliver , Basic Instinct - share shelf space with the complete works of Charles Dickens.

Eszterhas's wife, Naomi, moves as graciously around this ménage as is possible for someone who has given birth to a fourth son, Luke, just two days before. They are blissfully happy, 'but it took me 50 years to get there,' says Eszterhas. Their meeting is a story in itself: Sharon Stone ran off with Eszterhas's friend, Bill McDonald, who duly deserted his wife, Naomi. As an act of friendship, Eszterhas and his wife, Geri, decided to take Naomi on a break, only for the screenwriter and the jilted wife to fall in love. 'If someone asked me if I introduced Bill and Sharon deliberately to get hold of Naomi, I'd say, subliminally, I'm sure they're right.'

When most American writers call themselves 'outsiders', one is sceptical. With Eszterhas, you know it's more than partly true. 'I was six when we came to this country. When I was 14 or so, I still had a lot of trouble with it. I saw my father humiliated countless times in limitless ways. Every time I saw that happen, I was thrown into full-blown hysterics, like a two-year-old. I find myself with an immediate understanding of people who are on the outside, the Jews, whatever colour or creed they are. The showgirls, gays and outcasts.'

In Hollywood, Eszterhas has done many out-of-the-ordinary things, but one above all. He has made the usually hidden figure of the screenwriter into someone not only visible but also bankable. 'I have only one loyalty - to my writing. I never wanted to be the head of a studio or a producer,' he says. 'I just wanted to make sure that what I write is what appears on screen, to not have some idiot change it on its way to the screen. There sure as hell are some idiots in Hollywood. Complete morons.'

This attitude has led Eszterhas into some famous scraps, victories and defeats. It led to his fight with one of the most powerful titans in Hollywood, Mike Ovitz, when Eszterhas left Ovitz's Creative Artists empire to rejoin the agent with whom he originally worked in Hollywood, 'and who gave me my break' - out of loyalty. 'I'm the only sucker in Hollywood to be accused by Ovitz of disloyalty for doing something loyal,' he shrugs.

His greatest triumph, he says, was protecting the coda scenes of both Jagged Edge and Flashdance from 'going to the wall in the hands of the directors'. His biggest failure, he says, was the loss of control of a script dear to him, 'written with my friend, Richard Marquand, who later died. It was about an escaped convict and the relationship he had with children. The script was taken and destroyed many years later by Jean-Claude Van Damme as Nowhere to Run . It lost its sensitivity, it lost everything. I don't like to remember that movie.'

His favourite among his own movies is Music Box , in which Jessica Lange plays an attorney defending her Hungarian father against accusations that he was a collaborator with the Nazis and a war criminal. It was the most serious film to establish the hallmark Eszterhas theme - that everyone has a past, and that it is not always the past you want people to know about.

It was a theme he returned to in Showgirls , which he admits is the least favourite of his own films. In the film, a girl escapes a life of prostitution to join a dance troupe in Vegas. The film contained an infamous rape scene, 'which we should not, I feel now, have shown, although I do insist that to show such a scene does not imply any complicity in it. I worry that we are approaching a time when that which is shocking is squeezed out by the Stalinism of political correctness. I think the messenger was slain for the message. It's against the tyranny of political correctness that American Rhapsody is an assault.'

The book took shape after the failure of Showgirls and the sudden convergence of other movies. 'Every time I flicked channels, there I was, talking. I was talking too much and writing too little. So Naomi and I went to Hawaii. The phone was cut off and we lost touch. This gave me the chance to have a good think about my life.'

On his return to Los Angeles, the Lewinsky scandal was in full bloom, and Eszterhas became addicted and immersed. 'I had in mind to do a piece for Rolling Stone , but I had no idea that it would become an obsession and a 1,000-page manuscript. Maybe as a writer I was getting hemmed in by scripts. I felt like someone let out of jail and going berserk.'

Apart from Bill, Monica and the political cast, the book singles out Sharon Stone for treatment. Eszterhas claims to have 'created' Stone and to have been her lover. He feels a 'proprietary interest' when he hears about the friendship between Clinton and Stone. She was 'Bill Clinton's ideal woman' and 'every bit as political as he', given that 'a star's career is a lifelong political campaign'. She had 'ascended her star on the strength of her privates, but had handled the challenge well'.

'I just had this idea that Bill and Sharon wanted to get together and should have got together,' explains Eszterhas. 'But Bill would not have got away with what Hillary has let him get away with. Not only would he have had scratches on his nose, but Sharon can be quite lethal with an ice-pick.'

Does he have it in for Sharon Stone? Eszterhas puts on his sincere face. 'Of course not. Who would? She is cuddly and warm.' Cuddly and warm? 'She's a great actress and, like Marilyn Monroe, she's the sex symbol of her time. I'm just saying this: Kennedy-Monroe, Clinton-Stone - it would have been perfect.'

Then there's Warren Beatty, whose political ambitions are derided not only because he is 'the man with the golden Willard'. He quotes Joan Collins: 'Three, four, five times a day was not unusual for Warren. And he was able to accept phone calls at the same time.'

The most wonderfully insulting reference to Beatty concerns not his sexual prowess but his own presidential ambitions - and his lacking the concentration required to last four years in the White House. In conversation, Eszterhas adds: 'Warren's problem is common for method actors. It's a natural reaction - method actors getting too caught up in their parts. He had done Bulworth and he couldn't let go. He had to pretend that he could do it in real life. You see? Politics as Hollywood and vice versa.'

The book also fantasises about Farrah Fawcett Majors defecating on a lawn at a public function and Richard Gere unzipping his flies and revealing 'no boxers' while pitching a movie idea to Eszterhas.

Eszterhas said some weeks ago that he still intended to eat at Spago's and 'get good tables'. 'Since then,' he assured me last Wednesday, 'I have eaten there, got an excellent table and many people came up to me to say how much they enjoyed my book, not least because they were not in it.'

'He's made a few enemies with this,' one insider told The Observer . But when Tina Brown threw a party for him, 'about 300 of the supposedly offended Hollywood people turned up. Mike Medevos, head of Phoenix, said he loved it and he was happy he wasn't in it. There are plenty more like him.'

The White House has nothing to say, even though American Rhapsody is as sympathetic a portrait as Bill Clinton is likely to get in any book that is not by a party-political ally. In understanding the Willard-propulsion of Clinton the man, Eszterhas has explained the drama that befell Clinton the President. And by seeing that drama through Hollywood's eyes , he has spoken for that stubborn 65 per cent of Americans who were unmoved by the whole affair.

But there is one thing Eszterhas cannot forgive: the lying. Richard Nixon casts the shadow of evil in this book. 'The important thing,' says Eszterhas, 'was that Nixon was a liar and the Sixties was about telling the truth. Now we had Clinton, jabbing his middle finger at us with a great big fucking lie.'

He joined Jan Wenner's Rolling Stone and from there made the move to Hollywood. 'I remembered what Hemingway said,' recalls Eszterhas. 'He said, "Stop at the California state line, don't do it; it'll break your heart". I decided not to stop and not to let it break my heart.' His first script, which got him into an immediate fight with Sylvester Stallone, was 'Fist' . 'It was 300 pages long. A page a minute - that's a long movie, and that's how little I knew.' At the time, Eszterhas said: 'I have always been fascinated by the corruption of power.' Eszterhas lives in a house on the ocean-front of the Malibu Riviera. Bob Dylan is a neighbour. The greeting is warm and relaxed; his kids charge around covered in sand and seawater. The sofas are decorated with Native American designs and the walls are a shrine to the Sixties: a picture of the Beatles signed by George Harrison; Muhammad Ali; Robert Kennedy. His own scripts - Jagged Edge , Music Box , Telling Lies in Hollywood , Sliver , Basic Instinct - share shelf space with the complete works of Charles Dickens. Eszterhas's wife, Naomi, moves as graciously around this ménage as is possible for someone who has given birth to a fourth son, Luke, just two days before. They are blissfully happy, 'but it took me 50 years to get there,' says Eszterhas. Their meeting is a story in itself: Sharon Stone ran off with Eszterhas's friend, Bill McDonald, who duly deserted his wife, Naomi. As an act of friendship, Eszterhas and his wife, Geri, decided to take Naomi on a break, only for the screenwriter and the jilted wife to fall in love. 'If someone asked me if I introduced Bill and Sharon deliberately to get hold of Naomi, I'd say, subliminally, I'm sure they're right.' When most American writers call themselves 'outsiders', one is sceptical. With Eszterhas, you know it's more than partly true. 'I was six when we came to this country. When I was 14 or so, I still had a lot of trouble with it. I saw my father humiliated countless times in limitless ways. Every time I saw that happen, I was thrown into full-blown hysterics, like a two-year-old. I find myself with an immediate understanding of people who are on the outside, the Jews, whatever colour or creed they are. The showgirls, gays and outcasts.' In Hollywood, Eszterhas has done many out-of-the-ordinary things, but one above all. He has made the usually hidden figure of the screenwriter into someone not only visible but also bankable. 'I have only one loyalty - to my writing. I never wanted to be the head of a studio or a producer,' he says. 'I just wanted to make sure that what I write is what appears on screen, to not have some idiot change it on its way to the screen. There sure as hell are some idiots in Hollywood. Complete morons.' This attitude has led Eszterhas into some famous scraps, victories and defeats. It led to his fight with one of the most powerful titans in Hollywood, Mike Ovitz, when Eszterhas left Ovitz's Creative Artists empire to rejoin the agent with whom he originally worked in Hollywood, 'and who gave me my break' - out of loyalty. 'I'm the only sucker in Hollywood to be accused by Ovitz of disloyalty for doing something loyal,' he shrugs. His greatest triumph, he says, was protecting the coda scenes of both Jagged Edge and Flashdance from 'going to the wall in the hands of the directors'. His biggest failure, he says, was the loss of control of a script dear to him, 'written with my friend, Richard Marquand, who later died. It was about an escaped convict and the relationship he had with children. The script was taken and destroyed many years later by Jean-Claude Van Damme as Nowhere to Run . It lost its sensitivity, it lost everything. I don't like to remember that movie.' His favourite among his own movies is Music Box , in which Jessica Lange plays an attorney defending her Hungarian father against accusations that he was a collaborator with the Nazis and a war criminal. It was the most serious film to establish the hallmark Eszterhas theme - that everyone has a past, and that it is not always the past you want people to know about. It was a theme he returned to in Showgirls , which he admits is the least favourite of his own films. In the film, a girl escapes a life of prostitution to join a dance troupe in Vegas. The film contained an infamous rape scene, 'which we should not, I feel now, have shown, although I do insist that to show such a scene does not imply any complicity in it. I worry that we are approaching a time when that which is shocking is squeezed out by the Stalinism of political correctness. I think the messenger was slain for the message. It's against the tyranny of political correctness that American Rhapsody is an assault.' The book took shape after the failure of Showgirls and the sudden convergence of other movies. 'Every time I flicked channels, there I was, talking. I was talking too much and writing too little. So Naomi and I went to Hawaii. The phone was cut off and we lost touch. This gave me the chance to have a good think about my life.' On his return to Los Angeles, the Lewinsky scandal was in full bloom, and Eszterhas became addicted and immersed. 'I had in mind to do a piece for Rolling Stone , but I had no idea that it would become an obsession and a 1,000-page manuscript. Maybe as a writer I was getting hemmed in by scripts. I felt like someone let out of jail and going berserk.' Apart from Bill, Monica and the political cast, the book singles out Sharon Stone for treatment. Eszterhas claims to have 'created' Stone and to have been her lover. He feels a 'proprietary interest' when he hears about the friendship between Clinton and Stone. She was 'Bill Clinton's ideal woman' and 'every bit as political as he', given that 'a star's career is a lifelong political campaign'. She had 'ascended her star on the strength of her privates, but had handled the challenge well'. 'I just had this idea that Bill and Sharon wanted to get together and should have got together,' explains Eszterhas. 'But Bill would not have got away with what Hillary has let him get away with. Not only would he have had scratches on his nose, but Sharon can be quite lethal with an ice-pick.' Does he have it in for Sharon Stone? Eszterhas puts on his sincere face. 'Of course not. Who would? She is cuddly and warm.' Cuddly and warm? 'She's a great actress and, like Marilyn Monroe, she's the sex symbol of her time. I'm just saying this: Kennedy-Monroe, Clinton-Stone - it would have been perfect.' Then there's Warren Beatty, whose political ambitions are derided not only because he is 'the man with the golden Willard'. He quotes Joan Collins: 'Three, four, five times a day was not unusual for Warren. And he was able to accept phone calls at the same time.' The most wonderfully insulting reference to Beatty concerns not his sexual prowess but his own presidential ambitions - and his lacking the concentration required to last four years in the White House. In conversation, Eszterhas adds: 'Warren's problem is common for method actors. It's a natural reaction - method actors getting too caught up in their parts. He had done Bulworth and he couldn't let go. He had to pretend that he could do it in real life. You see? Politics as Hollywood and vice versa.' The book also fantasises about Farrah Fawcett Majors defecating on a lawn at a public function and Richard Gere unzipping his flies and revealing 'no boxers' while pitching a movie idea to Eszterhas. Eszterhas said some weeks ago that he still intended to eat at Spago's and 'get good tables'. 'Since then,' he assured me last Wednesday, 'I have eaten there, got an excellent table and many people came up to me to say how much they enjoyed my book, not least because they were not in it.' 'He's made a few enemies with this,' one insider told The Observer . But when Tina Brown threw a party for him, 'about 300 of the supposedly offended Hollywood people turned up. Mike Medevos, head of Phoenix, said he loved it and he was happy he wasn't in it. There are plenty more like him.' The White House has nothing to say, even though American Rhapsody is as sympathetic a portrait as Bill Clinton is likely to get in any book that is not by a party-political ally. In understanding the Willard-propulsion of Clinton the man, Eszterhas has explained the drama that befell Clinton the President. And by seeing that drama through Hollywood's eyes , he has spoken for that stubborn 65 per cent of Americans who were unmoved by the whole affair. But there is one thing Eszterhas cannot forgive: the lying. Richard Nixon casts the shadow of evil in this book. 'The important thing,' says Eszterhas, 'was that Nixon was a liar and the Sixties was about telling the truth. Now we had Clinton, jabbing his middle finger at us with a great big fucking lie.'

fields.headline: Audio
fields.trailText: Michael Maloney is a skilled narrator and he cannot be faulted on his understanding of the narrative. His female voices, however, leave much to be desired.
fields.body:
Women in Love
D.H. Lawrence
Read by Michael Maloney
Running time 6hrs
Penguin £8.99

Enjoying a reissue of a classic book is a wholly different experience to that of listening to a new novel with an unknown plot.

Before starting out on this deep and emotive story, I did not expect any surprises. I had read the book, seen the film and so was able to concentrate without distraction, as Lawrence would have wished, on the symbolism of the characters.

The Brangwen sisters, Ursula and Gudrun, are teachers in a small mining town. They meet and fall in love with two young men: Rupert Birkin, an idealist (a reflection of Lawrence's own character) and Gerald Crich, a progressive and capitalist, a product of the industrial revolution.

The sisters are symbols of the changing roles of women during the 1920s: Ursula, the more liberated, and Gudrun, domestic and chaste.

For the most part, it is possible to listen to the story with fresh ears, but it is not possible to shake off the image of Oliver Reed and Alan Bates as Gerald and Birkin respectively in the homo-erotic wrestling scene of Ken Russell's 1969 film.

Michael Maloney is a skilled narrator and he cannot be faulted on his understanding of the narrative. His female voices, however, leave much to be desired. He makes Hermione, Birkin's cynical ex-lover sound like a neighing horse and Gudrun and Ursula come across as shrill, neurotic females, not unlike the piano-playing drag queen sisters, Hinge and Bracket. Do not be put off - Lawrence's voice is the loudest of all.

webTitle: Paperback of the week: Galileo's Daughter

fields.headline: Paperback of the week
fields.trailText: To discover one twinkling tale - the much-acclaimed Longitude - might be considered a lucky break, but for Dava Sobel to gouge a second gem out of history is nothing short of miraculous.
fields.body:
Galileo's Daughter
Dava Sobel
Fourth Estate £6.99
Buy it at BOL

To discover one twinkling tale - the much-acclaimed Longitude - might be considered a lucky break, but for Dava Sobel to gouge a second gem out of history is nothing short of miraculous.

Sobel narrates the life of Galileo Galilei, the scientist who treasured his soul and came close to losing his spirit, through the 124 letters sent by his beloved but illegitimate daughter, Suor Maria Celeste, placed by her father in a nunnery at 13. The letters were discovered by Sobel in the bowels of Florence's National Central Library.

Galileo lived in a world where the Earth was the undisputed centre of the universe and where to suggest otherwise was to risk death at the hands of the dreaded Inquisition. Nevertheless, propelled by a determination to preserve Italy's scientific pre-eminence and protect the honour of the Roman Catholic Church, the devout astronomer risked his life to persuade the Pope to acknowledge the truth of his nocturnal observations.

Her side of the correspondence shows how the two doted on each other. The letters reveal an intimacy exacerbated by the poverty of the order which rendered the smallest detail of her comfort entirely dependent on her father's charity.

While he was teaching, inventing modern physics and defending his theories, he was also shipping homegrown fruit, wine and rosemary leaves to the nunnery, says Sobel.

As Galileo slid deeper into the Inquisition's deadly maw, his daughter attempted to raise his spirits with domestic anecdotes and loving advice. This is a biography, a thriller and a story of unrequited love rolled into one, but most of all, it's a cracking read.

fields.headline: Children's choice
fields.trailText: Successful author finally gets self-indulgent? Definitely not, says Kit Spring
fields.body:
Frenchtown Summer
Robert Courmier
Puffin £4.99, pp110
Buy it at BOL

When I first picked up this short book, my heart sank. Over the years, American author Robert Courmier has written intelligent, sensitive, hard-hitting novels for teenagers which are among the very best of the genre. So the last thing I expected was to find a novel written in verse. Successful author finally gets self-indulgent was my first ungracious thought. But this turned out to be very far from the case.

Frenchtown Summer, set in the Thirties - the era of Courmier's own youth - tells the story of 12-year-old Eugene. As he goes on his paper-round, he watches and wonders at the lives of the inhabitants - seeing a great deal, but always aware that there is so much more going on than he can comprehend. There is happy Uncle Med, who kills himself one day and doesn't leave a note, and silent Uncle Jules who wanted to go to war, but was crippled when crates at the comb factory fell on him. All is not sad. There are passages of great lyricism and beauty and the whole narrative flows smoothly and evocatively.

The heart of the story is Eugene's struggle to get closer to his father, who is distant and mysterious to him. The bond between them is finally forged in a totally surprising and surreal way.

fields.headline: Paperbacks
fields.trailText: Stephen Jay Gould revisits the strange creatures of the Burgess Shale, plus A World Full of Gods, James Miranda Barry, Flight Paths of the Emperor and One Fine Day in the Middle of the Night
fields.body:
Wonderful Life
Stephen Jay Gould
Vintage £8.99, pp347
Buy it at BOL

When they were found in the Canadian Rockies in 1909, the fossils of the Burgess Shale showed that the world held no shortage of surprises, but it took 50 years to realise how significant the discovery was. It later turned out that many of these strange beasts had no latter-day equivalent, prompting experts to rethink accepted ideas about evolution. Wonderful Life describes how the discovery makes it possible that Homo sapiens, rather than being on the top rung of human evolution, is 'an afterthought... just one bauble on the Christmas tree of evolution'.

The illustrations and glossaries often clutter more than they clarify, and the writing can be dauntingly dense, but it is worth persevering because of Gould's enthusiasm.

A World Full of Gods
Keith Hopkins
Phoenix £7.99, pp402
Buy it at BOL

Vastly more readable than Jack Miles's Pulitzer Prize-winning Biography of God, this is in effect its sequel, chronicling the rise of the Christian Church. Humanity's ever-changing relationship with God(s) is probably the most fascinating aspect of our mental evolution, and such books constitute a serious faith-test for fundamentalists. Hopkins is consistently inventive in adopting diverse strategies - teleplays, modern 'epistles', dialogues and first-hand reports from 'time-travellers' - to illustrate the variety of styles the Gospels' authors experimented with.

The Church we thought we knew is exploded into a profusion of bloodstained glass and wood; myths, sects and counter-sects. Versions of God have come and gone, but the imagination that produced afterworlds and netherworlds is alive and well.

James Miranda Barry
Patricia Duncker
Picador £6.99, pp375
Buy it at BOL

For all her success as a surgeon, duellist and philanthropist, the tragedies of James Miranda Barry's life were manifold. In Patricia Duncker's fictional version, her parentage was concealed from her, just as she concealed her sex from the world. Besides recreating a marvellous and minutely detailed vision of Empire in the nineteenth century, Duncker presents the continuous struggle with fate. The story has a moral to appeal to everyone - that even the best may feel that they have to hide some part of themselves.

Unfortunately, while the story and settings are magnificent, Duncker doesn't really succeed in eliciting much sympathy for Barry, who is described as 'a less appetising mixture of brains, calculation and the brisk chill of reason'. This novel has an austere beauty - to be admired rather than treasured, but admired a great deal.

Flight Paths of the Emperor
Steven Heighton
Granta £6.99, pp242

Buy it at BOL

Although many of these addictive stories were inspired by the author's first-hand experience of Japan, such is his talent that he effortlessly recreates the time - 1945 - when the schism between West and East became, if anything, more pronounced, rather than less. In fluid prose that is of haiku simplicity and poignancy, Heighton interweaves tales of strained relationships and the deaths of emperors. There is also some understated comedy in the kidnapping of a teacher by the last of the Yakuza - the self-styled Last Samurai.

Like Tobias Wolf or Carson McCullers, this acclaimed young writer seems to have the ability to produce story after story of unremitting ingenuity that seem to steadily improve as you are drawn further and further in. With his debut novel - The Shadow Boxer - being released simultaneously, this is evidently the start of something momentous.

One Fine Day in the Middle of the Night
Christopher Brookmyre
Abacus £6.99, pp373
Buy it at BOL

When Gavin Hutchinson, entrepreneur and former nonentity, organises a school reunion on his new oil rig-cum-holiday resort to bask in the envy of his classmates, he is immediately upstaged by a bunch of uninvited guests who happen to include a woefully shambolic group of terrorists.

One Fine Day may borrow heavily from Grosse Point Blank, Die Hard and High Fidelity, but with everyone vying to be John Cusack and Bruce Willis at once, it is hair-raising and hilarious in equal measure. In typically post-modern fashion, one character claims to have been enticed by the prospect of a half-finished resort 'because the Death Star and Jurassic Park were half-finished' - which is worth a bit of a laugh, even if the author hasn't added much to the Scream formula. Nevertheless, this is a vicious novel and one that you couldn't read faster if you were at gunpoint.
