fields.headline: Revolutionary Gothic
fields.standfirst: Patrick McGrath talks about rape, memory and the attraction of the Gothic
fields.trailText: Patrick McGrath talks about rape, memory and the attraction of the Gothic
fields.body:
Observer: You've subtitled this book, 'A Novel of the Revolution'. Is it just about the American Revolution or something else as well ?

Patrick McGrath: Centrally it's about the American Revolution, because it's about Martha Peake who would not have come to our notice were it not for her role in the American Revolution.

Obs: Is she a historical figure ?

McGrath: She's a complete invention.

Obs: And is New Morrock, the town to which she emigrates, also an invention?

McGrath: Completely.

Obs: So you've borrowed things from all over the place?

McGrath: Yes, whatever came in handy. I believe the context of the novel is as true to the American Revolution as I could get it, but my own story is invented.

Obs: There's a rape at the heart of the book. Was that difficult?

McGrath: It wasn't particularly, once I saw that it was necessary. I wanted the rape to occur for symbolic reasons largely, so that Martha could bear the child of her father in the New World, and then the problem remained of making it work psychologically.

I wanted to get at the relationship of England and America, to explore that in terms of a parent-child relationship. I wanted to get at the mythical element within every nation's own history. The simplifications that occur; the distortions that occur in history, or within the transmission of historical fact into national narratives.

Obs: Was there a specific moment of inspiration for your story?

McGrath: The overall story was inspired by the story that I think is now becoming familiar, of John Hunter, the anatomist, and his relationship to a man called O'Brien, an 8ft 2in Irish giant, whose skeleton can still be seen in the anatomy museum in Lincoln's Inn Field.

Obs: So on one level the book is a deliberately Gothic historical novel. Did you enjoy the experience of writing in this genre?

McGrath: I've always had a leaning towards the Gothic, and the Gothic seems to permeate my imagination, although I never sit down and say I'm going to set out and write a Gothic novel. But in this case I thought I had a chance to actually employ the Gothic in the most precise and proper way, because Gothic is a genre that concerns itself about time, and particularly the way that time both ruins things and also conceals things. I thought these attributes of the genre were perfectly suited to a novel that is to some extent questioning the historical method.

Obs: But it's also about memory, recollection and story-telling.

McGrath: Particularly memory as a sort of national attribute. The way that a country will remember its own past in certain ways that tend to reflect its own sense of importance, sense of glory, sense of triumph, sense of the struggles it has come through. The United States is remarkable among nations for this. So I wanted to see if personal memory, the way that we adapt and adjust and distort our memories in order to provide ourselves with the best possible biography, if you couldn't just transfer that process complete to the business of a nation telling its own story through history, with all of the foibles and idiosyncrasies of personal memory.

Obs: Martha Peake's story is told by an unreliable narrator who is also receiving the narration from a second narrator. Was that technically complex?

McGrath: It was a struggle to come up with that idea. I had my story, Harry Peake and his relationship with Martha, and then Martha in America. What I didn't have was a frame for it. I didn't know who was to tell this story, and I thought of Martha, I thought of Silas, I thought of the anatomist Lord Drogo, and then it occurred to me to have a young man, Ambrose, come out and speak to an old man. Neither of them is particularly reliable, and yet between them they somehow construct this thing that we will call the 'History of Martha Peake'.

Obs: The spirit of Dickens hovered in a benign way over much of the book.

McGrath: I always feel rather blinkered when I am writing a novel, and I seem to be inventing out of a whole cloth somehow, but I think I deliberately feed the imagination by reading. In particular, I read Barnaby Rudge for this book. But there's a certain way in which the reading is absorbed at a level which is not employed in the actual writing.

I let that all happen in an unconscious way, so I don't feel threatened by the proximity of Dickensian London. I was more conscious of Hogarth actually than Dickens.

Obs: Which writers would you say have influenced you the most?

McGrath: I think it's more a matter of books. I have a personal canon which would include Death in Venice and Heart of Darkness, Wuthering Heights, probably Brideshead Revisited, Doctor Jekyll and Mr Hyde, The Picture of Dorian Gray, Dracula. Probably for this one, I think, Roderick Random, I re-read that for this and went through my Fielding and my Johnson and Boswell.

But I think that little clutch of rather dark nineteenth, early twentieth-century novels and novellas would be my personal canon.

Obs: At times, the novel seems reminiscent of Stevenson.

McGrath: When I'd finished my previous book, Asylum, I wanted very consciously to write something that was much more driven by plot and narrative than by internal psychological development and went back to Stevenson and read things like Kidnapped and Treasure Island as well as Jekyll and Hyde.

I thought I would write a novel that gives the same sorts of pleasures that Stevenson does, and also John Buchan as well - romantic adventure. The idea was to get a sort of Stevensonian narrative pleasure working in the book, if at all possible.

Obs: How long did it take to write?

McGrath: Four years, which was largely spent immersed in American Revolutionary history, so as not to make a fool of myself.

Obs: Did you go out to Boston?

McGrath: I did a tour of New England and tramped about battlefields and so forth.

Obs: Is New Morrock based on anywhere?

McGrath: It's generic north Massachusetts or Maine, which at that time was part of Massachusetts. It seems a bit wild to be Massachusetts, so I imagine that it's somewhere in Maine. Actually it feels to me more Cornish than American. The cliffs of Maine don't tend to rise to those heights.

Obs: What are you writing now?

McGrath: Nothing at the moment. I'm mulling and reading and thinking and preparing to write. Something contemporary, I think.

Obs: But Gothic?

McGrath: I don't know. As I say, I don't start off thinking I'm going to write a Gothic novel.

Obs: But that's your subject, isn't it ?

McGrath: Yes, I suppose insanity has always been of great interest.

Obs: Why is that?

McGrath: Probably I got it from my father, who was a psychiatrist in charge of Broadmoor from 1955 to 1981. He taught me to see that the insane are ill rather than monstrous, and that they deserve the same sympathy and respect that any ill person deserves. I think my childhood gave me a moral position from which to develop character. I found that when I began to write fiction I ran through a number of genres in my first year and settled then on some sort of pastiche of Edgar Allan Poe, and sensed that I was on the territory that I should be on.

Obs: And did you always want to be a writer?

McGrath: I did, but then that sort of dream was submerged for about a decade from my late teens to my late twenties - when I thought that I should be doing a more socially responsible activity, much under the influence partly of the time and partly of my family, all of whom ended up being doctors or teachers of one sort or another.

But in the end that didn't work out, so I returned to the notion of writing as a last resort.

webTitle: Observer review: Martha Peake by Patrick McGrath

fields.headline: Don't read this when you're alone...
fields.standfirst: Patrick McGrath has forged a Gothic gem, Martha Peake, out of the American Revolution - but don't trust either of the narrators
fields.trailText: Patrick McGrath has forged a Gothic gem, Martha Peake, out of the American Revolution - but don't trust either of the narrators
fields.body:
Martha Peake
Patrick McGrath
Viking £12.99, pp352
Buy it at BOL

Gothic was an eighteenth-century invention, of course. And there's a wonderful sense of rightness about Patrick McGrath, the best of Gothic novelists, turning back to the period and writing this astonishing historical novel. For some time, I toyed with various reviewer's formulae along the lines of 'McGrath is the best Gothic novelist since'... Since who? Mary Shelley? Ann Radcliffe? Forget it. McGrath may be the best Gothic novelist ever.

The remarkable thing about McGrath is that, though he works within the conventions of his genre, he always seems to see the full range of their implications. Gothic, for McGrath, is not just a literary mode which may be dropped into or out of at will; it is the state of mind we have lived in since the Enlightenment.

One of the most pleasing things about Martha Peake is that it doesn't see the haunted house terrors which the late eighteenth century liked so much as an irrelevant diversion from its more serious inquiries. Rather, those serious inquiries - 'the American Revolution, the death of God, and Hume's epistemology' - exist alongside and within a Gothic world view. It feels like a real understanding of the period, and a big step forward in our understanding of ourselves.

It's set in the 1760s and 1770s and tells the story of a poor hunchback, Harry Peake, and his daughter Martha. Peake's extraordinary deformations come to the attention of an amateur physiologist, Lord Drogo, who exhibits him and shows signs of wanting to acquire his body for his museum of curiosities. Martha escapes the dreadful Castle Drogo, after being raped and impregnated by her gin-sodden father, and runs away to America.

Most of Martha Peake is more or less indistinguishable from the most elegant haunted-house nightmare one ever read. There is an insane hunchback, roaming the remote Castle Drogo. A lecherous body-snatcher hangs about, eyeing up any likely candidates for his employer's knife and occasionally delivering hanged wretches from Tyburn. Most of the story is told by an opium-addicted geriatric in front of the fire at dead of night. Beloved, angelic wives are killed in tragic fires; the children of incestuous rapes are born and discovered to be misshapen monsters; smugglers haunt the nearby coves, ready to signal to waiting ships.

Not many novelists now would have the nerve to end a chapter like this, 'And then, in the silence, with a last flare in the whivering gloom, one wall sconce in the ante-chamber gave out with a sputtering sigh', and then, a second later, 'and in the sudden darkness, a hand fell on my shoulder'. Gothic is, of all literary genres, the most irredeemably trivial, the one most incapable of dealing with the horrors it so eagerly evokes. One could not write a Gothic novel about Auschwitz.

McGrath's brilliance, however, is to see the Gothic fantasy within a proper, serious context. His last novel, the sublime Asylum, let the horrors arise slowly from the solipsistic and public mythologies of madness and psychiatry; this one uses the most tawdry trappings of Otranto and Udolpho to explore the mind and history of the age which dreamt them up.

Take the smugglers; they are an ordinary sort of theatrical prop. But why were they smuggling? Well, to avoid duty, which weighed heavily on the poor; and when Martha, later in the novel, escapes to America and meets more smugglers there, the Boston Tea Party and the American Revolution are not far away. And we realise we are in the hands of a novelist of unusual intelligence.

The fineness of Martha Peake is not in the absorbed exploration of intellectual life, but in the astonishing virtuosity of the plot. There are at least two unreliable narrators; there is a series of lucid, shocking reversals towards the end, which cannot even be hinted at; there is, throughout, a wonderful sense of delay and suspension, screwing the tension up to its highest possible point. If, in the end, it is a dazzling divertissement rather than the grand and troubling meditation of Asylum, it is an unusually intelligent and serious one.

At the end, the reader starts to wonder about things McGrath has not hinted at. If Martha's son inherits his father/grandfather's deformity, how can that deformity result, as the novel says, from a fire? And bigger questions; Martha runs away from a country which hangs innocents like a poor thieving actress, Mary Magdalen Smith, to America, land of the free. But the reader is bound to reflect that there are plenty of Mary Magdalen Smiths still being put to death in Texas today. You can't trust the words of this novel. But, my God, you trust its author.

webTitle: Observer review: The Island in the Mind by Rodney Hall

fields.headline: Travel broadens the mind
fields.standfirst: Rodney Hall sets out on three voyages of discovery in The Island in the Mind, but can he take us with him?
fields.trailText: Rodney Hall sets out on three voyages of discovery in The Island in the Mind, but can he take us with him?
fields.body:
The Island in the Mind
Rodney Hall
Granta £15.99, pp576

This is a big novel about a big continent, the one that exists just beyond the boundaries of everything you know. In the late seventeenth century, Europeans thought of it as terra incognita, a vast, floating island adrift in the southern hemisphere, filled with strange creatures, plants and trees. It was a potentially inexhaustible place where you could attach your name to things, material and people, load them on a boat and turn them into something you did know - money. If, that is, you could find your way home again.

The Island in the Mind is a triptych of novels about Enlightenment-age individuals verging too perilously into wide colonial spaces. First, and most memorably, there is the aspiring petty official who forsakes courtly politics for a secret alliance with the musician-in-residence, Orlande Scarron, whose vast operatic tribute to Louis XIV seeks to encapsulate everything the French empire does not - the undiscovered, the unquantifiable, the different.

What the world can never fully know is the human mind that knows it, and it is Scarron's duty to remind the king that there are subjective places he will never rule. It is a lesson that can only lead to exile.

In 'The Lonely Traveller by Night', the sin-haunted daughter of an Italian merchant makes the disorienting acquaintance of a displaced aborigine. In a world obsessed with curiosities, the savage's alienness makes him an object of value; both the Western pope and an Eastern sultan connive to sell his huge skull on the open market, rather than attempt to understand the thoughts and feelings locked inside it. In 'Lord Hermaphrodite', an obvious homage to Conrad, some British joint-stock associates journey into the limits of imperialism seeking authentic pirates, since they may be just the sort of people they can do business with.

Nothing benefits a developing mercantile empire better than true villains, unless the villains possess a deeper sense of moral purpose than you.

The unknown land which exists just beyond the horizon of all three stories is the author's native Australia, and they are all about what civilisation lost when the last undiscovered country was finally mapped and cultivated. But while this is an ambitious, intelligent book, expressing a unified view of our broken world with energy and conviction, it eventually grows rather deadening: the poststructural juxtapositions of self and other grow predictable, the characters get lost in philosophical speculation, and the dense, often expository prose lacks much human drama, even when it concerns what it means to be human.

The Island in the Mind will remind readers that Hall is a fine writer, but, sadly, it may not get him read.

webTitle: Observer review: Sick Puppy, Boiling a Frog, Hot Springs and Storm

fields.headline: Ecoterrorism can be fun
fields.standfirst: Greenery with violence? Hiaasen's back...
fields.trailText: Greenery with violence? Hiaasen's back... Peter Guttridge on Sick Puppy, Boiling a Frog, Hot Springs and Storm
fields.body:
Sick Puppy
Carl Hiaasen
Macmillan £16.99
Buy it at BOL

Boiling a Frog
Christopher Brookmyre
Little Brown £9.99
Buy it at BOL

Hot Springs
Stephen Hunter
Century £17.99
Buy it at BOL

Storm
Boris Starling
HarperCollins £5.99
Buy it at BOL

The intoxicating combination of wild humour and shocking violence in Carl Hiaasen's Florida-based novels have propelled him into the front rank of US crime-writers. His latest, Sick Puppy, is in his grand tradition: extreme eccentrics, corrupt politicians and an environmental issue mixed together to produce a powerful, page-turning, laugh-out-loud read.

Pathologically short-tempered eco-terrorist Twilly Spree is dedicated to direct action to save Florida's wilderness from the depredations of profit-oriented businesses and individuals. He also hates people who drop litter. When he sees Palmer Stoat throwing fast-food cartons out of his car on the interstate, he decides to teach him a lesson. When he discovers Stoat is a political fixer brokering deals to turn a pristine Gulf Coast island into a complex of hotels, houses and shopping malls, he decides to take things a little further.

What follows involves dognapping, bogus big-game hunting and a cast of eccentric characters that includes wealthy and semi-psychotic Spree, a prostitute who will only sleep with Republicans and Clinton 'Skink' Tyree, the state governor turned eco-warrior who lives off roadkill and is now a regular Hiaasen character.

There is something comfortingly familiar about each new Hiaasen novel in that we know pretty much what we are going to get, given that he is on a highly entertaining but nevertheless deadly serious crusade against the environmental pillagers of his native Florida. But he remains unequalled in taking humorous ideas further than you think they can possibly go. His characterisation, the inventiveness of his comic incidents and the sheer zest of his writing makes Sick Puppy a refreshing, exhilarating read.

Hiaasen is one of America's finest satirists. Christopher Brookmyre is Britain's. There's genuine anger in both of them. Sometimes a Brookmyre rant (his word) against some particularly monstrous piece of political/ social/ religious idiocy bursts out of the crime novel that nominally contains it, but the rants are usually so scabrously funny that he gets away with it.

As he does in Boiling a Frog, his fifth satirical crime novel and his third to feature Jack Parlabane, the lippy investigative journalist who gets his comeuppance with a stay in prison for breaking into the Catholic Church of Scotland's offices. It's the Catholic church that Brookmyre has in his sights - plus spin doctoring, the tabloid press, the Scottish Parliament and anything else he feels needs a good kicking.

The structure of the book is slightly unwieldy - Parlabane starts out in prison and indeed is a sort of bystander through most of it as we read an oblique account of how he ended up there. But it doesn't matter, as we're carried along by Brookmyre's humour and ability to present a lot of serious information.

In Parlabane's first two outings, the hilarious rancour was directed at the Conservative government. Doubts about whether he could survive a New Labour victory can now be laid to rest.

There's nothing subtle about Brookmyre's humour, as the title might indicate, and those who recall the calling-card he left on the mantelpiece in his debut novel, Quite Ugly One Morning (in the form of an unfeasibly large 'jobbie') will be heartened to know the plot proper kicks off with something equally gross here.

You won't get any of the appalled laughter Hiaasen and Brookmyre's work engenders from Stephen Hunter's brilliant new novel, Hot Springs. All of Hunter's work is along the solemn, but certainly not dull, lines of 'a man's gotta do what a man's gotta do'. That's Man with the initial capital, of course, so only the Homeric laughter Sam Peckinpah used in movies such as The Wild Bunch would pass muster.

Mentioning Peckinpah is apposite since Hunter, film critic for the Washington Post, writes novels that are highly cinematic and Hot Springs is redolent of several movies, including Last Man Standing, directed by Walter Hill, Peckinpah's cinematic heir.

Hot Springs is set in 1946. Earl Swagger, its central character, is an ex-marine, Congressional Medal of Honor winner and serious drinker plagued by survivor's guilt and blood-soaked memories of the Pacific War.

He feels himself beyond redemption until he is chosen to lead a team of rookie cops (cue The Untouchables) charged with bringing law and order back to the mob-controlled town of Hot Springs, Arkansas, the Las Vegas of its time. The result is an epic war between good guys and mobsters, where justice - and redemption - is achieved at the point of a Thompson sub-machine-gun.

What you might call 'adventure thrillers' are usually two-dimensional, with cardboard characters and formulaic storytelling. But there are a number of modern practitioners - they include Colin Harrison and Pinckney Benedict - who operate at a much higher level. Hunter has demonstrated in the past, especially with Dirty White Boys, that he is the best of them.

Judging by its sales, I was in a minority when I felt that Boris Starling's debut novel, Messiah, was a meretricious pick'n'mix of elements common to serial-killer novels. Now his second novel, Storm, has won the WH Smith Thumping Good Read Award and I'm still out of synch.

It's a good enough page-turner but the story, in which DCI Kate Beauchamp survives a catastrophic ferry accident, then gets involved in the pursuit of a murderer who leaves a poisonous snake on his victims as a calling card, once more seems like something out of the ABC of Serial Killers.

Sometimes a Brookmyre rant (his word) against some particularly monstrous piece of political/ social/ religious idiocy bursts out of the crime novel that nominally contains it, but the rants are usually so scabrously funny that he gets away with it. As he does in Boiling a Frog, his fifth satirical crime novel and his third to feature Jack Parlabane, the lippy investigative journalist who gets his comeuppance with a stay in prison for breaking into the Catholic Church of Scotland's offices. It's the Catholic church that Brookmyre has in his sights - plus spin doctoring, the tabloid press, the Scottish Parliament and anything else he feels needs a good kicking. The structure of the book is slightly unwieldy - Parlabane starts out in prison and indeed is a sort of bystander through most of it as we read an oblique account of how he ended up there. But it doesn't matter, as we're carried along by Brookmyre's humour and ability to present a lot of serious information. In Parlabane's first two outings, the hilarious rancour was directed at the Conservative government. Doubts about whether he could survive a New Labour victory can now be laid to rest. There's nothing subtle about Brookmyre's humour, as the title might indicate, and those who recall the calling-card he left on the mantelpiece in his debut novel, Quite Ugly One Morning (in the form of an unfeasibly large 'jobbie') will be heartened to know the plot proper kicks off with something equally gross here. You won't get any of the appalled laughter Hiaasen and Brookmyre's work engenders from Stephen Hunter's brilliant new novel, Hot Springs. All of Hunter's work is along the solemn, but certainly not dull, lines of 'a man's gotta do what a man's gotta do'. That's Man with the initial capital, of course, so only the Homeric laughter Sam Peckinpah used in movies such as The Wild Bunch would pass muster. Mentioning Peckinpah is apposite since Hunter, film critic for the Washington Post, writes novels that are highly cinematic and Hot Springs is redolent of several movies, including Last Man Standing, directed by Walter Hill, Peckinpah's cinematic heir. Hot Springs is set in 1946. Earl Swagger, its central character, is an ex-marine, Congressional Medal of Honor winner and serious drinker plagued by survivor's guilt and blood-soaked memories of the Pacific War. He feels himself beyond redemption until he is chosen to lead a team of rookie cops (cue The Untouchables) charged with bringing law and order back to the mob-controlled town of Hot Springs, Arkansas, the Las Vegas of its time. The result is an epic war between good guys and mobsters, where justice - and redemption - is achieved at the point of a Thompson sub-machine-gun. What you might call 'adventure thrillers' are usually two-dimensional, with cardboard characters and formulaic storytelling. But there are a number of modern practitioners - they include Colin Harrison and Pinckney Benedict - who operate at a much higher level. Hunter has demonstrated in the past, especially with Dirty White Boys, that he is the best of them. Judging by its sales, I was in a minority when I felt that Boris Starling's debut novel, Messiah, was a meretricious pick'n'mix of elements common to serial-killer novels. Now his second novel, Storm, has won the WH Smith Thumping Good Read Award and I'm still out of synch. It's a good enough page-turner but the story, in which DCI Kate Beauchamp survives a catastrophic ferry accident, then gets involved in the pursuit of a murderer who leaves a poisonous snake on his victims as a calling card, once more seems like something out of the ABC of Serial Killers.

webTitle: Observer review: The Justification of Johann Gutenberg by Blake Morrison

fields.headline: Medium fine. Pity about the message
fields.standfirst: Blake Morrison has done the research, but can he conjure up the father of printing in The Justification of Johann Gutenberg?
fields.trailText: Blake Morrison has done the research, but can he conjure up the father of printing in The Justification of Johann Gutenberg?
fields.body:
The Justification of Johann Gutenberg
Blake Morrison
Chatto & Windus £14.99, pp260
Buy it at BOL

In last year's endless millennial surveys of men who shook the world and inventions that revolutionised our lives, one name was on everyone's list: that of Johann Gutenberg, inventor of moveable type, and by Marshall McLuhan's famous reckoning the man most responsible for the galaxy as we know it.

Given this recent popular exhumation, and given also the post-Longitude rush towards eureka-narratives, it was all but inevitable that someone would try to write this book and attempt to put flesh on the bones of the long-dead German. In taking on the challenge, though, Morrison presented himself with a next-to-impossible act of resuscitation. His model was perhaps the poised and poetic fiction of John Banville which has breathed compelling life into Kepler and Copernicus, but he started at a great disadvantage.

Whereas the major dramas of Banville's historical heroes were reasonably well documented, allowing him to read between familiar lines, almost nothing is known of Gutenberg apart from that which is recorded in marginal references in wills and deeds and invoices - and those dry facts that are preserved do not point towards a great deal in the way of character.

In place of grid references to Gutenberg's life, Morrison has attempted to construct, from research into the social politics of the Rhineland in the fifteeenth century, something that might sound like the authentic voice of the inventor. Unfortunately, as cast here, this voice turns out to be stiffly poetic, given to melodramatic romantic asides and steeped in a kind of Victorian old English, all greenswards and nuptials.

Gutenberg tells the story of his life sequentially to a series of young scribes; it is a confessional of sorts and he holds up his autobiography as a paradigm for the larger historical shifts of the age: from superstition to secularism, craftsmanship to industry. But since the man himself never quite emerges roundly from his tale the result is too often an extended and not very dramatic monologue.

It is not that the author has shirked in his homework; this is a book freighted with research. There are little set piece inquisitions into the temper of the times: a dissection of complicated social hierarchies based on trade and the guilds; a digression about the contemporary obsession with mirrors; and caveats on fifteenth-century attitudes to gays and to marriage. There is too - and this is the best of the book - a requisite and exhaustive knowledge of early printing processes, which Gutenberg is seen working his way towards.

The problems lie more in the telling: the printer seems all too of aware of his role and as such his voice at times sounds as if it has been plucked directly from a speech bubble in a Nuffield History project: 'Mills and metal machines,' he says, typically, at one point, 'these - so I came to see - are what build our future. A man might make a tidy sum from them if he knew how...'

This kind of clumsiness of tone asks the reader to suspend disbelief to a degree which the tale itself never really warrants. Gutenberg's invention may have been world-changing, but that in itself does not make the man any more substantial or seductive.

Oddly, reading this novel, I was reminded of Tim Berners-Lee's recent Weaving the Web, in which the creator of the internet described the means by which he has eclipsed Gutenberg's galaxy. Despite its epoch-making content his was an account that came nowhere near to capturing the magic of his discovery. In this respect, I suppose, Morrison might be congratulated for reproducing the authentic literary tone of scientific genius: 99 per cent prolix, 1 per cent pedestrian.

There is, too, an irony in this, though. The really astonishing thing about Gutenberg's contribution to progress lay not in its mechanics but the way it allowed hordes of people access to worlds they hardly dreamed of, and make those worlds real in their heads. Blake Morrison, author of the candid and inspired memoir And When Did You Last See Your Father, is as aware as anyone of the ways in which the raw material of a life can be made transcendent.

Try as he might to resurrect Gutenberg here, however, the lasting impression of his book is rather of ink and paper than sweat and tears, and as a result it does not ever quite justify its billing as a novel. It is more like a handsome collection of many neat rows of type.

webTitle: Observer reviews: Patrick Robertson, The Hiding Place and Idioglossia

fields.headline: Bungle in the jungle
fields.standfirst: Being kidnapped by eco-terrorists is bad enough. But family life can be even worse. Maggie O'Farrell on Patrick Robertson, The Hiding Place and Idioglossia
fields.trailText: Being kidnapped by eco-terrorists is bad enough. But family life can be even worse. Maggie O'Farrell on Patrick Robertson, The Hiding Place and Idioglossia
fields.body:
Patrick Robertson: A Tale of Adventure
Brian Hennigan
Cape £10, pp198
Buy it at BOL

The Hiding Place
Trezza Azzopardi
Picador £14.99, pp378
Buy it at BOL

Idioglossia
Eleanor Bailey
Doubleday £16.99, pp378
Buy it at BOL

At first glance, Patrick Robertson did not bode well: the Thai adventures of a salesman sounded like something we could all live without. So imagine, if you can, my surprise when only 10 pages in I was reduced to a kind of delighted, giggly hysteria and was showing signs of extreme reluctance to be parted from it for long.

Patrick Robertson is a machine tools salesman, well-versed in the art of extracting large amounts of cash from Oriental businessmen. On a trip to Bangkok, he is ensnared and kidnapped by a group of barmy eco-terrorists who have mistaken him for the Patrick Robertson from the International Monetary Fund. By the time the mistake is discovered, they are deep in an unnavigable rainforest and if Patrick wants to live to reach closure on another sale, he will have to pull off a spectacular escape.

The book's success lies in the character of Patrick, as he lurches from one drink to another. His voice and views on everything from dealing with recalcitrant colleagues, to minibars, to taking a bath, to hotel mores are intensely readable in their warped rationality.

The text is littered with advice for living: 'Never take lucky charms from dead bodies,' he asserts. Food 'interferes with the absorption of alcohol'. 'The real strength of chopsticks is that you don't have to put them down in order to pick up your glass.' To say he is a man bereft of all morals is the understatement of the year.

He survives his ordeal by dint of being a complete asshole: he sets the eco-terrorists' other prisoners against each other so that he can escape, leaving them all with no food and water (when he discovers them later, all dead or dying, it doesn't even occur to him that he is to blame); he tricks a young balloonist into believing he has passed into the afterlife in order to steal his balloon.

If travelling sales is Patrick's religion, then the life of long-haul travel is his nirvana. When he is at his lowest ebb he rallies himself with visions of hotel 'velour curtains, padded coat-hangers and pygmy shampoo bottles'. There is moment nearing the end of the book when he finds a Gideon Bible.

'No traveller has ever received as much inspiration, taken such succour from it... All that was needed now was a hotel room to go around it.'

This book is sparky and spiky and - that very elusive thing - original. You'll be choked throughout with an almost equal mix of laughter and outrage. I just wouldn't like to meet Patrick on a dark night in the jungle.

Trezza Azzopardi is the only person I can think of with four zeds in her name; she is also an extraordinarily instinctive writer with a delicate feel for language. The narrator of The Hiding Place, Dolores, is a five-year-old girl living in a community of Maltese immigrants in Cardiff's Tiger Bay. As one of her relatives puts it: ' "This place - it's a little world, right?" he said, cupping his hands together as if he had captured a moth.'

Her father is the feckless Frankie Gauci who came to seek his fortune but found instead a wife, a taste for gambling and a dangerously close-knit ghetto run by the Maltese mafia. He is given the nickname Frankie Bambina because of his failure to sire a son and on the night Dolores, his sixth daughter, is born, he loses his house and his business at the card table. The mother has to hide the baby in chest: ' "He would've smothered you, she said".' The Hiding Place has been compared with the work of Frank McCourt and Andrea Ashworth and it is not hard to see why. But Azzopardi's book is fiction and it has a certain poise and cohesion of theme that cannot be achieved in memoir.

The most startling and lyrical passage is the description of how Dolores was burnt as a baby. Her 'right hand is fine' but on her left she 'lost the fingers. At one month old, a baby's hand is the tiniest, most perfect thing... that soft skin is petrol, those bones are tinder, so small, so easily eaten in a flame.' She thinks of it as 'a closed white tulip standing in the rain'; her father, however, refers to her as 'La Sinistra'.

The fire is the point of no return for the Gaucis. Fire and skin become unavoidable and dangerous elements in their lives: Fran, sister number four, becomes a pyromaniac; the sisters subject each other to primitive tattoos with knives and needles; the eldest sister's patent boots melt and ruin beside a gas fire while she struggles against the enforced attentions of her boss; it is the children's skin that is marked and flayed by the belt of the father.

One by one the sisters disappear from the family - Fran into care, Celesta into marriage with a balding businessman in return for favours and, most shockingly, Marina is sold to the mafia head to clear the father's debts. Azzopardi has written a scalding, thrilling book about the havoc and despair it is possible to wreak inside a family; but also how the bonds formed within it cannot be destroyed by violence, poverty, time, fire - anything.

Eleanor Bailey addresses similar themes in her debut, Idioglossia, a novel about the interlocking lives of four generations of women, all pulling in different directions.

Great Edie is an eccentric immigrant whose progeny don't share her colourful self-assurance: Grace, her daughter, is a schizophrenic who spends her life in asylums. Maggie, Grace's daughter, is torn between trying to persuade Great Edie into the bath, looking after a mystifying and barely conscious mother, and keeping an eye on her fragile daughter, Sarah, who is given to packing in her jobs and random sex with strangers.

It's a complex story with satisfyingly diverse characters, all of whom are blighted by secrets sealed up in the past: cleaning and the desire to clear away debris, actual or imagined, is something they all do at some point in the book. Great Edie was my favourite. I liked the Gothic awfulness of her refusal to wash, her staggeringly foul-mouthed insults, her insanitary house, and her wild psychic predictions.

webTitle: Observer review: The Far Side of a Kiss by Anne Haverty

fields.headline: Give them enough grope...
fields.standfirst: Anne Haverty can only summon up a pale shadow of the great William Hazlitt in her lazy bodice ripper, The Far Side of a Kiss
fields.trailText: Anne Haverty can only summon up a pale shadow of the great William Hazlitt in her lazy bodice ripper, The Far Side of a Kiss
fields.body:
The Far Side of a Kiss
Anne Haverty
Chatto & Windus £12.99, pp241
Buy it at BOL

The Far Side of a Kiss, the second novel by Irish author Anne Haverty, is costume drama in a state of salacious undress. William Hazlitt, Romantic critic and personality, once fell in love with a maid and then wrote an account of it, published in 1824, called Liber Amoris.

The Far Side of a Kiss takes up this gossip's morsel and offers the other side of the story, as told by Sarah, the maid. In a relentless trial by tedium, the reader is treated to all of Sarah's fancies and anxieties, all her faux moralising and self-serving strategising.

The effect is rather like being stuck in a sealed box with a linguistically impoverished version of Richardson's heroine Pamela (or, more accurately, Fielding's skit, Shamela). And where Pamela merely promises, Sarah shows all.

This is a novel absolutely littered with grabbings and peckings, a gruesome array of nudges, winks, bum-taps and breast-pokes and, finally, a rape scene described in tones of triumphant gothic melodrama.

This is all happening in the early decades of the nineteenth century, a fact which Haverty makes clear to us by having her characters describe past actions with 'he is come' and 'he is done' and inverting verbs after 'thus' -'Thus are all men used to talking of their wives' etc.

A few other period touches are added by Sarah's rather surprising knowledge of the personal lives of the literary figures of the age: 'Mr Lamb must indeed be the kindest of men, but among the most foolish too, for he keeps his sister, who went mad and killed their mother, loose in his house'; 'Mr Keats was a poor sick fellow gone off to Italy for the good of his health.'

The real-life Hazlitt was arguably possessed of one of the most agile and promiscuous minds of the age. Nevertheless, in Haverty's world, he confines himself to two modest obsessions: the game of fives, from which Hazlitt seems (qua the football-mad lads of recent years) unable to desist, and a delirious and clearly excessive consumption of tea. This seems a poor show, from the writer, critic, Coleridge-trouncer, mesmerising polemicist and scourge of the age.

If Hazlitt's written words are anything to go by, he was prone to sparkling pronouncements such as: 'Mr Wordsworth's genius is a pure emanation of the Spirit of the Age' or: 'We have said that Lord Byron is a sublime coxcomb; why should we not say that Mr [Leigh] Hunt is a delightful one?' Whether he downed his lexical rifles in conversation with maids is not known.

However, it seems unlikely that, even in a moment of overwhelming tenderness, Hazlitt would have cajoled his maid to 'let me see if your bubbies have grown'. Or that he would, upon proposing marriage to her, have fallen into the sort of 'half-laughter, half-crying' more usually seen on The Royle Family, 'declaring he was happy fit to burst'.

There is certainly no such hatefulness in Liber Amoris, which lurches chaotically between letter, dialogue and epigram, spanning wild arcs from fantastical ecstasy to dwindling melancholy. The Hazlitt of Liber Amoris, though self-indulgent, ravenous and selfish, is constantly multi-faceted and fascinating. He lies on his back all day, thinking of Sarah. He fears he is 'falling into a pit, without a hand to help me'. The hysteria passio comes upon him, hurling him towards lunacy; he infuriates his acquaintance by dwelling minutely on all Sarah's whispers and touches.

Haverty's loose, idle book misses the main joy of Liber Amoris, which is the many-mooded nature of Hazlitt's obsession and the many-sided nature of Hazlitt himself. Instead, she makes him an ahistorical, whingeing, old lecher, grabbing and pinching, salivating and beseeching, babbling his protestations in a hybrid babble of mock-archaism and lewd grotesquerie.

The combination of a mercilessly one-dimensional Hazlitt and a mercilessly archetyped age makes for a filthy, pseudo-historical misfire, a novel which relies on the mere mention of a famous literary character to secure its credentials as 'serious' or, equally mendaciously, plays the 'previously silenced female speaks' card to ensure a splash at Silver Moon.

This is a tale which sticks relentlessly to an age-old draw - the bodice unbuttoned.

Or that he would, upon proposing marriage to her, have fallen into the sort of 'half-laughter, half-crying' more usually seen on The Royle Family, 'declaring he was happy fit to burst'. There is certainly no such hatefulness in Liber Amoris, which lurches chaotically between letter, dialogue and epigram, spanning wild arcs from fantastical ecstasy to dwindling melancholy. The Hazlitt of Liber Amoris, though self-indulgent, ravenous and selfish, is constantly multi-faceted and fascinating. He lies on his back all day, thinking of Sarah. He fears he is 'falling into a pit, without a hand to help me'. The hysteria passio comes upon him, hurling him towards lunacy; he infuriates his acquaintance by dwelling minutely on all Sarah's whispers and touches. Haverty's loose, idle book misses the main joy of Liber Amoris, which is the many-mooded nature of Hazlitt's obsession and the many-sided nature of Hazlitt himself. Instead, she makes him an ahistorical, whingeing, old lecher, grabbing and pinching, salivating and beseeching, babbling his protestations in a hybrid babble of mock-archaism and lewd grotesquerie. The combination of a mercilessly one-dimensional Hazlitt and a mercilessly archetyped age makes for a filthy, pseudo-historical misfire, a novel which relies on the mere mention of a famous literary character to secure its credentials as 'serious' or, equally mendaciously, plays the 'previously silenced female speaks' card to ensure a splash at Silver Moon. This is a tale which sticks relentlessly to an age-old draw - the bodice unbuttoned.

webTitle: Observer review: How to Read and Why by Harold Bloom

fields.headline: The crack of Bloom
fields.standfirst: Terry Eagleton detects a whiff of desperation behind the heroism in Harold Bloom's How to Read and Why
fields.trailText: Terry Eagleton detects a whiff of desperation behind the heroism in Harold Bloom's How to Read and Why
fields.body:
How to Read and Why
Harold Bloom
Fourth Estate £15.99, pp283
Buy it at BOL

Harold Bloom was once an interesting critic. In the 1970s, he developed an extravagant theory of literary creation for which all authors were locked in Oedipal combat with some mighty predecessor. Literature was the upshot of rivalry and resentment, as poets beset by what Bloom called the 'anxiety of influence' sought to triumph over some 'strong' precursor by rewriting his or her text as their own. All literary works were a kind of plagiarism, a creative misreading of earlier efforts. Wordsworth tried to kill off Milton and Shelley had it in for Shakespeare. The meaning of a poem was another poem.

This theory, as Henry Fielding observed of the belief that the good will get their reward in this world, had only one drawback, namely that it was not true. But it was original, audacious and exciting and a spot of wild implausibility did it no harm at all. It was also remarkably cunning. What it did was to blend a traditional idea of literature with a modern one, thus winning itself the best of both worlds.

Literature was still a matter of great traditions and lonely giants bestriding history, as it had been for early Oxbridge aesthetes like Sir Arthur Quiller-Couch; but these mighty patriarchs were now pitched into a very Freudian antagonism. Bloom was an embattled Romantic, speaking up for genius, inspiration and the creative imagination in a cynically postmodern world.

Yet the message would get through to that world only if it was given a suitably bleak, up-to-date twist. You still had literary heroes, masters and disciples; it was just that what they did now was deconstruct each other.

Then, as now, Bloom was deeply scornful of historical criticism. Great writers needed no historical context any more than a gentleman needed to buy in his own marmalade. But it was always clear how socially conditioned Bloom's criticism was. These poetic warriors locked in virile combat were good old American entrepreneurs in literary clothing, Davy Crocketts and Donald Trumps of the spirit who shaped the world to their imperious will.

Bloom spoke up for universal humanity in a New York accent. Poetry had become a kind of Wall Street of the soul, full of pushy young brokers intent on sweeping the old guard into the gutter.

Bloom's rage against material limit, his pioneering belief in the indomitable will, was as American as cherry pie. It was just that he mistook this for some universal truth.

The critical wheel, however, has come full circle. Aghast at the theoretical excesses to which he so robustly contributed, Bloom, on the threshold of his seventieth birthday, has reverted to the quote-and-dote school of criticism. Indeed, he has fallen back to a level of critical banality which might even have embarrassed Quiller-Couch.

How to Read and Why takes us on a Cook's tour of some of its author's favourite poems, plays and novels, boring the reader with plodding plot summaries or ludicrously long quotations and then adding a few amateurish, undemanding comments. Thus, Maupassant is 'marvellously readable', the pleasures of great poetry are 'many and varied', while 'Shelley and Keats were very different poets, and were not quite friends'.

We are exhorted to chant a particular poem out loud repeatedly, and advised in an arresting flash of moral insight that 'in Raskolnikov's Petersburg, as in Macbeth's bewitched Scotland, we, too, might commit murders'. We are also instructed that 'irony broadly means saying one thing and meaning another' and is much to be commended, though this portentously self-important book would collapse at the faintest whiff of it.

It would be charitable to think that Bloom writes as slackly and cack-handedly as he does because he is out to attract the general reader. He is admirably intent on rescuing literature from the arcane rituals of US academia and restoring it to a wider audience. Even so, you cannot help suspecting that this rambling, platitudinous stuff is about the best he can now muster. As with all his work, a certain desperation runs beneath the heroism. Literature is the last surviving source of value in a degraded world, the only antidote to an academia obsessed with cross-dressing and multiculturalism.

Bloom is right to criticise US academia as sexually obsessed; but if literature is all that stands between us and suicide, then we might as well commit suicide.

Bloom comments after a reading of Browning's poem 'Childe Roland' that 'we have renewed and augmented the self, despite its despair, and its suicidal courting of failure'. Reading is a kind of confidence-boosting or spiritual muscle-building, a familiar enough American fetish from a man who claims to detest ideology.

His criticism is all about the success ethic and the terrors of being a loser. 'The creator of Sir John Falstaff, of Hamlet, and of Rosalind,' he tells us, 'also makes me wish I could be more myself.' There are those malicious souls for whom Bloom is quite enough himself without there being even more of him, but the notion of reading as a kind of self-entrepreneurship is plain enough.

Why does Bloom need to augment the self? 'We read,' he suggests, 'not only because we cannot know enough people, but because friendship is so vulnerable, so likely to diminish or disappear, overcome by space, time, imperfect sympathies and all the sorrows of familial and passional life.' It sounds as though Harold is a bit short of mates and reads to make up for it. Perhaps he alienates them by his repeated chanting of excessively long poems.

But there are other reasons for reading besides 'alleviating loneliness'. If there is Bloom the self-therapist, there is also Bloom the American TV evangelist, full of windy moralistic rhetoric about how to 'apprehend and recognise the possibility of the good, help it to endure, give it space in your life'.

Bloom may idolise Shakespeare with all the sticky sentiment of a teenage groupie, but his own language can be as cheap and threadbare as Jimmy Swaggart's. This book provides us with a number of reasons to read great literature, but none at all to read Harold Bloom.

fields.headline: McManaman hope
fields.trailText: Steve McManaman has been included in the squad for two of Real Madrid's pre-season friendlies and is also expected to travel to Monaco for Friday's European Supercup against Galatasaray.
fields.body:
Steve McManaman has been included in the squad for two of Real Madrid's pre-season friendlies and is also expected to travel to Monaco for Friday's European Supercup against Galatasaray.

The out-of-favour England international, who has not featured in any of the European champions' close season warm-up matches, was named in a squad of 25 announced by coach Vicente del Bosque.

The Real coach made it clear that the line-ups for warm-up games against Murcia and Naples will form the basis of the party for the Supercup game.

Del Bosque has told McManaman that he would have few chances of first team football in the coming season, but the attacking midfielder has made it clear he intends to fight for his place. McManaman turned in a string of fine performances in last season's victorious Champions League campaign, but has found himself pushed to the margins following an expansive summer signing spree by Real, which included the capture of Luis Figo from Barcelona for a world-record fee.

'We have been clear with the player about his chances of playing,' Del Bosque said. 'However, Real has to give a good image and behave in a gentlemanly way. We don't want to mess the player around.'

McManaman's inclusion is believed to be a reward for his enthusiasm and general conduct during the club's pre-season training programme.

Del Bosque has said that he will register the former Liverpool player in the squad for the Spanish league season if he remains at the club.

*****

AS Roma's new Brazilian signing, Emerson, will be sidelined for six months after tearing cruciate ligaments in his left knee, Italian media reported on Saturday.

The former Middlesbrough player, who joined the Serie A side from Bayer Leverkusen last month for a Bundesliga record 36 billion lire, fell awkwardly during a training session in Rome on Friday.

He faced an operation over the weekend, according to the Italian daily newspaper, Gazzetta dello Sport.

*****

Rivaldo has expressed his relief at being omitted from Brazil's football squad for next month's Olympics.

'Going to Sydney wouldn't have been good either for me or for Barcelona,' said Rivaldo. 'It would have been difficult to go the Olympics because people here would have criticised me.'

It has also been reported that Barcelona have recently improved Rivaldo's contract, making him the world's highest paid player.

An agreement between the Catalan club and the Brazilian Football Federation means that the world and European player of the year will now be able to begin the new season with his club.

In return, Rivaldo will be expected to attend Brazil's training camp on 28 August prior to their next South American World Cup qualifier, against Bolivia.

webTitle: Observer review: The Piano Shop on the Left Bank by TE Carhart

fields.headline: The ebony and the ecstasy
fields.standfirst: TE Carhart weaves the story of his search for a new instrument into a history of the piano in The Piano Shop on the Left Bank
fields.trailText: TE Carhart weaves the story of his search for a new instrument into a history of the piano in The Piano Shop on the Left Bank
fields.body:
The Piano Shop on the Left Bank
TE Carhart
Chatto & Windus £15.99, pp242
Buy it at BOL

The narrow cobbled ruelles that lattice the Left Bank of the Seine conceal all kinds of treasures which the tourist, breezing past with map and Rough Guide, would never know existed; half-hidden bookshops, cluttered galleries of maps and paintings, artists' and musicians' studios, or workshops crafting anything from furniture to pianos.

It was the latter that American writer TE Carhart stumbled upon almost by accident, intrigued by the unassuming shop front he passed every day that read simply ' Desforges Pianos: outillage, fournitures'. Venturing tentatively into the dingy little shop heaped with piano wire and swathes of felt, he inquired whether he might buy a used piano and received a polite but cryptic rebuff from the old man who appeared from a mysterious door at the back.

Undeterred, Carhart returned again and again to the shop and eventually, after securing a masonic introduction from one of Desforges's clients, he was allowed through the back door into an Aladdin's Cave of disembowelled pianos that had found their way from all over Europe to this vast, hidden atelier.

Carhart's book is the story of his relationship with Luc, the piano restorer whose craftsmanship and love for his instruments seems to belong to another century, and with the curious assortment of people who, like initiates of a secret cult, are allowed into Luc's workshop to share their passion for the beautiful piano - some valuable antiques - that he nurses back to health.

The book unfolds slowly, so that you may wonder after the first chapter whether Luc and his atelier can provide enough material to furnish an entire book - after all, there are only so many ways to describe dusty sunlight falling on rich mahogany - but Carhart uses the piano shop as a starting place for several strands of story in alternating chapters. Remembering his childhood in Paris, he returns to his first relationship with the piano and switches back and forth between these childhood anecdotes and the renewed passion for the instrument that Luc's pianos inspire.

Luc finds him a baby grand, a plucky little Stingl that is both bigger and more expensive than the author had planned, but Carhart immediately finds himself captivated by the sensual pleasures of a beautifully made instrument: 'Good God, I thought, this is a kind of love; and, as in love, my senses amplified and enhanced the love object, all with an insouciance and willing enthusiasm.'

But he has already learned Luc's distaste for people who treat pianos like an exquisite piece of furniture to display their wealth and taste (' "They might as well park a Mercedes at the end of their grands salons," he would rail'), and determines to take up lessons again so as to be worthy of his new possession.

Between these personal stories lies perhaps the most fascinating part of the book - a potted history of the piano from its origins to its heyday in the mid- to late-nineteenth century, and of the composers whose music developed alongside the technical advances of the instrument.

In 1774 Voltaire wrote 'Le pianoforte est un instrument de chaudronnier en comparaison du clavecin' ('The piano is a boilermaker's instrument compared with the harpsichord'), but only three years later Mozart was enthusing about the new instruments, though the Viennese-made pianos on which he and Haydn composed were small and delicate and not unlike the harpsichord. Beethoven was known to destroy them with the ferocity of his playing, until the English manufacturers of the early nineteenth century began to produce more robust models, such as the Broadwood on which he composed his most dramatic piano sonata, the Hammerklavier.

This is a gentle, meandering book, a collage of images, memories and history, and at times Carhart's effort to stuff these miscellaneous elements into a narrative feels a little strained. But the book is rich with understated evocations of Paris; Carhart has an eye for the salient detail that will conjure a person or a street vividly without tripping up in overwrought description.

He also writes with enthusiasm about the individual instruments he encounters, with a habit evidently learned from Luc of viewing each instrument as a living creature with its own personality, and his delight in the look and feel of a piano - the sheen of different woods, the curvature of the ivory keys - translates easily into prose.

Perhaps the best recommendation of his book is that it makes you want to reach immediately for Beethoven, Chopin, Mozart, Bach, Scarlatti and the other composers whose names litter the book; if his aim was to inspire in his readers a renewed love for the music, he has succeeded admirably.

webTitle: Shock! Horror! Men aren't always wrong

fields.headline: Shock! Horror! Men aren't always wrong
fields.trailText: I went to a wedding recently. The most remarkable thing about it was the high level of emotion between the couple. It seemed almost anachronistic to see two people getting married simply because they adored each other.
fields.body:
I went to a wedding recently. The most remarkable thing about it was the high level of emotion between the couple. It seemed almost anachronistic to see two people getting married simply because they adored each other. The bride didn't frisk the groom at the altar for his CV. The groom didn't insist on a chat with the bride's bank manager before signing the register. Nobody stood up at the reception to make tearful speeches about how nice it was to see two such financially compatible people embark on life's journey together. Sipping our champagne, the better informed among us could only wonder at the couple's astounding socioeconomic naivety. They kept speaking of something called... 'love'.

I jest, of course, but, should I ever decide to use a dating agency, I'd better get my act together, and not go on about being 'fun' and 'romantic', or anything socially undesirable like that. One in five people are turning to dating agencies to help them find a partner, and that figure is destined to double over the next five years. Women are leading the way, but men should be aware that they're no longer going to be content with a GSOH, and a cellophaned red rose from a street vendor. The biggest growth area is in the kind of dating agency which caters solely for 'successful professionals'. They mean 'rich', or at least 'richer than you'. It's a form of romantic apartheid, which, apparently, is just how successful professional ladies like it.

An extensive new study involving two million people, and 700 dating agencies, has revealed that, for the career-oriented modern woman, time is at a premium. According to the director of the study, Professor Richard Scase, '[Women] look at relationships in a very contractual way. They assess a person as you would test-drive a car.' On the positive side, this means that the post-Bridget Jones generation are proactive go-getters, unafraid to give men a taste of their own sexist objectifying medicine, and refusing to chow down with the kind of bozos who disappear when the restaurant bill arrives. A more negative slant would surmise that a new breed of female gold-digger seems to have emerged - the Designer Mercenary, for whom empire-building is everything, and love, lust and fun are just more things to put on the Amex.

Power-coupledom has always been around - you only have to read Jane Austen to realise that there's nothing new about the 'good match'. However, in this day and age, it seems a bit feeble of women to go in for what is essentially a form of socioeconomic inbreeding. While it's true that men use these dating agencies, too, let's face it, they'd probably sign up for anything where there's a possibility of sex. And even that seems thrillingly romantic compared to the flint-hearted way women are sizing up men these days. My bet is that, over the next decade, the variably incomed couple will replace the racially mixed couple in terms of rarity, and the rich woman-poor man combo will become the rarest of all. So, who's being the 'bastard' now?

You wonder how it started, and whether the more cynical episodes of Sex and the City should be rationed from now on. In defence of Designer Mercenaries, women, particularly thirtysomethings, have suffered some grievous setbacks in recent years. Men who, previously, would have been 'eligible' have been dodging the nets, like so many beer-swilling butterflies. They seem to prefer stuff like sex, fun and autonomy, instead of doing the decent thing, and giving us flash rings, buying us big houses, siring our children exactly when we say, and pretty much doing everything else we demand. Outrageous. Men also seem to have some strange fascination with much younger women who look just as nice, but don't nag, complain, and try to march them up the aisle with a gun to their head. Truly mystifying. Then again, maybe it isn't really.

I don't like to be a gender traitor about this, and believe me, I've racked my brains to figure out a way where it could be All Men's Fault. However, just this once, it isn't. It could even be argued that, by being so mercenary, and waving their list of self-serving demands, thirtysomething women are in danger of pricing themselves out of the market. Women are wonderful, but we come in all age groups, and the men who are also wonderful, the 'best catches' if you like, seem to have developed a noted preference for the age group that still knows how to have a laugh. They also get mysteriously attached to women who actually like them, instead of liking what they can do for them. Even more mysteriously, these are the women they marry.

Bearing this in mind, it would seem that the 'professionally successful' female opportunist can scheme through 'romantic lunches' all she likes, but only another social climbing desperado would ever fall for it. Modern man, 'professionally successful' or otherwise, seems to have got the Designer Mercenary's number. And not in a good phoning-her-up way.

barbara.ellen@observer.co.uk
fields.bodyText: I went to a wedding recently. The most remarkable thing about it was the high level of emotion between the couple. It seemed almost anachronistic to see two people getting married simply because they adored each other. The bride didn't frisk the groom at the altar for his CV. The groom didn't insist on a chat with the bride's bank manager before signing the register. Nobody stood up at the reception to make tearful speeches about how nice it was to see two such financially compatible people embark on life's journey together. Sipping our champagne, the better informed among us could only wonder at the couple's astounding socioeconomic naivety. They kept speaking of something called... 'love'. I jest, of course, but, should I ever decide to use a dating agency, I'd better get my act together, and not go on about being 'fun' and 'romantic', or anything socially undesirable like that. One in five people are turning to dating agencies to help them find a partner, and that figure is destined to double over the next five years. Women are leading the way, but men should be aware that they're no longer going to be content with a GSOH, and a cellophaned red rose from a street vendor. The biggest growth area is in the kind of dating agency which caters solely for 'successful professionals'. They mean 'rich', or at least 'richer than you'. It's a form of romantic apartheid, which, apparently, is just how successful professional ladies like it. An extensive new study involving two million people, and 700 dating agencies, has revealed that, for the career-oriented modern woman, time is at a premium. According to the director of the study, Professor Richard Scase, '[Women] look at relationships in a very contractual way. They assess a person as you would test-drive a car.' On the positive side, this means that the post-Bridget Jones generation are proactive go-getters, unafraid to give men a taste of their own sexist objectifying medicine, and refusing to chow down with the kind of bozos who disappear when the restaurant bill arrives. A more negative slant would surmise that a new breed of female gold-digger seems to have emerged - the Designer Mercenary, for whom empire-building is everything, and love, lust and fun are just more things to put on the Amex. Power-coupledom has always been around - you only have to read Jane Austen to realise that there's nothing new about the 'good match'. However, in this day and age, it seems a bit feeble of women to go in for what is essentially a form of socioeconomic inbreeding. While it's true that men use these dating agencies, too, let's face it, they'd probably sign up for anything where there's a possibility of sex. And even that seems thrillingly romantic compared to the flint-hearted way women are sizing up men these days. My bet is that, over the next decade, the variably incomed couple will replace the racially mixed couple in terms of rarity, and the rich woman-poor man combo will become the rarest of all. So, who's being the 'bastard' now? You wonder how it started, and whether the more cynical episodes of Sex and the City should be rationed from now on. In defence of Designer Mercenaries, women, particularly thirtysomethings, have suffered some grievous setbacks in recent years. Men who, previously, would have been 'eligible' have been dodging the nets, like so many beer-swilling butterflies. They seem to prefer stuff like sex, fun and autonomy, instead of doing the decent thing, and giving us flash rings, buying us big houses, siring our children exactly when we say, and pretty much doing everything else we demand. Outrageous. Men also seem to have some strange fascination with much younger women who look just as nice, but don't nag, complain, and try to march them up the aisle with a gun to their head. Truly mystifying. Then again, maybe it isn't really. I don't like to be a gender traitor about this, and believe me, I've racked my brains to figure out a way where it could be All Men's Fault. However, just this once, it isn't. It could even be argued that, by being so mercenary, and waving their list of self-serving demands, thirtysomething women are in danger of pricing themselves out of the market. Women are wonderful, but we come in all age groups, and the men who are also wonderful, the 'best catches' if you like, seem to have developed a noted preference for the age group that still knows how to have a laugh. They also get mysteriously attached to women who actually like them, instead of liking what they can do for them. Even more mysteriously, these are the women they marry. webTitle: Comment, Will Hutton: Faith in the moral choices of science

fields.headline: Losing the way of Winning
fields.standfirst:
Where once we were ruled by moral absolutes enforced by established religions, writes Will Hutton, our increasingly secular society places more faith in the moral choices that science offers

Special report: religion in the UK
fields.trailText: Where once we were ruled by moral absolutes enforced by established religions our increasingly secular society places more faith in the moral choices that science offers
fields.body:
Their spires grace almost every community in these islands. Enter any church, a place of worship and reflection, and the calm beguiles you. By this token, Britain remains a society firmly anchored in religion - Christianity, the native and majority faith, is now just one of a number of faith communities which together provide our moral and religious glue.

But the term faith communities gives the game away. Religions as proud as Christianity or Islam do not see themselves as but one of a number of 'faith communities'. Integral to their belief system is the claim that it is by adherence to their codes and systems of worship - and only by such adherence - that the route to happiness and salvation after death can be achieved.

And here is the contemporary paradox, the ultimate secularising conclusion of religious toleration. Religions today must respect each other's claim to exist and even recognise each other's underlying morality, but to do so is to surrender the claim that they offer the one true path.

Yet the instant any religion acknowledges that God takes more than one form, it concedes that there is more than one guardian of the true flame and thus, by inference, that there are moral choices rather than moral absolutes.

Thus, when the ethical and moral balloon goes up, as it did last week over the Government's willingness to allow a free House of Commons vote over the cloning of embryos under 14 days old, the pass has already been thrown. No religion can now claim to teach absolute moral certainties.

So, when Scotland's Cardinal Winning and the Vatican thunder that obtaining stem cells from embryos for research is morally wrong because it infringes the sacredness of human life, a sacredness conferred by scripture, they speak from a position that has already conceded its relativism.

The Roman Catholic church has tried to hold an absolutist position over the right to life across the body of its doctrine, famously ruling against contraception, but it has lost the fight. It has been reduced to but one faith community that necessarily respects others, a humbler position in the moral universe and which is, paradoxically, founded in the same humanism that lies at the core of science's case to extend the scope of its research.

For the trajectory of Roman Catholicism being the moral authority that underpinned every aspect of society - from the monarch' s divine right to rule to the rules over divorce - to its current standing alongside the Church of England and Islam as another faith community exactly mirrors the rise of science and its humanistic project to extend man's power over nature.

The terrible religious wars of the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries, which still have their echoes in Northern Ireland and Yugoslavia, so obviously breached every religious principle that the solution had to be toleration. The great constitutional settlements in Great Britain (1689), the United States (1789) and France (1793) that, in different contexts, placed the people rather than divinely mandated monarchs as the source of government legitimacy, necessarily enthroned religious toleration as a constitutional right. And intertwined with this rise of democracy and humanist rationalism came the associated right to explore freely the insights of science.

Over the last 50 years, the scientifically led breaches in the walls of the old, religiously protected system of morality are legion - and for the same fundamental reason. We are all humanists now. The free vote in the House of Commons will be won and the recommendations of Liam Donaldson, the chief medical officer, followed, for the same reasons that the battles over the Pill, abortion, in vitro fertilisation, the human genome and all the rest have been won.

The moral imperative in a humanist, secular age is to improve the human condition in the here and now; nor can there be any legitimate constraint on permitting scientists to follow where their ingenuity and logic leads them. The doctrine of constraining science because it might endanger the primacy of Christian morality began to collapse when the church tried to ban Galileo exploring the governing laws of the stars.

In short, religion has been losing the battle against science, humanism and the march of the rational for more than 300 years - and it will not triumph in the argument over stem-cell research. That does not mean there are not fundamental moral questions raised by where science is leading, but religion is not going to be able to provide the answers. We have to find the answers ourselves.

And the flurry of commissions and reports across the West, ranging from the Nuffield Council of Bioethics to President Clinton's council, established in the wake of the cloning of Dolly the sheep, all try to do just that. The Nuffield Council, for example, in a report that influenced the Donaldson inquiry, argued that as the embryos from which the key stem cells are gathered were never destined to become human beings and if the donor egg were freely given, then the potential scientific gains are so enormous that the research must be permitted.

If stem cells can be harvested and they subsequently migrate to parts of the body suffering from degenerative cellular disorders - from Parkinson's disease to cancer - and are then provoked to reverse the degeneration, then medicine makes a gigantic advance. To obstruct this research is to prolong unnecessary suffering - and to protect a worldview to which not even its proponents wholly subscribe.

This does not mean that research has no limit. The cloning of humans, with its associated overtones of eugenics, horrifies everyone, which is why all those who have looked into the cloning issue are careful to distinguish between research into cellular structures derived from cells that could never have become humans and those which could.

To insist that there is no practical dividing line, as religious absolutists do, is to make a profound error; it is to imagine that religion has a status which it no longer has. The religious Right in general and the Roman Catholic church in particular obviously believe that this is an issue on which they have to make a stand - and where they will find popular support. They are wrong.

It is true that we are decoupled from old certainties and would love to create some moral anchors like our ancestors possessed, hence the growing interest in environmentalism, natural remedies and new-age fads.

But we are damned by our knowledge and the frontiers that science opens up as it continues the quest to explore and control nature. At the same time, we are making our own ethical judgments as we progress. We are human beings. We can do no other.

This is not a crisis for science. It is a crisis for religion, whose moral impotence before the march of the rational is again so cruelly exposed.
