webTitle: The electric chair Gore should fear

fields.headline: The electric chair Gore should fear
fields.standfirst: Normally laid-back Californians are in revolt over power deregulation, and it could sway the US elections
fields.trailText: Normally laid-back Californians are in revolt over power deregulation, and it could sway the US elections
fields.body:
While reporters this week wasted their papers' budgets in Los Angeles covering the shadow puppetry called the Democratic Convention, America's political future was being decided 80 miles south, in San Diego.

Here, where a bilious tumble of freeways, McDonald's and Wal-Marts smashes up against the Mexican border, San Diego's 2.6 million residents have been involuntarily enrolled as laboratory rats in a scary economic experiment. Just weeks ago, San Diego became the first city in America to end the regulation of electricity prices.

When California's state senate voted to bring the miracle of market competition to electricity, they wrote right into the law that domestic prices would fall by 'at least 20 per cent'. No points for guessing what happened. The price for energy rose by 379 per cent compared with last year.

Actually, Californians were lucky. I located Beth Emory, former counsel for the agency that runs the daily power auction. She said that on the first hot summer day, when California needed every bit of juice it could find, generating companies bid in their electricity at $9,999 per unit. This was 1,000 times the formerly controlled price of $10.

But San Diegans were fortunate. In their greed-crazed rush, the sellers assumed the system's computers could only handle four-digit bids. In fact, the computers would have accepted seven figures, taking bids high enough to bankrupt half the families in the state in one day.

I have been able to trace San Diego's economic plague to the original carrier: one Daniel Fessler. Fessler, the Golden State's former chief utility regulator, flew to England some years ago and carried back with him an infatuation with Margaret Thatcher's economic theorems and an unnatural affection for her troubled offspring, the England and Wales Power Pool.

The Pool, at around 4pm or so each day, is seized by a clique of electricity companies which crank up prices by as much as 2,000 per cent. Even Britain's somnolent regulators have twigged to the fact that this supposed free-market auction house is, as Ofgem recently reported, a playground for price-fixing and collusion.

One suspects California's politicos knew this. After all, the majority of Britain's electricity system is owned by the same US operators that have San Diego by the bulbs, including Enron (Houston), Edison International (Los Angeles), PPL and Southern Company (Atlanta). This week, the last pair took over Hyder, Wales's water and power utility.

But something extraordinary has happened in San Diego. Laid-back Californians have leapt off their surfboards and are waving two fingers in the air and chanting 'Boycott!'

The electricity companies can send out their bloated bills, but the tanned masses are not going to pay. By the thousands and now, apparently, by the tens of thousands, customers have simply continued to pay only the old, lower, prices.

Joining the boycott this week: the city's school system, the Council of Churches and even, without a hint of shame, the state senator who sponsored the original deregulation law.

In Bolivia, when British-American, owner of the city of Cochabamba's utility, hiked prices and customers boycotted bill payments, the government confronted protesters with bullets and martial law.

But in California, protesters were met by panicked politicians. The leftish governor of California, Democrat Gray Davis, drafted an emergency law to knock back prices retroactively by 60 per cent. The state's utility regulators effectively endorsed the revolt by barring San Diego Gas and Electric from cutting off service to customers who refuse payments through October (up to election day).

The Governor has launched an investigation into market manipulation. According to consumer advocate Mike Florio, a member of the power system's oversight panel, the governor won't have far to look. There is 'stacking and cramming' (tricks learned in the UK) plus false scheduling and transmission line games that have cost San Diego about $304 million this summer.

On one day, for example, an Enron trader sold the state about 500 megawatts of power to go over a 15 mw line, which is like pouring a gallon of gasoline into a thimble. This forced the system operators to make costly emergency purchases, blowing market prices through the roof.

The power pirates are stunned by the public revolt. After all, though San Diego prices have skyrocketed to about 10p per kilowatt hour, this is no more than US power companies typically charge their British customers - who endure the fleecing with a stoic shrug.

So what has got the beach bunnies up in arms? Amer ica's little secret is that the New World Order of free markets and deregulation is for export only. America has always expected that, within its borders, the public, through state power, should squeeze down the prices and profits of monopoly service companies.

The city of Los Angeles owns its own electricity and water system and virtually gives the stuff away. Good. We don't have to put up with World Bank dicta for privatisation and market pricing designed, as we Angelenos say, for the rest of you schmucks.

webTitle: Russia's once-feared Northern Fleet lies rusting and radioactive

fields.headline: Once-feared fleet lies rusting and radioactive
fields.standfirst: The pride of the Soviet navy is a shell of its former self, reports  Jason Burke
fields.trailText: For 50 years the Northern Fleet was the pride of the USSR. From secret ports along Russia's Arctic coast, the iron ships ruled the steel-grey waves with a mailed fist. Beneath the waters, a formidable submarine fleet, diesel and then nuclear powered, chased intruding Americans away. Now the fleet is a shadow of its former self. It poses a greater threat to the environment than the West.
fields.body:
For 50 years the Northern Fleet was the pride of the USSR. From secret ports along Russia's Arctic coast, the iron ships ruled the steel-grey waves with a mailed fist. Beneath the waters, a formidable submarine fleet, diesel and then nuclear powered, chased intruding Americans away. Now the fleet is a shadow of its former self. It poses a greater threat to the environment than the West.

Once, the Soviet armed forces had an annual budget of £120 billion. Now it is a fraction of that, some say as little as £3bn.

The navy receives far less than the army and huge resources have been channelled into the war with Chechnya.

Much of the Northern Fleet is inoperable, and 88 of its submarines - about two-thirds of the total - have been decommissioned. At least 52 of these still contain their nuclear fuel.

All over the north of Russia their long steel hulls lie rusting at docksides. Elsewhere, huge piles of radio-active waste lie stored with minimum maintenance. All the purpose-built radioactive waste storage facilities are full, so a substantial amount is stored, unprotected, in the open.

At one base - Zapadnaya Litsa, only 25 miles from the Norwegian border - the equivalent of 90 nuclear re-actors is stored. Stockpiles have leaked in recent years.

'The whole navy is an accident waiting to happen,' said Peter Huchthausen, a former US intelligence officer.

And there have been accidents before. The Russian newspaper, Izvestia, recently reported that 507 crew members have died during the 40 years that the Russians have used nuclear-powered submarines.

It was the Americans who first launched a nuclear sub in the mid-Fifties.

The first major accident came in 1961 when a reactor on a Russian sub began to overheat. With its fuel rods at 1,000 degrees Celsius, nine men volunteered to go into the reactor compartment and shut it down. They all received 100 times the safe dose of radiation and died shortly afterwards.

In 1970, a November-class attack submarine sank in rough seas in the Bay of Biscay, and in 1986 a third Russian sub was scuttled after a fire.

Three years later the Komsomolets sank in the Barents Sea to a depth of more than 6,000ft. The accident was kept secret until the break-up of the Soviet Union.

The Cold War claimed its casualties in the West, too. The USS Thresher went down off the coast of New England in 1963 with 129 men on board. The USS Scorpion sank a few years later off the Azores.

Unlike the Kursk - which lies a mere 385ft down - all the others lie thousands of feet below the surface.

The Thresher is at a depth of 16,000ft. Only in one instance is there thought to have been a serious radiation leak, but the sub was so deep that, although the sea floor is thought to be contaminated, experts believe that marine life is unaffected.

However, the case of the Kursk is very different. Scientists believe that, if the nuclear reactors were not properly shut down, then there is a real chance of a meltdown.

The super-heated reactors would then burn their way through the bottom of the sub, releasing molten fuel on to the seabed.

Mils Bohmer, a Russian nuclear physicist, said that this would release fission products such as plutonium, caesium and uranium into the Barents Sea's fertile fishing ground.

So far, tests of water and air samples gathered by Norwegian vessels near the Kursk and analysed by the Norwegian Nuclear Protection Authority have not shown any abnormal levels of radiation.

In many ways the bottom of the sea - particularly an isolated and cold sea such as the Barents - can be seen as the best place for damaged nuclear equipment to be dumped.

But a dockside in a northern Russian port can only be one of the worst.

fields.headline: Fresh threat to BNFL sell-off
fields.standfirst: Special report: Britain's nuclear industry
fields.trailText: British Nuclear Fuels is preparing to unveil results showing mounting operating losses and a serious deterioration in the company's financial performance.
fields.body:
British Nuclear Fuels is preparing to unveil results showing mounting operating losses and a serious deterioration in the company's financial performance.

The atomic energy group's figures for the year to March 2000, due in the next month, are expected to show operating losses on its core business growing from last year's £62 million.

But the published operating losses will not reflect the full extent of what the company admits has been a very bad financial year; and they come on top of a string of safety problems.

The figures will be a further setback to the Government's ambition of completing the part-privatisation of BNFL by the end of 2002.

The losses have been driven by difficulties with BNFL's eight first-generation Magnox power stations, and the effective closure of its Mixed Oxide Fuel (MOX) facilities in the wake of a data falsification scandal. Compensation of £40m paid to Japanese utilities as a result of the MOX debacle may also be included in the accounts.

Magnox has damaged BNFL's financial performance ever since it took over the eight stations. In 1997, before it acquired them, BNFL made an operating profit of £116m. This became a £25m loss in 1998 and a £62m loss last year.

But the problem is going to intensify. BNFL has had operational problems with three stations - Bradwell, Sizewell A and Hinkley Point A - now permanently closed - and has suffered from a fall in the electricity price, from £24.64 a megawatt hour to £22.64. This price is expected to fall further.

BNFL's biggest station, Wylfa in Wales, which accounts for more than 30 per cent of capacity, stopped generating in April because of faulty welds and is likely to be out until Christmas. According to industry analysts, this could make next year's results - due only a year before the privatisation date - worse still.

In addition to the operating figures, BNFL's accounts are likely to make increased provision for its £29 billion clean-up liabilities - but the figure will be considerably lower than the £9bn 'black hole' that was being suggested in the spring.

BNFL will also make it clear that it is not technically insolvent - although it is not clear how it will account for any additional provision that may be needed.

The operating loss will mask a worse performance because it will include the first contribution from the Westinghouse nuclear reactor business, which BNFL bought for £641m last year.

It will also incorporate income from investments made with massive upfront payments by BNFL's customers to build the Thorp reprocessing plant. Until now this has been classified as financial income but, as chairman Hugh Collum told The Observer in April, some will have been reclassified as operating income.

webTitle: Prescott in move to save peat bogs

fields.headline: Prescott in move to save peat bogs
fields.trailText: John Prescott will this week announce a deal to halt peat excavation across prime swathes of British bogland, amid growing concern over the environmental impact of extraction at its current rate.
fields.body:
John Prescott will this week announce a deal to halt peat excavation across prime swathes of British bogland, amid growing concern over the environmental impact of extraction at its current rate.

Environmentalists have repeatedly criticised the quarrying of peat - mostly for use in compost by amateur gardeners - arguing it destroys rich ecological habitats and puts birds, butterflies and rare plants at risk.

The Deputy Prime Minister will designate 70 new Special Areas of Conservation - these will be protected sites regarded as internationally outstanding - as part of a countryside package in advance of his Rural White Paper this autumn.

Four of them will be areas of so-called raised bogland, which are or have been used for the quarrying of peat. Changing their classification gives local authorities the power to withdraw planning consent for such exploitation.

'We have campaigned for this for 10 years,' said Craig Bennett of Friends of the Earth. 'It is the beginning of the end for peat farming in Britain.'

The new protected areas are thought to include Thorne and Hatfield Moors in Yorkshire, the largest remaining expanse of English peatland currently excavated, and home to nightjars, 5,000 species of insects and invertebrates and rare plants.

Since 1993 the use of peat has increased by more than a quarter, mostly because of the boom in gardening as a hobby.

webTitle: Most wanted  woman in Britain slips the net again

fields.headline: Most wanted  woman in Britain slips the net again
fields.trailText: She is a master of disguise and one of Britain's most wanted women. Detectives this weekend appealed for help in tracing Fiona Mont, the 30-year-old daughter of a prominent Sussex Tory family who has been on the run since faking her own death in January.
fields.body:
She is a master of disguise and one of Britain's most wanted women. Detectives this weekend appealed for help in tracing Fiona Mont, the 30-year-old daughter of a prominent Sussex Tory family who has been on the run since faking her own death in January. But now, say police, a number of sightings have placed her firmly in Europe.

Nicknamed 'The Cat' because of her ability to keep ahead of detectives, Mont has proved expert at evading capture. Police say that by using seduction and charm she has become one of the most sophisticated and cunning fugitives they have encountered.

Mont faces charges relating to a huge computer fraud she is believed to have masterminded. Police are reluctant to give specific details of her probable location, as they believe friends and former lovers in Britain are keeping her informed of police progress. Her downfall began last September, when Steve Skerrett decided to buy a computer. A detective constable with Sussex police, Skerrett responded to an advertisement in his local paper and found himself sitting in a basement flat in Hove with Mont and her boyfriend, surrounded by boxes of new, branded computers.

He arranged to return the next Monday, but in the meantime spoke to a colleague who had been working on a case in which a computer manufacturer had been defrauded of tens of thousands of pounds of machines. A few calls reinforced their suspicions, and Skerrett returned on the Monday with a search warrant. Skerrett said of his first visit to Mont's flat: 'We started talking about our jobs, and I told them I was a policeman. There was no reaction, not even a flicker. Nothing at all. She was ice cool about it. I think, to be honest, she probably found the idea of selling something to me quite amusing. It's all a bit of a game to her.'

While on bail charged with fraud in this case, Mont continued to play games, calling Skerrett up at his office and inviting him out for a drink. He declined. Mont's confidence crumbled only when she attended an identification parade and was picked out by witnesses. Fearful of facing trial and possibly prison, she resorted to desperate measures and faked suicide. Her Rover 820 car was found abandoned on the edge of the notorious suicide spot at Beachy Head, near Eastbourne, a week later. Her keys had been left on the edge of the 535ft cliff - it seemed she had thrown herself off.

A search-and-rescue operation involving police and members of the Coastguard using helicopters and dozens of boats was launched, but called off after two days when Fiona's mother, Joan, said her daughter had called her. Mont now faces charges of wasting police time and skipping bail, as well as the original fraud allegations.

Police now know that, after leaving her car at Beachy Head, Mont fled the country in an aircraft piloted by Graham Hesketh, whose nickname is 'The Baron' and who is wanted by police in connection with a number of offences. It was originally thought the pair used the flight as a ruse to come back to England undetected, but detectives are now convinced they remained in Europe, where they may be engaged in a range of other criminal activities.

Mont has also left behind a string of broken hearts. One boyfriend is now in prison near Paris awaiting trial on drugs charges. Another is on bail in the UK. 'She is an extremely clever woman,' said Skerrett. 'She can make herself look like a duchess or a tramp and will use anyone who can be of benefit to her.'

For Mont, life on the run is a far cry from her privileged upbringing. Her mother is a prominent local Tory, a former leader of East Sussex County Council and president of the Rottingdean Conservative Association. Her late father, Neville, was a solicitor and former Under Sheriff of East Sussex. Mont was educated at the £6,975-a-year St Mary's School in Brighton, but was expelled because of her delinquent behaviour. Although she has been in and out of trouble with the law ever since, Mont has only two minor convictions and has never been to prison.

She frequently uses her background as evidence that she has no need to turn to crime. Mont studied law and worked briefly at a local business centre. Using these skills she has set up companies and is believed to have used accounts which indicate these companies have turnovers in excess of £1 million a year. Police say she used these accounts to apply to various computer companies for lines of credit and order tens of thousands of pounds of goods, which she allegedly sells without ever paying for them. Mont is believed to have pocketed more than £300,000 in this way in the past year alone.

She has allegedly placed dozens of ads in the Yellow Pages for her bogus companies, which have never been paid for. She has legally held passports in a number of different names to disguise her identity. After changing her name by deed poll, she sends off her old passport and applies for one in her new name. As anyone is entitled to change their name as often as they want, no checks are made at the Passport Office to see whether such changes could be used for criminal purposes. She uses a number of aliases, including Frances Montgomery, Alison Miller, Jacqueline Mayhew and Jamina Chadwick.

'She is an extremely clever woman,' said Skerrett. 'She can make herself look like a duchess or a tramp and will use anyone who can be of benefit to her.' For Mont, life on the run is a far cry from her privileged upbringing. Her mother is a prominent local Tory, a former leader of East Sussex County Council and president of the Rottingdean Conservative Association. Her late father, Neville, was a solicitor and former Under Sheriff of East Sussex. Mont was educated at the £6,975-a-year St Mary's School in Brighton, but was expelled because of her delinquent behaviour. Although she has been in and out of trouble with the law ever since, Mont has only two minor convictions and has never been to prison. She frequently uses her background as evidence that she has no need to turn to crime. Mont studied law and worked briefly at a local business centre. Using these skills she has set up companies and is believed to have used accounts which indicate these companies have turnovers in excess of £1 million a year. Police say she used these accounts to apply to various computer companies for lines of credit and order tens of thousands of pounds of goods, which she allegedly sells without ever paying for them. Mont is believed to have pocketed more than £300,000 in this way in the past year alone. She has allegedly placed dozens of ads in the Yellow Pages for her bogus companies, which have never been paid for. She has legally held passports in a number of different names to disguise her identity. After changing her name by deed poll, she sends off her old passport and applies for one in her new name. As anyone is entitled to change their name as often as they want, no checks are made at the Passport Office to see whether such changes could be used for criminal purposes. She uses a number of aliases, including Frances Montgomery, Alison Miller, Jacqueline Mayhew and Jamina Chadwick. tony.thompson@observer.co.uk

webTitle: Britain's oilmen trample on last great wilderness

fields.headline: Britain's oilmen trample on last great wilderness
fields.standfirst: Above ground are the caribou, essential to the livelihood of Alaska's Gwich'in tribe. Below ground lies up to 16 billion barrels of oil. Britain's BP is the invader and the battlefield is one of the most ecologically fragile sites on earth. Anthony Browne reports from inside the Arctic Circle
fields.trailText: Above ground are the caribou, essential to the livelihood of Alaska's Gwich'in tribe. Below ground lies up to 16 billion barrels of oil. Britain's BP is the invader and the battlefield is one of the most ecologically fragile sites on earth. Anthony Browne reports from inside the Arctic Circle
fields.body:
They hiked over mountains and canoed along crashing Arctic rivers. They were guided by a sun that set for only an hour a night and braced by freezing winds. For 800 miles across the wilderness they trekked, from the Yukon in Canada to remotest Alaska, far above the Arctic Circle.

When they finally made it to the log cabins of Arctic Village on Friday, their cries of joy and their dancing and singing for a moment drowned out the deep fear that drove them on their odyssey.

The 100,000-strong Gwich'in tribe's 'millennium trek' was a desperate plea for survival. One of the last tribes of native Americans to live by subsistence, they fear that they - and the caribou on which they depend - are about to lose a 25-year battle that could end in one last Klondike-like scramble for oil.

It is a battle that has pitched Alaska against the rest of America and the Indians and environmentalists against Britain's biggest oil company, BP.

The age-old conflict between development and environment has nowhere been so stark as in this fragile corner of the world. Nowhere are man's thirst for oil - and the effects of global warming - having such an impact.

The remote Gwich'in community of Arctic Village, 100 miles north of the Arctic Circle and with no access by road, nestles against the southern edge of the vast Arctic National Wildlife Refuge. The refuge is the last true wilderness in North America, so abundant in wildlife it has been dubbed America's Serengeti. Here are 20 million acres of soaring snowcapped mountains, marshy coastal plains, Arctic tundra and forests of stunted trees, with no signs of man: no roads nor car parks, no visitor centres nor hiking trails.

In the short summers the tundra explodes into vibrant reds and yellows. In winter it is smothered in snow. Visitors talk about a primal landscape that takes them back to a time before man, but to the environmentalists and the Gwich'in, it is the wildlife that makes it unique. It has the only population of Alaskan polar bears that live on land; it has the near-extinct shaggy musk ox, the regal moose, grizzly bears, wolverine and lynx.

The refuge is the breeding ground for 150 species of birds that migrate to the US, Asia and South America for the bitter winters, when for three months the sun does not rise and temperatures drop below minus 50 centigrade.

Above all, it is the 130,000 caribou which dominate the landscape and on which the Gwich'in depend for much of their food. "My people have always been known as the caribou people," says Sarah James of the Gwich'in steering committee, as caribou steaks sizzle on the stove of her cosy log cabin. "Without the caribou we are lost."

A sign in the Arctic Village community hall says of the caribou: "It's our dance, it's our language, it's everything to us."

Each year the caribou go on one of the last great mammal migrations on the planet, trekking from 1,000 miles away in Canada, through the 9,000ft Brooks range and swimming precariously across sweeping rivers, to the narrow coastal strip of the refuge.

Here, in the calving grounds sacred to the Gwich'in, the caribou fatten up with cotton grass to get them through the Arctic winter and, protected from predators, the cows give birth. But amid the majestic scenery are a few oil seeps, a tell-tale sign of what is underneath: below the feet of the grazing caribou lies enough crude oil to fill up to 16 billion barrels - worth many tens of billions of pounds - and the oil companies are pushing hard to start drilling.

Oil is already produced along much of the rest of the Alaskan coast but is starting to dry up. At the Prudhoe Bay field, just along from the refuge, production has fallen from two million barrels a day a decade ago to a million now.

The caribou are already having to deal with the effects of climate change. Scientists believe the Arctic is getting warmer up to five times faster than the rest of the Earth. The icepack in the Arctic Ocean is now 40 per cent thinner than it was. The permafrost on the tundra is showing signs of melting. Polar bears, short of food, have lost 10 per cent of their body weight.

Warmer winters mean more snow in the mountains, and for the first time this year the caribou did not make it to the coast before calving. According to Don Russell, a biologist with the International Porcupine Caribou Management Board, the unfriendly climate is already taking its toll and caribou numbers are falling.

"This year will be worse. Their migration is no longer coinciding with the fast seasonal changes in vegetation," he said. If the numbers of caribou fall much further the Gwich'in may have to cut down the number of animals - 4,000 at present - they allow themselves to hunt.

And the momentum to raid the refuge for oil, which will further promote global warming, is building. Americans, driving ever bigger and less fuel efficient cars - they are now back to the same consumption of cars 20 years ago - have been shocked by the price of petrol rising to 30p a litre.

Arctic Power, an oil-funded lobby group dedicated to opening up the refuge, says in its public literature: 'Worried about fuel prices? Arctic National Wildlife Refuge equals 30 years of Saudi oil. Industry and government experts recognise the coastal plain of the refuge as the single most promising unexplored region in the US for a major oil and gas discovery.'

On the other side of the continent, in Washington, pressure is mounting. President Clinton blocked earlier congressional attempts to open up the refuge but his likely successor, George W. Bush, is committed to letting in the oil companies to reduce US dependence on foreign oil.

At the Democratic convention last week a vote was passed to protect the refuge; only the Alaskan representative, Mano Frey, voted against it, declaring: "Our hope is to educate the government about the importance of Alaska as a resource extraction state."

Leading the charge is BP. It is a major funder of Arctic Power, has an executive on its board and has been lobbying intensely behind the scenes. Wary of bad publicity, BP spokesman Ronnie Chappell says coyly: "We are supportive of the state of Alaska and residents to give access to the area."

Not all its investors support the strategy. Last year two Gwich'in - backed by environmental groups - flew to Britain to the company's annual meeting and persuaded 13 per cent of BP's shareholders to support a motion to cut back new off-shore production in the area and spend the money developing alternative sources of energy.

Yet BP can count on the support of the majority of Alaskans. Oil has made this once poor and punishing state rich and far more comfortable, and now accounts for 85 per cent of its economy.

Anchorage, not so long ago a dusty hicksville, now boasts soaring, mirrored office blocks, and every village now has a million-dollar school. Oil money flows so fast into the government's coffers that, like a Middle East kingdom, no one pays state sales tax or income tax.

Each year the government gives money to every Alaskan - this year each man, woman and baby is about to get $2,000 just for living there, prompting an advertising bonanza for TVs, cars and computers. "It's bloody money. It's dirty money. They're just trying to buy the votes of Alaskans," sighs Melanie Duchin of Greenpeace Alaska, which has been campaigning hard against oil developments in the region.

Oil has also brought many thousands of well-paid jobs, and Arctic Power promises that opening up the refuge will create up to 700,000 more. With current oil fields drying up, pressure for new jobs is intense. BP's Chappell said simply: "Our activities are key to the economic well-being of the state." Alaska's pro-oil representative Don Young puts it more colourfully: "If you think billions of barrels of oil will stay in the ground, you're smoking pot."

A new oil boom would be a disaster to the Gwich'in nation, who are desperately concerned about the effect it will have on the caribou.

The Gwich'in have always left the calving grounds alone for fear of disturbing them: a pregnant caribou reacts badly to any disturbance or noise. BP insists such environmental concerns are unfounded.

Chappell said: "We have become very good at reducing our impact on the environment. We can explore for oil without leaving a footprint on earth."

BP boasts about its record at Prudhoe Bay, where oil development has even been described as 'caribou Viagra': the population of caribou has increased since drilling for oil started.

Recent studies have shown that it is the males and the young who are thriving - pregnant cows are indeed steering clear. One academic study suggested that the presence of oil installations mean that caribou give birth to fewer calves, which have lower birth-weights.

"Drilling for oil will permanently alter the characteristics of the refuge. No technology is good enough to leave no mark," said Sara Callaghan, Arctic campaigner for the Sierra Club environmental group.

BP declined to give The Observer a tour of its facilities at Prudhoe Bay; instead, Greenpeace offered to help us explore the area. As we sailed along the coast of the refuge on the icebreaker Arctic Sunrise, a BP helicopter trailed us.

Standing on the bridge, Duchin said: "It's the most compellingly beautiful, I-believe-in-God-when-I've-seen-it place. Imagine it scattered with oil platforms."

As we flew down the coast to Prudhoe Bay in Greenpeace's helicopter, imagination was not needed. It is one of the largest industrial developments in the world, with hundreds of miles of pipelines snaking across the damp tundra, disappearing off to the horizon in every direction. There are hundreds of well heads and processing facilities, flares, landing strips, roads, sea water processing plants and accommodation blocks. In between, the land is indeed clean - and soggy - and BP has managed to avoid any major oil spills.

However, its record is far from unblemished: earlier this year it had to pay a $15m fine for toxic waste dumping. That was not mentioned in BP's recent spate of advertisements in the British press, touting its green credentials.

"The British public is being hoodwinked," said Duchin, "and if they care about being hoodwinked, they should care about the refuge."

For the Gwich'in, there is a far more fundamental issue. Faith Gemmill, their spokeswoman, showed me around her ancestors' cemetary, on a bend in a river overlooked by the mountains. She then declared: "This is how we have lived for thousands of years. No one has a right to take this away from us for money or greed. This is what they did to the Sioux when they killed the buffalo. When is this country going to learn they can't do that to a people?"

fields.headline: Hibs keep ahead
fields.standfirst: Football Review
fields.trailText: Hibernian's excellent start to the season was maintained with a 2-0 win at Aberdeen.
fields.body:
Hibernian's excellent start to the season was maintained with a 2-0 win at Aberdeen.

The home team found themselves with a big challenge on their hands inside the opening five minutes, when Mark Perry handled in the area - a misdemeanor for which he was sent off - and Russell Latapy fired in the penalty. Aberdeen did have chances to get back into the game - particularly when the Hibs keeper, Nick Colgan, was forced into a superb one-handed save to keep out an effort from Robbie Winters - but were ultimately punished for not taking them when Mixu Paatelainen made it 2-0 after 78 minutes.

St Johnstone notched their first league win of the season in the Tayside derby against Dundee United at Tannadice.

Graeme Jones fired the visitors ahead after only 11 minutes and it came as no surprise when Kiegan Parker added a second after 24 minutes. United's increased work-rate was rewarded in the 63rd minute when Hasney Aljofree was on hand in a packed goalmouth to deflect a David Hannah shot into the net.

But, although United pressed for an equaliser, the Saints defence held firm.

Dundee also went down, at St Mirren. All the goals came in the last half an hour, with Ricky Gillies putting the home team ahead, Dundee's Argentine forward Juan Sara equalising with a penalty and Steve McGarry getting the winner.

There was some irony about Sara's spot-kick because earlier he had been booked for a penalty-area dive. Indeed, he seemed fortunate to remain on the field when he went to ground again shortly afterwards.

One of the best matches of the day was Kilmarnock's 3-2 win over Motherwell, after they had twice been behind. The decisive goal came from Frederic Dindeleux 10 minutes from the end.

fields.headline: Arms build-up 'breached anti-nuclear treaty'
fields.trailText: Britain has covertly built up its nuclear arsenal in what anti-nuclear campaigners claim is a clear breach of its obligations under international peace treaties.
fields.body:
Britain has covertly built up its nuclear arsenal in what anti-nuclear campaigners claim is a clear breach of its obligations under international peace treaties.

An official government report obtained by The Observer details how since 1978 British governments have made more than 500 transfers of 'civilian' nuclear material to the Ministry of Defence. In 1968 Britain was one of 62 countries which signed the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty (NPT), which was aimed at stopping such transfers.

Nations with nuclear weapons, such as the UK and the United States, have led international criticism of other countries for trying to develop atomic bombs by using nuclear material from civilian sources.

The imposition of international inspectors on Iraq was based on alleged breaches of the NPT.

The report, released by the Department of Trade and Industry, describes how in 1992 five tons of low-enriched uranium from British Nuclear Fuels' Capenhurst reactor in Cheshire was used to produce tritium, an important component of nuclear weapons manufactured at Aldermaston in Berkshire.

In 1983 almost 100 tons of low-enriched uranium from Capenhurst was used for nuclear weapons material.

The report also gives details of a previously undisclosed incident in 1986 when more than 800 grams of weapons-grade plutonium from BNFL's nuclear reprocessing plant at Sellafield in Cumbria was 'inadvertently' sent to another reactor.

In addition large amounts of depleted uranium from civilian reactors were used for conventional military purposes in making depleted uranium shells and armour for tanks.

Dr David Lowry, an environment consultant who has campaigned for years for the information to be released, said: 'It appears to be a case of one rule for us and another for other countries.'

A Department of Trade and Industry spokesman denied Britain had been guilty of any such breach.

webTitle: Donor row prompts fears of organ crisis

fields.headline: Donor row prompts fears of organ crisis
fields.trailText: Hospitals were braced this weekend for Britain's transplant crisis to deepen after a medical row about whether brain-dead organ donors can feel pain.
fields.body:
Hospitals were braced this weekend for Britain's transplant crisis to deepen after a medical row about whether brain-dead organ donors can feel pain.

The Royal College of Anaesthetists has called for anaesthetic to be given during operations to remove the heart, lungs and livers of donors. An editorial in the RCA journal this week said that increased blood pressure and heart rate in patients who have organs removed 'could be considered to represent an organism in distress. Our limited understanding of the process should demand caution before assuming that anaesthesia is not required.'

The disclosures in the Guardian newspaper prompted the Department of Health to insist last night that brain-dead donors were not in pain. However, a spokeswoman said: 'There is a very real worry that fewer people will come forward as donors when they hear about this. It would be a tragedy if misunderstanding about clinical practice led to uncertainty among the families of potential organ donors.'

A spokeswoman for the UK Transplant Association said: 'We cannot predict what the effect of this [publicity] will be. Organ donation is a very fragile and brittle decision, both for the family and the donor themselves.'

Last year 2,800 transplants were carried out in Britain from 815 donors. But there are still 5,500 people waiting for organs, some critically ill. The current crisis is the worst since 1990 when there were 1,009 donors.

The rate of donation has dropped sharply as healthier living has reduced the number of heart attacks. A large fall in the level of fatal road accidents has also reduced the level of donor organs available.

Received medical wisdom for 30 years has been that the reactions of bodies having organs removed is involuntary and unconnected with the brain. Giles Morgan, president of the Intensive Care Society, who wrote the most recent guidance for intensive care unit staff, said: 'In simple terms, if you are dead, you are dead and so dead people don't require anaesthesia.'

However Morgan admitted that he gives donor patients anaesthetic when they are having organs removed: 'I do it because I'm a human being and it does make us feel a little more comfortable. It is a very traumatic thing.'

Absence of brainstem function is now used in Britain as a definition of death. The brainstem is the connection between the main brain and the spinal cord. Only when this is confirmed can a ventilator keeping a patient breathing be lawfully turned off.

But as medical science has advanced, ethical uncertainties have deepened about the determination of death. It is now clear that even in some patients certified brain-dead there is evidence of electrical activity in the brain.

fields.bodyText: Hospitals were braced this weekend for Britain's transplant crisis to deepen after a medical row about whether brain-dead organ donors can feel pain. The Royal College of Anaesthetists has called for anaesthetic to be given during operations to remove the heart, lungs and livers of donors. An editorial in the RCA journal this week said that increased blood pressure and heart rate in patients who have organs removed 'could be considered to represent an organism in distress. Our limited understanding of the process should demand caution before assuming that anaesthesia is not required.' The disclosures in the Guardian newspaper prompted the Department of Health to insist last night that brain-dead donors were not in pain. However, a spokeswoman said: 'There is a very real worry that fewer people will come forward as donors when they hear about this. It would be a tragedy if misunderstanding about clinical practice led to uncertainty among the families of potential organ donors.' A spokeswoman for the UK Transplant Association said: 'We cannot predict what the effect of this [publicity] will be. Organ donation is a very fragile and brittle decision, both for the family and the donor themselves.' Last year 2,800 transplants were carried out in Britain from 815 donors. But there are still 5,500 people waiting for organs, some critically ill. The current crisis is the worst since 1990 when there were 1,009 donors. The rate of donation has dropped sharply as healthier living has reduced the number of heart attacks. A large fall in the level of fatal road accidents has also reduced the level of donor organs available. Received medical wisdom for 30 years has been that the reactions of bodies having organs removed is involuntary and unconnected with the brain. Giles Morgan, president of the Intensive Care Society, who wrote the most recent guidance for intensive care unit staff, said: 'In simple terms, if you are dead, you are dead and so dead people don't require anaesthesia.' However Morgan admitted that he gives donor patients anaesthetic when they are having organs removed: 'I do it because I'm a human being and it does make us feel a little more comfortable. It is a very traumatic thing.' Absence of brainstem function is now used in Britain as a definition of death. The brainstem is the connection between the main brain and the spinal cord. Only when this is confirmed can a ventilator keeping a patient breathing be lawfully turned off. But as medical science has advanced, ethical uncertainties have deepened about the determination of death. It is now clear that even in some patients certified brain-dead there is evidence of electrical activity in the brain. ben.summerskill@observer.co.uk

webTitle: Letters to the Editor: Police will help

fields.headline: Police will help
fields.trailText: Following on from Lauren Booth's article about the police helping victimised women (Comment, last week), I would like to point out that all police services in the UK are fully committed to investigate and record intimidation, harassment and assaults on gays and lesbians.
fields.body:
Following on from Lauren Booth's article about the police helping victimised women (Comment, last week), I would like to point out that all police services in the UK are fully committed to investigate and record intimidation, harassment and assaults on gays and lesbians.

Sadly, 90 per cent of these are not reported to the police, but each police division now has a fully trained officer to deal sympathetically with any hatred shown towards gays and lesbians.

There are committed police officers determined to end the long-held distrust between their service and minority groups and I would urge all gays and lesbians, as well as women, to seek help to end this historical divide.
David Hitchen
Fleet
Hampshire

fields.headline: The kids are all right...
fields.standfirst: ...but the system needs re-educating
fields.trailText: If it's mid-August it must be A-level anxiety. More passes than ever before; more A grades; more pictures of jubilant and despairing students - more dark muttering about 'grade' inflation and the debasing of the educational gold standard. More Tory spokesman calls for wide-ranging reviews of the system.
fields.body:
If it's mid-August it must be A-level anxiety. More passes than ever before; more A grades; more pictures of jubilant and despairing students - more dark muttering about 'grade' inflation and the debasing of the educational gold standard. More Tory spokesman calls for wide-ranging reviews of the system.

This year has run true to form. Since 1989 the pass rate has risen from 77 to 89 per cent of candidates, while the number of students achieving A grades has risen from 11.6 to 17.8 per cent.

Far from being a cause of joy, this has led to calls for investigations into falling standards. The consensus is not that students are working harder, teaching is better and state schools are closing the gap on private schools. Rather, the charge is that the system is softer and that the education establishment is infected by liberal doctrines that all must have prizes.

The criticism is hard to sustain. Closer examination of the results reveals that the increase is based mainly on the continuing improved performance of girls, discernible over a decade.

Children who in the main work much harder for their successes than their parents ever had to, have every reason to be furious at such politically motivated bleating about easier exams .

Children in Scotland have even more reason to be angry. The disgraceful virtual collapse of the examination system in Scotland has left many candidates without correct results or any chance of receiving them in time for their applications to receive proper consideration in the clearing system. Four Scottish universities now regard the reliability of the grades they have been notified as so uncertain that they plan to offer places on the basis of predicted rather than achieved grades.

The whole shabby affair is a betrayal of the hopes and efforts of thousands of 18-year-olds, and has shattered confidence in the Scottish Qualification Authority, which will only be recovered by wholesale reform and managerial overhaul.

Perhaps the silliest doom-mongering comes from Jeremiahs wailing that boys are being left behind. For the gap between boys and girls remains trivial; 18.1 per cent of girls got A grades compared with 17.5 per cent of boys.

Generations of politicians and pundits across the political spectrum have called for increasing effort towards improving girls' academic performance. Rough equality of intellectual ability between the sexes was always probable. Now that it is reflected in academic results we should be jubilant.

It is not grade inflation that ought to worry us, or minor differences in performance between the genders among the advantaged. What should worry us is ensuring that all children, from all ethnic groups and classes, share in an overall improvement driven by better teaching and political recognition that education matters.

webTitle: Leader: What prehistoric man has to teach Tony Blair

fields.headline: Prehistory lesson
fields.standfirst: More to cavemen than shadows
fields.trailText: A Scottish psychologist has claimed that prehistoric man sanctified the 'communist' values of equality and sharing. No doubt the news will tickle Mr Blair, who firmly believes that he rescued his party from a Jurassic Park inhabited by Old Labour cavemen.
fields.body:
A Scottish psychologist has claimed that prehistoric man sanctified the 'communist' values of equality and sharing. No doubt the news will tickle Mr Blair, who firmly believes that he rescued his party from a Jurassic Park inhabited by Old Labour cavemen. Far from New Labour promoting a culture of shared responsibility, the Industrial Society will suggest this week that the Government family policy is divisive and encourages employers to discriminate against women.

We hope the Prime Minister will now recognise the legitimate claims of both mothers and fathers to the same paid parental leave, even if this means conceding that Mr Blair is more helpfully taking lessons from a troglodyte than Mr Philip Gould and his focus groups.

webTitle: Letters to the Editor: Forestry omission

fields.headline: Forestry omission
fields.trailText: While you rightly point out that global warming is everyone's responsibility (Leader comment, last week), it is not beneficial to belittle the role that 'carbon sinks' (forestry) can play in tackling CO 2 emissions.
fields.body:
While you rightly point out that global warming is everyone's responsibility (Leader comment, last week), it is not beneficial to belittle the role that 'carbon sinks' (forestry) can play in tackling CO 2 emissions.

While 'Carbon sinks' are in no way a replacement to reductions of emissions at source, they are a valuable part of an integrated approach. We would also argue that the issues associated with forestry are no more or less complex than those associated with other 'offset' propositions, and that well-managed natural woodland programmes bring the added benefit of encouraging bio-diversity.
Dan Morrell
Chairman, Future Forests Ltd
Castle Cary
Somerset

webTitle: Letters to the Editor: Pension puzzle

fields.headline: Pension puzzle
fields.trailText: Simon Broadbent (Business, last week) is in danger of giving the impression that the Government expects the poorest pensioners to live on the Minimum Income Guarantee of £78.45 for a single person or £121.95 for a couple.
fields.body:
Simon Broadbent (Business, last week) is in danger of giving the impression that the Government expects the poorest pensioners to live on the Minimum Income Guarantee of £78.45 for a single person or £121.95 for a couple.

In practice, with automatic housing and Council Tax benefits, a pensioner couple have the equivalent income of a worker earning at least £11,000 a year or £5.29 per hour (40-hour week), and paying income tax and national insurance. The worker does not benefit from the winter fuel allowance, concessionary fares, free prescriptions, etc.

A substantial increase in the state retirement pension, while welcome, may in practice benefit the poorest pensioners least, because of reductions in benefits, and those with occupational pensions most.
Phil D'Arcy
Aberdeen

webTitle: Letters to the Editor: Tackling ageism

fields.headline: Tackling ageism
fields.trailText: It will be interesting to see how the Government proposes to tackle the problem of ageism in the NHS (News, last week) bearing in mind how widespread it is.
fields.body:
It will be interesting to see how the Government proposes to tackle the problem of ageism in the NHS (News, last week) bearing in mind how widespread it is.

For instance, at a meeting where I gave a paper on age-based rationing of health care to a group of GPs, a sizeable proportion of those present not only admitted that they practised ageism but were willing to admit that they did so.

My feeling is that the only way to eradicate ageism in the NHS is to make it illegal. The 1976 Race Relations Act and the 1975 Disability Discrimination Act made discrimination illegal in other areas and it should be therefore possible to take a similar statutory approach to protect elderly people within the NHS.
Dr M.M. Rivlin
Leeds

webTitle: Letters to the Editor: Why go private?

fields.headline: Why go private?
fields.trailText: My twin sons were born in St Mary's Hospital Manchester in February 1960. The hospital was old, the wards were large, and the care and attention we received could not be faulted, even though they arrived three weeks earlier than expected. I was told that the delivery room was full of staff who had come to see a twin birth as part of their training. I hope we were of help.

fields.headline: Leaving the teens
fields.trailText: Anna Stothard (People, last week) ascribes views expressed by the local WPC to me. This policewoman went on to acknowledge that under-age drinking and drug taking were a feature of the problems we experience in Cornwall.
fields.body:
Anna Stothard (People, last week) ascribes views expressed by the local WPC to me. This policewoman went on to acknowledge that under-age drinking and drug taking were a feature of the problems we experience in Cornwall.

I and residents have emphasised that too many teenagers have been left unsupervised, and without their parents having a clue of where they are or what they are doing.

The police have reported witnessing parents dropping off 10- and 11-year-olds, with large quantities of alcohol, for late-night beach parties. These are the same people who are contemptuous of football hooligans and drunken louts from a different social stratum.
Paul Tyler MP
House of Commons
London SW1

webTitle: Rowdy Euan tale a lie, says Blair camp

fields.headline: Rowdy Euan tale a lie, says Blair camp
fields.trailText: Friends of Euan Blair yesterday dismissed reports that the Prime Minister's son disturbed holidaymakers with rowdy behaviour.
fields.body:
Friends of Euan Blair yesterday dismissed reports that the Prime Minister's son disturbed holidaymakers with rowdy behaviour.

His parents are said to be increasingly worried that 16-year-old Euan is being 'hounded' by the media after being found drunk in London's Leicester Square by police last month.

The latest allegations - that Euan and two friends got back to their Italian hotel at 5am from a bar and indulged in noisy antics until staff sent them to bed - were described as 'totally false' by the couple supervising the boys on a trip to the Italian island of Ponza.

Nigel and Anah Ruddin, parents of one of Euan's friends, entertained him for a few days while the Blairs remained at their holiday villa 150 miles away. They said: 'We were with him the whole time. The incidents reported in the papers simply did not take place.'

The Blairs, who were this weekend moving to the south of France for the second leg of their holiday, have not yet ruled out referring the matter to the Press Complaints Commission.

'The Prime Minister and his wife are aware of the stories in the papers today but we are not going to fax them the cuttings - they are on holiday,' said a Downing Street spokesman. 'When they get back from holiday they will look at it and make a decision.'

webTitle: First ice-free North Pole in 50m years

fields.headline: First ice-free North Pole in 50m years
fields.trailText: The icecap at the North Pole has turned to water for the first time in 50 million years. Scientists aboard a Russian icebreaker have discovered an ice-free patch of water a mile wide at the top of the world.
fields.byline: Anthony Browne  aboard the Arctic Sunrise in the Arctic Ocean
fields.body:
The icecap at the North Pole has turned to water for the first time in 50 million years. Scientists aboard a Russian icebreaker have discovered an ice-free patch of water a mile wide at the top of the world.

It is the first time humans have seen water at the pole, and it is the most dramatic evidence yet of the impact that global warming is having. Satellite studies have shown that the ice pack is more than 40 per cent thinner than it was 50 years ago. The last time the pole was awash with water was during the Eocene period, 55 million years ago, when the world's climate grew significantly warmer.

'It was totally unexpected' said Dr James McCarthy, director of the Museum of Comparative Zoology at Harvard University and co-leader of a group working for the UN-sponsored Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change. McCarthy was the lecturer aboard a tourist cruise to the North Pole on the Russian ice-breaker Yamal.

Global warming is thought to be affecting the Arctic far more than other regions of the world, with temperatures rising three to five times faster. The icecap is melting so fast that climatologists have predicted that within 50 years it will disappear totally during the summer. This would cause devastation to the wildlife on the ice floes. Already, polar bears are reported to be losing weight because of difficulties in finding food, and walruses are having fewer young. The permafrost in north Alaska and Canada is also melting.

Normally the ice pack at the North Pole is three to 10 metres thick, but the Yamal crunched through thin ice and intermittent open water on its way to the pole from Spitsbergen, in the Svalbard archipelago. The ice was so thin that sunlight could penetrate it. When the ship reached the pole, water lapped at its bow. The captain of the ice-breaker, who had made the trip 10 times in recent years, said he had never before seen water at the pole. The scientists also reported seeing ivory sea-gulls, the first time they have been sighted there. The Yamal had to steam a further six miles before the 100 passengers could get out and be able to say that they had stood at - or near - the North Pole. McCarthy said the passengers were astounded by what they saw: 'There was a sense of alarm. Global warming was real, and we were seeing its effects for the first time that far north.'

Dr Malcom McKenna, of the American Museum of Natural History, also aboard the Yamal, said: 'I don't know if anybody in history has ever got to 90 degrees north to be greeted by water, not ice. Some people who pooh-pooh global warming might wake up if shown that even the pole is beginning to melt.'

The world's climate grew significantly warmer during the Eocene period, when water and jungles dominated the polar regions. In the last 100 years, the world's temperature has risen by about one degree Centigrade. Eight out of 10 of the hottest years have been in the last 20 years.

webTitle: Leader: New Russia is right to turn on Putin

fields.headline: Depth of despair
fields.standfirst: New Russia is right to turn on Putin
fields.trailText: The Kursk tragedy has left Russia stunned, grief-stricken and angry. The LR5 mini-submarine has taken a seeming eternity to get from Holy Loch to the Barents Sea and for that the blame rests squarely with the Kremlin and President Putin.
fields.body:
The Kursk tragedy has left Russia stunned, grief-stricken and angry. The LR5 mini-submarine has taken a seeming eternity to get from Holy Loch to the Barents Sea and for that the blame rests squarely with the Kremlin and President Putin.

More concerned with saving face than the lives of 118 submariners, he has utterly misread the mood of his people. Only a fortnight ago, 73 per cent of Russians thought Putin was doing a fine job. Today, the same number believe he should have been at the Barents Sea, not on holiday on the Black Sea.

Russian public opinion is extremely fickle and Putin is young and agile enough to recover from this fiasco. Nevertheless, the disaster represents a turning point, a sobering moment that must persuade him to reorder his priorities. All week, the Kursk drama has pitted Old Russia against New Russia, a clash of cultures that has seen the sad remnants of a failed and morally bankrupt system trying to lie its way out of trouble.

The human tragedy has been callously compounded by the venality, incompetence and high-handedness of the Russian military and political authorities. From the depths of its anger and frustration, New Russia has hit back with astonishing relish and energy, with television and newspapers exposing the misinformation and bungling and calling Putin to account, demanding that he justify himself. Public opinion is genuinely outraged.

Putin must side unequivocally with New Russia against Old Russia. He should abandon his pipe-dream talk of restoring quasi-Soviet power and prestige to a country and society that is critically dysfunctional. He should promise, instead, a more modest and realistic agenda of incremental improvement which takes as its aim the enabling of all Russians to lead decent lives in well-protected liberty.

The outside world may view Putin warily; what changed this last week was the Russians' view of their president.

webTitle: British porn comes out of the shadows

fields.headline: British porn comes out of the shadows
fields.standfirst: The sex industry is making a fortune as it moves into the business mainstream.
fields.trailText: The sex industry is making a fortune as it moves into the business mainstream.
fields.body:
Picture a lap-dancing club. There's the pole, of course, and the private booths.

But, writhing on the dance floor and around the male clientele, are there painfully thin, drug-addled girls? Are the men wearing greasy raincoats and leering grins? If you presume yes, think again. Gone are the quiet cash deals and the enforced extra services - the trade in ladies has gone legit.

The sex industry is one of Britain's fastest growing. Bright young business leaders, men and women alike, have recognised the potential of the world's oldest profession. Their determination to move lasciviousness into the mainstream and their use of the opportunities opened up by the new media has done much to aid their meteoric rise. Now big firms and City traders want to join in.

Erotica, the bi-annual trade fair at Olympia, is a case in point. More of an adults-only Ideal Home show than a full-blown, whip-cracking exercise in hard-core perversion, it was nevertheless thrown out of Scotland in 1998 after 25,000 Presbyterians picketed it.

Such has been the revolution in the way the sex industry is viewed, however, that more than 50,000 visitors are expected when the fair comes to London later this year. Sabbas Christodoulou, the Essex businessman behind the event, plans to float it on the Alternative Investment Market or Nasdaq next year, to raise up to £8 million to aid his expansion into internet erotica.

Beate Uhse, the 80-year-old businesswoman who has been running a chain of in-your-face sex shops in Germany for half a decade and who floated her company on the Frankfurt stock exchange for £431m last year, is planning to open 50 sex supermarkets in Britain by 2002.

Aware of the surge in competition, Ann Summers, Britain's home-grown purveyor of sex toys and lingerie, is also planning an ambitious expansion programme. It already commands a £43m turnover across its 35 branches, and owner David Gold plans to treble the number of high-street stores by 2003, making him one of Britain's wealthiest men.

Although it is fair to assume that the liberation and growing self-confidence of women is behind the growing popularity of sex shops, it is less easy to attribute the girl-power pound to the burgeoning profits reported by Britain's lap-dancing venues.

'It's not so much the increase in female customers that is responsible for our increased custom as the change in society's attitude towards sexuality and nudity, combined with the industry's determination to distance itself from the sex-pot, hellholes of the past,' said Caroline, a housemother at Secrets lap-dancing club in Hampstead, north London.

'It's no longer just working-class men or sleazy City boys who come to these sorts of venues,' she claimed. 'A night out and girls go together more naturally for more men now than beer and curry.'

Richard Desmond, owner of Northern & Shell, which publishes OK magazine as well as a string of porn publications, is about to make a fortune from the broadening of social attitudes.

Desmond announced flotation of his business in February, a move which could see his empire valued at £500m, which will be ploughed into online pornography.

Stan Myerson, joint managing director of the firm, believes the industry's determination to clean up has enabled it to appeal to a previously untapped market, once intimidated by tales of exploitation and sleaze.

'It's the start of something enormous,' he said. 'People are realising that they can come to us in safety.'

But there are still clubs which exploit and abuse women they employ. Jordana, 21, a student, has been a lap-dancer for two years in London clubs. 'There are clubs which look after you so well that you're probably safer there than walking down your local high street on a Friday night,' she said.

'But there are clubs that employ the women who aren't there out of their own free choice,' she added. 'The women who can't make money any other way or who have racked up huge debts. They are the ones without the power to say no.'

These are the clubs where the girls are expected to sleep with the boss, - and often his friends - on demand. They work six nights a week in situations that exploit dependency and crush the spirit.

But these are also the clubs which, Myerson insists, will be driven out of business as mainstreaming of the industry continues.

webTitle: Letters to the Editor:  The conflicts within the Blairs

fields.headline: The conflicts within the Blairs
fields.trailText: Richard Ingrams (Diary, last week) seems, to me, to miss what should be the main point. That is, the massive conflict of interest likely to exist between the Blairs.
fields.body:
Richard Ingrams (Diary, last week) seems, to me, to miss what should be the main point. That is, the massive conflict of interest likely to exist between the Blairs.

Most, if not quite all, cases involving 'human rights' will concern action taken by an individual against central government. If anyone from Mrs Blair's chambers represents such a client against the Government there will surely exist a conflict of interest of major proportions!

Consider the position of the lawyers acting on behalf of the state. They will know that they are up against the wife of the boss. That will put them in an invidious situation. Does no one else find this unacceptable?
Ian Kirk
Cheadle
Cheshire

'Morality or money' is the headline of your report on Cherie Booth's Matrix law firm and its quest for credibility in the field of human rights advocacy (Focus, last week). Is this Booth, who declared 'liberty, equality and community are indivisible', the same Booth QC who helped local authorities to find more efficient ways to prosecute Poll Tax defaulters in court?
Russell Cavanagh
Sheffield

webTitle: British orchestras under threat by eastern European musicians

fields.headline: Cut-price maestros call the tune
fields.standfirst: Low-paid musicians from eastern Europe are threatening the survival of British orchestras
fields.trailText: Britain's most respected independent touring orchestras, opera companies and ballet companies are being undercut and forced out of the market by musicians from eastern Europe.
fields.body:
Britain's most respected independent touring orchestras, opera companies and ballet companies are being undercut and forced out of the market by musicians from eastern Europe.

Musicians from the Czech Republic, Poland, Hungary and the former Soviet Union undertake intensive tours of Britain while spending as little as possible on travel and accommodation, enabling them to charge Britain's venues thousands of pounds less than domestic artists.

The growing number of eastern European musicians entering Britain has prompted the Musicians' Union to ask the Government to introduce legislation forcing all artists arriving from abroad to charge a standard fee so that they cannot undercut indigenous talent.

'We are increasingly concerned about this issue,' said Dennis Scard, general secretary of the Musicians' Union. 'Eastern European musicians are coming here and taking desperately needed work opportunities from our own companies.'

Scard believes foreign musicians are often exploited by agents who have charged so little for their services they end up living and travelling in terrible conditions.

The Chisinau National Opera of Moldova was criticised by the Performers' Alliance during its recent tour of the UK for performing 40 times during a 44-day visit. The company will be back again from mid-September until the end of November. British artists rarely play more than six dates in a single tour and never perform more than three days in a row without a break. The Polish State Opera of Wroclaw and the National Opera of Rousse, currently touring the UK, have similarly intensive programmes.

A leading orchestra from eastern Europe will typically charge around £15,000 for a concert, while a top British orchestra will expect around £28,000. A second-rate eastern European orchestra will charge as little as £8,000 for a single performance.

Antony Lewis-Crosby, former chief executive of the Royal Liverpool Philharmonic and now chairman of the Association of British Orchestras study, believes competition from overseas is forcing UK orchestras to spend more on marketing - leaving them either to take money away from the musicians or charge more for tickets, making them even less competitive.

'It's got to the stage where British orchestras can't reduce their prices any more without reducing the quality of their programmes,' said Simon Crookall, director of the Royal Scottish National Orchestra.

'We no longer do engagements in the north of England, for example, because we can't compete with the foreign orchestras they're bringing in.'

The Leeds International Series, which books tours in northern England, has employed four orchestras from eastern Europe for its next season and none from Britain. 'There's a flood of these orchestras coming over here, and it's a matter of great concern to us all,' said a company source who preferred to remain anonymous. 'Much as we'd like to, we just don't have the money to hire any homegrown orchestras.'

'I actively try not to promote too many eastern European orchestras specifically because I'm so concerned about the effect they're having on British orchestras,' said Geoffrey Owen, director of Van Walsum Management, one of the UK's main management companies specialising in international orchestras. 'It's impossible for our homegrown orchestras to compete with them, because they accept wages and living and travelling conditions our artists quite rightly will not.'

Mary Chambers, associate manager of UK tours at the International Management Group, admits that all of the five large orchestral tours she has organised this season are from eastern Europe. 'There just isn't the demand for British orchestras from promoters,' she said. 'The price difference is only going to become more pronounced because there are so many more orchestras clamouring for a chance to come over here in the future.'

webTitle: Euro car sales double to thrifty British drivers

fields.headline: Euro car sales double to thrifty British drivers
fields.trailText: One-in-five British motorists will buy a new car abroad this year as the backlash against 'rip-off' UK car prices grows, new figures reveal.
fields.body:
One-in-five British motorists will buy a new car abroad this year as the backlash against 'rip-off' UK car prices grows, new figures reveal.

The most comprehensive survey of the new car market shows that almost 20 per cent of cars bought this year will come from continental Europe. More than 140,000 private customers are expected to buy right-hand drive cars abroad - a 100 per cent increase on 1999.

The survey, using official data from the Driver and Vehicle Licensing Authority (DVLA), will prompt fresh calls for manufacturers and dealers to slash the price of new cars before the new X registration next month.

DVLA figures, released by the British Independent Motor Trade Association (Bimta), show that the number of 'parallel imports' from Europe rose from 35,000 three years ago to an estimated 140,000 this year. Sixteen per cent of new cars now come from mainland Europe.

The findings come less than a month after Stephen Byers, the Trade Secretary, confirmed that British customers are paying too much for new cars and ordered manufacturers to give private customers the same discounts offered to large fleet buyers.

A recent EU survey showed British motorists pay up to twice the price on the continent for similar models.

The DVLA figures reveal that 100,000 cars were imported in the first six months of the year. Almost 70,000 came from Europe and 30,000 from Japan and the US. Of around 880,000 new cars to be bought this year by private buyers, the DVLA estimates 140,000 will come from abroad.

Bimta, which represents independent dealers who import vehicles worth £500m a year, says the figures prove that British customers are no longer prepared to pay artificially inflated prices.

Richard Moore, a Bimta spokesman, said: 'The public is sending a clear message to motor manufacturers that they are fed up paying such crazy prices. The industry has been slow to respond to demands to slash prices and it is now paying the penalty.'

The Consumers' Association, which has waged a five-year campaign for price cuts, welcomed the survey's findings.

Phil Evans, senior policy adviser, said: 'Using official DVLA figures makes this survey the most accurate picture we have got. It tells us the private market is moving abroad and consumers are doing everything they can to avoid British forecourts.

'The manufacturers and dealers should take a good look at the figures and realise that the game is up. They should cut new car prices by a minimum of 15 per cent across the board.'

But manufacturers and dealers dismissed the findings. Al Clarke, spokesman for the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders, said: 'The plain reality is that people who look overseas to buy cars are finding their local dealers can match or beat the best price they can get.'

webTitle: 'Hi honey, it's me. I'm on the plane'

fields.headline: 'Hi honey, it's me. I'm on the plane'
fields.trailText: Aeroplanes used to be the last refuge from the trill of mobile phones, but now telephone firms are taking handsets to new heights.
fields.body:
Aeroplanes used to be the last refuge from the trill of mobile phones, but now telephone firms are taking handsets to new heights.

Revolutionary new British satellite technology means passengers will be able to use their mobiles at 35,000ft next year. CabinCall, developed by BAE Systems, replaces the current wired-in seat phones which airlines use in first class and business class.

Airlines hope the new technology will attract high-spending customers, but pilots and passengers' groups fear it will spark outbreaks of phone rage - similar to those on trains - from travellers wanting peace.

One BA pilot told The Observer: 'Who wants to watch a movie with some berk shouting down a mobile phone in the next seat? And what happens if your phone goes off while you are asleep? Who will answer it? I predict trouble.'

The Air Transport Users' Council says airlines should think about the requirements of all their customers, not just phone users. 'There is no direct evidence that all passengers want to see mobile phones in the cabin,' said Philip Martin, the council's director general. 'Airlines may gain some passengers but lose others by waking them in the night.'

But Julia Brookes, editor of Business Traveller magazine, insists passengers will welcome the new service. 'Mobiles are essential these days,' she said. 'Every time I go on the Eurostar I hear at least six high level, multi-million pound negotiations going on. With increasing globalisation of business, a lot of people are paid a lot of money to be available 24 hours a day - even in the air.'

BAE Systems, formed when British Aerospace and the defence arm of GEC Marconi merged last year, says pilots can switch off CabinCall for take-off and landing and overnight. Some airlines are planning to introduce mobile-free Quiet Zones.

'Most people now use mobiles as an integral part of their working lives and we believe passengers will accept them on planes,' a BAE Systems spokesman said. 'The cabin crew have complete control over the technology, and passengers will not be able to use phones at critical times, but if you are half an hour from landing and want to call someone to say you are late or early, you will be able to do so.'

CabinCall uses a transmitter in the roof of the plane to send messages to the ground via satellite. 'It is just like having a transmitter on the roof of your car. It creates a 'cell' which means mobile phones emit very little radiation and do not interfere with the avionics,' the BAE Systems spokesman said.

The Scandinavian airline, SAS, is to trial the system this autumn and it is expected to be approved by the Civil Aviation Authority next year.
