webTitle: If you want to get ahead, have a laugh

fields.headline: If you want to get ahead, have a laugh
fields.trailText: To manipulate friends and strangers, should you  a: tell them what they want to hear,  b: twist their arm, or  c: let out a laugh?
fields.body:
To manipulate friends and strangers, should you a: tell them what they want to hear, b: twist their arm, or c: let out a laugh?

According to research, a laugh can affect people more powerfully than speech, tapping into their subconscious and manipulating reactions.

But although laughter is controlling, it is also uncontrolled, the survey found, suggesting that humans evolved the ability to laugh as a means of manipulating others but employ it unconsciously and instinctively.

'We use laughter as a mechanism of social influence. We don't use it for the good of the social group. We use it for our own ends,' said Michael Owren, co-author of a study at Cornell University in New York. 'It's one of the most powerful and least understood of all the social tools human beings possess.'

Owren and Jo-Anne Bachorowski, a psychologist from Vanderbilt University in Tennessee, studied how laughing affects social situations by asking subjects, alone or paired with male and female friends or strangers, to watch funny film clips. Owren said: 'One of the first things we found was that, unlike speaking, people cannot laugh on cue. This suggests that while laughter is used as a tool of control, it is also used unconsciously.'

He found that men and women, monitored while watching the orgasm scene from When Harry Met Sally and the 'bring out your dead' scene from Monty Python and the Holy Grail, used and responded to laughter very differently. 'The amount and kind of laughter really did differ in men and women, but both sexes take advantage of the inherent ability of laughter to engage other people's emotional states.

'The acoustic properties of laughter induce the activation of the listener's nervous system in the same way that parents of pre-vocal infants use non-verbal ploys to catch and keep their child's attention.'

The study found that women laugh loudest and longest with male strangers, although they do so more frequently and heartily in general with male friends than with female ones.

Women laugh most rarely with other females, whether friends or strangers, although men laughed more frequently and with most acoustic variation when with male friends.

Owren believes laughter can also spark hostility, wariness and competitiveness in others. People unfamiliar to each other 'tended not to laugh much, suggesting an instinctive reluctance to trigger any hostility and competitiveness between them'.

He also found that although a woman laughs most with an unfamiliar man, that man hardly laughs at all. 'This suggests men are instinctively aware of the latent wariness unfamiliar women might feel towards them and are instinctively careful not to trigger that by any overpowering action on their part,' he said.

Robert Provine, a psychologist from Maryland University and author of a forthcoming book exploring the use of laughter, believes it is more powerful than speech. 'Laughter directly affects the emotional part of our brains instead of the cognitive, reasoning bits that are influenced by words,' he said. 'In short, laughter is used by people to make others do things.'

Women laugh most rarely with other females, whether friends or strangers, although men laughed more frequently and with most acoustic variation when with male friends. Owren believes laughter can also spark hostility, wariness and competitiveness in others. People unfamiliar to each other 'tended not to laugh much, suggesting an instinctive reluctance to trigger any hostility and competitiveness between them'. He also found that although a woman laughs most with an unfamiliar man, that man hardly laughs at all. 'This suggests men are instinctively aware of the latent wariness unfamiliar women might feel towards them and are instinctively careful not to trigger that by any overpowering action on their part,' he said. Robert Provine, a psychologist from Maryland University and author of a forthcoming book exploring the use of laughter, believes it is more powerful than speech. 'Laughter directly affects the emotional part of our brains instead of the cognitive, reasoning bits that are influenced by words,' he said. 'In short, laughter is used by people to make others do things.'

fields.headline: Japan's wartime camps 'healthy, kind, humane'
fields.trailText: Evidence of collusion between the Swiss and the Japanese over the plight of British prisoners of war has emerged in confidential government papers obtained by  The Observer.
fields.body:
Evidence of collusion between the Swiss and the Japanese over the plight of British prisoners of war has emerged in confidential government papers obtained by The Observer.

A report by a Swiss Embassy official based in Tokyo during the war praises the Japanese camps for British PoWs as being well-run, humane and 'kind'.

The official applauds the 'sunny, healthy location' of many of the camps and describes one of Japan's senior camp commanders as 'educated, rather refined' and with a 'sympathetic manner'.

Camp survivors have reacted angrily to the report, which will fuel criticism of the wartime record of the Swiss, who have been attacked over their role in handling Nazi gold.

The report on the camps was sent to the Government by the International Red Cross committee in Geneva in 1943. Before one visit the official, August Kengelbacher, re-ports: 'Lunch and dinner given by the mayor ... Then off to the camps in several cars, the whole party there - tea and cakes first.'

After visiting Camp Omine in southern Japan, he declares the camp 'a happy one', adding that prisoners were even allowed to raise poultry and pigs. At Camp Omaha he reports that prisoners were allowed to read the Nippon Times, listen to the radio and play a gramophone.

He reports that 'all these camps impressed me favourably, especially in regard to sunny, healthy and pleasant location as well as in respect to the living quarters, food supply and treatment at the hands of the camp authorities'.

Last night Arthur Titherington, chairman of the Japanese Labour Camp Survivors' Association, said: 'These descriptions are absolutely reprehensible and are as far from the truth as you can possibly imagine.

'If there was any suspicion that a prisoner had a radio they were executed, let alone getting daily copies of the Nippon Times. As for raising animals for food, most survivors I know were lucky to get three cups of rice a day and many died of starvation.'

Last week Titherington led a demonstration outside the Japanese Embassy in London on the 55th anniversary of VJ Day, to demand compensation and an apology.

Of the 46,000 PoWs who slaved to build the Burma Railway, 16,000 died after subsisting on one bowl of rice a day. Out of the 50,000 prisoners taken into Japanese camps, only 38,000 survived.

fields.headline: News in brief
fields.body:
No clemency for jailed Brit

The parents of the British activist James Mawdsley, 27, sentenced to 17 years in Burma for distributing pro-democracy pamphlets, spoke of their shock and anger after hearing that a court had turned down his appeal for clemency. Burmese officials have said there is little chance of a change of heart, since Mawdsley had already been pardoned twice after earlier offences.

Plea for kidnapped worker

The family of British oil worker Alistair Taylor, 45, kidnapped in Colombia a year ago by the National Liberation Front, issued a new appeal for his release. He was working for a US company.

Monopoly on Irish identity

Ireland's Nigerian-born Monopoly champion, Ekumdayo Badmus, has adopted the name O'Badmus for the Toronto world championships.

Dog's home

After spending 12 of his 13 years in a Gateshead refuge, mongrel Sandy has found a new home in Lutterworth, Leicestershire.

Students sue over results chaos

Numerous claims for compensation are expected to be made by some of the 5,000 Scottish students whose Higher and Certificate of Sixth Year Studies results were wrong or incomplete. As many as 2,000 are expected still not to know by tomorrow if they have the grades they need for university places.

Brawling couple divert jet

A British Airways jumbo jet from Los Angeles to Heathrow was forced to divert to Chicago after an American married couple traded punches. They were detained by police. The plane arrived at its destination three hours late.

Bonnie Prince stones stay

The National Trust for Scotland says there is no question of moving the celebrated Glenfinnan Monument at the head of Loch Shiel, said to mark the spot where Bonnie Prince Charlie launched the 1745 Rising, even though a local historian says it was erected in the wrong place. Carved stones a quarter of a mile away were uncovered by a moorland fire.

fields.headline: World in brief
fields.body:
Serb police in gunfight with Albanians on Kosovo border

Gunfire broke out near the border separating Kosovo province from the rest of Serbia when ethnic Albanian militants with automatic rifles battled Serbian police. The firefight lasted two hours.

Sri Lankan press bans to stay

Sri Lanka's government has rejected demands from newspaper editors that media censorship be suspended for forthcoming parliamentary elections. A spokesman said the censorship only concerned sensitive military information and therefore did not need to be lifted.

Nine killed after elections

At least nine people were killed and dozens injured in post-election violence between factions allied to the ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party in Chimalhuacan, an impoverished community on the outskirts of Mexico City. Shots were fired, petrol bombs thrown and cars burned.

Villagers kill man-eating tiger

Angry villagers hacked to death a Royal Bengal tiger with spears, axes and sticks after it killed a man and two cows on the fringe of the Sundarban forests in Bangladesh. Tigers, a protected species, killed at least 25 people last year, mostly wood-cutters, fishermen and honey-gatherers.

Flood torrent drowns 36

At least 36 people drowned in the central Indian state of Madhya Pradesh when a swollen river swept away a bus. Many others were still missing. Some had climbed trees and were awaiting rescue.

Newt Gingrich marries again

Former US House Speaker Newt Gingrich and his one-time congressional aide Callista Bisek were married in a private ceremony in a hotel courtyard just outside Washington DC.

It was the third marriage for Gingrich, 57, and the first for his 34-year-old bride.

fields.headline: The world's most deadly bubble
fields.standfirst: An explosion of lethal gas from a Cameroon lake killed 1,700 people. Scientists are racing to prevent a worse disaster, reports  Robin McKie
fields.trailText: The scene that lay before Mohammed Musa Abdulahi was one of devastation. His village - Subum in western Cameroon - was littered with bodies: humans, dogs, and cattle. Even bird and insect corpses lay scattered around.
fields.body:
The scene that lay before Mohammed Musa Abdulahi was one of devastation. His village - Subum in western Cameroon - was littered with bodies: humans, dogs, and cattle. Even bird and insect corpses lay scattered around.

Mohammed ran to his father's house, where he found all 11 members of his family dead. Each was a victim of lethal gas that had erupted from nearby Lake Nyos on the evening of 21 August, 1986. A total of 1,700 people perished as a cloud of carbon dioxide poured at 50mph down valleys that led from the crater lake, suffocating everything in its path.

Scientists now fear a similar calamity is about to engulf the countryside. 'Over the past decade, gas has built up to an extremely dangerous level inside Lake Nyos, and also in nearby Lake Manoun,' said US geologist Professor George Kling of Michigan University, the leader of an international research team investigating the lakes. 'There is now more than twice as much carbon dioxide in Nyos than there was in 1986. This is a time bomb primed to explode.'

However, local people remain as vulnerable as they were in 1986 to the killing lakes of this poverty-stricken country.

Indeed, geologists fear that this time more than 10,000 could die, for a dam on Lake Nyos's northern edge, if destroyed by an eruption, would release a surge of water that could reach the Nigerian border 50 miles away.

The only solution, say Kling and his colleagues, is to try to pump out the deadly gas dissolved in Lake Nyos and release it gradually into the atmosphere. Work on such project is set to begin in the next few weeks, although Kling acknowledges the undertaking will require pin-point precision to avoid disturbing the lake so badly that it releases all its carbon dioxide in another single catastrophic burst. 'It is tricky, but we are confident,' he told The Observer.

The idea that Lake Nyos could cause widespread death is hard to appreciate, given its beauty. As Marguerite Holloway states in a recent Scientific American article: 'Nyos is a stunning lake, surrounded by cultivated fields, cathedral-like rock faces and verdant hills.'

This charm is deceptive. Gas-rich water accumulates at the bottom of the lake and slowly gets richer and richer in carbon dioxide, thus becoming more and more unstable. Eventually this layer of water is disturbed - by a landslide or a storm, for example - and rises to the surface. As it moves upwards, it releases its carbon dioxide in a violent cascade.

Carbon dioxide is heavier than air and after it pours over the top of the crater lake, it hugs the ground in invisible suffocating waves that follow the contours of the countryside.

Entire villages are overcome while pockets often form in ravines where they persist for days, suffocating animals, and occasionally humans, who stumble into them. 'The lake is essentially like a bottle of beer that has been shaken up,' said Kling. 'When you open it, carbon dioxide bubbles up, and the beer froths over. A glassful is okay. A lakeful is deadly.'

More than 30 people living around Lake Monoun died in such an eruption in August, 1984, which provided a grim taste of the devastation that would strike Nyos two years later.

But now scientists are hoping they can break this cycle of death.They have designed a system to release the carbon dioxide from Nyos and Monoun, and in a few weeks, they will begin to transport equipment and start to construct their de-gassing plants.

One end of a six-inch-wide polyethylene pipe will be lowered to the bottom of each lake. Then engineers will begin to pump up water. 'As the water rises, the pressure will drop and the carbon dioxide will burst out of solution,' added Kling. 'The gas will rush up the tube, effectively creating an self-siphoning system.'

Instead of carbon dioxide boiling out of the lake, a gentle fountain will slowly disgorge its deadly dissolved cargo at the surface. 'We would need to run four or five pipes for two years to get rid of all the gas in Lake Nyos. However, one will be sufficient to reduce the carbon dioxide content to a far safer level and thus prevent disaster - provided we can get the thing started in time.'

fields.headline: On the market
fields.body:
Foreign & Colonial New@sia Fund

Contact 020 7628 1234 or your independent adviser

Aim To generate capital growth by investing in the Asian 'new economy', including shares through Initial Public Offers.

Bells & whistles Foreign & Colonial says Asian markets have remained undervalued since the Asian crisis. 'New Asia', which includes health, retailing and internet companies, is still in its early stages and Japan, as the second-biggest global economy, is experiencing a structural change that will become the catalyst for further developments in Asia.

How it works New@sia is a sub-fund of F&C's Luxembourg-based New Economy, an open-ended fund similar in operation to a unit trust. It currently has 25 per cent of assets in Hong Kong and China, 6 per cent in India, 5 per cent in Singapore, 65 per cent in Japan and the balance in other markets. Japan will soon be reduced to 60 per cent to enable 5 per cent to be invested in Korea. About 5 per cent is invested in shares obtained through IPOs. The fund has been running for several months, with 30 million euros of institutional money, and is now being offered to ordinary investors in the UK, Germany, Italy and Spain. It is denominated in euros, with a current price of €4.71 per share. The fund will be run by 10 managers, headed by F&C's director of Japanese equities, Stefan Rheinwald.

Minimum €2,500

Charges Initial charge 5 per cent, management charge 1 per cent, plus a performance fee of 20 per cent of the outperformance if the fund exceeds its benchmark. This is set at an absolute performance target of 20 per cent a year.

Tax No Isa is offered, so gains may be liable to capital gains tax when brought back into the UK.

Risk High

Should you invest? Andrew Miles of Thomson Financial Planning in Leeds, is wary. 'Asian markets are particularly susceptible to changes in the US economy. This is not a core holding. I doubt whether we would recommend it to more than half a dozen of our 15,000 clients. A new economy fund is fine, but we would prefer a global approach.'

In contrast, Chris Macdonald of London adviser Brooks Macdonald Gayer says it's not a bad time to launch this type of fund. But he thinks the performance-related fee should be paid if the fund matches or beats the performance of one index or possibly an average of two or more, rather than a fixed target of 20 per cent. 'A set benchmark like this could mean that you end up paying an extra fee even if the fund managers underperform the indices for this region,' he says.

Points out of 10 Miles - 7, Macdonald - 7.

fields.headline: Cashpoints
fields.trailText:
The saving rush
The threat of a housing market crash has scared the nation into saving, according to Abbey National. In a survey of 2,000 people, the mortgage bank found total savings in the first quarter of the year were up 18 per cent on the same period last year, from £12.7bn to £15bn. Abbey says after seeing property prices rocket, people want the safety net provided by savings . They are also worried about interest rates rising. Other factors prompting people to hoard their money during the first quarter were the Isa season, strong wage increases and the saving of annual and Christmas bonuses.

The equaliser

Coventry Building Society is equalising rates on its Isas and Tessas. It is cutting rates on its Square Deal Isa by 0.2 per cent to 6.85 per cent while the rate paid on its Tessa and follow-up Tessa will be raised to 6.85 per cent. The changes will apply to all customers. Coventry believes savers object to the disparity between the two types of account.

Costa mortgage

Norwich and Peterborough Building Society is launching a fixed-rate mortgage, at 6.24 per cent for two years, for people who want to set up home on the Costa del Sol. The limited edition mortgage is fixed at 6.24 per cent for two years after which it reverts to the lender's standard Spanish homeloan rate, currently 8 per cent. Up to 65 per cent of the purchase price can be borrowed. Tel: 01733 372 006.

fields.headline: Bursary aid down to a tee
fields.standfirst: Neasa MacErlean on sources of extra cash for students
fields.trailText: There is a parish in Scotland which gives a bursary each year to a Scottish student studying in Scotland who agrees not to touch drink. The sum is only £16 - but that could keep you in mineral water for a while.
fields.body:
There is a parish in Scotland which gives a bursary each year to a Scottish student studying in Scotland who agrees not to touch drink. The sum is only £16 - but that could keep you in mineral water for a while.

Even if you have ruled yourself out for that one, there are many other grants, scholarships and bursaries on offer - about 85,000 in fact, totalling about £100 million, according to Freefund (www.freefund.com), a dotcom which specialises in matching students with these awards.

But there are obstacles. Katie Norton of the National Union of Students says: 'The problem is that people don't know these bursaries are out there. And even if they do find out about them, they can be disheartened by a long application process.'

Wealthy individuals sometimes leave legacies to support people in difficult circumstances through education. There is the occasional bequest to help people with the same surname, and sometimes money is available to help people from a particular background - stable lads, for example, or women over 60. And there are many, very old bursaries which may have run beyond their sell-by date - such as the barrel of herrings provided once a year to a student in Sweden, a bursary discovered by Freefund.

But if Swedish herrings do not appeal, there are many more mainstream sources of help. Choose your course carefully, however. You are far more likely to find a bursary in engineering, sport or music than in English or geography. A shortage of engineering graduates means the Government and employers are eager to support those choosing this. There is a laser firm in Leicestershire, for instance, which provides half a dozen scholarships a year, each worth about £1,500, to local school leavers studying engineering.

Many sport and music scholarships are funded for the greater glory of the academic institution. 'Sports scholarships are extremely popular,' says Jamal Benmiloud of Freefund. 'Universities want to encourage people with exceptional talent to represent them.'

The high profile of the Oxford and Cambridge boat race each year shows just how useful good rowers are to the universities. But years before the boat race started, the universities were using organists, choristers and other musicians for similar purposes.

If you are looking for a scholarship or bursary, start by contacting your local education authority and the university you are applying to.

Some universities are keen to help students. De Montfort University, based in Bedford, Leicester, Lincoln and Milton Keynes, set up a scholarship fund two years ago to attract funding from local employers and others. However, Professor Mike Brown, pro-vice chancellor, encourages students to make their own contacts with employers: 'Write to them on spec. The big companies are looking for people with a bit of spark.'

Julie Hepburn of Cardiff University Careers Service tells a similar tale. She says many large employers will give some financial assistance to people who do work placements with them before or during university. 'Firms are using work placements as a way of spotting high-flyers,' she says.

While some employers expect the student to work for them on graduation, many give grants with no strings attached. But Hepburn warns potential applicants to start making their plans soon. 'Some of the closing dates for these schemes are as early as November,' she says.

Schools inspector Chris Woodhead may have attacked universities for providing golf management courses, but many universities clearly see golf as a legitimate area of focus. At least seven universities offer golf scholarships. St Andrew's makes one award of £3,750; Strathclyde offers eight scholarships of up to £250 a year each. Studying Anglo-Saxon may bring more academic kudos but if you cannot make ends meet, perhaps the 18 holes are worth a look.

But there are obstacles. Katie Norton of the National Union of Students says: 'The problem is that people don't know these bursaries are out there. And even if they do find out about them, they can be disheartened by a long application process.' Wealthy individuals sometimes leave legacies to support people in difficult circumstances through education. There is the occasional bequest to help people with the same surname, and sometimes money is available to help people from a particular background - stable lads, for example, or women over 60. And there are many, very old bursaries which may have run beyond their sell-by date - such as the barrel of herrings provided once a year to a student in Sweden, a bursary discovered by Freefund. But if Swedish herrings do not appeal, there are many more mainstream sources of help. Choose your course carefully, however. You are far more likely to find a bursary in engineering, sport or music than in English or geography. A shortage of engineering graduates means the Government and employers are eager to support those choosing this. There is a laser firm in Leicestershire, for instance, which provides half a dozen scholarships a year, each worth about £1,500, to local school leavers studying engineering. Many sport and music scholarships are funded for the greater glory of the academic institution. 'Sports scholarships are extremely popular,' says Jamal Benmiloud of Freefund. 'Universities want to encourage people with exceptional talent to represent them.' The high profile of the Oxford and Cambridge boat race each year shows just how useful good rowers are to the universities. But years before the boat race started, the universities were using organists, choristers and other musicians for similar purposes. If you are looking for a scholarship or bursary, start by contacting your local education authority and the university you are applying to. Some universities are keen to help students. De Montfort University, based in Bedford, Leicester, Lincoln and Milton Keynes, set up a scholarship fund two years ago to attract funding from local employers and others. However, Professor Mike Brown, pro-vice chancellor, encourages students to make their own contacts with employers: 'Write to them on spec. The big companies are looking for people with a bit of spark.' Julie Hepburn of Cardiff University Careers Service tells a similar tale. She says many large employers will give some financial assistance to people who do work placements with them before or during university. 'Firms are using work placements as a way of spotting high-flyers,' she says. While some employers expect the student to work for them on graduation, many give grants with no strings attached. But Hepburn warns potential applicants to start making their plans soon. 'Some of the closing dates for these schemes are as early as November,' she says. Schools inspector Chris Woodhead may have attacked universities for providing golf management courses, but many universities clearly see golf as a legitimate area of focus. At least seven universities offer golf scholarships. St Andrew's makes one award of £3,750; Strathclyde offers eight scholarships of up to £250 a year each. Studying Anglo-Saxon may bring more academic kudos but if you cannot make ends meet, perhaps the 18 holes are worth a look.

fields.headline: Do we need a cure for this glut of therapists?
fields.trailText: The UK may be in love with therapy (Life, last week), but what a pity that so many therapists are in love with power.
fields.body:
The UK may be in love with therapy (Life, last week), but what a pity that so many therapists are in love with power.

Maureen Rice's references to therapy being in deep trouble masked the extent to which her article was a salvo in the shameless turf wars being fought out in the therapy industry. The psychoanalytic/medical bias of her article mirrors the psychoanalytic world's continuing efforts to dominate psychotherapy, most recently, as Maureen Rice outlined, through Lord Alderdice's proposals for statutory regulation. Present and potential users of therapy should know that the form of regulation he proposes will extend the much criticised 'consultant culture' of medicine to an area where it is neither relevant nor appropriate.
Denis Postle
London W4

Maureen Rice says that therapy includes 'psychiatry, psychology, psychotherapy and counselling'.

This is a problematic conflation. Each of these disciplines has a different orientation and training, frequently with its own concept of 'cure'.

For example, a psychiatrist is very likely to have a different attitude to what she is doing because they are first and foremost working within a 'medical model', whereas a psychoanalytic psychotherapist is not.

Even the concept of 'cure' is a matter of debate within some (psychoanalytic) psychotherapies.
Angela Kreeger
London N13

The leading and largest organisation for counselling and psychotherapy in the United Kingdom, the British Association for Counselling, has nearly 25,000 individual and organisational members, about a third of whom hold a psychotherapy qualification.

Those belonging to BAC are properly supervised and subject to appropriate complaints and disciplinary procedures. Those accredited with BAC have undergone a minimum of 450 hours training plus 450 hours of supervised practice. Our message to the public is pure and simple - why visit the untrained? We urgently need regulation of the entire field and BAC urges the Government to attempt nothing less.
Phillip Hodson
Rugby

The British Confederation of Psychotherapists register only lists psychoanalytic and Jungian analytic therapists from a small number of organisations. It is the United Kingdom Council (not confederation) for Psychotherapy whose member organisations and registered therapists include not only psychoanalytic therapists but also family therapists, marital and sexual therapists, cognitive and behavioural therapists and humanistic therapists.
Penny Jaques
Oxford

webTitle: Blundering bank pays £3,800 for U-turn on pensioner's cash

fields.headline: Blundering bank pays £3,800 for U-turn on pensioner's cash
fields.standfirst: Has your bank, building society or insurer treated you badly? We seek justice for our readers
fields.trailText: Has your bank, building society or insurer treated you badly? We seek justice for our readers
fields.body:
For more than 20 years, I have paid into two separate Barclays pension policies, now worth £130,000. In the past few years, my health has been indifferent, and I decided to retire. I had no problems transferring my various other pensions to buy a Friends Provident annuity, but Barclays insists I pay an early with drawal premium of £2,000 for each one.

Friends Provident queried this with Barclays and was told that, in the circumstances, the exit charges would not apply. Seven days later, Friends Provident told me Barclays had changed tack and insisted that I do pay. I am deeply unhappy about this.

KG, Carluke

Barclays deducts the cost of the policy through 'initial' units. Your first few years' contributions buy only this type of unit which, throughout the life of the policy, attract higher charges until, on retirement day, you have paid the lot. Because you wanted to activate the pension before the age on the policy, Barclays imposed a fee to recoup the charges it reckoned you still owed.

But someone at Barclays' call centre mistakenly misled the Friends Provident adviser by giving him the current value, not the (lower) transfer value, of your pension. Barclays knows this because it has found a recording of the conversation. It has now agreed to pay you the difference between the two pension values. As you have already taken the pension, you will receive £3,824 with which to buy another annuity or go on a spending spree.

Credit note limit: Knickerbox block

My husband bought me underwear from Knickerbox last year but the bra was the wrong size. I returned the set and was given a credit note. I queried the three-month time limit printed on the note but was told not to worry as the note would be renewed if it ran out before I used it.

When I attempted to renew it, however, the note was kept and Knickerbox refused to give me another. In effect, they have had £16 of ours for nothing.

After one terse letter which restates that the credit note is valid for only three months, all attempts to contact them have been ignored. What can I do?

DL, London

Shoppers have no legal right to return goods just because they do not fit or they dislike the colour but, for the sake of good customer relations, many shops will exchange goods.

Knickerbox, now owned by Ann Summers, says it will exchange unworn underwear for any reason within 14 days of purchase, and thereafter gives a credit note. It will extend the note for a further three months if there has been a good reason why you could not use it sooner.

As you were misled into believing you could extend the credit note, you have cause to complain and the store should have passed you on to the customer services department. I have explained this, and it is now expecting your call.

Equitable Life: Should I leave?

I am 75 in October and must therefore take up my Equitable Life personal pension which I started in 1990. Should I exercise the open market option with another company, as Equitable seems to be in confusion? Or should I take an annuity with Equitable in case, by staying as a member, I might share in any distribution resulting from a sale of the company?

CP, Lustleigh

Equitable Life with-profits policyholders earned no annual bonus for the first seven months of this year but this loss will be made up when the company is sold. If by then you have another company's annuity, you will still get the shortfall when it is paid. There might also be a windfall payment from the sale but only if you are still a member. To qualify, you would have to buy a with-profits annuity from Equitable. If you have an Equitable guaranteed option, this would pay more than other annuities but without a widow's benefit, so you might not think it worthwhile. To help you decide if staying is best, get quotes from several annuity providers, or talk to a specialist annuity adviser.

Equitable's memorandum of sale goes out tomorrow, and potential purchasers should be known by the end of the year.

Selling life cover: The wrong policy

I have a whole-life plan with Axa Equity & Law which began in 1993. I wish to surrender the policy and have contacted the company for a quote. I tried to sell it through the second-hand market but was told that, as my policy is not an endowment, they were not interested. Is there anyone who will deal in this sort of policy?

JD, Londonderry

You can often get a better price for life insurance policies if, as you tried, you sell on to another investor. This is mainly for endowment policies but you can sell whole-life policies if they are with-profits policies and the insurer allows them to be converted to endowment. There is no market for unit-linked whole-life policies which, unfortunately, yours is.

Writeback: Who's stupid?

SK of Southport fears he may be 'seriously stupid' after his recent dealings with the financial services sector.

'I like to think of myself as passably intelligent, but Friends Provident tells me that my endowment is underperforming and then sends me a glossy annual report trumpeting its achievements. Scottish Life guarantees that, if I pay an additional £8 a month, I will get back less than I put in, in 11 years' time. In addition, they will deduct £31 to pay an advise, whether or not I consult one.

'When I was about seven, I learned that, if someone is top of the class, someone else must be at the bottom but I discover that all Isas, without exception, are top, and most have been selected for some award or commendation.

'Also, the organisations which run them are the nonpareils of the sector.'

fields.headline: Cashpoints
fields.body:
Fund entry is free

Investment manager Henderson is to offer entry to its 25 funds at no initial cost. Charges on conventional unit trusts can be as high as 5 per cent. The new Henderson system, operated through the creation of a new class of share, will have annual management fees that are 0.5 per cent higher than levied conventional funds. Annual fees can have a significant impact on fund growth, and the Henderson funds will also levy exit charges on investors who pull out within six years. Graham Hooper, of independent adviser Chase de Vere, says such charges will hit people who pull out early, but small investors should be investing for at least five years anyway. Henderson's performance is generally good, he adds. Tel: 0800 881144 or visit www. henderson.com.

Don't haggle

Haggling when you are on holiday could keep local traders in poverty warns Tearfund, the Christian relief and development agency. Tearfund, Britain's sixth largest aid agency, promotes 'ethical tourism' and urges tourists to pay a fair price for goods.

Rental buoyancy

The rented property market has remained buoyant in the past year, with a healthy balance between supply and demand in most areas, according to the Association of Residential Letting Agents(Arla). Arla, which polled its 600 members for its annual survey, found shortages of 'good quality' property to let in only some central London areas and the home counties. It says the growth in the rental market, around 0.5 per cent over the year, is mirrored by the continuing interest in buy-to-let property. Prices of such properties have risen by 13 per cent in the past year compared with 8 per cent for owner-occupied homes. The survey also highlights a continuing bias against housing benefit tenants: seven out of 10 agents advised landlords not to accept them.

webTitle: Football therapy is the goal at Tony Adams' clinic for addicts

fields.headline: Football therapy is the goal at Tony Adams' clinic for addicts
fields.standfirst: Premiership stars with drink, drug and gambling problems need to have their own treatment centre, says the England hero
fields.trailText: Premiership stars with drink, drug and gambling problems need to have their own treatment centre, says the England hero.
fields.body:
For years he epitomised the traditional British footballer who played hard on a Saturday afternoon and then drank just as hard on a Saturday night. Wrapping his car around a lamp-post after having a few beers at a barbecue, and earning himself a prison sentence for his antics, won Tony Adams a prominent place in football's overcrowded hall of shame.

But now the Arsenal and England centre-half is preparing to confirm his dramatic recovery from alcoholism by opening an addiction treatment centre for fellow players who end up hooked on drink, drugs or gambling.

Adams - who is 33, and who has just celebrated four years without a drink - plans to create a safe haven where big-name, well-paid stars can get specialist help with their problems, away from the limelight. He believes that such a haven would help players afraid to tackle their addictions to find the courage finally to confront their demons.

'I want to provide a safe place, a place of hope and trust,' he told The Observer . 'I think a lot of players are reluctant to come forward because of the stigma attached to the disease and because they think it will damage their careers. This could help. I think managers and clubs might also be more willing to let their players go to a centre like this.'

Adams, who is likely to be named as England's new captain to replace Alan Shearer on Thursday, would help patients settle into the rehabilitation clinic by using his own successful battle against alcohol as proof of what can be achieved. He and other players such as Paul Merson, Paul Gascoigne and Stan Collymore have all fought highly public battles against addiction, depression and illness, and some have stayed at the Priory clinic.

Adams is aiming to open a 12-bed facility in the next 18 months. Recent negotiations to buy a country house in Essex fell through, and he is again looking for a suitable venue. He will invest his own money in the project and has also received the promise of financial backing from an unnamed wealthy sympathiser.

The clinic would be loosely modelled on Crossroads, the rehabilitation centre established in Antigua by rock star Eric Clapton, who battled cocaine and alcohol addiction. Adams believes players would feel comfortable talking to him upon arrival, and then qualified experts would run the clinic on a day-to-day basis.

Residents would sleep in four-bed dormitories rather than the single private rooms found in other centres, in a deliberate attempt to combat the isolation which often accompanies addiction. Mobile phones would be banned. Football training would carry on as normal.

'There are some very good treatment centres, but I'm not sure some of them understand how and why it is important for players to stay physically fit during their treatment,' Adams said.

'A football club might be more keen to let a player go into an environment that is football-related, rather than just suppress the problem or shift the player onto another club.'

The centre will have a football pitch in its grounds, a weights and fitness room and an indoor swimming pool. Addiction counsellors would supervise group therapy sessions based on the Twelve Steps practised by Alcoholics Anonymous, while a physiologist would oversee the players' physical conditioning. 'It will be a place for mind, body and soul,' Adams said.

Regular attendance at groups such as AA, Narcotics, Gamblers and Overeaters Anonymous would be a condition of attendance.

Adams thinks his planned centre could have helped stars such as George Best, Diego Maradona and Gascoigne - and still could. 'I've seen too many players come to the end of their careers before they do anything about their problems,' he said. 'I wish I had got recovery ten years ago.'

Patients, who may include other sports stars, would receive counselling on issues raised by wealth and celebrity, which have grown alongside football's booming popularity but which receive little sympathy in society at large.

Adams is a changed man from the early days of his football career, when he often went on huge drinking binges with team mates such as Paul Merson. 'My whole world seemed to centre around drink', he said.

These days he plays the piano, reads Shakespeare and rejoices in the fact that he can spend all day in a bar sipping only Perrier water.

His transformation into Britain's best-known recovered alcoholic means other players with drink problems now sometimes approach him privately for advice. Addicted , his acclaimed autobiography, has sold more than 400,000 copies.

Both the Football Association and Professional Footballers Association, which represents Britain's 3,000 players, have welcomed Adams's plan. Alan Hodson, the Football Association's medical chief, offered Adams the use of its specialist medical facility at Lilleshall in Shropshire, but the Arsenal captain believes players would prefer to attend an independent centre.

Gordon Taylor, who is the PFA's general secretary, said: 'It's typical of Tony Adams that he now wants to pass on the benefit of his experience to help other players. As a footballer he has done extremely well, and as a man he has succeeded in overcoming some difficult problems.

'The pressures of the modern game mean young players are put into the spotlight, where they have never been before. Some cope well with it. Others don't, and they can turn to alcohol, drugs or gambling. An addictive personality can go off the rails. Tony Adams has seen how easily that can happen.'

Taylor hoped there would not be a big demand for places in Adams's clinic, but admitted that every year the PFA helps players and ex-players facing such problems, and pays for some to attend the Priory.

He said that British football's notorious heavy drinking culture was waning and that mineral water was now the most common drink in players' lounges after matches and also at football club functions.

But Liverpool legend Tommy Smith, who played at Anfield from 1964-78, said some players - British rather than foreign - still went drinking on a Saturday, and even a Friday, night.

'Because players are paid so much now, they're meant to look after themselves properly, but some rebel against that,' he said.

Sports Minister Kate Hoey welcomed Adams's plan, saying: 'Sports personalities do have extra pressures on them when dealing with personal problems. Tony has shown how these can be overcome, and his involvement in this project will make it a lot easier for other players to come forward to seek help.'

Alan Hodson, the Football Association's medical chief, offered Adams the use of its specialist medical facility at Lilleshall in Shropshire, but the Arsenal captain believes players would prefer to attend an independent centre. Gordon Taylor, who is the PFA's general secretary, said: 'It's typical of Tony Adams that he now wants to pass on the benefit of his experience to help other players. As a footballer he has done extremely well, and as a man he has succeeded in overcoming some difficult problems. 'The pressures of the modern game mean young players are put into the spotlight, where they have never been before. Some cope well with it. Others don't, and they can turn to alcohol, drugs or gambling. An addictive personality can go off the rails. Tony Adams has seen how easily that can happen.' Taylor hoped there would not be a big demand for places in Adams's clinic, but admitted that every year the PFA helps players and ex-players facing such problems, and pays for some to attend the Priory. He said that British football's notorious heavy drinking culture was waning and that mineral water was now the most common drink in players' lounges after matches and also at football club functions. But Liverpool legend Tommy Smith, who played at Anfield from 1964-78, said some players - British rather than foreign - still went drinking on a Saturday, and even a Friday, night. 'Because players are paid so much now, they're meant to look after themselves properly, but some rebel against that,' he said. Sports Minister Kate Hoey welcomed Adams's plan, saying: 'Sports personalities do have extra pressures on them when dealing with personal problems. Tony has shown how these can be overcome, and his involvement in this project will make it a lot easier for other players to come forward to seek help.'

webTitle: Now is the time to bet on sport

fields.headline: From Hades to happiness
fields.trailText: Now is the time to bet on sport. The conditions have never been more favourable for making big money from punting on pastimes. At the track, you don't have to pay any tax. And if you bet with the spread betting firms the tax is included in the spread.
fields.body:
Now is the time to bet on sport. The conditions have never been more favourable for making big money from punting on pastimes. At the track, you don't have to pay any tax. And if you bet with the spread betting firms the tax is included in the spread.

This prudent Chancellor is happy for sensible sports investors to keep their winnings. Compare and contrast with those fools who invest in What.com and the like. They have to pay dealing costs and when they pick a winner shell out 40 per cent in capital gains tax. A fair and reasonable levy to restrain such reckless gambling.

The differing treatment goes back to the courts being unwilling to sully their hands by dealing with filthy gambling disputes. 'Bets are legally unenforceable,' the judges decreed. And so it continued until the early Fifties when Churchill's government attempted to tax professional gamblers. Stupidly, they didn't ring-fence the provision to ensure that gambling losses could only be offset against gambling profits. Every butcher, baker and candlestick maker promptly claimed to be a pro gambler and set off their betting losses against the money they had made from meat, bread and wax. The government gave up.

Since then, betting shops were allowed to open so long as they resembled Hades. And everything was fine until Black Monday when some young speculators managed to do all their dough and then some. The Footsie fell hundreds and hundreds of points and the whippersnappers lost hundreds and hundreds of times their money. Decision time for Their Lordships. It is traditionally argued that hard cases make bad law, but in truth it is when the judges' prejudices come into play that duff judgments are spouted. They hummed and they hawed. It looked like gambling but it was done on the stock exchange. So it couldn't be gambling because if it was then... then... everything would be gambling. And then they'd be in a pickle.

To avoid such a fate they found that, despite all appearances to the contrary, the young guns hadn't been gambling, their debts were therefore enforceable and they should pay up promptly. They covered up this faulty logic by pointing out that the spread-betting firms were regulated by the Financial Services Act just like stockbrokers et al. Irrelevant, but sufficient.

You might have thought that it would follow from this that monies made from spread betting should be subject to capital gains tax just like monies made from other activities regulated by the FSA. Not a bit of it. 'A lot of people ask me that if it's [a spread bet] enforceable then why isn't it subject to Capital Gains Tax?' says Stuart Wheeler, head of IG Index, grandfather of spread betting, professional bridge player, and all-round shrewdie. 'But there is no connection between the two. Nor is it likely that the bets will be subject to tax in the future because the idea of making people pay tax on any betting profits is not a popular one and certainly not an election winner.'

The absence of CGT has saved Philip Peters, the star of Tuesday's edition of the much-improved Jackpot television series, a quarter of a million or so in tax because in the past five years he made £600,000 from spread betting. Peters' career has been picaresque. Here is his CV with, admittedly, somewhat sketchy dates:

1958-1963: Regular employment.

1963: Ceases regular employment.

1964: Having raised his stake money betting on photo-finishes at Reading dogs, realises that good money can be made backing second favourites each-way when there is a long odds-on favourite. 'You'd be getting 6-4 against when it should be 3-1 on,' says Peters.

1965-67: Works out way to make money on the Tote. 'When the bookies opened they would take any bet on anything and there was no minimum dividend. So if a dog was 8-1 on you'd get the same price for a place. There was nothing very clever about it.'

1967-72: Refines system and becomes heavily involved in Tote rigging. 'I was betting at Hastings dogs one afternoon and realised how little money was gambled on the place pool. It cost me very little to increase the minimum dividend and it worked very well.'

1972-77: Becomes very heavily involved in Tote rigging. 'I had 80 OAPs up and down the country working for me betting 12 of the straight forecast combinations off the track and we were betting the others at the track. We made a lot of money.'

1982: Wife nags him into getting a proper job on grounds of 'status'. He invests in a company making plastic containers for then new-in-the-kitchen microwave ovens. Dumb move. 'I'm the only person I know who got all his money from gambling and lost it all in straight business.'

1982-94: A bad dozen years.

1994: Introduced to spread betting. 'All I had was three years' worth of Racing Posts .'

1994-2000: Cleans up.

He has made his money primarily from betting on the spreads offered on horse-race distances, but has also trousered tidy sums from betting on the bookings index and the corners index. On all three markets he has sold. His reasoning is simple. Most punters find it psychologically soothing for their downside to be limited and their upside to be unlimited. They know exactly how much they can lose and can dream about how much they might win.

On the horse-race distances, about 19 out of 20 players would be buyers. Peters, a contrarian at heart, went the other way and turned nothing into £200,000. He has bad days - there have been a couple of £40,000 losses - but most days are good. He has used the same principles to win on corners and bookings. He has made healthy profits by taking the 'uncomfortable position' where you win a little often and lose a lot rarely and come out on top.

On the bookings index, in particular, he has been helped by the usual tabloid hype about card-crazy referees. The punters, whipped into a frenzy as effectively as Rebekah Wade inciting the unthinking majority, can't help themselves and buy away. The market is distorted. As Toby Brereton, chief market-maker at IG Index, says: 'Opposing hype is an extremely good tool for any bettor.' The latest market to attract the Peters Principle has been the time of Premiership goals. The spread makers have underestimated the number of goals in a match and therefore gone too high on the time of the opening goal. Once again, he has been selling and winning as the foolish crowd buy in the hope of that elusive big win.

fields.headline: Shaken Turkey's hopes crumble
fields.standfirst: Maureen Freely visits the Turkish cities devastated a year ago by an earthquake and finds little has changed for the better
fields.trailText: The earthquake that devastated western Turkey a year ago was one of the great disasters of the past 100 years. Official estimates put the deaths at almost 18,000; unofficial ones are much higher.
fields.body:
The earthquake that devastated western Turkey a year ago was one of the great disasters of the past 100 years. Official estimates put the deaths at almost 18,000; unofficial ones are much higher.

The real earthquake was followed by a political earthquake that even had the almighty Turkish military worried for its future. Public fury about its sluggish and unco-ordinated response to the crisis was so great it looked as if the nation was going to rise up and take matters into its own hands. In a previously unimaginable move, 58 organisations across the political spectrum signed a manifesto asking the government to admit defeat and allow 'civil society' to assume responsibility for the earthquake victims.

What happened next? Well, not as much as some might have hoped. For a few weeks the press talked about human rights, public accountability, internationalism, corruption and the fudging of the official casualty figures.

Angry mobs went after the corrupt bureaucrats and construction companies they held responsible for the disaster. A few governors were hounded out of office, along with just about everyone at the top levels of the Turkish Red Crescent. But then, it seems, there were various consultations behind closed doors. Almost all the columnists suddenly remembered that the army was in most ways quite wonderful. Indeed, its response to a smaller earthquake in November was exemplary. By then the government had passed a decree barring most volunteer groups from entering the tent cities. By the end of the year, order had been most definitely restored.

One year on, many Turks say only one good thing has come out of the earthquake: the rapprochement with Greece. Istanbul is packed with Greek tourists. In the ferry stations along the Bosporus are huge banners advertising Turkish Maritime Lines cruises to Kos, Rhodes and the Cyclades.

Last week rather smaller banners went up to advertise events to mark the first anniversary of the disaster. All were locally organised: 'Daddy State' did not get involved. In Adapazari, one of the worst hit cities, no one is surprised. There are rumours that the MP for a neighbouring city set up a tent after the quake to learn what his constituents needed. But consultative government is still a novel idea. Adapazari has four deputies, but I could find only one person who had had any contact with a deputy since the disaster, and that was only to shake his hand.

Although a third of Adapazari's population has left the area and most of its remaining residents expect to be living in 'Japantown', 'Israeltown' and other internationally sponsored prefab compounds in the outskirts for at least another year, it is still a bustling market town, full of new single-storey shopping complexes.

But they are surrounded by the tilting, twisted remains of buildings that should have come down months ago. These are still standing, residents say, because they are tied up in court cases - there are 700 pending in this city alone. No one has been charged or received compensation. It is hard to find anyone who thinks they ever will.

The house that makes them angriest is one that is still standing. It is a large, old wooden house in the centre of the commercial district that once belonged to the city's founding father. When people walk past it these days, some spit at it. There should never have been a city here. The water table is only a metre below the surface. In the nineteenth century, when the Ottomans decided to make a settlement here for Muslim refugees from the Balkans and the Caucasus, the German engineers they asked for advice told them to stay away from the marshes and build on the hills. But the owner of that wooden house was also owner of the marshes. To better line his pockets, he had the city built on his own land.

The new Adapazari, the new assistant governor assured me, was going to be on the hills some 12km away. All the government buildings would be moving there within the year. There were also 7,000 new homes going up, and there would be low- interest loans for those who wanted to build their own. This does not come close to meeting the needs of the city's 200,000 or so remaining inhabitants, but it is a start. And it is undeniable that the local government has looked after its people's basic needs. No one went hungry, and no one was left in the cold. There is a sense of a future here.

Eighty miles away in Golcuk, a much smaller city where the devastation per square metre was probably worst of all, the prevailing mood is despair. According to the manager of an internet café, the bulldozing of condemned buildings stopped five months ago and no one is sure why. The city is a ghost town, he and his patrons agree. It is going to be worse next year when the navy, the city's main employer, moves almost everyone stationed here to the Aegean.

There is only one sign of progress since my last visit in November. Then half of the 'waterfront', including a children's amusement park, was sitting three metres underwater. This was where the fault came in from the sea. When the earthquake happened, there was massive subsidence. By the time of my visit it had become a sort of anti-beauty spot. No tour of the earthquake zone was complete without it. It had become the defining image of the disaster: in the foreground the Ferris wheel rising out of the water; next to it the carousel and the half-nude Spanish dancer on top of the swing ride. In the background, a row of submerged street lamps leading to the roof of the municipal pool. Beyond it, a ship that had run aground.

But now they are busy reclaiming the land from the sea. The Ferris wheel now stands alone on a large stretch of landfill. When the next big earthquake comes, I hope to God that I'm not standing on it.

But at least in Golcuk people are still talking about the wisdom of building low on solid foundations and reliable soil. It is a discussion you do hear now and again in Istanbul, and certainly the rich are moving away from the areas of the city deemed unsound. But even they are still living mostly in high-rises, and although there is a subterranean anxiety about the Big One that experts expect to hit Istanbul some time soon, the skyscrapers keep going up.

The most flamboyant is the 20-plus-storey monstrosity that destroys the skyline behind Dolmabahce Palace on the European shore of the Bosporus. It was built illegally, allegedly by the mafia, which has prospered so much in recent years that it has, also allegedly, become the real power behind the throne. This is another building for people to spit at. But for the time being, there is not much else they can do.

webTitle: Comment, Robert McCrum: Clinton - great President,  rotten human being

fields.headline: A great President, a rotten human being
fields.standfirst: Nothing became Bill Clinton like his going - assertive, triumphant and making gaffes to the last
fields.trailText: Many of those who watched President Clinton's valedictory speech to the Democratic convention in Los Angeles heard the greatest political orator of his day wrap up a mesmerisingly boastful and assertive performance with a curiously self-abnegating farewell sentence.
fields.body:
Many of those who watched President Clinton's valedictory speech to the Democratic convention in Los Angeles heard the greatest political orator of his day wrap up a mesmerisingly boastful and assertive performance with a curiously self-abnegating farewell sentence.

'And remember,' he concluded, 'whatever you think about me, keep putting people first ... I love you and good night.'

But is that what he actually said? No sooner had the next day's papers hit the newsstands, with a swathe of commentators reluctantly acknowledging the President's rhetorical supremacy, than the White House press office put out an urgent correction. The President had emphatically not said 'whatever', it was announced; rather, he used the unambiguously self-satisfied 'whenever'.

For Clinton-watchers, it was a vintage moment. What exactly had we heard? Was it a Freudian slip? Did Clinton mean to say one thing but, stricken by an unexpected rush of conscience, end up improvising something else? Had he finally acknowledged that some voters might be justifiably disillusioned with his character, his equivocations and his failure to fulfil their expectations, only to back-track the next day when he started to brood on the implications of his unforced error of self-analysis?

Or had he meant it all along, seducing his audience with a brilliant tour-de-force recitation of his achievements (balanced budgets, crime-busting, the first steps towards world peace in a variety of hot-spots and record-breaking prosperity), while at the same time managing to gloss over the myriad catastrophes of his administration, from his proposed health-care reforms to the far greater disaster of his relationship with Monica Lewinsky and the other scandals that dogged his term of office - Whitewater, Vince Foster's suicide etc?

The 'whatever' fuss also brought back memories of that low point in Clinton's scandal-ridden second term in which, during his grilling by the special prosecutor, he debated, lawyer-like, the meaning of 'is'.

That the White House cared enough to issue a correction to his speech was telling in another way. Clinton is a President obsessed with his legacy. Few occupants of the White House have been as frank in their admission of job satisfaction. 'To serve as President,' he told the adoring convention delegates last Monday night, 'has been an honour, a privilege, and a joy.' And few have worried so much, perhaps with justification, about their place in the history books.

For the American people, the Clinton presidency has also been an unforgettable time, not least thanks to the millennial boom. But the true measure of their love-hate relationship with him has not, I think, been the astoundingly favourable poll numbers he has recorded, nor the widespread suspicion that if he were to run again, he would beat George Bush hands down.

Politically speaking, Clinton is formidably gifted, as enemies like Newt Gingrich have discovered. Power is a great aphrodisiac, but a remarkable range of normally cool-headed customers attest to Clinton's astounding personality, his rhetorical brilliance and wonk-like grasp of complex issues.

He is exceedingly intelligent and seems all the more so after the shocking stupidity of Ronald Reagan and the gung-ho anti-intellectualism of Bush Senior. It's only a guess, but Clinton must be among the most intelligent men to have occupied the White House in the last 100 years.

That is, however, as nothing compared to his psychological sway over the imaginations of the American people. One index of Clinton's dominance of the psychological landscape has been the remarkable quantity of cinematic fiction inspired by his tenure, from The American President to Independence Day, from Wag the Dog to Absolute Power. And there are many more to come. Clinton has captivated America's creative community, its writers, journalists and filmmakers as no other President in living memory.

It's often said that we live in an age of political pygmies, but here, in our midst, warts and all, is a giant, a psychologically enthralling character, a figure for the playwrights and a man of Shakespearian dimensions. Whatever his place in history turns out to be (either footnote or milestone), there can be little doubt that he will, like that other contemporary American political tragedy, Richard Nixon, provoke a library of political exegesis. There is, indeed, already a shelfload of pro- and anti-Clinton memoirs by ex-Friends of Bill.

Clinton has been a political giant, but a profoundly flawed one. As the New York Times observed after his speech: 'There will always be a sadness that the Clinton record will forever be blotted because his leadership gifts were offset by a self-destructive streak at the centre of his personality.'

The immediate aftermath of Clinton's convention speech has been typical of his time in office. First, there was the language, then there was the interpretation and then the correction. Next came the ugly rumours, crisply reported by the astute and reliable Maureen Dowd. (Bill is mad at Al; Hillary can't stand Tipper.) Finally, there was the reappearance of Clinton's vulnerability to scandal in the form of the reconvened Grand Jury.

To an Americanophile - and I confess to being one - it is a terrible shame. Here we have the spectacle of the most brilliant political performer of his age unable to break free from the prison of his character or from the prison of partisan politics which his genius has inspired.

And yet, to quote the New York Times again: 'For all that, Mr Clinton will go into party history as the only politician of his decade with a personal magnetism and communicative skill to match those of Mr Reagan and Mr Clinton's boyhood idol, John F. Kennedy.'
fields.bodyText: Many of those who watched President Clinton's valedictory speech to the Democratic convention in Los Angeles heard the greatest political orator of his day wrap up a mesmerisingly boastful and assertive performance with a curiously self-abnegating farewell sentence. 'And remember,' he concluded, 'whatever you think about me, keep putting people first ... I love you and good night.' But is that what he actually said? No sooner had the next day's papers hit the newsstands, with a swathe of commentators reluctantly acknowledging the President's rhetorical supremacy, than the White House press office put out an urgent correction. The President had emphatically not said 'whatever', it was announced; rather, he used the unambiguously self-satisfied 'whenever'. For Clinton-watchers, it was a vintage moment. What exactly had we heard? Was it a Freudian slip? Did Clinton mean to say one thing but, stricken by an unexpected rush of conscience, end up improvising something else? Had he finally acknowledged that some voters might be justifiably disillusioned with his character, his equivocations and his failure to fulfil their expectations, only to back-track the next day when he started to brood on the implications of his unforced error of self-analysis? Or had he meant it all along, seducing his audience with a brilliant tour-de-force recitation of his achievements (balanced budgets, crime-busting, the first steps towards world peace in a variety of hot-spots and record-breaking prosperity), while at the same time managing to gloss over the myriad catastrophes of his administration, from his proposed health-care reforms to the far greater disaster of his relationship with Monica Lewinsky and the other scandals that dogged his term of office - Whitewater, Vince Foster's suicide etc? The 'whatever' fuss also brought back memories of that low point in Clinton's scandal-ridden second term in which, during his grilling by the special prosecutor, he debated, lawyer-like, the meaning of 'is'. That the White House cared enough to issue a correction to his speech was telling in another way. Clinton is a President obsessed with his legacy. Few occupants of the White House have been as frank in their admission of job satisfaction. 'To serve as President,' he told the adoring convention delegates last Monday night, 'has been an honour, a privilege, and a joy.' And few have worried so much, perhaps with justification, about their place in the history books. For the American people, the Clinton presidency has also been an unforgettable time, not least thanks to the millennial boom. But the true measure of their love-hate relationship with him has not, I think, been the astoundingly favourable poll numbers he has recorded, nor the widespread suspicion that if he were to run again, he would beat George Bush hands down. Politically speaking, Clinton is formidably gifted, as enemies like Newt Gingrich have discovered. Power is a great aphrodisiac, but a remarkable range of normally cool-headed customers attest to Clinton's astounding personality, his rhetorical brilliance and wonk-like grasp of complex issues. He is exceedingly intelligent and seems all the more so after the shocking stupidity of Ronald Reagan and the gung-ho anti-intellectualism of Bush Senior. It's only a guess, but Clinton must be among the most intelligent men to have occupied the White House in the last 100 years. That is, however, as nothing compared to his psychological sway over the imaginations of the American people. One index of Clinton's dominance of the psychological landscape has been the remarkable quantity of cinematic fiction inspired by his tenure, from The American President to Independence Day, from Wag the Dog to Absolute Power. And there are many more to come. Clinton has captivated America's creative community, its writers, journalists and filmmakers as no other President in living memory. It's often said that we live in an age of political pygmies, but here, in our midst, warts and all, is a giant, a psychologically enthralling character, a figure for the playwrights and a man of Shakespearian dimensions. Whatever his place in history turns out to be (either footnote or milestone), there can be little doubt that he will, like that other contemporary American political tragedy, Richard Nixon, provoke a library of political exegesis. There is, indeed, already a shelfload of pro- and anti-Clinton memoirs by ex-Friends of Bill. Clinton has been a political giant, but a profoundly flawed one. As the New York Times observed after his speech: 'There will always be a sadness that the Clinton record will forever be blotted because his leadership gifts were offset by a self-destructive streak at the centre of his personality.' The immediate aftermath of Clinton's convention speech has been typical of his time in office. First, there was the language, then there was the interpretation and then the correction. Next came the ugly rumours, crisply reported by the astute and reliable Maureen Dowd. (Bill is mad at Al; Hillary can't stand Tipper.) Finally, there was the reappearance of Clinton's vulnerability to scandal in the form of the reconvened Grand Jury. To an Americanophile - and I confess to being one - it is a terrible shame. Here we have the spectacle of the most brilliant political performer of his age unable to break free from the prison of his character or from the prison of partisan politics which his genius has inspired. And yet, to quote the New York Times again: 'For all that, Mr Clinton will go into party history as the only politician of his decade with a personal magnetism and communicative skill to match those of Mr Reagan and Mr Clinton's boyhood idol, John F. Kennedy.'

webTitle: Maria Scott: Standard may not deserve to stay mutual

fields.headline: Standard may not deserve to stay mutual
fields.trailText: Standard Life is facing renewed agitation among policyholders about converting into a public company. Directors must have been cock-a-hoop last week when a squabble broke out among rival campaigners over who should do what, and how.
fields.body:
Standard Life is facing renewed agitation among policyholders about converting into a public company. Directors must have been cock-a-hoop last week when a squabble broke out among rival campaigners over who should do what, and how.

If the would-be challengers don't mount a credible campaign, Standard Life may hang on to its status. But this is not to say it would be deserved. The information management distributed last week was full of waffly insurancespeak.

Standard Life is also having to break bad news to hundreds of thousands of borrowers about possible mortgage shortfalls. It admits that roughly half of those it is writing to as part of an industry-wide 'come-clean' initiative forced by regulators are receiving warnings of possible shortfalls.

This mailshot did not start until after the demutualisation vote, provoking anger among some policyholders. Standard Life is setting up a helpline. It is, it seems, finally acknowledging the need to communicate more vigorously with policyhold ers. This is a step in the right direction, but there is a long way to go.

Wanted: community-spirited individuals to become non-executive directors of a building society. Norwich & Peterborough is inviting local residents to participate in the running of the society.

Historically, society appointments to boards have been 'done deals' involving worthies likely to toe the management line. It may be difficult for N&P to find someone who will challenge management without becoming obstructive, but this is nevertheless a worthwhile experiment.

In another sign of the way that societies are trying to reinvent mutuality, Yorkshire and Britannia are to allow their 4 million member to use each other's branches for payments and withdrawals.

Insurance companies and pension fund managers have a right to feel peeved at the Government's half-baked response to compen sating victims of the Serps scandal. Members of the state top-up pension scheme were not warned that widows' pensions were to be halved from April this year.

It is certainly unfair that the Government is not under the same obligation as private pension operators to inform people about changes to pension benefits.

fields.headline: What's the catch?
fields.trailText: Hargreaves Lansdown, the Bristol independent financial adviser and discount broker, has antagonised a Cash reader by recommending shares in German telecoms giant Deutsche Telekom.
fields.body:
Hargreaves Lansdown, the Bristol independent financial adviser and discount broker, has antagonised a Cash reader by recommending shares in German telecoms giant Deutsche Telekom.

In a leaflet entitled 'The World of Privatisations', sent out in May, Hargreaves Lansdown offered people the chance to invest in the company's new share offer. The broker said: 'There is nothing like a privatisation to focus the minds of management, and the fact that the "public sector culture" has already been reversed to some extent leads us to believe Deutsche Telekom could provide investors with excellent long-term growth prospects.'

The leaflet added that the firm was 'at the heart of a digital revolution reshaping the world' and at the cutting edge of IT, media, entertainment, security and system services.

On the basis of the leaflet, our reader decided to invest, with disappointing results so far: 'The price of the issue started at £40 and has fallen steadily.'

'Hargreaves Lansdown had blamed part of the fall on the strong pound,' the reader said. 'I think this issue was painted in glowing terms by Hargreaves Lansdown, and this advertising was unfair.'

Peter Hargreaves, the Bristol firm's managing director, says: 'I cannot disagree with your reader's view that the newsletter was extremely upbeat. There is also very little negative comment. However, all the information was factual, not fabricated.'

Hargreaves admits there are negative points which his firm could be criticised for not including, such as deregulation enabling anyone to set up a competing telephone company using Deutsche Telekom's lines.

The share price was hit by fears that the firm will have to pay billions at auctions for wideband channels in Germany and France for its mobile arm, T-Mobile (the German auction has raiseda staggering £30 billion, more than the £22bn raised in the British Government's recent sale) and that it has already paid too much for American mobile company Voicestream.

Hargreaves says: 'It looks as though Deutsche Telekom will be a longer-term investment than we envisaged in May. Unfortunately in a world of low inflation and commoditised products, prices will be under greater pressure. In May we felt increased [telecoms] traffic would outweigh the costs of staying in the game, but hindsight is a wonderful thing.'

Although the shares have fallen by about £10 since our reader invested, he could have done much worse. In March, they were selling for about £60 each. However, his experience shows that investors should be wary of recommendations sent out in indiscriminate mailshots which pay no regard to the recipients' attitude to risk or their finances.

If you have spare cash to invest, seek advice from an independent adviser, who will take you through a fact-find to identify an investment that really meets your needs.

Seen a mailshot or advertisement that looks too good to be true? Write to What's the Catch, The Observer Business Section, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER.
