fields.headline: The big issue
fields.standfirst: From starvation diets to injecting women's urine, losing weight hasn't been easy for Rafael Garcia-Navarro. But then he met Michel Montignac...
fields.trailText: From starvation diets to injecting women's urine, losing weight hasn't been easy for Rafael Garcia-Navarro. But then he met Michel Montignac...
fields.body:
Nowhere is western culture more baffling than in matters of body weight. From modern medicine, the caveats have come thick and fast. In 1997, the World Health Organisation declared a global epidemic of obesity. European health experts convened in May this year in Antwerp to call for action in order to prevent a 'lost generation' of children hooked on fast foods, television and computers from developing diabetes, heart disease and cancer. In July, the Medical Research Council cautioned MPs that unless efforts were made to cut obesity, the Government's targets to reduce these diseases wouldn't be met.

The codicils from this quarter don't help: the BMA announced in June that actresses and models during the late-1990s carried a scant 10 to 15 per cent body fat (the average for healthy women is 20 to 26 per cent), concluding that such exposure to 'unachievable' goals could spur eating disorders, and adding that 'more realistic body shapes need to be shown on TV and in fashion magazines'. Be slim to be healthy. Don't be too slim to be socially acceptable. And all you need to be slim is fat, sugar and calories. That was the message in that commercial for Häagen-Dazs in which a twentysomething man and woman made love on a sofa, mingling heaping spoonfuls of Pralines & Cream with the wettest of French kisses. Sex. Youth. Beauty. Ice cream? The incongruity didn't end there. The lovers are skeletons, an unlikely couple to imagine opting for a tub at the check-out counter.

I was 10 years old when I learned I was overweight. We had recently moved to London, and my mother ordered some custom-made suits for me from a tailor in Hong Kong, who specialised in mail-order finery. She sent the measurements along and, when the clothes arrived, there was a greeting from the tailor. The faltering English did little to soften its thrust: 'These are suits for your fat son. We made them special fat so he can grow extra fatty in them.' There was mild horror laced with hearty laughter at the dinner table that night.

Suddenly - and perhaps too early for my benefit - the 'big' issue was upon me. I've had to contend with being overweight for most of my 40 years. On the health side, I've been fortunate. I've suffered none of the scourges associated with the morbidly obese, which (as defined by the medical profession is anyone 100lb over their ideal weight) I gather I am. My yearly check-ups are unremarkable. My weight hasn't been an obstacle to pleasures enjoyed by the ideally trim: women haven't turned me away; I've played a good standard of tennis for 30 years; though buying clothes can be a challenge, in the competition between dessert and dressing up the winner has never been in doubt.

I am the product of a family and culture that lives to eat. My grandfather, who turns 100 in October, claims the source of his extraordinarily good health has been his refusal to eat vegetables or drink water without whisky in it. He has never exercised. His diet has been rich in saturated fats and refined grains and sugars. Despite a slight paunch, his weight has revolved around 12st 7lb for most of his life. Which isn't to say that the body image and health themes haven't been present. In my family, diets were frequently embarked upon between bouts of comprehensive bingeing. On the distaff side, the relationship to food has been ambivalent: one instance of anorexia, another of bulimia and generous helpings of crash dieting and pill popping.

My sisters have unquestionably managed their weight more consistently than I have, whereas my love of food has been singular and unequivocal. My seven years as a restaurant critic in America didn't do me any favours. My wife frets over what my appetite for eating, cooking and obsessing about food does to our time together, which might otherwise be better spent on more beneficial pursuits: she has a point. She worries that there's a limit to how much good genes can help and cautions that I shouldn't ignore my long-term health prospects: she has a point there, too. Meanwhile, my weight had recently ballooned to 21st. An exercise in futility and deprivation - that has been my experience with diets.

The so-called 'hungry high' is an oxymoron. I've tried the Scarsdale Diet, the Rotation Diet, the Atkins Diet, the Pritikin Diet, the Cambridge Diet, even the Beverly Hills Diet - mother of all crazies, truly a child of its time. In 1981, a self-anointed 'nutrition guru' named Judy Mazel theorised that by applying the enzymes in fruit according to her plan, one could lose weight. On a diet of fruit, there was little alternative. Week One's menu consisted of pineapples and two bananas on Monday; papayas and mangoes on Tuesday; papayas, pineapples and more papayas on Wednesday; watermelons all day on Thursday and again on Sunday; two bananas, dried apricots and blueberries on Friday; and prunes, strawberries and two bananas on Saturday. I tried it three times. By the week's end, I was a fruitcake. I never made it to Week Two.

I was 13 when I underwent my first fat-farm experience. My parents had travelled to a hospital in Italy to try a method that was all the rage in the 1970s, and soon after I was enrolled with my older sister. We did it again as a family, with my grandfather in tow, and in protest. I went to Rome no fewer than three times. We were informed that through an injection of a hormone extracted from a pregnant woman's urine, we could lose 21lb in 21 days. The full details were less salubrious. The human chorionic gonadotrophin (hCG) hormone is secreted by women during the first trimester of pregnancy. Dr A Simeons published a report in 1954 in which he observed how so-called 'fat boys' with adiposogenital dystrophy (a syndrome of undescended testicles) were helped by daily injections of the hormone. For a time, the world watched and some, like us, followed. Simeons was a poor advertisement for his method. He had died of weight-related coronary disease some years prior to my first visit to his centre of operations, Rome's Ospedale Salvatori Mundii. The regime worked insofar as I did lose 21lb. The 500 calorie-per-day diet may have had just a little to do with it.

Perhaps it can never be too emphatically said how, of all cities, Rome should be the last one in which to starve. Misery was the order of each day. A pricking needle in my buttocks was my wake-up call. Breakfast consisted of weak tea or coffee with skimmed milk plus all the saccharine I desired. Lunch was 100gm of meat, chicken or fish - boiled to a pulp - with boiled green vegetables, a single bread stick and a single piece of fruit. Dinner was a repeat of lunch. Water was the only beverage. It was abstinence, Italian-style. A wise move on the hospital's part was to have nuns serve the food, for the urge to physically assault the person serving your food was powerful. I actually fainted on one occasion. The nun gave a glucose tablet and a benediction. There was a silver lining, and it came early: two days before starting, you were encouraged to 'force feed' in order to build up what was enigmatically referred to as 'fat reserve'.

The obvious arguments - one, that we were obese, not geese, and two, that surely there was already more than enough of the latter - were never offered. Instead, we repaired to the most aromatic trattorias in nearby Trastevere and took no prisoners at the table. I should note that hCG has since been completely discredited as a treatment for obesity. Whatever weight was lost was quickly regained, usually with interest. My next big diet-centre experience was in North Carolina's Duke University Medical Centre, which has since become Diet Central for the variety of weight treatments on offer. I sampled the so-called 'rice diet'. It was a fitting appellation: rice for breakfast, rice for lunch and rice for dinner, puffed or boiled, no extras, and above all, with no salt. Patients who attended the 'Rice House' were simply the heaviest people I had ever seen in my life. I felt like a ballet dancer standing next to a fleet of barrage balloons. Some of the very largest had to be lowered like grand pianos down recesses beside staircases in order to help them make it to the dining room. Many were on respirators and the sound of wheezing breezed through the house.

The scene at the swimming pool in neighbouring Duke Towers evoked a lagoon teeming with hippos. I mislaid some 45lb, but soon found them again. The Rice House is still open for business, even on the web: www.ricediet.com. The realm of prescription medication has for the most part been terra incognita . In the 1970s, a well-known doctor in London gave me so-called 'fat-burning' and diuretic pills that had me sweating like an ox and feeling that a heart attack was around the corner. I haven't sampled the new generation.

As for the new miracle pill, Orlistat, let the side-effect literature speak for itself: 'oily spotting, flatulence with discharge, faecal urgency, fatty or oily stool, oily evacuation, increases defecation and faecal incontinence'. 'We have a paradox,' says Dr Robert Lefever, director of the Promis Counselling Centre in London, where compulsions of every type are treated as variants of the same fundamental disorder: addiction. 'Diets don't work,' he says. 'But the only way to lose weight is to diet.' His views can seem contradictory. He sees addiction as a condition best treated by former addicts, not shrinks. He's critical of surgical treatments from the medical world to which he belongs. 'Surgeons have no place in dealing with a psychological problem. There's an awful lot of quackery, such as stomach stapling and gastric bypass.' He isn't kidding.

Hospitals offer a wide menu of grisly procedures designed to put an end to obesity - and much else besides. Two primary bariatric surgical procedures are commonly used: vertical banded gastroplasty and gastric bypass. The genesis of this none-too-modest proposal for weight loss dates back to 1969, when it was noted that near total removal of the stomach for cancer and ulcers caused patients to remain at below their normal weight. The approach involves stapling off most of the stomach, bypassing the duodenum and allowing the undigested food to pass directly into the small intestine. The weight loss occurs as the body adjusts to its new, limited capacity to absorb nutrients, for which vitamin supplements are thereafter widely prescribed. The mortality risks are deemed 'relatively low', though there is a chance of forming adhesions in the bowel, which frequently calls for more surgery.

The aftereffects are a laundry list. My favourite is the 'dumping syndrome'. After surgery, all food is emptied from the stomach pouch into the small intestine. Sweets and fatty foods irritate the small intestine, causing symptoms such as abdominal cramping, sweating, and general malaise. Eating and drinking fluids simultaneously is another way to feel the dumping syndrome; they recommend waiting half an hour between eating and drinking - for the rest of your life. Can the surgery be reversed? Yes, but the risks are greater than those braved the first time. Hippocrates gave us the recipe for weight loss 24 centuries ago - eat less and exercise more - and while for most that still holds true, perhaps it's possible that there's an even better way.

France's Michel Montignac, in his book Eat Yourself Slim, proposes a diet that aims to satisfy the passionate eater and lacks the more usual element of self-denial present in every diet I've ever tried. Rather disarmingly, when I spoke to him recently he said, 'Forget about my book before embarking on a plan, and simply eat the French way, then read my book.' Montignac, formerly obese, now trim but still a foodie, advocates eating well, regardless of caloric intake. The way to avoid putting on weight, he claims, is by classifying foods by their glucose content, which causes the body to produce high amounts of insulin to combat it, resulting in obesity. Beer, potatoes, cooked carrots, soft drinks, and pastry are out. Beef, dark chocolate, red wine, foie gras, ice cream are in, along with healthier foods such as wholemeal grains and pasta, pulses, fruit, and green vegetables.

A typical Montignac day begins with either a lipid breakfast or a carbohydrate breakfast. The lipid is less healthy, but acceptable: fried eggs, bacon, tomatoes and mushrooms. The carbohydrate breakfast offers all the wholegrain toast and sugar-free jam you want, plus cereal with skimmed milk. Fruit before any meal must be consumed on an empty stomach, waiting 15 minutes to digest.

Lunch or dinner can be either salad with goat's cheese and fillet of beef with Béarnaise sauce and sautéed vegetables, then cheese for dessert, or brown rice with tomato coulis, salad with cottage cheese, and low-fat yogurt mixed with fructose jam. Dressings and sauces are fine, as long as they contain no sugar, honey or flour. Fats are to be avoided with carbohydrates, while refined starches and sugar in any form are banned. I haven't been stinting on any food group and have followed the plan to the letter. I have lost 1st 7lb. I've been travelling abroad with no regimen to keep me from restaurants or rich foods. It has all been dead simple. 'The way out is via the door,' said Confucius. 'Why is it that no one will use this method?' Now if I can only see it to the end.

fields.headline: News going nowhere?
fields.standfirst: Edward Helmore reports from New York on networks seeking any way to survive
fields.trailText: Edward Helmore reports from New York on networks seeking any way to survive
fields.body:
For mny years, journalists and media commentators have fretted over the fate of television news. They feared that news services would cease to be protected as a kind of public service and instead be subject to corporate pressures for ratings and profit, which they are almost uniquely unsuited to achieve.

Recent events at ABC News, once the best funded and most respected of the three US network news divisions, have served to give credence to those concerns, and its experience has sent a clear warning to the news business that the landscape is changing faster than anyone imagined.

Over the past four months, ABC News has developed a knack for attracting almost as much controversy as the news it carries. First came the Leonardo DiCaprio saga last March. In an effort to attract younger viewers, ABC dispatched the Titanic star to interview President Clinton about environmental issues, and was widely rebuked for taking an already dumbed-down news service to an all-time low and breaching standard journalistic codes. The broadcast was a ratings flop.

Then came the news that ABC had paid a Washington lawyer $25,000 to smooth the way for Monica Lewinsky's interview with Barbara Walters. The news division had long maintained that it had not paid for the interview, but as it paid Theodore Olsen, a friend of prosecutor Kenneth Starr, to negotiate access, and allowed Lewinsky to sell the foreign rights, the denial was considered suspect.

Another controversy arose over a decision to hire Mark Fuhrman, the retired LAPD detective who became notori ous for making racist comments during the OJ Simpson trial, as a consultant on the Martha Moxley murder case. And then there was the handling of Diane Sawyer's interview with Elian Gonzalez in which the legendary TV interviewer stood on her head in an effort to relax the frightened six-year-old.

Moreover, a number of stories killed by the network carried the impression they were abandoned to please ABC's parent, Disney. In one instance, the network dropped a report alleging that paedophiles had been employed at a Disney theme park. Similarly, ABC decided not to run a story about Chicken Run, a film produced by Disney rival Dreamworks.

While these incidents may not seem particularly heinous in themselves, as a whole they have tainted ABC News. The division's head, former entertainment executive David Westin, has come under attack for allowing journalistic standards to fall. 'It's much, much worse than you know,' said old guard news anchor Ted Koppel after the DiCaprio debacle.

But much of the mess at ABC speaks to a general sense of confusion in TV news. Twenty years ago, the US network's evening news broadcasts attracted more than three-quarters of the viewing public. According to a recent study, that figure has declined to less than half, and most of those are of an older demographic group, which is less appealing to advertisers.

Nevertheless, the decline is relative:the three nightly network news broadcasts still have a combined audience greater than the 50 leading metropolitan daily newspapers combined.

But as audiences have been 'Balkanised' - fleeing to niche-interest cable stations - the audience for broadcast television has declined. 'The changes that are happening in broadcast news aren't that different from what's been happening in broadcast television as a whole,' points out Andrew Tyndall, author of the industry newsletter Tyndall Report .

Tyndall says ABC News, along with CBS and NBC, are now in the business of survival. In the past, the big three networks were happy to subsidise their journalism because that helped to guarantee a network's federal broadcasting licence, and thus their virtual monopoly status. With the deregulation of television under Ronald Reagan, news shows became expected to not only turn a profit but to compete successfully with entertainment.

'If it were just a business that was shrinking in size, there wouldn't be a problem,' says Tyndall. 'But there's an argument that says news should not be distributed to niche audiences; the entire citizenry should be able to hear the same information, in the same tone of voice, from the same point of view, because that's the only way you can have a democratic discussion.'

Holding on to and increasing audiences is what ABC, and every other broadcaster, is desperately trying to achieve, and as much as Westin has been criticised for his efforts, it's what he has been trying to do, too. 'The one thing I know,' he told the New Yorker , 'is that if we don't change, we die.'

Polling techniques now allow networks to pinpoint exactly when audiences switch off - usually when international stories are broadcast. In November 1989, when the Berlin Wall came down, ABC journalists rushed to cover the event. The evening's broadcast got the second-worst ratings of that autumn's season.

Earlier this summer, the cable news stations - MSNBC, CNN and Fox - were licking their lips in anticipation of having the political conventions to themselves after the networks announced they would not be airing them except as part of their evening news broadcasts. In the event, the conventions have been a ratings disaster.

Network news divisions are under pressure to develop new angles for news. In an effort to attract younger viewers, ABC recently introduced 20/20 Downtown , a news magazine specialising in 'ultra-fascinating' topics ranging from armless aerobic instructors to the lives of prostitutes.

Westin has, according to some reports, also urged his correspondents to develop interesting personal lives, to get themselves in the gossip columns and create more 'buzz' to bring in viewers.

This may sound like desperation, and that is the nature of the business, says Tyndall. 'The long-term future of television is that it disappears and we get our news in a different way. There won't be television, newspapers or cable. It will all be internet. The travails of ABC and other broadcasters are based on "how are they going to negotiate the transition from here to there"?'

The broadcast was a ratings flop. Then came the news that ABC had paid a Washington lawyer $25,000 to smooth the way for Monica Lewinsky's interview with Barbara Walters. The news division had long maintained that it had not paid for the interview, but as it paid Theodore Olsen, a friend of prosecutor Kenneth Starr, to negotiate access, and allowed Lewinsky to sell the foreign rights, the denial was considered suspect. Another controversy arose over a decision to hire Mark Fuhrman, the retired LAPD detective who became notori ous for making racist comments during the OJ Simpson trial, as a consultant on the Martha Moxley murder case. And then there was the handling of Diane Sawyer's interview with Elian Gonzalez in which the legendary TV interviewer stood on her head in an effort to relax the frightened six-year-old. Moreover, a number of stories killed by the network carried the impression they were abandoned to please ABC's parent, Disney. In one instance, the network dropped a report alleging that paedophiles had been employed at a Disney theme park. Similarly, ABC decided not to run a story about Chicken Run, a film produced by Disney rival Dreamworks. While these incidents may not seem particularly heinous in themselves, as a whole they have tainted ABC News. The division's head, former entertainment executive David Westin, has come under attack for allowing journalistic standards to fall. 'It's much, much worse than you know,' said old guard news anchor Ted Koppel after the DiCaprio debacle. But much of the mess at ABC speaks to a general sense of confusion in TV news. Twenty years ago, the US network's evening news broadcasts attracted more than three-quarters of the viewing public. According to a recent study, that figure has declined to less than half, and most of those are of an older demographic group, which is less appealing to advertisers. Nevertheless, the decline is relative:the three nightly network news broadcasts still have a combined audience greater than the 50 leading metropolitan daily newspapers combined. But as audiences have been 'Balkanised' - fleeing to niche-interest cable stations - the audience for broadcast television has declined. 'The changes that are happening in broadcast news aren't that different from what's been happening in broadcast television as a whole,' points out Andrew Tyndall, author of the industry newsletter Tyndall Report . Tyndall says ABC News, along with CBS and NBC, are now in the business of survival. In the past, the big three networks were happy to subsidise their journalism because that helped to guarantee a network's federal broadcasting licence, and thus their virtual monopoly status. With the deregulation of television under Ronald Reagan, news shows became expected to not only turn a profit but to compete successfully with entertainment. 'If it were just a business that was shrinking in size, there wouldn't be a problem,' says Tyndall. 'But there's an argument that says news should not be distributed to niche audiences; the entire citizenry should be able to hear the same information, in the same tone of voice, from the same point of view, because that's the only way you can have a democratic discussion.' Holding on to and increasing audiences is what ABC, and every other broadcaster, is desperately trying to achieve, and as much as Westin has been criticised for his efforts, it's what he has been trying to do, too. 'The one thing I know,' he told the New Yorker , 'is that if we don't change, we die.' Polling techniques now allow networks to pinpoint exactly when audiences switch off - usually when international stories are broadcast. In November 1989, when the Berlin Wall came down, ABC journalists rushed to cover the event. The evening's broadcast got the second-worst ratings of that autumn's season. Earlier this summer, the cable news stations - MSNBC, CNN and Fox - were licking their lips in anticipation of having the political conventions to themselves after the networks announced they would not be airing them except as part of their evening news broadcasts. In the event, the conventions have been a ratings disaster. Network news divisions are under pressure to develop new angles for news. In an effort to attract younger viewers, ABC recently introduced 20/20 Downtown , a news magazine specialising in 'ultra-fascinating' topics ranging from armless aerobic instructors to the lives of prostitutes. Westin has, according to some reports, also urged his correspondents to develop interesting personal lives, to get themselves in the gossip columns and create more 'buzz' to bring in viewers. This may sound like desperation, and that is the nature of the business, says Tyndall. 'The long-term future of television is that it disappears and we get our news in a different way. There won't be television, newspapers or cable. It will all be internet. The travails of ABC and other broadcasters are based on "how are they going to negotiate the transition from here to there"?'

fields.headline: Media diary
fields.trailText: Not the News at Ten | Aura of excess
fields.body:
Not the News at Ten
Victory at last for BBC journalists who resisted attempts by Tony 'Head Prefect' Hall to rebrand the Nine O'Clock News as the 'BBC News at Nine'. Greg Dyke is expected to use his MacTaggart speech in Edinburgh this week to confirm that the programme will move to 10pm.

But calling it BBC News at Ten is impossible. ITN owns the rights to the News at Ten name and has just revived the title on its new digital 24-hour news channel. So what will Dyke's new offering be called? Roll credits - and cheering in the gallery - for the Ten O'Clock News. Inspired and on its own worth the cost of the licence fee.

Aura of excess
Anyone surprised by recent revelations surrounding Aura, the now defunct women's magazine run by ex-Sunday Express and Sunday Mirror editor Eve Pollard's Parkhill Publishing, clearly doesn't know La Bollard. While some people's jaws may have dropped at suggestions that Eve had a somewhat imperious approach to management, her larger-than-life style is legendary among hacks who've worked for the exemplary campaigner for Women in Journalism. One former Sunday Express city editor was once ordered to pick up a new video machine in La Bollard's chauffeur-driven car and install it at her London pad.

Sensing a scoop, he was only too happy to oblige. The device was installed in record time, ready to receive what the poor hack thought would be a video of shady shenanigans in the Square Mile. Alas, secret film of City goings-on there was none. But like Eve's many fetchers of make-up and fresh apples, said city editor did prove himself in tune with the boss's whims.

Deep Timidity Indicated
Rumours continue to swirl that the Slickers, those very ex-Mirror tipsters, have been interviewed or arrested by the Old Bill during the Department of Trade and Industry's inquiry into share dealings at the tabloid. Not true. Nor is the DTI likely to see them before the autumn. Chief Slicker Boyhrul and his legal eagle are going on hols and sidekick James Hipwell is, sadly, waiting for a kidney transplant. Meanwhile, the DTI has taken soundings from not one, but three eminent law firms. One is said to be for a prosecution, one against and one undecided. Surely the DTI isn't behaving like a rabbit in headlights - yet again?

JSP goes AWOL
Don't ever let it be said that media diary thinks it's above helping out a rival paper in times of need. So here goes. Janet, you're supposed to turn up to work on Saturdays - that's what being the editor of the Sindie is all about. Staff say that JSP's increasing absence on the day her paper goes to print is prompting serious concern at Canary Wharf. Jan Thompson, managing editor of the Independent and its Sunday stablemate, is said to be 'more than miffed'. Oh dear.

fields.headline: The OFT's new eco worrier
fields.standfirst: Oliver Morgan  on John Vickers, a pricing philosopher who shuns the limelight
fields.trailText: Oliver Morgan on John Vickers, a pricing philosopher who shuns the limelight
fields.body:
John Vickers, the Oxford economist who will become head of the Office of Fair Trading in the autumn, has gained a reputation as a man of few words.

As the Bank of England's chief economist he has, for the past two years, been a member of the Bank of England's Monetary Policy Committee.

While other members of this highly influential body have spent time lecturing and speaking publicly about the thinking behind their decisions on interest rates and inflation, Vickers has kept his counsel. One observer says: 'He has become well known for having views which are not well known.'

But while he has generally shunned the limelight as far as his MPC duties are concerned, Vickers's previous academic work gives some indications of what the OFT is likely to be under him.

First, he will be a big contrast to the previous director-general of Fair Trading, John Bridgeman, who was a businessman. Vickers is a Fellow of All Souls Oxford (he achieved fellowship aged 21), and has held posts at Princeton, Harvard and the London Business School, as well as consulting and working for Shell.

What people say about him reflects who they are. One leading competition lawyer said: 'I was rather surprised. What does an academic know about the day-to-day running of competition cases? There is nothing in his background which suggests he knows how to deal with companies, and across the wide range of markets.'

Unsurprisingly, the lawyer said he would have preferred the other front-running candidate - Philip Collins, another leading competition lawyer.

On the other hand, academic economists feel that the Vickers appointment marks a significant change for the better in the Government's view of the OFT.

Paul Klemperer, an influential competition expert, says: 'He is someone who understands and has thought deeply about competition issues for a long period of time.

'This is important, especially as the economy has moved in a direction where these issues are becoming more complex and technical.'

Another economist who knows Vickers well says: 'The level of economic literacy in the policy process in the UK is appallingly low. The same is true of the British judiciary, which is not economically literate. With Vickers's appointment, I am optimistic that economics will be at the heart of policymaking in future.'

Business is not unhappy. Ruth Lea, of the Institute of Directors, says: 'It seems a natural fit for him. He is very well respected and I am sure that he will do a good job.'

Consumers are content, too. Phil Evans, senior policy adviser to the Consumers' Association, says 'he will potentially make OFT investigations more robust', suggesting that Vickers will take a less business-orientated view than Bridgeman.

But do we need economists to play this role? Look at the US, they say. The Federal Trade Commission is crammed with economists. The judiciary is too. Not only would the Microsoft judgment have been much less likely in the UK, the amount that business and economics learnt from it would have been far smaller.

Second, Vickers made his name formulating an analytical framework around precisely the issues which face the OFT today.

The value of his work was recognised when he was one of the 'wise men' appointed by Tony Blair to advise Labour on competition policy. Vickers has focused on privatisation, regulated industries, the extent to which competition can replace regulation as these industries mature, and the problems of developing policies which compensate for imperfections in markets caused by monopolies and dominant companies.

The rules of supply matching demand through a straightforward pricing mechanism can become distorted where monopolistic or dominant companies operate, or in industries which are highly capital-intensive and have high fixed costs.

The interests of companies which look to compete with dominant players as well as consumers can be threatened. For example, instead of simple market principles, the theory of second best - in which prices have to be taxed to level the playing field between companies with high fixed costs and those without - may take hold.

In a 1997 paper, Vickers examines one aspect of this, known as Ramsey pricing, which is concerned with finding the best possible price for consumers, subject to a firm not going out of business. It may all seem very dry. But as Klemperer says: 'While he has done important work in theoretical economics, it has always been very much with an eye to practical applications.'

This is the rub.

The OFT which Bridgeman leaves is different to the one that he joined. Vickers's role will be to make the new OFT work. The Competition Act gives the OFT strong powers, first to bust cartels and second to prevent the abuse of market power by dominant firms - an agenda which could create greater tensions between the organisation and business.

The second of these is more controversial, certainly with business, than the first. Although lawyers have for years applied EU legislation in this area, the Act gives the OFT a role for the first time

Vickers will need to ensure the OFT pursues its high-profile role effectively and does not come a cropper, as it did in controversial cases such as the pricing of Rupert Murdoch's Times newspaper.

In addition, there is a great deal of work in progress, not only on mergers and cartels but investigations into areas where market dominance plays a part, such as motorway service stations, computer retailing agreements, the conduct of the professions, and the 'beer orders'. One colleague and friend says: 'His grounding in industrial organisation will be invaluable. A lot of the issues in regulating BT, for example, which he has looked at carefully, are about when you have a dominant provider but a fringe of competitive providers. How do you regulate access to the network and to the market? That is not far away from regulating market dominance.'

One area, however, remains less clear. Although the third significant change in policy is the removal of ministerial involvement in merger decisions, it is unlikely that the DGFT will become an apolitical job.

Bridgeman was denied a second term as DGFT, something he is said to have wanted badly, because of politically generated problems. He is said to have fallen out with Ministers - officials insist it was not Byers, but Consumer Affairs Minister Kim Howells - because he was reticent about the Government's 'rip-off Britain' campaign.

In particular, he saw no merit in investigating the prices of soft drinks charged in pubs after Howells had demanded they be examined.

He was also seen as less than enthusiastic about other elements of the campaign - for example, an investigation into supermarket pricing. Vickers's academic expertise on pricing issues will be applicable to 'market dominance' among retailers as it was in his work on BT. But whether he will be any better than Bridgeman at producing a politically digestible result is unclear. His 'Trappist' tendencies suggest he is not keen on playing in the political limelight.

Some officials in the DTI are pleased with the Vickers appointment, which was said to have the stamp of the Treasury on it. But Evans at the Consumers' Association says Bridgeman was badly treated by his political masters, who looked for policies which had the populist touch, and which the CA on the face of it would endorse, but which were difficult to implement. They cannot expect Vickers to lend authority to policies which don't stand up.

'The OFT has had a lot of investigations dumped on it which it has not got the power to carry out. Bridgeman was shabbily treated. I am sure Vickers will not be pushed around by Ministers. He will just have too much professional integrity.'

On the other hand, Vickers's presence may mean that policies which are not intellectually robust will not see the light of day in the first place. Ministers could only thank him for that.

Profile

Subject: John Vickers

Born: 7 July 1959

Job: Director-general of Fair Trading designate

Interesting fact: Vickers is Lord Mallard, an important and honorary position at All Souls dating back to the 15th century. This requires him to perform an obscure ritual involving a dead duck on New Year's Eve.

webTitle: Time for junior market to Aim for tighter rules

fields.headline: Time for junior market to Aim for tighter rules
fields.trailText: Throg Street
fields.body:
Make no mistake. London's junior Alternative Investment Market has been a great success. And, rightly, it will be kept as a valuable third-tier source of capital for fledgling companies when the Stock Exchange merges with the Deutsche Börse to create the iX international exchange.

Never mind the occasional sneering about the quality, just feel the quantity. More than 600 firms have come to Aim in its five-year existence. In all, more than £5 billion of equity has been raised - £2.2bn this year alone - and on better terms than typical venture capital. Fewer than 20 Aim firms have gone bust or exited in disgrace, a surprisingly good record for such a risky, start-up market.

Enviable though that record is, it is no reason for complacency. True, on Aim caveat emptor rules. But it is also a disclosure-based mar ket, which places great responsibility on directors and nominated advisers ('nomads') to keep investors properly informed. When those duties go unfulfilled it is important to act and be seen to act to preserve confidence in the fledgling market.

At the start of the year Aim officials were worried by the risks posed by a flood of shell internet firms coming to market. In turn, nomads politely declined to sponsor a number of dotcom wonders. One 'internet incubator' which arrived in December was Jellyworks, whose shares leapt an amazing twentyfold on its debut.

Jellyworks was hard to grasp from the start. It intended to operate out of Guernsey, but switched at the last minute to London. It came to market not with a large portfolio, but an option over internet shares owned by trusts of veteran City investor David 'Spotty' Rowland. The option structure, co-founder Ed Guinan explained to us, was aimed at avoiding an accountants' lengthy valuation of the portfolio. Despite the hype, from the outset with Jellyworks you didn't quite know what you were getting for your money.

Then in February, with amazing haste, Guinan quit. At the time, he walked away from a £20m profit on share options, but the reasons why he should do so were never explained. Further digging revealed that Guinan's business record was hardly glittering. He was in dispute with his last company, which had terminated his contract. Another he had been involved with was struck off and dissolved last year. Never mind, the companies' names were disclosed in Jellyworks' Aim prospectus and there's no obligation under Aim rules to disclose sackings or strikings-off (so, officials, please tighten the wording).

The rules are very specific, however, in obliging firms to disclose share options granted to directors. And here in March - in granting 2 million options to chief executive Jonathan Rowland and 1 million to chairman Graham Robeson - Jellyworks slipped up. If this 'oversight' were the only cause for concern, it would not matter so much. But it is not.

Announcements by the firm also gave the impression that Jellyworks had more cash than it had. In particular, €20m stated to have been loaned to it by the Rowland trusts was, in fact, not loaned. Jellyworks' nomad Nabarro Wells now admits the announcement was 'badly worded'. But it was not corrected. Nor, indeed, were grand announcements about partnerships with German broker VMR - Jellyworks' biggest investment - which later did not go ahead.

There are other new little facts about Jellyworks that rankle. Like the £714,000 it spent in its short life on its premises under a 10 year lease from Starmount, a related company. Jellyworks, remember, was a tiny band of people picking internet stocks not a Mercury Asset Management. Those lease improvements will now be written off and a further £470,000 paid to terminate the lease, which was only taken shortly after its flotation and, therefore, not disclosed in Jellyworks' Aim admission document. Creditably, however, during the Shore Capital takeover lawyers insisted that the lease termination payment be subject to shareholders' approval at a special meeting.

That perception accords closely with reality in key areas: like directors' interests, a firm's financial position and its overall strategy -are a fundamental concern of regulators for Aim companies generally. Another is transparency when it comes to dealings with related parties be it in day-to-day business affairs, significant transactions or share issues.

For the most part, Aim officials have used private persuasion and secret fines to regulate the market. Powers of public censure have rarely been used and then only at the start. From time to time, however, pour encourager les autres , it is important that they are. True, Jellyworks was taken over last week. But this is not to urge Aim to shut the door after the horse has bolted, as it still has jurisdiction over directors and nomads.

And the moral for Aim investors? Examine nomads' and directors' track records, for sure. And heed the warning signals, not the hype.

Diageo's high spirits over Seagram raid
So the race for Seagram's spirits brands is on in earnest. Diageo's cheeky three-paragraph announcement on Friday of a joint bid with Pernod Ricard succeeded in its aims.

First, it told Seagram and the world it was serious and neither just a stalking horse, nor on a fishing expedition. And Diageo raised the pressure on Allied Domecq, its main rival.

Diageo's main interest is in Captain Morgan, Canada's Crown Royal and Seagram's wines. The French, meanwhile, want the scotch, including Chivas Regal and Glenlivet. Seagram's tail of lesser brands will be parked in a joint venture to be dealt with later, like the Absolut vodka rights. It's a neat solution, which will probably see Diageo paying up to 60 per cent of Seagram's sale price.

Allied, meanwhile, really needs the lot. There's still a question mark over other potential bidders. Bacardi was ditched by Diageo but may yet team up with Brown Forman of the US. There are venture capitalists, too, and possibly the big brewers. But for now the auction looks a mainly British affair.

Fears that it will overpay will continue to dog Allied's shares. The intriguing question, though, is what happens if it loses. Failing another deal, Allied may well become a target itself.

At the time, he walked away from a £20m profit on share options, but the reasons why he should do so were never explained. Further digging revealed that Guinan's business record was hardly glittering. He was in dispute with his last company, which had terminated his contract. Another he had been involved with was struck off and dissolved last year. Never mind, the companies' names were disclosed in Jellyworks' Aim prospectus and there's no obligation under Aim rules to disclose sackings or strikings-off (so, officials, please tighten the wording). The rules are very specific, however, in obliging firms to disclose share options granted to directors. And here in March - in granting 2 million options to chief executive Jonathan Rowland and 1 million to chairman Graham Robeson - Jellyworks slipped up. If this 'oversight' were the only cause for concern, it would not matter so much. But it is not. Announcements by the firm also gave the impression that Jellyworks had more cash than it had. In particular, €20m stated to have been loaned to it by the Rowland trusts was, in fact, not loaned. Jellyworks' nomad Nabarro Wells now admits the announcement was 'badly worded'. But it was not corrected. Nor, indeed, were grand announcements about partnerships with German broker VMR - Jellyworks' biggest investment - which later did not go ahead. There are other new little facts about Jellyworks that rankle. Like the £714,000 it spent in its short life on its premises under a 10 year lease from Starmount, a related company. Jellyworks, remember, was a tiny band of people picking internet stocks not a Mercury Asset Management. Those lease improvements will now be written off and a further £470,000 paid to terminate the lease, which was only taken shortly after its flotation and, therefore, not disclosed in Jellyworks' Aim admission document. Creditably, however, during the Shore Capital takeover lawyers insisted that the lease termination payment be subject to shareholders' approval at a special meeting. That perception accords closely with reality in key areas: like directors' interests, a firm's financial position and its overall strategy -are a fundamental concern of regulators for Aim companies generally. Another is transparency when it comes to dealings with related parties be it in day-to-day business affairs, significant transactions or share issues. For the most part, Aim officials have used private persuasion and secret fines to regulate the market. Powers of public censure have rarely been used and then only at the start. From time to time, however, pour encourager les autres , it is important that they are. True, Jellyworks was taken over last week. But this is not to urge Aim to shut the door after the horse has bolted, as it still has jurisdiction over directors and nomads. And the moral for Aim investors? Examine nomads' and directors' track records, for sure. And heed the warning signals, not the hype. Diageo's high spirits over Seagram raid So the race for Seagram's spirits brands is on in earnest. Diageo's cheeky three-paragraph announcement on Friday of a joint bid with Pernod Ricard succeeded in its aims. First, it told Seagram and the world it was serious and neither just a stalking horse, nor on a fishing expedition. And Diageo raised the pressure on Allied Domecq, its main rival. Diageo's main interest is in Captain Morgan, Canada's Crown Royal and Seagram's wines. The French, meanwhile, want the scotch, including Chivas Regal and Glenlivet. Seagram's tail of lesser brands will be parked in a joint venture to be dealt with later, like the Absolut vodka rights. It's a neat solution, which will probably see Diageo paying up to 60 per cent of Seagram's sale price. Allied, meanwhile, really needs the lot. There's still a question mark over other potential bidders. Bacardi was ditched by Diageo but may yet team up with Brown Forman of the US. There are venture capitalists, too, and possibly the big brewers. But for now the auction looks a mainly British affair. Fears that it will overpay will continue to dog Allied's shares. The intriguing question, though, is what happens if it loses. Failing another deal, Allied may well become a target itself.

webTitle: Return to the Seventies is more groovy than gloomy

fields.headline: Return to the Seventies is more groovy than gloomy
fields.standfirst: Oil prices rise but there is no crisis yet, writes  Faisal Islam
fields.trailText: Oil prices rise but there is no crisis yet, writes Faisal Islam
fields.body:
If disco-inspired Groovejet pips Posh Spice to the top of the UK singles chart tonight, it will complete a week of mid-Seventies revival. The light-fingered funk guitar whirring its way back into the limelight was preceded on Wednesday by the return of the unemployment rate of 1975 - 3.7 per cent.

Oil diplomacy is back in vogue too. Now, as in 1974-5, the price of oil is the subject of politicking and posturing. The 1973-4 oil crisis saw the price of crude oil quadruple from $3 to $12. Over the past 18 months crude oil prices have trebled to some $32 a barrel, and analysts, mindful of low stocks in the US, are talking about the $40 barrel. Levels of corporate debt have returned to the peaks of late 1974, and late 1989.

The PNFC borrowings (private corporations not in the financial services) are, according to the Bank of England, close to a historic high relative to earnings. Politicians are talking about full employment again, as the claimant count measure hovers just above a million. The breaching of that mark in 1975 was deemed a national disaster. If the claimant count dips below that figure, we can expect an equivalent celebration.

'We aren't there yet, but we are quite definitely getting closer,' says David Brickman, senior economist at Paine Webber. The participation rate, the proportion of the working-age population who has or wants a job, is 79 per cent - much higher than in continental Europe - but it has not changed much in a decade. The employment rate has risen steadily since 1993 to 75 per cent. The four percentage point gap between these figures is narrower than it has been, but would of course need to be zero for full employment. Other Seventies' revivals have in the past been the indicators of imminent gloom.

First, the high levels of corporate debt increase the vulnerability of the economy to slumps in share prices. In Europe, telecoms companies have been selling multi-billion-dollar megabonds to fund the purchase of licenses and other companies. 'There are qualitative similarities with previous peaks - cashflow and profitability have been under pressure,' says Robert Barrie, economist at CSFB. 'But there are aspects that are positive in what this debt is funding: mergers and acquisitions, and corporate restructuring.'

Similarly, the equivalent rise in oil prices is thought of as benign, because it has come more gradually and because the world economy is no longer as dependent on oil. (Back then, oil represented 10 per cent of the retail price index; now it is 3.6 per cent.) But the trend towards reduced unemployment started with a sustained period of very low oil prices which is now over.

'The period of low energy prices can be thought of as a positive supply shock,' says Professor Andrew Oswald of Warwick University. 'If that's true, it's about to reverse: prices have been rising for a year and a half, and that's the usual lag before it feeds into the real economy.'

In a recent paper Oswald argued: 'Historically, sharp rises in the price of energy are our best predictor of a slump to come. This happened in the mid Seventies, late Seventies and early Nineties. No doubt it will happen again. Energy is a key input. When inputs become more expensive, cost curves rise, and firms go out of business.'

In this context, it is perhaps not surprising that President Clinton wrote to Crown Prince Abdullah to express concern about oil prices. Only Saudi Arabia can turn more taps on and force the price down, but this will not happen before an Opec meeting on 10 September. Meanwhile, winter approaches.

'If the price is $32 a barrel in August, what happens in October when demand increases?' asks Brickman. Although this trend may give a foretaste of troubles ahead, the key difference between now and the situation 25 years ago is inflation. While unemployment was at the same levels then, inflation peaked at 24.2 per cent in 1975. Inflation is just 2.2 per cent now, and earnings growth actually declined recently.

'How can you have unemployment at a 25-year low and inflation low?' asks Oswald. 'It has to be explained on the supply side.' The structural shifts in employment patterns, flexibility and part-time work, and participation by previously inactive workers such as secondary earners, all allow unemployment to decline without stoking inflationary pressures.

In the US, the trend towards reducing unemployment without increasing inflation is coupled with tangible increases in productivity which have not been seen in the UK. 'It's sensible to stand back and look at the international picture,' says Oswald.

'Politicians in all countries are trying to take credit, but all industrialised countries are going through this. You have to look for a common explanation.' Low energy prices may form part of this but there is also the generic 'new economy' effect - the productivity- enhancing magic of information technology. But could this magic also reduce the danger of oil price rises?

Not necessarily. For all the talk of knowledge transfer and service industries, transport is still key to globalisation. Clearly there is scope for the economy to develop an immunity to the effects of oil prices, but we would not know now whether that has happened or not. 'The next two years could see a battle between the recessionary effect of rising oil prices and the booming effect of the new economy,' Oswald says.

So the economy may enjoy the positive Seventies revival of low unemployment without the negatives of high inflation and spiralling oil prices. If so it would appear to be a case of the new economy coming to the rescue.

But if faith in this amorphous concept is misplaced, watch out for the effect of a revival of corporate debt.

fields.headline: Stockwatch
fields.trailText: Winners' curse | BAT's Bush telegraph
fields.body:
If leopards really can change their spots, perhaps it is now time to take a fresh look at SR Pharma, the AIM- listed drugs outfit.

Three years ago, SR had a rocky ride under its old name, Stanford Rook. Then the shares slumped from a 540p high to just 150p when the firm's much-hyped drug treatment for tuberculosis was abandoned as a lost cause.

It was, however, a crash widely foretold: the firm's managing director quit before its 1995 flotation, refusing to sign up to the extravagant claims made for the drug.

From a low of 60p, SR has since climbed back, with most of the gains coming after the change of name in May last year. SR is now pinning its hopes on its SRL172 treatment for asthma and lung cancer, with phase III trial results due next year on the cancer front.And last week US partner Corixa signed a deal to commercialise SR's PVAC treatment for psoriasis, under which SR will receive licence fees, royalties and milestone payments.

The shares regained their old heights in May after positive phase II results for SRL172. They have since drifted back, however, and barely moved on last week's deal. Clearly the shares are risky, but SR followers believe the lull offers a buying opportunity. Broker Lehman thinks the shares, now at 335p, could go to £14 if SR finally realises its potential.

Laporte revival
Laporte, the chemicals group, has enjoyed a renaissance of sorts following a solid set of interim results. First-half profits may have come in only fractionally ahead, but in the face of the high pound and rising raw material costs, that in itself was quite an achievement.

The management is strongly rated and a bid is likely. Swiss rival Clariant made an approach last year, and Laporte will not be short of suitors next time round.

At 497p, the shares are way below broker Schroder Salomon Smith Barney's target 700p take-out price.

Winners' curse
The telecoms sector breathed a sigh of relief on Thursday with the end of the German auction for six new mobile licences. After 173 rounds of bidding, the £30 billion of cash flowing into German coffers topped the £22.5bn raised by Gordon Brown. More good news then for the Chancellors, but bad news for the likes of Vodafone Airtouch, which now has to fork out £5bn for its winning bid. With more auctions to come, broker Charles Stanley reckons Vodafone is likely to spend £18.5bn on third-generation mobile licences around the world. And that's before a capital expenditure bill that could top £20bn by 2010.

Vodafone shares have dropped from a high of £4 to 268p now following the UK's groundbreaking auction. Given that it is unlikely to show any real return on its investment until 2007, Charles Stanley's team thinks the shares are still too high compared with its 231p benchmark valuation.

Also, the impending reflotation of Orange by France Telecom and other mobile offerings are likely to put pressure on Vodafone in the near term.

BAT's Bush telegraph
BAT, the world's number two tobacco group, has held its ground following the latest assault on the industry in the US courts last month. The jury may have awarded $18bn in damages against BAT, but broker Merrill Lynch believes the verdict will fall apart on appeal.

The broker remains upbeat on the European tobacco sector in general, with lots of positive news likely for BAT. Also, if the Republicans look likely to win the US Presidential election, tobacco shares may well gain on anticipation that Bush will influence the Justice Department lawsuit. At 449p, BAT shares are still worth a look.

webTitle: Prescott faces fight on council borrowing

fields.headline: Prescott faces fight on council borrowing
fields.trailText: The government is poised to relax tough limits on local government borrowing in a move that could transform council finances, allowing them to kickstart major transport and housing projects.
fields.body:
The government is poised to relax tough limits on local government borrowing in a move that could transform council finances, allowing them to kickstart major transport and housing projects.

As the financial straitjacket on councils has been drawn ever tighter local councils were starved of real political clout.

However, a Local Government Finance Green Paper next month is expected to advocate that, for the first time in more than a century, local authorities have the power to borrow on the financial markets.

But the Government is likely to demand that, for transport improvements in particular, any funding be linked to road levies or workplace parking charges.

'We've got pretty firm indications that this will be included in the Green Paper,' said Keith Beaumont, head of capital finance at the Local Government Associations.

But the Treasury will seek to block the measure, arguing that in America, where cities can issue bonds, there have been several instances of cities and districts nearly going bankrupt - the most notable being New York 30 years ago.

'Strict [financial] controls on councils have been applied since the beginning of the century,' said Tony Travers, local government expert at the London School of Economics. 'They've been controlled for a long time because the Treasury is afraid of what might happen if a local authority ran into trouble.'

The moves are seen as a major plank in Deputy Prime Minister John Prescott's desire to return democracy to the regions. But change is likely to be at least two years away.

At present, if councils want to borrow money, they have to apply to the Public Works Loan Board, which is controlled by the Treasury.

webTitle: De Beers needs to dig for credibility

fields.headline: De Beers needs to dig for credibility
fields.trailText: Jamie Doward: Just what is De Beers up to? The South African diamond giant has for the past hundred years or so endured a reputation similar to Big Brother's Nick Bateman, thanks to the way it has ruthlessly dominated its industry.
fields.body:
Just what is De Beers up to? The South African diamond giant has for the past hundred years or so endured a reputation similar to Big Brother's Nick Bateman, thanks to the way it has ruthlessly dominated its industry, shoring up its position by mopping up surplus diamonds to help keep gem prices high.

Despite being banned from the US on anti-trust grounds, De Beers' control of the diamond market has hitherto seemed unassailable. But recently it seems to have had something of an epiphany. A little over 18 months ago De Beers was sitting on around $5 billion worth of diamonds. Now its stockpile has been reduced by more than half. As a result, the firm last week unveiled record half-year sales figures of more than $3.5 billion, triple the figure for the same period last year.

And what is more, the company has pledged to clamp down on 'conflict diamonds' - those extracted in war zones and sold to raise money that fuels the fighting. By next year, De Beers insists, none of its diamond partners will be trading in conflict gems.

Admirable. But of course, in the meantime, De Beers will continue to use its stockpile, pumping into the market gems extracted from who knows where on the Dark Continent. The company bridles when asked whether the gems now going on sale came from conflict zones. In legal terms, they will have been mined before a recently agreed definition of conflict gems by human rights groups, governments and the likes of De Beers.

The more important point in the longer term is how the big diamond firms can guarantee that their wares are not from conflict zones. This means independent auditing. All the mining firms agree that this is a good idea - after all, consumers are increasingly concerned about where their rocks are coming from, and this could threaten sales.

But building an efficient, globally endorsed verification system is a huge challenge. De Beers created its own internal auditing system a few years ago but this lacks credibility, according to human rights groups which know how it works.

The firm's managing director, Gary Ralfe, may last week have been talking up his company's prospects, but ultimately he knows that bridging this credibility gap is the diamond industry's biggest challenge. If it fails to do this, consumers will seek other ways of telling their partners that they love them. Diamonds are not necessarily forever.

 Two cheers for Jim Rose, one of the few UK dotcom bosses who seems to appreciate that, dammit, a merging of internet firms should, just like marriage, be entered into soberly and responsibly. While the wreckage that now constitutes the dotcom sector has prompted many firms to enter into hasty and perhaps ill-starred unions, QXL's chief executive had the audacity to question the sense of merging the auction firm with Germany's Ricardo at any price.

As the negotiations progressed, it emerged that QXL's potential partner was not all it was cracked up to be. Question marks hung over its sales figures. Rose, in the interests of QXL's shareholders, balked at the deal and forced Ricardo's investors to accept 38 per cent of the newly combined company, rather than the 43 per cent the original deal would have brought them.

Given the way internet paper has been sprinkled around like confetti over the past couple of years, Rose's decision was a welcome reality check.

However, while question marks hung over the deal, both sides saw the value of their paper slide dramatically. When the deal was announced, Ricardo was worth nearly £630 million. The new deal values it at £170m.

Given the greatly diminished value of the new company, the real winner from the deal could end up being arch US rival eBay, which many analysts argue is the only play in town.

Rose accepts that Europe has room for only one online auctioneer. Ensuring it is QXL will earn him a full quota of cheers in the City.

fields.headline: Two held over Bloomberg 'blackmail'
fields.trailText: Billionaire media mogul Mike Bloomberg is seeking the extradition of two alleged extortionists from Britain to the US following a sting operation by Scotland Yard and the FBI.
fields.body:
Billionaire media mogul Mike Bloomberg is seeking the extradition of two alleged extortionists from Britain to the US following a sting operation by Scotland Yard and the FBI.

Two Kazakhstani brokers appeared at Bow Street magistrates court last Friday following their arrest in London 10 days ago. Oleg Zezov, 27, and Igor Yarimaka, 37, allegedly hacked into the Bloomberg news computers in New York and demanded $200,000 to explain how they had infiltrated the system.

Both were employees of a Bloomberg customer, Kazkommerts Securities in Almaty, Kazakhstan, and travelled to London to meet the American mogul. This weekend the Yard declined to give full details of the sting. 'The Metropolitan Police kid nap and specialist investigation unit arrested two men in London on 10 August in connection with a major international extortion attempt,' a spokeswoman said. 'It's an FBI investigation supported by us and they were arrested on a US extradition warrant.'

It is understood, however, that two undercover officers, posing as a media executive and as a translator, accompanied Bloomberg to his meet ing with the alleged hackers.

According to federal prosecutors in New York, Zezov had allegedly been making threats via emails and faxes since March. Both he and Yarimaka also allegedly used fictitious names. Zezov said his intent was to 'help you [Bloomberg] to understand some drawbacks to your system,' according to the criminal complaint filed in the US.

A warrant has also been issued for the arrest of a third alleged accomplice, Elena Gorokhova. If convicted in the US, they face up to 20 years in prison for extortion and computer intrusion.

The affair is the second major alleged hacking incident to involve Bloomberg. Two years ago, consultants at rival Reuters were accused of stealing Bloomberg data but no charges were brought.

fields.headline: Black magic wears off
fields.standfirst: Faced with trendy bars and imported lagers, the Guinness genius is not looking so clever.  Jamie Doward  reports
fields.trailText: Faced with trendy bars and imported lagers, the Guinness genius is not looking so clever. Jamie Doward reports
fields.body:
It is enough to test the brightest of pub geniuses. Why did spiralling consumer demand in the Irish Republic not prevent the first fall in sales of Guinness in the company's 241-year history? Inflation there last month was the highest for 15 years - 6.2 per cent - yet the brewer's annual sales are down by 4 per cent.

'Younger people here have a lot more money than they used to - they all want yuppie drinks,' says John Kane, of Ireland's Services Industrial Professional Technical Union, which is in talks to save jobs at Guinness's packaging plant in Dundalk. 'Guinness, despite all its advertising, hasn't been able to hold market share.'

As part of a cost-cutting exercise, Guinness's parent company, Diageo, is now looking to move the Dundalk plant to Northern Ireland. The move comes as Guinness reviews all its operations in Ireland in the face of cutthroat competition in a shrinking beer market.

Kane is right. People are switching from beer to lager, wine and spirits - a trend not unnoticed by the big drinks firms, which are scrambling to develop their market share.

Last Friday, Diageo announced it was teaming up with Pernod Ricard to make a joint bid for Seagram's wines and spirits division, valued at around £4.5 billion. The business, which boasts brands such as Chivas Regal scotch, Martell cognac and Captain Morgan rum, also interests Allied Domecq.

So what does this mean for Guinness? According to Pearse McCabe, strategist with the Fitch brand and design consultancy, the challenge is to 'achieve the dream of retaining their core audience - the old bloke in a pub - and attracting a younger audience.'

Guinness is clearly looking to do this. Tom Innes, editor of Flavour , the UK-based bar trade magazine, says: 'Guinness is trying to adapt to changing circumstances such as the growth of trendy bars. To combat that, it is heavily promoting draught Guinness in bottles .'

The company has also introduced Guinness Extra Cold, which is served two degrees cooler than its normal stout. Lyndsey Sexton, spokeswoman for Guinness UK, says: 'Research showed that people saw Guinness as warm. A lot of work went into how we could respond to that. Now all of a sudden you're getting people treating it as a session beer, rather than drinking one pint and moving on to something else.'

The repositioning of the brand has been boosted by a huge marketing campaign. During last year's Rugby World Cup alone, Guinness spent £16 million promoting the black stuff. And although all this may not be working so well in Ireland, it has helped boost the stout's share of the UK beer market from 5 per cent in 1998 to 5.5 per cent now. But this is at a time when competition in the UK's £1bn stout market is weak.

Innes of Flavour adds: 'Guinness is helped at the moment by the weaknesses of the other brands. Scottish Courage is not doing much with Beamish. Murphy's was quite promoted but there was uncertainty over the sale of Whitbread's brewing arm [owner of Murphy's]. St Patrick's Day was just left to Guinness this year.'

Guinness is aware that it cannot afford to be complacent. Publican newspaper last week unveiled its annual survey asking landlords which three beers they would most like to stock. Last year, Guinness was on the wishlist of 30 per cent of the UK's publicans. This year the figure has fallen to 24 per cent.

One solution may be to draw on the strength of the Guinness brand - which the company says is recognised by 99 per cent of consumers - and use it to move into new areas. In Ireland the company has launched a white beer called Brio, which is designed to compete with the fashionable influx of continental speciality lagers such as Hoegaarden.

Such a brand metamorphosis would have seemed unthinkable only a few years ago. But Guinness knows it will always have to work hard to keep customers. People may like its clever TV ads, but they don't always drink the product.

fields.headline: Island hostage talks fail
fields.standfirst: Rebels in Philippines refuse to release captives amid fears of army strike on their remote base
fields.trailText: Rebels in Philippines refuse to release captives amid fears of army strike on their remote base
fields.byline: John Aglionby, South East Asia correspondent
fields.body:
After days of mounting expectation that the four-month hostage crisis in the southern Philippines would end yesterday, negotiations floundered at the eleventh hour when the Muslim separatist Abu Sayyaf rebels refused to release their prisoners in one group.

Libyan intermediary Rajab Azzarouq and a colleague returned visibly upset and empty-handed from the rebels' hideout on the remote island of Jolo yesterday afternoon because, they said, the hostage takers insisted that their mostly foreign captives be freed in batches. Philippine President Joseph Estrada has ordered that all the hostages must be released together.

It is not clear how many people the Abu Sayyaf are still holding. Some sources say it could be as many as 19. It is known that two Germans, two Finns, two South Africans and six French are among the prisoners.

Azzarouq said that during six-and-a-half hours of talks, the Abu Sayyaf offered him two male European hostages of his choice as a sign of their goodwill but he turned them down. 'It's all or nothing,' he said, adding that there was now no timeframe for their release. 'We will have to renegotiate for the hostages' freedom,' Azzarouq said. The Libyan has taken an increasingly prominent role in recent weeks since his leader Muammar Gadaffi offered to pay $25 million for the hostages' release.

An aide to chief Philippine government negotiator Robert Aventajado said the hostage takers were afraid that if the prisoners were released all at once, the Philippine military would immediately launch a major offensive against them. Thousands of troops have been on a high state of readiness in the area for weeks and the only reason they have not attacked is the presence of the foreigners.

He could not comment on the current state of the hostages' health. They have all been suffering depression and deteriorating physical health because of the strain of their ordeal as well as inadequate food and insufficient medical supplies. Some have written about being on the verge of suicide.

'We were so optimistic that it would all end today,' one European official said. 'It seems we are now back at the beginning, at square one.'

There was also no word yesterday on the whereabouts of four hostages, three Malaysians and one Filipino, reportedly freed on Friday but unable to cross over to the Philippine army lines.

The crisis began on Easter Sunday, 23 April, when 21 tourists, hotel staff and forest rangers were seized on the luxury Malaysian resort island of Sipaden and taken to Jolo. At least another 18 people have been seized since then, including several foreign journalists covering the protracted dispute.

Some Abu Sayyaf leaders initially demanded a separate Muslim state in exchange for the hostages but in the last two months it became increasingly clear that the only serious demand was for at least one million dollars for each hostage.

Of the original hostages, six Malaysians, one Filipino and one sick German woman have been freed at various stages. Philippine armed forces commander General Angelo Reyes has admitted that at least £3m was paid for their release, although all the governments involved proclaimed a firm policy that no ransoms would be paid.

Abu Sayyaf has also released a German journalist, reportedly for a one million dollar ransom. Three of the remaining French hostages are a TV crew who thought they had secured an exclusive interview with the hostages and their captors but were not allowed to leave the camp.

As a result of receiving so much money, the Abu Sayyaf has seen its ranks swell from fewer than 100 fighters to more than 3,000 members. It is a splinter group of the Moro Islamic Liberation Front that has been fighting for a separate Islamic state in the southern Philippines for more than two decades.
