webTitle: Mbeki 'lets Aids babies die in pain'

fields.headline: Mbeki 'lets Aids babies die in pain'
fields.standfirst: South African President faces court battle over refusal to buy drugs
fields.trailText: Campaigners against Aids in South Africa will start legal proceedings this week to force the government to save thousands of babies from painful and lingering deaths.
fields.body:
Campaigners against Aids in South Africa will start legal proceedings this week to force the government to save thousands of babies from painful and lingering deaths.

It emerged last week that for four months the government of President Thabo Mbeki has been sitting on a European Union-sponsored report suggesting that giving retro-viral drugs to pregnant women could save the lives of nearly 14,000 babies.

It is estimated that such a programme, involving the use of Nevirapine anti-viral drugs, would cost the country the equivalent of about 20p per head of population - less than £700 for each life saved. The report says overall savings for the public purse could even result from such a programme, because the new-born babies would not require treatment for HIV or Aids.

In the absence of any coherent explanation for the government's refusal to extend anti-viral treatment to expectant mothers who are HIV positive, Mbeki is being accused of having taken a decision to kill the babies by way of an act of omission rather than to burden the country with orphans.

The failure to act against mother-to-child infections is only one facet of the South African government's baffling approach to the epidemic - which includes a continued refusal by Mbeki to extend anti-viral treatment to rape victims, as well as his government's failure to provide such treatment for the infected general population.

It is becoming apparent that the explanation for these seemingly perverse policies lies in South Africa's state of denial over Aids.

The official refusal to face the facts of the epidemic, at least as a first-hand experience, is chilling in its pervasiveness. While Aids is openly recognised and debated in the media - and undertakers are enjoying their biggest boom since the slaughter during the township uprisings of the mid-Eighties - any mention of the killer disease is taboo, where individual deaths are concerned.

Legislation introduced prohibiting mandatory testing of workers by employers - designed to prevent victimisation - has fuelled myths among even trained medical personnel that it is a criminal offence to confirm anyone is dying of, or has died of, Aids.

Ironically, the effect is often to lift responsibility from the employer. The Observer has obtained a copy of a circular issued by the Chamber of Mines to mining houses offering an interpretation of the law - which some lawyers would regard as tendentious - prohibiting employers from HIV testing, even if it is requested by an employee.

The result of such advice is that mine doctors stand by helplessly while men whom they know are probably dying are sent to work in extreme underground conditions.

There are courageous individuals who break the silence. In Soweto recently, a mother interrupted the funeral service of her son, said to have died of pneumonia, to announce that his killer was, in fact, Aids. She then distributed free condoms among the mourners in the church.

But such openness can be dangerous, as was famously discovered by a young woman in KwaZulu-Natal province who announced that she was HIV positive and was promptly stoned to death by neighbours.

Nelson Mandela's one-time aide, Walter Sisulu, also 'came out' with an announcement recently that one of his grandchildren had died of Aids. Another instance of going public was the case of Charlene Smith, a rape victim who identifed herself and told her story in The Observer last year in an attempt to help fellow rape victims avoid the trauma she had suffered in the attack itself, and the subsequent battle to get anti-viral treatment.

Smith was denounced as 'racist' by Mbeki, on the ground that she was propagating the myth that all black men were rapists.

The presidential outburst was possibly a significant pointer where explanations for the denial are concerned. One of the most compelling analyses of the syndrome was offered here last week by Dr Suzanne Leclerc-Madlala, a medical anthropologist at the University of Natal.

In a lengthy and sensitive article on the subject, published by Johannesburg's Mail & Guardian, she wrote: 'For a variety of reasons, all strongly rooted in the continent's unique political, economic, social and racial history, there are layers of denial and silence that preclude a serious grappling with sexual cultures. There are widespread beliefs that males are biologically programmed to need sexual relations regularly with more than one woman and often concurrently. Such beliefs are logically consistent with societies that were traditionally polygamous. Research has found that these beliefs are held almost as strongly by women as by men.'

She said: 'There is a significant body of well-researched and well-documented social science studies that points to high levels of premarital sexual activity, extramarital relations and sexual violence, making African societies more at risk for HIV/Aids than those in other parts of the world.

'In many communities, women can expect a beating, not only if they suggest condom usage, but also if they refuse sex, if they curtail a relationship, if they are found or suspected to have another partner, or or even if they are believed to be thinking about someone else.'

If such analysis holds true, the situation would appear to call for strong national leadership to deal with the denial. Tragically, in Mbeki the country seems to have precisely the opposite - a man who is not only in denial himself, but preaches his own version of reality with potentially dire consequences.

A Sussex University economics graduate, seen during the years of struggle against apartheid as the African National Congress's arch-diplomat, Mbeki was widely regarded as sophisticated and cosmopolitan. Time and experience now offer, however, another perspective - of a man whose sensitivity on race points to a previously undiscovered psychological trauma which, while deserving of sympathy, makes him among the politicians least qualified to heal past wounds.

Nursing the dreams of an Mbeki-led African 'renaissance', in the cauldron of which he sees the rebirth of black pride, he seems driven to deny the reality of Aids. He has done so by the pursuit of 'African' cures such as Virodine, a drug containing an industrial solvent, which is considered by safety experts to be toxic.

The President has tried to force an alternative explanation as to the pathology of the disease on a scornful and appalled medical world. He is allowing his people to die painful, lonely, and at times unnecessary deaths.

Nero fiddled while Rome burned. And while Mbeki spreads his fanciful opinions about Aids, South Africa sickens and dies.

webTitle: Holiday market in a whirl as C&N casts about for its dream choice

fields.headline: Holiday market in a whirl as C&N casts about for its dream choice
fields.trailText: German holiday company C&N Touristic is eyeing Britain's Thomas Cook and First Choice travel firms after being deterred from buying Airtours by the high price.
fields.body:
German holiday company C&N Touristic is eyeing Britain's Thomas Cook and First Choice travel firms after being deterred from buying Airtours by the high price.

Growing expectations that C&N was poised to take over Airtours, creating the largest package holiday business in the world, were dampened last week when it emerged that the UK number two will not surrender easily.

Industry sources said Airtours founder and chairman David Crossland, in talks with C&N, had demanded between £4 and £5 per share, valuing the company at up to £2.4 billion. The share price closed last week at 298p. That prompted C&N to step back.

But while C&N considers whether to renegotiate with Airtours, First Choice chief executive Peter Long is understood to have approached C&N. He believes he can demand £2 a share, valuing his company at £1.2bn, though observers said between 150p and 175p was more realistic. The shares closed last week at 136p.

First Choice is expanding in Europe and increasing profits, but it ranks fourth in the UK. Observers believe that if C&N cannot secure Airtours at a realistic price, it could be more interested in UK number three Thomas Cook. The unquoted Cook's is valued at just £600 million, but it owns the most famous name in pack age travel, and a fast-growing holiday arm and airline under the new JMC brand.

Cook's is being sold by its parent, Preussag, the German holiday industry leader, as a condition for the latter's takeover of UK market leader Thomson. Preussag trumped rival C&N for Thomson in a bidding war earlier this year.

But US travel company Carlson owns part of Thomas Cook and has first refusal on the rest of the company when Preussag sells. Sources said Carlson was keen to do the deal but would be likely to hand a majority stake to a European partner - and C&N is discussing the option of taking that stake.

But while C&N considers whether to renegotiate with Airtours, First Choice chief executive Peter Long is understood to have approached C&N. He believes he can demand £2 a share, valuing his company at £1.2bn, though observers said between 150p and 175p was more realistic. The shares closed last week at 136p. First Choice is expanding in Europe and increasing profits, but it ranks fourth in the UK. Observers believe that if C&N cannot secure Airtours at a realistic price, it could be more interested in UK number three Thomas Cook. The unquoted Cook's is valued at just £600 million, but it owns the most famous name in pack age travel, and a fast-growing holiday arm and airline under the new JMC brand. Cook's is being sold by its parent, Preussag, the German holiday industry leader, as a condition for the latter's takeover of UK market leader Thomson. Preussag trumped rival C&N for Thomson in a bidding war earlier this year. But US travel company Carlson owns part of Thomas Cook and has first refusal on the rest of the company when Preussag sells. Sources said Carlson was keen to do the deal but would be likely to hand a majority stake to a European partner - and C&N is discussing the option of taking that stake.

fields.headline: To the power of four
fields.standfirst: Mike Figgis's movie gives you four stories at once, but is it worth the effort?
fields.trailText:
Time Code (97 mins, 15) Directed by Mike Figgis; starring Saffron Burrows, Stellan Skarsgard, Holly Hunter, Salma Hayek, Julian Sands

Mike Figgis's movie gives you four stories at once, but is it worth the effort?
fields.body:
A hundred years ago, primitive movie narratives would go back in time to show both sides of an event, as, for example, firemen called to a blazing house and the experience of the people trapped by the fire. Soon, with the discovery of montage, crosscutting and the flashback, the new language and grammar of film developed. By 1956, Stanley Kubrick's The Killing could jolt an audience by reverting to the primitive technique of turning back in time to show the roles of different participants during the course of a complex racetrack robbery.

There has, however, always been the possibility of simultaneous action being presented simultaneously by multiplying the images - Abel Gance experimented with a triple screen in Napoleon during the silent era; the short-lived Circlerama process had the audience promenading in an arena surrounded by a panorama of images; during the Sixties, a number of mainstream pictures (Frankenheimer's Grand Prix and Jewison's The Thomas Crown Affair ) used multiple images to rather chic effect; currently at the National Theatre, Alan Ayckbourn's House and Garden simultaneously cover two aspects of the same event in adjoining theatres with the same actors.

Now, Mike Figgis has had the idea of dividing the screen into four segments and following a group of characters over 90 minutes of unbroken time, using a digital video camera so that there are no cuts, thus going far beyond the elaborate 10-minute takes of Hitchcock and Miklós Jancsó. The experience is not unlike that of a security guard constantly having to keep an eye on a bank of screens to spot intruders or shoplifters, except that in this case everyone in sight has a familiar movie face and they're all carefully miked.

The time is an autumn afternoon in Hollywood. As the movie begins, in the top left-hand corner, a rich lesbian (Jeanne Tripplehorn) with a stretch limo, is taking her flighty Hispanic lover (Salma Hayek) to an audition. In the top-right frame, a distressed woman (Saffron Burrows) is talking of a failing marriage to her shrink (Glenne Headley). The bottom-left image takes in the lobby of the independent film company, Red Mullet Productions (the title of Figgis's firm), where a notice announces that auditions are being held for Bitch From Louisiana . The bottom-right screen shows an office where the studio's young executives wait the arrival of their inspirational chief, Alex (Stellan Skarsgard).

Over the next 90 minutes, as the characters criss-cross and collide, moving from one frame to another, we come to understand the relationships (for example, the woman in therapy is the producer's wife, who, in turn, is the lover of the Hispanic actress) and to recognise them as Tinseltown types - the coke-sniffing director, the alcoholic executive at the end of his tether, the disgusted wife, the suave agent.

That they carry conviction stems from the fact that the performers, who are ad-libbing, know these people and their jargon, though towards the end there are some awkward moments.

The action is punctuated by four jarring earth tremors (surely a record for one afternoon in LA) and like most Hollywood tales (Fitzgerald intended to conclude The Last Tycoon with Monroe Stahr's murder), the film leads towards a violent death.

Time Code is a virtuoso exercise of timing, lighting and planning; one marvels at the sang-froid of Figgis, his cast and crew. Though he constantly directs us to the dominant image of the moment by lowering the sound in the other panels, we're always watching what's going on elsewhere from the corner of our eye.

In the long take that opens Altman's The Player , several characters discuss the nature of the long takes in Welles and Hitchcock. In Time Code , a pretentious woman director, quoting Leibnitz, Borges, Eisenstein, and the Bauhaus theorists, makes a pitch to executives of Red Mullet about a film that uses multiple screens and continuous takes to tell a story in which 'the audience will provide the synthesis'. She's describing the film we're watching and though Alex the producer calls it 'the most pretentious shit I ever heard', they agree to green-light her movie.

Will Time Code lead some where or is it a one-off? The Danish films from the soon-defunct Dogme group made us reconsider the technique of current mainstream cinema and it may well be that this California syrup of Figgis may prove a useful intellectual purgative.

It makes us think about the way our perception of the world has been affected by film. But entertaining as it is, Time Code is physically taxing and one recalls those doctors in the early part of the last century who cautioned that the flickering screen could make you blind.

I admire this film, but emerged from it feeling exhausted, the way you do from a cocktail party where the chatter has been deafening and you've been anxiously glancing around, wondering whether conversation in other parts of the room was more interesting.

fields.headline: Can you really have a superhero called Xavier?
fields.standfirst:
X-Men (104 mins, 12) Directed by Bryan Singer; starring Ian Mc-Kellen, Patrick Stewart, Bruce Davison, Anna Paquin, Hugh Jackman
Those Who Love Me Can Take the Train (122 mins, 15) Directed by Patrice Chéreau; starring Jean-Louis Trintignant, Charles Bering, Pascal Greggory, Dominique Blanc
Me Myself I (104 mins, 15) Directed by Pip Karmel; starring Rachel Griffiths, David Roberts, Sandy Winton
Himalaya (108 mins, PG) Directed by Eric Valli; starring Thilen Lhondup, Gurgon Kyap
Siberia (91 mins, 18) Directed by Robert Jan Westdijk; starring Hugo Metsers, Roeland Fernhout, Vlatka Simac
Ring (95 mins, 15) Directed by Nakata Hideo; starring Matushima Nanako, Sanada Hiroyuki

X-Men (104 mins, 12) Directed by Bryan Singer; starring Ian Mc-Kellen, Patrick Stewart, Bruce Davison, Anna Paquin, Hugh Jackman
Those Who Love Me Can Take the Train (122 mins, 15) Directed by Patrice Chéreau; starring Jean-Louis Trintignant, Charles Bering, Pascal Greggory, Dominique Blanc
Me Myself I (104 mins, 15) Directed by Pip Karmel; starring Rachel Griffiths, David Roberts, Sandy Winton
Himalaya (108 mins, PG) Directed by Eric Valli; starring Thilen Lhondup, Gurgon Kyap

Siberia (91 mins, 18) Directed by Robert Jan Westdijk; starring Hugo Metsers, Roeland Fernhout, Vlatka Simac
Ring (95 mins, 15) Directed by Nakata Hideo; starring Matushima Nanako, Sanada Hiroyuki
fields.body:
In Quiz Show, the high-minded university teacher Mark Van Doren, played by Paul Scofield, dismisses cheating on a TV quiz show by saying that 'it's like plagiarising a comic strip'. The line is presumably intended to show how simple and naive people were back in the 1950s.

For as every child of our time knows, what could be more damnable, and actionable, than plagiarising a comic strip? Comic-strip authors are now cult figures like the superheroes they create, and Jack Lee, only begetter of Spiderman and the Hulk, was one of the chief speakers last week at a rally honouring President Clinton.

Bryan Singer's hi-tech SF fantasy, X-Men , is inspired by the legendary comic-book characters Jack Lee came up with in 1963 who, at the time, were a liberal challenge to various kinds of racial, social and political prejudices of the day. Lee proposed the existence in our midst of a species of mutants with super powers who are perceived by ordinary humans as a threat to society.

These mutants are divided into two rival camps that corresponded in the 1960s to the followers of Martin Luther King and Malcolm X. The calm, benevolent Professor Xavier (Patrick Stewart) attempts to shape his mutants to use their gifts on behalf of mankind and to work for assimilation or at least peaceful co-existence.

His deadly enemy and former friend, the hot-headed Magneto (Ian McKellen), fed up with compromise, is in favour of a pre-emptive strike against a hostile, inferior human race. He kidnaps a McCarthy-like US senator (Bruce Davison), who seeks to register and sequester mutants, and plans to wipe out a summit conference of world leaders convened to consider the mutant problem.

Like Tim Burton's two Batman films, The X-Men is a dark work with an emphasis on pain and suffering that is more masochistic than sadistic. Magneto and the wheelchair-borne Xavier go through self-inflicted agony in the pursuit of their causes and there are constant mutilations and woundings. The special effects are impressive, and ironic use is made of Ellis Island (setting for the world summit) and the Statue of Liberty (where Magneto establishes his headquarters).

But while Stewart and McKellen lend gravitas to the proceedings, The X-Men lacks the humour that made the similar, but more ambiguous, Men in Black such a delight.

Tolstoy was probably right in saying that every unhappy family is unhappy in its own way. But in the movies, dysfunctional families the world over act much like each other. Which is to say when gathered for weddings, birthdays and funerals they fight, go in for figurative and literal blood-letting, drag skeletons from cupboards, get maudlin drunk and try to put tiny plasters on the old wounds they've opened up.

Patrice Chéreau's Those Who Love Me Can Take the Train is a superior example of the horrific family reunion picture, in this case for the funeral of the 70-year-old minor painter, Jean-Baptiste Emmerich (a silent Jean-Louis Trintignant), who insists that his body be taken from Paris and buried in the world's largest cemetery in his native Limoges.

The film's first act takes place on the train where the friends, relatives and hangers-on of the exploitative, bi-sexual artist bicker and backbite as they recall their association with the deceased.

Meanwhile, the body is being transported south in the back of a car driven by an Algerian male nurse who had been his lover. 'Is it legal to carry a coffin in a private vehicle?' someone asks.

At Limoges, the painter's long-estranged twin brother (a more vocal Trintignant) is there to put everyone at ill-ease, and in the absence of a priest at the graveside, an elderly intellectual reads a poem by Stevie Smith and the dead man's embittered nephew (Charles Berling) makes a speech about how much they'd all been hated by the man they've gathered to bury.

More of the same ensues in Act Three, the wake in the family mansion, and because it's so wild, the effect is exhilarating rather than depressing. The actors confidently inhabit their characters and the picture looks good and has a stunning final helicopter shot of Limoges and the necropolis from the air, accompanied by the adagio from Mahler's Tenth Symphony. Generally, however, there's far too much music on a soundtrack that includes songs by Charles Aznavour, Björk, James Brown, Nina Simone and the Doors.

Me Myself I is a lightweight Australian comedy in the style of Peggy Sue Got Married and Closing Doors , starring Rachel Griffiths as a single career woman in her thirties.

While pondering her fate, Griffiths suddenly meets in some kind of parallel universe the version of her younger self who married her university sweetheart and settled down as housewife and mother.

The doppelgänger leaves her to cope with this new world in a Sydney suburb and the jokes are none too funny, especially those about potty training, helping a 10-year-old to fit her first tampon, and learning how to insert a diaphragm when you've become used to using condoms.

The charming Griffiths, who's like a restless Australian version of Juliette Binoche, almost makes it bearable.

Himalaya , the first feature film by Eric Valli, a French documentarist resident in Nepal, is a slow, ravishingly beautiful picture. A sort of Asian western, it's about the rivalry during a long, arduous journey over the Nepalese mountains between a village elder and a young drover with aspirations to become chieftain of the community.

This is in effect Red River with yaks instead of steers and there's even a sensible woman to mediate between the men, the role Joanne Dru has in reconciling John Wayne and Montgomery Clift in Hawks's film.

The heroes of Robert Jan Westdijk's Siberia , a flashy Dutch comedy, are two nasty young layabouts who exploit foreign female backpackers in Amsterdam, sleeping with them, stealing their money and ripping the identity page from their passports to keep as souvenirs. Neither gets his just deserts though a Russian girl rumbles their scheme.

I left this nasty picture reflecting that as students of law and medicine study legal and medical ethics, similar courses should be made obligatory in film schools.

Ring , one of the most popular Japanese pictures of recent years, is a mildly intriguing horror picture in which a Tokyo TV reporter investigates an urban legend about a strange video cassette that leads anyone seeing it to die within a week.

The story turns out to be true, and risking their lives, she and her ex-husband follow clues that lead to an offshore island and a witch's curse. Ring brings to mind the first hour of Lost Highway but lacks the haunting power of David Lynch's film.

fields.headline: Feat of Klee
fields.standfirst: The court jester of early modernism is on display. And about time too
fields.trailText: The court jester of early modernism is on display. And about time too
fields.body:
The Private Klee: Works by Paul Klee from the Burgi Collection
Scottish National Gallery of Modern Art, 22 October

The Buddha of the Bauhaus is what his pupils called him, the spiritual guru with the far-away mind. If that doesn't square with your image of Paul Klee as the creator of playful, scratchy, postcard-sized comedies, then it's hardly surprising - there hasn't been a show of his work in Britain for decades.

With a few exceptions in permanent collections, postcards are practically all we've had of his prodigious output until now. For that reason alone The Private Klee is a revelation, particularly since most of the paintings have never been seen in public before. But more than that, the show manages to condense his whole career in 140 tiny pictures. This is the miniaturist in miniature, the pocket A-Z.

If you see him as a comic master, the court jester of early modernism, then you won't be disappointed by this wonderful selection. Dogs perform antic send-ups of human dramas, room-service is provided by angels bearing tea trays, fish migrate upriver, winking conspiratorially as they shimmy off to breed.

From 1905, when Klee was in his twenties, there is a gruff-looking Icarus, one limb in a splint, and a decrepit phoenix not so much rising as stuck in the mud. From 1918, there is a church bell tolling, the chimes drawn as a juddering Heath-Robinson contraption exploding directly into the ear of a startled passer-by. Klee had already invented the ingenious pictographic style that would run and run from Hoffnung, Thurber and Ronald Searle to the illustrators and cartoonists of the present day.

This humour is not incidental to some high-art enterprise - it is the essential character of everything he made. Klee didn't even call himself an artist until 1914, when he took a trip to Tunisia and declared he'd finally discovered colour at the age of 35.

Look at The Harbour of Hammamet , painted in 1914, and you see some truth in this claim. There are the tessellations of floating colour - decoupled from line - the toy boats, the little palm trees, the trademark triangles. It could be an overture of things to come, right down to the backside of a quizzical beast legging it from the picture.

From this point until his early death in 1940, Klee was absorbed in a continuous, unpredictable, exhilarating experiment. 'No day without a line' was his motto and no day without some quirky new method. Edinburgh has a case of his improvised tools: dinner knives, manicure sticks, a few hairs bound to a bamboo tube.

He painted on glass, canvas, plaster and newsprint, on handkerchiefs, wrapping paper and parachute silk. He would turn an accidental blot into a sudden new planet or exoticise a panel of invented hieroglyphics with a frame of tin foil.

One of the most brilliant works here, Scholar (1933), is a mixture of watercolour and wax applied to sackcloth. Three lines - an oval, a tight lip and a frown drawn pompously low over one eye - and you have the parody Casaubon incised in a brown study of fusty old fabric.

'Taking a line for a walk' was Klee's imperishable phrase, though it doesn't begin to describe his gift for selecting, balancing and orchestrating lines so that they take the eye for a walk through fields of graphic energy. You need time for this show because there is so much to read, from the swarms of coded symbols - arrows, clefs, pyramids, flags - along the high wires, up and down the ladders and via the crosshatchings and musical staves that act as a kind of underlying grammar. This is even before the words Klee inscribed in his pictures, the titles, jokes and comic exclamations, the tiny signatures alighting on the canvas like interested insects.

It is often said that Klee created music for the eye or that he took the language of art and translated it into a new idiom scaled to the world of a child. That may be so, but it seems to take too simple a cue from all those quavers and punctuation marks. It also accepts at face value Klee's own theories about art, elaborated during his stint as the Buddha of the Bauhaus in the 1920s.

For such a modest man - look at his oblique, effacing self-portraits - Klee's manifestos were incredibly ambitious. He believed that musical counterpoint could be transcribed into colour, that a visual equivalent to every spiritual emotion could be found. Fortunately, you can walk right through this show unaware of Klee's theories, which is the emotional equivalent of escaping homework. But his deepest statement has been included - 'Art does not render the visible, it renders visible.'

Klee was speaking mystically, but what's rendered visible in his work is surely the artist's own spirit - lightsome, benign, supremely comical.

Klee has a whole range of humorous smiles. The sympathetic: a man obsessed, tiny hands clasped to breast, his outsize head filled to bursting with the shapely image of the beloved. The zany: a menagerie of wild animals on a day-trip to the country. The affectionate: badly over-excited children collapsing in a scribble on the floor.

Above all, Klee's wit disarms. His snakes - he apparently liked chatting to snakes while out walking - are skittish wriggles, not even Jungle Book scary. Anxiety, for him, is a little guy toying absurdly with the edge of a cliff; war is a bunch of cockeyed devils.

Klee did paint more ambivalent and melancholy works, particularly after escaping from the Nazis in 1933, but the Burgi family, who helped him reach Switzerland, have more light than shade in their private collection.

Even on this scale, it's possible to see the colossal influence Klee has had over art - from Picasso to op and pop - and the way he opened up the whole act of making. You can't get this from reproductions, any more than the humour that seems to be ingrained in the very fabric of his paintings.

Edinburgh is the only chance to see the Burgi collection in Britain. Don't miss these smiling, smile-inducing paintings.

Klee had already invented the ingenious pictographic style that would run and run from Hoffnung, Thurber and Ronald Searle to the illustrators and cartoonists of the present day. This humour is not incidental to some high-art enterprise - it is the essential character of everything he made. Klee didn't even call himself an artist until 1914, when he took a trip to Tunisia and declared he'd finally discovered colour at the age of 35. Look at The Harbour of Hammamet , painted in 1914, and you see some truth in this claim. There are the tessellations of floating colour - decoupled from line - the toy boats, the little palm trees, the trademark triangles. It could be an overture of things to come, right down to the backside of a quizzical beast legging it from the picture. From this point until his early death in 1940, Klee was absorbed in a continuous, unpredictable, exhilarating experiment. 'No day without a line' was his motto and no day without some quirky new method. Edinburgh has a case of his improvised tools: dinner knives, manicure sticks, a few hairs bound to a bamboo tube. He painted on glass, canvas, plaster and newsprint, on handkerchiefs, wrapping paper and parachute silk. He would turn an accidental blot into a sudden new planet or exoticise a panel of invented hieroglyphics with a frame of tin foil. One of the most brilliant works here, Scholar (1933), is a mixture of watercolour and wax applied to sackcloth. Three lines - an oval, a tight lip and a frown drawn pompously low over one eye - and you have the parody Casaubon incised in a brown study of fusty old fabric. 'Taking a line for a walk' was Klee's imperishable phrase, though it doesn't begin to describe his gift for selecting, balancing and orchestrating lines so that they take the eye for a walk through fields of graphic energy. You need time for this show because there is so much to read, from the swarms of coded symbols - arrows, clefs, pyramids, flags - along the high wires, up and down the ladders and via the crosshatchings and musical staves that act as a kind of underlying grammar. This is even before the words Klee inscribed in his pictures, the titles, jokes and comic exclamations, the tiny signatures alighting on the canvas like interested insects. It is often said that Klee created music for the eye or that he took the language of art and translated it into a new idiom scaled to the world of a child. That may be so, but it seems to take too simple a cue from all those quavers and punctuation marks. It also accepts at face value Klee's own theories about art, elaborated during his stint as the Buddha of the Bauhaus in the 1920s. For such a modest man - look at his oblique, effacing self-portraits - Klee's manifestos were incredibly ambitious. He believed that musical counterpoint could be transcribed into colour, that a visual equivalent to every spiritual emotion could be found. Fortunately, you can walk right through this show unaware of Klee's theories, which is the emotional equivalent of escaping homework. But his deepest statement has been included - 'Art does not render the visible, it renders visible.' Klee was speaking mystically, but what's rendered visible in his work is surely the artist's own spirit - lightsome, benign, supremely comical. Klee has a whole range of humorous smiles. The sympathetic: a man obsessed, tiny hands clasped to breast, his outsize head filled to bursting with the shapely image of the beloved. The zany: a menagerie of wild animals on a day-trip to the country. The affectionate: badly over-excited children collapsing in a scribble on the floor. Above all, Klee's wit disarms. His snakes - he apparently liked chatting to snakes while out walking - are skittish wriggles, not even Jungle Book scary. Anxiety, for him, is a little guy toying absurdly with the edge of a cliff; war is a bunch of cockeyed devils. Klee did paint more ambivalent and melancholy works, particularly after escaping from the Nazis in 1933, but the Burgi family, who helped him reach Switzerland, have more light than shade in their private collection. Even on this scale, it's possible to see the colossal influence Klee has had over art - from Picasso to op and pop - and the way he opened up the whole act of making. You can't get this from reproductions, any more than the humour that seems to be ingrained in the very fabric of his paintings. Edinburgh is the only chance to see the Burgi collection in Britain. Don't miss these smiling, smile-inducing paintings.

fields.headline: Strip poker and cross-dressing... not in Handel's notes
fields.standfirst: The city heaves with youthful exuberance, but to listen to the music programme you'd never know it
fields.trailText: Newly arrived in Edinburgh from the Moon, you could be forgiven for thinking that music suffered the same demise as the dinosaurs, coming to a cataclysmic end after a period of unchallenged glory.
fields.body:
Cleveland Chorus St Giles's Cathedral
Cleveland Symphony Usher Hall
Gregory Turay The Queen's Hall
Alcina Stuttgart State Opera, Edinburgh Festival Theatre
Gothic Voices St Mary's Cathedral

Newly arrived in Edinburgh from the Moon, you could be forgiven for thinking that music suffered the same demise as the dinosaurs, coming to a cataclysmic end after a period of unchallenged glory. On the evidence of the Festival's first week, you might date that flowering between 1770 (to include the best of Mozart) and 1890 (allowing for Wagner, Schumann, Bruckner and a few familiar others).

After that, barring a few survivors and oddballs, it appears to be all over. The idea that the art form is still vital, with living composers as multifarious and adventurous as at any time in history - in Scotland as well as further afield - simply wouldn't occur.

This dismal state of affairs is little different this year from last, the last from the one before. What is it with Edinburgh and music? The city seethes with youth and novelty, good or bad, in the theatre, whether fringe or mainstream festival. Things happen. Careers are made.

With concerts and opera, there appears no pretence at innovation, only safe endorsement. The same old favourites return year after year. Audiences grow greyer. Traditions such as Andras Schiff playing Bach, an old Edinburgh habit, provide a skeleton on which to build a good festival. But only risk and deviation can bring life.

You could hardly imagine Sir John Drummond, that veteran rattler of cages, to have settled for such an easy time in his days at the Edinburgh helm. In his new book (out next month), he implies, with a characteristic sting, that his successor, Brian McMaster doesn't have to leave home to seek his artists: 'The fact that he invites the same people year after year means he probably needs to travel less than I did.'

Edinburgh favours the monothematic: all Schumann's symphonies, all Haydn's string quartets and this year, in seven concerts, all Mozart's piano concertos. Premieres are hard to track down amid the thickets of all this Austro-Hungarian repertoire. Last week, the only hint that works are still being written today were two short choral pieces by James MacMillan (highly engaging, with blazing organ writing, but not new) in an afternoon concert by the Cleveland Chorus , an agile, beautifully drilled choir despite its great size.

The Cleveland singers also sang, with admirably silky tone, three Bruckner motets, a warm-up for the same composer's popular Fourth Symphony played that evening by their parent orchestra, the Cleveland Symphony , at Usher Hall. Christoph von Dohnanyi and this streamlined ensemble gave a stoutly robust account of the work Bruckner called his 'Romantic'. The brass revelled in the colossal chorales and fanfares but the symphony's dissatisfyingly episodic nature was never quite resolved. Frank Peter Zimmermann was a sympathetic soloist in Berg's Violin Concerto, though the work's ghostly, veiled textures only just survived under the weight of this orchestra's generous and eager sound.

The Queen's Hall morning chamber series usually guarantee quality, which should provide excitement of a kind. But the week began unhappily, with an ill-judged recital by the young American tenor, Gerald Turay . His voice sounded strained and tense, his grasp of the texts, and the languages in which he sang, unconvincing. His facial mannerisms, hand waving and impassioned gaze into the middle distance is better suited to an Al Jolson repertoire than to Schubert, Fauré or Rachmaninov.

Turay has a big, ringing top register which has already served him well in smaller roles on the opera stage. At 26, he is still young in singers' terms. Despite his evident talent, he should never have been thrown into a recital of this prominence so early in his career.

The opening opera production was a modern dress (or undress) staging of Handel's Alcina by Stuttgart State Opera which managed to make this vivacious, sparkling work dour, boring and baffling. The set featured a huge magic mirror and a pile of old rag-and-bone junk in an otherwise empty, seedy, flock-wallpapered salon with fluorescent striplights. Most of the tricks in Jossi Wieler and Sergio Morabito's production were played out in the first half hour and then repeated ad tedium . Despite the cuts to the score, it was a long evening.

In the title role, a seductively-voiced Catherine Naglestad appeared in a fashion parade of unflattering garments while everyone else engaged in their own versions of strip poker and cross-dressing with much shoe-kissing, groping and widespread slobbering. Handel's subtle psychological edifice was flattened beyond recognition. Nevertheless, musical standards were high, with fine performances from Alice Coote, Helene Schneiderman and Claudia Mahnke. Alan Hacker conducted a meaty, spirited performance on modern instruments, a missed opportunity for period playing but the Edinburgh Festival appears to have a resistance to that form of music making.

At least Gothic Voices , at the start of a Music of the Millennium series , managed their own inspired, pure-voiced kind of authenticity with a programme of works by Hildegard of Bingen and twelfth-century contemporaries. The group's regular line-up of one soprano and three tenors, directed and introduced by Christopher Page, sang the abbess's jewelled texts to a hushed, capacity audience in St Mary's Cathedral, Gilbert Scott's now sooty Victorian Gothic tribute to a medieval past we scarcely understand but whose spirit we seem to know. Suddenly, Edinburgh came alive.

fields.headline: Now is the time to forget Fonteyn
fields.trailText: Fireworks greeted the opening night of New York City Ballet's Edinburgh season, 33 years after the company last appeared in the festival. Brian McMaster has been heralding the return of NYCB by programming smaller, regional American companies in previous festivals.
fields.body:
New York City Ballet
Edinburgh Playhouse

Fireworks greeted the opening night of New York City Ballet's Edinburgh season, 33 years after the company last appeared in the festival. Brian McMaster has been heralding the return of NYCB by programming smaller, regional American companies in previous festivals.

Directed by former NYCB members, these troupes dance Balanchine ballets with a verve that some New York critics rate more highly than the style of the home team.

George Balanchine, NYCB's founder-choreographer, died in 1983 and his chosen successor, Peter Martins, has been criticised ever since for failing to keep the faith. Anthony Dowell has endured similar attacks over the Royal Ballet's Ashton heritage.

While critics cavil, audiences get on with enjoying the ballets and the current generation of dancers. Forget Fonteyn and Farrell, let's respond instead to today's youngsters. Yet there is still a need to be reassured that what we are seeing is the Real Thing.

Peter Martins has met the challenge head on by bringing three programmes of Balanchine 'classics' that are danced by other companies around the world: tutu ballets, such as Symphony in C and Serenade , as well as the black-and-white modernist works - Agon , The Four Temperaments , Symphony in Three Movements . And to show that NYCB is not purely a Balanchine museum, he also brought his own Fearful Symmetries (1990) and Jerome Robbins's Dances at a Gathering (1969).

There can be no doubting that this company speaks Balanchine as a first language, a father-idiom. When Mr B (as he became known to Americans) moved to the United States in 1933, he reconfigured Russian ballet training to suit New World bodies and spirits.

He didn't want American girls trying to be sylphs, swans or dryads; he moulded them into balletic amazons - the pony-tailed, long-legged athletes of Symphony in Three Movements , a predatory swarm in The Four Temperaments .

He didn't expect them to look like the Kirov corps or the Paris Opera Ballet. Yet because those companies have reclaimed the Balanchine ballets that draw on their history - Symphony in C , Jewels , Theme and Variations - they dance them better, more classically, than the Americans.

NYCB's corps in the opening night Symphony in C looked like hell in their Karinska tutus, and collectively blurred their famously fleet technique. Admittedly, they were handicapped by the shallow Playhouse stage and by Andrea Quinn as guest conductor, but they were not dancing in the same league as the Kirov.

Yet the soloists can be incomparable, from mature dancers like Kyra Nichols, Helene Alexopoulos, Peter Boal, Jock Soto, all the way through the new breed - Maria Kowroski, Jenifer Ringer, Jennie Somogyi, Dana Hanson and Benjamin Millepied.

The older dancers play with the music and their emotions; the younger ones are eager, razor-sharp. There is none of the sentimentality that can taint the interpretations of non-Balanchine companies.

So, when the top soloists and supporting casts come out in Agon or The Four Temperaments, they deliver the authentic thrill of amazement that ballet can be like this. You wonder how on earth Balanchine could have imagined anything so strange and so apt. The dancers know, because they have grown up understanding his grammar, his wit and his way of apprehending music.

And when they wind their way through Concerto Barocco , they look like Stanley Spencer's selfless workers in his shipbuilding on the Clyde series at the National Portrait Gallery, most truly themselves when absorbed in a community task, part of an overarching pattern.

fields.headline: Come up and see my leching
fields.standfirst: It's a Spanish philanderfest - from an oversexed Don Juan to Picasso, the 'penis who paints'
fields.trailText: It's a Spanish philanderfest - from an oversexed Don Juan to Picasso, the 'penis who paints'
fields.body:
No 2 Assembly Rooms
Barbaric Comedies Kings Theatre
Don Juan Royal Lyceum Theatre
Picasso's Women Assembly Rooms

The festival is in disarray. Stretched between official and Fringe events, it lasts too long and it's too bad. And its points of reference are topsy-turvy. Where do you expect the crispest writing and accomplished direction? The Traverse. So in what sense is the Traverse part of the Fringe? Why should the official festival, with its big-name directors, its makeover merchants, be called 'international' when it's more often a modestly funded Fringe performance that wires you directly into another culture's psyche?

As does Toa Fraser's gentle Fiji romance, No 2 . This South Seas bubble draws on the background of its 25-year-old dramatist and its 20-year-old actor: Fraser's family left Fiji for New Zealand in the Fifties; the magically self-transforming Madeleine Sami is part Fijian Indian. A gradually unwinding story of family quarrels and closeness is told through dreams and legends, sharp gossip and hip-hop.

In an Auckland house, the number two of the title, a crotchety old Fijian matriarch, drinker of homemade grog, puffer of cigars, lover of fighting and music, of Jill Dando and Jamie Oliver, dreams of long-lost ancestral customs - and of deciding which of her grandchildren will succeed her as head of the clan.

Sami plays all the contenders. She's the crosspatch, sentimental old woman, with clipped vowels and crooked arms. She's the precocious infant with a big chin and a comprehensive knowledge of island legend. She's a lovesick rugby player - her voice shifting into a husky male register - and his randy, athletically break-dancing cousin. She's a self-obsessed model called Hibiscus, and an eerie English girl. She's a marvel who could only happen on the Fringe.

The International Festival got off to a dreadful start with the Abbey Theatre Dublin's production of Barbaric Comedies . The Galician dramatist Ramón Maria del Valle-Inclán has been credited as an influence on Almodóvar, Lorca and Buñuel; he has been lauded for employing a ground-breaking, anti-naturalistic cinematic technique, and celebrated as a self-destructive dandy. All this may be true, but on the evidence of Frank McGuinness's new version of the dramatist's trilogy, it's hard to see why anyone would love his plays for themselves.

Under Calixto Bieito's direction, Barbaric Comedies is a mess. On to a murkily lit stage surge grateful peasants, corrupt cardinals, unsullied damsels, wild-eyed whores and bloodthirsty brothers. Everyone seems to have come out of the stock cupboard of Spanish drama. A randy old goat of a father provides one of the mainstays of the plot, with his unconvincing progress from lech to penitent. Its most lucid moments are its most lurid: varied violent rapes, and masturbation over the boiled-up corpse of a woman. Hardly a minute of the four and a half hours seems to pass without someone yelling, wailing, falling to the ground or waving their legs in the air.

Mats Ek's production of Molière's Don Juan - brought from the Royal Dramatic Theatre, Stockholm, and performed in Swedish - is more composed. So composed that, with all its wheezes, it gives off an air of being constructed, made up. Which is not entirely appropriate as a way of treating a hero who gets carried away. A director is strutting his stuff.

Ek's major innovation - apart from turning every sexual innuendo into a sexual act - is to introduce dance sequences throughout the play. Squirmy-legged or smooching, these intervals are often amusing, but it's not clear what prompts them. Are they underlining or undermining what is being said? Why does such movement not seep into the rest of the play?

There's more flash than illumination. But there are moments of great flair. About to be given the nod by the statue of the Commendatore, Don Juan and his valet advance towards the audience, only to find themselves cut off - and forever - from the world they've inhabited as the safety curtain comes down behind them. Just before going to hell, the dirty Don slumps in a scarlet chair, with the orange glow from a television flickering over his face like infernal flames. And Mikael Persbrandt is compelling in the title role: a fleshy, dead-eyed voluptuary who puts on a really bad black wig to go wooing.

This year is proving to be something of a philanderfest. At the Assembly Rooms, four one-person plays are devoted to the cross reflections of women who have been soured by living with a 'penis who paints'.

Picasso's Women sets out to tell the stories of some of the artist's companions, to give them back the voices they always thought they had. But despite the considerable and sometimes glittering efforts of the four actresses, Brian McAvera's plays succeed only in presenting a series of dull stereotypes.

There's Dora Maar, played unweepingly and too reverentially by Toyah Wilcox: the mad (but not really) one. There's Olga, the Russian aristocrat of the 'darlink' variety who obliges Geraldine Fitzgerald to produce a quantity of soulful, gurgling vowels. More fruitfully, Amanda Harris - as Françoise Gilot, the fierce one who got away - steamrollers over the banalities of her script with her great swooping voice and powerful, pent-up movements, and suggests someone who might have sculpted her own life and works. And Susannah York is so fluid and beguiling that she takes the sting out of the boringly reductive view of Jacqueline Roque as the minx who plotted to get the genius.

Still, it's a good idea and talent wasted. The women are diminished by the language they use. Their excitement at their lover is sometimes banal - Pablo provides 'the aphrodisiac of power' - and sometimes craven: 'after Picasso - God'. Their sexual descriptions are Mills & Boon: female mounds and tent-peg nipples. And never is there a glimmer of what might be the other point: how each woman entered the paintings.

Squirmy-legged or smooching, these intervals are often amusing, but it's not clear what prompts them. Are they underlining or undermining what is being said? Why does such movement not seep into the rest of the play? There's more flash than illumination. But there are moments of great flair. About to be given the nod by the statue of the Commendatore, Don Juan and his valet advance towards the audience, only to find themselves cut off - and forever - from the world they've inhabited as the safety curtain comes down behind them. Just before going to hell, the dirty Don slumps in a scarlet chair, with the orange glow from a television flickering over his face like infernal flames. And Mikael Persbrandt is compelling in the title role: a fleshy, dead-eyed voluptuary who puts on a really bad black wig to go wooing. This year is proving to be something of a philanderfest. At the Assembly Rooms, four one-person plays are devoted to the cross reflections of women who have been soured by living with a 'penis who paints'. Picasso's Women sets out to tell the stories of some of the artist's companions, to give them back the voices they always thought they had. But despite the considerable and sometimes glittering efforts of the four actresses, Brian McAvera's plays succeed only in presenting a series of dull stereotypes. There's Dora Maar, played unweepingly and too reverentially by Toyah Wilcox: the mad (but not really) one. There's Olga, the Russian aristocrat of the 'darlink' variety who obliges Geraldine Fitzgerald to produce a quantity of soulful, gurgling vowels. More fruitfully, Amanda Harris - as Françoise Gilot, the fierce one who got away - steamrollers over the banalities of her script with her great swooping voice and powerful, pent-up movements, and suggests someone who might have sculpted her own life and works. And Susannah York is so fluid and beguiling that she takes the sting out of the boringly reductive view of Jacqueline Roque as the minx who plotted to get the genius. Still, it's a good idea and talent wasted. The women are diminished by the language they use. Their excitement at their lover is sometimes banal - Pablo provides 'the aphrodisiac of power' - and sometimes craven: 'after Picasso - God'. Their sexual descriptions are Mills & Boon: female mounds and tent-peg nipples. And never is there a glimmer of what might be the other point: how each woman entered the paintings.

fields.headline: The hardest working arse at the Fringe
fields.standfirst: Charlie Skelton's Fringe awards
fields.trailText: I'm no fan of Shakti's arse. Which is a shame, because Shakti herself seems terribly fond of it. Fond enough to shove it like a cat on heat into her audience's faces for two long hours every day. In Shakti's head, her exuberant dance piece 'The Woman in the Dunes' is a fearless examination of the battle between freedom and constraint in the workings of the subconscious.
fields.body:
I'm no fan of Shakti's arse. Which is a shame, because Shakti herself seems terribly fond of it. Fond enough to shove it like a cat on heat into her audience's faces for two long hours every day. In Shakti's head, her exuberant dance piece 'The Woman in the Dunes' is a fearless examination of the battle between freedom and constraint in the workings of the subconscious.

Whether or not the large numbers of middle-aged single men in the audience see it as such is a matter of debate. Perhaps they are experts in the subtle nuances of Hindu bum-shaking. Perhaps the constant crossing and uncrossing of their legs is a sign of thoughtful artistic appreciation. Perhaps Shakti's bottom is conveying dark truths about the human condition which are simply too stark and raw for me, with my narrow Western mindset, to take on board. Either way, the whole thing was a bit too buttock-heavy for my liking.

So, although she's heading for her fourth consecutive Hardest Working Backside At The Fringe award, Shakti's set to lose out in the Most Entrancing Genitals category. Pipping Shakti's classically trained rump to the post are the genitals of Steve Ryland, who plays The Monster in a profoundly trite dance interpretation of Frankenstein.

At the point of the Monster's creation, Ryland stands boldly starkers at the front of the stage, groaning and racked with birth pangs, for a good five minutes. In Ryland's head, he is laying bare the primordial anguish of creation. Whether or not the large numbers of middle-aged single men in the audience see it as such is a matter of debate. Certainly, any thoughts about the primordial anguish of creation were absent from my mind as my eyes, like the eyes of a buzzard fixated upon a shrew, followed his cock and balls as they bounced about the stage.

Frankenstein is tipped for several other Observer Real Fringe awards this year, including Worst Sound Effect (when Mary Shelley puts pen to paper, it sounds like she's sanding the rust off a tin bath, in the company of 30 hungry mice), and Most Preposterous Overacting (for Shaun Haggan's hilarious Victor Frankenstein - which resembles the lovechild of Brian Blessed and Basil Brush).

And yet, Haggan is by no means the Worst Actor at the Fringe. The real contenders for this coveted crown are lurking in the world of comedy. A good half dozen are lurking in Tickle Soup. Not since the first series of Holding the Baby has a group of people more ill-suited to performing been assembled in a single cast. Whoever told James Woroniecki that he should tread the boards either loved him rather too much or had a sick sense of humour. My guess is that it's the same twisted genius who told a well-meaning trio of Hull drama students that they should bring the world Four Little Plays Called Rape. Whoever it was has done the world a service. I doff my cap.

fields.headline: I have seen the future
fields.trailText: You can tell it's the twenty-first century because the hot, cramped, lower-echelon comedy venues of Edinburgh are a mess of cables and electronic equipment.
fields.body:
Noble and Silver Gilded Balloon
The League Against Tedium Meadows Theatre Big Top

You can tell it's the twenty-first century because the hot, cramped, lower-echelon comedy venues of Edinburgh are a mess of cables and electronic equipment. In the future, it seems, comedy will have no punchlines and live performers will function merely as cogs in a precisely timed multimedia machine. That, at least, is if Noble and Silver are the future of comedy.

Two hollow-cheeked twentysomething men with the serious, expressionless faces of slightly funky scientists or a young Gilbert & George, Noble and Silver are the most innovative live comedians I have ever seen; to such an extent that most people would probably not consider them comedians at all. In place of jokes and observations and funny faces and impressions and swear words and interpersonal chemistry and all the standard armaments of the comic duo, Noble and Silver have digital video cameras, a TV set, a video screen, a tape player, and a series of intriguing little playlets, in which their relationships and personalities are swapped and multiplied with perplexing randomness. They stare out blankly from the screen for minutes on end, larger than their living selves, then suddenly make a comment, instigating a four- or six-way conversation.

What they don't do is as important as what they do. Noble and Silver are so dessicated and abstract, so ruthless in their refusal to use any of the clichés or old tricks of comedy that they make the more innovative major comics - Steve Coogan, Reeves and Mortimer, The Boosh - seem positively music-hall. I would guess that Chris Morris and Simon Munnery are their only role models; but even the deadpan satire of Brass Eye and the pitch-dark psychodramas of Jam conform to more conventions of humour than this one-hour show.

Which will, naturally, lead lots of people to conclude, angrily, that they are just not funny at all . The fact that Noble and Silver will provoke such outrage despite (or rather, because of) being so non-attitudinous themselves, only adds to their attractiveness, and their funniness.

The trouble with technology, of course, is that sometimes it doesn't work. The night I saw Noble and Silver, they were glitch-free; The League Against Tedium , on the other hand, was one long glitch. Simon Munnery's 'ubertechnokomedie' was at its peak 18 months ago at London's ICA, when he had a two-hour show which was both crowd-pleasing and highly original.

For this year's festival, he has tried to up the technology stakes by using a keyboard guitar linked to a camera, computer and projector. Given the right money, it would probably have been stunning, but Munnery has instead found himself stranded embarrassingly in the middle of the Meadows, relying on his old stock of one-liners to cover up the electronic holes. It's a setback, comrade, but persevere: the revolution will be televised.

fields.headline: Welcome to the new brutalism
fields.standfirst: Horrific sexual acts on stage. Mutilated bodies in a gallery. And now Chopper, a new movie about a real serial killer. But what does shocking art tell us about the way we live now? By  Vanessa Thorpe
fields.trailText: Horrific sexual acts on stage. Mutilated bodies in a gallery. And now Chopper, a new movie about a real serial killer. But what does shocking art tell us about the way we live now?
fields.body:
Mark Brandon Read is clearly a suitable case for treatment. After all, he earned his affectionate nickname, the Chopper, by using a bolt-cutter to separate his victims' feet from their toes. He also won himself a place in the gossip columns when he shaved his own ears off in a Melbourne jail. Grounds for some psychiatric interest there certainly, but is Read also a suitable case for film treatment?

The programmers at this year's Edinburgh Film Festival are in no doubt. Chopper , the blackly comic film version of the books that Read wrote while he was serving time in Australia, may not be listed in the official programme, but organisers see its last-minute accquisition as a 'coup'. The director of the festival, Lizzie Francke, secured screening rights after lengthy negotiations and points out that this homely story of 'a normal bloke who likes a bit of torture' has pushed Mel Gibson's The Patriot off the top box-office spot in Australian cinemas.

The film has taken the fashionably flip approach to brutality into fresh territory. It marks another staging post in the quest to be artistically modern by shocking the public, if not with violence itself, then with a glibly amoral perspective. Murdoch's Fox Corporation abruptly pulled out of a distribution deal for Chopper over there, but back here, Metrodrome, the British independent, has boldly stepped in. Despite accusations that the film wilfully glamorises a man who admits 'wiping out' 19 people 'for the good of society', Metrodome's managing director, Rupert Preston, is happy to be bringing Chopper to a wider public.

'Whatever people say about the violence, it is actually a good film,' he says. 'There is a gruesome scene where he is stabbed and we do see him cut his ears off so that he can get into prison hospital, but actually there is more vivid violence in any of the Scream sequels.'

Preston believes what has shocked some people is the screenplay's obvious empathy with Read, who is played by the stand-up comedian Eric Bana. 'That is rather disturbing,' he admits.

Across the city, Edinburgh's theatre audiences are shying away from the equally shocking excesses of the Barbaric Comedies . This play, which features necrophiliac masturbation, among other arcane depravities, has just as much to offer when it comes to shock value, but, according to critics less in the way of artistic merit.

It is the Irish playwright Frank McGuinness's four-hour reworking of a Spanish trilogy which was written early last century by Ramón del Valle-Inclán. 'The world portrayed by Valle-Inclán is a very brutal one,' says Ben Barnes, the artistic director of Dublin's Abbey Theatre, the company behind the production. 'But none of the violence is there without a purpose.'

Rather like Mark Brandon Read, Valle-Inclán was more famous for his eccentric lifestyle than for his writings. He insisted on having his left arm amputated when it was injured in a fight. His 16-hour stage epic was not thought fit to stage in his lifetime, so why are we expected to embrace it now?

It is a sympton of a new brutalism in entertainment which is sweeping across both traditionally highbrow and lowbrow cultural platforms. The Royal Court Theatre's recent production of On Rafferty's Hill upset audiences with its opening rape scene and Patrick McGrath's new novel, Martha Peake , contains an equally unsettling incestuous rape scene at its core. Looked at in tandem with the headline-grabbing tactics of the Young British Artists, such as the biologically-fixated Jake and Dinos Chapman, it seems that art has to be unpleasantly disturbing.

Jonathan Bartley, the general secretary of the Movement for Christian Democracy, claims he is far from a foam-mouthed censor, but he believes that the search for artistic impact has now gone too far.

'The work we have been doing on media and screen dependency has suggested that people have been desensitised,' he says. 'In order to get a better reaction artists have had to go to further extremes. It is about finding a new kick and a new thrill. Very often, these shock tactics are a substitute for real creativity.' So is there no other purpose behind this ceaseless search for more raw and brutal forms of diversion?

The playwright Howard Brenton views the question with more perspective than most. Twenty years ago, his play Romans in Britain rocked the middle classes with its scenes of nudity and male rape. The critic James Fenton called it a 'nauseating load of rubbish' and moral guardian Mary Whitehouse launched a private prosecution against the director, Michael Bogdanov. 'Shock tactics are as old as the theatre,' he says, 'but they are not enough on their own.'

Brenton believes the only memorable dramatic shocks are those that reveal something relevant, whether it is the moment in Euripides's Bacchae when Agave enters carrying the head of her son, or the moment in Coward's The Vortex when a heroin syringe is produced. 'Shakespeare understood the proper build-up of horror in Titus Andronicus , but people do it now because you can write it quickly and it is a solution to a creative problem.'

The modern race for value-added shocks may then be heading for an artistic brick wall. For a start, many of those supposedly 'upset' audience members who walked out of performances of the Barbaric Comedies in Edinburgh are as likely to have been bored as they were offended.

If creative brutality has really entered a phase of destructive decadence, there is at least one man who will be celebrating. J.G. Ballard, who wrote the book Crash that was then turned into a controversial film, suspects the trend is a good thing.

'In the years leading up to the abolition of censorship in the late Sixties, filmmakers and writers and artists were all pushing against those barriers,' he argues. 'But since then we have been fighting back against something different - against the all-pervasive entertainment culture and the sentimentalised values of TV blandness. People are searching for truth through trying to shock, although it may sometimes be an artificial truth that they find.'

Ballard points to the public reaction to Tracey Emin's unmade bed or to David Cronenberg's film version of Crash . 'Mainstream entertainment is so manufactured now and this is what extreme artists are kicking against.

'As a result, many younger writers and filmmakers are now simply expressing their own obsessions; that is all that is left that they feel they can say something truthful about. They don't want to accept the values imposed on them by adverts and entertainment corporations - and on the whole that is a good thing.'

Ballard concedes, however, that it is all too easy to exploit shock tactics. 'After all, any drunk on an aeroplane can lean over and vomit on you and there is nothing original in that.'

For Susie Orbach, the way that society handles its essential brutality is a key to understanding its pressures. 'We have lived in barbaric societies for many centuries now, but what is different is the particular forms that culture finds to express this,' she says. 'Shocking art does extend the repertoire, but I really don't think these images of depravity and mutilation are sitting inside everyone's psyche just waiting to come out.

'I do think a more general rage and emptiness can produce very violent feelings in society. The forms in which these are then being expressed creatively speak, instead, of a kind of desperation rather than about the brutality they seek to portray.'

The new brutality is a symptom, then, of a general malaise. Something that may serve as a cry for attention but does not stand for the violence it enacts. 'These films and plays and artworks give an image to something that there is disquiet about,' says Orbach. 'They are not overtly political, but I think that what globalisation does is depoliticise people because no one has a relationship with civic society.'

Orbach, like Ballard, believes brutal art forms represent part of a search to express something; it is just that, unfortunately, not every search produces something artistically interesting on its own terms.

In attempting to encourage artists away from sex and violence, campaigners like Bartley and his Movement for Christian Democracy accidentally show how culturally defining the creative search for taboos always is. 'Playwrights and artists have always pushed back barriers, but those barriers have changed so that, for example, at certain times even paedophilia and rape were not quite so taboo and so were left alone. These things change.'

The brutality that elicits a gasp or a boo from an audience will always highlight exactly where the edges of social acceptability lie, and, as a result, artists are never likely to be able to leave that edge alone.

fields.headline: This too, too solid flesh
fields.standfirst: Simon Russell Beale is not everyone's ideal Hamlet and he's heard all the 'tubby or not tubby' jokes. But when you're this good an actor, you don't need to have a pretty face
fields.trailText: Simon Russell Beale is not everyone's ideal Hamlet and he's heard all the 'tubby or not tubby' jokes. But when you're this good an actor, you don't need to have a pretty face
fields.body:
Simon Russell Beale has been deliberating the question of being or not being Hamlet for more than a decade. Ever since his landmark performance as Konstantin in Terry Hands's production of The Seagull in 1991, in which he graduated from being the RSC's favourite caricaturist to becoming the most perceptive English stage actor of his generation, he has been widely championed to play what he calls the 'other great mother-son role'.

Still, he says, sipping coffee in the morning sun outside the Festival Theatre in Malvern where 'the H play' is previewing: 'You have to keep asking yourself, "Why do I want to do it?", though you know that at least part of the reason is that you want to join the club...'

Even the current production has had its share of procrastination. It was originally to be directed for the National by Sam Mendes last year: 'Sam had said to me, kindly , after I'd done Iago with him in 1998, "Christ you're not getting any younger, let's do it now".' But then American Beauty was released and Mendes found himself jigging, ambling and lisping in Los Angeles. John Caird eventually offered to direct and Beale, at 39, will finally step out at the Lyttleton in his inky cloak at the beginning of next month.

Surrounded now by Malvern's morning marketgoers, several of whom enthusiastically interrupt us to congratulate the actor on the previous night's performance (one formidable townswoman places Beale resolutely in her 'top three', as if he were vying for a place in the Champions League), he wears a look of relaxed relief that it's all finally happening.

None the less, the first night in London will have an extra poignancy for him. He talks of the play as being 'a very accurate charting of grief' and that emotion has not been hard for him to summon in recent months. Immediately before he went into rehearsal, Russell Beale lost his mother, after a six-month battle with cancer. He comes from a close military family - his father was surgeon-general, in charge of medical matters for the armed forces - and it was his mother who primarily encouraged his acting. His own sense of loss being so raw has, he suggests, helped to resolve for him the question of Hamlet's 'madness'.

'Grief is like being mugged,' he says. 'Things are going along fine and then suddenly it hits you. So you can have a period where you are genuinely pleased to see your old friends, or enjoy fooling about or whatever, and that can exist alongside genuine despair. In that sense, the soliloquies are the moments when he is mugged. I know very clearly now how grief is unpredictable, how you don't know how you are going to feel one minute to the next, and that is Hamlet's madness exactly.'

He says that in preview he has found himself thinking of his mother a lot while on stage - 'you can't avoid mothers in this part anyway' - and especially, poignantly, how 'the reason that she was able to resist the illness for as long as she did was her desire to see me do this play'. In some ways, he says, it's his tribute to her and, certainly, he explains, when he kneels down at the beginning of the play or when he describes 'that undiscover'd country from whose bourn no traveller returns', she is always there in his mind.

I wonder if the role has helped him to work through his grief but he says it is too early to tell. 'I went straight into it after she died, so I've had no option in a way. What I'm not looking forward to is the bit after the press night in that sense. I always feel a bit postnatal anyway after the opening and I suspect I will be very aware that she should have been here to see it.'

He suggests that in the past he has scoffed at fellow actors - Ralph Fiennes, Alex Jennings - telling him that playing Hamlet would change his life; now he's not so sure. What he has found in himself for the role, he says, is a 'much gentler, more autumnal Hamlet than I would have imagined myself doing; I suppose because I'd just done Iago and Richard III they are quite high definition. Hamlet is less definable; you just let it flow really.'

Certainly, anyone who saw Russell Beale's scabrous Thersites (a part for which he rubbed tomatoes into his face every night so his skin stung and stank) will find his Hamlet surprisingly generous. The previous night, even on the cramped nutshell of the Malvern's stage, about half the size of that at the Lyttleton, he had managed to make his performance redolent of infinite space.

His great facility has always been to interrogate every syllable in the text and to invest exuberant life in the most abstract of lines. As Hamlet, he continually finds humour and delight where many have been content to portray a more soupy melancholy.

Though this ability to extract new nuances from the language has never been doubted - Russell Beale, who took a first in English at Cambridge, approaches his parts, as he says, as a visceral kind of 'three-dimensional lit crit' - there have been some critics over the years who have suggested that he would not make a great, top three Hamlet because he does not look the part.

As he is the first to admit, his short, stocky frame and 'ordinary' face preclude the possibility of a Ralph Fiennes pretty-boy-lost interpretation. And though he thinks it's nonsense, really, the sense of his 'too-too solid flesh' remains at the back of his mind. 'You can't ignore it, I'm afraid,' he says, smiling a little wearily. 'The local paper here carried the inevitable "Tubby or not tubby, fat is the question" headline, so you can't help but be a little bit aware of it. But, in fact, it is totally ludicrous, even for someone as famously self-loathing as me, which I hasten to add I no longer am.'

He points out that there are only two references to Hamlet's appearance in the play and both are 'extremely ambiguous'. First, there is Ophelia's description of the prince as a 'glass of fashion, mould of form', ('and there's no reason,' Russell Beale says, patting his belly, 'that I couldn't be the mould of form to someone who loves me'); while the later observation during the fencing match that he is 'he's fat and scant of breath' suits his purposes perfectly. 'I've been wondering why that was written,' he says. 'Maybe Richard Burbage was playing it till he was a middle-aged man.'

Ever since he admitted in an early interview that 'I hate my body. I hate my looks. I hate my voice', questions of Russell Beale's appearance have rather dogged his career. He laughs them off now ('I rather like it when they call me "potato face"'), but when we talk about what he will do after Hamlet , when he's turned 40, I wonder if he's not a little envious of more glamorous contemporaries - Fiennes, Branagh - who have made the transition to film.

'It'll be odd' he says, of next year. 'I'll have done all the whoppers in terms of Shakespeare. I wonder if I'll go off in a different direction, I don't know, something off the stage, something more academic.' Over the years, he has often wondered this, talked about teaching, described himself as a frustrated historian, a subject he dropped in order originally to follow in the family footsteps and become a doctor.

Still, talking to him, you get the sense that what he would really like to do is to give film acting a proper try. He laughs when I suggest to him that his career has been a serious and classical progression, as if that was never really what he had in mind.

'People always wonder why I've never done film as if there were these scripts piling in at all times. I can assure you that there aren't. I've sometimes said I'd probably be better on stage than on film, but I don't even know that really. I imagine I was covering my back a little.'

He says that he has been half-hoping that his old friend Sam Mendes will offer him a screen role: 'I actually read an article yesterday about Sam doing this film with Tom Hanks and I did look down to see what the subject matter was in case I could phone him up. But it's gangsters in Thirties Chicago.' He rolls his eyes and adopts an even camper version of his voice: 'So maybe there are a few more suitable people around than me. It would take me years to adopt a Chicago accent.'

Certainly an injection of film money would not be unwelcome. He bought his flat in Pimlico, where he lives alone ('I've not given up hope') with the proceeds of his show-stealing portrayal of Widmerpool in the televised adaptation of Anthony Powell's A Dance to the Music of Time , but other than that, and though he's not complaining, he lives on the £600-a-week regulation performance fee he gets from the National. 'It's funny,' he says. 'People always assume you earn hundreds of thousands of pounds for doing this, but that's not really the case at all.'

Still, the wonderful thing about Russell Beale is that, for the next few months at least, you know he will not be worrying too much about his bank balance or what his Hollywood agent is up to ('I only saw him once and I've never heard from him since'). Instead, he'll be fretting about quite what he should be doing while the play within a play is in progress or the exact nature of his relationship with Ophelia.

'The great thing about this part is that you think you have it all tied down and then suddenly you find yourself wondering if you really know what "calumny" means or you think, "Shit, am I sure what a bodkin is?"' These are the big questions; smaller ones can look after themselves.
