webTitle: Is that room service? Where am I?

fields.headline: Is that room service? Where am I?
fields.standfirst: You could be in Birmingham, you could be in Bali, thanks to the bland conformity of hotel architecture. But a new breed of architect is putting individuality back into hotel design
fields.trailText: You could be in Birmingham, you could be in Bali, thanks to the bland conformity of hotel architecture. But a new breed of architect is putting individuality back into hotel design
fields.body:
The entrance pavilion of the Prince Maurice hotel sits in the middle of a small, artificial lake. Its thatched roof is supported on a skimpily elegant structure of teak logs, deftly lashed together and carefully lit at night to give the internal face of the thatch the delicate texture of a piece of fine, tobacco- coloured silk.

There are no walls; a light soaking of tropical rain can be just as enjoyable an experience as a warm breeze. You can sit in a teak chair watching the sky reflected in the tiered infinity pool that merges imperceptibly into the sea. The rest of the hotel, an intricate assembly of moated pavilions on stilts, none of them more than two storeys high, divided by pools and courtyards, is all but invisible in the palms.

To all intents, it's a Balinese village, just the kind of sensitive piece of hotel architecture built with a respect for local traditions that should give a certain kind of well-heeled tourism a good name. Or, at least, it would be a piece of respectful and sensitive architecture if this particular hotel actually were in south-east Asia.

But it isn't. This is Mauritius, 5,000 miles away, off the east coast of Africa. And the Prince Maurice is a brand-new hotel whose non-specific Asian style has suddenly become as ubiquitous as the modified Bauhaus glass slab used to be. It looks as if it embraces the climate, but it's air-conditioned. It looks green, but it is just as demanding on water and sewage systems as any other kind of hotel.

The language of hotel design has a significance way beyond the daily preoccupations of the tourist industry. In the 1960s, the hotel became a kind of national calling card, allowing a country to demonstrate to a captive audience how up to date it was. A glass-slab hotel, like the SAS Palace designed by Arne Jacobsen in 1960, or the vast hotels of Moscow of the same period, were once regarded as being as essential to the apparatus of an ambitious state as a nuclear power station or a steel works. And they managed to look much the same.

Now a city state like Dubai feels it has to find ways of suggesting its deep cultural roots architecturally when it builds a high-rise hotel, even when the real point is to demonstrate how sophisticated and modern it is. That schizophrenia is clearly apparent in the architecture of the Burj Al Arab, which tries to have it both ways. It's a skyscraper built on an artificial island linked to the mainland by a causeway that is meant to convince us that Dubai has more to offer than sand and a distant view of oilfields.

The architects, WS Atkins, came up with a queasy mixture of a Star Trek baroque structure and a translucent, plastic façade to provide the local colour. Allegedly, it looks like the sail of a dhow, inflated to a gargantuan 35 storeys.

There was a time when hotels did all they could to persuade us we hadn't left home. Now they do all they can to show us how different they are from home and, paradoxically, the effect is to go on making everywhere look the same. Partly, it was because the international style seemed self-evidently right for hotel architecture. Travel was a reflection of the same kind of rootlessness as the international style, an architecture ostensibly without national inflections.

But there was also something reassuring about the fact that an international hotel didn't quite belong to its context. Apart from hard-core minimalists, most of us would rather not have to deal with the very particular bathing arrangements of a traditional Japanese ryokan at the end of a long day fighting off jet lag. You know where you are with a Holiday Inn. You can be sure you will find the light switch in the same place on the same wall from Mexico to Belgium, and you can be pretty confident that the lavatory is not going to present too many challenges either.

There is a price to pay for reassurance. The Costa del Sol and the Turkish Riviera finished up lined end to end with what looked very much like the council flats and office blocks that their package-holiday occupants had left behind at home in search of a change of scene.

Magaluf started to look very much like Mile End, while the Hilton in downtown Istanbul felt much the same as the Hilton at Heathrow or the Hilton in Shinjuku, except for the customised cocktail of the day and the usually sanitised names on the brass tags pinned to the waistcoat lapels of the lobby staff.

It was a certain level of guilt about the consequences of all this, together with shrewd commercial calculation about increasingly sophisticated tourists, that triggered the process that eventually led to the arrival of Asia in Africa.

Architecture was used to make politically correct hotels that wanted to stop looking like ugly Americans, and tried to become part of the landscape instead. Rather than transplant Western models to the tropics, Adrian Zecha, founder of the Aman hotels group, tried to use authentic indigenous architecture to build hotels that looked as if they belonged. Amanpuri was the first, opened in 1988 in Phuket, and was instantly successful. Zecha's architect, Ed Tuttle, developed a style that quickly spread from Thailand to Bali, Java, the Philippines and eventually reaching not just Mauritius but even the outskirts of Marrakesh, the Arizona desert and Australia. Tuttle based his hotel designs on the work of the great Sri Lankan architect Geoffrey Bawa, who tried to mix indigenous traditions with a vision of modernity. Bawa built a new parliament for Sri Lanka that looks like a monumental version of an Aman resort, or the Prince Maurice for that matter. It was meant to express a sense of national identity, a blend of tradition with modernity. But the style has been hi- jacked, to become the acceptable face of contemporary luxury, a place for latterday Marie Antoinettes to play at being castaways.

webTitle: 'It was the world premiere... to two people'

fields.headline: 'It was the world premiere... to two people'
fields.trailText: World Premiere.  Sounds impressive doesn't it? And when you tell people that a play you have written is having its world premiere at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival, it sounds more impressive still. Which is probably why I tend to gloss over the fact that only two people turned up to the world premiere of  Whacked! and that only one   of them was a paying customer.
fields.body:
World Premiere. Sounds impressive doesn't it? And when you tell people that a play you have written is having its world premiere at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival, it sounds more impressive still. Which is probably why I tend to gloss over the fact that only two people turned up to the world premiere of Whacked! and that only one of them was a paying customer.

Actually it wasn't the disaster it might appear to be. The premiere was on 4 August and the festival didn't officially begin until 6 August so we weren't really expecting anyone to turn up at all. Many other shows running on the same day were completely empty.

Of our two punters, one was a young, local journalist and the other a swarthy late-middle-aged man, somewhat askew of the target audience, who I couldn't help thinking had only come along to have a closer look at the cleavage of the leading lady, Sarah McGuinness, which is something of a feature of the leaflet and poster campaign.

Then the lights dimmed, the music started and my gangster's moll monologue came to life before my eyes.

I'd seen dozens of rehearsals but this time round it felt completely different. I spent the whole time glancing at the two members of the audience, trying to gauge their reaction to each and every line, willing them to laugh at the allegedly funny bits. Forty-five tense minutes later, I made the mistake of asking Mr Sleazy what he thought of the show.

'Well, I thought she was very good,' he began. 'Marvellous. Fantastic in fact.' Beads of sweat were starting to form on his brow, his veins were throbbing. 'Amazing woman, very good at what she does. Stunning,' he continued. 'Didn't think much of the content, mind, didn't care for the play at all, but she was good, really good. I'd like to see more of her, much more...'

Later that first week the journalist who attended the premiere awarded Whacked! eight out of 10, called it 'seductive', described Sarah's performance as 'hypnotic' and the script as 'taut and evocative' with a twist that came 'like a knife in the ribs'.

Within a couple of days, our performances were one third full. So far so good. Then, at the end of our first week, came a review in The Stage which described the show as 'a sensational story...enchanting... a revealing production'.

Well, that's not quite true. All those words appear in the review in that order but they are intermingled with others which make it clear that the writer thought Whacked! was a pile of wank. Not all of Whacked! mind you; the set, the design, the music and the acting are all praised, but the script is criticised in every single line. Talk about a knife in the ribs.

It's fascinating the effect a bad review has on you and those around you. Friends and family tend to flap around saying: 'It's only one person's opinion, what does it matter?' But that's rubbish. If you get a really good review somewhere, people don't say: 'Hey, don't bother getting excited, that's only one person's opinion.' People tell you to be thick-skinned, to rise above it, but I don't think you can. Bad reviews hurt like hell and that's all there is to it. Now I know why so many actors say they never read them at all.

Bad reviews also make you question yourself and your abilities. You wonder if you're the emperor in his new suit and that the people around you are just too polite to tell you what they really think.

The review cast a grey cloud over the whole production team which lasted until the following day when, for no particular reason, we had our biggest audience to date and the show went down a storm. Since then, we have played to bigger and bigger crowds. We've actually sold out on a couple of occasions and the reaction from the audiences couldn't be better.

At the end of the day, what matters is that the people who see the show like it. Oh, and if those people just happen to be theatre critics, then that would be even better.

Whacked! is at the Gilded Balloon 2 at 2.30pm until 28 August
fields.bodyText: World Premiere. Sounds impressive doesn't it? And when you tell people that a play you have written is having its world premiere at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival, it sounds more impressive still. Which is probably why I tend to gloss over the fact that only two people turned up to the world premiere of Whacked! and that only one of them was a paying customer. Actually it wasn't the disaster it might appear to be. The premiere was on 4 August and the festival didn't officially begin until 6 August so we weren't really expecting anyone to turn up at all. Many other shows running on the same day were completely empty. Of our two punters, one was a young, local journalist and the other a swarthy late-middle-aged man, somewhat askew of the target audience, who I couldn't help thinking had only come along to have a closer look at the cleavage of the leading lady, Sarah McGuinness, which is something of a feature of the leaflet and poster campaign. Then the lights dimmed, the music started and my gangster's moll monologue came to life before my eyes. I'd seen dozens of rehearsals but this time round it felt completely different. I spent the whole time glancing at the two members of the audience, trying to gauge their reaction to each and every line, willing them to laugh at the allegedly funny bits. Forty-five tense minutes later, I made the mistake of asking Mr Sleazy what he thought of the show. 'Well, I thought she was very good,' he began. 'Marvellous. Fantastic in fact.' Beads of sweat were starting to form on his brow, his veins were throbbing. 'Amazing woman, very good at what she does. Stunning,' he continued. 'Didn't think much of the content, mind, didn't care for the play at all, but she was good, really good. I'd like to see more of her, much more...' Later that first week the journalist who attended the premiere awarded Whacked! eight out of 10, called it 'seductive', described Sarah's performance as 'hypnotic' and the script as 'taut and evocative' with a twist that came 'like a knife in the ribs'. Within a couple of days, our performances were one third full. So far so good. Then, at the end of our first week, came a review in The Stage which described the show as 'a sensational story...enchanting... a revealing production'. Well, that's not quite true. All those words appear in the review in that order but they are intermingled with others which make it clear that the writer thought Whacked! was a pile of wank. Not all of Whacked! mind you; the set, the design, the music and the acting are all praised, but the script is criticised in every single line. Talk about a knife in the ribs. It's fascinating the effect a bad review has on you and those around you. Friends and family tend to flap around saying: 'It's only one person's opinion, what does it matter?' But that's rubbish. If you get a really good review somewhere, people don't say: 'Hey, don't bother getting excited, that's only one person's opinion.' People tell you to be thick-skinned, to rise above it, but I don't think you can. Bad reviews hurt like hell and that's all there is to it. Now I know why so many actors say they never read them at all. Bad reviews also make you question yourself and your abilities. You wonder if you're the emperor in his new suit and that the people around you are just too polite to tell you what they really think. The review cast a grey cloud over the whole production team which lasted until the following day when, for no particular reason, we had our biggest audience to date and the show went down a storm. Since then, we have played to bigger and bigger crowds. We've actually sold out on a couple of occasions and the reaction from the audiences couldn't be better. fields.headline: Have a nice year...
fields.standfirst: Kibbutzes are old hat. Gap year students these days go to Goa to get wasted. It may no longer be worthy, but it's still worthwhile
fields.trailText: Kibbutzes are old hat. Gap year students these days go to Goa to get wasted. It may no longer be worthy, but it's still worthwhile
fields.body:
Picture this: a reception in Fresher's Week and a cluster of tanned first-year students are hovering in an oak-panelled room, clutching warm sherry and eyeing each other self-consciously. 'I just got back from Australia two days ago,' says one. 'I'm like totally jet-lagged, we were just drinking twenty-four seven.' 'Oh God, yah, I was just in Goa,' says another, anxious to compete, 'and we were just like off our faces the whole time.' 'When I was in Koh Pan Yang,' says a blond boy with public school vowels, 'mushrooms were so cheap, I don't think I was straight for like six months.' 'I was the same in Bolivia,' says another, nodding sagely. 'I think it's like a really valuable experience to go to the East - it's so important to get away from western consumerism,' says a girl festooned in designer labels. 'What about you?'

'Oh, I spent the year teaching illiterate Gypsy children in the south of Spain,' I say, aiming for studied nonchalance. A puzzled silence descends. The tanned faces buckle into expressions of incomprehension - ' Why? ' they are not quite saying. 'But I was like completely loaded the whole time,' I add quickly, in case they think I'm a Christian or a member of Amnesty International.

Voluntary work always used to be the justification for spending a year abroad before university - you could get sponsorship, you got all the benefits of travel and it allowed you to demonstrate to your prospective institution what a noble person you were. It was also useful for persuading a generation of middle-class parents doubtful as to the wisdom of a year off that you were doing something that could be quantified as 'worthwhile', so they'd let you out of their sight. But in recent years there seems to have been a subtle shift of emphasis. According to the latest report by the Gap Year Company, fewer than 5 per cent of students travelling abroad before university take part in voluntary work; travel has become a valid end in itself and universities and employers are no more likely to be impressed if you spent a year building a hospital in Angola than if you spent it face down in your own vomit in a Thai brothel.

Even Prince William - who will probably do neither of the above - is being encouraged to broaden his horizons by spending a year sampling another culture. The mere business of getting yourself to the other side of the world, not losing your passport or return ticket, avoiding rapists, pickpockets and murderers, and managing to get yourself home again without unwittingly packing 10 kilos of heroin is evidence of initiative, curiosity and a survival instinct that will prepare you well for adult life. At least, this is what the students tell their parents.

But even if all this unbridled hedonism has left the do-gooding teenager on the edge of extinction, I still firmly believe that a gap year should be compulsory for all right-thinking young people about to go off to university. There are pros and cons to every choice, of course, but the crucial advantage common to all gap year experiences is that it forces you to grow up. Some might argue that stumbling round the subcontinent in your underwear eating the local hallucinogens while trying to have sex with Australians is not necessarily proof of maturity, but at least it gives you the chance to live away from home for the first time and make all your mistakes before you get to college. A gap year is a chance to reinvent yourself. You're transient, as are the people you meet - they don't know your parents, they don't know whether you were a geek at school, they don't know that you used to do your hair like Robert Smith without irony. You can be an entirely different person, and since you'll never see any of these people again (even if you do, none of you will remember), you can practice inventing your new away-from-home personality so that you get it right before you make it to university and are stuck with it for the next three years.

It's also very hard not to become more interesting after a year of travel. During those first terrifying days at university, no matter how often people tell you their totally cool and totally identical stories about trekking through Nepal on acid, they're still more fun to talk to than those - how young they seem! - who are still having the conversation about what A levels they got. That was, like, years ago ! (Or - God forbid - the ones who spent their year off working for an engineering firm in Swindon and who turn up at college with smug sponsorship cheques in their student account and rollerball pens in their breast pockets. This is not a valid use of your year off.)

A gap year is for being bold, adventurous, wild - and, in some cases, altruistic. The great advantage of voluntary work, apart from the spiritual rewards and the warm glow inside that comes from helping others, is that people are more likely to give you money if they think you're teaching poor children how to read than if they think you're spending it on skunk and tequila. (Which is not to say that you can't do both.) It also gives you the chance to engage with the local people and become part of a community in a way that is impossible if you only pass through with a backpack. The key is to find an organisation that is not too rigid in its structures and rules, so that you can combine the hard work with the kind of self-exploration and experimentation that is the main point of a gap year.

Unless you're exceptionally lucky - or rich - you'll leave university with at least £5,000 of debt, get sucked into the relentless carousel of job interviews, acquire more debt, and carefree travelling will become an impossible luxury. My advice would be: go while you've got the chance - build schools, climb mountains, learn to dive, learn a language, smoke dope, drink too much and have a fantastic time. Find yourself. Just don't find yourself in an office...

Ten facts about gap years

150,000, or one in five, students take a gap year before entering university

2 35,000 are state school leavers and 15,000 are from independent schools. 30% are women travelling alone.

3 Only 10,000 of the 200,000 people aged 26 and under who take gap years embark on a structured placement.

4 More than half of all school leavers taking gap years remain in Europe; one in 10 visits Central or South America.

5 Australia is the most popular destination among older travellers, with one-fifth spending most of their time there.

6 The least popular destination is Africa.

7 Asia is popular among all age groups. On average, 14% of British travellers visit the Far East.

8 Of those returning from trips, 70% say they would go again. Two-thirds claim that their gap-year experience has changed them.

9 One-third of people taking a gap year travel alone, and nearly half set off with just one companion; 20% of backpackers do not return with the person they left with.

10 £2,000 is the average spent on a six-month trip. The biggest problem for those wishing to take a gap year is raising enough money; the second biggest problem is securing a visa.

Research by Ben Cooper

webTitle: 'It's more fun than a Travis concert'

fields.headline: 'It's more fun than a Travis concert'
fields.standfirst: Vomiting and simulated sex... it's all in a night's work for the Bloodhound Gang
fields.trailText:
Bloodhound Gang
London Astoria
fields.body:
Bloodhound Gang
London Astoria

At times it feels like you've wandered on to the set of a Farrelly brothers movie: two men are projectile-vomiting over each other's trousers; a fat boy is munching his way through a huge bag of doner kebabs; a girl is simulating fellatio with a musclebound man; another girl is pulling her hot pants up to reveal her buttocks; there are tasteless jokes about disabled people. Oh, and there are some songs as well.

The Bloodhound Gang are determinedly not 'all about the music'. Despite having four albums to their name - Dingleberry Haze , Use Your Fingers , One Fierce Beer Coaster and Hooray for Boobies - this American five-piece only really have one song. But what a song. 'The Bad Touch' is one of the biggest-selling singles of the year; you will probably know it by its fantastically catchy chorus - 'You and me baby, we ain't nothing but mammals/ So let's do it like they do on the Discovery Channel' - and the video in which the band dress as monkeys and beat a gay French couple with baguettes. 'It's not homophobic,' they claimed when an airplay ban was threatened, 'it's anti-French.'

As you may have gathered, the Bloodhound Gang are not exactly tortured souls. Of the current wave of US guitar bands beginning to break big over here - Limp Bizkit, Slipknot, Deftones, Korn - the Bloodhounds are the jokers in the pack; almost unknown in their homeland, but loved by Britain's obnoxious teen population due to their radio-friendly outrageousness and GSOH. As lead rapper Jimmy Pop says, just after he's initiated a bodysurfing 'swim race' between two audience members, 'It's a lot more fun than a Travis concert, isn't it?'

Part of the reason the Bloodhound Gang are big here and not in the States is that they are, at heart, anti-American anglophiles. Their favourite bands are Depeche Mode and The Smiths; the bass player wears Union Jack boxer shorts (as we discover when he wedges a pair of abandoned panties down them prior to a good sniff); they even crack jokes about Joey Deacon, for God's sake. And their frat-boy celebration of the grosser aspects of American culture is so over the top - they habitually offer a $100 bill to anyone who can consume vast quantities of soft drink or fast food, the intention being to make them vomit on stage - that it almost looks like satire.

Which is not why 3,000 people are crammed into the humid Astoria on Wednesday night. They're here because Bloodhound Gang, like the Beastie Boys and King Kurt before them, are enormous, delinquent fun. The music, though generally devoid of tunes, is rap-rock by numbers, perfect for a good shoutalong with your mates. They're a student party that's just spun out of control, a kids' breakfast TV programme with added pornography, a punk karaoke session, a puke-covered pantomime. Even the aftershow party, sponsored by Ann Summers and featuring cocktail waitresses in bondage gear, is a good laugh, which is definitely not normal.

And, in fact, they don't just have one song - because their new single, 'The Ballad of Chasey Lain', is pretty good too. It's not really a ballad, of course. That would be, like, sad. It's actually a love letter/chat-up line addressed to a famous porn actress: the first line of the chorus is 'You've had a lot of dick...' What a bunch of sweethearts they are.

webTitle: My boyfriend talks about his ex. Should I mind?

fields.headline: My boyfriend talks about his ex. Should I mind?
fields.trailText: I've been with my partner for several weeks, and since the beginning of the relationship, references to his ex-girlfriend have been slipping into our conversations on a daily basis. They take the form of reminiscences and anecdotes, but sometimes he'll mention her in circumstances where her presence is only incidental. Their break-up a few years ago was very painful for him, and she is evidently   still on his mind. He is open about still finding her attractive but believes this is irrelevant. We are happy together, but when he makes these references, I feel vaguely resentful and find myself wondering if he would like go back to her. Do you think it would be a good idea to discuss things with him or is my insecurity doing him a disservice?
fields.body:
I've been with my partner for several weeks, and since the beginning of the relationship, references to his ex-girlfriend have been slipping into our conversations on a daily basis. They take the form of reminiscences and anecdotes, but sometimes he'll mention her in circumstances where her presence is only incidental. Their break-up a few years ago was very painful for him, and she is evidently still on his mind. He is open about still finding her attractive but believes this is irrelevant. We are happy together, but when he makes these references, I feel vaguely resentful and find myself wondering if he would like go back to her. Do you think it would be a good idea to discuss things with him or is my insecurity doing him a disservice?

RC, Swansea

Your ultimate question is a good example of how women are prepared to accept the blame for a situation which is not of their making. It's part of our inherent baggage, which can defuse a short-term, difficult situation but can also perpetuate a long-term one. You should certainly tackle him on this.

Forget for the moment the amount of emotional investment which you may have placed in this man. Think in terms of what one human being owes to another in simple courtesy when they are in close proximity for an hour or two. Think of the rule that should guide this man if he were taking you out for the first time. Would he make an ex-girlfriend the main topic of his conversation? Most certainly not! However intimately two beings mingle, the principles of politeness should never be forgotten. Working partnerships depend on give-and-take - so obvious it's trite.

There are a number of possible explanations for his preoccupation. If his ex was indeed the love of his life, her defection may have severely traumatised him. As I recall myself, one way of coming to terms with the loss is to talk endlessly and perhaps tediously about it.

If, however, the break-up was a few years ago and he has been with you for several weeks, he really ought to be way beyond that now. Some men, while at ease and excellent communicators in an all-male or mixed company, have huge difficulty in talking one-to-one with their partners. They have to construct conversation and line up topics rather than let things flow. This state of affairs can extend to an inappropriate choice of subject.

Yet other men are manipulators, and try to engage affections by making women feel sorry for them. And some women are remarkably susceptible to this ploy.

Whichever of these is the reason, neither is insurmountable, though he does not seem a particularly intuitive man, or of a naturally considerate nature. Certainly discuss his lapse in gallantry. but be aware that this may demolish some of his self-confidence, creating awkward silences. And don't put a complete taboo on the subject, for if she was part of his life for a number of years she is bound to crop up in conversation occasionally.

A reader's reply

My partner and I never talk about previous relationships. If this man does not have the decency to consider your feelings, then it does not bode well for future communication on his part. Tell him how you feel. If he insists on still referring to his ex, I would dump him.

K.A. of Croydon

Next week's dilemma

My husband and I had a beautiful wedding four weeks ago. We received more than 100 gifts. However, there are about six close friends who apparently have not sent us presents. Obviously we are very hurt that they did not acknowledge our marriage with a gift and I would like to let them know how I feel. Not for reasons of acquisitiveness, but as a matter of principle: the wedding was an expensive affair, undertaken as much for our friends' enjoyment as our own. My husband thinks that I should keep quiet and not judge. Who is right?

J.K. of Luton

Write to Observer Review or email margaret.cook@observer.co.uk. Views on each week's problem to reach us by Wednesday. Margaret Cook writes for Woman's Journal

webTitle: Hope you die before you get old?

fields.headline: Hope you die before you get old?
fields.standfirst: None of us are getting any younger, but in the twenty-first century we are trying ever more desperately to cling on to youth. We need to see the ageing process as a life filling up, not a life running out
fields.trailText: None of us are getting any younger, but in the twenty-first century we are trying ever more desperately to cling on to youth. We need to see the ageing process as a life filling up, not a life running out
fields.body:
A few years ago, interviewing the actress Susan Sarandon, I asked her if she minded getting older. She turned her beautiful face, with its tiger eyes, towards me and answered rather scornfully. 'Tell me, what's the alternative to getting older? Death!'

Which is splendidly to the point, but misses the point as well. Because many, even most, of us - while not wanting to stay in the same place and not wanting to die - are yet fearful of getting older. We do try and prevent it. We dress young, speak in the language of youth, listen to the same music as our children, no longer move through life in the measured stages of previous generations, nor understand the concept of being 'grown up'. For tomorrow is for the young. On the front of magazines are young faces, glossy bodies, models who look like waifs and like children. Youth is seen as a valuable commodity, age as a time of diminishing returns. In our fast-moving, youth-obsessed, short-shelf-life culture, the old are often undervalued, neglected, almost invisible.

The process of moving from youth to old age can feel like a journey into invisibility. When you are old, you are expected by the cruel clichés of society to give things up: desire and desirability, ambition, eagerness, passion, anger, beauty, selfishness, hope. In return for this, the old are expected to attain a weary kind of wisdom and peace. 'When you are old and grey and full of sleep, and nodding by the fire...' No wonder we fear this journey, which seems to be all about loss.

I don't know when the fear begins, or why it kicks in. Is it when we approach a milestone year - 40, say, or when we realise that the pattern of our life is set, and we can see into the future as if we are looking along a Roman road, all the way to the horizon, or when we realise that possibilities are closing down? Is it when our parents die and we step into that front line? When our children no longer need us? Or is there simply a day when we have a spasm of knowledge felt in the bones that we are on a one-way journey? There's no way back. Sometimes I wake in the night with my heart racing. I lie there in the dark and wait for the terror to slow down. I used to think I was scared of death, but now I think it's more a fear of life bolting away from me like this, which isn't quite the same thing.

We spend our childhood waiting to become adults; can't wait to grow up. We spend much of our adulthood looking back with nostalgia at ourselves when we were young and time seemed infinite, and we had no sense that the runaway years would gallop past so quickly. There's a reason for this, of course: we measure our life against the life we have already had, the life that lies behind us. For a child, one year may be a quarter of their conscious existence; for an old person, it may be only one or two per cent, the tiniest shred of time.

For the past few years, since my mid-thirties perhaps, I have found getting older a confusing business. It's not that I dislike it, or deny it, or try to prevent it. In many ways, I rather love it - that sense of not caring so much about what people think, that freedom from embarrassment and insecurity and shame. I am happier than I was, more confident, I think I know myself better. But nevertheless, I look in the mirror and am taken aback by the woman I see - can this be me, this creased face, a furrow between my eyes, fillings in my teeth, a tired skin? And where did the person go that I was, careless of risk and waste?

I'm taken aback when young teenagers hide their cigarettes behind their backs. I find it hard to believe that those job ads for recent college graduates no longer apply to me. It is as if all the people that I was now exist only in photo albums, like exhibits in a gallery: the baby, the toddler, the child, the teenager, the young woman. They've all been eaten up by the person I have become.

As the Dutch biologist, Midas Dekkers, writes in his playfully disturbing book The Way of All Flesh: a Celebration of Decay , 'your body is your museum to yourself'. While the body is continually reconstructed - during a lifetime, every part is replaced by a replica of itself dozens and dozens of times over - the mind is like an 'attic full of dusty memories'. Memory is our only continuity.

A blink ago, my world was all possibility, doors that I might push open, whereas now it is equally about memory. All the things I've done that I will never do again: learn how to ride a bike, do cartwheels on the lawn, feel dizzy with excitement because it's my birthday, fall in love for the first time, leave home, wear a miniskirt, drink too much without getting a hangover, stay up all night without feeling ruined, give birth, hold my baby bunched up mewling under my chin.

I sometimes wake in the morning with a slight stiffness in my body, like a premonition. Children become alarming yardsticks of time passing. I look at my parents and realise all over again that they are getting old now, though I persist in thinking of them as my age, in thinking of myself as only just beyond childhood, with the world spread out before me. I look at my friends who are my age and realise that they are approaching middle age, or in it, and if they are, then... I look in the mirror, and I think: it's too soon. I am not ready for this. But are we ever ready for this?

From an alarmingly young age, we begin to decay. Dekkers charts in his book how we wear out ('the flowering of wrinkles. The withering of flowers...'). Bones creak and calcify, joints become less supple, vertebrae degenerate until we are like old cars headed for the scrapheap. Antibodies become less efficient. Skin becomes less pliant, until it gathers in bags and pouches on our face. Hair gets thinner, falls out. Lung capacity decreases (between the age of 20 to 80, by an average of 40 per cent). The heart beats less strongly.

Women begin their life with one million eggs in their ovaries, but by 20, they only have one quarter left; by 40, just a few tens of thousands, if we're lucky. Our teeth decay (I've always thought mortality begins in the mouth) and fall out. Hearing deteriorates. Eyesight. Taste.

Brain cells cascade away - 50,000 each day, so that by the end of an average life-span we will have lost an ounce of brain. We fight this decay with health foods, with exercise, with vitamins, with pills and potions, with diets, with drugs. Anything, really, that promises to stop time. But time won't stop. There's no way to cheat the clock. The only way is forward, towards age and death.

Above all, we wage a war upon our faces, where the process of ageing becomes visible, public. Actually, the skin we see is already dead. It flakes away, as if in life we are turning to dust. It does no good to rub rejuvenating cream into it (which I nevertheless do every evening). We may cover it with make-up, paint a face that we want on to the face that is starting to remind us where we are headed. But make-up can't hide the ravages of time. You have to do more than colour it in.

For a week, I went without any make-up. This is a trivial thing, of course, but I wanted to see how I'd feel without preparing my image to face the world. I don't put make-up on at home, anyway, but when I go to work or out to a party, it feels necessary to stand in front of a mirror and rub in foundation so my skin doesn't look blotchy, to apply eye-liner so my eyes look larger, to put on mascara, lipstick.

Without that ritual - a ritual I used to watch my mother going through; the way she would lean forward to stare into her own eyes, the way she'd press her lipsticked mouth against a tissue, leaving a red kiss on it - I feel a bit naked. I feel vulnerable in front of other people, not the woman I want to be, but the woman I am and don't feel entirely confident about.

Theoretically, I want to look my age. George Orwell famously said that at 50 you have the face you deserve - I'm not 50, but nevertheless I do want to earn my face. I want the life I have had to show in my lines and wrinkles; in my stretch marks from being four times pregnant; in my scars and blemishes. I want to own my imperfections, not hide them as if time hadn't marked me at all. Faces become more interesting as they get older - and more beautiful.

I firmly believe all that - yet I stand in front of the mirror, day after day, gazing at the soft skin under my eyes, the forlorn lines around my mouth. I want to hide.

Apparently, with cosmetic surgery you should really have it done before you need it. If you wait until there is crepey skin under the eyes, a mournful downward tug to the mouth when you are tired, tiny cross-stitching above your upper lip, the first traces of a double chin, then you have left it a bit late. And such is our terror of growing older, of looking the age that we are, such is our difficulty in finding beauty in experience, that it doesn't seem extraordinary to us that thousands of women go under the knife to be stitched into the semblance of youth.

Ribcages are reduced. Lips inflated. Thighs liposuctioned. Bits of the self are lopped off and chucked away. Women seem to panic. 'We must learn to love our bodies,' said Jane Fonda, shortly before having herself drastically remade by the cosmetic surgeon. Julie Christie succumbed to cosmetic surgery because she suddenly noticed that in Hollywood she was starting to look older than women who were older than her.

Midlife crises hit as we look ahead at life, as it stretches towards old age and death, and say: is this all there is? The menopause - all those hormones charging round the body - often makes women feel jittery, panicky, hot, weepy, dreary and scared. But it also makes us depressed because the change reminds us how we are crossing over a line - from fecundity to barrenness. No wonder so many women have late pregnancies: it's a way of holding back the stages of life, trying to stay put. For older women are no longer objects of desire. Germaine Greer wrote how this was a freedom for her, liberated at last from the ceaseless tyranny of men's lust and her own desire, but for many women it's a kind of terror. We are so used to being judged by how we look and so used to being noticed. Nowadays, when I walk down the road with my eldest daughter, who is nearly 12, it is her that young men are looking at, not me. I'm passing on the baton. This is how it should be and that's how I want it to be. So why do I feel so proud of her, but so peculiar about me?

There's another kind of change for men. Where women get depressed, and turn in on themselves, men often do the opposite, turn outwards and smash up their old life to create an entirely new one. They panic. They go jogging with their fear running after them, fall in love with a younger woman, leave the old and known for the youthful, the unfamiliar, the exciting. For a time they can feel that they have begun again. As Groucho Marx said: 'Men are as old as the women they feel.' But time won't let them get away with that for long - their new life becomes old too; their new wife ages as well. They need another one. Another. The clock still ticks.

Are we more scared of getting older than we used to be? I think so. Maybe this is partly - and paradoxically - because we now expect to get older, whereas in the past we couldn't take it for granted at all. It used to be unusual to go grey, to retire, to become senile. There was a sense of the precariousness of life, which could end at any time - and often did end very young. There was a sense of the extraordinariness of old age.

In nineteenth-century Ireland, for example, parents used to give each of their sons their father's name, to make it more likely that at least one child would carry it on. Death was expected all the time, and so you were alive right to the edge of the grave. Now, we place dying in what we think of as a logical position - at the close of a long life, unless we are unlucky.

At the same time as we are living longer and longer, there has never been a time, in the Western world, when we have denied age and death as we do today. We want to live longer still, a thousand years, forever. The meaning of life is radically wrenched by this great denial. Once we valued age and wisdom; now we value youth, newness, and we dread old age, the lines on the face, life marking us, experience burdening us: not just closer to death, but further away from what we think of as life.

Instead of thinking of the elderly as full of years, it is as if the more years we have, the emptier of life we become - we are using it up, running out of life and of time. But actually, by trying to stay young we don't prolong youth at all, we do the opposite. We deny ourselves the pleasure of all the selves we may become, stage by stage, all the experience we gather. 'The older you get,' says Dekkers, 'the more you come to resemble yourself.' In his view, we are always moving and changing towards the person that we really are: the self at the end of the line.

Yet still I think: how quickly it's gone, the first half of my life. One minute I was lying under the copper beech in my parents' garden, watching the way the light fell through the leaves, dreaming of what I would be, one day an unbearably long way off, when I would be grown up.

Now here I am, a grey hair in my eyebrow. Where did time go? Is it really true it isn't coming back?

Sylvia Ratcliffe, 62 I feel there's not a lot of time left. I do calculations about when my grandchildren are a certain age, and I'll be gone. I feel energetic and enthusiastic to learn, and I feel the same inside despite the creeping years. One of my biggest fears, though, is memory loss.

Caroline Rogers, 36 I definitely feel like I'm going through the ageing process. I'm much more willing to spend money on my appearance to maintain the looks that I previously took for granted. I recently caught sight of myself in a mirror smiling and was shocked by the crows' feet round my eyes. When people guess my age as being less than it is, I feel like a cat that has just been stroked, which is ridiculous.

Robert Hokum, 49 In the workplace a man in his forties must be in a respected position or he is seen as a sad old duffer.

Older women can still be very sexy, for them style and allure is more important than youth. I think you know you're getting old when you start to think June Whitfield is attractive. But if you plan your life right, you see a level of economic freedom which has previously been unknown in your life.

Gordon Agar, 38 When I was a teen I didn't think I would live to be old, but then I thought 30 was old. As a gay man, I might clock a guy and turn round to have another look. When I was younger more often than not the other person would turn round and have a look as well. Now it doesn't happen so much. But I'm more concerned with my image than about getting old. There's no excuse for not looking good.

Katrina Heart, 26 I'm terrified of getting old because men are attracted to younger women, not fortysomething women. When I hit 26, I thought that's it, I'm only ever going to look worse from now on. Also you can't get away from the fact that this society values youth and youthful good looks. If I wrote my first novel at 35, nobody would be really interested. But if I wrote it at 25, it would be different. Wisdom is a nice consolation of age, but if I could make a pact like Dorian Gray and stay 22 forever, I would happily miss out on the advantages of later life.

William Johnson, 29 I turn 30 next week and I am starting to get a stiff back and my body doesn't recover from a hangover so quickly, but people still think I look like a teenager anyway. I like the idea of getting old. You get wiser as you get older and I feel more secure and happy than I did at 21. I'm looking forward to being a grouchy old man.
Interviews by Kim Bunce

fields.trailText: Kate Kellaway had a lot to learn when she took charge of two little girls
fields.body:
Delphine looked like a doll. She had a bob of black hair, shining eyes and a rosebud mouth that seemed painted onto her face. Her clothes were perfection. I remember the smocked dress she wore when I first saw her: cherries against a white background. When I first came to be Delphine's au pair, I had never been in charge of a child before but had a broad experience of looking after dolls. I thought this exquisite five-year-old Parisienne would be as charming as she looked - she would be a kind of doll.

Her younger sister, Audrey, was a shambolic, demonstrative, vulnerable creature with blurry features. She retained a recently born look through her first two years of life and was still in nappies. I liked everything about her, although I was a little nervous about the technical challenge the nappies might present, having never changed one in my life.

The sisters lived in a third-floor flat in the sixteenth arrondissement of Paris. It was my job to scrub floors, Hoover, iron, cook and look after them. Mme de Saintville was awesomely elegant. It was a look that, at 18, I admired despairingly. She made me feel doomed: lumpenly, irredeemably English. But, I was soon to discover, there was nothing about her mothering that I would ever wish to emulate.

I was not aware that I had any ideas about children until I became an au pair. The first thing I learnt is that children change your life forever. Children take away your freedom. You can't even leave the house when you want to, you can't think your own thoughts. I was in genteel slavery. Delphine was in turmoil beneath her pretty frocks. She was a spoilt, neglected child - a torturer (and victim). But there was a nice child in there somewhere too.

I felt sorry for Delphine, she had had a string of au pairs - and I only planned to stay for three months. I realised how cavalier and selfish this was. But shouldn't the parents have hired someone who could stay longer? Why weren't they worried about the string of broken attachments?

Delphine was jealous of Audrey. She used to bite her in the bath. Her parents described her as spiteful. Sibling jealousy? They either had not heard of it or were not interested. And when they left me in charge of the children for a long weekend and came back to find that Audrey was more clingy to me than usual and had a stomach upset, they blamed everything on her illness, unable to see that it was their absence that had rocked her little boat.

Mme de Saintville lived according to two laws: one for adults, one for children (and au pairs). Every night, the children had to eat macaroni without sauce. They didn't like it - and I didn't blame them. I regularly used to bury it in the bin. Sometimes I would glimpse Mme gliding out to one of her bridge parties carrying one of her heavenly strawberry tarts to offer her friends.

I was learning what a difficult thing it is to look after children, especially when they are not your own; to have responsibility without authority. I was learning too that children feel with a passion that is total: they swerve between love and hate in a way that is exhausting for slower, more emotionally desiccated adults.

I decided not to have any children of my own - or at least not for a very, very long time. And when I got back England, the first thing I did was to send my favourite dolls to Delphine and Audrey.

fields.headline: Fergie: Cole to replace Shearer
fields.trailText: Alex Ferguson believes Alan Shearer's retirement from international football spells good news for Andy Cole and England.
fields.body:
Alex Ferguson believes Alan Shearer's retirement from international football spells good news for Andy Cole and England.

Cole has recovered from a toe injury and is fit to start against his former club at Old Trafford this afternoon.

With an England squad to be announced this week for next month's friendly with France, a head-to-head confrontation with Shearer is the perfect opportunity for Cole to finally win over Kevin Keegan.

Ferguson said: 'I think this is a better opportunity for England if Andy Cole is there. Now Alan Shearer has retired, they can look at a different way of playing.

'Players like Cole and Fowler, if he is fit, and young Owen is developing. It is a great opportunity for Andy Cole.

'He always felt he should have been playing anyway, I don't think there is anything wrong with that and I don't think Kevin would be disappointed in hearing that. You want players to be thinking they should be playing.

'The difficulty is that Alan Shearer has become the image of England and that image was very hard for managers to change. But now he has retired, it is opening up for someone else, a different way of playing.'

Ferguson has still to decide whether Cole starts this afternoon, and he admitted that his problem of choosing two starting strikers from Cole, Yorke, Sheringham and Solskjaer has not eased.

He said: 'It's been like this the last three years, nothing changes. I know I'm going to disappoint two of my players but I look at the Newcastle game in a different way to the Ipswich game on Tuesday.'

United scored a record 97 goals in the Premiership last season, many of them coming from midfield, but Ferguson clearly believes there is room for improvement and has singled out David Beckham as a player who could do better.

He said: 'If you go back three or four years he was scoring 15 two seasons in a row. He's gone down a bit the last couple of years, but he is capable of scoring inside or outside the box and is a good header of the ball.

'David should be getting 16 goals a season. I think he is maybe concentrating too much on playing wide all the time, providing for others. He had a little run late last season and ended up with nine goals but he is capable of more than that. He is an excellent finisher in training.'

fields.headline: Blackburn mourn Jack
fields.trailText: Fooball Review
fields.body:
After just two matches, the only First Division teams with 100 per cent records are Fulham, Preston and Watford.

That Watford are members of this select club is due to their young Irish striker Dominic Foley. He came on as a substitute against Barnsley seven minutes from the end, in place of the injured Michael Ngonge, and scored the only goal with a left-foot shot from outside the box in stoppage time.

Of the teams who might have been expected also to be in this 100 per cent bracket, it was perhaps inevitable that Blackburn should falter - through a goalless draw at Crewe - in view of the cloud that has descended upon the club following the death of Jack Walker.

Blackburn's manager, Graeme Souness, said: 'The players did their best in the circumstances, but I thought their minds weren't entirely on the game. Maybe some of them didn't know Jack that well but the aura of the man was huge and his memory will always be around the club and the training ground.

'They were quiet at training yesterday and at the hotel last night. Today, they did not really get going until after half-time, and then they could easily have won it. They were disappointed because they wanted to win it for him and the fans.'

While Watford were inspiring early confidence in their chances of bouncing straight back to the Premiership, their relegation partners, Sheffield Wednesday and Wimbledon, were given a sharp reminder of how difficult it will be for them in their new environment, with defeats at the hands of Huddersfield and Burnley respectively.

fields.headline: A whole new ball game
fields.standfirst: Warren Barton on the shift from Crazy Gang to football madness
fields.trailText: When Newcastle United visit Manchester United this afternoon, the attendance of up to 67,000 is certain to be a new Premiership record. The ever expanding Old Trafford set the existing record of 61,629 at the end of last season, and at this rate will soon overhaul its own record of 76,936, which is quite a feat considering the latter has stood for more than 60 years since the pre-Premiership, pre-seating, pre-war days of early 1939.
fields.body:
When Newcastle United visit Manchester United this afternoon, the attendance of up to 67,000 is certain to be a new Premiership record. The ever expanding Old Trafford set the existing record of 61,629 at the end of last season, and at this rate will soon overhaul its own record of 76,936, which is quite a feat considering the latter has stood for more than 60 years since the pre-Premiership, pre-seating, pre-war days of early 1939.

In the circumstances, 3,000 seats for visiting supporters, as stipulated in the new charter, still seems something of a token gesture, but Sir Alex Ferguson insists home supporters must be looked after first. 'We accommodate more away fans than most grounds, but we still can't get enough of our own supporters in,' he said. 'When I came here we used to take 15,000 to Sheffield Wednesday, but when capacities started to be reduced for safety reasons away fans had to be limited. There's no perfect solution, but you have to draw the line somewhere. We don't complain about only getting 1,200 tickets for Southampton.'

Something similar is happening on Tyneside, where, on Wednesday, the newly-enlarged St James' Park will admit 52,000 paying customers for the game against Derby County. The fact that the visitors are relatively low-key opponents matters not a jot - both Uniteds are in the position of turning away supporters for every home game and Newcastle are confidently predicting a sell-out. The Magpies cannot physically make their present home much bigger; awkward considerations such as a Metro station at one end and listed buildings at the other rule out further construction for the foreseeable future, but if it were merely a matter of satisfying demand Newcastle would also be approaching a crowd record of 68,386.

This sort of ever-upward progress is barely considered remarkable in the ninth season of the Premier League, except by supporters struggling to keep up with the cost of it all and players lucky enough to have had their financial horizons expanded beyond all expectation in the past eight, dizzying years. Players like Warren Barton, of Newcastle, who went from the crazy, but cash-strapped, Wimbledon gang to discover real football madness in the North-East.

Barton's former clubmate Carl Cort has just made the same journey, but the difference is that in his first-team career, the younger player has only known Premiership standards. And as Barton says, by the time Wimbledon were relegated they had actually stopped being the Premiership's ugly ducklings and turned into quite a respectable, well-supported club with gates averaging about 20,000.

It wasn't quite like that in Barton's time with the Dons, and not just his pre-Premiership time either. It is an obvious truism that the advent of the Premier League has transformed what went before, but what is less commonly realised is how different the Premiership is now to what it was seven or eight years ago. 'What everyone said at the time was that nothing had really changed,' Barton explained. 'It's funny, but you don't hear anyone saying that any more.'

Though practically ever-present for Wimbledon in the first Premier League season, Barton managed to miss the home game against Oldham Athletic on 12 December 1992. He was not the only one. The 'crowd' of 3,386 still stands as the Premiership's lowest, a record which current trends suggest will stand for some time. It is not just that crowds are up, it is that clubs like Wimbledon and Oldham are undeniably down. Barton naturally feels Wimbledon will be back in the big time before long, but not even the most bonkers of Boundary Park die-hards thinks that about Oldham. Even Wimbledon, for all their fighting qualities, may discover that getting back into the Premiership is nothing like as easy as cracking the old First Division.

It was not immediately apparent in 1992, but within the last eight years most of the predictions have come true. The Premiership has become predominantly a place for big clubs, with big grounds, in big cities. There are exceptions to the rule, notably Everton and Tottenham, but the rich have got richer, to such an extent that the Manchester United manager last week said he would be 'shocked' if anyone from outside the perceived top five managed to win the league. Perhaps that was always the case, but clubs the size of Aston Villa or Newcastle ought to be able to at least dream of the title. The perception of a league within a league is now stronger than ever, though it is not all the Premiership's fault. Uefa's Champions League deserves at least half the blame.

Barton has played in the Champions League, battled relegation, worked under four different managers in five seasons and lost two successive FA Cup finals, but says he has never regretted leaving London for the North. 'I wouldn't change a minute, I can't complain about a single thing,' he said.

'I would never have imagined I would be spending so much of my career so far from home, or that I would have enjoyed it so much, but I've told Carl [Cort] that this could be the best move he's made.

'Getting out of London helped me concentrate on my football. You come up to a place like this and you don't know anybody, people are a bit suspicious of you in fact, and you have to prove yourself.

'All you can do is work hard and focus on your football, and of course that's what you should be doing. Carl will be fine. He's an honest player and the fans will love him because he'll never put his head down. He's played in front of big crowds before, of course, just like I had. But it's a bit different when they are all for rather than against you. Nice, but different. It takes a bit of getting used to. So do crowds of two or three thousand at training sessions, something else that never used to happen at Wimbledon.'

According to Barton, the Premiership has not only become much faster, it has become much more intense and the stakes are high. Fortunately, so are the wages. You do not need to tell Barton how lucky he is, he will be too busy anyway, investing his small fortune in a myriad of new business plans for the future.

'The rewards are like never before, but that's what you work for,' he said. 'It's not easy holding down a place at a top Premiership club, especially if they keep changing the manager. I've had my ups and downs, but I think I give good value and I'm proud I've never been discarded. Kevin Keegan originally made me an offer I couldn't refuse. Not with money, he just said, "Come on the journey," and made it sound like the most exciting thing in the world. He wasn't far wrong either.'

fields.headline: Holiday rules for part-time workers
fields.standfirst: I am a part-time worker, working mornings every day. I know that new rules give a minimum of 20 days' paid holiday a year. How much of that applies to me?
fields.trailText: I am a part-time worker, working mornings every day. I know that new rules give a minimum of 20 days' paid holiday a year. How much of that applies to me?
fields.body:
You are entitled to a minimum of 20 days' paid holiday a year. The principle is that you have four weeks away from your workplace.

If, instead of working each day, you worked the first half of the week, to Wednesday lunchtime, you would also be entitled to four weeks away. But instead of getting five consecutive mornings off for each week, you would get the first two-and-a-half days off.

Since 1 July, part-timers have been protected by the Part-Time Workers (Prevention of Less Favourable Treatment) Regulations 2000. It is no longer legal for employers to ban part-timers from the pension scheme, for instance. Part-timers should also get the same benefits as full-timers but on a pro-rata basis.

It may take employers a while to comply. If you need to tackle them on this issue, you could visit a citizens' advice bureau. Many trade unions are doing a lot of for part-timers. Some of the issues are very complicated and it will probably take court cases to sort them out.

 Legal advice from Labour Research Department.

 Problem at work? Write to Neasa MacErlean, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1 3ER. Answers are for guidance only.

fields.headline: Pulling the rug under the 'sickie'
fields.standfirst: Absenteeism is a national disease. Neasa MacErlean looks at employers' drastic remedies
fields.trailText: Absenteeism is a national disease. Neasa MacErlean looks at employers' drastic remedies
fields.body:
As a nation we take seven days off sick each year on average. But more and more employers are becoming sceptical about our absences and taking measures to reduce them. They have a point. Research conducted by the IRS publication Employee Health Bulletin suggests that much sick leave is cultural or emotional, rather than physical.

'Absence levels within organisations vary widely between departments, sections and work groups,' conclude the authors of the research. The survey of 182 employers also found that women take more time off than men; that managers take less time off through sickness than other employees; and that absence rates are higher in large companies than small ones and higher in the public sector than in private businesses.

The country's largest private sector employer, Tesco, has concluded that there are many attitudinal factors in taking sick leave. 'If you don't think you are likely to be missed, you are more likely to take time off,' says Keith Luxon, human resources policy manager. A year ago, Tesco's absenteeism rate was 5.8 per cent. Now it is down by a fifth to 4.6 per cent.

This follows the implementation of new 'attendance management procedures'. As a result, some of the supermarket chain's 175,000 workers have been dismissed because of the time they have taken off sick. Some may think this a harsh approach, but Tesco is happy to talk about its reasons. 'We wanted more openness and honesty about absence,' says Luxon. 'We are operating in an incredibly tight market, which is forcing us to control costs wherever we can. Absenteeism was costing us between £30 million and £40m a year, and it was impacting on customer service. If you operate with 5.8 per cent of your staff away, you have fewer tills open and fewer goods on the shelf.'

Every Tesco employee who takes sick leave of any duration has to have a 'return to work' interview with one of the store managers. In a substantial number of cases, it has emerged that the person was off for domestic or family reasons - looking after a sick child, for example. If this is the case, the employee is given various options about how they want to treat that time: it could be taken as holiday, as unpaid leave, or set off against overtime, but they will not get it for free.

People who have two periods of sickness within 24 weeks are then drawn into the 'attendance management' process, where their attendance is monitored. If they then have a third absence, or if their total time off sick goes above 5 per cent, they are interviewed again and banned from doing overtime for six weeks.

In the interview, they will be asked more about their time off - whether there are common patterns to the different periods of illness. Occupational health services will be made available if a pattern is established - if, for example, they are suffering from repeated back trouble or if they want to space their shifts out differently. If over the next 12 weeks their sickness record does not improve, they get another interview and probably a verbal warning. They will be told: 'We can't run a business effectively on this level of absence.'

If within the next eight weeks there is no improvement in absenteeism levels, they could get a final written warning, and then it is possible that they could be sacked. Tesco says it has tried to be fair and open with staff. An employee will not have to go through this process if there is a clear medical problem. Employment lawyer Michael Burd of solicitor Lewis Silkin believes that many other employers will follow this type of example. Persistent or repeated sickness is one of the most difficult issues for employers to deal with at the moment, he says. 'Doctors seem all too ready to dish out medical certificates giving quite vague reasons for an inability to work.'

Burd says he is constantly dealing with medical reports which say simply 'stress', 'hypertension and work-related stress' or even 'work-related stress _ Mr X should not return to work until the problems there are resolved'. He adds: 'Doctors are doing this with the best interests of their patients in mind. But they sometimes just take that person's word for it. And they have no concept of the kind of legal problems this approach can lead to.'

He has frequently seen businesses come under great pressure when a staff member is suddenly signed off for two months. Unless the employment contract states that the employer can get an independent medical assessment, the employee is protected. Under the confidentiality rules for patients, doctors can not give out any personal information unless they have the patient's consent.

Even when consent is given, the doctors are often not forthcoming. Burd quotes the following 'report' he received from a GP: 'X attended my surgery on X date. I formed the opinion she was unfit to return to work as a result of that consultation. Yours sincerely...' Another part of the reason why employers are clamping down where they can is the Disability Discrimination Act.

This gives a lot of protection to employees who have long-term illnesses, which could last for more than a year. Even if an employee suffers from depression and is away for long periods of time, and the company is suffering as a result, the employer will need to be very careful about taking disciplinary steps. Damages that can be awarded under the Act are unlimited. Tesco has decided that the comfort of its staff cannot be ranked above the interests of its customers in this regard. As Lewis Silkin's Burd points out, many other employers are sure to follow suit.
