fields.headline: Are new 'vocational' degrees worthless?
fields.standfirst:
Yes: Alan Smithers, University of Liverpool
No: Alan Roff, University of Central Lancashire
fields.trailText: Alan Smithers of the University of Liverpool questions the long term value, both for students and society, of vocational degrees, suggesting that their expansion has been largely fuelled by a desire to meet arbitrary participation targets. However, Alan Roff of the University of Central Lancashire argues for their validity, maintaining that the intellectual and practical skills which they foster - the ability to synthesise knowledge and apply it to complex problems - are comparable to those acquired through the more traditional disciplines.
fields.body:
Dear Alan Roff,

For the life of me I cannot see the point of some of the new, so-called vocational degrees in car selling, curry making, beauty therapy, rock music and golf, to name but a few.

Each of these areas has industries associated with it. There may well be a case for some hard practical work-related courses, but why pad them out with quasi-academic philosophy, sociology and the rest, and call them degrees?

Everyone loses: students waste three valuable years developing a false consciousness; employers are left with a lot of nonsense to knock out; the raison d'être of universities is compromised and the country misses out on the practical-technical skills base vital for a competitive economy.

What seems to drive this madness is the need to meet ever-increasing, but arbitrary, participation targets. Never mind the quality, feel the width. I am not saying that the "philosophy of golf" or "the horse in Europe" cannot be interesting, and if students want to back their wish to study them by paying, fine. But, as a taxpayer, I would like to see the government investing the money it takes from me in something more meaningful.

Best wishes,

Alan Smithers.
Director of the Centre for Education and Employment Research,
The University of Liverpool

Dear Alan,

Your letter seems to contain a general argument about vocational degrees and an implied set of specific arguments about a list of specific named courses. I am not sure that we gain much by trying to deal with the latter, as no British university offers degrees in things like "car selling" or "the horse in Europe".

But 30 years ago, when I was a mathematics undergraduate, some people looked down on engineering as being purely vocational. Ten years on, I became heavily involved in the development of business studies degrees and subsequently, business information systems degrees, which again took time to gain acceptance. However, the intellectual and practical demands on students (in terms of knowledge of several disciplines; the ability to synthesise this knowledge, to apply it to complex problems and to communicate the results) were certainly comparable to those required in more traditional disciplines.

I dwell on this because it took place prior to the more recent expansion of higher education and was certainly not driven by any obsession with targets.

Business studies and engineering attempt to provide both rigorous theory and the ability to apply that theory. This is hardly radical. The BA in philosophy here does the same, giving students a clear grounding in philosophical theory and then encouraging its application to important ethical issues, for example.

Our experience is that they are intellectually challenging and have an excellent record in terms of graduates securing jobs and making a big contribution to the UK economy. That seems to me to be a good use of your taxes.

Best wishes,

Alan Roff,
Deputy vice-chancellor,
University of Central Lancashire

Dear Alan,

All the examples I give are real. "Car selling" is automotive retail management at Loughborough and "the horse in Europe" is an option in Equine Studies at Coventry. The fact that you thought I had made them up suggests that you are not entirely convinced either.

There is no long-standing rejection of the vocational as you imply. Universities began with medicine, law and the church. Originally, it was academic subjects like the sciences that had to fight for their place. More recently, a number of vocational disciplines, like those you cite, have proved themselves.

The key issue is the extent of the necessary body of understanding that has to be mastered. This is the difference between training to be a surgeon and a butcher. In the case of the former it is substantial, and hence a degree. Universities are rather good at developing and passing on theory. Even when there is no real need, they may still invent it. Practical learning can then become inflated with pseudo-knowledge. That seems to me to be the fundamental flaw at the heart of the new vocationalism.

Best wishes,

Alan (Smithers)

Dear Alan,

Thanks for the translation and for accepting that vocational degrees like business and engineering have now proved themselves and rightly sit alongside medicine and law as valuable degrees. I will certainly not try to claim that every single degree which has recently been developed will similarly prove itself but if there is an extensive body of knowledge, valid underlying theory and a real need for its application, previous experience suggests that many will do so, even if they have to face the same challenges which science, business and engineering have overcome in the past.

For example, like many universities, we have a degree course in retail management. We offer degree level business education with a specialism in a key business sector. In time, such degrees may even help some people to stop denigrating "sales" - but I recognise that this may take a some time.

Best wishes,

Alan (Roff)

Dear Alan,

Although we can easily agree that some of the vocational education in universities is good and some poor, I suspect we differ profoundly on the current state of higher education.

In my view, it has lost its way. Required in the mid-80s to double numbers on per capita funding cut by nearly half, it has struggled to devise inexpensive courses with which the new students could cope. It came up with confections of vocational and academic studies as the new degrees. Ironically, these drew from shorter, more focused training in further education and industry, which was of genuine benefit.

Hard to explain in educational terms, this makes sense in a wider context. The government of the time was faced with a crisis. There were not enough jobs to go round and it judged this to be a threat to social cohesion. It badly needed something that young people would volunteer to do, and they would go to university.

Much vocational education in universities is a waste of time because that is its role - a means of occupying young people who would otherwise be making a nuisance of themselves.

Best wishes,

Alan (Smithers)

Dear Alan,

I'll have to rush. Since the A-level results came out, we've been overwhelmed with callers. We've had a 50% increase in UCAS applications this year, affecting old and new courses alike. I expect it's because of all the excellent ratings we've had from the Quality Assurance Agency, the very high employment rate of our graduates or just the student grapevine giving us a good press.

You're right that we disagree about the current state of higher education. Most other developed countries had a third of their young people going into higher education years before the UK. It is obviously nonsense to suggest that our young people should be denied the opportunities they deserve or that our economy does not need the sort of graduates the universities are producing. Why else would graduate unemployment rates be so low and getting lower?

From your letters, you sound fairly down. Have you thought about a complete change of lifestyle? Our BSc in multimedia system design may be a bit too modern for you, but I'm sure we could find you something. Most courses run in Preston but we've got a campus in Cumbria if you want to get away from urban life. Call soon or we'll be full.

Must go now,

Alan (Roff)

fields.headline: Holidays in hell
fields.standfirst: Adrian Mole, aged 33
fields.trailText: There are seven of us squeezed into a six-berth caravan. Rosie and Mad Dog Jackson arrived last night on his Harley-Davidson.
fields.body:
Saturday, Utopia Boarding Ouse, Skegness

I've finished packing. Barry Windermere has just wheezed up to the attic to demand compensation for the damage Glenn did (inadvertently) to the Queen Mother's photograph. I refused to give him any more, and told him that the use of unguarded candles is a contravention of the 1981 Hotels & Boarding House Act. He believed this ridiculous lie, and scuttled back down the dark stairs with the stained carpet.

The rest of the family have voted to continue the holiday elsewhere. I was the only one who voted to return home. I feel like a contestant on Big Brother. (Incidentally, that Nicholas is a great bloke, I hope he wins.)

Sunday, Plot 8, Sunny Sands Caravan Site, Hunstanton

There are seven of us squeezed into a six-berth caravan. Rosie and Mad Dog Jackson arrived last night on his Harley-Davidson. I refuse to call him Mad Dog as he requested; it is bad enough having to be seen in his greasy, denimed company. My mother told me proudly that "he's very high up in the Hell's Angels hierarchy". She astounds me. If Rosie was my daughter, I would lock her away in a tall tower until she had woken up from the spell that Jackson has cast over her.

My whole family are in love with him. William and Glenn hang on to his every word. It is now Glenn's ambition to be inducted into the Ashby-de-la-Zouch Chapter of the Hell's Angels. Apparently, there are six of them living in a maisonette in Rosebud Drive. The induction ceremony involves eating raw tripe while being hung upside down from a tree. I said to Glenn that I had other plans for him. That he is to study the history of art at a decent university. Glenn muttered under his breath "Art fart", but I let it go. My nerves are in shreds. I couldn't face another acrimonious confrontation.

The caravan is too confined. I can hear everything through the plywood walls. I overheard my mother saying to Ivan Braithwaite tonight, "Ivan, why are we all cramped up in a caravan in Hunstanton when we can easily afford to stay in a decent Aparthotel with free watersports somewhere abroad?" He chuckled in that maddening way that makes me want to rip his smarmy head off his hairy shoulders and said, "Pauline, you're in denial about your working-class heritage. I'm doing this for you. I want you to rediscover your roots".

My mother snapped that she had spent most of her adult life trying to better herself and hoped to be lower-middle class by the time she was 55, and middle-middle class at death. "The Co-Op won't be doing my funeral," she hissed. I heard her move along their bed in the kitchen (it doubles as a work-top and ironing board during the day). I was glad that their ardour was cooling. I was sick of having to listen to their pathetic attempts at love-making every night. Ivan is having trouble with his prostate. Fortunately, Mad Dog and Rosie are sleeping outside under the awning extension on a double Therm-A-Rest.

Monday

Jackson has gone into Norwich to have a drink with Professor Malcolm Bradbury. He is hoping to get some lecturing work out of him. Is Professor Bradbury being terrorised into giving Jackson work? Has the notoriously gentle academic been threatened and intimidated? It would explain why that monosyllabic thicko, Jackson, has two degrees.

Thursday

I took the boys to Wells-next-the-Sea today. As we strolled up the crowded main street, I saw Glenn looking with interest at a tray of tripe in a butcher's shop window. "It don't look too bad, Dad," he said. "I could get that down my neck."

Friday

The Hog Roast-On-The-Beach has been cancelled due to the unreliability of English pigs.

fields.headline: Companies win sucks.com fight
fields.standfirst:
Net news

Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: Five British companies won the right to internet domain names that claimed they "sucked" yesterday, in a case that delivers a blow to anyone hoping to cash in on website registration.
fields.body:
Five British companies won the right to internet domain names that claimed they "sucked" yesterday, in a case that delivers a blow to anyone hoping to cash in on website registration.

The World Intellectual Property Organisation, Wipo, ruled in Geneva that websites called natwestsucks.com, standardcharteredsucks.com, directlinesucks.com, dixonssucks.com and freeservesucks.com should all be owned by the companies concerned.

NatWest, Standard Chartered and Direct Line, three financial services groups, the electrical retailer Dixon's, and the internet service provider Freeserve filed their complaint two months ago to the United Nations' arbitration panel after Purge IT, a British company, had registered the sucks.com domain names.

Disputes involving some of the thousands of so-called cybergriping sites have escalated in the past year as companies have decided to stop turning a blind eye to what they consider blackmail.

In a separate case yesterday, Wal-Mart, the world's largest retailer, won control over wal-mart-europe.com from a resident of Geneva. In May, Wipo handed the Wal-mart several sucks.com domain names.

So far this year, Wipo has accepted 954 domain name disputes for arbitration, although not all of these relate to corporate insults. The UN body introduced a new arbitration procedure last year to cut down on so-called "cybersquatting" amid complaints from corporations that it cost too much to buy back the rights to their names.

In yesterday's ruling, William Cornish, the arbitrator, said that Purge, which is based in Bicester, had no legitimate interest in the names and had registered them in bad faith. He had heard evidence in the case that Purge had asked the companies concerned for money. He found the company had bought the domain names solely to sell them on rather than protest about the targeted companies.

Purge argued that it had never used the domain names and had never intended to sell them to anyone but the companies involved.

fields.bodyText: Five British companies won the right to internet domain names that claimed they "sucked" yesterday, in a case that delivers a blow to anyone hoping to cash in on website registration. The World Intellectual Property Organisation, Wipo, ruled in Geneva that websites called natwestsucks.com, standardcharteredsucks.com, directlinesucks.com, dixonssucks.com and freeservesucks.com should all be owned by the companies concerned. NatWest, Standard Chartered and Direct Line, three financial services groups, the electrical retailer Dixon's, and the internet service provider Freeserve filed their complaint two months ago to the United Nations' arbitration panel after Purge IT, a British company, had registered the sucks.com domain names. Disputes involving some of the thousands of so-called cybergriping sites have escalated in the past year as companies have decided to stop turning a blind eye to what they consider blackmail. In a separate case yesterday, Wal-Mart, the world's largest retailer, won control over wal-mart-europe.com from a resident of Geneva. In May, Wipo handed the Wal-mart several sucks.com domain names. So far this year, Wipo has accepted 954 domain name disputes for arbitration, although not all of these relate to corporate insults. The UN body introduced a new arbitration procedure last year to cut down on so-called "cybersquatting" amid complaints from corporations that it cost too much to buy back the rights to their names. In yesterday's ruling, William Cornish, the arbitrator, said that Purge, which is based in Bicester, had no legitimate interest in the names and had registered them in bad faith. webTitle: The first high-concept Jackie Chan flick high-kicks its way onto the big screen

fields.headline: Won ton violence
fields.standfirst: The first high-concept Jackie Chan flick high-kicks its way onto the big screen this week. Joe Queenan is knocked out
fields.trailText: The first high-concept Jackie Chan flick high-kicks its way onto the big screen this week. Joe Queenan is knocked out
fields.body:
Although Jackie Chan has only been known to the general public for a few short years, it seems like he's been around forever. That's because he has now made 3,500 films, many without having to re-feed the cameraman's parking meter. The oriental, martial-arts version of G*rard Depardieu or Gene Hackman or the sorely missed Klaus Kinski, Chan makes movies faster than most people can make change, which is astonishing considering the number of bones he has broken during his career. In the time it will have taken to write this review, Chan will have made another three movies: Enter The Kimono Dragon, Rumble In Little Formosa and Last Tango In Hunan. Jackie Chan is more than a movie star. He is an entire industrial sector.

One of the things that makes Jackie Chan movies so appealing is their fabulously cheesy quality. Shot on shoe-string budgets in out-of-the-way locales with no stars and wafer-thin plots, films like What's My Name? are basically just an excuse for Chan to clamber up and down the facades of tall office buildings and ride motorcycles atop speeding locomotives. The basic plot-line is set up immediately, and then the stunts begin; niceties like subplots, character development or actual acting are dismissed out of hand.

Although the films are filled with fight sequences, the combat tends to be of a decidedly cartoonish variety, with little blood and few mutilations. This makes the films suitable for viewing by all age groups and genders, though Chan's biggest fans are young men, just as Meg Ryan's biggest fans are not.

Primitive yet clever, the average Jackie Chan movie is the celluloid equivalent to the average pop song: dumb but entertaining. They are what they are.

Shanghai Noon is not, however, the average Jackie Chan movie. Determined to reach a much wider audience, to bring an actor who is still basically a cult figure to the masses, Hollywood has now produced the first high-concept Jackie Chan movie. (Rush Hour, released two years ago, was a step in this direction, but it was still basically a slap-dash affair.) The results are immediately apparent. In Shanghai Noon the camerawork is better than in previous Jackie Chan movies. The locations are more seductive. The plot is more complex. A co-star with an actual role shares the screen with Chan. The minor characters have not been dubbed into English, but actually speak it. In every way imaginable, the film has a much more polished look than the usual Jackie Chan fare, radiating a visual and thematic professionalism that is rarely part of the Chan oeuvre. Personally, I still prefer crummy-looking movies like Twin Dragons and Who Am I? But if loftier production values will make Chan a bigger star, then I'm all for it. This guy deserves whatever he can get.

Stripped to the core, Shanghai Noon is a fusion of the traditional buddy film with the traditional fish-out-of-water film, superimposed on the traditional western settling-of-accounts film. Early in the proceedings, the daughter of the Chinese emperor is abducted by a scoundrel masquerading as her tutor. After she is carried off to the Old West and held for an enormous ransom, three Imperial guards are dispatched to retrieve her. At the last minute, Chan, who plays a somewhat inept Imperial guard, also joins the group. Since Chan was on duty the night the princess was abducted, and might have prevented her kidnap, he has a personal stake in the matter. He also has a crush on the princess, played with appropriate mystery by Ally McBeal's Lucy Liu, who will soon light up the screen in Charlie's Angels.

The Chinese warriors soon arrive in the Old West, make a complete hash of things, realise that they are out of their element and drop out of the film until its exciting conclusion. But the diligent, smitten Chan soldiers on, running through his usual gamut of amazing stunts, performing a sort of Greatest Hits medley for people who have never seen him in action before.

In due course, Chan hooks up with Owen Wilson, a downwardly mobile gunslinger and bank robber of vaguely philosophical bent. Seeking to unlock the inner hombre that he believes resides inside himself somewhere, Wilson imbues the film with a charming New Age fatuousness that would have been even funnier if the scriptwriter had written better, and more, jokes. In the meantime, Chan continues to run through his repertoire, performing hilarious, mind-boggling routines with savage Indians, racist cowboys, unscrupulous sheriffs, determined vigilantes, uncooperative horses.

Where the average Jackie Chan movie lasts 90 minutes or less, Shanghai Noon drags on for almost two hours, which is exactly 30 minutes too long. Director Tom Day seems to have wanted to make a horse opera spoof on the order of Mel Brooks' peerless Blazing Saddles, but he doesn't have enough material to work with. Moreover, he seems to have persuaded himself that Owen Wilson is much funnier than he is. Wilson is OK. But he's not going to make anyone forget Gene Wilder. Unless they already have forgotten Gene Wilder.

The one thing Shanghai Noon lacks is the manic quality of many earlier Jackie Chan movies; the momentum is constantly slowed down by Wilson's amusing but extraneous antics. It is as if the producers of Shanghai Noon didn't trust Chan to carry the ball all by himself. As anyone who has been following his career knows, this is a serious underestimation of Chan's talents: once he gets going, he's a human tornado. Nevertheless, Shanghai Noon is far from a dud.

As is always the case, the best thing about going to see a Jackie Chan movie is the feeling that every penny spent going to see him is money that is not going to Jean-Claude Van Damme or Chuck Norris. This is one of the most exhilarating feelings known to man.

 Shanghai Noon is out on Friday

fields.headline: Birdcage, London
fields.standfirst: Matthew Fort doesn't really go in for fusion food, but when it's done as brilliantly - not to mention strangely - as at the Birdcage, even he is forced to reconsider
fields.trailText: Matthew Fort doesn't really go in for fusion food, but when it's done as brilliantly - not to mention strangely - as at the Birdcage, even he is forced to reconsider
fields.body:
Address: Birdcage, London

There is something agreeably laid back about the Birdcage. "If you want to book for lunch," says the message on the answerphone, "leave your name and telephone number twice, or just turn up at the restaurant." Obviously, they're not overwhelmed with lunchtime trade, but it still has an efficient, cheerful, friendly tone to it, and that sets the style for the service, as well. It's as if all those associated with the Birdcage want to convey that the restaurant is rather different.

In fact, it is about as different as it is possible to be -from entry to exit, from menu to wine list, from first mouthful to last, it is like being in the company of a kindly, eccentric, humorous relative who has a mad enthusiasm for the Orient. The dining room, which isn't exactly gigantic, is so stuffed with Orientaliana as to hardly allow any room for tables. Figurines, peacock feathers, swathes of decorative fabrics, mirrors, pictures, plants glitter in the crepuscular gloom. The tables themselves are so covered with decorative bits and bobs as to scarcely have room for plate, bread, wine and all the other paraphernalia of eating. Then the menu comes, stuck to the flyleaf of a book; and the wine list is in the form of an origami bird.

In the face of this onslaught of individuality amounting to nuttiness, it is easy to be distracted from the originality and excellence of the food. Even here the sense of having entered another world persists. There aren't many places - actually, there aren't any places - where you will find goat consommé with Irish moss and wakame tartlet, ackee whitefish in paperbark with lavender-drenched potato, or Japanese golden plum echinacea ice cream with baby bee or giant hornet honey glaze, or that suggests a glass of pudding wine to wash down a chocolate-covered scorpion, worm or cricket. And, yes, that's real scorpions, worms and crickets. Three crickets (though they might have been locusts), cropped up on top of my bitter cactus rice knapsacks in pan-leaf canvas.

This outré display of exotic ingredients might simply be distracting, ridiculous or downright disgusting in incompetent hands, but they aren't. They all play useful and active parts in the utterly consistent and highly structured world of Michael von Hruschka, itself a name that is cause for wonder. I believe he helped out at that early bird of east-meets-west fusion, the Hempel, but has since taken the precepts, and indeed the whole notion of fusion, to an illogical but divertingly delicious extreme. On the whole, I am no great lover of fusion food. Too often, it is an excuse for culinary promiscuity in which the sum is considerably less than the parts. But von Hruschka manages to avoid both cliché and confusion.

After much mulling, Blossom - who eats fish but not meat - and I chose: a triptych of squid, honeyed Hungarian chilli pig with tiger-nut pesto square, then pear-and-raisin cigarillos with jasmine and poppyseed anglaise to finish (me); salmon with Japanese spices, then mohinga with ackee fishballs (Blossom); and bitter cactus rice in pan-leaf canvas between us out of curiosity.

Each dish arrived in exquisite arrangements of tiny parcels, blocks and bricks. You think you are getting one thing, but no, you get three variations, each tied in a Lilliputian strip of lime peel, decorated with a stem of cress or whatever. The effect is like being served a series of Fabergé miniatures. This is labour-intensive stuff to cook, but not to eat.

Take my triptych of squid. There was a diminutive heap of roasted rice with scrolls of limpidly tender squid, that cephalopodic sweetness peeking through a clean, chilli-driven dressing. There was a dainty bowl of Stygian black soup made of squid ink and heaven knows what else, which was slightly thickened, seductively, sourishly acidic and rich beyond measure. Between these came a brace of taut and spiced squid spring rolls. It was a brilliant sequence of differences, each fully characterised and compellingly edible.

A true-blue Hungarian might have trouble recognising a national dish in von Hruschka's version of the pork dish, but the restrained sweetness of the honey, pointed warmth of the paprika and the aromatic dryness of the tiger-nut pesto square made for a rare and meticulously balanced mouthful. And as for the Japanese gold plum business, well...

Given the range and variety within each dish, I would need a volume or two to describe the elements and effects of our lunch, and after a while such detail becomes as wearisome to read as it is to write. Who, after all, stops to note, codify and remember tastes in detail in the course of a meal when your companion is amusing, intelligent, diverting and perceptive. Sad sacks only. I did take notes, because I am a compulsive sad sack, but I have no intention of inflicting my affliction on you.

Instead, I want you to go along and try out the Birdcage for yourselves. It will not be to everyone's taste. The mad clutter, quirky humour and the wild combinations, unabashed theatricality, fastidious decorative style and miniaturism of the dishes will irritate as many people as those who fall in love with them.

Those who want to love need to be prepared to pay a price. I paid £86.30, which included a restricted amount of wine - five glasses between us, including two glasses of champagne: £30.50-worth, to be exact. Two courses at lunch cost £19.50, three cost £26.50, but considering the labour, love, originality and Epicurean pleasure involved in each mouthful, it isn't unreasonable. You will pay more and have less fun in most places in London. Or the Orient, come to that.

fields.headline: Loud and proud
fields.standfirst: Don't be too demure in your planting, says Christopher Lloyd. Summer just cries out for bold, bright colours - especially in Britain
fields.trailText: Don't be too demure in your planting, says Christopher Lloyd. Summer just cries out for bold, bright colours - especially in Britain
fields.body:
The summer garden is so full of good things that it is hard to know which to highlight. Centaurea glastifolia (1m) is a modest perennial, and modesty can (in my view) easily be overdone in a garden - too much of understatement results in boredom. "Quietly pleasing" can also be a back-handed compliment, for which "small yawn" is the underlying interpretation. Well, this is a knapweed of quality (I'm not sure that I've hit the right note yet). Unlike the brighter yellow, larger-flowered C. macrocephala, it is not at all a coarse plant, and has pale-yellow thistle-heads opening from a near spherical bud in which the overlapping bracts are carefully dappled in dark and lighter brown. The plant is branching and its flowers open over a longish period. I mean to make more of it.

This is a great time for crocosmias - the junior partners of gladioli - and there are many named cultivars now available. They should be chosen on the hoof, so to speak, but whether scarlet, orange or yellow, all team up effectively with one or other of the many blue agapanthus. It is just a question of choosing so that both flowers peak simultaneously (and at roughly the same height). Trial and error is probably the simplest way of achieving this, as timing can vary considerably, even in different parts of the same garden.

There is another partnership that I am planning to initiate for next year. I have a dramatic specimen in flower of Sambucus canadensis 'Maxima'. This is an elder that flowers on its young wood, so it can be headed quite hard back every winter to promote strong new growth. Feed it well at the same time. It will then carry truly enormous flat heads of scented, cream-white blossom from top (3m) to toe. There being far more to gardening than just grow-ing a plant well, I intend in front of mine to make quite a large colony of a tall border phlox called 'Princess Sturdza' (2m), which is deep mauve and not unlike the species Phlox paniculata itself, but stiffer and more upright. With so much cloud cover this summer, it has been a great year for phloxes, and colour in general has been more intense than under blazing sunshine.

Even though it may qualify for the "quietly pleasing" category, I want also to recommend a tree mallow with a difference: Lavatera cachemiriana (2m). Its flowers are a quite soft version of the usual mallow pink, but the five petals are widely separated and each is deeply notched, which gives the whole plant a distinctive appearance, as do its pale-green developing seed pods. Prune it quite hard in the dormant season, as you would with all tree mallows, so this associates well with herbaceous perennials in a mixed border; a purple Clematis 'Jackmanii', say, behind it looks good. The mallow can be raised from Thompson & Morgan seed.

Also from seed, you should grow the pure-white version of perennial pea, Lathyrus latifolius, which may be listed as 'Albus' or as 'White Pearl'. Don't be too surprised if some of the seedlings come in one of the many shades of pink or magenta that this species also embraces. The white kind is the cleanest, and the pea flowers are borne in short, one-sided racemes.

In a mixed border, they will materialise unexpectedly when you have forgotten about them and will then clamber gracefully over their neighbours. One of the yellow-flowered clematis, such as 'Helios', will make a good companion.

Many perennial sunflowers are currently on trial at Wisley. Cultivars of heliopsis are a particularly rich shade of yellow, and the one that has struck me most forcibly is called 'Benzinggold' (1.5m), which carries upright daisies with several layers of petals. Slug damage can ruin young plants from the start, and it is a genus that doesn't respond well to undue competition from neighbours, so try to give them an open, sunny site. That said, I would recommend growing, fairly nearby, Salvia guaranitica 'Blue Enigma' (2m), which is an intense deep blue and has a long flowering season. Most people's concept of impatiens is the dwarf busy lizzie, widely grown for bedding and in a range of contrasting colours. In which case, I. tinctoria (2m) will come as a surprise: not only is this plant tall and lush, but its large, butterfly- like flowers are presented as individuals (albeit in an inflorescence). They are white with a conspicuous central purple blotch, and are powerfully night-scented. The plant has tubers, and mine overwintered so well in the garden that it has been flowering already for a long while and will continue until the first frost. We covered the crown of the plant with protective litter in the winter. It is safer to lift and store, much like a dahlia, though not so dry. Cuttings of young shoots can be taken in spring. Capsid damage can be crippling on this species, as on fuchsias and many other summer flowers.

Do try to remember to collect seed of various plants from your own garden. One that ripens over a long period is Cerinthe major 'Purpurascens' (0.5m). This is a member of the borage family, and one in which the most noticeable feature is the broad, rounded and utterly smooth purple bracts that subtend the tubular flowers.

Unsurprisingly, it has caught the imagination of its public in a big way. The seeds are quite large, and almost black. The finest plants will be obtained from an autumn sowing, say in late September, potting the seedlings individually and overwintering them under just frost- free glass. We usually stop the seedlings once, to make them stock out. Plant them in the garden in April, or move them into larger pots for display. They have a long season.

This is an elder that flowers on its young wood, so it can be headed quite hard back every winter to promote strong new growth. Feed it well at the same time. It will then carry truly enormous flat heads of scented, cream-white blossom from top (3m) to toe. There being far more to gardening than just grow-ing a plant well, I intend in front of mine to make quite a large colony of a tall border phlox called 'Princess Sturdza' (2m), which is deep mauve and not unlike the species Phlox paniculata itself, but stiffer and more upright. With so much cloud cover this summer, it has been a great year for phloxes, and colour in general has been more intense than under blazing sunshine. Even though it may qualify for the "quietly pleasing" category, I want also to recommend a tree mallow with a difference: Lavatera cachemiriana (2m). Its flowers are a quite soft version of the usual mallow pink, but the five petals are widely separated and each is deeply notched, which gives the whole plant a distinctive appearance, as do its pale-green developing seed pods. Prune it quite hard in the dormant season, as you would with all tree mallows, so this associates well with herbaceous perennials in a mixed border; a purple Clematis 'Jackmanii', say, behind it looks good. The mallow can be raised from Thompson & Morgan seed. Also from seed, you should grow the pure-white version of perennial pea, Lathyrus latifolius, which may be listed as 'Albus' or as 'White Pearl'. Don't be too surprised if some of the seedlings come in one of the many shades of pink or magenta that this species also embraces. The white kind is the cleanest, and the pea flowers are borne in short, one-sided racemes. In a mixed border, they will materialise unexpectedly when you have forgotten about them and will then clamber gracefully over their neighbours. One of the yellow-flowered clematis, such as 'Helios', will make a good companion. Many perennial sunflowers are currently on trial at Wisley. Cultivars of heliopsis are a particularly rich shade of yellow, and the one that has struck me most forcibly is called 'Benzinggold' (1.5m), which carries upright daisies with several layers of petals. Slug damage can ruin young plants from the start, and it is a genus that doesn't respond well to undue competition from neighbours, so try to give them an open, sunny site. That said, I would recommend growing, fairly nearby, Salvia guaranitica 'Blue Enigma' (2m), which is an intense deep blue and has a long flowering season. Most people's concept of impatiens is the dwarf busy lizzie, widely grown for bedding and in a range of contrasting colours. In which case, I. tinctoria (2m) will come as a surprise: not only is this plant tall and lush, but its large, butterfly- like flowers are presented as individuals (albeit in an inflorescence). They are white with a conspicuous central purple blotch, and are powerfully night-scented. The plant has tubers, and mine overwintered so well in the garden that it has been flowering already for a long while and will continue until the first frost. We covered the crown of the plant with protective litter in the winter. It is safer to lift and store, much like a dahlia, though not so dry. Cuttings of young shoots can be taken in spring. Capsid damage can be crippling on this species, as on fuchsias and many other summer flowers. Do try to remember to collect seed of various plants from your own garden. One that ripens over a long period is Cerinthe major 'Purpurascens' (0.5m). This is a member of the borage family, and one in which the most noticeable feature is the broad, rounded and utterly smooth purple bracts that subtend the tubular flowers. Unsurprisingly, it has caught the imagination of its public in a big way. The seeds are quite large, and almost black. The finest plants will be obtained from an autumn sowing, say in late September, potting the seedlings individually and overwintering them under just frost- free glass. We usually stop the seedlings once, to make them stock out. Plant them in the garden in April, or move them into larger pots for display. They have a long season.

webTitle: Gibraltar steps up row over British sub

fields.headline: Gibraltar steps up row over British sub
fields.trailText: The Ministry of Defence was last night threatened with unprecedented legal and industrial action if it goes ahead with plans to repair a nuclear-powered submarine moored off Gibraltar.
fields.body:
The Ministry of Defence was last night threatened with unprecedented legal and industrial action if it goes ahead with plans to repair a nuclear-powered submarine moored off Gibraltar.

The government of the British territory yesterday joined an escalating campaign among increasingly angry Gibraltarians demanding access to secret MoD reports on the safety implications of the plan to fix the submarine's nuclear reactor cooling system.

The Gibraltar government says it was initially given the impression by the MoD that there was "no risk at all" involved in repairing HMS Tireless in the harbour of the Rock.

Sir John Cadogan, chairman of the defence nuclear safety committee and professor of chemistry at London University, has now said the risk is "modest", according to sources close to the Gibraltar government. He is reported to have told the government that there would be no greater risk than repairing the submarine in a British dockyard, such as Devonport, specially equipped to deal with damaged nuclear submarines.

However, this view was challenged yesterday by a source familiar with the problems confronting the Tireless. He described the risk of repairing the submarine on the Rock as "high". He said the fault was located above valves controlling pressure to the submarine's generators close to the reactor itself. Leaking water was close to the reactor's fuel, he added.

This, according to other sources, is why the MoD abandoned plans to tow the submarine back to Devonport where the fuel would have been drained from the reactor.

The proximity of the leaking water and the fuel carries the risk of spillage from the submarine in the event of any abrupt movement, sources who did not want to be identified told the Guardian.

Peter Caruana, chief minister, said: "What is concerning Gibraltar, which has a long and close relationship with the MoD, is that while we are used to receiving visits from nuclear submarines, and we are relaxed about that, there is no experience in Gibraltar of repairs to broken down nuclear submarines being undertaken here.

"The position that the government have adopted and have maintained is that repairs should only be carried out in Gibraltar if there is no risk to public health from the carrying out of repairs," he told BBC radio.

Mr Caruana said his government wanted the MoD to hand over its safety case so that a panel of independent experts could assess Gibraltar's suitability as a place for the repairs to be done.

He added: "The MoD have declined to make that information available to the Government, the Government is therefore unable to say whether the repairs are safe or not.

"I think the MoD needs to think long and hard about whether it proceeds with the repairs in Gibraltar unless the government and people of Gibraltar can be satisfied."

Lawyers acting for groups representing a broad cross-section of the Gibraltarian community, including the local branch of the Transport and General Workers' Union, sent a letter to the MoD demanding access to its official safety assessment. They are considering taking the issue to the high court in Britain.

Levi Attias, spokesman for the Voice of Gibraltar group, accused the ministry of "sheer disregard for the rights of Gibraltarians".

The MoD said it had followed "exhaustive procedures" to assess the risks involved. The safety case would be presented to the Gibraltar government on Monday.

webTitle: Stop the bullying: change the groundsmen

fields.headline: Stop the bullying: change the groundsmen
fields.standfirst: Charles Britten calls for a proactive solution to the England's pitch crisis
fields.trailText: Punter's Point Charles Britten calls for a proactive solution to the England's pitch crisis.
fields.body:
It was John Bracewell who first labelled Graeme Hick a "flat-track bully", a label that has stuck during a Test career of notorious underachievement. Less well known is the original context. The accusation arose in the aftermath of a humiliating defeat in 1988 for Bracewell's Auckland against those rural upstarts from Northern Districts, whose victory was built upon a double century from a player who in those days seemed destined for greatness. Bracewell's own bowling was cut (not to mention pulled and driven) to ribbons, and his response, both on and, so memorably, off the field, was far from magnanimous. Hick recounted this as his first experience of sledging.

However questionable the context of the most memorable cricketing words Bracewell has ever spoken may be, his recent comments on the standards of pitches in England are indubitably not. Joined by others such as Glenn McGrath, Bracewell has rightly condemned the quality of tracks that are anything but flat, on which neither Hick nor anybody else can bully the bowlers.

This problem has long been recognised in English cricket. In a drive to eliminate result pitches over a decade ago, four-day cricket was phased in and point penalties for bad pitches levied. One such penalty of 25 points cost Essex the 1989 Championship, handing it on a plate to the flat-track bully and his Worcester team-mates. For a while a plethora of excessively flat pitches were produced, which is no more desirable as it rewards mediocre batsmen, but the scales have tilted back dramatically in recent years. Result pitches are again appearing with alarming regularity. Once more it is the bowler who is the bully.

Last year it was argued that the splitting of the Championship encouraged more result pitches than ever to help teams win enough matches to stay in the upper half of the table. Now, Bracewell argues, result wickets are prepared to help teams get vital points when chasing promotion or trying to avoid relegation. Whether he is right or not, a new solution to the pitch problem needs to be found. Awarding more points for drawing games was correct from a purely meritocratic playing point of view, but ineffective in producing better pitches. Point deductions have not been used often enough, and when they are the subsequent appeals against them are frequently successful. In short, nobody is bullying the counties into producing flat tracks.

There is, however, one straightforward solution. Having put the interests of the England team first by having centrally contracted players, the ECB could go one step further by having centrally contracted groundsmen, whose brief would be to produce good wickets that last four days. No longer will the short-term interests of counties be put before needs of the English game. As these groundsmen will also be preparing the strips at Test grounds, those wickets should be the same type and quality as used in county games. Without doubt, the Test pitches in England in recent years have also left much to be desired.

Will the counties object? They shouldn't. On this issue they can hardly have the support of the members, who often see little or no fourth-day cricket on Saturdays. The fact that their teams' bowlers may have a field day means little if they can't see a day of them in the field. It is as much in the interests of these hardcore followers, as those of the casual fan who would watch England if they were winning, for this change to occur.

Furthermore, counties worried about the financial implications of second-division cricket should consider the amount of money they receive from international match receipts now, and think about how much more there will be in gate money and post-Cornhill sponsorship if England are winning in the years ahead. There really is no reason for any bullying, or a pitch battle.

Charles Britten, 27, comes from Marple in Cheshire. To read last week's Punter's Point, which asks whether cricket really isn't what it used to be, click here

webTitle: They still take aim at the death strip but these days it's from the tee

fields.headline: They still take aim at the death strip but these days it's from the tee
fields.trailText: Most of what you see from behind the petrol station at the end of Habersaathstrasse is as bleak as urban-desolate gets, even in the former East Germany.
fields.body:
Most of what you see from behind the petrol station at the end of Habersaathstrasse is as bleak as urban-desolate gets, even in the former East Germany.

Ringing the vast open space where the Stadium of World Youth once stood is a row of depressing buildings - offices, factories and warehouses - broken only by a giant, 300ft-high smokestack. Behind you is a line of archetypal east German houses. Their mud-coloured walls are covered in a hideous surfacing, not so much pebble-dash as grit-dash. Their windows have barely any sills, let alone balconies.

The people who ran the German Democratic Republic (GDR) did not lay out cash on details aimed at generating a little pleasure. One can only speculate on what these officials would make of the steady trickle of people parking on Habersaathstrasse, reaching into the boot for long, heavy bags and heaving them across the road to the open space - now east Berlin's only golf course.

"There's no green fee," said the enthusiastic young woman in the shop on the corner which hires out equipment. "So if you turn up with your own clubs and balls, it's free."

The Golf-Zentrum Mitte is a practice ground. It has a driving range, a putting green, a chipping green and a couple of bunkers. It has its own club house - a portable building painted green with a tiny flower bed outside. And it is big - 100,000 square metres of undulating, lovingly tended grass.

Before the fall of the Wall, golf was unthinkable in the east and virtually unplayable in the west. Space was at a premium in the old "island city", encircled as it was by a hostile GDR. The RAF had a club, but the only one run for and by Germans was out in suburban Wannsee, and it was kept hyper-exclusive.

Golf has yet to catch on among easterners, but it has undergone an explosion in popularity among westerners anxious to try out once forbidden fruit. Today, there are 16 courses in and around Berlin. Most of the players at the Golf-Zentrum Mitte last week were from the west. Martin Neumann, an internet designer who now lives in the east, had come along with some friends.

"We bought him a golf club and a couple of lessons," he said, gesturing towards one of his party. "It was a joke, really. But we came along too, and we got to enjoy it. Now, we try to meet here once a week."

It was a warm evening. The sun was sinking behind the smokestack as a covered buggy trundled to and fro across the driving range scooping up the balls. Behind us, a line of golfers aimed drives towards what was once the "death strip". The strip, just a few hundred yards away, was the territory cleared by the communist authorities so that their border guards could get a clear sight of - and aim at - those desperate enough to try to flee to the west.

One of the golfers was instructing a friend.

"No. Not like that," he was saying. "Just try to keep your ankles loose."

webTitle: Unfurnished football club for sale, suits ex-international

fields.headline: Unfurnished football club for sale, suits ex-international
fields.standfirst: Archibald at Airdrie and football's financial realities north of the border
fields.trailText: Archibald at Airdrie and football's financial realities north of the border.
fields.body:
It was reported this week that Paul Miller, the former Tottenham defender, has been recruited by a leading merchant bank to head a division that will help professional footballers organise their bloated incomes. Things have grown a bit more sophisticated since the days when players bought a pub as a pension scheme: offshore hedge funds and convertible stock options are more the financial order of things.

We can only assume, then, that Miller was not involved in advising his old Spurs colleague Steve Archibald, who is on the verge of concluding a transaction which, traditionally, has all the fiscal rectitude of using £50 notes as emergency toilet tissue. Archibald is about to complete the purchase of Airdrieonians, the Scottish First Division Club that limped into liquidation last season.

"It's entirely my money. Don't even ask how much," Archibald explains, speaking this week from that hotbed of international finance, the Shyberry Excelsior stadium in Airdrie. "And no, I'm not happy with the possibility of losing the lot. I just felt that if I was coming in here doing the things I wanted it had to be my money I risked. If all goes well, I'll reap the benefits. And if it goes wrong, then there's only one person who will take the consequences."

The Scottish First Division is, financially, on another planet from the one Miller will be patrolling, that inhabited by Beckham, Bergkamp and Ken Bates's dividend payments. Here, profit is an entirely theoretical concept. As, apparently, is furniture.

Archibald arrived at his new domain last month to discover that, on the eve of the first match of the season, the previous chairman had turned up in the dead of night with a removal van and taken away what few assets remained at the club.

"Sofas in the players' lounge, office furniture, the lot," says Archibald, who was used in his playing career to the elegant surrounds of the Nou Camp. "In a way it was quite funny, but it gives you an idea of how the place used to be run."

Presumably standing up as he speaks on the phone, Archibald none the less appears in good spirits as he talks about his new purchase, using terms such as "project" and "attractive package" where others might have preferred "barge pole". What was it that persuaded him to leave his handsome home in Barcelona, where he has lived and prospered in business since retiring as a player, to risk all in Lanarkshire? Is he a diehard Airdrie fan?

'A bsolutely not," he says. "I deliberately chose a club I had no association with. If you buy something you love, you lose all perspective. It can be very dangerous financially. No, I was looking for an opportunity like this for some time. We have an excellent new stadium here which was a big attraction. Plus I believe, business wise, Scotland is the land of opportunity."

A view not shared by Celtic and Rangers, who seem as determined as ever to cut their ties with their homeland and make their future overseas in an Atlantic League. Perhaps that was what tempted the former Spur, the chance to become the premier force in Scottish club football.

"I haven't made any promises like that," he says. "We're very wary of raising expectations which we can't fulfil. Our short-term vision is just to stabilise the club, to produce an attractive package on the park which will get the fans back in and provide financial solidity."

To that end, Archibald has been using his Barcelona contacts to bring in an assortment of Spanish and South American players - 10 so far - whose performance against Raith Rovers in a 1-1 draw last week was described by Scottish Television as "sexy stuff".

"Well, they moved the ball around on the deck," says the new man, drily. "Which can be said to be unusual here."

Nevertheless, he seems pleased with the critical response to his side - after all, he has been coaching them himself. But you have to wonder if a player of his reputation could not have found himself a managerial position without the necessity of buying a club first.

"My intention is not to be the coach, I'm just doing it in the meantime," he says. "When you buy a club, you've got to get the right people round you. When we find the right coach, he will come in."

In the meantime he is doing everything, from working out how to spring the offside trap to negotiating with creditors. "Every day I'm going through a mountain of stuff," he says. "Leases for this and that. The old administration was in hock up to its eyeballs. Even the pictures on the wall were leased. And the plants in the reception area. They owned nothing."

Except the furniture.

"That's true, they owned that," he says. "Still do."

Except the furniture. "That's true, they owned that," he says. "Still do."

webTitle: Olympics: Cuba to hold firm over ban

fields.headline: Cuba to hold firm over ban
fields.standfirst:
Stars set to miss Olympics in campaign to end rich world's 'poaching', writes Duncan Mackay

Special report: Sydney Olympics
fields.trailText: Athletes have long been prepared to switch countries as easily as they might change their vests. But now Cuba has put its foot down and is prepared to stop three of its former sports heroes competing for their adopted countries in the Sydney Olympics next month, claiming that rich countries are robbing the best athletes from poor ones.
fields.body:
Athletes have long been prepared to switch countries as easily as they might change their vests. But now Cuba has put its foot down and is prepared to stop three of its former sports heroes competing for their adopted countries in the Sydney Olympics next month, claiming that rich countries are robbing the best athletes from poor ones.

The Cuban-born athletes Niurka Montalvo, the world champion in the women's long jump, and the water polo player Ivan Perez were refused permission by Cuba to compete for Spain, where they are now citizens, while the former Cuban kayaker Angel Perez has been told he cannot compete for the United States in Sydney.

Adding to the controversy, Cuban athletes training in Spain for Sydney, including the world high jump record holder Javier Sotomayor, were told by Cuba to leave the country last Sunday. The 15 Cuban athletes arrived in May in Guadalajara, a city east of Madrid, where they have based their training camp for the last 15 years. They were planning to stay until next month but have now decamped to a new base in Italy.

"This is our final position," the president of the Cuban athletics federation Alberto Juantorena said. "This is not a political question, it is a question of rules."

Under the Olympic Charter, any athlete who changes his or her nationality must get permission from their country of origin before competing for their adopted homeland.

Montalvo, 31, competed for Cuba in the 1996 Olympics in Atlanta but has lived in Spain for nearly three years. She was granted citizenship last year after marrying a Spaniard and beat Marion Jones to claim the long jump title at the world championships in Seville.

"It's treason," said Juantorena, the 400 and 800 metres gold medallist at the 1976 Olympics in Montreal. "Niurka abandoned the Cuban team in 1997 when she left Cuba. She is the fruit of Cuba's sports movement.

"She is being depicted as a victim, and she is not a victim. How are the Cuban people supposed to feel? They have supported her training for 16 years so she can compete under another flag."

Juantorena said Cuba is trying to draw international attention to what it claims is the common practice by rich nations of wooing the best athletes from poor ones. "Cuba develops talent. It does not rob talent," Juantorena said. "This is a trafficking of people."

Montalvo is the unhappy victim of Juantorena's campaign. "I've spent a year preparing for the Games," she said. "I meet all the requirements to be at the Games and I don't think it's right that other things prevail over sports matters. I'm only an athlete, not a politician."

Meanwhile, Morocco is refusing to allow three of its athletes to run for France in Sydney, rejecting pleas to allow Driss Maazouzi in the 1500m, Smail Sghir in the 5000m and Roukaya Maraoui in the 10,000m to compete despite the fact they are now all French citizens.

Jose Ramon Fernandez, the president of the Cuba's Olympic committee, said his country continues to believe in the basic principles of the Olympics, which were "established to promote friendly competition among amateur athletes of the world's nations".

Cuba's refusal to allow Perez on the US team will be appealed to the International Olympic Committee when it meets in two weeks. "We would hope that sport on an international basis will rise above what tension is between our two countries," said Bill Hybl, chairman of the US Olympic committee. "That's what the Olympic movement is all about."

Perez, who competed for Cuba in the 1992 Olympics, defected to the United States the next year. He became a US citizen nine months ago and made the team in Olympic trials in June.

Hybl went to Cuba early last month to try to convince Cuban sports authorities to allow Perez to compete, but was turned down. "Faced with the theft of athletes, our position is a legal, just and ethical position," Fernandez said.

Last week, Yueling Chen, a 1992 Olympic champion race-walker for China, was cleared to represent the United States at Sydney. Chinese officials originally refused to give her permission but reversed their decision after a request by the USOC.

fields.headline: Sweatshop v corporation
fields.standfirst:
Only 50% of Americans vote for the president and the protests outside the Democratic convention explain why

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Two images stand out from the protests taking place outside the Democrats' convention in Los Angeles this week. The first was of battalions of riot police, equipped as if for an invasion, standing guard outside the downtown temples of corporate America as demonstrators marched past. The second was of the mainly Latino workers in the Broadway sweatshops leaning out of windows to cheer on the marchers protesting against "corporate greed" and globalisation.
fields.body:
Two images stand out from the protests taking place outside the Democrats' convention in Los Angeles this week. The first was of battalions of riot police, equipped as if for an invasion, standing guard outside the downtown temples of corporate America as demonstrators marched past. The second was of the mainly Latino workers in the Broadway sweatshops leaning out of windows to cheer on the marchers protesting against "corporate greed" and globalisation.

The images symbolise both what is missing from conventional American politics, what divides the haves and have-nots of the world's richest country and what is fuelling the still unspecific but growing international movement that started in Seattle last year and will be seeking another platform in Prague next month.

Only half of the American electorate vote for the president and the events of the past week in LA have partly served to explain why. The financial clout of the corporations now gives the appearance of having permeated every aspect of policy-making so that it is no longer clear to many people whether their elected representatives are acting in the voters' interests or their backers' interests.

Do politicians shy away from real gun reform because of the gun manufacturers' lobby? Do they back a judicial system that jails more than 2m Americans because the prison-industrial complex now carries such weight? Are they helping the Colombian government in a civil war because they want to protect the interests of American oil and because it suits the military-industrial complex? For many politicians the answer may be no, but the suspicion will remain as long as the race is to the richest. The news this week that George W Bush had now raised $100m for his campaign and his running mate, Dick Cheney, had received a corporate pay-off of $20m further emphasised the great gulf between those inside the safe convention walls and those outside on the streets. And it is this gut feeling that the corporations and the international financial bodies are now controlling decisions on wages, the environment or immigration, that has helped to mobilise this still loosely-knit confederation of protest.

What fuels it, too, in the United States, is the feeling that neither of the two main parties offer alternatives on what are to some people the most important issues of the day. One of the angriest demonstrations of the week focused on those on death row and in jail for drugs offences. Both Democrats and Republicans back the death penalty and both support the "war on drugs" that has led to the incarceration of so many. Indeed one of Al Gore's pledges during his acceptance speech was for a further 50,000 police officers. Not a further 50,000 teachers for a country with the illiteracy levels similar to those of many third world countries; not a further 50,000 medical workers for a country where 40m are not entitled to healthcare. No wonder some of the placards outside carried the slogan: "Don't incarcerate, educate".

The ghost at the feast this week has been Ralph Nader, the Green party's candidate and now the repository of the hopes of the liberal left outside the Democratic party. His name was written in the heavens by a sky-writing plane on Wednesday and has been on the lips of many throughout the week. Is a vote for Nader a vote for Bush is the question that will be asked many times between now and November, but increasingly the evidence is that the uncommitted, the independents and the disillusioned Democrats will be heading his way. If these votes do indeed lose Gore the election, the next big question will be whether it leads to a larger, more focused movement and whether the Greens are the party best equipped to lead it.

Al Gore and George W Bush may bask in the warm glow of their respective conventions, but outside the air-conditioned halls it is clear that the old order is no longer trusted by the very people - the young, the poor, the Latinos, the blacks - they are claiming to want to help. Somehow, it seems unlikely that many hands would be waving from sweatshop windows if either of the two presidential parties had ventured down Broadway in their limos this week.

webTitle: Hostages to be freed 'this weekend' - Libyans

fields.headline: Hostages to be freed 'this weekend' - Libyans
fields.trailText: All 28 hostages being held by Muslim rebels on the Philippine island of Jolo would be freed "within the next hour, or by the weekend", Libyan sources reported late last night.
fields.body:
All 28 hostages being held by Muslim rebels on the Philippine island of Jolo would be freed "within the next hour, or by the weekend", Libyan sources reported late last night.

"We confirm that all the hostages will be freed soon, in the next hour or [at latest] at the weekend," said the government spokesman, Hassouna Chaouch. It is the second time this week that their release has been declared imminent.

Mr Chaouch denied reports that Libya had agreed to pay a $25m (£17m) ransom for the release of hostage group, made up of French, Germans, Finns, South Africans, Malaysians and a Filipino.

"Libya did not and would not pay a dinar," he said. "We have confirmation that the operation of freeing the hostages is going well and will be concluded positively soon."

He added, however, that some "technical problems" had arisen because of the mistrust between the Philippine government and the kidnappers.

His comments echoed an earlier statement by a the German diplomat, Cornelius Sommer, who said the hostages could leave for Tripoli early this morning. But Mr Sommer, Germany's Asian affairs adviser, said it was still uncertain whether the Libyan negotiator, Rahab Assurak, would be able to secure the release of all 16 hostages, including nine western tourists kidnapped from a Malaysian diving resort on Sipadan island on April 23.

"It is a nail-biter," he said. "There is hope that they can leave [today]."

He warned, however, that the release of three French television journalists, who were seized in July while covering the hostage crisis, could still pose a problem. But he described the obstacle as one that "could be overcome".

German teacher Werner Wallert and his 25-year-old son, Marc, are among the Europeans expected in Tripoli. Mr Wallert's wife, Renate, 56, was freed a month ago after 12 weeks in captivity.

The Philippines' chief negotiator, Robert Aventajado, said earlier yesterday that four Malaysian and Filipino captives had been released but that the group not yet made its way to freedom.

webTitle: The submarine tragedy: 'No one will tell the truth'

fields.headline: 'No one will tell the truth'
fields.standfirst: Special report: Russia's stricken submarine
fields.trailText: The rough track that stretches 30 miles between the far northern city of Murmansk and the closed military base of Vidyayeva is usually deserted apart from the occasional military vehicle.
fields.body:
The rough track that stretches 30 miles between the far northern city of Murmansk and the closed military base of Vidyayeva is usually deserted apart from the occasional military vehicle.

Yesterday, as the sense of crisis in Russia mounted, a constant stream of cars passed through the Arctic landscape, carrying more relatives of the 118 Kursk sailors to the town where the crew was based, to wait for news.

Documents allowing them to make their way past the checkpoint, a metal gate guarded by half a dozen soldiers on a lonely stretch of the road, had been prepared for them in advance. Only permanent residents and the closest relatives were allowed to enter the military zone.

Several teams of steamrollers and roadworkers had been dispatched to the remote potholed track, where they spent the day labouring to spread fresh tarmac over the worst of the gashes in the road - a clear sign that senior figures from Russia's government were expected at any moment to join the vigil.

Naval workers leaving the base described the atmosphere in Vidyayeva as one of utter desolation. Victor Sakolov, a submarine navigator who lives within the closed confines of the base, said: "People are weeping in public. Everyone is deeply concerned. No one can talk about anything else."

He had several friends on board the submarine, but was particularly concerned for the safety of his next-door neighbour, the Kursk's captain, Gennady Lyachin.

"He is a wonderful man - educated and brave. People just don't come any better than him." He said the captain's 21-year-old son and teenage daughter had arrived to wait with their mother. "No one knows what happened. No one will tell you the truth," he added.

The naval community has learnt to deal with the constant anxiety inevitably associated with the nature of their work by focusing their attention on a series of superstitious rituals.

Submarines must never leave the base on Mondays; whenever a sailor is about to embark on a mission, friends and family part with the words "May there be seven feet under your keel"; and every time a submarine returns to safety, it is traditional for the naval command to celebrate by dispatching a roasted suckling pig to the exhausted crew on board.

Yesterday, however, the prospect of triumphal homecoming arrangements appeared extremely remote. Vidyayeva residents also have special funeral traditions for sailors who die at sea, but no one was ready to describe them. In the face of increasingly bleak information about the accident, most appeared determined to hold on to the hope that the men might still survive.

Pavel, 37, a retired acoustics engineer who spent 11 years on submarines, said: "Everybody knows each other in towns like this. We can only hope that the rescue operation will be successful."

With no clear details about the cause of the disaster, he said the community was rife with speculation. "I think there must have been a collision. In 1989, the submarine I was working on almost collided with an American submarine, at almost exactly the same spot - it was only about 185 metres from us.

"Everyone in the town has a different opinion, but I think that is what must have happened this time. We don't yet know if all the American and British submarines are accounted for. There is no reason to believe that we're getting the truth." He said the men on board would be well trained in how to cope with the consequences of an underwater disaster. "I was in two serious accidents during my submarine career. It's terrifying, but you are given precise drilling in how to respond. These men are all highly professional."

The atmosphere of despondency has stretched to the city of Murmansk, the regional capital, where car radios and cafe television are all tuned to the news.

In the blue-domed church of St Nicholas - the patron saint of sailors - which stands on a hill overlooking the sprawling, grey concrete city, special services have been organised twice a day to pray for the sailors.

Inside the incense-laden building, a red-bearded young priest in a heavily embroidered gold gown sang prayers for the men, as headscarved women knelt to kiss the floor. Outside in the icy drizzle - normal summer weather for the city - Raisa Yermolovka, who was begging on the steps, paused to berate the government for its failure to act more swiftly.

"They should have done something straight away. It's too late now," she said. But, recounting a vision she had in her sleep, she was positive about the fate of the crew. "I was in a dark place underwater. It was cold and it was black, but there were people there and they were alive."

For the first time, a representative from the northern fleet broke the traditional secrecy that surrounds the organisation to hold a press briefing yesterday in an attempt to allay the increasingly vicious Russian media coverage of the catastrophe.

Igor Babenko read a prepared statement that said nothing new. As he came to the end, reporters began shouting questions.

"Why won't anyone tell us the truth?" one demanded. Capt Babenko replied: "I do not have the authority to answer any of your questions."

webTitle: QXL pays less for rival to keep expansion on track

fields.headline: QXL pays less for rival to keep expansion on track
fields.standfirst:
Net news
Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: QXL.com yesterday clawed back from the brink its European expansion plans by confirming that it would, after all, buy German rival Ricardo.de but on different terms.
fields.body:
QXL.com yesterday clawed back from the brink its European expansion plans by confirming that it would, after all, buy German rival Ricardo.de but on different terms.

The UK online auctioneer said it would pay £171m, a reduction of 71% on the originally agreed price of £627m, to reflect an unexpected downturn in revenues and gross auction value at Ricardo.

Analysts had warned that if QXL's deal with Ricardo fell apart it could spell disaster for the company's European growth plans. It would also end its hopes of beating eBay, the US company, and becoming Europe's dominant inter net auction company. Shares in QXL rose to 63p in early trading amid initial relief that the deal would go ahead, but ended the session down 0.5p at 59.75p. Shares in both companies have fallen by some two-thirds since the deal was first announced in May.

Analysts say the merged group will have a lot to prove, not least improving revenues and better gross auction value at Ricardo, which the company warned would be 20% lower in the fourth quarter than it was in the third.

"OK, the price is far lower than previously announced, but with already small revenues down 20% you have to ask what exactly QXL are buying," said one analyst.

QXL insisted that the fall in revenues was temporary, and that Ricardo presented good growth prospects in one of Europe's most important markets. The revised terms of the deal will see QXL give 34 of its shares for each Ricardo share, as opposed to the previously agreed 42.6 shares. Last week QXL said that the deal was being re-examined after new information about Ricardo had come into its possession.

The renegotiation of the merger has cost Ricardo chairman Eckhard Pfeiffer his place on the enlarged board.

QXL said that the former Compaq chief executive and director of General Motors would be replaced by another Ricardo director.
