Analysts had warned that if QXL's deal with Ricardo fell apart it could spell disaster for the company's European growth plans. It would also end its hopes of beating eBay, the US company, and becoming Europe's dominant inter net auction company. Shares in QXL rose to 63p in early trading amid initial relief that the deal would go ahead, but ended the session down 0.5p at 59.75p. Shares in both companies have fallen by some two-thirds since the deal was first announced in May. Analysts say the merged group will have a lot to prove, not least improving revenues and better gross auction value at Ricardo, which the company warned would be 20% lower in the fourth quarter than it was in the third. "OK, the price is far lower than previously announced, but with already small revenues down 20% you have to ask what exactly QXL are buying," said one analyst. QXL insisted that the fall in revenues was temporary, and that Ricardo presented good growth prospects in one of Europe's most important markets. The revised terms of the deal will see QXL give 34 of its shares for each Ricardo share, as opposed to the previously agreed 42.6 shares. Last week QXL said that the deal was being re-examined after new information about Ricardo had come into its possession. The renegotiation of the merger has cost Ricardo chairman Eckhard Pfeiffer his place on the enlarged board. QXL said that the former Compaq chief executive and director of General Motors would be replaced by another Ricardo director.

webTitle: Hopes fade as rescue capsule fails to dock

fields.headline: Hopes fade as rescue capsule fails to dock
fields.standfirst:
Beleaguered Putin admits chances of any survivors slim

Special report: Russia's stricken submarine
fields.trailText: President Vladimir Putin yesterday declared that the chances of any of the Kursk seamen surviving their week-long entrapment on the Arctic seabed were extremely slim as a Russian rescue capsule reached the wrecked submarine's escape hatch after several days of trying.
fields.body:
President Vladimir Putin yesterday declared that the chances of any of the Kursk seamen surviving their week-long entrapment on the Arctic seabed were extremely slim as a Russian rescue capsule reached the wrecked submarine's escape hatch after several days of trying.

The navy said the damage to the sunken submarine was so great that the capsule, while making contact with the escape hatch, was unable to dock despite several attempts and then had to make an emergency ascent after running out of battery power, causing decompression damage to the six men on board.

The failure underlined pessimism that there would be any Russian breakthrough in opening the submarine. There have been no signs of life for days from the 118 submariners trapped inside. Dozens, if not all of them, are assumed dead. They include several senior navy officers not normally on the Kursk, but on board to observe the course of the war games during which the disaster struck last Saturday.

While the Russian capsule was unable to lock on to the escape hatch of the submarine, the British embassy in Moscow said the British LR5 rescue vessel, expected to rendezvous at the accident site later today, was "technically capable of connecting with the escape hatch on the Kursk".

Confronted by a chorus of ferocious criticism for his response to the tragedy, Mr Putin was forced on to the defensive yesterday, delivering only his second statement on the drama.

He said his first desire when he learned of the accident was to head to the Arctic from his holiday residence on the Black Sea, but he then reconsidered and decided he did not want to get in the way of the experts.

"I stopped myself and I think I did the right thing," Mr Putin said at Yalta in the Crimea where he cut short a summit meeting with regional leaders to return to Moscow last night after a week's holiday.

He denied that the navy had been slow to organise a rescue mission or that the government sought to put off accepting offers of western help. Mr Putin said his feelings when he learned of the tragedy were "vividly emotional", not least because he met the 45-year-old commander of the stricken submarine, Captain Gennady Lyachin, last November.

Despite Mr Putin's attempt to claw back his prestige after what has been the worst week of his presidency, the Russian media maintained their assault on the country's political and military leadership. The liberal politician Boris Nemtsov described Mr Putin's response to the tragedy as immoral.

In a devastating blow to the image of the discredited navy chiefs, the tabloid newspaper Komsomolskaya Pravda published the names and ranks of all 118 men on board the Kursk, declaring that it had had to bribe navy officers to the tune of more than £400 to obtain the list.

"We have finally lost all faith in the honour of our commanders," the newspaper commented. It said it had been asking the navy command for the list for days to no avail. The officers had been "hiding the lists of the crew from the country... and on the sly doing a deal on this 'super-secret' information".

The front two compartments of the Kursk were destroyed in the two explosions that sent the submarine to the seabed. The personnel located in these compartments included five senior submarine divisional officers from the northern fleet in addition to Capt Lyachin and the rest of the vessel's senior staff, according to the list.

Mr Putin reinforced the widespread feelings of hopelessness when he made a slip of the tongue in talking about the Arctic drama, strongly suggesting that he knew it was too late for survivors.

He referred to "the events which took place there", before quickly changing that to "which are taking place there".

While the government and the navy talks increasingly of the submarine having collided with another vessel at sea, a Russian television reporter on board a cruiser in the Barents Sea said foreign emergency buoys, coloured differently from Russian buoys, had been spotted at the scene of the disaster before disappearing.

This fed speculation in the Russian media that the Kursk had collided with a foreign vessel.

Navy sources dismissed the buoys report, although several officers have spoken of the possibility of a foreign craft being involved in the accident. There is no known evidence of damage to another vessel.

fields.headline: And we shall see God
fields.standfirst: Special report: religion in the UK
fields.trailText: Why do so many people doubt the truth of Christianity? Could it be because their ideas are circumscribed not by the words of the Bible but by the images they see?
fields.body:
Why do so many people doubt the truth of Christianity? Could it be because their ideas are circumscribed not by the words of the Bible but by the images they see?

In this millennium year, the image of Christ is attracting more than usual attention. However, we do not know what Christ looked like, because the gospels are silent on the subject. So all these images are just that - imaginary objects purporting to represent truth.

It is not just that the image of Christ itself, as portrayed by artists down the centuries, is a fiction, but, more importantly, the actions that are portrayed are also an invention of the artist to try and give visual effect to an idea. This leads to the showing of the resurrection, for example, as Jesus Christ lifting off into the air from his tomb. This we all know to be impossible. In fact, we are not told how the Resurrection took place. We are, in the Bible, merely told that the tomb was empty when the disciples and the women went to visit it.

Certainly, for the modern child, the explanation given by the artists is misleading. When asked to make an Easter card, a 20th-century child, clearly having seen some artistic interpretations, drew Christ ascending to heaven strapped to a booster rocket. The question then arises whether children should be shown these images before they are old enough to consider the metaphysical aspects of Christian doctrine.

The problem is that they will see them - sometimes in their religious education textbooks, and sometimes on the walls of galleries - because it is now part of the national curriculum to introduce children to art from the earliest ages.

To query the validity of the images is also to call into question the faith of many adults, for whom the image has become definitive. Remembering the furore caused by the former Bishop of Durham, David Jenkins, when he talked about "a conjuring trick with bones", it is extremely difficult to raise questions surrounding the correct interpretation of the gospel stories without raising the hackles of those of a fundamentalist persuasion.

It is vital, however, that children, in particular, have these images de-mythologised and placed in their proper contexts so that further misunderstandings do not occur. Nor is it only the more obvious images - such as those of the Resurrection and Ascension - which are misleading.

Take the great painting by Cima de Congeliano, in the National Gallery, of The Incredulity Of St Thomas, and you run straight into trouble. There is the risen Christ, standing in the midst of a group of disciples, with the wound in his side prominently visible, and St Thomas reaching to touch it. The trouble is that Christ looks thoroughly alive. He is a full bodily presence, not substantially different, apart from his state of undress, from the other disciples.

What we do not know - because the gospels do not tell us - is what exactly was Christ's resurrected body. The gospels are ambiguous. It could be that, in fact, he was alive in the fullest and most human sense, and that it was not until the Ascension that his earthly body finally died. This, of course, is not orthodox Christian doctrine, where the creed firmly tells us that Christ died and, on the third day, rose again from the dead. Here again, the artists are giving to the gospels nuances and meanings which were never intended by the writers.

The question of whether or not there should be Christian images is an age-old controversy. Perhaps John Calvin best summed up the predicament when he said that you cannot make images of "that which you cannot see". Using this as a benchmark, almost all Christian images become invalid because they are based totally on the imagination and not on fact - because the doctrines of the Christian church are not facts, but mysteries, and need to be interpreted, not represented literally.

What can be done about this? With children, information and education are important. If the images are explained to the children and put into context, then they can become useful teaching tools, leading to creative discussion of the great Christian doctrines. What must not be allowed to continue is the indiscriminate use of images without explanation, so that children make assumptions, and possibly form opinions, based on the images, which later inhibit them from developing a mature faith.

The solution is for religious education teachers to learn something of art history, and for art teachers to learn something of religious education, so that when these images are shown to children their teachers are in a position to explain them in both their art-historical and religious contexts.

The cry will go up that teachers have no time to acquire such extra knowledge. But this knowledge must be obtained and used in order to clear up the current confusion. Then Christianity can be explained in its truth, and not its imagined truth, so that everyone can have an accurate portrayal of the Christian faith.

Vivien Northcote is an art teacher and author of the book Using Art In RE: Using RE In Art

webTitle: Dogs of war in nudist coup

fields.headline: Dogs of war in nudist coup
fields.trailText: For 50 years, he was France's best-known and most-feared mercenary: a man dubbed  l'Affreux - the terrible - who sowed mayhem across Africa, terminated terrorists in Morocco, ran guns to Biafra and mounted no fewer than four coups in the Comoros Islands.
fields.body:
For 50 years, he was France's best-known and most-feared mercenary: a man dubbed l'Affreux - the terrible - who sowed mayhem across Africa, terminated terrorists in Morocco, ran guns to Biafra and mounted no fewer than four coups in the Comoros Islands.

Now, far from retreating into the anonymity of well-earned retirement, Colonel Bob Denard is back in the thick of the action. It may not be doing his rabble-rousing reputation much good, but the 71-year-old chien de guerre is reportedly running a nudist camp.

"He may not be prancing around with his private parts in the air, but he's involved all right," one unhappy naturist told the daily Libération. "He's thick as thieves with the managing director and half the staff are now ex-special forces soldiers who sit around discussing their favourite wars. It's not good for the atmosphere."

Mr Denard said five years ago, shortly after a failed fourth coup in the Comoros when he and his handful of diehards were finally forced to surrender to a 1,000-strong force of French troops, that he planned to give up his career as a soldier of fortune and invest in the lucrative leisure business in his native south-west France.

He was finally acquitted last year of assassinating the Islands' president, Ahmed Abdallah, after arguing that the 1989 killing was an unfortunate accident caused by a trigger-happy bodyguard.

But he is now reported to have played a shadowy but crucial role in a controversial recent putsch at a Gironde nud ist colony, the Centre Hélio-Marin in Montalivet. His alleged henchmen, who own the centre after building up a controlling stake, are a local businessman, Didier Vacher, and a former special forces operative, Christian Philippo.

Mr Denard's two trusted lieutenants are said to have spent a year undercover as nudists to mount the coup, which was opposed by many of the 16,000 overwhelmingly peaceable naturists who visit the camp each year and who suspect ill-gotten gains may have been used to finance it.

Mr Denard strenuously denies any part in the bloodless overthrow of the original owners. "I'm not involved in any of this crap, honestly," he said. "I live down there, I was born there and since I was a little kid I have gone swimming there. I know the new owners, yes, but I see them only because they want to make a film about me. Can you really imagine me as a nudist?"

Mr Vacher also denied that the celebrated mercenary, who for much of his career was employed at arm's length by the French secret service, was up to his old tricks again. "It wouldn't do an upmarket place like this much good to have a shareholder like that now, would it?" he asked. "Denard is a friend, no more."

But as another disgruntled nudist told Libération: "The whole place has changed. There are lots of new staff, and they all look and behave like ex-soldiers. When they were repairing the winter storm damage, they were comparing it to Dien Ben Phu. I don't think they have much time for wholesome open-air living."

webTitle: Doctors reopen the life or death debate

fields.headline: Doctors reopen the life or death debate
fields.standfirst:
Anaesthetists divided in row over organ removal

Intensive care society
Christian Medical Fellowship
fields.trailText: Death used to mean - and still does for many - the moment when the heart stops and we breathe our last. But for the teenager who arrives in casualty with catastrophic brain damage after a car crash, it may not mean that at all.
fields.body:
Death used to mean - and still does for many - the moment when the heart stops and we breathe our last. But for the teenager who arrives in casualty with catastrophic brain damage after a car crash, it may not mean that at all. Their heart, lungs, liver and pancreas could be used to allow somebody else to live after their death, but the organs can only be removed while the donor's heart is still beating.

In 1976, the conference of medical royal colleges and their faculties set down criteria for establishing what was at first called brain death, and is now more accurately referred to as brainstem death. The tests allowed doctors and families to make the dreadful decision to switch off the ventilator that kept a relative with brain damage breathing and allow them to die. The criteria were generally welcomed as compassionate and sensible. Nobody was more pleased to see them than surgeons working in the burgeoning heart transplant programme.

A further pronouncement in 1979 established that brain death was actual death - the moment of death which used to be recognised by the stopping of the heart. This is now the legal position. It meant that heart transplants, which were taking off in the US and South Africa, could begin in the UK too.

But there are those who feel that in the rush to facilitate a hugely important life-saving medical development, there has been a philosophical and ethical fudge which has put anaesthetists in an awkward dilemma.

While they accept that people who are brainstem dead cannot survive and have no measurable consciousness of the world around them, there is evidence of electrical activity in parts of their disconnected brain - even though they may just be signs of disintegration. And, the monitors show a racing heart beat and soaring blood pressure as the surgeon begins the incision.

It leaves anaesthetists in a quandry. The person before them is legally and effectively dead. But most of them will instinctively want to use not only muscle-relaxant drugs but an anaesthetic. Yet why use an anaesthetic, if the person is dead?

For Philip Keep, consultant anaesthetist at Norfolk and Norwich hospital, the only problem is the one that was caused by the rush to classify brainstem death as death in the sense that we recognise it. He believes there would be no damage to the transplantation programme if it was acknowledged that death in the old-fashioned sense of it had not quite occurred at the time of organ removal.

"I'm very much in favour of transplants," he said. "I see no problem at all in squaring it with the family, saying your relative can't survive and it is absolutely pointless to go on like this - why not let me anaesthetise them and we will take the organs out?" But the royal colleges rushed things, in his view, in their haste to start heart transplants in Britain in the 70s. "They nailed their colours to the mast and said they are dead. I have always argued they are not dead.

"The whole thing needs to be re-thought. It makes no sense at all to throw away organs that are no good to people, but I'm against the economy of truth that we have used to get there."

Few, apart from those with particular religious convictions, argue that brainstem death classification is in any way flawed. Basil Matta and Peter Young, in their editorial in the journal Anaesthesia, remark that "the futility of continuation of artificial support for patients who are clinically brainstem dead is well recognised".

A retrospective study in 1981 of 609 neurological patients with a clinical diagnosis of brainstem death showed that none of them survived.

This group of patients must not be confused with those in a persistent vegetative state, some of whom do recover. PVS patients, like the Hillsborough victim Tony Bland, whose family got a court's permission to stop artificial feeding and let him die, still have activity in the brainstem.

The criteria for brainstem death are strict. First of all, the patient must be in an unresponsive coma and unable to breathe by themselves because of brain damage usually caused by an accident.

Seeking a response

Second, it must be certain that no drugs, hypothermia or other reversible conditions are preventing the patient regaining consciousness. Third, a series of tests to measure any residual response from the brainstem must be carried out on two separate occasions.

The brainstem is the part connecting the main brain (the cerebrum) to the spinal cord. It is the "motorway" for messages between the main brain and the nervous system. It initiates breathing and is responsible for consciousness.

The tests for brainstem death are simple and carried out at the bedside. The ventilator is disconnected for 10 minutes to see whether the body will make any attempt to breathe, although the blood must continue to be oxygenated or the organs will deteriorate. A strong light is shone into the pupils and the cornea is touched to try to make the person blink. Iced water is applied to the ears, a catheter put down the windpipe and painful pressure applied to the eyesocket. If none of these things get a response on the second occasion, the person is certified brainstem dead. If there is no brainstem activity, the UK criteria say, then the rest of the brain cannot function.

But other tests are carried out in the US and some countries in Europe, including electroencephalography (EEG), which measures electrical activity in the brain, and dyes injected into the major vessels to demonstrate that no blood is circulating to the brain. Brainstem death is not enough in the US. A president's commission requires the "irreversible cessation of all functions of the entire brain, including the brainstem".

Random electricity

Giles Morgan, president of the Intensive Care Society which published guidelines saying anaesthetics are not required for brainstem-dead patients, acknowledges that some electrical activity can be perceived in parts of the brain even when the brainstem is dead. "It is disorganised random electricity. The whole brain is functionally disintegrating," he said.

David Wainwright Evans, a former consultant cardiologist at Papworth hospital who retired early because his personal convictions led him to oppose the removal of organs from people who are brainstem dead, argues that the wording on the donor card should be changed.

"It says you can have my organs after my death," he said. "It may be that the other party has a totally different idea as to what that death means. Because the protocol has been completed, you are dead, but it is not the same as the death you signed up to."

But others say that rather than enter into philosophical arguments about what death is and when exactly it takes place - given that there is general agreement that it is imminent - there is a simpler solution: to trust the public not to over-react against the transplant programme, and to give an anaesthetic in every case.

"I don't carry a donor card at the moment because I know what happens," said Dr Keep. "If I knew I was going to be anaesthetised, I certainly would."

But there are those who feel that in the rush to facilitate a hugely important life-saving medical development, there has been a philosophical and ethical fudge which has put anaesthetists in an awkward dilemma. While they accept that people who are brainstem dead cannot survive and have no measurable consciousness of the world around them, there is evidence of electrical activity in parts of their disconnected brain - even though they may just be signs of disintegration. And, the monitors show a racing heart beat and soaring blood pressure as the surgeon begins the incision. It leaves anaesthetists in a quandry. The person before them is legally and effectively dead. But most of them will instinctively want to use not only muscle-relaxant drugs but an anaesthetic. Yet why use an anaesthetic, if the person is dead? For Philip Keep, consultant anaesthetist at Norfolk and Norwich hospital, the only problem is the one that was caused by the rush to classify brainstem death as death in the sense that we recognise it. He believes there would be no damage to the transplantation programme if it was acknowledged that death in the old-fashioned sense of it had not quite occurred at the time of organ removal. "I'm very much in favour of transplants," he said. "I see no problem at all in squaring it with the family, saying your relative can't survive and it is absolutely pointless to go on like this - why not let me anaesthetise them and we will take the organs out?" But the royal colleges rushed things, in his view, in their haste to start heart transplants in Britain in the 70s. "They nailed their colours to the mast and said they are dead. I have always argued they are not dead. "The whole thing needs to be re-thought. It makes no sense at all to throw away organs that are no good to people, but I'm against the economy of truth that we have used to get there." Few, apart from those with particular religious convictions, argue that brainstem death classification is in any way flawed. Basil Matta and Peter Young, in their editorial in the journal Anaesthesia, remark that "the futility of continuation of artificial support for patients who are clinically brainstem dead is well recognised". A retrospective study in 1981 of 609 neurological patients with a clinical diagnosis of brainstem death showed that none of them survived. This group of patients must not be confused with those in a persistent vegetative state, some of whom do recover. PVS patients, like the Hillsborough victim Tony Bland, whose family got a court's permission to stop artificial feeding and let him die, still have activity in the brainstem. The criteria for brainstem death are strict. First of all, the patient must be in an unresponsive coma and unable to breathe by themselves because of brain damage usually caused by an accident. Seeking a response Second, it must be certain that no drugs, hypothermia or other reversible conditions are preventing the patient regaining consciousness. Third, a series of tests to measure any residual response from the brainstem must be carried out on two separate occasions. The brainstem is the part connecting the main brain (the cerebrum) to the spinal cord. It is the "motorway" for messages between the main brain and the nervous system. It initiates breathing and is responsible for consciousness. The tests for brainstem death are simple and carried out at the bedside. The ventilator is disconnected for 10 minutes to see whether the body will make any attempt to breathe, although the blood must continue to be oxygenated or the organs will deteriorate. A strong light is shone into the pupils and the cornea is touched to try to make the person blink. Iced water is applied to the ears, a catheter put down the windpipe and painful pressure applied to the eyesocket. If none of these things get a response on the second occasion, the person is certified brainstem dead. If there is no brainstem activity, the UK criteria say, then the rest of the brain cannot function. But other tests are carried out in the US and some countries in Europe, including electroencephalography (EEG), which measures electrical activity in the brain, and dyes injected into the major vessels to demonstrate that no blood is circulating to the brain. Brainstem death is not enough in the US. A president's commission requires the "irreversible cessation of all functions of the entire brain, including the brainstem". Random electricity Giles Morgan, president of the Intensive Care Society which published guidelines saying anaesthetics are not required for brainstem-dead patients, acknowledges that some electrical activity can be perceived in parts of the brain even when the brainstem is dead. "It is disorganised random electricity. The whole brain is functionally disintegrating," he said. David Wainwright Evans, a former consultant cardiologist at Papworth hospital who retired early because his personal convictions led him to oppose the removal of organs from people who are brainstem dead, argues that the wording on the donor card should be changed. "It says you can have my organs after my death," he said. "It may be that the other party has a totally different idea as to what that death means. Because the protocol has been completed, you are dead, but it is not the same as the death you signed up to." But others say that rather than enter into philosophical arguments about what death is and when exactly it takes place - given that there is general agreement that it is imminent - there is a simpler solution: to trust the public not to over-react against the transplant programme, and to give an anaesthetic in every case. "I don't carry a donor card at the moment because I know what happens," said Dr Keep. "If I knew I was going to be anaesthetised, I certainly would."

fields.headline: Transplant row over pain rule
fields.standfirst:
Doctors call for anaesthetics for brainstem-dead donors

Intensive care society
Christian Medical Fellowship
fields.trailText: Leading anaesthetists are calling for every patient about to have their organs removed for transplantation to be given an anaesthetic to ensure there is no possibility of awareness or pain.
fields.body:
Leading anaesthetists are calling for every patient about to have their organs removed for transplantation to be given an anaesthetic to ensure there is no possibility of awareness or pain.

More than 20 years after the definition of "brain death" was established in Britain, enabling heart transplants to take place, a controversy that has been simmering in operating theatres round the country has broken into the public arena.

The issue of whether pain might be experienced by a patient certified brainstem dead whose heart is still beating during surgery to remove donated organs, has long been controversial among anaesthetists, but feelings have become inflamed since the publication of guidelines from the Intensive Care Society last year stating that analgesia is not necessary.

An editorial in Anaesthesia, the journal of the Royal College of Anaesthetists, has now called for an anaesthetic to be given routinely during operations to remove the heart, lung, liver and pancreas - all of which take place while the patient is on a ventilator.

Although they have been reluctant to speak publicly for fear of damaging the transplantation programme, which is desperately short of life-saving donated organs, many anaesthetists confess to lingering doubts as to what might still be happening in the brain of the donor, even though his or her brainstem shows no response to tests and there is no question of survival - even on a life-support machine - for more than a few days.

"Almost everyone will say they have felt uneasy about it," said Philip Keep, a consultant anaesthetist at the Norfolk and Norwich hospital. "Nurses get really, really upset. You stick the knife in and the pulse and blood pressure shoot up. If you don't give anything at all, the patient will start moving and wriggling around and it's impossible to do the operation. The surgeon has always asked us to paralyse the patient."

The accepted wisdom since criteria for establishing brainstem death were laid down in 1976 and 1979 by the medical royal colleges is that these responses are unconnected with the brain. They are the same kind of reaction that is caused when a hammer hits a knee, or a hand accidentally touches a hot stove.

But while most anaesthetists accept that the patient is in an unsurvivable coma and has no consciousness, the majority prefer to give an anaesthetic as well as the necessary muscle-paralysing drugs.

Basil Matta and Peter Young of the critical care unit at Addenbrooke's hospital in Cambridge say in their editorial in Anaesthesia that some feel uncomfortable with the Intensive Care Society's guidance. It does not feel right to an anaesthetist to give a paralysing drug without an anaesthetic, they write. Second, the soaring blood pressure and heart rate "can be distressing for operating theatre personnel to witness".

"This haemodynamic response [increased blood pressure and heart rate] could be considered to represent an organism in distress and probably occurs at spinal level, although we are unaware of EEG studies [monitoring the brain's electrical activity] during organ collection to confirm this," they say.

"Third, death is not an event but a process and our limited understanding of the process should demand caution before assuming that anaesthesia is not required."

Dr Matta and Dr Young point out that a few scientific studies have shown that some activity persists in brain cells even though the brainstem - which connects to the spine and is responsible for consciousness - is unresponsive. They urge that sedation and analgesia be given in every case.

"It is imperative that public confidence is maintained in the transplant programme. The act of organ donation is a final altruistic one and we should ensure the provision of general anaesthesia at least sufficient to prevent the haemodynamic response to surgery," they write.

Michael Harmer, editor of the journal and a professor at the University of Wales college of medicine, said the issue has sparked more controversy and more letters than anything in the past. "It is a debate that is ongoing and likely to continue.

"While everybody is very confident that the current brainstem death tests mean it is impossible to survive without artificial support, what we don't know for certain is what happens at the higher centres.

"We don't want to alarm people. I don't think there is a problem. We don't think there are patients who know what is happening to them, but the problem is, if one does see some activity on a monitor, what does it mean? It is impossible to know. This group of patients does not survive."

Giles Morgan, president of the Intensive Care Society, which represents doctors - 85% of them anaesthetists - working in ICUs, is the author of the guidance that appeared last June. "Brainstem dead patients do not require analgesia or sedation" during surgery to remove their organs, it said.

"In simple terms, if you are dead, you are dead and so dead people don't require anaesthesia," he said. "That is a fact. If you aren't dead, you shouldn't be having your organs taken away."

But he acknowledged that the issue is contentious.

Electrical activity can be perceived in some parts of the brain even when the brainstem is dead, he acknowledged. "It is disorganised random electricity. The whole brain is functionally disintegrating." Death, he said, in a phrase used by every anaesthetist questioned, is not an event but a process, which Dr Morgan described as "a process of cellular disintegration". He compared the brainstem to the fuse box of a house. Without it, nothing functions.

Even so, he said, he would not preclude the possibility that one small light bulb some where would flicker. "Nobody knows what it is like to be dead. We can't tell, so we are giving it our best shot." An anaesthetist and intensive care specialist in Truro, Cornwall, Dr Morgan does give his patients an anaesthetic.

"Why do I do it?" he said. "Because I'm a human being and it does make us feel a little more comfortable. It is a very traumatic thing.

"We reassure everybody that the donor will not be at risk of perceiving anything and is dead. And they are - or we wouldn't be doing anything. But we all worry about it and I think it is healthy that we do."

Transplants in the UK and US

Brainstem death is a definition accepted in the UK and former Commonwealth countries, but not in the US or most of Europe, which require tests to ensure the whole brain is inactive. The president's commission in the US ruled that there must be 'irreversible cessation of all functions of the entire brain, including the brainstem'. There are debates in Canada and Australia as to whether to switch from brainstem to whole brain criteria for death

There were 5,433 people on the waiting list for a solid organ transplant (heart, liver, lung, kidney, etc) on December 31. Last year 2,516 transplants took place, of which 105 were hearts, 21 heart and lung and 47 lung only.

There has been a 9% increase in new donors but the number of new transplants has only gone up by 4%. UK Transplant, which matches donor organs to recipients on the waiting list, says the increase is mostly in older donors, who can provide kidneys but often do not have useable hearts, lungs and livers - the organs that need to be removed in 'beating heart' operations. Largely due to the greater use of seat belts, the number of younger people dying and donating organs has dropped.

fields.headline: Key Bloody Sunday witness found
fields.standfirst:
Former para to testify against ex-colleagues in return for security deal

Special report: the Bloody Sunday inquiry
fields.trailText: A former soldier who has claimed that his colleagues in the Parachute Regiment deliberately shot innocent civilians on Bloody Sunday in Londonderry in 1972 has agreed to give evidence to the Saville inquiry
fields.body:
A former soldier who has claimed that his colleagues in the Parachute Regiment deliberately shot innocent civilians on Bloody Sunday in Londonderry in 1972 has agreed to give evidence to the Saville inquiry in exchange for a personal security package from the Northern Ireland Office worth £44,000. It includes insurance cover in the event of his death.

The evidence of Soldier 027, who says his written evidence to the original Widgery inquiry in 1972 was fabricated by government lawyers, was a key factor in persuading the prime minister to set up the Saville inquiry in 1998.

The Irish government has summarised his account as "grim and, at points, grisly" with the paratroopers being briefed by a lieutenant the day before the Bloody Sunday confrontation to "get some kills". Some of those shot had their arms in the air, he says.

If his evidence is accepted it will decisively overturn the conclusions of Widgery, who exonerated the army from serious wrongdoing, and would support the allegations from the nationalist community of murder.

At hearings in Londonderry in November it will be decided how and where he will take the witness stand.

It has taken 25 years for his story to emerge. After leaving the army in 1974 he wrote a full account of the events in the city where 13 unarmed civilians on a civil rights march were shot dead by members of the 1st Battalion, the Parachute Regiment.

In 1997 this was handed to a Northern Ireland journalist who published extracts in the Sunday Business Post. Copies were sent by the journalist to the Irish government which included the material in its representations for a new inquiry to the prime minister, Tony Blair.

Dublin summarised the most serious allegations in this way:

"The contents of the transcripts are grim and, at points, grisly. They allege that members of 027's unit engaged in the robbery, beatings ("beastings"), torture, mutilation and murder of civilians in North ern Ireland.

"On Bloody Sunday they allege that the anti-tank platoon of support company had, on the previous day, been encouraged by its lieutenant to get some "kills", that they had their own supply of ammunition, that they used dum-dum bullets on the day, that paras deliberately shot at unarmed civilians in Rossville Street, that named members of the anti-tank platoon entered Glenfada Park and that 027 witnessed some of them unlawfully kill four demonstrably unarmed civilians there, including at least one who was already wounded, that soldiers lied to the Widgery tribunal and that members of the tribunal altered 027's statement so that it 'bore no relation to fact and I was told with a smile that this is the statement I would use when going on the stand'. "

In the event 027 was not called and he disappeared. In April 1998 his solicitors contacted the Saville inquiry saying that he was willing to give evidence but was concerned about his safety. His lawyers were asked what protection he wanted but he replied that the tribunal should make him a proposal.

For several months the Saville team tried to find him. A private detective was hired. Summonses were served on various ultility companies and other organisations in an attempt to find his address.

It became apparent that he had moved several times. Negotiations were then set up between the NOI and his lawyers to draw up a security package. It was signed on July 6 this year.

It provides for a payment of £1,400 a month in lieu of earnings for up to a year; payment of £100 a month for life insurance for a year; £6,000 for a car; a loan of £20,000 towards buying a house or flat which will not have to repaid if he fully cooperates.

Sinn Fein vice-president Pat Doherty said: "If this is an aid to establishing the truth then it is moving in the right direction, but the soldier in question must feel under grave strain from the establishment to seek such protection."

webTitle: East Timor massacres may go unpunished

fields.headline: East Timor massacres may go unpunished
fields.standfirst: Special report: Indonesia and East Timor
fields.trailText: Indonesia's disgraced army could be granted an amnesty for human rights abuses in East Timor after a last-minute amendment to the country's constitution.
fields.byline: Jon Aglionby in Dili, East Timor
fields.body:
Indonesia's disgraced army could be granted an amnesty for human rights abuses in East Timor after a last-minute amendment to the country's constitution.

The amendment appeared to contradict President Abdurrahman Wahid's assurances to the UN that Indonesia would conduct its own investigation into massacres in East Timor, and that an international war crimes tribunal was not necessary.

The controversial change was introduced on the final afternoon of the annual session of the country's supreme legislative body, the people's consultative assembly (MPR). Some legislators tried to reassure critics that it would exclude major human rights abuses.

The MPR also voted unanimously to allow the military to retain its formal role in government for a further five years after the next election, taking it to 2009.

Analysts said the moves indicated a reluctance to offend the armed forces, which are still powerful. There has been speculation that the army might stage a coup if it were forced from the political scene.

Indonesia's constitution will now say that military personnel cannot be prosecuted for crimes committed before the enactment of the legislation used to prosecute them. A decree to enable Indonesia to investigate the atrocities was cancelled in February, even though a law aimed at creating a special court to deal with past human rights violations by the security forces had yet to be enacted.

The constitutional amendment could affect the investigation of military abuses all over the archipelago, from Aceh to West Papua, but will have most immediate relevance to events in East Timor.

Hundreds of East Timorese were murdered by Indonesia's military-backed militias before and after the territory voted for independence last year, and hundreds of thousands more were forcibly evacuated to neighbouring West Timor. Soldiers and militiamen destroyed tens of thousands of buildings.

Political analyst Kusnanto Anggoro said of the amendment: "This shows that the military is still a powerful force to be reckoned with."

But a senior MPR legislator, Jacob Tobing, indicated that it might still be possible to prosecute the dozen generals allegedly responsible for the East Timor abuses. He said that the amendment would probably not apply to "special crimes" such as genocide, war crimes and terrorism.

One western diplomat said: "It is all very vague. What is more worrying is that the investigation is proceeding without any formal legal basis so the defence lawyers will be able to announce a very strong case to have any charges thrown out."

In East Timor, the vast majority of people say those responsible must be tried. What's more, they say the trials should take place in an international tribunal because they do not have confidence in Indonesia's notoriously corrupt legal system.

"The location of the tribunal is not important as long as it's not in Indonesia or under Indonesian law," said Aniceto Lopes of the East Timor Human Rights Foundation.

A UN spokeswoman said yesterday that the MPR decision would have to be studied more closely before she would comment on whether the international community would now push for an international tribunal.

Many UN sources in East Timor say that the international community has little appetite for organising prosecutions because they would be extremely expensive and would risk further destabilising Indonesia.

This sentiment is reflected in a UN proposal to cut by almost half the number of international investigators looking into last year's atrocities.

Senior UN officials and East Timorese political leaders such as Jose "Xanana" Gusmao are also advocating reconciliation rather than justice.

But their calls are mostly falling on deaf ears. "We endured 25 years of hell under Indonesian occupation," said Augusto da Silva, a farmer. "Not only do we want justice, but we need justice in order to put the past behind us and move on."

Senior UN officials and East Timorese political leaders such as Jose "Xanana" Gusmao are also advocating reconciliation rather than justice. But their calls are mostly falling on deaf ears. "We endured 25 years of hell under Indonesian occupation," said Augusto da Silva, a farmer. "Not only do we want justice, but we need justice in order to put the past behind us and move on."

fields.headline: Bookham's breathtaking £10bn
fields.trailText: Optical chip specialist Bookham Technology topped the FTSE 100 performance table yesterday enlivened by fresh takeover speculation.
fields.body:
Optical chip specialist Bookham Technology topped the FTSE 100 performance table yesterday enlivened by fresh takeover speculation.

Canadian group Nortel Networks was the name in the frame, with dealers mentioning an £85-a-share takeout price that would value the Oxford company at a breathtaking £10bn.

Analysts did not dismiss the speculation but noted that turnover was lowish and it was silly season for takeover stories. Dealers, meanwhile, said the shares were due a bounce and that chip stocks were also strong in the US.

Nortel, which accounts for more than half of Bookham's revenues, would want Bookham for its technology that makes it easier to manufacture the optical chips used in fibre optic networks.

Nortel has been active in snapping up companies with proprietary technology for its own use. It has acquired a number that, like Bookham, are low on revenue but high on potential. It acquired two optical switching operations - Qtera and Xros - that had no sales at all.

Bookham shares ended 640p higher at £39.60.

A late spurt saw the FTSE 100 index end 25.5 points better at 6,543.7 - its highest close in 11 weeks - thanks to continued strength in BP, up 5p at 629.5p, and good performances from HSBC, 8.5p higher at 946, and British Telecom.

BT finished 25p stronger at 837p, lifted by positive comment on Thursday's deal to take control of German telecoms group Viag Interkom. Its shares did touch 844p early in the session after a report that claimed BT had discussed the prospect of a formal merger with US joint venture partner AT&T.

But City analysts were concentrating on fundamentals. Most reckon the stock is incredibly cheap and Viag represents a transformational step for BT. Even the debt implications of the Viag deal, which sent BT shares to a 20-month low on Thursday, were played down. According to Mike Williams at Deutsche Bank, the deal will not crystallise until the first half of next year, allowing BT to defer the cash outflow in the meantime initiating disposals and spin-offs.

On the flip side, Vodafone eased 2p to 268p, despite upbeat recommendations from City analysts. With the end of the German third generation mobile phone licence auction, they reckon investors will start to look once more at the mobile data opportunity.

Allied Domecq fell 1.25p to 325p amid concern that it will lose out in the battle for control of the world's third largest wines and spirits business.

These fears intensified yesterday, as it rival, Diageo, off 11p to 600p, announced its intention to bid for the wines and spirits division of Canadian group Seagram with French group Pernod Ricard. According to analysts, Allied Domecq must acquire the Seagram business if it is to compete with Diageo on a global scale.

Royal Bank of Scotland declined 21p to £13.34 hit by a flurry of profit taking. Securities house Commerzbank spoke for many when it said the 30% appreciation in Royal Bank's share price since interim results earlier this month had been overdone. Commerzbank has lowered its rating on the stock to "hold".

The FTSE 250 finished 33.6 points stronger at 6,913.2 - a closing high. Internet auction house QXL.com was 0.75p higher at 59.75p, the market unimpressed with the revised terms of the Ricardo.de acquisition.

Among smaller companies, brewer Wolverhampton & Dudley lost 25.5p to 457p after it rejected an offer from venture capital outfit Botts & Company. W&D feels the offer undervalues the company.

Elsewhere, engineering group L. Gardner slid 43p to 185p as it warned on profits. A similar problem was behind the decline in Character Group, which moved 15p lower to 61.5p.

fields.headline: At this price?  Glaxo-Cantab
fields.trailText: Relationships involving genital herpes are often tricky. It was therefore hardly surprising when Glaxo Wellcome and Cantab Pharmaceuticals revealed yesterday that they were scaling down their collaboration on the disease.
fields.body:
Relationships involving genital herpes are often tricky. It was therefore hardly surprising when Glaxo Wellcome and Cantab Pharmaceuticals revealed yesterday that they were scaling down their collaboration on the disease. They have been co-developing two products for herpes - one to prevent infection and the other to treat it.

Regulators have ordered Glaxo Wellcome to end its involvement in the preventative vaccine. After its merger with SmithKline Beecham, the pharmaceuticals group will have too many products in the area - Zovirax and Famvir, to name just two.

This sent Cantab Pharmaceuticals' shares tumbling 25p to 313.5p, which appears to be an overreaction. The herpes vaccine is merely the third product in Cantab Pharmaceuticals' portfolio, after products for genital warts and cervical cancer.

Glaxo Wellcome had agreed to fund phase three trials of the vaccine, which will cost several million pounds. In breaking the agreement, it will have to make a fairly big compensation payment.

It was always the case that Cantab Pharmaceuticals would retain the intellectual property rights for the product so the break-up should not be too complicated.

The wild card question is how the setback will affect Cantab Pharmaceuticals' ongoing merger negotiations with another Cambridge-based vaccine specialist, Peptide Therapeutics.

Discussions have been under way for several months, and an agreement had been expected imminently.

Yesterday's setback is unlikely to be a deal-breaker. Cantab Pharmaceuticals remains the stronger partner in the merger. Peptide has had several setbacks on key products, and its shareholders are anxious to see it pool its research line with a rival.

At £139m, Cantab Pharmaceuticals' valuation appears relatively modest. All biotech shares are risky, but yesterday's fall is a buying opportunity for investors seeking a modest wager.

fields.headline: Brewer rejects £470m bid offer
fields.trailText: Wolverhampton & Dudley Breweries has knocked back a £470m takeover proposal from the venture capital group Botts & Co, complaining that the offer lacks firm backing.
fields.body:
Wolverhampton & Dudley Breweries has knocked back a £470m takeover proposal from the venture capital group Botts & Co, complaining that the offer lacks firm backing.

After a preliminary meeting with Botts on Wednesday, Wolves issued a statement yesterday saying it had received an "indicative proposal which was highly conditional". The brewer said the offer undervalued its business and was "too uncertain" to pursue.

Sources close to the talks said the two sides were caught in a catch-22 situation - Botts was unable to secure commitment from its backers without carrying out detailed due diligence, while Wolves was not prepared to open up its books unless it received a firm bid.

It is understood that the offer was for 500p a share in cash, with the possibility of more if Wolves' finances proved better than expected. Wolves' shares fell 31.5p to 451p.

Botts has provisional backing from institutions including the US bank Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. It wants permission to talk to executives at Wolves' various businesses to establish monthly cashflow, barrelage and detailed revenue figures.

The future of discussions was in the balance last night. Botts is reluctant to table a hostile bid, partly because it wants to retain some of Wolves' senior executives. Industry experts believe Botts is hoping that Wolves' shareholders put pressure on the brewing group's directors to resume negotiations.

There has been speculation that Wolves' board is considering a management buyout. Directors could, however, struggle to secure financial backing for such a major undertaking - the business has debts of more than £600m.

But Tom Shrager, a director of Tweedy, Browne - a 6.13% shareholder in Wolves - expressed support for the bid. "I think the price is not bad, they should consider the offer," he told Reuters news agency.

Wolves & Dudley is Britain's biggest regional beer company, with three breweries and more than 1,700 pubs, including the Pitcher & Piano chain.

webTitle: Entrepreneur cleaned up on a smart idea

fields.headline: Entrepreneur cleaned up on a smart idea
fields.standfirst: Brand values Hoover
fields.trailText: History is often kinder to those who use inventions than to those who create them. People tend to talk, for example, about hoovering their rooms rather than "spanglering" them.
fields.body:
History is often kinder to those who use inventions than to those who create them. People tend to talk, for example, about hoovering their rooms rather than "spanglering" them.

The inventor of the first practical upright electric vacuum cleaner was not one William Hoover, though. It was James Murray Spangler, a department store cleaner in Canton, Ohio.

Spangler did not have the funds to turn his invention into a commercial product, so he sold his idea to Hoover, a leather goods manufacturer who made it a commercial success. Hoover, rather than Spangler, was given credit for one of the most useful domestic appliances, and it is his name which has became part of everyday English - to the despair of the lawyers charged with protecting the Hoover trademark.

The general public, little concerned with trademark issues, happily uses hoover as a generic term for an electric vacuum cleaner or its use. In retrospect we have been lucky. Somehow "to spangler" the house gives the impression of creating overwhelming chaos rather than cleaning carpets.

Not even Spangler was the inventor of the vacuum cleaner. They had been around for some years before he came up with his electric model. Non-electric cleaners had been on sale since the latter half of the 19th century, and a couple of San Francisco inventors claim to have invented the first portable electric vacuum cleaner in 1905.

Early vacuum cleaners were cumbersome affairs. Civil engineer Herbert Cecil Bothe made a petrol-powered machine in 1901 which was so big that it had to be left outside houses and so noisy that it frightened horses. Bothe, whose machine was used to clean the carpet in Westminster Abbey before Edward VII's coronation, later made smaller cleaners under the Goblin trade name.

Driving force

People using some early vacuum cleaners in the United States had to turn a handle to create the vacuum with one hand and steer the machine with the other.

Spangler's achievement in 1908 was to design a vacuum cleaner using a small and relatively light electric motor to create the vacuum and rotate the brushes. His original upright model was made of wood and tin, with a cloth bag as a filter. The driving force behind his invention had been the need to replace the broom and carpet sweeper that he used every day. They tended to stir up the dust, exacerbating his asthma.

Hoover started making vacuum clean ers based on Spangler's design in a room at his saddle and leather goods business.

The new gadget, weighing about 40lbs, proved popular because it was much lighter than its rivals, some of which weighted up to 100lbs.

It could not have come at a better time for Hoover. Horses were rapidly being replaced with motor cars, and the market for his leather goods was declining.

Soon the Hoover factory was concentrating on the new household appliance. Its designers came up with the idea of gently beating the carpet to dislodge dirt, allowing the company to market its products for years under the slogan: "It beats as it sweeps as it cleans".

By 1919, Hoover had abandoned the leather goods business and renamed his firm The Hoover Suction Sweeper Company. Three years later, it became just the Hoover Company.

For nearly 70 years Hoover and its rivals produced similar upright vacuum cleaners, adding features such as lights or variable suction levels. They diversified into other domestic appliances, with Hoover making washing machines, dishwashers, refrigerators and floor polishers.

The arrival of James Dyson's bagless vacuum cleaner in the early 1990s changed the dynamics and technology of the industry. Dyson's company and Hoover recently went to court in Britain in a battle over technology rights.

Surefire winner

Hoover tried to counter the success of the revolutionary Dyson cleaner with a marketing campaign offering two free flights to the United States for every £100 spent on one of its products. It seemed a surefire winner to the marketing department in Merthyr Tydfil, where it was dreamed up. It seemed to have the desired effect. Up to 200,000 Hoovers were bought.

Then Hoover was faced with a flood of demands for the free flights.

Canny consumers had bought Hoovers they did not want just to get hold of the bargain tickets. Free advertisement papers were swamped with offers of Hoovers at knockdown prices.

Hoover turned to the small print but found no way out. Angry customers campaigned publicly for their right to free flights. In the end the promotion generated £30m in extra sales - largely of £119 models. But the company had to spend £50m on airline tickets.

The fiasco resulted in management changes and the European business was sold in 1995 to Candy, a privately owned Italian domestic appliance group.

Today there are two Hoover companies, each producing their own models. The Hoover Company is part of Maytag, an American domestic appliance group which started out making wooden tub washing machines in 1907. It designs and makes Hoover vacuum cleaners and floor polishers predominantly for the north American market.

Hoover European Appliance Group designs and makes a much wider range of goods, including vacuum cleaners, washing machines and dishwashers, and serves the European market.

The success of the Hoover and its rivals is often credited to its ability to take much of the drudgery out of housework. But sales in Britain during the early part of the 20th century got an unexpected boost from the shortage of servants after the first world war.

The fax a

dded value Hoover's famous slogan, "It beats as it sweeps as it cleans", was introduced in 1926, when a way to beat carpets to dislodge dirt was added to the vacuum cleaners' existing sweeping and vacuuming functions

Fifties' icon the Hoover logo - a red roundel carrying the company's name - first appeared in an advertisement in Life magazine, in February 1950

Recycled the company's first British factory, an Art Deco building, opened in Perivale, London, in 1932. The listed building has now been converted into a Tesco superstore

Time management an upright cleaner comes off Hoover's European production lines every 11 seconds, and a cylinder cleaner every nine seconds

webTitle: Severn Trent issues writ over Hyder bid

fields.headline: Severn Trent issues writ over Hyder bid
fields.trailText: Severn Trent yesterday intervened in Western Power Distribution's ill-starred bid for Hyder, the owner of Welsh Water and South Wales Electricity.
fields.body:
Severn Trent yesterday intervened in Western Power Distribution's ill-starred bid for Hyder, the owner of Welsh Water and South Wales Electricity.

The Midlands utility group issued a writ challenging WPD's plan to bring in United Utilities to manage the regulated Welsh Water operation.

The Midlands group is seeking to force the Welsh Water directors to put the contract out to tender. It is arguing that the Welsh company is required to do so under European and UK procurement regulations.

US-owned WPD, an energy business with electricity operations in Devon and Cornwall, turned to United Utilities - the owner of North West Water - because it needed a partner with industry experience.

Brian Duckworth, the managing director of Severn Trent Water, said: "We are not trying to frustrate WPD's bid for Hyder, but we believe that this is a piece of procurement which should have gone out to competitive tender."

Severn Trent's thinking is in line with that of Sir Ian Byatt, the former industry regulator. Before he stepped down last month, Sir Ian said there should be open competition for such contracts, which should not be the subject of cosy deals.

Industry sources estimate the Welsh Water contract could be worth about £1bn over seven years.

Mr Duckworth said that Severn Trent had the capability to take on the contract. Severn Trent first objected to the plan in June when the regulator was seeking views on the WPD bid plan. It has been in direct contact with Welsh Water during the past week.

WPD said it did not expect the Severn move to derail its bid. A spokesman said: "It would seem they are behind the game. Our bid has been cleared by the authorities."

On Thursday WPD's rival, Nomura, withdrew from the four-month contest after the takeover panel rejected its appeal that the WPD bid was invalid because it had not been announced by 4.30pm on Friday - the deadline set by the panel's executive under a sealed bid procedure to end the bidding war.

The panel said yesterday that WPD had met the deadline but had been forced to redraft the announcement of its winning bid in the light of new arrangements made with United Utilities.

The new terms had to be approved by Hyder's advisers, with the result it was not ready until 4.52pm. The panel said that its code had to take account of underlying purpose and that legitimate expectations should not be frustrated by "a technical application" of the code or bid procedure.

webTitle: Four years for 'dishonest fool' in £30m fraud

fields.headline: Four years for 'dishonest fool' in £30m fraud
fields.standfirst: Passion for racehorses and gambling led to 15-year life of crime
fields.trailText: A commodities dealer with a passion for race horses and gambling was sentenced yesterday to almost four years in prison for long-term fraud that cost one of Britain's wealthiest families up to £30m.
fields.body:
A commodities dealer with a passion for race horses and gambling was sentenced yesterday to almost four years in prison for long-term fraud that cost one of Britain's wealthiest families up to £30m.

Allan Leonard, 50, of Chislehurst, Kent, was sentenced to three years and nine months at the Old Bailey after admitting 15 separate counts of fraud and a further 257 counts of false accounting over a 15-year period at derivatives firm Muirpace.

He was also banned from serving as a company director for seven years.

The company was owned by the Thompson family, founders of the Hillsdown Holdings combine. They lost £28.5m, while a private investment company Kris Fund III lost a further £4m.

Despite strong denials from Mr Leonard's defence team that his motive was personal gain or that he still owned several racehorses in France, the Serious Fraud Office said it would continue to try to establish where all the money went.

"Enquiries into the possibility of personal benefit continue to be made," the SFO said in a statement.

The judge, Common Serjeant of London Neil Denison, described Mr Leonard's crime as "fraud on a massive scale". But he took into account Mr Leonard's remorse and co-operation with the SFO by giving the former trader the minimum possible sentence.

Oxford educated Mr Leonard was described by his counsel William Boyce as "a dishonest fool".

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.body:
Steel float held up three years ThyssenKrupp will not float its steel operations for at least three years, according to reports yesterday. The German company has had no talks with other companies over a sale of the steel business and that a sale to Usinor - long cited as a potential bidder - has not been considered, the Berliner Zeitung paper said. ThyssenKrupp cancelled the flotation of its steel operations on Wednesday, due to to the low valuation of the steel market. The company's bankers had feared that the business would only have been valued at 3bn German marks (£94m). Sanyo licenses from Symbian

Symbian, the mobile technology consortium headed by Psion, has agreed to license technology to Japan's Sanyo Electric for use in its next generation of wireless devices.

Sanyo yesterday said it aims to develop a range of advanced mobile communication devices based on Symbian software. Others already developing Symbian technology include Ericsson, Matsushita, Motorola, Nokia, Philips and Sony. Symbian uses the Epoc system developed by Psion for its hand- held computers.

Kozmo delays public offering

Kozmo.com, the New York-based home delivery service started by two former Goldman Sachs bankers, has postponed its initial public offering until next year as the market for internet shares remains weak. A report in the Industry Standard this week suggested that the upstart company was in talks to acquire its arch-rival, Urbanfetch.com, in order to cut costs.

The company also cut 275 jobs a week ago in a bid to stem continuing losses.

Sale at Reed's US arm Cahners Business Information, the American arm of magazine publisher Reed Elsevier, yesterday hired two banks to help with the divestment of several publications, including those in Cahners travel group and the automotive & trucking group. Allen & Co will advise on the sale of those in the Cahners group. Jordan Edminston Group will advise on the sale of the automotive & trucking group, as well as several other Chicago-based titles in the food processing, building and manufacturing sectors. The sales will include directories and internet operations related to the publications. Icahn targets General Motors General Motors' shares jumped yesterday after the American financier, Carl Icahn, said he would buy a stake in the Detroit car maker - which analysts said would add to pressure for a spin-off of its Hughes Electronics interest. GM said it received a letter from Mr Icahn on Wednesday saying that he would buy at least $15m worth of stock but not more than 15%, or about $5.3bn based on Thursday's closing price. Mr Icahn has gained a reputation as a corporate raider of some tenacity. In June, he walked away from Nabisco with a $600m profit after a long battle to take over the food producer.

webTitle: BT denies merger talks with AT&T

fields.headline: BT denies merger talks with AT&T
fields.standfirst: Speculation surrounds former state monopolies
fields.trailText: BT has denied that it is in talks with the huge American telecoms group, AT&T, despite speculation that the pair are to merge, thereby creating one of the world's biggest companies in the sector.
fields.byline: Anne Hyland  and  Jane Martinson  in New York
fields.body:
BT has denied that it is in talks with the huge American telecoms group, AT&T, despite speculation that the pair are to merge, thereby creating one of the world's biggest companies in the sector.

A BT insider yesterday quashed suggestions of such a merger and said the group would continue to focus on the growth of Concert, the UK company's international joint venture with AT&T.

Concert, which sells telephone, data and internet services to multinationals, has delivered strong cost savings for both companies.

A potential flotation of Concert has been proposed.

John Heath, a spokesman for AT&T, refused to comment on the "rumour and speculation" about a deal with the British group yesterday.

BT and AT&T - both former state monopolies - have been under pressure from shareholders to restructure their business and undertake disposals to boost their flagging share prices.

BT has talked of partial flotations of its mobile and internet businesses but still has to produce a timetable for such sales. AT&T has made similar noises.

This week BT revealed that its debt may balloon to £30bn, after it agreed to spend almost £9bn to buy a third generation German mobile telephone licence and take a controlling interest in Viag Interkom, its German subsidiary.

The increase in debt for the British group has concerned agencies Standard & Poor's and Moody's, who said they may slash BT's credit rating.

AT&T and BT also have a mobile phone alliance known as Advance that is striving to provide the first internation service. It is here that analysts see the potential for a deepening of a potential alliance between the two companies.

However, a full merger is unlikely, said one analyst familiar with both.

"I think it's going to be difficult for BT to look at AT&T, or vice versa, and find compelling strategic reasons for a merger - given they have probably achieved a significant portion of savings through Concert." The potential delay caused by the regulatory and legal inquiries attached to a full merger would also be a deterrent, another analyst said.

BT and AT&T are grappling with the need to compete more effectively with Vodafone and Deutsche Telekom, which are rapidly tightening their near-stranglehold on the global telecoms market. BT and AT&T are also desperate to make strides in the fast-growing market for cellular telephones and high speed data and net services. But the former state monopoly status of BT and AT&T means that they are lumbered with increasingly competitive and less profitable domestic and fixed-line networks.

webTitle: Vauxhall profits grow, but not enough

fields.headline: Vauxhall profits grow, but not enough
fields.trailText: Vauxhall boss Nick Reilly yesterday said the Luton-based car maker was still not making enough money despite improved profits last year.
fields.body:
Vauxhall boss Nick Reilly yesterday said the Luton-based car maker was still not making enough money despite improved profits last year.

The group, part of General Motors, reported that pre-tax profits rose from £72.6m to £127.7m last year on turnover up from £4bn to £4.4bn. But £40m of the profit rise stemmed from the write back of unused provisions made in previous years.

Mr Reilly said that 1999 had been a reasonable year for the group despite difficult trading conditions including downward pressure on car prices.

The underlying profit stability was achieved through increased efficiency, manufacturing cost savings as well as improved aftersales and headquarter operations.

But Mr Reilly said that the company would still have to re-assess all its activities to remain competitive.

He said that profit margins remained too low. Union leaders said they were expecting no new negotiations on jobs or conditions but they pointed to increased profits in the car industry due to the strong pound. Most of the record production of V6 engines at Vauxhall's Ellesmere Port plant went for export.

Much of the 21% jump in car production levels during the year was the result of a third shift at the Ellesmere Port plant, now making the new Astra for export to Europe.

Vauxhall, which earlier this year announced plans to invest £189m in its UK manufacturing facilities, increased its share of the UK car market from 12.6% to 13.3% through the sale of 291,598 vehicles, up from 282,560 the previous year.

fields.headline: Dream team in Seagram bid
fields.standfirst: Diageo and Pernod spring £4.5bn surprise on Allied Domecq in battle for brands
fields.trailText: Diageo and Pernod Ricard wrong-footed the rest of the spirits industry yesterday by announcing that they are to team up to make a joint offer for Seagram's $7bn (£4.5bn) international drinks portfolio.
fields.body:
Diageo and Pernod Ricard wrong-footed the rest of the spirits industry yesterday by announcing that they are to team up to make a joint offer for Seagram's $7bn (£4.5bn) international drinks portfolio.

The surprise combination was immediately taken as the favourite to win the auction, causing panic selling during the morning in the shares of rival bidder Allied Domecq.

Diageo, the world's biggest drinks group, had been negotiating a joint bid with Bacardi, the Bermuda-based group best known for its rum. Talks collapsed earlier this week and the company began secret discussions with Paris-based Pernod.

Pernod's joint-managing director, Richard Burrows, said: "This is a unique opportunity within the wines and spirits industry - it is unusual for a business of the importance of Seagram to come on to the market."

Mr Burrows said that Pernod was particularly interested in acquiring Seagram's Scotch whisky brands - which include Chivas Regal and The Glenlivet. The French group already owns a selection of middle-ranking brands, including Aberlour and Clan Campbell and the Irish whiskey, Jameson.

Industry experts reckon that Pernod would take on the majority of Seagram's brands, with Diageo picking up the American group's Crown Royal whisky, Captain Morgan rum and various wines for around $1.5bn.

Analyst Philip Hawkins of Merrill Lynch said: "It's a marvellous combination - they can probably afford to pay more than anyone else."

Seagram's wines and spirits portfolio is the third biggest in the industry. Allied Domecq, which ranks second, is anxious for a deal in order to close the gap with Diageo.

Allied's shares plunged 8% yesterday morning on fears that the extra competition may tempt the company to overpay, although the price later recovered to close down 4p to 322p.

Advisers to Allied rejected suggestions that the company could be squeezed out of the race. One said: "Alliances are always weaker than single bidders."

Allied maintains that it could raise enough money to make a $7bn cash bid for the business, while still having the cashflow to cover its interest payments three times over.

A possible third bid could come from the Bronfman family, which founded Seagram. The Bronfmans are understood to be reluctant to lose control of the drinks business.

Sources close to the transaction said that Seagram's adviser, Morgan Stanley, was likely to publish an information memorandum within the next week giving details of the businesses for sale. Seagram is refocusing on the entertainments industry - it is about to merge with the French group, Vivendi.

Diageo and Pernod are likely to escape close regulatory scrutiny if their bid is successful. Some brands could fall through the net - it is understood that neither side is keen to take on Martell cognac.

Members of Pernod's controlling family have made it clear that they would be prepared to dilute their control of the business if this was necessary to secure a substantial deal.

Mr Burrows said: "Scale is important. It is no secret that we want to expand. The creation of Diageo was a spur for everybody to look for more size in this industry."

webTitle: Li pockets won't stretch to G3 licence

fields.headline: Li pockets won't stretch to G3 licence
fields.standfirst: Germany's auction of third generation mobile phone licences yesterday proved too expensive even for the deep pockets of Hutchison Whampoa, writes Anne Hyland.
fields.trailText: The Hong Kong conglomerate quit the E-Plus consortium that had won the right to operate the new technology in the government auction.
fields.body:
The Hong Kong conglomerate quit the E-Plus consortium that had won the right to operate the new technology in the government auction.

Hutchison was in partnership with KPN and Bell South Corp in E-Plus, which was one of that six consortiums that each won a licence on Thursday when the total bids reached £31.8bn.

Shares in KPN fell as the Dutch mobile phone operator said it would now assume funding for 77.5% of the third generation licence or £4bn. Bell South will pay the remainder.

Hutchison Whampoa, controlled by the billionaire tycoon Li Ka-shing, said the withdrawal in the final hour of Thursday's auction was forced because the Hong Kong group had thought it would be winning 15MHz of spectrum and not 10MHz.

Mr Ka-shing said he did not consider the licence good value but might instead buy shares in KPN.

Each bidder was awarded less spectrum because the German government decided to award the maximum of six licences, and not the four hoped for by some of the telecom operators.

Germany is potentially the biggest mobile market in Europe.

KPN and Hutchison had been planning to fund building the infrastructure for the new licence together and then each to operate its own network. Some analysts said 10MHz was not sufficient spectrum to support two network operators.

KPN said it will still act in a consortium with Hutchison to bid for third generation licences in other European markets.
