fields.headline: Gore bets on substance
fields.standfirst:
After all, he can hardly promise style

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: There will be plenty of Americans wondering this weekend why on earth their political parties still bother hosting conventions. Every four years US commentators lament the lack of debate, the absence of tension, which makes these stage-managed gabfests such an apparent waste of time. Yet every four years the same commentators return, in ever larger numbers, to observe every detail. Is it all in vain? Well, not quite. For conventions still serve two useful purposes. First, they provide an insight into the state of the parties which hold them. Second, they often give a presidential candidate a vital dose of "bounce" in the opinion polls before campaigning gets underway in earnest in September. Judged by those standards, how did the Democrats do this week in Los Angeles?
fields.body:
There will be plenty of Americans wondering this weekend why on earth their political parties still bother hosting conventions. Every four years US commentators lament the lack of debate, the absence of tension, which makes these stage-managed gabfests such an apparent waste of time. Yet every four years the same commentators return, in ever larger numbers, to observe every detail. Is it all in vain? Well, not quite. For conventions still serve two useful purposes. First, they provide an insight into the state of the parties which hold them. Second, they often give a presidential candidate a vital dose of "bounce" in the opinion polls before campaigning gets underway in earnest in September. Judged by those standards, how did the Democrats do this week in Los Angeles?

The first measure does not yield good news. Two weeks ago the Republicans staged a near-model convention. They presented a public face utterly at odds with the mean-spirited, harsh image the party acquired in the age of Newt Gingrich. Instead of white men in suits, they presented an on-stage gala of blacks and Hispanics, gays and single moms: all wordlessly reinforcing George W Bush's message of "compassionate conservatism". Sure, it was fake - but it worked. Mr Bush left Philadelphia with a poll lead close to 20 points.

The aim of the Republicans' cuddly new image was to reach out to non-committed voters in the centre. That's what the Democrats needed to do in LA, too. Instead they spent most of the week talking to themselves, shoring up their own liberal base by wheeling out old favourites like Ted Kennedy and Jesse Jackson. They had to because Democratic activists arrived in LA still distinctly lukewarm towards their candidate, Al Gore. They needed to be revved up. But it is a sure sign of weakness if a party has still not mobilised its own troops by the time it meets for a convention.

Still, if Los Angeles shed some unflattering light on the Democrats, what did it do for Mr Gore? On the positive side, it confirmed that he is a man of substance. His acceptance speech on Thursday night was unashamedly focused on the issues. He boasted of the prosperity which has flowered under the Clinton-Gore administration and explained how he would use it on health and education, while his opponent would squander it with "a huge tax cut for the wealthy". He said he was on the side of working families, while Mr Bush would be the poodle of powerful corporate interests. And he staked out progressive stances on social questions like the environment, abortion, gun control and the overweening influence of cash in American politics.

It all added up to a decent programme, one usefully distinct from Mr Bush's - which is clearly how Mr Gore wants to be judged. "The presidency is more than a popularity contest," he said, tacitly acknowledging the charisma advantage his opponent enjoys over him. This may be his best hope: to admit that, as he put it, he will never be "the most exciting politician" - and then to define the contest as a clash of rival plans for the country. That, Mr Gore believes, is a fight he can win. The cruel question now is whether he is right. Can a politician who cannot deliver a speech without treading on his own applause lines beat an opponent with real charm? Can a man so wooden, he makes a kiss with his own wife look excruciating seduce a nation? Even if America agrees with Mr Gore on the issues, will that be enough to make them vote for him? In November Americans will decide what matters more: style or substance. After this week, that choice is clear.

That's what the Democrats needed to do in LA, too. Instead they spent most of the week talking to themselves, shoring up their own liberal base by wheeling out old favourites like Ted Kennedy and Jesse Jackson. They had to because Democratic activists arrived in LA still distinctly lukewarm towards their candidate, Al Gore. They needed to be revved up. But it is a sure sign of weakness if a party has still not mobilised its own troops by the time it meets for a convention. Still, if Los Angeles shed some unflattering light on the Democrats, what did it do for Mr Gore? On the positive side, it confirmed that he is a man of substance. His acceptance speech on Thursday night was unashamedly focused on the issues. He boasted of the prosperity which has flowered under the Clinton-Gore administration and explained how he would use it on health and education, while his opponent would squander it with "a huge tax cut for the wealthy". He said he was on the side of working families, while Mr Bush would be the poodle of powerful corporate interests. And he staked out progressive stances on social questions like the environment, abortion, gun control and the overweening influence of cash in American politics. It all added up to a decent programme, one usefully distinct from Mr Bush's - which is clearly how Mr Gore wants to be judged. "The presidency is more than a popularity contest," he said, tacitly acknowledging the charisma advantage his opponent enjoys over him. This may be his best hope: to admit that, as he put it, he will never be "the most exciting politician" - and then to define the contest as a clash of rival plans for the country. That, Mr Gore believes, is a fight he can win. The cruel question now is whether he is right. Can a politician who cannot deliver a speech without treading on his own applause lines beat an opponent with real charm? Can a man so wooden, he makes a kiss with his own wife look excruciating seduce a nation? Even if America agrees with Mr Gore on the issues, will that be enough to make them vote for him? In November Americans will decide what matters more: style or substance. After this week, that choice is clear.

fields.headline: The curse of the Kursk
fields.standfirst:
Yeltsin would have done better than Putin

Special report: Russia's stricken submarine
Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: When Mikhail Gorbachev promised the Soviet people glasnost, there was a sceptical cheer. It seemed too good to be true and when days of official silence followed the Chernobyl disaster in 1986 many felt their doubts justified. But Gorbachev learnt the lesson and after Chernobyl openness did indeed take wing.
fields.body:
When Mikhail Gorbachev promised the Soviet people glasnost, there was a sceptical cheer. It seemed too good to be true and when days of official silence followed the Chernobyl disaster in 1986 many felt their doubts justified. But Gorbachev learnt the lesson and after Chernobyl openness did indeed take wing.

Vladimir Putin emerged in the Kremlin at a different juncture in Russian history. By now the press is incomparably freer than in Soviet times. It is not always accurate. Polemics often take precedent over balanced reporting, and the media tycoons interfere too much. But there is a rough-and-ready pluralism and a courage in questioning the Kremlin which were inconceivable a decade and a half ago. The public's appetite for decent reporting is also far higher.

So Putin has to operate in a new climate. Sadly, the Kursk submarine disaster has shown his inadequacy. The official version of the disaster has flowed up and down as treacherously as the underwater currents in the Barents sea. First there were different accounts of when the disaster occurred. Then came rival explanations. Initially it was a collision, then an explosion and now we are back to a collision. The worst fumbling surrounds the crew's fate. One minute all are reported alive, though with declining stocks of air. Then video footage is produced to suggest half died at the start of the disaster. Why did it take so long to make the video, if diving bells have gone down regularly, or was the video suppressed for days? As a former KGB man, Putin was never schooled in openness, and this tragedy has shown he is still living in the Soviet past.

Equally bad is his lack of leadership. During the election campaign his personality was promoted in part as a contrast to his predecessor, Boris Yeltsin. A vigorous, modern leader would replace an ailing fumbler. Yet Yeltsin, for all his faults, was a consummate showman and populist. The man who had himself filmed on a tank in the 1991 coup would surely have flown to Murmansk and sat with the grieving wives of the sailors. Putin, foolishly, hid in an elite holiday compound on the Black Sea and then emerged in holiday clothes. Gesture politics can be overdone, but there are moments when a genuine leader captures - and eases - the national mood by moral example and the right symbols of concern. Let us hope that Putin, like Gorbachev, is agile enough to learn.

webTitle: Key to a good flat deal

fields.headline: Key to a good flat deal
fields.standfirst: Landlords are playing at the dubious game of gazumping. Richard Colbey reports
fields.trailText: Landlords are playing at the dubious game of gazumping. Richard Colbey reports.
fields.body:
The legal rules which allow unscrupulous house sellers to "gazump" their buyers are something that dodgy landlords seem to increasingly believe they can also take advantage of.

Ian Leatherman found this out to his cost after seeing a flat advertised in a Southampton local paper. He and his girlfriend viewed it the same evening, liked it, and agreed with the landlord that they would take it at the advertised rent of £125 per week from the beginning of the following month.

The landlord asked them for a deposit of £250, which they paid in cash, and gave them a note saying that he had received a £250 "holding deposit". They were to pick the keys up and pay the first month's rent on the day the tenancy was due to start.

However, when they called to collect the keys, he told them he had let the flat to someone else who had offered to pay £135 per week. The landlord told them he was sorry but "as nothing had been signed I was enti tled to do that". He claimed to have tried to phone to tell them this. They didn't believe him, but felt they had no choice other than to sim ply take their £250 back. Fortunately, they could stay in their old flat and so their only real loss was the wasted cost of hiring a van for the day.

Had they decided to pursue the matter, a court would probably have awarded them damages and, if they had acted quickly enough, ordered the landlord to let them into the flat.

The Law of Property Act (Miscellaneous) Provisions Act 1989, which requires property transactions to be in writing, does not apply to tenancies unless they are to last for longer than three years. Here, as both sides had committed themselves orally, with the receipt helping to prove it, the courts would treat it as a binding contract to grant a tenancy, which would allow Mr Leatherman and his girlfriend to occupy the flat for at least six months.

The landlord could be ordered to pay them the £10 a week extra rent he received by letting it to someone else for that six-month period, as well as the £45 it cost to hire the van and a small sum for inconvenience.

Even so, the damages would not be much over £500, and quite sensibly they decided it was not worth taking any action. Had they not been able to return to their flat and had had to move into expensive temporary accommodation the loss would have been much greater.

The fact that the sum they paid was described as a "holding deposit" makes little difference. The expression suggests that the tenant has paid a sum in consideration for the landlord agreeing to keep the property available. It isn't unreasonable, then, if the tenant doesn't take the property and the landlord has turned away other people who wanted it, for the deposit to be lost.

But it is obviously unfair if the landlord is not put under any obligation by accepting the deposit. However, some letting agencies are trying to enable landlords to do just this. More carefully worded receipts than that Mr Leatherman got are used when deposits are taken so landlords can still offer the property to someone willing to pay more.

One agency makes the tenant handing over the deposit sign a form saying: "This deposit does not create a tenancy, and does not require the landlord to grant one. It is merely an indication by the tenant of his or her good faith, and if he or she is subsequently offered a tenancy it will be retained by the landlord regardless of whether or not the tenancy is accepted."

Words such as these do have the effect that there is not a binding tenancy, unless the landlord subsequently grants one. But if a tenancy is offered and the tenant decides not to take it, they are probably entitled to the deposit back.

The Unfair Terms in Consumer Contract Regulations 1999 say that clauses which allow the retention of money in this situation, where the party keeping the money has not put himself under any obligation, are unfair and hence usually void.

Tenants faced with an established agency using this type of dubious device are likely to find the threat of legal proceedings quickly brings them the remedy they are seeking. Few will want terms of this sort subject to the scrutiny of a court.

Richard Colbey is a barrister

webTitle: When the numbers add up to buying a seriously big house

fields.headline: When the numbers add up to buying a seriously big house
fields.standfirst: Old care homes and hostels are being snapped up by families, reports Elizabeth Langton
fields.trailText: Old care homes and hostels are being snapped up by families, reports Elizabeth Langton.
fields.body:
In Eliza O'Driscoll's house, guests directed towards the living room need only to head for the door numbered 1. If they want to spend a little time with a book they are shown to the study, number 6.

It's not that Ms O'Driscoll and her family are keen to pigeon-hole their guests. Rather, the door numbers are inherited, along with the numerous chipped basins, baths and toilets that form part of their new home - a constant reminder of the property's former existence as a hostel for backpackers and language students.

The O'Driscoll family is among the increasing number of buyers who are snapping up old nursing homes, hostels and houses full of bedsits and turning what were once multiple-occupancy properties back into large family homes.

As local authorities have squeezed the fees they pay to care homes, many nursing and care homeowners have decided to call it a day. They've sold up and in doing so have released substantial properties on to the market. The larger homes are suitable only for the very wealthy or for use as hotels. But smaller former care homes can make stunning five- or six-bedroom family homes.

Lenders are less enthusiastic than buyers when it comes to stumping up cash for such properties. Many will agree to a loan but impose conditions, even withholding all the funds until specified work is carried out.

Ms O'Driscoll was house-hunting with little joy when she came across her three-storey Edwardian home in south London. "We lived in an area we really loved but had a hard time trying to find a larger house. Nearly everything available can be described as small, Edwardian and three-bedroomed. Larger homes with five bedrooms are usually converted into flats."

While viewing: "We were told it had been divided into two flats, but once we got inside it was obvious it had been used as a hostel - there were four single beds in some of the rooms. There was a bathroom and tiny kitchen on the ground floor, a bathroom on the middle floor and a kitchen on the top floor.

"All the bathroom and kitchen fittings were cheap and nasty, cracked and chipped and in shades of avocado and primrose. The cisterns were quite a different shade from the loos."

But as soon as she saw it she knew it would make a great family home: "I could see past all the tat," she says. Ms O'Driscoll offered £10,000 below the asking price and their offer - £275,000 - was accepted.

Raising the loan was not as straightforward as they had expected, she says. "The mortgage companies can get a bit sticky when you want to buy places that have been multiple-occupancy. They are obviously afraid that you've no intention of turning it into a family home at all but will continue to rent it out."

Ray Boulger, of mortgage brokers John Charcol, agrees. Lenders will be wary of making a loan for something that could be used as a business. "One of the key things that worries them is if you have more than one kitchen. If you have, it makes it easier to sub-let. Likewise if there are bathroom facilities in every room, not just a couple of en-suites."

Patrick Bunton, of mortgage brokers London and Country, says: "Lenders don't like parting with the money until the property has been restored to a single dwelling place. The bigger high street banks will look at doing it but they might charge a higher interest rate during the restoration."

Lenders will lend on commercial properties but they will usually only advance 75% of the value and the in terest rate won't be as favourable, says Mr Boulger.

To qualify for a normal home loan applicants are typically asked to remove all kitchens bar one prior to completion, Mr Boulger explains. Also, buyers of properties divided into flats might be asked to remove surplus utility meters.

"Borrowers may be given one lump sum after the work has been done upon completion or it might be released at various stages during the restoration, when the sur veyor says enough work has been done," says Mr Bunton. "In some ways it is rather like a hybrid self-build," he adds.

In Ms O'Driscoll's case, "there was a full retention subject to all evidence of multi-occupancy being removed. Even down to all the Yale locks on the bedrooms being taken off."

She was able to gain access to the property two weeks before completion when much of the work was carried out.

Others may not be so lucky, says Mr Boulger. "If buyers can't get access they may face a full retention of the monies before the work is carried out, so money for the alterations needs to be found up-front."

Brokers will know which lenders look favourably on properties with a former life, says Mr Boulger. "It depends on the merits of each case. It will largely come down to the status of the applicant. Lenders can see how a couple with children would want to turn a property back into a family home. But they might be suspicious of a single person with no family who claims to want to live alone in a very large property," he explains.

"We got much more house for our money than we would have if we'd bought a house already done up," says Ms O'Driscoll. Although her lender did impose conditions, it did not insist on the numbers being removed from the internal doors. Before long, the numerals will be the only evidence that the property was anything other than a London family home.

webTitle: Mortgage offers that can save you a fortune

fields.headline: Mortgage offers that can save you a fortune
fields.trailText: NatWest is offering a new deal for homeowners who want to switch mortgages for a better rate without moving property. There are five different remortgage deals on offer, including a two-year fix at 7.15%, a two-year discount of 1.9% giving a current rate of 5.84%, and a five-year discount of 1.2%, taking the current rate to 6.54%. The bank will pay the valuation fee (generally around £200) and the solicitors fees (around £150). David Evans, head of mortgage products at the bank, says: "Homeowners are often surprised by the substantial savings to be made by switching their mortgage, and yet are often reluctant to change because of the hassle and costs involved." He adds that it can take as little as four weeks for the remortgage process to go through.
fields.body:
NatWest is offering a new deal for homeowners who want to switch mortgages for a better rate without moving property. There are five different remortgage deals on offer, including a two-year fix at 7.15%, a two-year discount of 1.9% giving a current rate of 5.84%, and a five-year discount of 1.2%, taking the current rate to 6.54%. The bank will pay the valuation fee (generally around £200) and the solicitors fees (around £150). David Evans, head of mortgage products at the bank, says: "Homeowners are often surprised by the substantial savings to be made by switching their mortgage, and yet are often reluctant to change because of the hassle and costs involved." He adds that it can take as little as four weeks for the remortgage process to go through.

Hinckley and Rugby Building Society is offering a mortgage at 7.5% which pays a cashback and gives free accident, sickness and unemployment insurance for six months. The product is available for loans of up to 75% of the property value.

Online mortgage broker Creditweb is launching two products which cannot be bought directly from the banks or building societies. The first, offered by Birmingham Midshires, is a three- year fix at 5.99% with a maximum loan to value of 95% and the second, also a three-year fixed rate with 95% loan to value, this time at 4.95% is offered by mortgage lender Verso. Creditweb is at www.creditweb.com.

For those looking to buy a property in Spain, Norwich and Peterborough has launched a fixed-rate mortgage specifically for people buying on the Costa del Sol. The loan is fixed at 6.24% for two years, after which it reverts to the N&P Spanish home loans rate, currently 8%. The money is paid in sterling and repayment must also be paid in pounds. The only problem is the low loan-to-value ratio, which is just 65%.

A spokesman for the society says: "Up to now we have provided some home loans at a standard variable rate in Spain, but demand has been growing for a fixed-rate scheme, similar to those customers can obtain in the UK. People buying abroad like the idea of getting their mortgage from a familiar, trusted British mutual building society."

fields.headline: Working week
fields.standfirst: ICL targets sixth-formers for IT summer school project
fields.trailText: ICL targets sixth-formers for IT summer school project.
fields.body:
With the skills shortage in IT showing no sign of slowing down ICL, the e-business services company, has launched a summer school in partnership with the Technology Colleges Trust.

Eighteen sixth-formers from schools around the country attended the summer school at ICL's training centre in Windsor. The school was part of ICL and TCT's Magnet for Talent initiative which aims to raise awareness of IT job opportunities among school students.

IONANN Management Consultants is launching the London Open Programme to offer personal and organisational development to women working in the capital. Starting on September 14, the programme is a development of the Springboard Women's Development Programme, which operates inside organisations and is often used to underpin Investors in People schemes.

The London Open covers topics such as confidence building, presenting yourself, stress management, skills and experience audit and networking.

Courses will be at the Friends House in Euston Road. For more details contact IONANN on 0207-874-1200.

British bosses take more holidays than ever before, but they find it difficult to turn off when they're supposed to be relaxing, says the Institute of Management. A survey showed that nearly half of them (48%) were in touch with their offices at least once a week during their annual leave.

One in five of these workaholics takes their laptop on leave with them - compared with only one in 10 two years ago.

More than half - 55% - said they had no problem with contacting the workplace while they were away and regard it as part of their job. A quarter were not happy about it but understood why it was necessary.

Hot issues for secretaries were revealed in a recent survey by Office Secretary Magazine recently. The biggest thing that made them lose their cool was working late when they had a date - 68% said this was a major issue.

Equipment failure and colleagues stealing their lunch from the fridge were high on the list of complaints but a hot office in summer was the biggest irritant. Of the 300 who took part 97% said they wanted air conditioning in the office, especially as it would impress visitors, and 57% said the lack of air conditioning made them unmotivated and unappreciated.

fields.headline: Talking heads
fields.standfirst: Mary Francis: Director general of the Association of British Insurers
fields.trailText: Mary Francis: Director general of the Association of British Insurers.
fields.body:
When did you first become a manager?

In 1986, when I became head of the Treasury's central privatisation team.

What has been your best moment in management?

Putting together an excellent team here at the Association of British Insurers.

What was your greatest mistake?

Occasions when I have put off resolving a difficult issue.

Which deal would you most like to have done?

Vodafone-Mannesman. It's undeniably a groundbreaking deal.

What do you find most annoying in your staff?

Not telling me if I've made a mistake. It's far worse when you realise people are trying to hide something from you!

Does your organisation have a "glass ceiling"?

Certainly not.

Which management wisdom is most overrated?

Any that suggests you can manage by formula.

What will be the big business issue of the next decade?

In the financial services industry it will be the ageing profile of the population and government's need to cut down on the amount of protection provided from taxpayers' money. That will hugely increase the market for commercial pensions, long-term care insurance, mortgage protection and so on.

What one lesson would you pass on to aspiring managers?

Never stop asking: "Who are my customers?" And make sure your staff do the same.

Which management guru do you believe in?

None.

Who is your management hero?

Alan Greenspan: he's either an immensely skilful manager of the US economy or very lucky.

Who is your favourite politician?

Gladstone.

What phrase or saying do you most over-use?

"Yes -but".

Apart from your family, what else makes you happiest in life?

The first swim on holiday in warm water.

What annoys you most?

A boring answer really: people who shout into mobile telephones.

How do you relax?

Long walks, reading political biographies and detective stories and drinking red wine.

What was your last cultural experience?

Don Giovanni at Glydebourne, and American Beauty.

What is your favourite city?

Edinburgh: it's a complete combination of 18th century architecture and natural beauty and home to some of the world's greatest insurance companies.

Do you have a favourite website?

www.royal.gov.uk keeps me up to date with my last employer.

What is your greatest regret?

Not having had a wilder time at university.

What would you really like to have been?

A Cumbrian hill farmer.

fields.headline: When peace work pays off
fields.standfirst: Alison Buchanan's job with the Ministry of Defence has led to her nomination for a European Woman of Achievement award. Rachel Spence talked to her
fields.trailText: Alison Buchanan's job with the Ministry of Defence has led to her nomination for a European Woman of Achievement award. Rachel Spence talked to her.
fields.body:
One day the phone rang and someone said: "How do you fancy counting arms in Russia?" Straightaway I said, "Yup, that sounds great."

As job offers go, it wouldn't be to everyone's taste, but to Lieutenant Commander Alison "Aji" Buchanan, it was a golden opportunity. After 14 years in the Royal Navy she had two years left to serve and hoped to finish with something "a bit different".

Her new position at the Joint Arms Control Implementation Group (JACIG) - the Ministry of Defence body responsible for implementing arms treaties between former Warsaw Pact countries and Nato - saw her appointed second-in-command of her team, unheard-of seniority for a woman.

Last month she was nominated in the professional category for a European Women of Achievement award. "I felt humbled by nominees like the woman who single-handedly started orphanages in Romania. I thought: "Gosh, you just inspect weapons as part of a well-trained team." Her modesty belies the rigorous demands of her work; in the last two years she has done around 20 trips to Warsaw Pact countries. "Much of our brief is to check data," she explains, "So if Romania say they have x number of tanks we go out and count them. Glamorous it isn't: when you're trudging around in the mud and snow with a clipboard, trying to work out what tank is what, you do wonder what you're doing."

Sheer poverty can make certain countries hazardous. "Once in Moldova [the former Soviet state] I travelled by helicopter with six pilots who had to get in their year's flying time - they hadn't flown for months. The fuel tank was leaking and there was a chap smoking a cigarette. Sure, I was glad to get back."

She has been moved by the poverty of nations once considered a threat. "We go there and realise how lucky we are to have such excellent military resources. But I wonder what they think when they come here."

This state of affairs - whereby formerly secretive enemies now get to see exactly what their opposite numbers are up to - is central to modern-day arms control. "As well as physically verifying weapons, we also undertake 'confidence and security-building measures', where we meet soldiers and visit training areas; then they come and visit us," she explains. "It's the antithesis of our Cold War relationships; now it's about breaking down barriers, not building them."

It is this which attracted her to arms control in the first place. "With JACIG, you go out and do it for real. It's not an exercise, it's actually about preventing war. I love that." But what if there are no tanks where tanks should be - or too many? "There's rarely a serious problem," she says. "Occasionally we'll want to see something or go somewhere and they'll argue the treaty doesn't cover that. If they won't let us, we make a comment in our report."

Earlier this year, the Lieutenant Commander undertook her biggest responsibility, seconded to Sarajevo as part of an international team. "We were there to support arms control among the three groups - Bosnian Muslims, Croats and Serbs - who live in Bosnia-Herzegovina. We were mediating requests for inspections between different parties and the decision-makers in Vienna."

The job called for all her diplomatic skills but she thrived on the challenge. "It's a beautiful, tattered city. I enjoyed buying my fresh vegetables from the market and getting to know local people. But it was chastening to see the devastation of a post-war city." She felt quite safe. "Several war criminals were picked up while I was there so perhaps I should have worried more."

Her career has been affected by a traditional division of labour: "It was great to get this job at the end, as it would have been hard to compete for seniority with men for naval posts. When I joined the navy, women weren't allowed to go to sea. That changed in the early 90s and I joined HMS Fearless. I did well to be promoted to Lieutenant Commander at 34, but I was always going to be seven years behind the men in terms of seagoing experience."

In December 2001, - after two months secondment in Zagreb - she hits civvy street. "I don't know what I'm going to do but I reckon I've got something to offer." After dodgy helicopters and Balkan diplomacy, she should find it plain sailing.

fields.headline: From the top
fields.trailText: We are surrounded by successful niche brands. But successful niche companies are becoming increasingly rare.
fields.body:
We are surrounded by successful niche brands. But successful niche companies are becoming increasingly rare.

Ferrari, Aston Martin and Jaguar are examples of niche car brands; Cartier and Piaget are niche watch brands. Niche brands are specialist products targeted at narrow market segments that will pay premium prices. But none of these examples is any longer a niche company. All have been absorbed into large businesses such as Ford and Fiat.

At the early stage of an industry's evolution niche companies appear to prosper. Last year hundreds of internet start-ups were launched in Europe, attracted by the prospects of boundless growth and easy profits. Similarly, at one time there were more than 200 firms making cars in Europe and nearly a thousand motor cycle companies. But long before the industry matures a shake-out occurs and a handful of global players emerge. Over the last couple of months we have seen this beginning among internet businesses.

When companies perceive that they have missed the cut in becoming a major they often declare that they are niche players. They believe they can escape the competitive struggle and concentrate on a smaller segment willing to pay higher prices for something different. Alchemy recently proposed such a strategy in its abortive effort to take over Rover.

Such strategies rarely work today. Globalisation has eroded the barriers that once protected smaller, nationally based companies. More importantly, the bigger players have learned to be effective niche marketers themselves. Some companies, like Sony and Toyota, have developed niche brands internally. More often they have simply bought smaller companies that have valuable brands.

Acquisition is attractive because the small size of niche companies can make them easy to buy. Indeed, seeing the writing on the wall, the owners are usually eager to sell. They lack the resources, economies of scale or marketing muscle to battle it out in today's increasingly fierce markets. For big companies, acquiring niche brands can offer real value, because it is virtually impossible to create the heritage and prestige associated with great brands like Gucchi or Jaguar.

The majors often bring real synergies to these brands by lowering their cost structures, introducing up-to-date technology and having stronger marketing capabilities. Before it was acquired by Ford, Jaguar was a dying business, unable to compete with its obsolete technology, high costs and eroding brand image. Ford was able to transform it by injecting the capital and management that enabled it to modernise its processes, improve productivity and restore it as a truly powerful world brand.

Managers and investors need to understand these market dynamics. At the beginning, an explosion of opportunities appears to promise untold riches. Thousands of new companies are sucked into the market by the promise of rapid growth and easy profits. For most this turns out to be illusory.

A handful of winners soon emerges and demand for the myriad of followers dries up. The characteristics of winners like Microsoft, Intel and Ford have been an early understanding of the importance of achieving global dominance as a means of underpinning economies of scale and brand leadership.

Management has to decide early whether it has the resources and commitment to make the business a global player. If not, it pays to look for an acquirer while investors still perceive the business as having value.

Peter Doyle is professor of marketing and strategic management at the University of Warwick Business School.

fields.headline: We have ways of making you work
fields.standfirst: It's off the couch and into the workplace for today's practitioners of a science with its roots in factory conditions during the first world war. Eileen Sheridan reports
fields.trailText: It's off the couch and into the workplace for today's practitioners of a science with its roots in factory conditions during the first world war. Eileen Sheridan reports.
fields.body:
Forget Freud, the Fantasia of the Unconscious and all that: we're into science here. Occupational psychology is a million miles from the work of the beardie weirdie of Vienna and it has had an effect on everyone's working life.

It is a discipline which first made its mark in the first world war with studies on munitions workers and the hazardous effects on them of long working hours and is now in big demand.

"Occupational psychology has contributed to the understanding of skills, aptitude, intelligence and teamwork," says Cranfield Business School lecturer in psychology Richard Kriatkowski. Training for a career in occupational psychology and its offshoot discipline, organisational psychology, is long and extensive. This is not something you can qualify for the easy way because of the rigorous standards of the British Psychology Society (BPS).

Currently, anyone can set themselves up as a psychologist, says Mr Kriatkowski, something he sees as a scandal. The Institute, however, is working towards statutory regulation for the profession to cut out quacks who have not reached its high standards.

Only the BPS can confer chartered status on a trained psychologist and anyone entering the profession should be aiming for this. You need a first degree in psychology, but it must be a degree course which will give you the BPS's graduate basis of registration (GBR) to start you on your way. "Other degrees, such as joint degrees, will not give you the graduate basis, so you would need to do further study," the Society advises, "But there is provision within the statutes for the exceptional awarding of GBR via a PhD or the Society's Qualifying Examination."

This is followed by a period of assessment, during which graduates have to show they have the breadth and depth of competence across a range of areas in occupational psychology and this must be done as supervised practice.

Supervision lasts a staggering minimum of three years. The areas of knowledge which graduates must possess cover human and machine interaction, design of environments, personnel selection and assessment including test design, counselling and personal development, training, employee interaction, motivation, performance appraisal and organisational development and change.

Mr Kriatkowski recommends companies like BT, psychometric test specialists Savill and Holdsworth, the Ministry of Defence, the Employment Service and the Metropolitan Police. "It has to be real-life experience in a work situation," he says.

Only around 10% of psychology graduates go on to be practising psychologists and the BPS estimates its numbers of chartered occupational psychologists at around 7,000. They are employed by government departments, large management and accountancy consultancies and other large organisations. There is a growing number of smaller occupational psychology consultancies, some of which specialise, and some university departments have private consultancies attached to them.

"At the moment demand for occupational psychologists is buoyant," says Mr Kriatkowski, who currently teaches MBA students. "This is because of the difficulties of recruitment. Companies and organisations need to find good people and, in years of full employment, the main task is to keep the good people once you have them."

Psychology, he says, is a numerate discipline which also involves communication and the discussion of ideas, and for this a graduate needs a good grounding in maths - to GCSE level at the very least. "Psychology is studying how people be have and think and interact in a fundamental way, based on empirical research and examination of theory," he says. "Management trends can become flavour of the month without data to back them up. Psychologists have been trained to have a sceptical attitude about the efficacy of different processes."

The BPS has close links with the Chartered Institute of Personnel and its members have taken up development and ideas from psychologists. Psychometric testing is one of the areas of occupational psychology which most people are familiar with, but its theory has led to the introduction of assessment centres, personal development, training and mentoring. "Some large accountancy and management consultants employ occupational psychologists," says chartered occupational psychologist Kisane Prutton. "The profession is very like management consultancy, but instead of looking at bank balances, we are looking at people - the currency is people."

Other areas occupational psychology covers are stress management, advising trainers and sometimes counselling chief executives. "It's lonely at the top," says Ms Prutton, "And they need someone to talk to that they can trust and chartered psychologists are bound by a code of conduct, so anything that is said is confidential."

Stress, says Ms Prut ton, is an umbrella term for many problems, and occupational or organisational psychologists are often called in to analyse just what is going wrong.

"Perhaps people are working too hard, or the job itself can be dangerous. Or perhaps people are not getting enough support or feedback, all of which de-motivates them and destroys goodwill," she says. "We talk to people or use questionnaires or psychometric tests to measure stress."

Occupational psychologists, therefore, have a deep reach into an organisation. If they identify stress as a problem, the cause is often poor management.

"Managers are not trained to manage," says Prutton. "They are made managers because they are good at their jobs. Most organisations are businesses and they are looking at performance, which is short-term. They are not looking at the long-term damage caused by poor management."

Mr Kriatkoswki sees organisations making increased use of occupational psychology to pick the managers and fast-track the directors of tomorrow, as certain government departments have already done. "And the police know the value of occupational psychologist and have used them for years," he adds.

But it is getting the right people in the first place which is the biggest challenge to recruiters today because of the cost of the process, which is wasted if an organisation gets it wrong. There are specialist firms which devise psychometric tests but these, says Ms Prutton, have to be administered by specialists. Occupational psychology has developed competence tests which can be used by trained people in the organisations themselves.

"The traditional interview has a poor measure of success," says Ms Prutton. "People are appointed because the interviewer likes them. Competencies are a more objective measure and ask: can this person do the job?"

For more information: British Psychology Society,www.bps.org.uk.

fields.headline: Spotting runners with dot.com form
fields.standfirst: Gerry Mulvin, head of e-commerce at Bain & Co, tells how it set about devising a league table of internet winners and losers
fields.trailText: Gerry Mulvin, head of e-commerce at Bain & Co, tells how it set about devising a league table of internet winners and losers.
fields.body:
This quarter's dot.com market shake-up has demonstrated the need for a barometer to distinguish the good business models from the bad. We at Bain & Co have built a league table that is a serious attempt to sift the winners from the losers.

The Management Today/Bain e25 index is our assessment of what makes an internet business succeed. Is money more important than management? What is good management for an internet start-up? Is a vision of tomorrow more important than revenue today, and what is success for these companies?

Winners are companies with a unique and sustainable idea. We gauge their ability to execute that idea, gain the funding and put management in place to ensure they are getting the right product to the right customers.

The strongest management team is a hybrid of "athletes" and "specialists": athletes who can translate a web-based idea into business fundamentals and specialists who know the sector in which the company aims to establish itself. Old economy business fundamentals still apply. The only parameter that has changed dramatically is the speed with which these companies have to innovate.

Our experience over 30 years has given Bain & Co yardsticks by which to measure success. Any operation, dot.com or otherwise, has to build a sustainable, profitable business that gains a significant market share. There are three measures of success in the e25 index. First, you need a a clever idea that makes the business sustainable. So, Sportingbet.com spotted the tax advantage of offshore bookmaking early and based itself in Alderney, where punters could gamble tax-free. That launched its brand into places where its big-name competitors in the UK had no market share. The current e25 number one, auctioneer QXL, developed technology to hold live internet auctions and so attract business away from me-too sites.

Second, the business needs smart managers. Innovation in e-commerce can't be done by a committee. Dot-com managers need to retain control, establish a clear direction and communicate it. Many of the e25's founders are handing over day-to-day running of the company to experienced business people.

Finally, you need money. Recent experiences of several high-profile dot-com companies show that without money, a bright idea and good management are useless. For consumer-focused start-ups, the cost of acquiring each new customer has quadrupled to £80. Nine out of 10 internet companies are undercapitalised. The money will be gone before there are profits to replace it.

QXL is a good example of a company that used its market capitalisation to expand overseas, buying Bidlet in Sweden and ricardo in Germany. Its success means it is able to buy quality and expand quickly to market-leadership in 11 countries.

To compile the e25, we took these principles and scored candidates in six categories: concept, innovation, execution, traffic, financing and profile. The final figure is a mark out of 100. Among the 50 or so top candidates there's not much in it - between 5th and 15th, the difference is only 5%.

The direction in which you are heading in the index is as important as your place in it. Branding is vital - and for companies whose brand becomes tarnished, like boo.com, a slide can be very hard to reverse. The e25 will create a record of who did what, and whether it worked. It will also be able to tell us which companies will be working in the future, too.

The annual update of the e25 will be published in next month's issue of Management Today.

fields.headline: Company vitae
fields.standfirst: Balfour Beatty: Which this week announced a doubling of pre-tax interim profits to £35m
fields.trailText: Balfour Beatty: Which this week announced a doubling of pre-tax interim profits to £35m.
fields.body:
What? Not that bunch of dam-building ...

Hold your tree-hugging horses for just one moment before you get us sued. We'll come to the issue of the controversial Ilisu Dam project in due course. But let's consider some of the company's pluses first.

Go on, then - dazzle me.

Balfour Beatty is one of the UK's biggest engineering and construction groups with activities encompassing civil, railway and power engineering, building and building services and maintenance and facilities management. Founded in 1909, it built its reputation constructing dams, power stations and railways around the world. By the mid-80s it ranked alongside Tarmac as the UK's biggest road builder. It was brought into the BICC group in 1969, but shareholders have just voted to ditch the BICC moniker in favour of Balfour Beatty.

Is it good at building?

Oh yes. Balfour Beatty turns over more than £2.5bn per annum and employs around 20,000 people. In its interim results published this week, the company announced a doubling of pre-tax, pre-exceptional profits to £35m.

Any projects I'd recognise?

The £94m Cardiff Bay Barrage project in South Wales was one of Balfour Beatty's, as is the infrastructure for the south Yorkshire Supertram. Other UK projects range from strengthening works on the Forth Road Bridge in Scotland to building services contracts on the British Library and Barbican arts centre in London. The group is one of the front-runners in the market for Private Finance Initiative projects, including the recent £800m contract to refurbish GCHQ. It is also bidding for all three concessions to maintain the London Underground.

Golly. But is it a major player on the world stage?

About one-third of Balfour Beatty's turnover comes from international operations, so for employees there are plenty of opportunities to work overseas on short or long assignments. It has regional bases in the US, the Middle East and Asia Pacific. International project work has included the Muela Dam, part of the Lesotho Highlands Water Project in southern Africa, retrofitting bridges in California, such as the Golden Gate Bridge, against earthquake damage, and managing the Ministry of Defence's estate on Gibraltar.

Good at career-building?

Balfour Beatty seems to have a healthy appetite for talent, recruiting, for example, more than 80 graduates a year. New starters are offered structured schemes leading to professional qualifications, coaching and mentoring, on- and off-the-job education and training courses, secondments and attachments where appropriate.

What kind of talent is it hunting?

Balfour Beatty say it has openings in the areas of civil, electrical, mechanical and building services engineering, building and construction management, quantity surveying, finance and business studies. It also looks for people prepared to move around the UK and overseas in the early years of their career.

Might that include Turkey?

Perhaps. Balfour Beatty has been chosen to lead the civil engineering work on the Ilisu Dam project in Turkey. The dam is opposed by the Arab League, human rights groups and environmentalists who say the historic town of Hasankeyf will be drowned and up to 25,000 Kurds will lose their homes.

What does Balfour Beatty say in its defence?

It claims that the adverse publicity given to the project contains inaccuracies and says the project is capable of being of "very considerable benefit to a very large number of people".

Other items worth glossing over at a job interview?

Balfour Beatty has had several run-ins with the authorities in recent years. It was at the centre of the Pergau dam battle in Malaysia and was charged by the government of Lesotho for allegedly paying bribes. Its Massachusetts offices were raided in June by the FBI as part of an inquiry into rail modernisation in Boston and it was fined £1.2m following the collapse of tunnels during construction at Heathrow.

Anything else to declare?

On a positive note, Balfour Beatty instigates archaeological investigations on all major projects and carries out plant and animal relocation as a matter of course. For example, it has constructed badger runs and relocated badger setts in danger of being disturbed by construction.

Who wants my job application then?

Apply online by pointing your broswer at www.balfourbeatty.com/careers

fields.headline: Leading the drive for diversity
fields.trailText: Some areas of UK management have a long way to go when it comes to encouraging diversity in the workforce.
fields.body:
Some areas of UK management have a long way to go when it comes to encouraging diversity in the workforce.

"Things have progressed," says occupational psychologist Binna Kandola, co-founder of Oxford-based consultancy Pearn Kandola. "But in many organisations there is a lack of understanding of what diversity is in practice."

On diversity, he says, many organisations have policies in place. "It is easy to develop a policy but that is only the end of the beginning. Sometimes the follow-through is not there," he says. Diversity is one area in which Pearn Kandola specialises. Recent work includes a Europe-wide audit for Ford and work for Abbey National, and Hewlett Packard.

Dr Kandola's own studies for his PhD, sponsored by the Runnymede Trust, highlighted the early signs of unconscious racial and gender bias. He looked at the fairness or otherwise in the use of selection tests for the Civil Service. "We were working on how to get agreement on what was fair and unfair. What is a fair test anyway?" he asks. "Selection tests had an enormous adverse impact on ethnic minorities. They would be the first stage of application but did not come through the test sessions - there was an enormous fall-off."

His consultancy avoids the use of selection tests, favouring instead a work sample test. Candidates are put through a realistic simulation of what the job actually entails. "This has proven to be fairer. We avoid aptitude tests wherever possible."

It is companies' unconscious bias towards the white male which, says Dr Kandola, has led to a belief that there is a "war for talent" going on. "There are 110 universities in the UK and a lot of people with talent that nobody knows how to get," he says. Visible ethnic minorities form 13% of the undergraduate population and women 52%, a higher percentage than white males. "But companies still target white males," he adds.

And his own peers in the world of psychology are insufficiently open to the issue of diversity, he says. As chairman of an equal opportunities committee for his own profession he was appalled at the lack of awareness. "I was surprised at how much resistance there was among psychologists. I can understand banks not being aware, but not psychologists. We are failing if we don't recognise the importance of diversity."

Another difference in the modern workplace has arisen from the change in the psychological contract between employer and employee which took place in the 80s. When companies decided to become leaner and meaner they abandoned the old tacit "job for life" agreement with their workforce. "People have adapted to this," says Dr Kandola.

"Now organisations are having to live with the consequences." So in the fight to get and keep good people, organisations are moving back to the older paternalistic position - but in a different form.

fields.headline: Let's face it, fans have always been really cool
fields.standfirst: An elegant way to beat the heat, much favoured by royalty, has saleroom potential, says Stewart Dalby
fields.trailText: An elegant way to beat the heat, much favoured by royalty, has saleroom potential, says Stewart Dalby.
fields.body:
Among the welter of memorabilia to celebrate the Queen Mother's one hundredth birthday one item seemed missing: there were no commemorative fans. Just about everything else was produced - teacups, spoons, teaspoons, mugs, dolls and so on - but no fans. Come to think of it, the Queen Mother is a hat person; you do not usually associate her with fans.

But they were great favourites with previous royals. Queen Elizabeth I apparently left a collection of 27 fans when she died. She was so fond of them she often carried them in portraits and considered them a suitable present for a queen.

In their book Elizabeth R , Dr Roy Strong and Julia Trevelyan Oman list a number of them:

"Item - one handle of gold enameled, set with small rubies and emeralds lackinge nine stones, with a ship under sail on the one side.

Item - one fanne of white feathers, with a handle of golde wyndinge about it, garnished with a ball of diamonds in the end, and a crown on each side within a paire of wings garnished with diamonds."

From a similar period a taffeta fan, believed to have belonged to Mary Queen of Scots, survives in the National Museum of Antiquities for Scotland. It is a cockade fan with sliding tortoiseshell sticks. Queen Victoria is also said to have left a large number of fans.

Fans are of great antiquity. In its earliest form the fan was probably a small hand-sized screen used to alleviate the heat. Handles were added and the fan became a work of art used in religious and royal ceremonies. Later still they became decorative accessories often made of precious metals, incorporating valuable jewels and with finely painted screens.

The earliest fans are depicted in bas-reliefs and paintings. In Egypt, fan bearing courtiers carried semi-circular feather fans on long poles. Some surviving examples have been found in tombs. That of Tutankhamen (1350BC) contained one chased in gold with scenes of the young king hunting ostriches. Their feathers would be used to decorate fans.

In China, the first fans - hand screens - were probably of feathers, which would not have survived. Both sexes carried fans and detailed regulations accorded different types of fans to each rank of person. It is now thought that the first brisé fan originated in Japan and was taken to China by a missionary in the 9th century.

The brisé is one of three basic types of fan. First there is the fixed fan. This is rigid in shape and generally has a handle to hold. It can be shaped like a leaf, circular, or like a spade or flag. An early example of these is the Chinese "pien-mien" which are made from paper stretched over a wire frame.

The brisé fan consists of thin, light strips of ivory, wood or mica, held together by a rivet or cord along the base and along the top. Mica is a silicate mineral, which is separable into thin plates. The brisé gave way to the folding fan, which was almost certainly oriental in origin.

The folding fan, which is made in one piece and like a bird's wing, became very popular - they could folded up small and put in boxes, cases or pockets. Although there are many sub-categories, these are the basic three models that have survived down the ages.

The handles are made of various materials like ivory and tortoiseshell and the screen can be kid or goatskin, fine kidskin known as chicken skin, vellum, paper or silk.

Susan Mayor in her book Collecting Fans, published in the Christie's South Kensington Collectors series in 1980, says that it is unlikely that the collector today will come across fans earlier than the second half of the 17th century. She is still the specialist at Christie's, as well as press secretary for Fans Circle International. Christie's has four sales a year - the next is on September 19.

She says: "There is terrific interest among a large body of collectors. They buy them because they are beautiful, like works of art, and because they have great historical interest. They are usually folding fans.

"We did have one 16th century fan once, but the earliest are usually 17th century. But fans of quality of any age, the 18th century, the 19th century, can be valuable, if they are well painted or have unusual handles."

A highlight of the September sale is a fan celebrating the birth of a little Italian prince, entitled "Infante Philipe, Duc of Calabria with his mother Queen Marie Emilia of Saxony in the Palace of Portici near Naples." This has six ladies standing around and dates from 1747. It is painted in thickened watercolours and has ornate ivory handles. It is expected to fetch between £5,000 and £10,000.

But there are cheaper fans. Among the 200 lots, prices start at £250. Susan Mayor says: "You can buy a set of 1920s advertising fans for £250. I seem to sell more and more fans for thousands of pounds with each passing year."

For further information telephone Christie's, 020-7581-7611.

Susan Mayor in her book Collecting Fans, published in the Christie's South Kensington Collectors series in 1980, says that it is unlikely that the collector today will come across fans earlier than the second half of the 17th century. She is still the specialist at Christie's, as well as press secretary for Fans Circle International. Christie's has four sales a year - the next is on September 19. She says: "There is terrific interest among a large body of collectors. They buy them because they are beautiful, like works of art, and because they have great historical interest. They are usually folding fans. "We did have one 16th century fan once, but the earliest are usually 17th century. But fans of quality of any age, the 18th century, the 19th century, can be valuable, if they are well painted or have unusual handles." A highlight of the September sale is a fan celebrating the birth of a little Italian prince, entitled "Infante Philipe, Duc of Calabria with his mother Queen Marie Emilia of Saxony in the Palace of Portici near Naples." This has six ladies standing around and dates from 1747. It is painted in thickened watercolours and has ornate ivory handles. It is expected to fetch between £5,000 and £10,000. But there are cheaper fans. Among the 200 lots, prices start at £250. Susan Mayor says: "You can buy a set of 1920s advertising fans for £250. I seem to sell more and more fans for thousands of pounds with each passing year." For further information telephone Christie's, 020-7581-7611.

fields.headline: A Country Diary
fields.standfirst: West Yorkshire
fields.trailText: Any project which seeks to restore or recreate colourful, herb-rich meadows has to be welcome. Kirklees Metropolitan Council has, for the past three years, run a Millennium Meadow project using wildflowers grown in the council's nurseries from locally sourced seed and   planted out in otherwise species-poor open spaces. School grounds, manicured public parks and other sites have been transformed.
fields.body:
Any project which seeks to restore or recreate colourful, herb-rich meadows has to be welcome. Kirklees Metropolitan Council has, for the past three years, run a Millennium Meadow project using wildflowers grown in the council's nurseries from locally sourced seed and planted out in otherwise species-poor open spaces. School grounds, manicured public parks and other sites have been transformed.

Kirklees, centred on Huddersfield, includes the mill towns of Batley, Heckmondwike and Holmfirth. They are surrounded by an agricultural landscape that has been managed by man for centuries. Meadows, as opposed to rough pasture, have been ploughed up and resown many times. Herbicides and pesticides have reduced diversity to a handful of flower species and even fewer grasses. The council's scheme creates a resource, an oasis of wildflowers from local genetic stock that can spread naturally.

The project has been very successful. New meadows, some in formal public parks, others in the wider countryside, have bloomed with ox-eye daisies, yellow rattle, ragged robin, red campion and meadow cranesbill. Local companies and institutions are planning to join in, creating wildflower meadows on land of their own.

The current project is sponsored by Yorkshire Electricity, whose community affairs manager, Regan Cooper, told me: "We began with 100,000 wildflower plants, one for each household in Kirklees. This year, we expect to produce 360,000 - a new plant for every individual in the borough."

Today, a wildflower festival takes place in a public park in Almondbury on the outskirts of Huddersfield. Horse-drawn mowers will cut the hay crop, and ricks will be made from grass cut earlier. This celebration will focus on the importance and benefits of wildflower meadows. That success is largely because the project engages local communities. Local people are creating their own meadows. This provides a sense of ownership that will ensure the project's long-term success.

webTitle: How I bought my way into the parade ring at Ascot for the price of an eyelash

fields.headline: How I bought my way into the parade ring at Ascot for the price of an eyelash
fields.trailText: As a horseracing-mad child in the 70s, I was green with envy at those who were admitted into the parade ring to watch their very own thoroughbreds sway elegantly past. In those days, owning a racehorse was a sport, if not for kings, at least for the very, very wealthy.
fields.body:
As a horseracing-mad child in the 70s, I was green with envy at those who were admitted into the parade ring to watch their very own thoroughbreds sway elegantly past. In those days, owning a racehorse was a sport, if not for kings, at least for the very, very wealthy.

Earlier this month, as I too stood in that charmed circle and watched my eight-year-old sprinter Almasi parade at Ascot I realised how much has changed. Today there can be anything from two to 20 shares in a racing partnership; and a remarkable number of "ordinary" people have discovered the thrill of owning a racehorse.

Currently, there are some 1,800 such schemes in the UK with approximately 12,000 members. What you get for your money depends on many variables. The average cost of a horse in training is £16,000 per year - this covers everything from stable staff, jockeys and entry fees to suppliers' bills and transport costs.

Some trainers require a monthly fee; others prefer a single annual payment. If you buy into a syndicate, or a horse the trainer already owns, you'll also be charged your share of the buying price. When I bought into Almasi - then a hairy, just-ridden yearling - the trainer, Chris Wall, had paid £8,000 for her at auction and there were 10 shares.

My partner and I agreed to split a half-share which cost us the princely sum of £250 each and then a further £300 each to cover her training costs for the year. As the other half-share was owned by Mrs Wall, the trainer's wife, I became the "named" owner.

We nicknamed Almasi "the eyelash", feeling that we didn't own enough of her to call it a whisker.

As with any investment, it pays to shop around. Most owners want more than anything to feel involved in a world that may have figured in their dreams for years. Standing on Newmarket Heath on a misty spring morning watching your horse thunder up the turf is as moving as being in the winner's enclosure.

As to the question of risk versus return, owners must be realistic. It's estimated that barely 20% of racehorses ever win a race; a considerable proportion - through injury or growing poorly - never make it to the course at all.

Although the really powerful owners do, through breeding opportunities, make their horses a profitable enterprise, for the average man in the paddock it has to be about fun first with financial gain a very poor second.

There are plenty of satis fied customers - and most will tell you they have been lucky. Almasi, for example, has been almost injury-free. She has run 60 times, won seven races and been placed in 16. In all, she has won nearly £50,000 in prize money. As a result of her efforts, she has cost me in total a little less than £2,000.

Now eight years old and still racing - most flat racing careers are over by five or six years old - she has also given me untold fun. In terms of money risked and pleasure returned, it's been worth every penny, although, like most owners, I haven't made any money.

But Clive Middleditch is a very happy man. Last year, his two-year-old colt Primo Valentino won the prestigious Middle Park Stakes at Newmarket, bringing his total winnings for the season to £124,300.

Trained by Peter Harris, the horse is owned by a 12-strong syndicate called the Primo Donnas; each share costs them around £325 per month and buys them two years' ownership. Today the colt is valued at around £600,000, which means Mr Middleditch's half-share is worth around £25,000.

But not every story has such happy reading: of the 13,000 horses in training, several thousand are injured every year, many permanently. For personal assistant Jane Lewis, the journey to the winner's enclosure has been arduous. Three years ago she and her partner bought a 12th share in a yearling at Peter Harris's yard for £250 per month. But the colt had knee problems and never raced. Finally he was put down.

"Although we were were told not to get too attached to the horse, it was terribly upsetting," recalls Ms Lewis. Like most ordinary horses, the colt was insuffi ciently valuable to be insured. Many owners simply have to write off this loss but in Ms Lewis' case, Mr Harris moved the syndicate into another two-year-old but he was unplaced in six races, "so we sold him at the end of the season for £300".

The syndicate's new colt has won twice this year; but the story illustrates the bleaker side of this notoriously unsentimental industry. For the Primo Donnas, the big question is: "What to do next?"

Most syndicates decide by majority vote and the more whiskers you own, the more weight you pull.

Primo Valentino's options are: to run next year as a four-year-old; to be sold; or to go to stud. In terms of making money, the last two are clear winners. This Lothario won't come cheap: it's estimated he'll cost £5,000 per session and will mate with around 60-70 mares per season.

Yet Mr Middleditch wants him to race again, although it could damage his stud value if he fails to win. "In the end, it's not about money," he says, "it's about fun."

Of course,the danger with getting involved in racehorse ownership is that it's never enough. The exhilaration of watching your horse first past the post is an addictive pleasure. Next time, forget the eyelash; I want a whisker.

webTitle: First leg of a horse race

fields.headline: First leg of a horse race
fields.standfirst: Bill Stack explains how to buy a part share in a thoroughbred and enjoy the sport of kings
fields.trailText: Bill Stack explains how to buy a part share in a thoroughbred and enjoy the sport of kings.
fields.body:
If taking tea with the Queen Mum or discussing form with Frankie Dettori sounds a pleasant way of spending a summer's afternoon, why not join the growing number of people who have become racehorse owners?

Buying a horse outright may be a little adventurous. Even a modest purchase is likely to set you back £5,000 to £10,000, plus as much again each year on stable and training fees.

With no guarantee of any return whatsoever, joining a racing club or syndicate is a way to achieve ownership while keeping costs and risks under control. Perhaps the first thing to decide is if you want a jumper or a horse for the flat season.

The flat season runs from March to November and with the advent of summer jumping, hurdlers are now busy all year round. It's worth bearing in mind that, generally, prize money for jumpers is less than for flat racing. Syndicates come in sizes to suit all pockets.

Cheltenham Racing Ltd, which is linked to Cheltenham racecourse, has been running an owners' club since 1993. For £230 annual membership plus a £25 joining fee, you get a club badge, car park label, and use of the marquees at the National Hunt Festival. You also get free admission to the course when your horse is running and eight stable visits a year. Currently, the syndicate runs four National Hunt horses with a restricted membership of 250 people.

If you have more to spend, Delta Bloodstock Management, based in Newmarket, has a syndicate of 20 people with shares starting at £3,000. This covers all equity, training and management fees for a year. The syndicate is currently running seven flat horses.

Partnerships can be formed with as few as two or four people. The cost of the horse is paid for up front and a variable amount paid each month for the training and running fees. Partners have to register with the Jockey Club and are also liable for occasional running expenses such as veterinary and blacksmiths' fees.

Partners can name their horse and choose the colours in which they will run. The services of a good bloodstock agent or trainer are essential in buying the animal. The two big auction houses, Tattersalls and Doncaster Blood Sales, each have several public auctions during the year where a range of animals from foals, yearlings and two-year-olds will be available. In 1999 the average price paid for a yearling at public auction was £30,450 and for a two-year-old in training £13,000.

Choosing a trainer is almost as difficult as choosing a horse. Some owners like to visit their animals often and follow them from meet to meet; others are quite happy to let the trainer make the decisions. The British Horseracing Board's website gives brief details of trainers such as how many winners, how many horses in their yard and their philosophy towards owners.

James Bethall, who runs a number of syndicates from his yard at Leyburn in north Yorkshire, advocates owner involvement. "They are most welcome to come to the stables and watch us gallop the horses. I regard every horse as an investment into which I put my knowledge and expertise."

The board also runs a twice-yearly owner seminar to give prospective buyers an overview of what horse ownership is all about. The semi nars are held at Epsom in April and Newmarket in September and last two days. The subject matter covers essentials about setting up and running a partnership, the role of the bloodstock agent and how to choose a trainer.

They cost £225 plus VAT per delegate, but if you become a registered owner within 12 months you will be entitled to a full refund of the fee plus a year's free membership of the Thoroughbred Breeders Association, worth £75, and a year's free membership of the Racehorse Owners Association, worth £80.

And the rewards? It may not be the place to put your pension, but if you buy a winner, it could well provide a pension. Earth Summit, owned by the Summit Partnership and winner of the 1998 Grand National, cost the miserly sum of £6,090 and has so far won in excess of £373,000. Istabraq, the Champion Hurdler, which cost £39,900, has notched up more than £847,000 and See More Business, the Tote Gold Cup winner bought for £5,880, has passed the £400,000 mark.

This year alone the estimated prize fund at Britain's 59 racecourses is expected to exceed £70m, ranging from a guaranteed £160 appearance fee for all Sunday runners up to £1m for the Derby.

fields.headline: Tony Stuart
fields.trailText: In the twilight of variety theatre, Tony Stuart, who has died aged 78 of broncho-pneumonia, was a familiar fixture on provincial bills. He was a dancer of what others in the business believed to be considerable talent. But although he appeared on the West End stage, featured in the television series about a home for the aged, Waiting For God, and even choreographed a Sadler's Wells opera, the really lucky breaks that he hoped would bring him stardom eluded him.
fields.body:
In the twilight of variety theatre, Tony Stuart, who has died aged 78 of broncho-pneumonia, was a familiar fixture on provincial bills. He was a dancer of what others in the business believed to be considerable talent. But although he appeared on the West End stage, featured in the television series about a home for the aged, Waiting For God, and even choreographed a Sadler's Wells opera, the really lucky breaks that he hoped would bring him stardom eluded him.

Stuart ended his days running a gay club in Brighton and producing charity revues. But in the heady postwar period, he was an up-and-coming youngster who, in the West End show, Starlight Roof, rivalled Julie Andrews for the audience's attention.

He was born Harry Brigden in Burnley, Lancashire, to a working-class family who were not best pleased to discover that his first stage job, aged 11, was playing a Dutch girl doing a clog dance. The idea of appearing in drag shocked his brothers, but his parents eventually accepted his lifestyle.

Stuart - at over 6ft, an upright, athletic-looking figure - was not the conventional gay performer. After wartime army service, he was featured as a dancer in the Emile Littler revue, The Night And The Music, at the London Coliseum, a show that opened in May 1945, a week after VE-day. He made sufficient impact to be featured in that year's Royal Variety Performance, dancing with Beryl Kaye, a popular name at the time.

At the end of the decade, Stuart appeared in Starlight Roof, the show that launched Julie Andrews. He also worked in a double act with the dancer Marion Grey. But it was meeting the singer Dorothy Squires that provided Stuart with his most lasting professional associations. He wrote and produced pantomimes for her, and also appeared as the "heavy" villain in her versions of Robin Hood, Babes In The Wood and Aladdin.

At the same time, he was the professional partner of the singer Joyce Golding in the Golding And Stuart duo. Ms Golding, whose remarkable voice could go from soprano to baritone, also worked with Max Miller, Norman Wisdom and Max Bygraves, and had previously entertained with the services' wartime entertainment group, ENSA. She met Stuart in Llanelli in 1950.

In 1954, Stuart changed tack completely, and went off to choreograph Gian Carlo Menotti's opera, The Consul, at Sadler's Wells, though it would not prove to be more than a one-off engagement. In 1960, he had his own last dancing role, as Pepe, the tango dancer, in a national tour of The Boy Friend.

In 1969, along with hundreds of other Brighton residents, he worked as an extra on the Richard Attenborough film, Oh! What A Lovely War. Sir John Gielgud spotted him in this and engaged him as his body double. During the 1970s, he appeared in The Two Ronnies television series and was later a regular cast member on Waiting For God.

For the last 20 years, Stuart owned and ran the 42 Club, a gay centre in Brighton. His last professional job was organising a local gay revue to raise money for the Red Cross.

He lived for 41 years with the landscape painter Sydney Lewis, who survives him.

Tony Stuart, actor and dancer, born April 18 1922; died July 29 2000
