Stuart - at over 6ft, an upright, athletic-looking figure - was not the conventional gay performer. After wartime army service, he was featured as a dancer in the Emile Littler revue, The Night And The Music, at the London Coliseum, a show that opened in May 1945, a week after VE-day. He made sufficient impact to be featured in that year's Royal Variety Performance, dancing with Beryl Kaye, a popular name at the time. At the end of the decade, Stuart appeared in Starlight Roof, the show that launched Julie Andrews. He also worked in a double act with the dancer Marion Grey. But it was meeting the singer Dorothy Squires that provided Stuart with his most lasting professional associations. He wrote and produced pantomimes for her, and also appeared as the "heavy" villain in her versions of Robin Hood, Babes In The Wood and Aladdin. At the same time, he was the professional partner of the singer Joyce Golding in the Golding And Stuart duo. Ms Golding, whose remarkable voice could go from soprano to baritone, also worked with Max Miller, Norman Wisdom and Max Bygraves, and had previously entertained with the services' wartime entertainment group, ENSA. She met Stuart in Llanelli in 1950. In 1954, Stuart changed tack completely, and went off to choreograph Gian Carlo Menotti's opera, The Consul, at Sadler's Wells, though it would not prove to be more than a one-off engagement. In 1960, he had his own last dancing role, as Pepe, the tango dancer, in a national tour of The Boy Friend. In 1969, along with hundreds of other Brighton residents, he worked as an extra on the Richard Attenborough film, Oh! What A Lovely War. Sir John Gielgud spotted him in this and engaged him as his body double. During the 1970s, he appeared in The Two Ronnies television series and was later a regular cast member on Waiting For God. For the last 20 years, Stuart owned and ran the 42 Club, a gay centre in Brighton. His last professional job was organising a local gay revue to raise money for the Red Cross. He lived for 41 years with the landscape painter Sydney Lewis, who survives him. Tony Stuart, actor and dancer, born April 18 1922; died July 29 2000

fields.headline: Jack Walker
fields.standfirst: Millionaire football fan who made stars of Blackburn Rovers
fields.trailText: Jack Walker, the Blackburn-born steel magnate, who has died aged 71, stood on the terraces of Blackburn Rovers in the 1950s watching the team's local-born England internationals, Ronnie Clayton and Bryan Douglas, excel, then made a fortune in industry and ploughed much of it back into his beloved football club. Between 1991-92 and 1994-95, he saw the team rise from sustained obscurity to win their first championship since 1914 - only to then implode and fall out of the Premier League in 1999, proving, perhaps, that even in today's football, money isn't everything.
fields.body:
Jack Walker, the Blackburn-born steel magnate, who has died aged 71, stood on the terraces of Blackburn Rovers in the 1950s watching the team's local-born England internationals, Ronnie Clayton and Bryan Douglas, excel, then made a fortune in industry and ploughed much of it back into his beloved football club. Between 1991-92 and 1994-95, he saw the team rise from sustained obscurity to win their first championship since 1914 - only to then implode and fall out of the Premier League in 1999, proving, perhaps, that even in today's football, money isn't everything.

Walker left school at 14, joined his father's small sheet-metal business, worked variously as sheet-metal worker, welder and a conscript craftsman in the Royal Electrical and Mechanical Engineers, and, in 1951, took over the family firm with his brother, Fred.

Together, they transformed the business into a steel stockholding concern, which, in 1990, Walker sold to British Steel for £360m, before retiring to St Helier, Jersey. He still, however, commuted regularly to Lancashire for Rovers' games. He had helped them financially in the past, but was now able to commit himself fully to the club. Effectively its owner, he remained officially no more than vice-president, although everybody knew who was in command.

Some clue to Walker's determination and entrepreneurial style was given by rhymes and slogans which hung on his office wall. One, the gift of a Blackburn printing company, ran: "If you think you are out-classed, you are/ You've got to think high to rise/ You've got to be sure of yourself before/ You can ever win a prize/ Life's battles don't always go/ To the stronger or faster man/ But soon or late the man who wins/ Is the fellow who thinks he can."

Another said, simply: "Rule One, I am always right. Rule Two, when I am wrong, read Rule One."

Estimated to be the 21st richest man in Britain, the initial transfers Walker funded for Blackburn were relatively unexceptional. But they became more and more expensive, though many were sold on, some at a phenomenal profit. Alan Shearer, the England centre-forward, came from Southampton in July 1992 for £3.3m, then, having helped Blackburn win the championship, moved on to Newcastle United in July 1996 - netting Walker's club £15m in transfer fees.

Signing Shearer was a colossal coup for Walker, but persuading Kenny Dalglish to come out of retirement to manage Blackburn was just as important. Dalglish, a renowned Scottish international and manager at Liverpool, had seemingly been devastated by the Hillsborough disaster, but came to Ewood Park in 1991.

The following year, after several failures in the play-offs, Blackburn, who had come only sixth in the first division, prevailed and entered the Premier League. Coming fourth in their first season, runners-up in their second, they took the championship in 1994-95, with Shearer establishing a formidable striking partnership with Chris Sutton, himself bought for £5m from Norwich City and transferred on to Chelsea for double that sum in 1999. (He has now moved to Celtic.)

When it came to the European Cup in 1995-96, however, Blackburn went out early, and feebly, to Swedish opposition. The following year, Dalglish became general manager, and seemed to spend much of his time on the golf course, leaving the managerial job to his coach, Ray Harford, who found it hard to make the transition.

Walker was never tolerant of failure, and, in 1997, Harford gave way to Roy Hodgson, who had managed Switzerland and Inter of Milan. He, too, failed to bring new success to Blackburn, and left in 1998, giving way to the Manchester United coach, Brian Kidd. This was another disappointment, so much so that Blackburn, despite frantic expenditure, dropped out of the Premiership in 1999. Kidd did not last out the following season, being replaced by Graeme Souness, another former Liverpool and Scottish international, and Liverpool manager.

Walker was usually a shy and reclusive man, always eager to avoid publicity - except when his team won the Premiership and he exulted on the field. But at the end of 1998-99, he appeared before the fans at rebuilt Ewood Park to exhort them and his players. The ancient stadium had been transformed, a plenitude of back-to-back houses knocked down to accommodate it, not always to the satisfaction of their inhabitants. A plague of rising damp, the collapse of the cotton industry, a local authority which could not keep pace with such depredations: Blackburn Rovers alone, Jack Walker's creation, assuaged the populace.

He was just as generous in Jersey, where he successfully established his own airline, and, for many years, subsidised and supported the local First Tower United team, happy to sit among the fans to watch their amateur endeavours. "I get just as much enjoyment from First Tower as I do from watching Rovers," he said. "I'm just a dedicated supporter. I've travelled to matches with them on the coach, when the windows have been frozen outside and in. I come to every game and reserve games. I just love it. I even get drunk with them."

"I was always working," he used to say. "Until I got a chauffeur, I was driving up to 70,000 miles a year for my various companies, and travelling through Europe in the steel industry, mainly to Italy, Belgium and Germany." By the time he sold his company to British Steel, it was making an annual profit of £48m.

Legends grew up about Walker. In the 1960s, fearful of losing a deal, it is said that he persuaded a taxi-driver to take him through the ravages of Hurricane Donna, more than 1,000 miles down the east coast of America. They arrived, the deal was done - and the taxi-driver received an enormous tip.

Colin Jones, the secretary of First Tower, for whom Walker bought a training ground (just as he had done for Blackburn), said: "He's a very down-to-earth man, who loves nothing better than having a drink and a chip butty with the boys after the game. You would never know he had so much money."

Married to Carol, who survives him with two sons, Walker lived in a huge house amid 30 acres of grounds in St Helier. Last May, it was announced that he was fighting cancer - news that was all the sadder for the fact that Blackburn, despite his huge expenditure, stayed marooned in the first division of the Nationwide League.

Jack Walker, industrialist and football-lover, born May 19 1929; died August 17 2000

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: An Analysis piece yesterday on railway reforms (Another age of the train? page 17) said Connex South Central was unwilling to give up its franchise before expiry in 2003, thus holding up a replacement. While Connex is negotiating for a new franchise, it has never ruled out relinquishing the present one early.
fields.body:
An Analysis piece yesterday on railway reforms (Another age of the train? page 17) said Connex South Central was unwilling to give up its franchise before expiry in 2003, thus holding up a replacement. While Connex is negotiating for a new franchise, it has never ruled out relinquishing the present one early.

An article on student debt, page 12, A-levels supplement, Clearing 2000, August 17, said most applicants sought the maximum student loan "as you cannot apply for a top-up later". It also said the money came in a lump sum or three equal instalments. The Department for Education says students can apply twice and pay-outs can vary: "If they apply for their loan between the start of the second and third term, they get the funds in two instalments; if they apply in their third term, they get one payment."

Tampering with the life of Angela Rippon continues. A panel yesterday, page 3, G2, said the former newsreader performed her high kicks on the Morecambe and Wise Christmas show in 1977. She did make a brief appearance that year, but as our correction said yesterday, her famous debut was 1976.

This column did err yesterday in naming the actor who played Kookie in the 1958-64 American TV series, 77 Sunset Strip. He was Edd Byrnes, not Ed Burns.

fields.headline: Speaking in tongues
fields.trailText: As a teacher of English now working in Italy, I have often made Michael White's point (Comment, August 17), that being a mother-tongue speaker of the world's lingua franca puts one at a cultural and commercial disadvantage, to my students.
fields.body:
As a teacher of English now working in Italy, I have often made Michael White's point (Comment, August 17), that being a mother-tongue speaker of the world's lingua franca puts one at a cultural and commercial disadvantage, to my students. Faced with the costs and difficulties of studying English as well as earning a living, they are often unwilling to concede the point. "You English don't have to bother with French/Italian/German", they say. "No," I reply, "but when I take the train across Europe, I'm expected to know the language of every country I pass through if I want to avoid looking like a stupid foreigner - you are only expected to know a little English."

I sympathise with language teachers in British schools - how do they motivate pupils to take any interest in language learning when few of the languages offered have the coverage of English, let alone the MTV street cred, and when students may have no interest in or knowledge of the country where the language is spoken? Whatever difficulties my students face, they rarely lack reasons to try.

Daniel Stephens, Bologna, Italy

English incompetence in foreign languages may have paid off, but the arrogant cultural imperialism you so often witness abroad makes me want to throw up. In a restaurant in Italy I listened to English holidaymakers reading the menu out, giggling over their inability to pronounce or understand it. When I asked the owner how she could stand it, she said: "We serve them, we smile at them and we charge them about three times as much as our local customers." Quite right too.

Bridget Patterson, Melton, Suffolk

webTitle: Letters: Only the cash is green

fields.headline: Only the cash is green
fields.trailText: In the presidential elections (A vote for Nader is a vote for Bush, August 17) Americans face the same old Tweedledee or Tweedledum, two parties financed and driven by the big dollars of corporate America.
fields.body:
In the presidential elections (A vote for Nader is a vote for Bush, August 17) Americans face the same old Tweedledee or Tweedledum, two parties financed and driven by the big dollars of corporate America. Clinton backtracked on just about every promise made to working people; the great wealth boast was at the top, as it was with Bush before him. Ralph Nader's vote will be a protest, but it only points up the need for a party of labour. Only when the trade unions stop bankrolling the Democrats, who kick them in the teeth every time, and start seriously posing a real alternative will the US public have a real choice. I predict a massive abstention in these elections.

R Faulkes, London

Although we concur with George Monbiot's analysis of the democratic deficit in US politics, when he talks about Green candidate Ralph Nader's support base, he assumes support for Nader will be at Al Gore's expense.

Nader has supporters among new voters, former non-voters and even liberal-minded Republicans. When we attended his inaugural speech the last time he stood for the presidency, he was heckled by a small group of Republicans. They felt that, as an establishment figure within the legal profession, Nader's advocacy of personal liberty and consumer rights made him an ideal choice as a moderate Republican candidate.

Cllr Craig Simmons and Cllr Elise Benjamin, US Monitors, Green Party

George Monbiot would sacrifice the world to four years of George W Bush on the basis of the calculation that chastened Democrats would kick out corporate funding to win back Ralph Nader's support. The next Democratic nominee is more likely to stay just as attached to his/her millions while adopting a few token green policies. Sustained grassroots pressure is a better guarantee of progressive green policies than egotistical adventures in electoral politics.

Dr Adam Lent, Edgware, Middx

fields.headline: Parable of the pedalo
fields.standfirst: But do not rush off to follow it
fields.trailText: It makes last year's circumnavigation of the earth in a balloon by the British-Swiss team look "easy-peasy". After all, that only took 20 days.
fields.body:
It makes last year's circumnavigation of the earth in a balloon by the British-Swiss team look "easy-peasy". After all, that only took 20 days.

Robbie Knievel, Evel Knievel's son, who last year became the first person to jump the Grand Canyon on a motorbike, would probably concede his challenge was easier. For it is seven years since two British adventurers left Greenwich to pedal their way round the world - by boat and bike. They began in July, 1994, bicycling to Rye before beginning an epic 4,900 mile pedalo journey across the Atlantic. It was part of the "pedal for the planet" programme, endorsed by Unesco. Part of its purpose was to remind people of the possibility of human power - and part to inspire young people to "follow their dreams". Jason Lewis, 32, from Bridport, Dorset, has now completed the first east-west crossing of the Atlantic and the first Pacific crossing, all 9,000 miles, by pedal boat. Yesterday, he talked to the press about shark attacks, sea pirates and the problem of the tides, which sometimes exceed the pull and power of even experienced boat pedallers. Now he is planning to bike - and roller blade - across Australia. What could be more romantic?

Before the young rush off in an armada of pedalos from Britain's western ports, we should perhaps remind readers of what Jason's first partner, Steve Smith, told us last year. He lasted five years but bailed out in Hawaii. The first problem was finance - "schmoozing existing sponsors and finding new ones". The men were forced to work in various boatyards to raise cash. Then there's the pedalling - almost permanent pedalling "like a hamster in its cage" with a "rat-hole of a bed" and living space only 10ft long. But worst of all, was the failure to achieve the simplicity sought: "The cost of having this very, very ambitious scheme means that you really don't have time to get back to simplicity." That's the parable of the pedalo in the Pacific.

fields.headline: A princely offer
fields.trailText: As chair of the St Andrews University Labour Club, I would like to congratulate Prince William on his exam results and wish him well for his year out (William makes the grade, August 16). We look forward to recruiting him at the societies fair next September.
fields.body:
As chair of the St Andrews University Labour Club, I would like to congratulate Prince William on his exam results and wish him well for his year out (William makes the grade, August 16). We look forward to recruiting him at the societies fair next September.

Nicholas Jones, St Andrews University

Is there a student in the country whose future is less dependent on their exam results than Prince William? Do we really need a third of a page in the main paper and a whole page in G2 devoted to this young man? Please leave the Royals to the tabloids.

Peter Halsey, London

Is this government that wasted £800m on the benefits card (Report, August 18) the same as the one that regularly attacks local government for incompetence and inefficiency?

Roger Backhouse, Ilford, Essex

"Sexually mature men"? (Letters, August 18). An example of an oxymoron, surely?

Ian Thompson, Enfield, Middx

What is a sexually mature man supposed to do with a Mars Bar?

Martin Rathfelder, Manchester

The Concise Oxford dictionary defines mature as being "ripe", having fully developed powers or duly careful and accurate. As a 73-year-old, I was just asking (Letters, August 17) for clarification and accurate information regarding the Mars Bar and therefore to my mind behaving in a sexually mature manner.

Jack Hill, St Albans, Herts

For the first time in years David Lacey has not tipped Southampton as a likely relegation prospect (Sport, August 18). Does this mean that, at last, they really are doomed?

Terry Vincent, Woking, Surrey

fields.headline: Testing time for boys
fields.trailText: How refreshing to read correspondence on A-level results (Letters, August 18) that recognises and congratulates achievement - the annual ritual of slating teachers and devaluing the efforts of students is intolerable and unjust.
fields.body:
How refreshing to read correspondence on A-level results (Letters, August 18) that recognises and congratulates achievement - the annual ritual of slating teachers and devaluing the efforts of students is intolerable and unjust.

It's true that in previous years boys have outstripped girls. But this issue has concerned educators for some time; a plethora of books and theses on the subject has been written. Consequently, numerous initiatives have been conducted at local, regional and national level to improve female attainment. The success of such strategies, combined with wider societal changes, is becoming apparent: for some time girls have been outperforming boys at GCSE and now, it appears, the chronological migration of this success to A-level has begun. This may eventually lead to a reversal in the gender disparity of university results.

Male superiority is certainly not regarded as "the normal course of things" - at least, not by teachers. Our overriding concern is to get the best possible results from every individual, regardless of sex, race, religion - or sexuality. Underachievement at school is an exceptionally destructive force in terms of a child's life-chances.

Morgan Thomas, Wembley, Middlesex

More girls than boys passed the old 11-plus exam, but it was deemed necessary for equal numbers of boys and girls to "succeed" to grammar school, so more girls were "failed". Surely this affected past A-level results? As one who "failed" and then suddenly became top-of-the-class at the local secondary modern, I am now embarking on my masters degree aged 36. I can't help feeling I could have got here 10 years earlier.

Celia Fowler, London

Maybe boys would get a more positive image of academic achievement if instead of the now ubiquitous front-page picture of attractive girls getting brilliant A-level results (August 18), there were pictures of some attractive looking boys, or a even a mixed group, doing likewise. It seems that media images of boys doing well academically fall into either the expensively educated or "Owl of the Remove variety". Girls shown doing well seem always to be ordinary kids, the sort of person you'd like to meet and, if you are younger, be like.

Jane Tomlin, Wylam, Northumberland

The annual school exam hysteria reminds me of a Cup Final. Weren't comprehensive schools meant to reduce the "winners" and "losers" culture?

Max Nottingham, Lincoln

I have taught A-level for nine years, I honestly do not know whether standards have risen, fallen or gone sideways in that time, because the many syllabus changes make comparisons well-nigh impossible. I do know one thing: you cannot measure the achievement of a student in any subject with complete objectivity; we are not weighing potatoes or counting money.

John Purser, Hoddesdon, Herts

At 47, I have just had my English Literature A-level result. I see no evidence of a softening of standards since I sat A-levels at a grammar school 30 years ago - the teachers at my FE college were just as demanding and the syllabus and marking schemes seem as rigorous as ever.

Tim Griggs, London

A-levels was a lot harder in my days. That's why I didn't get none.

K Holmes, Witham, Essex

webTitle: Naive Nick, from Big Brother, flounders before media

fields.headline: Naive Nick flounders before media
fields.standfirst: Special report: Big Brother
fields.trailText: The pantomime villain of the voyeuristic game show Big Brother turned out yesterday not to be so much of a scheming Machiavelli after all.
fields.body:
The pantomime villain of the voyeuristic game show Big Brother turned out yesterday not to be so much of a scheming Machiavelli after all.

More naive than nasty, and unable to comprehend the interest in his fate, Nick Bateman faced the media with an often contradictory and incomplete explanation for his behaviour over the past few weeks at the centre of a television phenomenon.

He told reporters in London that he expected the softly-spoken former trainee nun, Anna Nolan, to walk away with the £70,000 prize; yet predicted to Davina McCall on Channel 4 that rival contestant Tom would emerge the victor.

It was meant to be reality: but the bank of television cameras trained on the podium at a central London hotel appeared far more intrusive than the smaller, wall-mounted versions that keep watch over the Big Brother house. And it was meant to be a press conference, but reporters' attempts to elicit a coherent explanation foundered, just as the attempts of his bewildered fellow contestants to establish a motive for his actions had failed the day before.

"It's a game show, not a garden party," he said several times, in answer to questions on his motives for playing off his fellow contestants against each other.

But neither was he playing to win. "I was playing to participate and people thought I was playing to win. I was planning to get as far - and enjoy the experience - as I could."

So why spin a fanciful tale of tragedy, in which he attempted to elicit sympathy by describing how a fictional wife had been killed in a honeymoon car crash? "At that time, the house was going through a very strange process of the first nomination." Did he regret it? "Yes, I regret saying it."

Not once did Nick, 32, answer a question about his motives directly. There were evasions, pauses and contradictions. Curiously, he confessed he had not yet spoken to his family. It seemed even nasty Nick could not bring himself to admit how devious he had been. "I'm just an ordinary guy who took part in a very unusual experiment under a lot of scrutiny and a lot of pressure," he said. "I haven't committed a murder - it's a very small error."

As he faced the world, his former housemates were getting used to life without treachery in their midst. Could they now trust each other? How would they cope with the next month together? And what about the new arrival, the replacement for Nick that is demanded by the game show rules? (Nick was kicked out not in the usual process of nomination by the contestants, who put up two of their number for a public vote each week, but by the show's producers after his attempts to influence the votes of his fellow flatmates were revealed.)

This week's nomination process was declared valid after the contestants gave an assurance that they had not succumbed to manipulation. Transformed from cheery Scouser to national hero after uncovering Nick's antics - yet sparing him extensive humiliation - Craig Phillips was expected to survive the telephone vote last night. His sister, Beverley, 31, said: "I am so proud. Nick is an ex-public schoolboy with all that expensive education and Craig just wiped the floor with him."

Nichola's exit makes it more likely that the show's producers will replace Nick with a woman: they were considering their choice from a shortlist of four.

The only victor appeared to be Channel 4, which was celebrating record viewing figures. Thursday night's show, which played out the denouement in full, was watched at its peak by almost 63% of the available audience. An average of 5.5m people tuned in - for a late-night show, outside peak time, these are figures with which the mighty BBC1 and ITV would be delighted. It was the highest-rated programme for Channel 4 since the screening of Four Weddings and a Funeral in 1995.

Matt Baker, Channel 4's head of press, declared: "It's a ratings phenomenon."

webTitle: Letters: Nick is in a class of his own

fields.headline: Nick is in a class of his own
fields.trailText: The so-called "pike amongst minnows", Nick Bateman, has gone (Report, August 18). Perhaps now Big Brother can refrain from class stereotyping.
fields.body:
The so-called "pike amongst minnows", Nick Bateman, has gone (Report, August 18). Perhaps now Big Brother can refrain from class stereotyping. Born to succeed, public school, City, as the show's experts have presented him, Nick is shown to be nothing but a liar. Some of the "minnows", such as Caroline and Craig, on the other hand have displayed emotional intelligence and decency. One for the class war and against middle-class TV moguls.

Gerry Hassan, Glasgow

Big Brother last Thursday was one of the most fascinating pieces of television I have ever seen. I'm so glad Nick was evicted. It was typical that someone of his class would believe himself to be above the laws of society and subsequently the rules of the game show. But the ratings may go down now, because everybody, myself included, loves a baddie.

Paul Taylor, Stockton on Tees, Cleveland

The downfall of Big Brother's Nicholas resulted from his personal pursuit of success at any cost. It seems there is hope for socialism.

Ceri England, Manchester

A front page and a leader on Big Brother, while brief coverage of the leaked privatisation "safety threat" to the London tube is relegated to page five?

Gerald Crompton, Canterbury

Big Brother has reduced a once great paper to the level of witless drivel. I presume you enjoy the sound of James Cameron turning in his grave?

Kit Jackson, London

fields.headline: Call it off
fields.trailText: The most remarkable fact about the chief rail inspector's letter ('Safety at Risk' in Tube sell-Off, August 18) is that it was written at all.
fields.body:
The most remarkable fact about the chief rail inspector's letter ('Safety at Risk' in Tube sell-Off, August 18) is that it was written at all. Notwithstanding the efforts and commitments of hundreds of field inspectors, the HSE has never adopted anything like a "punitive" approach to safety. HSE chiefs see the organisation's role as educating, advising, sometimes cajoling a little, rather than referring to companies' legal duties and actually enforcing health and safety law; companies are given a great deal - indeed, far too much - latitude in this area. So, when this mouse roars, even New Labour should sit up and listen. For the sake of safety - let alone cost and efficiency - even Prescott must now see that this is a privatisation too far.

Prof Steve Tombs, Liverpool John Moores University

fields.headline: War cry
fields.trailText: Your leader (August 18) does not deign to refute the charge that Nato's action in Kosovo was illegal, immoral and stupid, asserting merely that action "had to be taken".
fields.body:
Your leader (August 18) does not deign to refute the charge that Nato's action in Kosovo was illegal, immoral and stupid, asserting merely that action "had to be taken". This shameful and cowardly action cost many non-Nato lives, caused great material and moral damage and achieved little beyond underlining our irrational faith in force and subservience to the US. The Guardian may have had its reservations, but nevertheless it sided with the ruthless and the credulous, the bombers and the liars. To go on even now trying to justify such a stance without offering better reasons seems extraordinary.

David Gentleman, London

Instead of the 10,000 dead claimed, there are around 3,000. So we didn't need to bother, then?

Simon Hunter, Brookmans Park, Herts

fields.headline: Prescott unveils green manifesto
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Labour's manifesto is likely to promise the abolition of fuel poverty among the poor and elderly by 2010 as part of a "green housekeeping" package designed to win back support among disadvantaged voters.
fields.body:
Labour's manifesto is likely to promise the abolition of fuel poverty among the poor and elderly by 2010 as part of a "green housekeeping" package designed to win back support among disadvantaged voters.

Next month's party conference in Brighton will be asked to endorse a 12 point plan that would also commit Labour to a national noise strategy, and involve voters in decisions on GM foods and other environmental matters.

John Prescott yesterday told Labour activists that the government would bow to demands at their national policy forum in Exeter last month, and seek to overcome fuel poverty in 10 years instead of the 20 years envisaged.

That will translate into a firm promise to pensioners (many angry over Labour's 75p a week increase in the basic pension this April) to cut the money they spend on keeping their homes warm to under 10% of their weekly income, the official definition of "fuel poverty".

The pledge should benefit 3.3m households by offering grants of up to £2,000 to improve home insulation and thereby lower fuel bills.

In a letter to activists today, the deputy prime minister will also commit a second-term Labour government to introducing an environmental productivity index (EPI), copying economic models for improving labour productivity. Just as firms constantly seek to get more work out of employees and equipment, so the EPI would generate pressure to create economic growth using less energy and fewer resources.

Mr Prescott praised the party's consultative process for enabling ministers to listen to ideas on environmental issues from unions such as MSF and Unison, and from the Socialist Environmental and Resources Association. "It has allowed us to argue through the difficult issues and test out new policy suggestions," he said.

"Our policies are costed, worked-through and credible. Compare our wide-ranging policy process with William Hague's desperate call for manifesto ideas... on the back of an envelope."

The proposed package for submission to the Brighton conference and then to Labour's manifesto-writing team would include:

 eradication of fuel poverty by 2010, not 2020;

 higher recycling and waste reduction targets and more incentives to reduce waste;

 improvements in energy efficiency, especially in the home;

 more money to develop off-shore wind power and other renewable energy;

 no commercial cultivation of GM crops until 2003 and then only if proved safe for public health and the environment;

 citizen commissions and similar consultative mechanisms to address health and environmental concerns;

 more environmental investment and jobs through energy efficiency programmes;

 leading the fight against climate change, including new ideas for Kyoto-style trades between states on carbon dioxide emissions;

 water supplies at lower prices and with higher quality;

 national strategies to address noise, rubbish and other pollutants;

 neighbourhood wardens to enforce higher standards;

 environmentally friendly public procurement policies;

 action to protect and increase wildlife diversity.

Mr Prescott said: "Our new pledge on fuel poverty gives a flavour of what we will be offering to the electorate - tackling social exclusion, delivering for pensioners, improving our health and protecting the environment."

webTitle: Diabetes oral drug cleared for NHS

fields.headline: Diabetes oral drug cleared for NHS
fields.standfirst:
Panel recommends limited usage but ruling will still cost millions

Special report: the future of the NHS
fields.trailText: A new diabetes drug which could help thousands of people avoid the need for daily insulin injections should be made available on the NHS, the government body charged with assessing new medicines said today.
fields.body:
A new diabetes drug which could help thousands of people avoid the need for daily insulin injections should be made available on the NHS, the government body charged with assessing new medicines said today.

But the ruling by the national institute for clinical excellence could cost the health service millions of pounds.

A panel of experts from Nice concluded that the drug Avandia, made by SmithKline Beecham, should be offered to sufferers of type 2 diabetes, which affects around 800,000 people in England and Wales.

But the medical and lay experts have recommended that it should be offered only to patients unable to take traditional combinations of older drugs or if those have not proved effective.

Avandia is one of a new range of glucose-lowering drugs for diabetes which can be taken orally, rather than by injection.

Diabetes sufferers complain that the need for daily injections of life-saving insulin means they face discrimination and driving restrictions, as well as the physical toll of administering the jabs.

It is also thought that Avandia can give better protection against the damage to blood vessels which diabetes causes, and reduce the risk of heart and kidney disease, strokes, blindness and ulcers.

Andrew Dillon, chief executive of Nice, said: "This new guidance is an example of the way Nice intends to support and promote clinically and cost effective new medicines at the time they become available. Our guidance should ensure uniform take-up of rosiglitazone [the medical name for Avandia] throughout the NHS."

Nice was set up last year to issue guidance on which new drugs and therapies should be available on the NHS in England and Wales, and end so-called postcode prescribing, where new treatments are available from some health authorities and not others.

Experts make decisions based on the clinical benefits and cost-effectiveness of drugs and the government is expected to accept the latest guidance.

But the body has made some controversial decisions, including a recommendation that the flu drug Relenza should not be prescribed on the NHS. There have been claims that this is "rationing by the back door".

The junior health minister, Gisela Stuart, said: "Today's guidance opens up options for treating some patients with diabetes.

"It is another step towards our goal of ensuring that people with diabetes have equal access to the best treatments wherever they live."

Avandia has been available for a year in the US and is used by around a million diabetics.

It costs £320-£640 a year per patient, depending on the individual dose.

Suzanne Lucas, director of care at the charity Diabetes UK, said: "It is vital that greater effort is made to prevent the long term complications of diabetes by keeping good control of blood glucose levels.

"Any treatment which promises to help this should be available to everyone that needs it.

"Avandia may well allow those who would otherwise be considered for insulin therapy to delay this, thus avoiding the difficulties and discrimination, such as driving restrictions, with which insulin therapy can be associated."

Avandia has been available for a year in the US and is used by around a million diabetics. It costs £320-£640 a year per patient, depending on the individual dose. Suzanne Lucas, director of care at the charity Diabetes UK, said: "It is vital that greater effort is made to prevent the long term complications of diabetes by keeping good control of blood glucose levels. "Any treatment which promises to help this should be available to everyone that needs it. "Avandia may well allow those who would otherwise be considered for insulin therapy to delay this, thus avoiding the difficulties and discrimination, such as driving restrictions, with which insulin therapy can be associated."

fields.headline: Pedalling Briton tames Pacific
fields.standfirst: Global traveller leaves storms and gunmen in his wake
fields.trailText: He has battled storm force winds, 20ft ocean swells and sharks, but when Jason Lewis spotted gunmen approaching his pedalo off the Solomon Islands he knew drastic action was needed.
fields.body:
He has battled storm force winds, 20ft ocean swells and sharks, but when Jason Lewis spotted gunmen approaching his pedalo off the Solomon Islands he knew drastic action was needed.

He stripped off, stood up stark naked and waved wildly at the militiamen. They dropped their automatic weapons, turned their speedboat around and fled.

Yesterday, Mr Lewis celebrated completing a near 7,000-mile pedal boat voyage from the United States to Australia. The 32-year-old from Bridport, Dorset, and 42-year-old teacher April Abril pedalled the 26ft craft into Port Douglas on the Queensland coast at 6am BST yesterday.

"We had a great reception on the final run in, with every boat which passed us shouting, waving, honking horns and lobbing beers at the boat," said Mr Lewis, who admitted he was having trouble walking because of salt water sores from being permanently wet.

He made landfall with Ms Abril, from Rye, Colorado, who rejoined the £26,000 wooden self-righting vessel, Moksha, for the last eight or nine miles of the 1,100 mile voyage from Tulagi in the Solomon Islands. She had been transferred off Moksha for a medical check-up after the craft was towed through the Great Barrier Reef to prevent it being smashed.

With no charts for the area, the pair accepted an 11-mile tow through the treacherous reef following a hair-raising week of adverse tides, huge seas and 30 knot winds which blew the expedition 130 miles north of its target, Cairns.

Speaking from Port Douglas, Mr Lewis, a musician, said: "It is so great to be off the boat, but it is only just sinking in what has been achieved.

"It is a huge deal, we have just crossed the biggest ocean in the world by human power. Three or four days ago we faced a pretty serious situation and were getting blown on to the reef itself in 30 knot winds.

"During the last 10 days we were pedalling full bore southwards against the trade winds but we were slowly going backwards so we had to use a sea anchor, which is like a giant parachute, to check our drift."

The voyage was part of Mr Lewis's 35,000-mile, human-powered circumnavigation of the world, which began in London six years ago. But the expedition is in desperate financial straits, and Mr Lewis said he hoped the Pacific crossing would generate sponsorship.

Ms Abril, for whom the trip was her first sea voyage, said: "I am really happy and excited to have had the chance to do it. It was such a test of perseverance to hang in there. I lost quite a bit of weight, but I never lost my desire to pedal."

During the journey the pair had little chance of privacy, but working as a team, which included fighting off a marauding 14 ft shark which tried to eat their propeller, the pair overcame any shyness.

Mr Lewis's journey began from Greenwich in July 1994, and he has travelled more than 20,000 miles in his vessel, which is equipped with a satellite phone, global positioning system and desalination plant.

He started with Steve Smith, from Wolverhampton, who left to pursue other projects after helping to pedal the Moksha from San Francisco to Hawaii on the first 2,200-mile Pacific leg.

Mr Lewis then went solo for the next leg - a 2,200 voyage to Tarawa, in the Kiribati Republic.

He was joined for the 1,100-mile leg from Tarawa to the Solomon Islands by 34-year-old Chris Tipper, from Brighton, who built the Moksha but had never sailed it. Ms Abril, who had helped with the expedition's schools education programme, joined him for the final leg.

Now he is in Australia, Mr Lewis plans to cycle and roller blade across the country before heading back towards Europe across Asia - another three or four years and 15,000 miles of travelling before he returns to Greenwich.

Describing a cramped and cold life on the ocean waves, eating mainly porridge, supplemented by M&Ms and Mars Bars, Mr Lewis said the pedalo offered little shelter from the elements. The only moments of comfort were during the gruelling 12 hour pedalling shifts. Because they were permanently damp, with waves constantly drenching their sleeping bags, pedalling was the only way to keep warm. And Ms Abril suffered sea sickness.

webTitle: Pilot killed as plane plunges into sea during aerobatic show

fields.headline: Pilot killed as plane plunges into sea during aerobatic show
fields.trailText: A pilot died yesterday when his fighter jet crashed into the sea in front of thousands of spectators as he tried to complete a complex aerobatic display.
fields.body:
A pilot died yesterday when his fighter jet crashed into the sea in front of thousands of spectators as he tried to complete a complex aerobatic display.

The man, who has not been named, was five minutes into his act at a four-day air show in Eastbourne, East Sussex, when he failed to pull out of a diving roll and plunged 2,000ft into the water, just 800 yards from the seafront.

He did not eject and died instantly when his two-seater L29 Delfin disintegrated on hitting the water and sank. Emergency services were immediately scrambled, and a diver recovered the man's body.

The accident happened at Airbourne 2000, the south coast's biggest air event.

The lifeboatman who helped to recover the body said it was extraordinary there had been just one casualty.

"It was 200 or 300 yards from three of the safety boats which were patrolling the area and we are all lucky to be alive," said Gary Mead, an RNLI volunteer.

A fellow lifeboatman, who gave his name as Brian, said: "If he had skimmed across the water he'd have gone straight into the crowd."

Brian's son, 29, added: "He was coming in at probably a 45-degree angle and tried to pull up but belly-flopped into the sea. He just didn't have enough space. There was a flash, a big spray of water and a huge noise."

Another onlooker said: "He went about 400ft vertical in the air to do a turn and dived back down again.

"He did that twice, but on the second time he did not pull out of it and plunged into the sea. There was a massive splash. There was no way anyone could have survived that. It was awful."

Others spoke of debris flying through the air as the shattered plane billowed smoke.

"It was quite a terrible atmosphere," said Moira Mogford, 68, a retired air traffic controller.

"One minute everyone was laughing and joking, the next it was an incredible sense of disbelief. Everything went silent, it was horrible."

Eastbourne borough council, the organiser of the annual event, which last year drew 500,000 people, cancelled the rest of the day's flying but said the air show would continue over the weekend.

In the aftermath of the crash it emerged that the pilot had been due to fly a different plane at the air show, but the L39 Albatross he had chosen was substituted for his own Delfin because of a problem with its ejector seat.

Three inspectors from the air accident investigation bureau were last night beginning their inquiry into how the plane, built in Czechoslovakia in the 1960s and of a type often used as a training plane for the Red Arrows team, could have been involved in such a tragedy.

The accident is the first to have occurred during the nine years the event has been running, and last night council officials were keen to stress it was exceptional.

"It is extremely regrettable that the pilot has died but fortunately no members of the public were injured because the pilot was flying in the exclusion zone, where he was meant to," said Barbara Goodall, a member of Eastbourne tourism committee.

"We must stress that everything was done to make this show safe."

The council said onlookers were being urged to stay out of the sea after two swimmers were taken to hospital after swallowing aircraft fuel.

webTitle: Soldier crushed by vehicle during mock battle

fields.headline: Soldier crushed by vehicle during mock battle
fields.trailText: A young soldier was crushed to death when an Army personnel carrier reversed during a simulated battle, an inquest was told yesterday.
fields.body:
A young soldier was crushed to death when an Army personnel carrier reversed during a simulated battle, an inquest was told yesterday.

Lance Corporal Andrew Smith, 21, from Barry, south Wales, was run over during an exercise in Sennelager, Germany, in preparation for a posting to Bosnia. He had only recently undergone training for armoured infantry.

Cardiff coroner Lawrence Addicott, who recorded a verdict of accidental death, heard that Lance Corporal Smith, who was serving with the 1st battalion of the Royal Regiment of Wales, stepped out of the moving personnel carrier in the belief that the battalion was about to go into battle, on July 30, 1999.

But as he followed the vehicle it reversed and he slipped and was trapped underneath and crushed, the inquest was told.

Captain Malcolm Downey of the Royal Military police special investigation branch said the soldier in the back of the Warrior vehicle would not have been able to tell the driver that Lance Corporal Smith had got out of the personnel carrier because he would have taken his headphones off in the belief that he also was about to go into battle.

The driver reversed quickly after deciding that to continue in the same path would have damaged several trees and so breached environmental rules.

Lance Corporal Smith was trapped after slipping in the path of the reversing vehicle. By the time the driver had moved the personnel carrier forward again, Lance Corporal Smith's chest and abdomen had been crushed, and attempts to resuscitate him failed.

Capt Downey said the army had introduced safety measures to prevent similar accidents. These included fitting an audible alarm to alert drivers that the back door of the vehicle was open and soldiers had dismounted.

fields.headline: Latest poll shows Bush trailing
fields.standfirst:
Protesters, police and delegates all claim success in Los Angeles

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: The first reactions to Al Gore's speech were positive with an instant ABC poll showing Mr Gore ahead of George W Bush by 46% to 43%. While the poll comes with the usual health warnings, it is in sharp contrast to the instant poll after the Republican convention two weeks ago which showed Mr Bush with a 17 point lead.
fields.body:
The first reactions to Al Gore's speech were positive with an instant ABC poll showing Mr Gore ahead of George W Bush by 46% to 43%. While the poll comes with the usual health warnings, it is in sharp contrast to the instant poll after the Republican convention two weeks ago which showed Mr Bush with a 17 point lead.

The results of the poll were reflected by reactions both inside and outside of the convention. Joan Groener, a Democrat attending the convention as a guest, said: "He may be a little stiff but that doesn't matter. He's got what it takes to lead this country. Mr Gore's smart and, bless him, Mr Bush ain't."

Andres Torres, 82, a former social worker, said: "I voted for Roosevelt when I was in the army and I had a great admiration for Gore's father. I think that Gore has shown he is for the working man, the less-chance people. He's shown that he's head and shoulders above Bush. You've got to look into his heart: he wants to help."

Gonzalo Rojas, 21, a student from San Diego, said: "I think that Gore has shown that he represents the ideals that I was raised to respect."

As Mr Gore was receiving his ecstatic standing ovation inside the Staples Centre, around 5,000 protesters were gathered outside in the designated demonstration area as the week's protests ended. Most of the demonstrators then marched through the night under the watchful eye of a police helicopter to the Twin Towers jail in central Los Angeles where those who had been arrested during the week and not bailed were being held. A total of 194 people were arrested during the week.

A rally with the singing of Bob Marley's No Woman, No Cry and Zapatista songs took place as relatives of people who had died in custody made brief speeches. There was a minute's silence for "the brothers and sisters in Twin Towers".

Once again there were tense standoffs between the two sides and once again the demonstration passed off mostly peacefully. Earlier in the day there had been a march against sweat-shops through the city centre.

Lisa Fithian, one of the members of D2KLA, which had helped to coordinate the week's protests said: "I think it's been an amazingly successful week. People came here with the goal of bringing their messages to the delegates in a powerful and creative way and they have done that. We faced police violence and we de-escalated it." She said that the movement had learned a lot about organisation in the week and about working out future strategy.

"I think people have been showing a lot of maturity and showing that it's not just here today and gone tomorrow," Ms Fithian said. "I have heard that the delegates are talking about the protests." She said she had been disappointed in some of the media coverage: "We had a march of 20,000 strong and it got bumped from the news."

Commander David Kalish of the LAPD expressed his satisfaction with the week's events: "Generally we are quite pleased." He said that the demonstrators had been largely peaceful. It was confirmed that police "scouts" had mingled with the crowd and some had even been arrested and shot at when police opened fire on two occasions with rubber bullets. Many businesses reopened yesterday after shuttering their premises in anticipation of violence.

Inside the convention, Kathleen Kennedy Townsend, the lieutenant-governor of Maryland and the eldest daughter of Robert Kennedy, who was assassinated in Los Angeles, acknowledged the protesters at a briefing with the foreign press.

"I'm very excited about the protests and it gives me great hope for the future," Ms Townsend said. "The worst threat to democracy is apathy and indifference. They are raising serious issues about the globalisation of the economy. We are blessed by the protests."

webTitle: Large payout likely for sex case worker

fields.headline: Large payout likely for sex case worker
fields.trailText: A mortgage adviser stands to be awarded tens of thousands of pounds after an employment tribunal yesterday ruled she had been sexually harassed by her manager.
fields.body:
A mortgage adviser stands to be awarded tens of thousands of pounds after an employment tribunal yesterday ruled she had been sexually harassed by her manager.

Instead of studying sales figures in after hours meetings, Robert Allen masturbated in front of Monika Sheridan, exposed himself, and showed her pornography. He also made offensive phone calls, the tribunal in Ashford, Kent, was told last month.

Miss Sheridan, 45, from Chatham in Kent, was so traumatised she took no action for nearly six years, she told the tribunal. She alleged sexual harassment, personal injury, disability discrimination and constructive unfair dismissal against Arun Estate Agencies Ltd, parent company of Ward and Partners.

The tribunal yesterday upheld her claim of sexual harassment, although all the other claims were dismissed. She said afterward: "I'm grateful to everyone who has stood by me, and now I can get on and repair the things inside me that still need fixing."

In a statement to the tribunal, she had said that Allen, the financial director, gave her a job in 1991. By 1993 "I became frightened of him and tried to avoid these meetings. I needed to take action, but also I was afraid if I reported him I would lose my job."

She had claimed senior management did nothing to stop Mr Allen after several pleas for help. But the tribunal ruled that, though there was no doubt she suffered severe sexual harassment, and therefore the company was responsible, "it seems two managers acted very promptly, and cannot be criticised".

A company spokesman said it had been vindicated by this part of the ruling. Mr Allen had admitted all the obscenities at an internal disciplinary hearing days after the last incident, saying he had not been well.

The case made legal history after the tribunal used its discretion to hear it six years after the events. A later hearing will determine compensation.

fields.headline: Festival chiefs deny cash crisis
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Edinburgh festival 2000
fields.trailText: The organisers of the crisis-hit Edinburgh international festival last night shrugged off rumours that they were on the brink of bankruptcy.
fields.body:
The organisers of the crisis-hit Edinburgh international festival last night shrugged off rumours that they were on the brink of bankruptcy.

A disastrous run for the festival's four-hour centrepiece, the Barbaric Comedies - which has been playing to audiences of only a few hundred - has put huge strain on its already precarious finances.

The Spanish epic, translated by the Irish writer Frank McGuinness from the works of Ramon del Valle-Inclan for Dublin's Abbey Theatre, was only half full at its premiere on Monday. With another week to run, and despite heavy discounting of tickets, only around a quarter of the seats have been sold.

Last month the festival's artistic director Brian McMaster predicted that if the risk on the production did not pay off the event might go to the wall.

"We are trying to turn it into a piece of popular, spectacular theatre that talks to a lot of people," he said.

With reviews damning McGuinness's translation as a "parody, a case of excess run riot" and, in the case of the Daily Telegraph critic, "everything that is wrong, and rotten about the Edinburgh international festival", the writing now seems to be on the wall.

But yesterday, despite the increasing sense of doom surrounding the play, McMaster insisted that he had meant the remarks as a "joke", and that he would never risk the festival on a single production.

McMaster's five-year reign at the festival has been heavily criticised for its lack of adventure and for elitism, while the rival fringe has gone from strength to strength. But he maintains that the point of a festival like Edinburgh is that organisers can take a bet on productions that might otherwise never be staged.

Yesterday his spokeswoman said that while the Barbaric Comedies "had not been performing quite as well as we had hoped", the losses so far had been more than compensated for by the surprise success of the New York City Ballet at the 3,000-seat Edinburgh Playhouse.

"A festival like this is full of checks and balances, so what you lose on one you gain on the other. We are confident the Barbaric Comedies will pick up," she said.

Meanwhile, the Edinburgh film festival has turned up that rarest of beasts, an extremely good new British film which has rival distributors battling to sign it up. The Low Down, a wry urban love story starring Aidan Gillen of Queer As Folk fame, is the first feature from the Londoner Jamie Thraves, who has already stacked up a mantelpiece full of prizes for his short films. He also shot the award-winning video for Radiohead's song Just.

The film is a smart, funny and surprisingly sophisticated story about a group of twentysomething slackers in east London who are drifting towards that pivotal moment in life when mortgages and marriages begin to happen.

Critics are already comparing Thraves to Lynne Ramsay, the fastest rising star of the British screen, whose debut Ratcatcher won a Bafta last year and high praise at Cannes.

The other big hit of the festival so far has been the Brazilian film Me You Them, which tells the story of a peasant woman in Ceara state who manages to keep three husbands on the go at once.
fields.bodyText: The organisers of the crisis-hit Edinburgh international festival last night shrugged off rumours that they were on the brink of bankruptcy. A disastrous run for the festival's four-hour centrepiece, the Barbaric Comedies - which has been playing to audiences of only a few hundred - has put huge strain on its already precarious finances. The Spanish epic, translated by the Irish writer Frank McGuinness from the works of Ramon del Valle-Inclan for Dublin's Abbey Theatre, was only half full at its premiere on Monday. With another week to run, and despite heavy discounting of tickets, only around a quarter of the seats have been sold. Last month the festival's artistic director Brian McMaster predicted that if the risk on the production did not pay off the event might go to the wall. "We are trying to turn it into a piece of popular, spectacular theatre that talks to a lot of people," he said. With reviews damning McGuinness's translation as a "parody, a case of excess run riot" and, in the case of the Daily Telegraph critic, "everything that is wrong, and rotten about the Edinburgh international festival", the writing now seems to be on the wall. But yesterday, despite the increasing sense of doom surrounding the play, McMaster insisted that he had meant the remarks as a "joke", and that he would never risk the festival on a single production. McMaster's five-year reign at the festival has been heavily criticised for its lack of adventure and for elitism, while the rival fringe has gone from strength to strength. But he maintains that the point of a festival like Edinburgh is that organisers can take a bet on productions that might otherwise never be staged. Yesterday his spokeswoman said that while the Barbaric Comedies "had not been performing quite as well as we had hoped", the losses so far had been more than compensated for by the surprise success of the New York City Ballet at the 3,000-seat Edinburgh Playhouse. "A festival like this is full of checks and balances, so what you lose on one you gain on the other. We are confident the Barbaric Comedies will pick up," she said. Meanwhile, the Edinburgh film festival has turned up that rarest of beasts, an extremely good new British film which has rival distributors battling to sign it up. The Low Down, a wry urban love story starring Aidan Gillen of Queer As Folk fame, is the first feature from the Londoner Jamie Thraves, who has already stacked up a mantelpiece full of prizes for his short films. He also shot the award-winning video for Radiohead's song Just. The film is a smart, funny and surprisingly sophisticated story about a group of twentysomething slackers in east London who are drifting towards that pivotal moment in life when mortgages and marriages begin to happen. Critics are already comparing Thraves to Lynne Ramsay, the fastest rising star of the British screen, whose debut Ratcatcher won a Bafta last year and high praise at Cannes. The other big hit of the festival so far has been the Brazilian film Me You Them, which tells the story of a peasant woman in Ceara state who manages to keep three husbands on the go at once.

fields.headline: Gore wins over the doubters
fields.standfirst:
Presidential hopeful seizes his moment and opens up the race for the White House

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Al Gore offered Americans a continuation of Bill Clinton's centrist policies dressed in more class-conscious language in his acceptance speech to the Democratic convention in Los Angeles, and then set off at once for the battleground states where the US election will be won and lost in November.
fields.body:
Al Gore offered Americans a continuation of Bill Clinton's centrist policies dressed in more class-conscious language in his acceptance speech to the Democratic convention in Los Angeles, and then set off at once for the battleground states where the US election will be won and lost in November.

Mr Gore's speech was universally seen as the most important 51 minutes of his political life, because he had to calm the worries of a party that feared he was a loser and persuade the general public that he has what it takes to set his stamp on the post-Clinton era.

Early assessments were that Mr Gore did what he had to do, energising his supporters and reaching out to uncommitted voters in a more conversational style than he has achieved in the past.

Thursday's news that a new grand jury had been empanelled in Washington to examine Mr Clinton's conduct in the Monica Lewinsky affair failed to derail either Mr Gore's big moment in Los Angeles or the politically crucial American media coverage of it yesterday. None of the US television networks featured the Clinton story on breakfast time bulletins, while the Los Angeles Times relegated the story to an inside page.

The now officially nominated Democratic presidential candidate and his running mate, Joe Lieberman, lost no time in taking their message to middle America. Only hours after wrapping up the conven tion in California, they boarded a river boat in La Crosse, Wisconsin, to begin a campaign trip down the Mississippi under the banner "Setting Course for America's Future".

In what many see as the crucial line of his speech Mr Gore told the 4,000 delegates: "I stand here tonight as my own man, and I want you to know me for who I truly am." Those words marked a climactic moment in the vice-president's long and sometimes laboured struggle to define his political personality in terms with which both he and the voters can be at ease.

Mr Gore's speech reflected what may be an irreconcilable problem facing not just the Democrats but all third way political strategies. Mr Gore needs to stop the centrist voters, whom Bill Clinton successfully courted, from reverting to Mr Bush, but at the same time he needs to mobilise his own core support to turn out on November 7 and to prevent the left from defecting to the Green candidate, Ralph Nader.

Mr Gore's policy prescriptions were generally Clintonite: fiscal discipline (he promised to balance the budget every year he is in office), guaranteed health care for children, prescription drug benefits for the elderly, universal pre-school education, and a continued expansion of community policing (Mr Gore also promised to bring the crime figures down each year).

As in Mr Bush's speech to the Republican convention two weeks earlier, there was only a brief discussion of American foreign policy. Mr Gore said nothing about national missile defence.

Throughout his speech Mr Gore used a language which Mr Clinton generally avoids. He presented himself as a "fighter" - the term was used repeatedly both by and about Mr Gore all week. "I've taken on the powerful forces. And as president I'll stand up to them and I'll stand up for you," he said.

He also appeared to go some way towards tightening the US stance on global free trade policy, pledging standards on child labour, workers' rights and the environment. Free trade must "lift everyone up, not bring anyone down", Mr Gore said.

Early in his remarks, he paid tribute to Mr Clinton. "Millions of Americans will live better lives for a long time to come because of the job that's been done by President Bill Clinton," he said. But that was the one and only mention of the leader whom Mr Gore has served with for eight years. "This election is not an award for past performance," Mr Gore said.

Towards the end of his speech Mr Gore addressed some of his perceived failings head-on. "I know my imperfections. I know that sometimes people say I'm too serious, that I talk too much substance and policy. Maybe I've done that tonight."

The crowd roared back that he had done no such thing, even though Mr Gore's address was full of detailed pledges on domestic issues with middle American voters in mind - "working families" as Mr Gore repeatedly calls them.

Mr Gore went on: "If you entrust me with the presidency, I know I won't always be the most exciting politician. But I pledge to you tonight: I will work for you every day and I will never let you down."

The final reckoning

Gone but not forgotten

The 21 plane trees removed from the area before the convention because police believed they could be used as weapons by protesters. They are now due to be replaced.

webTitle: Brat pack takes on Japan's old guard

fields.headline: Brat pack takes on Japan's old guard
fields.standfirst: With its average age approaching 70, the cabinet is under attack from within the party's own ranks
fields.trailText: Japan's conservative ruling party is being shaken up by a "brat pack" of impatient young MPs who are threatening to topple the prime minister Yoshiro Mori.
fields.body:
Japan's conservative ruling party is being shaken up by a "brat pack" of impatient young MPs who are threatening to topple the prime minister Yoshiro Mori.

About 50 Liberal Democratic party MPs elected in the past decade have formed a new group to mount a rare generation-based challenge to the country's ageing leadership.

Headed by the sons and daughters of some of Japan's most powerful leaders, they are pushing for economic reform and an end to the wasteful pork-barrel spending that has left the country with the biggest national debt in world history.

In a campaign for greater democracy in the LDP, they are preparing to put forward a candidate to stand against Mr Mori as head of the LDP.

"The ruling party has failed to keep up with the rapidly changing times and the shift in voter preferences," said Yoshimi Watanabe, one of the founders of the Group to Build a New LDP. "The quickest way to improve the situation would be to get rid of Mr Mori."

This outspoken criticism of one's own party is unusual in Japanese politics, which has long been defined by the Confucian values of group loyalty and respect for seniority.

But the new group represents a generation of young, mostly urban voters who have been frustrated by the slow pace of change in Japan, which they blame on the hidebound traditions and vested interests of the ruling gerontocracy.

While reforms in the private sector have seen companies ditch the inefficient practice of promoting workers by age, the LDP continues to promote government ministers according to how many terms they have served in parliament.

As a result, the average age of the current cabinet is 67, with two ministers more than 80 years old. Established less than two months ago, it already looks past its sell by date with ratings of just 20%.

By contrast, the new group contains some of Japan's most popular, media-savvy and international-minded politicians such as Makiko Tanaka, the woman most Japanese would like as prime minister.

Although the group is criticised as a collection of spoilt rich kids, its members have demonstrated their independence by openly rebuking their parents in parliament. Among the most vocal has been Taro Kono, who has lambasted his father, Yohei - the foreign minister - during committee sessions.

"Our impression of the younger Kono is that he is more like a member of the opposition than the LDP," confided one member of the bureaucracy, which is used to manipulating frail ruling party politicians. "We cannot control him."

The new group was formed in the wake of June's general elections, which saw the ruling party lose seats and votes, especially in urban areas.

"The result reflects city voters' loathing of the LDP," said Nobuteru Ishihara, the head of the new group and the son of Tokyo's governor. "There is no tomorrow for the party unless this is recognised."

Partly to appease the new group, the LDP abandoned a bailout plan for the Sogo department store, which led to the country's second biggest corporate collapse. Mr Mori has also agreed to carry out a review of public works projects.

It is far from certain that the group can maintain its early momentum, given the mixture of views among its members and the pressures to conform inside the LDP.

But among the electorate, expectations are high that the brat pack - which has begun reaching out to young MPs in opposition parties - can act as the catalyst for change. For now however the group is biding its time.

"People say I should leave the LDP or get rid of Mori," Mr Ishihara said. "But my message is please be patient and watch what we do from now on."

New breed of radical rattles the house

Underlining the shift in values in Japan, the politician who has made one of the biggest splashes since June's election is a 32-year-old woman who has been married four times.

Hiroko Mizushima, a psychiatrist turned opposition MP, has been the subject of intense media scrutiny since pulling off the shock of the elections by defeating one of the most powerful patriarchs in the ruling party.

The attention is partly based on her impressive parliamentary debut, a grilling of prime minister Yoshiro Mori that he described as "deeply moving".

But it is also because she represents a generation of Japanese whose values are so far removed from those of their conservative parents that they have been dubbed shinjinrui - a new breed of the human.

As numerous magazine articles have pointed out, Ms Mizushima is radical both in her politics and her lifestyle.

Far from the Confucian ideal of deference to her father - a ruling party MP - she chose to run for the op position Democratic party of Japan after seeing a newspaper advertisement for candidates.

She is already refusing to toe the cautious line of her party's male leaders by recommending an alliance with the Communists and declaring that she wants the job of shadow education minister.

But her most scathing criticism is reserved for the ruling gerontocracy. "Elderly Japanese people are becoming unworthy of respect," she says. "If they set a good moral example young people will follow them, but instead they lie and accept bribes."

In protest against Japanese laws that forbid married couples from having separate surnames, she has divorced the same man three times and set up an internet site recommending others pursue the same strategy.

How effective such shock tactics will be in Japan's consensus-driven political world is open to question.

But Ms Mizushima says she is not trying to ram her ideas down people's throats, only to offer alternatives.

webTitle: Five siblings found starved to death

fields.headline: Five siblings found starved to death
fields.trailText: In what appears to be the latest stark example of Japan's growing economic woes, police near Osaka have found the bodies of five siblings who died from starvation.
fields.body:
In what appears to be the latest stark example of Japan's growing economic woes, police near Osaka have found the bodies of five siblings who died from starvation.

The decomposed bodies of five brothers and sisters, aged between 27 and 41, were discovered on Wednesday evening lying side by side on futons in a house in Sennan.

"Some of the faces were beyond recognition. The bodies were covered with maggots and flies," a police official said.

Investigators also found the mother and an uncle lying on a bed in the house. Both were suffering from severe malnutrition.

The uncle, Takao Wakasa, a self-styled religious guru, said that he had instructed the family to drink only water after they ran out of savings six weeks ago.

Police are investigating whether the starvation was related to the unusual religious practices of the family.

Akiko Wakasa, the victims' mother, said her children had been given a "divine order" not to eat. The uncle told police that he had to purify the five because they were unclean.

According to neighbours, the Wakasa family - none of whom was employed - led reclusive lives. They played religious music throughout the day and spread large quantities of salt - used for purification in Japan - outside their house. They covered up their windows with corrugated iron and dug huge circular holes in their back garden.

The mother said the holes were made "to allow God to breathe".

Faced by evidence that a growing number of Japanese have become vulnerable to cults and religious charlatans, the country's prime minister, Yoshiro Mori, has called for greater moral education. But its social problems and escalating crime rates also appear to be related to the economic slump.

According to a report by the National Police Agency, a record 33,048 people killed themselves in 1999, giving Japan one of the highest suicide rates in the world.

Almost half of those who took their own lives were unemployed.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Man charged over hostel fire
fields.body:
Man charged over hostel fire

An itinerant fruit-picker was charged yesterday with murder arising from a fire at a backpackers' hostel in Australia. Robert Long, 37, was also charged with arson.

Fifteen people, including six Britons, died in the Queensland hostel on June 23. Police did not say why Long was charged with the murders of only two victims, 22-year-old Australian twins, Kellie and Stacey Slarke.
AP, Bundaberg

Five die in Lisbon blaze

A fire engulfed the first floor of a rundown building in central Lisbon yesterday, killing three men and two women - all in their twenties - and injuring five others. It was not clear what caused the blaze. Neighbours said the building was inhabited by drug addicts.
AP, Lisbon

Brazil's great plane robbery

Armed hijackers in Brazil who stole nearly £2m are believed to have evaded capture by overpowering police at a roadblock.

They forced a Boeing 737 down on a rural airstrip in Parana state during a domestic flight and fled in a truck with bank pouches before being stopped 300 miles away. "The eight detained men overpowered the highway police and escaped," said a police official.
Reuters, Sao Paulo

Sydney to get heroin 'gallery'

Australia's first approved heroin shooting "gallery" will open in Sydney in October after the Uniting Church received a state operating licence yesterday.

The director of the injecting room, Dr Ingrid van Beek, said: "Many drug users die... alone in back alleys, parks or dingy rooms and are not found until it is too late." Around 360 people died of heroin overdoses in Australia in 1998.
Reuters, Canberra

fields.headline: Pigs 'infected by wild boar'
fields.standfirst:
Swine fever nearly under control, minister believes

Special report: what's wrong with our food?
fields.trailText: Nick Brown, the agriculture minister, said yesterday he believed the outbreak of swine fever on East Anglian farms had been contained but that final confirmation would not be received until tests on 31 farms still under investigation had been completed.
fields.byline: Paul Brown and Andrew Osborn in Brussels
fields.body:
Nick Brown, the agriculture minister, said yesterday he believed the outbreak of swine fever on East Anglian farms had been contained but that final confirmation would not be received until tests on 31 farms still under investigation had been completed.

An optimistic Mr Brown met leaders of the pig industry yesterday and reassured them of extra government help if the outbreak continued.

In Brussels, the European commission disclosed that the virus which caused the East Anglian outbreak was very similar to one carried by a wild boar illegally imported into continental Europe from Asia two years ago.

Officials believe the contaminated boar may have passed the contagious disease on to a pig which was later imported into the UK with catastrophic consequences.

EU experts working at a laboratory in Hanover made the connection after testing blood samples from infected East Anglian pigs.

"It's a new strain, but it is similar to the one that came from Asia. It could be a mutation but it's too early to tell," an EC spokeswoman, Andrea Dahmen, explained.

The revelation will come as a relief to many farmers in the UK, since it had earlier been feared that the disease was the same virulent strain which swept through the Netherlands in 1997, spreading to Belgium and Germany.

Millions of pounds were paid out in compensation during that outbreak and 14m pigs had to be slaughtered before the disease was brought under control.

A panel of EU veterinary experts will meet in Brussels on Tuesday to discuss whether the Europe-wide ban on the export of English pigs should be extended or amended.

Mr Brown said that by then extensive results should be available from all 31 farms under investigation and from another 100 farms which are under restrictions because of their proximity to the outbreaks or because of some link to them.

Despite hundreds of tests over the last week no pig has tested positive since August 12, although there is still time for the disease to incubate in pigs which so far appear to be healthy. The government's chief veterinary officer, Jim Scudamore, said signs were "encouraging."

Only five farms have been confirmed with swine fever, Mr Scudamore said, with a further 31 premises reporting sick pigs, but none of the tests on these had so far provided a positive result.

Mr Scudamore said: "I am not going to commit myself on what is happening because it would be very unwise, but... the results seem to be encouraging."
