webTitle: Days of wine and roses, backed by subsidies

fields.headline: Days of wine and roses, backed by subsidies
fields.standfirst: Ten years after reunification, Germany's east is still the poor neighbour. But Schröder's tour takes him to Freyburg, a rare success story
fields.trailText: Rotkäppchen, says its managing director, Gunter Heise, is a "very solid enterprise".
fields.body:
Rotkäppchen, says its managing director, Gunter Heise, is a "very solid enterprise".

You sense as much when you step onto the expanse of brand new marble surrounding the reception area of its headquarters in the town of Freyburg, south of Leipzig. It says: this is a firm that has made a lot of money, and expects to make more.

Ten years ago, though, as the two Germanies raced towards reunification, Mr Heise and his colleagues were plunged into despair. "We were saying: 'That's it. It's over. Our time has past'," he recalls.

Their company takes its name, which means Little Red Riding Hood, from its main product, a blended sparkling wine with a distinctive red capsule over the cork. Rotkäppchen was a symbol of the now-defunct German Democratic Republic (GDR).

But as easterners scrambled to try the new goods suddenly made available in the west, the GDR's products tumbled from favour. By 1991, when Mr Heise became managing director of Rotkäppchen, sales of its inexpensive, but highly quaffable bubbly had dropped by 90%.

"More out of intuition than because of any rational decision, we decided to give the firm another chance," he says. Money was raised to buy bottling equipment that increased productivity 20-fold. The workforce was slashed from 350 to less than a hundred. West German consultants were hired to advise on a marketing strategy. In 1992, Mr Heise and his colleagues felt confident enough to launch a successful buy-out in alliance with a big west German wine-producing family.

Today, Rotkäppchen sells three times as much as before the fall of the Berlin wall.

Its headquarters is one of the stops on a tour of the former GDR which Germany's chancellor, Gerhard Schröder, is due to begin on Monday. He will be meeting up with east Germans of every variety from craft workers to professional footballers. He plans to stay on the road for two weeks.

One reason for this unusually lengthy journey is to commemorate German reunification. The 10th anniversary of the signing of the treaty falls on August 31. But Mr Schröder will also be after votes. In the east, his Social Democratic party still lags far behind the rival Christian Democatic Union. Along the way, he can expect to hear depressing accounts of soaring unemployment, disaffected youth and the spread of rightwing extremism.

But in Freyburg, he will get a glimpse of another east Germany. Everywhere you look, there are newly cobbled lanes, newly tiled roofs and houses in various stages of refurbishment.

The symbol of Freyburg is its castle, Schloss Neuenburg. Elegantly renovated, it has become a tourist attraction. Ten years ago, it was a ruin.

Soon after Martin Bertling, a former refinery engineer, was elected mayor in 1990, he led the townspeople up the hill to Schloss Neuenburg and in an act intended to symbolise Freyburg's new beginning, cut through the wire fence the communist authorities had erected. "It was as if we were tearing down our own Berlin wall", he says.

Initially, though, the end of the GDR was as much of disaster for Freyburg as it was for Rotkäppchen wine. A dormitory town for the industrial zone around Leipzig, it was hit hard as east Germany's uncompetitive manufacturers caved in or were taken over and shut down. The number of jobless in Freyburg soared.

But, as a devout Protestant, Mr Bertling was in no mood to regret the passing of communism. "Kohl didn't need to tell us twice that there was financial assistance on offer. We grabbed chances as soon as we could and got funding from everywhere we could," he says.

Mr Bertling estimates that in the 10 years since reunification, Freyburg has received DM30,000 (£10,000) in public subsidies for every man, woman and child in the town.

But by no means all of that has come from the west. Between a fifth and a third has come from the ratepayers and as much again has come from the regional authorities in Saxony-Anhalt.

Bringing in the money was more than just a question of rattling the collection tin.

"You have to establish what your identity is. You must ask: what sort of town am I?" says Mr Bertling.

In the case of Freyburg, that was not a particularly easy question to answer. The town lies in the middle of Europe's most northerly vineyards, planted by monks in the ninth century. The chalk soil is laden with fossils, and the whole area is subject to a protection order banning industry.

Some of the aid was ploughed into reviving the wine industry and using it, together with the restored castle, to attract tourists. Freyburg today has six hotels which did not exist at the time of reunification. Last year, it had 286,000 visitors.

But tourism alone would not have made much of an impact on its high levels of unemployment. The council's masterstroke was to see that the protection order ruled out a manufacturing industry, but not construction. Mr Bertling won official backing for an ambitious project of infrastructure development and steered the contracts towards three newly-founded local firms.

"We arranged a construction boom and that absorbed all the people who had been thrown out of work," he says.

The jobless rate in Freyburg today fluctuates between 12% and 15%. In the rest of Saxony-Anhalt it is around 23%. The mayor reckons that the local construction firms have enough work in the immediate vicinity to keep them going for another 15 years.

Sitting at his desk, looking out at the pretty central square of Freyburg with its carefully tended window boxes, Mr Bertling beams contentment.

"In this democratic system, there is nothing you cannot achieve", he says. "If you are plausible, if you have a good idea and you can present that idea in a convincing way, the money flows."

webTitle: Pilgrims bring youth and hope to Vatican

fields.headline: Pilgrims bring youth and hope to Vatican
fields.trailText: Rome has not seen the like of these pilgrims before. With their mobile phones and internet savvy, they have applauded the Pope like a rock star, prayed through the night in normally abandoned churches, and queued for hours to pass through the Holy Door of St Peter's.
fields.body:
Rome has not seen the like of these pilgrims before. With their mobile phones and internet savvy, they have applauded the Pope like a rock star, prayed through the night in normally abandoned churches, and queued for hours to pass through the Holy Door of St Peter's.

The six-day jubilee of the young, perhaps the largest ever spiritual gathering of Christians, reaches its climax this evening when up to 2m people gather in a field south of Rome for an overnight prayer vigil followed by mass tomorrow morning with the Pope. Those who expected a low turnout for the Roman Catholic church's celebrations of the 2000th anniversary of the birth of Jesus Christ have been proved wrong.

Since the youth event opened on Tuesday, with mass rallies outside St Peter's and St John Lateran, observers have been amazed at the number of its participants, and their fervour. Pilgrims have waited patiently in the sun for the chance to confess their sins - not usually a popular activity.

It is estimated that around 300,000 people will have made use of improvised confessional tents set up on the Circus Maximus, where the ancient Romans once held their chariot races.

Contact with the enthusiastic crowds appears to have given the ailing 80-year-old pope a shot of youthful adrenalin. And his severe stand on questions of sexual morality does little to deter the young pilgrims, many of whom tranquilly follow an easier line of their own.

The success in mobilising such a large number of young people bodes well for the future of the church at the beginning of the third millennium. Religious songs, meditation and prayer have filled the churches and monasteries of Rome, where, in normal times, repetitive liturgies are uninspiringly performed for a dwindling, ageing audience.

"I really thought it was crazy. I thought it was a complete waste of time, but when you see it, you feel the faith, you feel the fervour," said Farley Clinton, an American Vaticanologist based in Rome.

Mr Clinton said that he had been struck by the commitment of the pilgrims and did not share the misgivings of those who detected echoes of the mass rallies of totalitarian regimes.

"Here you have people coming from the ends of the earth to rally around the symbol of a traditional religion. I don't in the least feel this is a mass thing. On the part of every kid who has come it is a personal statement, made of his own free will."

Mr Clinton said that the success of the event was likely to affect the eventual selection of the Pope's successor. "There will be a lot of pressure to choose another telegenic Pope."

Archbishop Sean Brady of Armagh, who has led a pilgrimage of 2,000 from Ireland, was also impressed by the participants. "It's not a jamboree, it's not a festival. It's a very focused, purposeful kind of meeting, where they have spilt buckets of sweat, endured hours of thirst and yet remain good-humoured, disciplined, remarkably respectful of the environment," he said. "These people are not fools. They don't spend their time, or their money, or their energy on things they don't find fulfilling."

For Cardinal Carlo Maria Martini, the archbishop of Milan, the response has rewarded what he called the Pope's courage in reaching out to the young. The World Youth Day gatherings devised by the Pope showed it was possible to take the faith into the secular city, he told the Milan daily Corriere della Sera.

webTitle: Amazon's lost tribe emerges for land protest

fields.headline: Amazon's lost tribe emerges for land protest
fields.trailText: A Brazilian Indian tribe thought to have been extinct for nearly 100 years has resurfaced deep within the Amazon jungle, coming forward to protest at the creation of a national park on their land, government officials said yesterday.
fields.body:
A Brazilian Indian tribe thought to have been extinct for nearly 100 years has resurfaced deep within the Amazon jungle, coming forward to protest at the creation of a national park on their land, government officials said yesterday.

They said some 250 members of the long-lost Naua tribe, which once dominated the population of Brazil's state of Acre, emerged from their jungle isolation.

"They said they should not have to leave their land, since they had always been there. They said they were Naua," Antonio Pereira Neto, a spokesman for the state-funded National Indian Foundation (Funai), said.

Mr Neto said the most recent document on the Naua was a newspaper article dated 1906, headlined: Last Naua woman marries.

"We thought there were no more Naua," he said. "Our job now is finding them land... No humans are allowed in the park, just the forest and the animals."

The survivors have lost most of their native customs, with many now working as rubber-tappers in the remote jungle regions near Brazil's border with Peru, Mr Neto said.

Not all tribal members are fluent in the Naua language, which shares a common linguistic origin with dialects spoken by tribes in Peru and Bolivia, he said. One third of the tribe are children, with most below the age of 10.

"They have had a lot of contact with the white man, probably through the rubber-tapping industry," Mr Neto said.

Most speak Portuguese, the main language of Brazil's 165m inhabitants, he said.

Mr Neto said that despite the contact, the Naua remain highly isolated on their lands, which can only be reached from the nearest semi-urban hamlet by travelling two days up the Rio Branco.

webTitle: Surgeon suspended in first use of new banning powers

fields.headline: Surgeon suspended in first use of new banning powers
fields.trailText: A plastic surgeon accused of bungling operations on dozens of patients has been suspended from the medical register while complaints against him are investigated.
fields.body:
A plastic surgeon accused of bungling operations on dozens of patients has been suspended from the medical register while complaints against him are investigated.

David Herbert is the first doctor to be dealt with under new powers which enable the General Medical Council to impose interim bans. Previously the GMC could only impose suspensions in restricted circumstances, and some doctors continued practising for years while waiting for their cases to go before its professional conduct committee.

Mr Herbert, 62, was working as a consultant at the private Cromwell clinic in Huntingdon, Cambridgeshire. In May, the Labour MP Ann Clwyd told the House of Commons he had left some patients scarred for life and one close to death.

The GMC is investigating several complaints against the surgeon, who qualified in 1961. But the backlog of cases before it means it could be months before his case is heard.

Ms Clwyd's allegations high lighted the GMC's inability to stop doctors from working until they had been found guilty of serious misconduct. The change to the law has just come into affect and a new interim orders committee met yesterday to discuss the case.

"After full consideration of the case the committee decided to impose interim suspension on Dr Herbert's practice for a period of 12 months," a GMC statement said. "This suspension does not amount to a finding of fact against the doctor but was imposed to protect the public pending further investigations."

Earlier this month there was anger after a consultant surgeon who removed a woman's breast unnecessarily after wrongly diagnosing cancer was not struck off, despite being found guilty of serious professional misconduct.

The doctor only received the medical equivalent of a slap on the wrist after the professional conduct committee said it would not be in the public interest to remove William Thomson, of Cambuslang, Glasgow, from the medical register.

Previously, surgeon Richard Neale was struck off after it was found he carried out sub-standard surgery in which he cut main arteries and ruptured bladders, and failed to monitor the condition of patients.
Press Association

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Victim of racism wins retribution
fields.body:
Victim of racism wins retribution

A black building worker left paralysed by a racist attack while working in Berlin has won civil damages on top of £180,000 victim compensation. Judges in Potsdam ordered skinheads Mario Poetter and Sandro Ristau to pay Noel Martin, 40, from Edgbaston in Birmingham, £150,000 plus £300 a month for the rest of his life.

Caroline is back on air

Radio Caroline, the 1960s pirate station, is back on air today, 11 years after it was boarded to stop its unlicensed transmissions. Moored in the Medway estuary, the ship will broadcast on 1296 AM , playing "Pink Floyd to god knows what", to advertise the station's availability on the internet or by satellite.

Sailor charged with toilet rape

A sailor will appear in court today charged with raping a lawyer in a station toilet during the rush hour. Vadim Bulgakov, 31, from St Petersburg, was charged following an incident on Sheerness station, Kent, on Wednesday morning.

Murderer is recaptured

One of two murderers on the run has been recaptured in the north of England, Suffolk police said. James Howey, 38, from Liverpool, and Michael Boyd, 49, from Leeds, escaped from Hollesley Bay prison on Thursday.

Soul legend's Oxford address

Soul legend Barry White is to address students at the Oxford Union next month. Pop group Steps, actor Leonard Nimoy, and talk show host Jerry Springer have also been invited.

Like most six-year-old boys, Liao Xingwen enjoys playing games, but the one he sits down to with his friends happens to be one of the most challenging board games in the world.

Liao (pictured above), who lives in the northern Chinese city of Guilin, is learning to master go, which was invented 4,000 years ago by Chinese royalty and used to plot wars. It is now considered a supreme test of the mind.

Around 50m people in east Asia play go, some of them professionals who earn huge sums, and the game is shown on television in China and Japan.

Tomorrow Liao, said to be a child genius, will demonstrate his skill against a computer at the Fourth Mind Sports Olympiad at Alexandra Palace in London, which starts this weekend. Go takes pride of place as the most difficult game in the competition.

Liao, who arrived in London this week, was sent by his family a year ago to live in Guilin with a couple who are professional players. He plays for about eight hours a day under the guidance of his instructors .

The rules are fairly simple but the technique needed is fiendishly difficult. The emperors who invented the game claimed that it would take "two minutes to learn but a life time to master". Go, known as wei chi in China, is for two players. Its board is inscribed with 19 vertical and horizontal lines, making up 361 intersections. Black and white stones are placed alternately on the intersections, and the aim is to mark out territory with your stones and to take your opponent's stones. Professionals are ranked from dan one to dan nine.

Liao said: "My ambition is to become a dan nine player. I have one or two friends that I play go with, and I really enjoy it. I am looking forward to playing the computer, and hopefully I will do my best."

Around 5,000 people are expected to attend the olympiad. While most eyes will be on Liao, organisers say several other events among the 40 mind sports will be equally challenging.

One of them, twixt, involves building a bridge across a board while preventing your opponent from completing first. Another, boku, was "too difficult to explain", said organisers.

There will also be competitions in intelligence, speed reading, Scrabble, creative thinking, poker, mental calculations and memory skills.

webTitle: Coffee stall could stem tide of despair

fields.headline: Coffee stall could stem tide of despair
fields.standfirst: Edinburgh homeless charity plans 'Big Issue with caffeine' in city square to draw street drinkers back into community
fields.trailText: On the raised dais of Hunter Square at the heart of the Royal Mile in Edinburgh a man is holding court. He is tapping out an unsung tune with the toe of his boot, and people are watching.
fields.body:
On the raised dais of Hunter Square at the heart of the Royal Mile in Edinburgh a man is holding court. He is tapping out an unsung tune with the toe of his boot, and people are watching.

But he is not a busker. Officially, he is a problem. Just one of the city's 250 street drinkers who use the square as a focus point in chaotic lives. Most are homeless, one in four is a woman, and 146 of them are alcoholics.

They have been drawn in small groups to the square since its refurbishment a few years ago, when the concrete slabs that circled a public toilet were replaced by polished stone, benches and a high, flat platform.

"It's like a concert stage; a perfect setting for what I would call a drinking school," says Tam Hendry, general manager of the homeless charity Streetwork. "They can sit up there and watch the world go by."

Mostly, the world has done just that. Until the crescendo of complaints about their presence reached such a level that the politicians stepped in.

It is a delicate issue for Edinburgh, which recently launched a social inclusion initiative amid reports that the city is enjoying a record level of prosperity. There has been talk of setting up "tolerance zones" for rough sleepers and drinkers.

But Mr Hendry thinks he may have an answer and it lies in the square itself and the people who use it. It is a coffee stall. A small business to be run by the dispossessed for passing trade; a kind of Big Issue with caffeine. It was just a notion but it has caught the imagination of civic officials and business representatives and it is hoped a pilot project will be running by next spring.

One of the city's top hotels, the Sheraton Grand, sent a team of executives down to Hunter Square and they are exploring the idea of training those involved and possibly offering jobs at the end of it.

It would start small with six or so of the city's 490 rough sleepers. Mr Hendry envisages most of them being young and homeless without alcohol problems, but he wants it to be open to everyone.

A new report by Streetwork has revealed the devastation wrought by alcohol on the homeless community. More than half identified problems with drink, and 42% reported chronic problems.

"If you put tables and chairs in Hunter Square it makes it difficult for people to sit around and drink alcohol," Mr Hendry said. "It will change the dynamic. They would also get help and support to deal with their alcohol problems.

"There are so many homeless people and so many street drinkers out there. If you try to deal with it by using the police and making it a public order issue you just drive it away to another part of the town.

"You would be taking people who are completely unemployable in the eyes of most employers and give them the chance to develop an employment skill."

Marjorie is 54 and has been on the streets for 10 years. She thinks the coffee scheme would be a godsend. She used to work in hotels before she had her children, but then her marriage broke down and she started drinking, and before long she had lost everything.

"I think it's a brilliant idea," she said. "I don't go to the square so much these days because there's too much drinking and I came off the drink two years ago. I didn't want to live like that anymore. I deserve a better life than that. Everybody does."

Jane Wright, director of human resources at the Sheraton, said the hotel was enthusiastic about the proposal.

"We are very interested in exploring it," she said. "But we are realistic. There are a lot of people on the streets who have a lot of problems that would need to be sorted out before they could get involved.

"But there are some who are just on the edge and this is about giving people more ownership of their own space and giving them some skills."

Edinburgh council has been looking at a number of options to tackle the Hunter Square dilemma, including tolerance zones. But a Calton councillor, Dougie Kerr, said the council had been impressed by the coffee stall idea.

"We've seen how the Big Issue has helped homeless people and there's no reason why this could not," he said. "If it can get up and running it might be self-policing, because they would not want their chances of doing business being compromised by drinking."

Mr Hendry welcomes the council's support but is wary of tolerance zones. The homeless community has been marginalised and homogenised for too long, he said, and they should not be tidied away. They are mothers, fathers, landscape gardeners, tradesmen; people with dormant skills and hidden abilities. They must play the key part in any solution.

"This coffee stall idea is about self-esteem and confidence," he said.

"It's about looking at this situation with honesty. No one wants to be an alcoholic out on the streets. No one would choose to be there.

"But if you are constantly treated as worthless, as underclass scum, then that's exactly where people will remain."

fields.headline: Dome apology to disabled children
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: The Millennium Dome's chief executive has apologised after a member of staff humiliated a group of severely disabled children for making noises when they were happy.
fields.body:
The Millennium Dome's chief executive has apologised after a member of staff humiliated a group of severely disabled children for making noises when they were happy.

The children, with physical and learning disabilities, had found it difficult to enjoy the more frenetic aspects of the dome but found pleasure in the calming music and lights of the rest zone.

They showed their pleasure by humming, muttering and occasional clapping of their hands.

This proved too much for the able-bodied visitors in the zone, on whose behalf a female staff member asked the group to be quiet or leave.

Adrian Gordon, development officer for Islington social services, who was escorting the children, said the noises were "a part of the children's personality, which can't be 'switched off' on demand".

The group chose to leave rather than make a scene, but Mr Gordon wrote a letter of complaint to dome management on behalf of the children's angered parents.

Mr Gordon pointed out that the rest zone was one of the few areas the party had found stimulating during their visit in April.

Elsewhere in the dome, there was a lack of the space and time the children needed to make decisions or carry out movements.

"As a group we paid over £200 to go to the dome only to find that for some of them, the only area they found stimulating was inaccessible because of the need to respect the needs of 10 other (able-bodied) people in there.

"It is worth mentioning that the majority of visitors did not respect the needs of our group when it came to viewing displays or trying to take part in areas such as the play zone."

Mr Gordon said that although the toilets were spacious, they did not have a suitable changing bench, which meant some young people had to lie on the floor.

However, he noted that some of the dome staff were helpful and friendly. "Indeed the highlight of the day was an impromptu wheelchair dance outside the dome when a jazz band came over to play to us."

In a written apology, the dome's chief executive, Pierre-Yves Gerbeau, said: "We do ask all our visitors to be as quiet as possible within the zone so that everyone can enjoy it. Nevertheless, we do appreciate that different visitors have different reactions to the zone and the hosts in the rest zone have been reminded of the importance of respecting this."

webTitle: House buyers staying on home ground

fields.headline: House buyers staying on home ground
fields.standfirst: Homes to ease London's problems are attracting 'locals' instead
fields.trailText: There are stone gates marking the entrance to the Kings Hill housing development near West Malling in Kent. Behind them is a flower-decked wooden barrow, brightly painted with the name of the estate. Drive up the brick-block road, past the wide swaths of grass and trees and you will come to hundreds of new houses.
fields.body:
There are stone gates marking the entrance to the Kings Hill housing development near West Malling in Kent. Behind them is a flower-decked wooden barrow, brightly painted with the name of the estate. Drive up the brick-block road, past the wide swaths of grass and trees and you will come to hundreds of new houses.

Turn down Discovery Drive and you will find the "dream" homes, four and five bedroom places built to lure the rich and wealthy from all over the south-east. The houses are faux traditional, Stepford Wives-uniform in their attempt to be different.

Kings Hill sits on a brownfield site and could be the epitome of John Prescott's vision of the future of housing. For those who live there, it is a suburban utopia reminiscent of Disney's purpose-built family town, Celebration. Two miles from the M20, Kings Hill aims to house 1,850 on just under a square mile of land. Last year, 90 babies were born on the estate and Kings Hill primary has expanded from 200 to 420 to meet the area's demands.

All over the site, houses grow daily skyward, and sales people are showing eager buyers round grand, tassle-curtained, fake-flower-filled show homes with Please Keep Off the Grass signs outside. Kings Hill is a mixed-use development supposed to reflect "a traditional English village, complete with green". There is already an Asda and there are plans for shops, a pub, a day nursery, sports and leisure facilities, a hotel and a medical centre.

By encouraging developments such as Kings Hill, the deputy prime minster aims to combat overcrowding in London and the south-east by building 43,000 homes a year for five years and possibly 860,000 homes over the next 20. He also wants to shift the balance of building from greenfield to brownfield, or recycled, land.

Kings Hill lies on the site of the former West Malling airfield, which used to be a nightfighter squadron base. The American company Rouse Kent bought the site and crafted a "masterplan" which mixes a business park with low density housing.

As well as alleviating the London housing crisis, Mr Prescott aims to bring the poor and the unemployed from the north to the south. But the majority of people living in Kings Hill were residing in Kent already. They have simply moved a few miles up the road. And until now they are fairly wealthy. There are plans to build social housing in the coming years.

If people do not fill the Prescott target profile, who is moving to Kings Hill and equivalent housing estates sprouting up all over this part of the country?

A few families have already moved in to a cul-de-sac on the Charles Church development in Kings Hill. Steve Thompson, 41, and his wife Jackie, 35, moved from Orpington, 25 miles away. The couple have four children, Louise, 11, Matthew, five, Elliot, two, and Hannah, three months, the first baby born on this newest part of the development. The family moved to Kings Hill because they needed more space and property was cheaper than in Orpington.

Mrs Thompson said: "I jokingly said if we had a house like that, that would be my dream house. I fell pregnant and we knew we had to move. We were the first people who bought off the plan - just like that."

The couple had a three-bed semi in Orpington and now have a five-bedroom house which cost them £297,000.

They like Kings Hill, although facilities are sparse. Mrs Thompson admitted: "I miss the shops at Orpington and I used to think they were a dump."

Returning from work, Mr Thompson, who is in sales, said the place makes him feel less stressed. "I think this is a nicer area. It's nicer for the children because it seems a slower way of life. As you get nearer London you find that people haven't got the time. I don't think it is any safer but we do feel we are fractionally more in the country."

Next door to the Thompsons, Michael Courtier is washing one of the two cars in his drive. He and his wife have retired and decided to downsize before their home was too big to manage. He said: "When I first came up here I thought I was in Florida. It is so nice. It does attract you to move."

The couple moved last May from New Barn, near Meopham, about 15 miles away. "I had half an acre and it was just too much work. We had a swimming pool," said Mr Courtier.

Mrs Courtier has not settled quite as easily as her husband and misses her old house.

"We have made a few friends on the site already but I have always said to my wife, if it doesn't work out, we'll move again. I think one or two people have made that arrangement with their wives."

At the edge of the street, the garden of Sue and Peter Warren's five bedroom house is filled with the playful screams of their children and friends.

Unlike most of their neighbours, the Warren family have travelled a distance from their old home in Devon after Mr Warren was made redundant and got a new job as a sales director with a company in Aylesford, a 10-minute drive away. The family has lived at 14 addresses in 12 years.

"We were trying to get as much space as possible. We got quite a good deal because there is still so much building work going on. We now have a bedroom for each of the babies. I just love the house," said Mrs Warren. "My husband lived in the States when he was a child and Kings Hill is very much like an American development. There are lovely wide boulevards and trees. "

Maureen Hill, a sales executive based at the Charles Church Chiltern show home, said people loved Kings Hill . "The whole feel of the place is very American. People are very afraid of large developments but when they actually get here they realise it's got a wonderful feel to it," she said. "The concept is that you can live here, work here and go to school here. But that hasn't really been the way it is. The majority of people who live here are really commuters. They need to get to London."

While many prospective buyers are from the Kent area some hail from London itself, one family is from Belfast, another is from Singapore and there, in the office, poring over a floor plan, is a couple from Hong Kong.

In the Chiltern, Eric Elliott, 68, and his wife Oonagh, 65, are pondering the £385,000 price tag. The couple currently live in High Halstow about 15 miles away but their garden, which overlooks the river Thames, is becoming too much of a handful.

"We are getting older and we want something newer, something that will be easier to look after," Mr Elliott said. "We just know that in six years' time our six bedroom house and garden is going to be too much."

webTitle: Worker recovering after anthrax strikes in factory

fields.headline: Worker recovering after anthrax strikes in factory
fields.trailText: A disease at the centre of germ warfare scares during the Gulf war has returned to a northern industrial city where it haunted textile workers in Victorian times.
fields.body:
A disease at the centre of germ warfare scares during the Gulf war has returned to a northern industrial city where it haunted textile workers in Victorian times.

The virulent bacterial infection anthrax, seldom encountered in Britain today, has struck down a factory worker in Bradford, where stringent measures were taken to prevent its spread during the heyday of the woollen industry.

The man aged 35, who has not been named, is recovering in hospital after emergency treatment with antibiotics. Although anthrax cannot be passed on by person-to-person contact, all other workers at the plant have been alerted and informed of early symptoms of the disease, which is potentially fatal if not treated rapidly.

The victim, the first in Bradford for at least 18 years, has cutaneous anthrax, the least serious of the disease's three forms but one in which seeping black ulcers develop on the body. He is thought to have become infected when his arm was cut at work, triggering public health alarm about possible contamination inside the factory.

Staff from the health and safety executive and the city's environmental health department are checking the building for sources of anthrax spores, which are found in animal material such as elephant tusks (which led to the death of a London piano key maker in the 1940s) and hides used in textile production, especially goat fleeces, such as mohair, and alpaca.

"The other workers have been alerted as a precautionary measure," said Ruth Gelletlie, consultant in communicable disease control for Bradford health authority. webTitle: A good week for Gustav le Bon

fields.headline: A good week for Gustav le Bon
fields.trailText: This has been a pretty good week for Gustav le Bon. People have taken to quoting him, not something that often happens nowadays.
fields.body:
This has been a pretty good week for Gustav le Bon. People have taken to quoting him, not something that often happens nowadays.

Alan Watkins, in the Independent on Sunday, unveiled this gobbet in the context of the demonstrations on the Paulsgrove estate: "We have shown that crowds do not reason, that they accept or reject ideas as a whole, that they tolerate neither discussion nor contradiction, and that the suggestions brought to bear on them invade the entire field of their understanding and tend at once to transform themselves into acts." Mick Hume in the Times referred to Le Bon's contention that "a man descends several rungs in the ladder" when he joins a crowd.

As I pondered these words, a trickle of questions started to seep like treacle through the ramshackle teashop which is my mind.

1.Where did this fellow spring from?

2. Had he the slightest idea what he was talking about?

3. Was he any relation of Simon and Yasmin?

Here, in descending order of reliability, are some of the answers.

1. Gustav le Bon was born in Nogent-le-Notrou in 1841 and died in Marnes-la-Coquette (what a delightful name!) 90 years later.

2. His main scholarly interest was crowds, yielding books called The Crowd; The Crowd and Extraordinary Public Delusions; and The Psychology of Revolution. He was also a steaming racist, who regarded it as a proof of the emptiness of sociology that a rival scholar had dared to assert that black people (Le Bon used the word negroes) might be the equal of white. A note in Encyclopaedia Britannica refers to his strong anti-democratic bias. He attributed true progress, it says, to the work of an intellectual elite, believing the masses to be devoid of reason. Not a natural Guardian reader. He may also have fancied himself as a coiner of pithy apophthegms: at any rate, the Oxford Book of Aphorisms quotes a Gustave le Bon as saying in 1913: "Virtuous people often revenge themselves for the constraints to which they submit by the boredom which they inspire." (I fear there is some truth in that observation.)

3. I haven't the vaguest idea.

The Marquis of Vauvenargues writes: I think you should note that this is the only aphorism of Gustave le Bon in the Oxford book. There are 52 of my own.

 Rocket Surgeon of the Week - an occasional Smallweed series. Manchester United footballer Henning Berg on the club's plethora of defenders: "I don't think you have to be a brain surgeon to see that I'm fifth or sixth choice".

 Here is something still more peculiar told to Smallweed this week, leaving him gawping. When TE Lawrence signed up for the RAF, under the pseudonym Shaw, the officer who interviewed him was WE Johns, creator of Biggles. What a clash of literary titans was there, my countrymen! Or not, as the case may be.

 And now for Heartbreak House, Smallweed's riposte to the show that has seized the throat of the nation: Big Brother, about these oddballs living together and getting thrown out one by one. In my version, one new nominee is exiled to the house each week, to stay there for ever, I hope. This week's choice is between two ubiquitous Charlies. They are:

1. Charlie Dimmock, who appears in gardening programmes plashing on about water features, though what she's really famous for is not wearing a bra.

2. Charlie Whelan, a professional mouth who used to nurture the interests of Gordon Brown and is now firing off almost everywhere.

I wish I could ask my readers to vote on the choice but my budget does not run to it, so I'm forced to fall back on chance. Take the 27th word of the piece to the left of this column (the regular weekly debate) and note its opening letter. If it's an odd-numbered letter, like A C or E, Dimmock is doomed. If it's an even number, like B D or F, Whelan gets it. My show, by the way, is completely unscripted. Can the same be said of Big Brother?

The other day, while my wife and I were at Loggerheads...

A pedant writes: I think you mean "when my wife and I were at loggerheads".

Smallweed brusquely retorts: I mean what I say. The other day, while my wife and I were at Loggerheads, a village near Market Drayton in Shropshire, a nun of forbidding demeanour waved us down, and producing a gun from her wimple...

The Marquis of Vauvenargues writes: How Smallweed forgets his old friends! I thought we would have some reference this week to the proud achievements of table-topping Cowdenbeath, top of the Scottish third division, unbeaten all season and nary a goal thumped past their custodian.

A pedant writes: I think you owe it to readers to point out that this happy record reflects a mere two games played.

Smallweed retorts with a fury which makes bystanders flinch: Begone, you frightful old spoilsport.

 After my blunder with Hounslow Heath I suppose it was inevitable that complaints would pour in about my reference to the Boat Inn, Jackford, Shropshire. A kindly scourge from Birmingham suggests that I must have drunk rather too much on the premises, since the place is called Jackfield. You are wrong, wrong, wrong, Mr Holyoak, and don't think you are going to be spared for sending your allegation on a postcard with a picture of Samuel Morse, he of the Code. I wrote Jackfield: some jackanapes corrected it. I hope very soon to make an arrest. Let me only discover someone in this building who thinks John Wayne's best movies were directed by John Field, that Frank Ford was charged by Tony Blair to think the unthinkable, and that Graham Thorpe fords in the England outford, and that will be it. He will pretty soon learn that he can't affield to mess with Smallweed.

 In response to popular demand: smallweed@theguardian.com

webTitle: Blair bans top civil servant from advising defence firm

fields.headline: Blair bans top civil servant from advising defence firm
fields.trailText: Tony Blair has imposed a two-year ban on a former civil servant giving commercial advice to Britain's leading defence contractor, British Aerospace, to pre-empt allegations of sleaze over billions of pounds of orders for the armed forces.
fields.body:
Tony Blair has imposed a two-year ban on a former civil servant giving commercial advice to Britain's leading defence contractor, British Aerospace, to pre-empt allegations of sleaze over billions of pounds of orders for the armed forces.

The prime minister personally approved the ban on Sir David Davies, the former chief scientific adviser at the Ministry of Defence, because he used to chair an internal Whitehall committee which advised ministers on the "best buys" for defence equipment. Sir David holds enormous inside knowledge about the MoD's defence procurement needs.

He applied on retirement last year to join British Aerospace as a member of the strategy board of the Virtual University - an initiative funded and run by BAe.

This led to the appointment being referred to Whitehall's advisory committee on business appointments, which recommended a six-month delay in him taking up the job and two year ban on his advising BAe about anything except education and staff training.

The committee asked Mr Blair to approve its recommendation, which will remain in force until December 2001.

The prime minister's involvement is revealed in the latest report from the committee, which was placed in the House of Commons library as MPs went on their summer recess.

The report reveals that restrictions have been imposed on 129 senior civil servants and one minister in taking up private sector jobs. Of Sir David's case it says: "We were concerned that his early association with this large defence contractor, albeit in an academic capacity, might be viewed with suspicion."

Mr Blair also approved a six month delay on Air Marshal Sir Colin Terry becoming group managing director of Inflite Engineering, a company which works for defence contractors.

Other former civil servants who face restrictions in taking up new jobs include Stephen Littlechild, the former head of the electricity regulator, Offer, who was banned from advising electricity companies seeking licences for a year.

Sir David Gore-Booth, the former high commissioner for India, was prevented for six months from dealing with India in his new job as special adviser to the banker HSBC holdings.

Another civil servant, Brian Hilton, the former director general of corporate and consumer affairs at the Department of Trade and Industry and the man who ran John Major's citizen's charter office, was handed a six month ban on dealing with any company involved with the competition authorities. He has set up his own consultancy and has to get approval for each new commission until 2002.

Doug Henderson, the former defence minister, has also been banned for a year from dealing with defence companies in his two new jobs as an adviser to BIC Systems and as a director of Audioware, his own company. This runs out in November.

There was no objection to Lord Hoyle, a former government whip, taking up three new jobs since he left the government in May last year. These are as a consultant to Greenalls Group, the brewers; as chairman of Wire (FM); and as a parliamentary adviser to Whitehall advisers who have defence clients.

Nor were there any objections to Lord Gilbert, the former defence procurement minister, taking up eight appointments.

webTitle: Is the BBC dumbing down the nation?

fields.headline: You just can't get the quality any more
fields.standfirst:
Nigel Williams responds to John Drummond's claim that the BBC is dumbing down the nation
Special report: the future of the BBC
fields.trailText: Nigel Williams responds to John Drummond's claim that the BBC is dumbing down the nation.
fields.body:
Sir John Drummond, the former Head of Radio 3, let it be known this week at the Edinburgh Festival (always a good place to let off steam) that New Labour is plotting to dumb down British culture. One of the principal agents they have selected for this sinister task is the BBC - once a haunt of civilised intellectuals like... er... John Drummond and now, apparently, run by a shower of "middle aged men in baseball caps turned round the wrong way, who don't want to grow up".

One of the chief architects of this general lowering of tone is my old friend Alan Yentob, now the BBC's head of drama, entertainments and arts, who is described as "a prat".

Has the Beeb "dumbed down"? Is it all a desolate expanse of gardening programmes and endless shows about how to do up your house or cook a three course meal for four with your hands tied behind your back? Is Alan Yentob a prat? Even if he is (and, like all of us, I am sure he has done things that merit that description), is the current rash of consumer programmes and lack of profiles of Zemlinsky and Hans Werner Henze his fault ? It is just possible that Sir John Drummond is the real prat for introducing the word into the discussion, for what he has to say is serious and worthy of more elevated discussion than the trading of playground insults.

Since both Drummond and I worked in the music and arts department of the Beeb in the early 70s (although I am relieved to discover I do not figure in his soon to be published memoirs, Tainted By Experience, Faber, £25 ) the broadcasting industry, and especially the public sector of it, has changed at a rate that makes me constantly surprised that I am still employed in it. I would argue that it is these changes, and not a conscious conspiracy by highly placed prats, that have created Sir John's sense of isolation and frustration .

The old BBC's sense of confidence came from the fact that it had an absolute monopoly of the culture market. Sir John, and, indeed, I, go back to the days before Channel 4 or Classic FM were invented. I can remember sitting in one of the last programme review boards of the old Third Programme and listening to our chief, the late novelist PH Newby, first winner of the Booker Prize, ask a room packed with 50 people how many had heard the interval talk on Wednesday night as a bit of light relief between chunks of Schoenberg. "I am afraid," said Newby, in the genuinely heartfelt tones of a man apologising for being a class traitor in Stalin's Russia, "that I have deplorably little first hand knowledge of the Viennese school of linguistic philosophy."

Over in television, people had time not only to debate the meaning and purpose of the programmes they were making without reference to market forces, but also to spend hours pulling each other's programmes to pieces. One of my most awkward experiences was at the hands of Sir John himself (then known more colloquially as Drumfilms, perhaps because of his individualist approach to BBC politicking) who leaped out at me from behind a potted plant in the club bar at Kensington House, now a hotel, and tore a film of mine to shreds in one sentence that lasted 15 minutes but would have taken a lesser man at least an hour to repeat. "A lot of little tricks... clever but empty," he fumed. His eyes popped with such fury that I thought he was going to bite me.

This was a time in which you (I mean I) could transmit a documentary about a reasonably serious subject - an examination of the true facts behind the legend of Dick Turpin - at 7.30pm on BBC1 and get an audience of 25m for it. Omnibus, the arts flagship programme, came on after the news at 9.25pm on BBC1 and the arts department's idea of light relief was a classical music quiz in which people like Joyce Grenfell and Robin Ray traded Köchel numbers in full evening dress. I don't want to sound like I'm wearing my baseball cap the wrong way round but - hey dudes - there wasn't anything else to watch.

The competition from outside stole talent and leisure from the Beeb (Michael Jackson, current head of Channel 4, and Michael Bukht of Classic FM, were both Beeb graduates) and that well known apologist for arts funding, Margaret Thatcher, made sure that the organisation was suitably geared up to facilitate its free-market rivals' success. It was Thatcher who decreed, as a warning shot across the Beeb's bows for daring to criticise her style of government, that 25% of the corporation's production would go to independent producers. That was the single most important and radical change to the system since Reith got the general manager's job in 1922.

It began by destroying the collegiate programme-making set-up that had sustained the BBC's cultural life and made it one of our great institutions. And, because the market decrees that those who serve it get higher wages, even Birt's increase in salaries (mainly for those at the top of the organisation, none of whom have any direct contact with programme making) did not stop the gradual haemorrhaging of creatives from the place, nor the erosion of confidence among those who were left, in the patrician right to assert that this or that work of art is good. Not that this stopped Birt from letting me know that he thought my season of Omnibus was no good by printing his views in the staff magazine, as opposed to letting me know in person.

I am not saying that independent production meant a lowering of standards. It didn't. But it did mean fewer programmes for more money, and ultimately the ghettoisation of quality broadcasting simply as a matter of scale. We made less for more. Instead of Play for Today (writer-led, often studio-based, and reasonably priced) we had the ludicrous contradiction, for a public service broadcaster, of BBC Films, which have to compete in the commercial market alongside Steven Spielberg.

Digital choice, brought to us courtesy of that other well-known patron of the arts (and friend of Mrs Thatcher) Rupert Murdoch, accelerated this process even further, for digital choice's most important effect duplicates that of the economic system which spawned it: the free market.

It guarantees that consumers can zero in on their particular need or preference and have no necessity or desire for someone to tell them what they should or should not watch. Focus groups and audience profiles (and all the other things that old hands like Sir John may not like although I seem to remember him getting quite worked up about viewing figures) are simply an expression of the way in which the economic system that now rules the broadcasting industry - a crude form of capitalism that has turned the idea of "public service" into a sick joke - divides sections of society into self-limiting groups.

Like Sir John, I like the idea of a Radio 3 that instructs its audience by introducing them to things they may not think they will like but then find they do: although I am sure that what is news to me may well be old hat to him. But the world in which the BBC can assume that it has the right, or indeed the ability, to find pupils is simply not there any more.

That is why Mark Thompson, our head of factual programming, was absolutely right, whatever the politicians may say, to announce at the last Banff Television Festival that the BBC has to adjust its programme transmissions - with a minimum of four channels, one of which would be devoted to arts and culture - to deal with the new technology.

There is absolutely no doubt that the volume of serious arts or science programmes on the Beeb is less than it was. I know this principally because I only have to go down the lists of current projects commissioned out to the arts department, in which I work and have worked for 30 years. I only have to count up the numbers of talented people who have left or been driven away or drunk themselves to death to know that, now, as ever, it isn't easy for serious culture. But I don't think it's quite good enough to blame it all on New Labour and baseball caps.

 Nigel Williams, formerly editor of the BBC arts flagship programme Omnibus, is the writer and presenter of The Great Detectives, a documentary history of detective fiction. He is currently working on programmes on the history of spy fiction to be transmitted by the BBC next year. His latest novel, Fortysomething, is published in paperback by Penguin, £6.99.

The competition from outside stole talent and leisure from the Beeb (Michael Jackson, current head of Channel 4, and Michael Bukht of Classic FM, were both Beeb graduates) and that well known apologist for arts funding, Margaret Thatcher, made sure that the organisation was suitably geared up to facilitate its free-market rivals' success. It was Thatcher who decreed, as a warning shot across the Beeb's bows for daring to criticise her style of government, that 25% of the corporation's production would go to independent producers. That was the single most important and radical change to the system since Reith got the general manager's job in 1922. It began by destroying the collegiate programme-making set-up that had sustained the BBC's cultural life and made it one of our great institutions. And, because the market decrees that those who serve it get higher wages, even Birt's increase in salaries (mainly for those at the top of the organisation, none of whom have any direct contact with programme making) did not stop the gradual haemorrhaging of creatives from the place, nor the erosion of confidence among those who were left, in the patrician right to assert that this or that work of art is good. Not that this stopped Birt from letting me know that he thought my season of Omnibus was no good by printing his views in the staff magazine, as opposed to letting me know in person. I am not saying that independent production meant a lowering of standards. It didn't. But it did mean fewer programmes for more money, and ultimately the ghettoisation of quality broadcasting simply as a matter of scale. We made less for more. Instead of Play for Today (writer-led, often studio-based, and reasonably priced) we had the ludicrous contradiction, for a public service broadcaster, of BBC Films, which have to compete in the commercial market alongside Steven Spielberg. Digital choice, brought to us courtesy of that other well-known patron of the arts (and friend of Mrs Thatcher) Rupert Murdoch, accelerated this process even further, for digital choice's most important effect duplicates that of the economic system which spawned it: the free market. It guarantees that consumers can zero in on their particular need or preference and have no necessity or desire for someone to tell them what they should or should not watch. Focus groups and audience profiles (and all the other things that old hands like Sir John may not like although I seem to remember him getting quite worked up about viewing figures) are simply an expression of the way in which the economic system that now rules the broadcasting industry - a crude form of capitalism that has turned the idea of "public service" into a sick joke - divides sections of society into self-limiting groups. Like Sir John, I like the idea of a Radio 3 that instructs its audience by introducing them to things they may not think they will like but then find they do: although I am sure that what is news to me may well be old hat to him. But the world in which the BBC can assume that it has the right, or indeed the ability, to find pupils is simply not there any more. That is why Mark Thompson, our head of factual programming, was absolutely right, whatever the politicians may say, to announce at the last Banff Television Festival that the BBC has to adjust its programme transmissions - with a minimum of four channels, one of which would be devoted to arts and culture - to deal with the new technology. There is absolutely no doubt that the volume of serious arts or science programmes on the Beeb is less than it was. I know this principally because I only have to go down the lists of current projects commissioned out to the arts department, in which I work and have worked for 30 years. I only have to count up the numbers of talented people who have left or been driven away or drunk themselves to death to know that, now, as ever, it isn't easy for serious culture. But I don't think it's quite good enough to blame it all on New Labour and baseball caps.  Nigel Williams, formerly editor of the BBC arts flagship programme Omnibus, is the writer and presenter of The Great Detectives, a documentary history of detective fiction. He is currently working on programmes on the history of spy fiction to be transmitted by the BBC next year. His latest novel, Fortysomething, is published in paperback by Penguin, £6.99.

webTitle: Critics' guide to the Edinburgh festival

fields.headline: And still they keep coming...
fields.standfirst:
Film, music, dance, theatre, comedy... our critics continue their guide to the Edinburgh festival
Special report: the Edinburgh festival 2000
fields.trailText: Film, music, dance, theatre, comedy... our critics continue their guide to the Edinburgh festival.
fields.body:
Dance

New York City Ballet
***
Edinburgh Playhouse

"Ballet is woman," said George Balanchine, a choreographer notoriously susceptible to the beauty of female dancers. Balanchine may have proved a feckless husband off-stage, but on stage he served his ballerinas faithfully, with some of the greatest roles of the 20th century, courting them with delicately nuanced poetry and empowering them with steps of blazingly articulate authority.

To his male dancers Balanchine often proved less generous; yet one of the quirks of NYCB's current, erratically danced season at the Edinburgh international festival has been the degree to which the men have dominated the stage.

In The Four Temperaments (1946) Damian Woetzel performed the Melancholic variation as a gracefully skewed clown, whose mournful secrets were intriguingly on the point of disclosure. Albert Evans phrased the fractured, jazzy classicism of the Phlegmatic variation superbly. We were as captivated by his own wit as by that of the choreography. Evans also charmed the crowd as the second cowboy in Western symphony (1954). In this frothy piece of Americana, Evans was the perfect feckless dude, and a fine foil to Nicolaj Hubbe's flirty, skinny cowboy in the final movement.

Unlike these charismatic men, however, many of NYCB's women seemed to have left their personalities at home. Margaret Tracey displayed some vibrant dancing in Concerto Barocco, but only a couple of dancers - Wendy Whelan and Helene Alexopoulos - reminded us how real ballerinas both command the stage and define the poetry of the ballet around them.

Not that Symphony in Three Movements (1972) is balletic in a traditional sense, with its strident corps de ballet and its drastic changes of speed. Yet in the central duet, its volatile energies are concentrated into a love affair of breathtaking intensity. Whelan and her partner Jock Soto not only shaped the choreography's exaggerated detail with stinging clarity but showed us a real man and woman together. All the senses of the two dancers seemed preternaturally alert, so that when Soto inclined his face towards Whelan's arm he seemed to be drinking in the perfume of her skin.

In Serenade (1935), Alexopoulos showed a similar ability to convey both the shape and music of the steps and their imaginative life. The fact that she and Whelan are among the more senior dancers in the company gives credence to the worries of certain New York critics that the NYCB's current director, Peter Martins, isn't training up a new generation of ballerinas.

For the audience on Wednesday, however, Martins was the hero of the evening, as choreographer of the 1990 ballet Fearful Symmetries. Martins's choreography is actually a far less coherent response to John Adams's huge, scintillating score than Ashley Page's version for the Royal Ballet. But the music is irresistible under any circumstances and Martins does rise to it occasionally, with some grave and feisty invention in his pas de deux. Certainly the dancers seemed to have as much fun dancing it as the audience did watching it.
Judith Mackrell

Ends tonight. Box office: 0131-473 2000.

Theatre

Voices
****
Traverse

One-person shows can often be deadly bores; this one, a European prizewinner from Theatergroep Hollandia, is a striking exception. Based on the writings of Pier Paolo Pasolini, it gives Jeroen Willems the chance not only to play a variety of characters assembled around a dinner table but also to engage in a dialectical debate about the future of a society increasingly run by hypocritical industrialists and corporate apologists.

Auden warned us against "public faces in private places": Willems gives us a whole gallery. The resident intellectual speaks an arcane language designed to enhance his own power. A top industrialist dazzles us with his expertise. Most disturbing of all, because he is outwardly beguiling and because the words come from a former Shell chairman, is a spokesman for the multinationals who defends the benefits of "a state within a state" and who attacks the moral imperialists who question its supra-governmental role.

In the course of 90 minutes Willems metamorphoses from male to stilletoed female to horned devil. The show is artfully directed by Johan Simons, but it is not simply a display of versatility. It is really a moral and political debate about a world in which our lives are shaped by unelected experts and in which even governments are subordinate to corporations. The irony is that it deals with the loss of individual power yet it is performed, with silky authority, by a mesmerising soloist.
Michael Billington

Till August 26. Box Office: 0131-228 1404.

Bertrand's Toys
****
South Bridge Resource Centre

This has nothing to do with those cute stories for kids about the toys that come alive in the nursery when you are not looking. This hour-long performance piece from underground Moscow theatre company blackSKYwhite is a waking nightmare. It is very, very scary.

The first thing you notice is the similarity between a marionette and a hanged man. Secondly, you wonder whether the figure you are watching is human or a clockwork doll, such is the appalling flexibility of her jerky joints and the blankness of her leering face. You want to cower under your seat and whimper as the music pounds relentlessly in your head and out of the darkness loom ever more grotesque figures. There is the joker with his juggling balls and a featureless mannequin who is deaf, dumb and blind. These are the toys you keep in the attic and which have escaped to haunt you. You notice that it has started to snow.

This show is like a panto that has gone badly wrong, a slasher movie in which you are the victim, a circus act where the clowns have run amok with meat cleavers. You admire its brilliance and hate it for its lack of humanity. It is theatre and it is anti-theatre.
Lyn Gardner

Till August 26. Box office: 0131-558 9991.

Classical

Schumann chamber music
****
Queen's Hall

The first movement of Schumann's Piano Trio in D Minor contains a passage of such strangeness that the entire fabric of the piece seems to collapse into a different musical dimension. A ghostly theme appears in the violin and cello; it hints of recollection but is actually a completely new melodic idea. The way pianist Andras Schiff, violinist Yuuko Shiokawa and cellist Miklos Perenyi integrated this chilling premonition into the remainder of the first movement was profoundly moving. Their account of the rest of Schumann's trio was similarly stimulating: throughout, the players emphasised the poetic flow which characterises so much of Schumann's late music.

There was continuity of another kind in Schiff and tenor Peter Schreier's performance of Schumann's Liederkreis Op 24. Schreier may no longer possess the sheerly beautiful voice he once used to, but the wisdom and wit of his singing seems to have increased over the years. Alive to all the irony, bitterness and tenderness of Schumann's settings of Heine's poems of frustrated love, this was a performance of towering intellect.
Tom Service

Film

The House of Mirth
****
Odeon/Cameo

When Martin Scorsese tackled an Edith Wharton adaptation in The Age of Innocence, the tone was romantic and a little touristic - as if the camera couldn't resist swooning over the silverware. Terence Davies's approach to Wharton is more severe, which may make The House of Mirth seem a forbidding proposition. But his detachment makes for a film that is at once pure Wharton and pure Davies - not that this Visconti-esque costume essay is an obvious choice for the director of the British sitting-room memoir Distant Voices, Still Lives.

Wharton's story - sketching the descent of socialite Lily Bart from glamorous heights to ignominious exclusion - calls for both analytic coolness and a flair for evoking social surface. It's a difficult balance, which Davies has hit partly in the inspired casting of X-Files star Gillian Anderson. She has the look of a John Singer Sergeant portrait, and if she is sometimes presented as a mannequin in the film, that suits the way Lily's peers perceive her, as a consummate image. But Anderson really can act: she is subtly deceptive as the Lily who hides her intellect beneath a wryly flirtatious exterior, and finally moving as she rises to the operatic heights of Lily's martyrdom.

Other actors you never rated come unexpectedly into their own. Eric Stoltz perfectly embodies the reserve of Lily's never-quite-lover Lawrence Selden; Laura Linney is chilling as Lily's social nemesis Bertha Dorset. Most improbable of all is National Lampoon farceur Dan Aykroyd, playing a boorish, financier who sees Lily as a luxury commodity for the taking.

Davies plays the costume game very much on his own terms. Salon furnishings are never just local colour. They flourish when necessary, and at other times are starkly reduced to highlight the dramatic stakes. Lily's initial appearance as a silhouette wreathed in railway steam is an early emblem of the chiaroscuro approach.

The House of Mirth is not easy viewing. Davies's script refuses to play down the complexities of Wharton's language and narrative - be prepared to go in with ironic antennae tuned, right from the opening bout of emotional fencing between Lily and Selden. But this is a rare achievement: a costume adaptation that treats its audience like thinking adults. You may even sob a little, too.
Jonathan Romney

Tonight at the Odeon and Thursday at Cameo 1. Details: 0131-623 8030.

The Beaver Trilogy
***
Filmhouse

The Beaver Trilogy starts in a car park and ends on an open road; that linear narrative device aside, these three circular, intersecting films are not unlike a Möbius strip. They encourage scrutiny of the film-making process, of the assumptions we make about it, and of how manipulative it is.

In the car park of a television station we meet Gary, a geek with faith in the redeeming power of TV: "You're on television, you're OK. People take you seriously." He encourages a seedy-looking TV producer-director to film the people of his town, Beaver, in their talent show, with him as the star attraction, Olivia Newton Dawn.

While the first film, shot like a cinema-verite home movie, has a documentary feel, Beaver Kid No 2, in black and white, is more stylised. Gary's goofiness is replaced with the drama queen persona of Larry, played with camp abandon by Sean Penn. The third film, The Orkly Kid, sees Crispin Glover take on the mantle of Larry and moves the story from that of a small town joker to small town outcast, with a corresponding darker twist.

Through the trilogy, the process by which each film is made, and made to elicit particular emotional responses from the audience, is laid bare. By the time Larry/Gary becomes Olivia Neutron Bomb in the third film, the unease is palpable because of what we know from the previous two.

The Beaver Trilogy reveals just how predatory and damning television can be of its subjects. Wannabe docusoap stars take note.
Gareth McLean

Tomorrow and August 25. Box office: 0131-623 8030.

Comedy

Boothby Graffoe
****
Gilded Balloon Main Theatre

If you ever tire of comedy, see Boothby Graffoe. Not only does his set also include music hall, song and theatre, but the comic's wit alone could restore a jaded palate. He benefits, too, from an outstanding supporting cast. Veteran Steve Frost is superb as a comedy butler figure, and Graffoe has recruited Antonio Forcioni, one of the great acoustic guitarists, for semi-comedic duels. After a staggering display of virtuosity from Forcioni, Graffoe shrugs, looks at the audience and quips, "Has he got a work permit?"

Graffoe is an utterly deadpan stand-up. He is never less than acutely funny, whether improvising (on finding a biochemist in the crowd: "Have you got a girlfriend? Did you make her yourself?") or muttering about dogs in space. When the jokes are over, out come the songs: quirky little jewels like Radiator Head Child that have an idiosyncratic beauty worthy of Syd Barratt or Robyn Hitchcock. Barratt may have baulked at a line like "Your heart's in LA, your head's in my fridge", but then he never had to contend with fighting off a werewolf or the perils of the modern, urban comedy songwriter. "This is a guitar tuner," shrugs Graffoe. "My neighbours bought it for me." Fabulous.
Dave Simpson

Till August 28. Box office: 0131-226 2151.

 The Guardian recommends

Comedy

Dave Gorman
Impeccable timing as Gorman chronicles his quest to find others who share his name

Pleasance Above (0131-556 6550) till August 28

Otis Lee Crenshaw
Rich Hall as the singin' bigamist Tennessee jailbird

Pleasance Cabaret (0131-556 6550) till August 28

Pick Ups and Hick Ups
Subtitled To Love, Honour and Castrate, a cynical look at mating and dating

Pleasance Upstairs (0131-556 6550) till August 28

Scott Capurro
Subversive American comedian takes on child abuse and the Holocaust. Not for the easily offended.

Pleasance One (0131-556 6550) till August 28

Theatre

Messiah
Steven Berkoff at his blasphemous best, resurrecting Jesus while pondering whether he even existed

Assembly Rooms (0131-226 2428) till August 28

For What We Are About...
Powerful look at family life from a woman's point of view

Brunton Theatre, Musselburgh (0131-665 2240), till August 26

fields.headline: The last word on Poverty
fields.trailText: Draconian new restrictions on government loans to people on low-incomes - loans designed to help the poor to buy essentials like beds and cookers - have meant that of the £1.5m loan applications made last year, over 360,000 were refused as against 11,500 the preceding year.
fields.body:
Poor men's reasons are not heard - Thomas Fuller

Draconian new restrictions on government loans to people on low-incomes - loans designed to help the poor to buy essentials like beds and cookers - have meant that of the £1.5m loan applications made last year, over 360,000 were refused as against 11,500 the preceding year. These figures, published this week in the government's own Social Fund report, reveal a dramatic increase in hardship for many indigent people in Britain.

One of the measures of a good society is how it treats the poor. On the evidence of these numbers, we are not doing well. The government says it is limiting loans to prevent the poor getting further into debt. Critics appositely remark that the solution is not to restrict loans, but to reinstate the system of grants instead.

"Short of genius," observed Charles Peguy, "a rich man cannot imagine poverty." That is why the better-off think that poor people should go without television and cigarettes if they cannot afford them. This is a mistake, as an understanding of the nature of poverty shows.

There are several kinds of poverty. Third and first world poverty are entirely different in character because of the great difference in their historical and economic settings. The gruelling problems faced by the poor in the developing countries relate to bare survival, to the elemental task of getting water and food. Their plight is often further deeply complicated by war, corruption, flood or drought. Third world poverty is life on the margins of existence, a tough and unforgiving struggle, dedicated to the present moment and having room in it for only two feelings: despair and hope.

First world poverty is a relative matter, but no less painful for being so. Seneca's remark that "the poor man is not one who has little, but one who hankers after more" applies here. In developed societies possession of the amenities of life - which includes not just objects like houses and motor cars, but also powers, like being able to go out to the cinema or a restaurant, and to take holidays abroad - is equivalent to status, to full membership of the community, to having a place and a voice. Without these things one is less than half a citizen, disempowered and sidelined.

It is not merely a matter of symbols. The person who cannot afford a television or newspaper is not only barred from the life of the community, but is even detached from knowing what is happening in it. Poverty is not a virus, a natural disaster, an accident. It is man-made. The world's wealth is distributed in a grossly uneven way, not always or often reflecting true value - the MD of a City company annually earns more than 50 nurses, which is a strange fact. "The rich cannot eat money," a Russian proverb dryly observes, "so it's just as well that there are poor folk to grow their food."

The moral reasons for alleviating the hardships of poverty speak for themselves, but doubtlessly the pragmatic reasons for doing so are more likely to persuade the better off. In his Yorktown oration, Robert Winthrop wisely remarked that the poor should be treated liberally "so that mendicity shall not be tempted into mendacity, nor want exasperated into crime."

The link between poverty on the one hand, and on the other hand social unease, resentment, crime, unrest and eventually upheaval, is obvious enough; but it is not the mere fact of deprivation - by itself rather a damper than an igniter of action - but the sense of exclusion and injustice that grows from it, which drives people to antisocial action.

Few consciously choose poverty - saints and philosophers might, but it does not take one of the latter to teach us that elective poverty is not poverty - and the arrantly feckless and lazy are only a few of that few. "The rich man may never get into heaven," remarked Alexander Chase, "but the poor are already serving their term in hell."
