fields.headline: Welcome to the House and Garden of fun
fields.trailText: I went to the National theatre the other evening to see Alan Ayckbourn talking about his new plays, House and Garden.
fields.body:
I went to the National theatre the other evening to see Alan Ayckbourn talking about his new plays, House and Garden. Ayckbourn staged the platform interviews in the same way as the plays, moving from the Olivier to the Lyttleton and rotating with the actors - like Jane Asher - who were being interviewed. He was wearing large, all-terrain, shoes. Never was a man less equipped physically for all-terrain work; he described his scramble from one theatre to the other as "the actors' revenge" as he sat down panting.

Two nights later I went to see House. There had been warning signals in the interviews about the fundamental seriousness of Ayckbourn's views when he spoke of the alienation and remoteness of personal relationships. He cited the mobile phone as an example: in a restaurant he had seen a man chatting up a woman break off for a conversation and he wanted to warn him that this was going to prejudice his chances of scoring.

The play itself is often hilariously funny, only marred by the serious bits, which are strangely artificial and trivial: politics is a rum game; political fixers are loathsome ; the squirearchy is degenerate; teenagers are difficult; a woman's lot is impossible.

All good material for a comedy, but not new news. By introducing quasi-serious speeches I think Ayckbourn has made a category error, as if he isn't confident the audience can see that life isn't all froth, to use John Prescott's word of the week, and feels obliged to introduce a few homilies. Indeed Jane Asher, as the long-suffering wife, is given the weakest couple of lines I have heard in many a year to close the play.

Ayckbourn is concerned about the state of society, as the middle-aged are prone to be. Their assumption is that things were better once. You only have to read Virginia Woolf writing about a woman's lot in 1938 - the heyday of this golden era of public service broadcasting and focus-group-free politics - to know that a more closed society is not the same as a happier society. Things were much simpler in the recent past. As HR Haldeman told Nixon: "Once the toothpaste is out of the tube, it's goddamned difficult to get it back in."

Edinburgh is the place where disgruntled or superannuated broadcasting folk sound off. The latest salvo is from Sir John Drummond, once controller of Radio 3 and director of the Edinburgh festival. He trundles out the heavy cavalry with the word "Philistinism", which, in the acute gradations of cultural snobbism, is used to refer to anyone who has never sat through the Ring Cycle and doesn't know any Greek. The origins of the word lie with Matthew Arnold in an essay on Heinrich Heine: the English, like the townies or " Philister " at German universities, were thought to be inaccessible to ideas. Sir John thinks that baseball caps, worn backwards, are also a sign of Philistinism. The time has come for the walruses of culture to mothball this word, with its intimations of class; the day will never come again when a knowledge of the classics is the starting point for an educated man or woman.

That said, Drummond, makes some telling points. The most striking is perhaps the simplest, that culture is not just a question of feeling, or as he puts it, of gratification. I once had the pleasure of interviewing Harold Bloom, who believes that culture begins and ends with Shakespeare. Although this is a dotty idea, Bloom is passionately concerned about the lack of reading in America, by which he means the inability to understand and enjoy the texts themselves.

He told me, his voice ripe with derision, that one of his former students is now a leading deconstructionist. It is much easier to mount some trivial theory about the author and his times than to read and understand the language itself. Bloom and Drummond are absolutely right, there are no short-cuts to culture - not the internet, not media studies, not Britart, not relativism.

The problem, the deep philosophical problem, however, is in attributing value in a fragmented society. Are we in mourning for a society of posh chaps who knew a lot about everything except the real world or are we trying to produce an undemanding, serviceable education that will equip most people for life as they find it? Drummond's charge is that in TV, radio and politics, the choice has already been made of the undemanding and the superficial.

I did note that when he poured scorn on University Challenge, his criticism was of the failure of undergraduates to recognise Hamlet; no doubt he, like me, hasn't a clue about the science questions, but of course ignorance of science is not Philistinism, merely breeding.

These islands' greatest golfers are fat, comfortable-looking men. Darren Clarke's rear end juts like a rock ledge as he lights a large cigar on the last green and paddles off to the nearest bar or restaurant with all the contentment of a clubman of old. Little Ian Woosnam is an india rubber ball, no sharp edges visible, as he whacks the golf ball with his outsize driver, the shaft so long that its head cannot lie flat on the green. Lee Westwood, young, prematurely ovoid, looks as though he is eagerly anticipating the arrival of the scooter bringing the pizza, with extra pepperoni, at any minute.

And then there's Colin Montgomerie, he of the wobbly pectorals. Monty, after the Open, said he would lose weight. Most professional commentators thought it was a joke, but I thought I detected a certain seething discontent. And sure enough, a few weeks later a trim new Monty was unveiled. Just when it seemed that the Brits had found a sport at which they could excel, one which demanded neither self-denial nor unnecessary exercise, Monty has broken ranks.

But being thin - relatively - doesn't suit him. His face, an old-fashioned, relaxed hold-all, has become unnaturally drawn. Nor does the new face go with the relaxed, looping, swing. He wants to be Tiger Woods; he wants to be whippet-lean and toned. I think this is a mistake. A man swinging a golf club, says John Updike, is at his most naked. Wealth, birth and status mean nothing at that moment. The player is utterly alone.

Monty is a chubby fellow, with a chubby swing. This swing is untroubled by fine-tuning and introspection, but it may be ruined by diet. The swing may try to escape this regime. As someone said, in every Lean film, there is a fat film trying to get out.

webTitle: Newspapers' role in promoting ethnic diversity

fields.headline: Name fame
fields.standfirst: Them and us... deaths, marriages and birth announcements
fields.trailText: Last year the king of Jordan was supposed to have disguised himself as a taxi-driver to find out what his people really felt and thought. Driving a cab or riding the Tube would be a good idea, not only for kings and prime ministers, but also for newspaper editors, who play a crucial role in shaping a national identity and culture.
fields.body:
Last year the king of Jordan was supposed to have disguised himself as a taxi-driver to find out what his people really felt and thought. Driving a cab or riding the Tube would be a good idea, not only for kings and prime ministers, but also for newspaper editors, who play a crucial role in shaping a national identity and culture. A nation's fears and prejudices can certainly be triggered by sensational tabloid campaigns, such as the News of the World's name-and-shame anti-paedophile campaign. But they also develop, less visibly and dramatically, on a day-to-day basis, in response to more muted signals and omissions in the broadsheets.

This week I witnessed a scene on a London bus that strikingly reflected both the real changes in the city's multicultural demography and the lingering racism, xenophobia, and aggression below the surface. A large middle eastern family, including women and babies, and laden with pushchairs and shopping, were having trouble keeping their packages out of the aisle. An elderly lady nearly tripped over their trolley. When they got off at the next stop, a man near the exit loudly expressed his disgust: "Wouldn't have been allowed on the bus in my day. Should go back where they came from! No buses in the desert!"

How did this incident connect to the influence of the serious press? Neither the xenophobe nor the women were probable readers of the Guardian or the Telegraph. I remember that when I first came to London in the 60s, elderly ladies would also make racist remarks on the buses, usually about the Jamaican conductors. Certainly Britain has become a more legally egalitarian country, and the press has contributed, through editorials, to the notable decline of intolerance, incivility, and small-minded provincialism.

But the press could also take more notice of the subtle changes that occur when a society is transformed by immigration and manners, and help its readers become more aware and understanding. As an American, I'm aware of small but intriguing differences between British and American media, especially around the representation of birth, marriage, and death. Such events and their accompanying rituals are part of our lives, but they get widely varying treatment in the press.

Some British newspapers, including the Guardian, ignore birth and downplay marriage. Others treat birth and marriage as society news or paid announcements. Virtually all give most attention and space to death, in obituaries and wills.

An obituary signals that someone has had a life of distinction, whereas a newborn has few accomplishments beyond its parentage. But the British broadsheets, despite their enlightened editorial policies, still seem to reflect the beginnings and endings of an elite population. American newspapers give most attention to marriage, in a culture where intermarriages, upwardly mobile marriages, and contemporary courtship are subjects of intense social scrutiny.

The British press is more interested in birth than its American counterpart, but in a different way. The Times and Telegraph publish birth announcements as social events: "Born to James and Antonia, Cassandra Hermione, a sister for Tarquin." All the papers treat the arrival of a well-born infant, from baby Leo to baby Rocco, as a significant news item (and Hello! and OK couldn't survive a week without "presenting" the infants of B-list celebs).

The papers list birthdays, not only of the famous living but also of the dead; and they are impressed by the birthdays of the very old, especially aged royals. Undoubtedly, most of this coverage is simply tradition, but it also reinforces an anachronistic image of the class system, with its hereditary titles, and of the traditional family with two parents.

By contrast, when American newspapers report birth, they tend to do so as a sociological rather than a social occasion. The Washington Post lists "district newborns" by hospital in a weekly column, an illuminating glimpse of American diversity and social change. Many of the births are to single mothers, or unmarried couples, and the babies' names reveal ethnicity and inventiveness. These are examples from the weeks in which my grandchildren were born: Va'Shay, Bridget, Valencia, Precious Tityana, Lovely Candy, Nirvana Joy, Lawrencia Noelene, Ebony Imani (girls); Efuw Bandiwa, Kavon Shamal, John Geoffrey, Sincere Lamont, Da'Quan Ali, Marques Javonne (boys).

I suspect that most of the babies on that bus were born here, and I'm sure that a journalistic record of births in London would reveal as much ethnic diversity as in Washington or New York. All of the papers devoted considerable space this week to Madonna's complaints that English hospitals were inefficient and Victorian; they pointed out that infant mortality rates in Britain are lower than in the US. There are social as well as medical changes taking place in those Victorian hospitals, with long-term significance for the culture as a whole, and not just for jetset celebrities.

fields.headline: Turning off the testosterone tap
fields.standfirst: 'Older men going out with young women have as much in common (low sex drive) as do older women with young men (high sex drive)'
fields.trailText: 'Older men going out with young women have as much in common (low sex drive) as do older women with young men (high sex drive).'
fields.body:
Until very recently, no matter how liberal he was, a man could argue himself blue in the face that he was totally in favour of all possible equalities between men and women, and then at the last moment slip the stiletto between the ribs: "Ah, but Nature, you see - Nature's different. No matter how many laws we pass to legally enshrine women's equality, Nature is always going to put the boot in. And it's a sad fact that, while women become sexually superfluous after the menopause, a man can have children until the end of his life. Look at Charlie Chaplin - he was fathering babies in his 80s!" Though, as Nora Ephron pointed out in When Harry Met Sally, he was also so infirm that he couldn't pick them up.

But all that man-eternally-fertile/ woman-good-for-15-years-tops eyewash has come in for a right bashing over the past few weeks. First, there were the conclusive studies showing that sperm quality decreases in men over the age of 24, and that it would take a man of 35 at least twice as long as a man of 25 to get the same fertile woman pregnant. In a nice twist on the old cliché, this means that it is not wise to send a man to do a boy's job.

It also means that all that jive from the likes of Dr Michael Odent - about how women should "purify" themselves for a year before attempting to conceive, while putative fathers may go on smoking and drinking and generally whooping it up - is a pile of sexist claptrap. (Where I come from, it's invariably the girls who drink and smoke the most who get pregnant quickest - I think it's called being loose.) Can it be any coincidence that, between the ages of 25 and 35, most men will eat their own weight in fry-ups, piss away a river of lager and smoke themselves blue in the face! It's a wonder their sperm can be arsed to move at all: "Nah, don't fancy it, bruv. Man U's playing. You go instead. And give 'er one from me, mah son." How ironic that adhering to the Loaded lifestyle has done far more than the hobnail-booted march of feminism in rendering man "unmanly".

Then, last week, the much-respected Professor Mel Greaves of the Institute of Cancer Research announced that, if women wished to remain cancer-free, they should have more children far younger - and, more problematically, that men could best avoid the disease by not copulating beyond their prime. Prostate cancer is now the second most common male cancer, diagnosed in 21,000 men each year and killing more than 9,500 of them; this, says Professor Greaves, is because men are not biologically programmed to have sex beyond the age of 50: "What other mammal, including dogs and our great ape relatives, continues to indulge in sexual activity long after it can successfully compete with younger, fitter males for the favours of the harem?" he demanded rhetorically. Failure to turn off the "testosterone tap", apparently, promotes the growth of fatal cancers.

With women now bearing the burden of Aids in Africa (due largely, it is thought, to men's refusal to wear condoms in general, and to the nasty habit of old men forcing themselves on to very young girls in particular - in some parts of Africa, it is thought that sleeping with a virgin "cures" a man with Aids) and dropping like flies with breast and cervical cancer at home (cervical cancer itself being widely thought to come from sexual exposure to men, as nuns hardly ever get it), it's a relief to find out that there's something we can't get. And it's the cherry on the top that men would get it less if they only learned to practise sexual continence - something that has apparently been the answer to every last bit of female trouble since time immemorial.

Add to this the news that no critics will be allowed to see the new Richard Gere and Winona Ryder film before its release due to audience previews, which ended in hilarity and disgust at the May-September romance (have you ever noticed how that "September" is always stuck in to preserve the old guy's glamour, like he's still in the "Indian Summer" of his youth? Anyone looking at the 51-year- old Gere next to the 29-year-old Ryder would surely agree that May-November is nearer the mark) and we might venture the guess that the myth of men getting "better" as they get older, while women just go south, is well and truly on the skids.

Women have been treated like sexual livestock for so long - in training, nubile, past it - that we have long since learned to live with the insults that come with each stage and just get on with enjoying them, anyway. For men, who are encouraged to think of themselves as veritable sex machines from the cradle to the grave, the news that they wither and perish reproductively - just like a woman - is going to take some getting used to. Exactly how differently men and women approach ageing can be seen, interestingly, in aforementioned May-September flings. webTitle: Review: Così Fan Tutte - Salzburg festival

fields.headline: A new leash of life
fields.standfirst: It shocked Salzburg, but a racy version of Così Fan Tutte delighted Edward Greenfield
fields.trailText: It shocked Salzburg, but a racy version of Così Fan Tutte delighted Edward Greenfield.
fields.body:
A kinky Così at the Salzburg festival? Whatever next? That was the immediate shocked response to Hans Neuenfels's new production of Mozart's opera at the Kleines Festspielhaus. Not only does it dress all four lovers in identical unisex outfits (including corsets) and Despina in men's clothes, but the heroine, Fiordiligi, sings her big aria of defiance, Come Scoglio, holding the leashes of two men on all fours wearing leather dog-masks.

Performance, however, reveals that this vision is intended merely to illustrate Fiordiligi's defiance - just one example of Neuenfels's inventive, if overenthusiastic, use of symbols. So there are no disguises when Ferrando and Guglielmo return as Albanians: the women have drunk the juice of a giant poppy and are just suffering from hallucinations.

This is far too busy a production, but the performance is hard to match, with Lothar Zagrosek drawing stylish playing from the Vienna Philharmonic. Karita Mattila as a radiant Fiordiligi, Vesselina Kasarova as a feisty Dorabella and Maria Bayo as a pert Despina make an ideal team of women, with Rainer Trost (Ferrando), Simon Keenlyside (Guglielmo) and Franz Hawlata (Don Alfonso) almost as strong.

The other Mozart/Da Ponte opera at Salzburg this year, Don Giovanni, comes in a revival of last year's production by Luca Ronconi. This too is heavily weighed down by symbols, with clock faces littering the stage of the Grosses Festspiel haus, but the 30s setting generally works well. It only loses its way at the end, when the principal characters suddenly grow old and grey.

With conductor Valery Gergiev a hectic but electrifying Mozartian, the performance is musically magnetic, with Renée Fleming masterly as Donna Anna and well contrasted with Marina Mescheriakova as Elvira. Ferruccio Furlanetto is a strong, mature Don, and René Pape as Leporello gives the most vivid performance of all.

Also at the Grosses Festspielhaus, Lorin Maazel has taken over from an indisposed Claudio Abbado for Klaus Michael Grüber's production of Tristan und Isolde. Eduardo Arroyo's sets, including a skeletal sailing ship in act one, are undistracting (if not ideally atmospheric) while Maazel, using the widest dynamic range, draws sensuously beautiful playing from the Vienna Phil. It provides rich support for the glorious Isolde of Waltraud Meier, and makes one forgive the lumpishness of Jon Fredric West as Tristan.

One major theme at Salzburg this year is French opera, with the showpiece a new production by Herbert Wernicke of Berlioz's epic, The Trojans. Still ignored at the Paris Opera after almost 150 years, this gloriously wilful masterpiece comes in a warmly idiomatic performance with the Orchestre de Paris and a French conductor, Sylvain Cambreling. Though Wernicke's production, using a stage cliche, has modern combat troops carrying Kalashnikovs, the simple white semi-circular permanent set works well. Deborah Polaski is a pillar of strength as both Cassandra and Dido. Next to her, Jon Villars as Aeneas is rather a stolid hero.

It was good, too, to have the last of the reform operas that Gluck wrote for Paris, Iphigénie en Tauride. This was bitingly compact, with Ivor Bolton drawing stylish playing from the Mozarteum Orchestra. That and superb singing from the three American principals - Susan Graham in the title role, with Thomas Hampson as Oreste and Paul Groves as Pylade - made it easier to accept an uninspired production by Claus Guth. He failed totally to exploit the atmosphere of the courtyard of the Residenz Palace, again relying on the cliche of updating, with the women in Victorian black and the men in combat trousers.

fields.headline: Holidays in hell
fields.standfirst: Last night's TV
fields.trailText: Last night's TV
fields.body:
There is, I believe, a cunning plan by TV executives to reverse the decline in audiences. Not unlike the evil Syndicate from The X Files, they are a shadowy lot - maybe with names like the Well Manicured Man, the Cigarette-Smoking Man, the Man-Breasts Man - whose sole aim is to frighten the British public into never leaving home again. How else do you explain Destination Nightmare (BBC1), which told horror stories of holidays gone wrong?

There was Kevin and Samantha, whose Bahamanian wedding was ruined by Hurricane Floyd; Peter, who got shot in a taxi in Bangkok; and Steven, who was trampled by an elephant in Botswana. They had all set out for a dreamy time and it had turned nightmarish. "It was worse than Blackpool," Samantha's chum Suzanne noted. And before you think that is simply a lesson in avoiding destinations beginning with the letter B, John and Edna had a terrible time in the Seychelles, while in Interlaken a flash flood killed 21 people canyoning in a gorge.

Of all the contributors, Kevin and Samantha and friends Robbie and Suzanne were the most hilarious. Not ones to let a terrifying weather phenomenon get in the way of their holiday videomaking, Kevin and Robbie wandered round the deserted beach in gale-force winds, camera in hand. Robbie was most excited: "It's a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity." Sure is. Can't think of anything more once-in-a-lifetime than getting killed by a flying deckchair. And we wonder why foreigners think British folk are stupid.

Destination Nightmare was a truly appalling programme, not because of the natural disasters, rogue animals and human incompetence that it depicted - although the story of a man whose bungee-jump rope was too long was pretty awful - but because it was a sprawling mess of voyeuristic sensationalism dressed up as a public-service broadcast. Its tone was uneven and crass, lurching from the Interlaken deaths to John and Edna's building-site fiasco with indecency not seen since That's Life moved from stories of child abuse to Doc Cox and potatoes resembling ladyparts. As if that weren't terrible enough, we got to see Nick Ross in skintight rubber, a delight normally reserved for the Crimewatch wrap party.

Over on Brookside (Channel 4), meanwhile, Our Linz has taken her first tentative steps into Liverpool's gay scene. If it's really as rubbish as Brookie makes out, there must be closets stuffed with scouse jessies gagging for somewhere decent to dance to Kylie (Minogue, not Lindsey's daughter) and wear their tight, bright white shirts.

Of course, telly never does clubbing very well. It doesn't even do dancing. If ever there's a club night at E20 in EastEnders, the place looks like a waiting room for people desperate for a pee.

Anyway, Linz was enthusing. "It's packed in here," she breathed, when it quite obviously wasn't, possibly displaying the first signs of agoraphobia. And it was all going splendidly until they met Lance from the bar (Lance is a more Home and Away name, don't you think?) and Shelley's ex, a Bronagh Gallagher lookalike. Suddenly Shelley had a headache and had to go home. And Linz never even got to do her Britney routine (that's dancing, not believing in God and capital punishment).

On the Close, Jimmy popped round to Dr Darren's for some more "tabs" (unspecified, as prescription drugs always are in Soapland), having gone through them like smack all day. The good doctor snarled: "This isn't an all-night drop-in centre". Well, that's not what he tells Susannah, is it? Word to the wise, Darren: don't let her drive you anywhere or you'll find yourself shooting through the windscreen at 100 miles an hour.

And not in a nice way. Susannah, meanwhile, was convincing Victoria, Darren's ex, to give up on him so she could have his little injections all to herself. A sticky end awaits that lady. Again, not in a nice way.

Find a Fortune (ITV): steal Carol Vorderman's cheque book.

fields.headline: Watch the skies
fields.standfirst: The week in radio, by Tanya Wilson
fields.trailText: The week in radio, by Tanya Wilson
fields.body:
Summertime, and the living is easy. Well, no, not really. The radio schedules go all fluffy on us; midges are everywhere (in Scotland), as are flying ants (in England). So much of a summery thing are the winged creatures that one Dr David Stradling even dedicated a short programme to them, Ant Flying Day (Radio 4). Adults and children shared their thoughts on why "their world feels out of kilter on the day the ants take over". Some people have led sheltered lives.

My world felt pretty much out of kilter with the slew of seasonal dramas this week.Take Summer of Love at the Buena Vista, Margate (Radio 4). It is true that this was an afternoon play and thus I should not have been expecting Brechtian alienation techniques - but still...

The music interludes of the play, set in 1967, were the best bits, with plenty of Beach Boys and Scott Mackenzie's San Francisco: "Be sure to wear some flowers in your hair." But I, in my deckchair and with lobelia in my locks, would have been a more convincing evocation of the summer of love than this overripe little drama. We had cheeky northern types ("rutting stags"), a Swedish girl with "enormous - they really are enormous" breasts; stuck-up Sally who wasn't really; Alfred the Teutonic chef with a broken heart, and a truly ludicrous plot.

Equally bizarre was the first part of Memoirs of a 12th Man (Radio 4) a new comic series by Anthony Couch. The Beast of Chardley was that uphill struggle of a concept, a comedy about the pressures of village cricket. I'm quite prepared to believe there are people out there who find this kind of country-bumpkin, ooh-arr nonsense funny - I just don't want to be sat next to them on long coach journeys. It was full of men called things like Gussy, Withers and Ted Lusty, and jokes of this ilk: "Fellas with rollers? - do you mean hairdressers?" Roll on winter, eh?

All that saved me from that sacrilegious thought was Picnic Fever (Radio 3), a short stab of summery nostalgia, lovely in the way that rubbing sand off your feet as you leave the beach is lovely.

A woman remembers her child-hood, moving from place to place because of unpaid bills that sat in jars "like wild flowers". The two big things in her life were her first love, Billy Cudlipp, master of pickled-onion burps, and a picnic her mother organised. The picnic went sour, the sun went in, she had to leave Billy behind, but this was a burst of warmth, briefly evoking that glow childhood summers have in old photographs.

fields.headline: Dixieland, mid-Wales
fields.standfirst: This year's Brecon jazz festival was hectic as ever, says Tony Heath
fields.trailText: This year's Brecon jazz festival was hectic as ever, says Tony Heath.
fields.body:
Showcase for the famous or seedbeed for undiscovered talent? The 17th Brecon jazz festival, with its 90-odd gigs packed into 48 hours, showed that it could be both.

This year Regina Carter, a virtuoso of the violin - an instrument with an obscure place in jazz despite the fame of Stephane Grappelli - took the audience by storm. Lady Be Good has always offered fertile ground for improvisers, but the New Yorker pushed the old standard towards new horizons.

Dr John, an elegant and eager pianist with three Grammy awards under his belt, and Bud Shank, a professor of the cool school of West Coast music, also made it across the pond to the mid-Wales town, which coped perspiringly with an influx of around 50,000 visitors. Shank, a mannered saxophonist who played with Stan Kenton and Charlie Barnett half a century ago, recalled the tribute paid to him by Duke Ellington: "He even shook Johnny Hodges - he is something else."

George Melly, an honorary Brecon citizen who used to live near the town and fished in the River Usk with ferocious determination, tirelessly champions the festival. This year he teamed up again with his old friends the John Chilton Feetwarmers.

Finding new sounds means dodging around between outdoor venues and a multitude of hostelries. The urge to move came to a halt at the Castle Hotel, where the 18-piece Byron Jones Big Band performed. A modern edge was given to the band's swinging roots; favourites like You'd Be So Nice To Come Home To and It Might As Well Be Spring had a sharpness to them. Solos set a couple of numbers alight. Gethin Liddington, a muscular trumpeter, produced a memorable rendition of Night in Tunisia. Mike Starr handled the alto sax with aplomb and Sophisticated Lady gave him a chance to explore. His improvisations were carefully crafted in sharp and clear tones.

There was never any doubt about the success of the final concert when Chris Barber's Jazz and Blues Band took the stage in the town's market hall. Their version of St Louis Blues had a clarinet singing happily above Barber on trombone - he is a true veteran, who has been playing for more than 50 years. Rampart Street Parade and Sweet Georgia Brown were performed with gusto, proving that there's nothing like a familiar tune to send audiences away happy.

George Melly, an honorary Brecon citizen who used to live near the town and fished in the River Usk with ferocious determination, tirelessly champions the festival. This year he teamed up again with his old friends the John Chilton Feetwarmers. Finding new sounds means dodging around between outdoor venues and a multitude of hostelries. The urge to move came to a halt at the Castle Hotel, where the 18-piece Byron Jones Big Band performed. Gethin Liddington, a muscular trumpeter, produced a memorable rendition of Night in Tunisia. Mike Starr handled the alto sax with aplomb and Sophisticated Lady gave him a chance to explore. His improvisations were carefully crafted in sharp and clear tones. There was never any doubt about the success of the final concert when Chris Barber's Jazz and Blues Band took the stage in the town's market hall. Their version of St Louis Blues had a clarinet singing happily above Barber on trombone - he is a true veteran, who has been playing for more than 50 years. Rampart Street Parade and Sweet Georgia Brown were performed with gusto, proving that there's nothing like a familiar tune to send audiences away happy.

fields.headline: Watery smiles of a summer night
fields.standfirst: David Ward endures and enjoys Shakespeare al fresco
fields.trailText: "The fold stands empty in the drowned field... The nine men's morris is filled up with mud." The words warn anyone tempted to stage Shakespeare in the open air in a British summer.
fields.body:
"The fold stands empty in the drowned field... The nine men's morris is filled up with mud." The words warn anyone tempted to stage Shakespeare in the open air in a British summer. The lawn wasn't filled up with mud but it was squelchy. As feet went down, water came up. Chairs were set on plywood planks to stop their legs sinking into the sog.

Come early, they said, we'll stroll to the play across the fields. An agreeable way to approach A Midsummer Night's Dream on a summer night in the north. But on our motorway journey, the horned moon, the governess of floods, had scarpered behind black clouds over Bolton; through streaming windows we thought we glimpsed pelting rivers which had overborne their continents.

We won't walk, they said when we arrived, so we piled picnics, brollies, boots, and Goretex galore into their car. Down the hill, the company was still selling tickets and programmes with heroic optimism. Puddles filled every plastic chair and we hijacked a park bench, sat on Tesco bags and cowered beneath a protecting but embarrassing Guardian/ Observer umbrella.

Before us a large audience suspended disbelief, refusing to accept that rain coming down in torrents, floods, cats, dogs and stair-rods could possibly stop play. The precipitation was wished away; it did not exist.

But a woman wandered up in one of those long brown coats from Australia that have replaced Barbours as stylish foul weather gear. "This is my birthday," she sniffed, taking a sad swig from a fizzing glass. "The rain is diluting my champagne and my smoked salmon looks as if it wants to swim back to its natural state."

Enter a man with a megaphone, his defiant white shirt already transparent with wet. "We'll give it five minutes," he said, already knowing in his brave heart that this deluge would last longer than Noah's.

We hit the red plonk. Someone with sopping hair, a man recklessly cheerful because, so it was said, he had at last completed his PhD on Noddy, ate a giant muffin. Wet Shirt came out again and gurgled a message down his dripping megaphone.

A waterlogged recorder played a few liquid bars and Theseus, Hippolyta, Egeus, Hermia, Lysander and Demetrius flippered on to the stage. "Now, fair Hippolyta, our nuptial hour/ Draws on apace," gurgled Theseus as a waterfall cascaded down his bride-to-be's cleavage. Not that we could see or hear her or him. Our eyes were full of umbrellas and our ears full of the sound of much water striking tensed cotton.

We hit the red plonk again and wondered how long this would go on. If Puck was going to reach that bit at the end of act five where he asks us to give him our hands, he would need an aqualung and we would need armbands. After eight minutes, a woman in the third row cracked. Gathering up her gear and her husband and muttering " 'Scuse please, thank you," she shuffled down the row and towards her car.

After the briefest of pauses, another couple rose and did a bunk. Then a third and fourth. The trickle turned into a torrent. Suddenly we could see the young actors thinking. "Bugger this," they said, or so we thought. "If the audience is leaving, so are we." They ran for the tennis lawn and the cover of their tents where they floated off into dreams of drier nights.

The next night most of us came back. A warm sun shone on this sylvan glade and from our dry seats we could hardly see the pylon on the horizon. New bottles popped and someone dropped a luscious strawberry. It was a proper summer night, one for merriments and the pert and nimble spirit of mirth. (And midges.)

The only signs of the previous wet Dream were the damp patches on Puck's leggings as he knelt on the grass after translating Bottom.

"I go, I go: look how I go/ Swifter than arrow from the tartar's bow," he cried just as a Ford Transit drove slowly through a gap between the trees. As he put a girdle round the world in forty minutes, he appeared to enlist the help of a Tiger Moth which buzzed lazily over the natural auditorium before disappearing towards the western flanks of the Pennines. When he came back, so did a train, scurrying home from Blackburn.

"Hand in hand with fairy grace," said Titania, as the revels ended, "We will sing and bless this place."

webTitle: Harsh realities behind the recent Irish success story

fields.headline: A tiger by the tail
fields.standfirst: After a decade abroad, John O'Mahony goes home to Dublin and finds that the fabled Celtic success story conceals a harsh reality of corruption, poverty and racism
fields.trailText: After a decade abroad, John O'Mahony goes home to Dublin and finds that the fabled Celtic success story conceals a harsh reality of corruption, poverty and racism.
fields.body:
Back in 1992, long before Ireland began its dizzying economic upward curve, a group of theatregoers huddled into Dublin's cramped Project theatre to witness The Emergency Session, an evening of hardcore Celtic gangsta-rap, presented by the country's most celebrated young company, Rough Magic. As the lights came down over thumping breakbeats, our MC, a hip-hop reincarnation of Ireland's first president and guiding spiritual father, Eamon de Valera, pimp-rolled onstage to the rhythm, spitting out the verses in that priestly county Limerick twang so familiar to the home audience.

Numbers included Cead Mile Failte [100,000 welcomes], Bitch, an indictment of the Republic's treatment of women, and Neutral, More or Less, about Ireland's famed nudge-and-wink neutrality. However, the most memorable moment came with a tongue-in-cheek vision called Eire 2016AD, which conjured up a rosy picture of the state a century on from the uprising against British rule that led to its foundation: "This country's really moving, the economy's improving," rapped MC Dev to incredulous guffaws, before following up with the queasy prediction:

"We all know how it's going to be, don't we?
One big theme park, a quaint holiday,
Unless you're female or homeless or gay.
But we won't let reality get in the way,
Here in theme park Ireland, Slainte, have a nice day..."

Returning to live in Ireland after almost 10 years away, I have often been struck by the eerie prescience of that show, a cassette of which I carried with me on my odyssey first to London and then to St Petersburg. What was then so preposterous that it barely made sense in the realm of satire has now miraculously become a reality. From a basket-case economy that ran up such debilitating international debt in the late 70s and 80s that the IMF seriously considered foreclosure in 1986, Ireland has been transformed into the mythical Celtic Tiger, a technological overachiever with double digit growth rates approaching three times the European average.

Unemployment, which approached 20% in the 80s, is now down to 4%, and the debilitating, centuries-old emigration trend has been shunted into reverse. In the most startling development, Ireland is now the world's biggest exporter of computer software, nudging ahead of America for the first time last year.

Entirely new stereotypes have displaced the downtrodden models of the past: "Striding through the streets of Dublin these days," gushed Fortune magazine late last year, "is an entirely new species of Irishman and Irishwoman: educated, optimistic and affluent - unaffected by the twin demons of poverty and despair that hounded their ancestors for the last several hundred years."

And the Irish Times recently claimed: "There is now a real surge of power in the Celtic psyche, where the Irish in the world are seen as models for business acumen, drive, ambition, political and social progress and achievements in the arenas of music, sport and literature."

Yet despite the frothy rhetoric - which appears to have intoxicated most politicians - it is difficult to escape the sense that the Irish were still refusing to let "reality get in the way". Certainly the Dublin that greeted me was not the vibrant model capital of these congratulatory profiles, but largely the same scattered, grubby and vaguely planned provincial city I'd left 10 years ago, though now far more polluted and congested. House prices had gone up 300-500% and, as was obvious from the blankets and bundles in shop doorways across the city, homelessness had reached conspicuous, Thatcherite proportions, rising by 150% in the past year. Though there were considerably more jobs around, few people in my immediate circle were materially better off, and many felt the opposite.

And the general mood among many commentators was far from celebratory: "The economic boom has not really reflected itself on the basics of what people expect of living in a decent society," says author and columnist Fintan O'Toole, "A lot of the impact has been negative, in that it is much more difficult to buy a house, to travel around the capital, and to access a lot of basic services." Far from being a nation finally at peace with itself and comfortable with its new-found affluence, Celtic Tiger Ireland seems increasingly fraught with contradictions.

Few economists or politicians predicted this and, consequently, even fewer have any idea of what course it will take in the future. It is also an economic recovery that happened almost entirely independently of the Irish business elite, who had conspicuously failed for decades to lift the country out of terminal depression.

The Celtic Tiger was essentially created not by the Irish but by American hi-tech multinationals, eager to find a convenient launch-pad into Europe and attracted to Ireland by its educated and moderately rewarded workforce, Euro-friendly orientation, and crucially, by its rock-bottom 10% rate of corporate tax (compared to 40% in Germany and over 30% in Britain). Put bluntly: "It was based on criminally low taxation rates to attract foreign industry," says writer and journalist John Waters. " In effect, Ireland became a laundering operation for multinational industry in order to avoid tax."

By the mid-90s, this was beginning to bear fruit: $7bn direct investment in 1997 alone. The impact has been most beneficially felt in the employment market. Jobs have become so freely available that Ireland, once Europe's greatest exporter of humanity, has now begun to run out of people - every shop or restaurant window in Dublin now displays "help wanted" notices, computer programmers are recruited en masse from Russia and navvies shipped in from London. Meanwhile, wages for the majority of the Irish inhabitants have been kept artificially low by a "social partnership" agreement and still weigh in at just 80% of the European average.

Corruption is now ancient history
There were no convictions (obviously)
Well, different standards applied at the time,
We didn't know taking a bribe was a crime,
It used to be called a consultancy fee
Way back in 2015AD.

No other single factor has done quite so much to undermine the inflated rhetoric of the boom than the constant revelations flowing from tribunals set up to investigate massive wrongdoing by the political and business elite in the 70s, 80s and early 90s. Irish politics is now not merely tainted by corruption, but characterised by it. The definitive Irish sleaze bible is an engrossing little tome entitled This Great Little Nation: the A-Z of Irish Scandals and Controversies. It was written by Gene Kerrigan and Pat Brennan, and runs to over 300 pages of epic wrongdoing in the beef industry, a little priestly paedophilia, land re-zoning scams, bribe-taking, party political cronyism and a massive banking tax evasion scheme.

At the centre of the vast web of political scandal is Charles Haughey, the country's taoiseach - prime minister - throughout much of the 80s and early 90s. It transpires that Haughey supported a lavish lifestyle by soliciting "donations" from businessmen totalling some IR£8m, and misdirected party funds, including some for his own use. Facilitated by his financial adviser, he also operated a secret offshore financial haven, and in the latest, grubby instalment, played out some weeks ago before the Moriarty tribunal, ran up a IR£1.1m unauthorised bank overdraft in the 70s, some of which was never paid off. Beneath Haughey, there appears to have been a legion of dishonest politicians and business leaders, many operating the same Cayman Island scheme to evade tax.

Exactly how and why Ireland became the land of crooks and shirkers may puzzle us for decades. Much of it happened simply because, amid weak democratic structures and lazy press reporting, it could. But some of it must be put down to a peculiarly Irish distrust of structures of power, rules and regulations, always considered alien and Anglo-Saxon.

The essential "truth" of Irish social interaction - ad hoc, unstructured, public house relations - was always liable to degrade into cronyism and graft: "It was part of that kind of macho world where one could also tell your friends how you had drunk seven pints, driven home and evaded Garda checkpoints," says novelist Dermot Bolger. "In the same way that drunken driving was publicly acceptable, tax evasion wasn't regarded as criminal."

By far the most disturbing aspect of this corruption is the country's reluctance to punish any of the culprits. To date, none of the major protagonists has been imprisoned or even fined. After an abortive attempt to bring Haughey to trial, he still enjoys a luxurious lifestyle in his north Dublin mansion and on his own private island. Instead of being penalised, these disgraced figures of the past have simply crept back into the system and many have been the greatest beneficiaries of the boom. It is likely that we are now generating plenty of fresh material for the tribunals of the future.

Now we're no longer down on our knees,
Our children don't have to seek work overseas
And so we can counsel these new refugees
Flooding into the country in twos and threes
Get back in line, can't you read the sign
No dogs or Bosnians please.

On a social level, the boastfulness and bluster of the new Celtic Tiger ethos has not translated into an inclusive and open-minded national outlook, a real confidence that would reflect a people sure of their own abilities and able to respect the contributions of others. In fact, it appears to have triggered long-dormant prejudices, actively encouraging a nasty strain of unselfconscious xenophobia.

The persistent railing against "blacks" that many of us have heard from friends and relatives, and the often naked aggression against foreigners on the streets of the capital, couldn't be more profoundly disappointing. Most of the hostility is directed against asylum-seekers, who have begun to arrive in significant but relatively small numbers - rising from 362 to 8,000 over the past six years: nine in 10 have experienced verbal abuse on the streets, according to one survey, and seven out of 10 had been refused services.

The government this year launched a policy of dispersal, which basically dumps refugees in rural areas where they are isolated from support and aid groups, barred from working, given meals in B&B or hostel conditions that they often cannot tolerate on religious grounds, and given just IR£15 a week to live on. John McDermott of the Refugee Information Service, says: "Opposition politicians are fond of saying that it is a shambles. But it's not a shambles if you are a racist. If you are a racist it all makes perfect sense."

We've got democracy the Irish way,
With a referendum every day,
News update on the latest amendment,
You can have an abortion, as long as you're not pregnant.

There can be little doubt that Ireland has made a giant leap towards becoming a secular state over the past decade: contraception is now freely available, limited divorce is finally on the statutes and the influence of the church largely destroyed by sex scandals in the early 90s. The country is now predominantly urban, with two-thirds of the population living in towns and cities, a negative image of the 30s and 40s, when De Valera forged his vision of a rural priest-ridden Catholic wonderland, populated by athletic farm-boys and comely maidens dancing at the crossroads.

Yet, almost by sheer force of habit, much of the old order remains. This is still the only country in Europe to outlaw abortion, the only country in the world with this ban written into its constitution. In an act of collective moral doublethink, we continue to tolerate the fact that over 6,000 Irish women must travel every year to Britain for the operation, an alarmingly high percentage in late-term because of the lack of support and advice at home.

And though, in the wake of the infamous X case in 1992, when the state attempted to prevent a 14-year-old rape victim from travelling to London for a termination, abortions have been allowed on a technicality when the life of the mother was in danger, a new referendum is currently being mooted to plug this loophole.

A frantic Riverdancing nation,
Faint with self congratulation,
Where the only debate we'll ever condone, is
Will there be life after Boyzone?

One of the more striking ironies of the Irish resurgence is that, as the new mythology rises up to displace the defunct rural, mud-hut primitive imagery of the past, Ireland has become far more efficient, in the cultural arena, at manufacturing and marketing the old stereotypes. The success of this strategy is reflected most spectacularly in the onward march of the Riverdance extravaganza, which has now moved ahead of U2 as Ireland's most lucrative cultural export. But the same dynamic is also evident in some more upmarket recent international successes, such as Martin McDonagh's Tony award-winning play The Beauty Queen of Leenane, and, to a lesser extent, Conor McPherson's The Weir, both of which peddle nostalgic and distorted aspects of Ireland and now appear even more hollow and untruthful.

McDonagh's melodramatic oeuvre seems particularly symptomatic of a culture being driven by an outmoded and objectified self-image, its plots crammed with stage-Oirish creatures of mind-boggling artifice, and dialogue laced with sub-Synge idioms that could creditably pass for parody.

For the audiences in London or New York who made successes of these plays, the west of Ireland shack settings and their logorrhaic muck-savage inhabitants appear impossibly exotic and elemental. When the works eventually return to Ireland, they are protected from any kind of vigorous criticism by a phalanx of awards and accolades. Overall, the dynamic is not unlike the one that has colonised downtown Dublin with fake Oirish pubs, whose emeraldy, signposty, plastic ambience proved such a huge hit in Helsinki and Manhattan that it was then re-imported back into Ireland, widely supplanting the authentic item that inspired them.

Irish culture has been transformed into little more than a brand name, specifically and somewhat cynically engineered to appeal to foreign or expatriate perceptions, and then mistaken for the real thing when it arrives home. Product that doesn't match the ingredients listed on the label, such as Marina Carr's play, On Raftery's Hill, which brilliantly captured the spirit of a xenophobic, inward-looking nation, is simply discarded, playing to half-full houses at home and receiving cool reviews abroad.

Ireland cannot really be like this.
One big theme Pub, the Pogue Mahone,
Where the rackrent landlords are all home grown,
There's a new pornography: property prices,
And the sexiest words are 'housing crisis.'
It's our own asylum, and so it will be,
In Eire 2016AD

Despite the economic and material advances made over the past decade, and the revolution in employment opportunities, Ireland is failing to live up to the expectations generated by its own propaganda and its new status as one of Europe's more affluent nations. If the new wealth is viewed as a test of national character, it is one that we have failed quite abjectly, in our treatment of refugees and other races, in our ability to build and maintain adequate public and social services, in our ability to share the dividends with the poorer sectors of society.

This adoptive self-image of a brash modern nation also fails to take account of the deeply conflicted nature of Irish society and alienates the majority who appear to be reaping meagre benefits. Truth for truth, and folly for folly, the idea of a technologically advanced, highly affluent Tiger nation striding boldly into the 21st century seems to be no more nor less accurate than any of the previous fictions that exerted such a grip on Irish identity, from the misty Celtic Twilight of Yeats to Dev's rosy rustic picture, each of which eventually led into a cultural and spiritual dead end.

Ireland is given to illusory, indulgent images of itself. With the latest Celtic Tiger variant, all it has managed to do is modernise its self-delusion. What Eire really looks like in 2016AD depends on decisions taken right now. With extra cash surging through the system, there is for the first time a chance to cut through these prevailing fictions and build a society on well-funded social principles.

However, we seem more intent on using further tax cuts to prolong the party, letting us bask a little longer in the glow of the superheated economy. All the indications suggest that we will be gazing back from MC Dev's watershed centennial year, fondly recalling the frenzy of the Celtic Tiger boom years and perhaps lamenting the missed opportunity to transform Ireland into a modern, egalitarian, inclusive as well as affluent country.

It transpires that Haughey supported a lavish lifestyle by soliciting "donations" from businessmen totalling some IR£8m, and misdirected party funds, including some for his own use. Facilitated by his financial adviser, he also operated a secret offshore financial haven, and in the latest, grubby instalment, played out some weeks ago before the Moriarty tribunal, ran up a IR£1.1m unauthorised bank overdraft in the 70s, some of which was never paid off. Beneath Haughey, there appears to have been a legion of dishonest politicians and business leaders, many operating the same Cayman Island scheme to evade tax. Exactly how and why Ireland became the land of crooks and shirkers may puzzle us for decades. Much of it happened simply because, amid weak democratic structures and lazy press reporting, it could. But some of it must be put down to a peculiarly Irish distrust of structures of power, rules and regulations, always considered alien and Anglo-Saxon. The essential "truth" of Irish social interaction - ad hoc, unstructured, public house relations - was always liable to degrade into cronyism and graft: "It was part of that kind of macho world where one could also tell your friends how you had drunk seven pints, driven home and evaded Garda checkpoints," says novelist Dermot Bolger. "In the same way that drunken driving was publicly acceptable, tax evasion wasn't regarded as criminal." By far the most disturbing aspect of this corruption is the country's reluctance to punish any of the culprits. To date, none of the major protagonists has been imprisoned or even fined. After an abortive attempt to bring Haughey to trial, he still enjoys a luxurious lifestyle in his north Dublin mansion and on his own private island. Instead of being penalised, these disgraced figures of the past have simply crept back into the system and many have been the greatest beneficiaries of the boom. It is likely that we are now generating plenty of fresh material for the tribunals of the future. Now we're no longer down on our knees, Our children don't have to seek work overseas And so we can counsel these new refugees Flooding into the country in twos and threes Get back in line, can't you read the sign No dogs or Bosnians please. On a social level, the boastfulness and bluster of the new Celtic Tiger ethos has not translated into an inclusive and open-minded national outlook, a real confidence that would reflect a people sure of their own abilities and able to respect the contributions of others. In fact, it appears to have triggered long-dormant prejudices, actively encouraging a nasty strain of unselfconscious xenophobia. The persistent railing against "blacks" that many of us have heard from friends and relatives, and the often naked aggression against foreigners on the streets of the capital, couldn't be more profoundly disappointing. Most of the hostility is directed against asylum-seekers, who have begun to arrive in significant but relatively small numbers - rising from 362 to 8,000 over the past six years: nine in 10 have experienced verbal abuse on the streets, according to one survey, and seven out of 10 had been refused services. The government this year launched a policy of dispersal, which basically dumps refugees in rural areas where they are isolated from support and aid groups, barred from working, given meals in B&B or hostel conditions that they often cannot tolerate on religious grounds, and given just IR£15 a week to live on. John McDermott of the Refugee Information Service, says: "Opposition politicians are fond of saying that it is a shambles. But it's not a shambles if you are a racist. If you are a racist it all makes perfect sense." We've got democracy the Irish way, With a referendum every day, News update on the latest amendment, You can have an abortion, as long as you're not pregnant. There can be little doubt that Ireland has made a giant leap towards becoming a secular state over the past decade: contraception is now freely available, limited divorce is finally on the statutes and the influence of the church largely destroyed by sex scandals in the early 90s. The country is now predominantly urban, with two-thirds of the population living in towns and cities, a negative image of the 30s and 40s, when De Valera forged his vision of a rural priest-ridden Catholic wonderland, populated by athletic farm-boys and comely maidens dancing at the crossroads. Yet, almost by sheer force of habit, much of the old order remains. This is still the only country in Europe to outlaw abortion, the only country in the world with this ban written into its constitution. In an act of collective moral doublethink, we continue to tolerate the fact that over 6,000 Irish women must travel every year to Britain for the operation, an alarmingly high percentage in late-term because of the lack of support and advice at home. And though, in the wake of the infamous X case in 1992, when the state attempted to prevent a 14-year-old rape victim from travelling to London for a termination, abortions have been allowed on a technicality when the life of the mother was in danger, a new referendum is currently being mooted to plug this loophole. A frantic Riverdancing nation, Faint with self congratulation, Where the only debate we'll ever condone, is Will there be life after Boyzone? One of the more striking ironies of the Irish resurgence is that, as the new mythology rises up to displace the defunct rural, mud-hut primitive imagery of the past, Ireland has become far more efficient, in the cultural arena, at manufacturing and marketing the old stereotypes. The success of this strategy is reflected most spectacularly in the onward march of the Riverdance extravaganza, which has now moved ahead of U2 as Ireland's most lucrative cultural export. But the same dynamic is also evident in some more upmarket recent international successes, such as Martin McDonagh's Tony award-winning play The Beauty Queen of Leenane, and, to a lesser extent, Conor McPherson's The Weir, both of which peddle nostalgic and distorted aspects of Ireland and now appear even more hollow and untruthful. McDonagh's melodramatic oeuvre seems particularly symptomatic of a culture being driven by an outmoded and objectified self-image, its plots crammed with stage-Oirish creatures of mind-boggling artifice, and dialogue laced with sub-Synge idioms that could creditably pass for parody. For the audiences in London or New York who made successes of these plays, the west of Ireland shack settings and their logorrhaic muck-savage inhabitants appear impossibly exotic and elemental. When the works eventually return to Ireland, they are protected from any kind of vigorous criticism by a phalanx of awards and accolades. Overall, the dynamic is not unlike the one that has colonised downtown Dublin with fake Oirish pubs, whose emeraldy, signposty, plastic ambience proved such a huge hit in Helsinki and Manhattan that it was then re-imported back into Ireland, widely supplanting the authentic item that inspired them. Irish culture has been transformed into little more than a brand name, specifically and somewhat cynically engineered to appeal to foreign or expatriate perceptions, and then mistaken for the real thing when it arrives home. Product that doesn't match the ingredients listed on the label, such as Marina Carr's play, On Raftery's Hill, which brilliantly captured the spirit of a xenophobic, inward-looking nation, is simply discarded, playing to half-full houses at home and receiving cool reviews abroad. Ireland cannot really be like this. One big theme Pub, the Pogue Mahone, Where the rackrent landlords are all home grown, There's a new pornography: property prices, And the sexiest words are 'housing crisis.' It's our own asylum, and so it will be, In Eire 2016AD Despite the economic and material advances made over the past decade, and the revolution in employment opportunities, Ireland is failing to live up to the expectations generated by its own propaganda and its new status as one of Europe's more affluent nations. If the new wealth is viewed as a test of national character, it is one that we have failed quite abjectly, in our treatment of refugees and other races, in our ability to build and maintain adequate public and social services, in our ability to share the dividends with the poorer sectors of society. This adoptive self-image of a brash modern nation also fails to take account of the deeply conflicted nature of Irish society and alienates the majority who appear to be reaping meagre benefits. Truth for truth, and folly for folly, the idea of a technologically advanced, highly affluent Tiger nation striding boldly into the 21st century seems to be no more nor less accurate than any of the previous fictions that exerted such a grip on Irish identity, from the misty Celtic Twilight of Yeats to Dev's rosy rustic picture, each of which eventually led into a cultural and spiritual dead end. Ireland is given to illusory, indulgent images of itself. With the latest Celtic Tiger variant, all it has managed to do is modernise its self-delusion. What Eire really looks like in 2016AD depends on decisions taken right now. With extra cash surging through the system, there is for the first time a chance to cut through these prevailing fictions and build a society on well-funded social principles. However, we seem more intent on using further tax cuts to prolong the party, letting us bask a little longer in the glow of the superheated economy. All the indications suggest that we will be gazing back from MC Dev's watershed centennial year, fondly recalling the frenzy of the Celtic Tiger boom years and perhaps lamenting the missed opportunity to transform Ireland into a modern, egalitarian, inclusive as well as affluent country.  Verses by Arthur Riordan

fields.headline: The questionnaire
fields.standfirst: Chris Addison
fields.trailText: Chris Addison
fields.body:
Chris Addison, 28, grew up in Manchester. An arts graduate of Birmingham University, he began doing stand-up comedy at 23. He made his solo debut at Edinburgh Festival in 1998 and was nominated for the Perrier Best Newcomer Award. He co-hosts Channel 4's dotcomedy with Gail Porter. His new stand-up show, Cakes And Ale, is at Edinburgh Festival until August 28.

What is your idea of perfect happiness?
Tailback on the motorway with Stephen Fry's unabridged reading of a Harry Potter book on the car stereo.

What is your greatest fear?
The return of Voldemort.

What is the trait you most deplore in yourself?
Idleness.

What is the trait you most deplore in others?
Most bad traits come down to selfishness, in the end.

What has been your most embarrassing moment?
The ages of about 4 to 23.

What do you most dislike about your appearance?
Let's not open that can of worms.

What is your most unappealing habit?
Sucking my teeth.

What makes you depressed?
Pressure; house-buying; not knowing.

What is your favourite book?
Asterix And The Chieftain's Shield, by Goscinny and Uderzo.

What is your favourite fantasy?
Being a father - and being as good at it as my own father.

For what cause would you die?
I would defend to the death this country against further invasion by the Vikings.

Do you believe in monogamy?
I think it's pretty essential.

Have you ever said 'I love you' and not meant it?
No. Or at least I always thought that I meant it at the time.

When and where were you happiest?
Tooting, April 1999-May 2000.

How do you relax?
Settee, girlfriend, cold beer and a big stack of Bond videos.

What single thing would improve the quality of your life?
Space to call my own (two disastrous, expensive attempts so far this year).

What would your motto be?
Duck, you fool!

What keeps you awake at night?
The Edinburgh Festival and the housing market.

How would you like to die?
At a great age, in rude health, peacefully and satisfied.

Do you believe in life after death?
Yes.

How would you like to be remembered?
Fondly and often. And some sort of statue might be nice.

fields.headline: How to do foreplay
fields.trailText: For men, foreplay is like a slice of honeydew melon - you know it's a starter, but there's nothing much to it and it wastes a lot of time before the main course.
fields.body:
For men, foreplay is like a slice of honeydew melon - you know it's a starter, but there's nothing much to it and it wastes a lot of time before the main course. Women, on the other hand, want the initial contact to be something akin to the landing of 1,000 butterflies all over their skin. What they get, however, is more like a heavy deck landing on an aircraft carrier.

This difference in expectations may stem from the fact that men and women differ in their notions of when sex actually starts. For men, if you're going to do a job, you get on with the job; you don't start by creosoting the shed. Women, meanwhile, can be going in the opposite direction to bed (for example, to a shoe shop) and this still counts as foreplay.

Even once you're in bed with your kit off, the last place you head for are accredited sexual areas. Heaven forbid! First, you must trek off to bits of the body that don't often see a flannel, let alone another person, so don't be surprised if foreplay starts with nibbling a toe, sucking an ear, wobbling a kneecap, or all three. Just view it as you would shopping with a woman: you have to go to a lot of different places before you actually get the cash register ringing.

A word of warning - foreplay varies depending on the woman involved. You may have been trained up to drag unhemmed sheets between the toes of one woman, but if you try it with another they're likely to sit bolt upright and say, 'What the bloody hell do you think you're doing?'

One of the secrets of foreplay is gentleness, which makes it very difficult for the clumsy. Half an hour of feather-light kisses all over the body can be wiped out by one elbow in the face. The verbal equivalent of an elbow in the face is any kind of joke. You can laugh a woman into bed, but then you should shut up, because you're going to find most requests for foreplay laughable.

Given the choice, most men would prefer to do foreplay after having sex, as they're much more relaxed then. On the other hand, that's also the time when most men are overcome with the need to go to sleep and the last thing they want to be doing is licking chocolate spread from shoulder blades, or whatever.

The key to foreplay is to think of yourself as a power-drill. Naturally, you want to get on with drilling at full power, because that's the fun part, but the woman will be more interested in the sanding, grouting and buffing attachments at slow speed.

fields.headline: Dulcie Domum: dire straits
fields.standfirst: 'Scrutinise silverfish closely and wonder what it is - name is a red herring'
fields.trailText: 'Scrutinise silverfish closely and wonder what it is - name is a red herring'
fields.body:
"Where you goin' for your 'olidays, then?" asks Maureen next door as we watch the lightly-clad scaffolders dismantling their erection.

"Umbria."

"I love the Lake District." She has confused Umbria and Cumbria. I have the same problem with Grenada and Granada. Thank God for the uniqueness of Gatehouse-of-Fleet, where Ex-Spouse is taking Great-Aunt for a week beforehand, to pre-empt any sudden geriatric crises. She will be bonnie in Scotland, as long as she remembers her Devil's Claw. It seems to help her arthritis. But whether it's the Namibian herb or the enveloping hydroxyproplmethylcellulose, who knows?

Ex-Spouse will not accompany me to Umbria. We agree that it would be folly to leave the aunt home alone, especially now that she's internet-addicted. She surfs for hours without the least twinge of RSI, whereas my hitherto supple right hand has developed into a cramped, tingling knot of bones. A Devil's Claw. Harriet, however, will have to endure both near-water experiences: Gatehouse-of-Fleet followed by Castiglione del Lago. She is, of course, disgusted, although marginally more attracted to the idea of Umbria because of the possibility of Lago Louts.

"Think of all the lovely books you can read in Scotland!" I encourage her, offering a couple of Stephen Kings as thick as home-made lasagnes. But wait! Is the plural of lasagne lasagnes? Or is it already a plural? Must revise, urgently.

Aunt is taking her favourite whodunnit - Five Red Herrings, by Dorothy L Sayers - a work set in Gatehouse-of-Fleet. Ex-Spouse is not taking anything. He has booked them into a Guesthouse-of-Fleet that has digital TV, before which he intends to slump while aunt wallows in Wimsey and Harriet sulks in stereo. I have told aunt that Harriet was named after Harriet Vane, a Dorothy L Sayers character, in an effort to make Harriet appear less disagreeable.

They drive off, aunt waving rapturously and ex-Spouse and Harriet with faces like thunder. Since Henry is in Amsterdam, I now have the place to myself. Apart from the painters. They are painting Elspeth's room while she is away. I had suggested Whisper - a favourite shade of cream, now discontinued, along with other old favourites such as Body Shop Watermelon sun screen and Coconut Oil Shampoo - a kind of low-budget Caribbean holiday

After the painters leave, the house is suddenly silent. I walk in Cistercian solitude to the kitchen and embark on a low-fat meal. According to Woman's Hour criteria, I am overweight but not yet obese (32-inch waist, if you must know). Select low-fat silent glass dish from cupboard. Silverfish observed scampering within. Feel jolt of disgust, then wave of penitential affection. Scrutinise silverfish closely and wonder what it really is - "Silverfish" is a red herring. Try to encourage it to climb onto helpful piece of kitchen roll, to be transferred to the garden where, no doubt, it will be eaten by blackbird. Silverfish unco-operative. Decide to keep it as a pet.

I shall eat simple apple instead - no plate needed. Buddhist approach. Just fruit. Follow apple with several simple apricots and nectarines. Freedom! Solitude! Spontaneity becomes possible at last. Perhaps I shall go for a little drive tonight out into the country. Although can't bear killing all those innocent, wandering moths with my horrid hot radiator. Fall into light doze on futon, though slightly annoyed by its persistent slope - steep enough to roll a cheese down.

Awoken by intestinal cramps and doorbell. Waddle, doubled up, to door, aware that lavatorial experience is urgently required. Open door. Tom stands there: another old favourite who has been discontinued. "Just thought I'd call by on the off-chance," he says. "Elaine's taken Sandy off to Cornwall for a week."

"Come in!" I cry, trying for delight but only achieving loudness. "How lovely to see you! But I must just go off and have diarrhoea first." Uneasily aware that the seductive potential of my welcome is limited and that, in the absence of everybody else and their noises, the house has become a cathedral-like resonating studio for the slightest sound. Lock myself in the bathroom and pray for a sudden thunderstorm, street carnival or convoy of hurtling fire-engines.

webTitle: Room with a view to work

fields.headline: Room with a view to work
fields.standfirst: Be it a purpose-built study or makeshift corner, the perfect home working space should be an environment for optimum productivity, says Sophie Radice. And, of course, it must be inspiring
fields.trailText: Be it a purpose-built study or makeshift corner, the perfect home working space should be an environment for optimum productivity, says Sophie Radice. And, of course, it must be inspiring.
fields.body:
When people who work from home meet for the first time, they always seem unusually interested not only in the seemingly dull details of each other's work routine - "What time do you start? When do you have lunch? Do you listen to music/the radio or take any exercise?" - but also in exactly where they work in their house or flat. Those who have their own room or study tucked away from the other functions of living are regarded with envy, whereas those who fit their workspace into the kitchen or sitting-room are probed about their desk, computer, drawing board, closeness to windows and colour of the room. Working from home supposedly means being in control of your own environment - and, because of that, it always holds the promise of being the perfect place to inspire original thought in an atmosphere of lively contemplation.

I work in the messiest room in the house: the children's playroom. Toys are strewn on the floor - Lego models mix with unloved Pokémon figures, and Barbies lie in a horrible tangle of plastic flesh. Large, black hardware items such as TVs and long-obsolete games consoles nestle among the debris, so that getting to my desk can be something of an assault course. It could be used by a feng-shui expert as a perfect example of the worst kind of bad chi.

A new book, Calm Working Spaces, by Lorrie Mack, aims to "help create a haven of peace and productivity". It advises that a tidy and ordered atmosphere will create a sense of purposeful calm. But in my case that would be a waste of precious work time, and a bit pointless considering it will all be messed up as soon as the children get home from school. My desk, too, echoes the general chaos - a pile of interesting bits of paper - letters from people I want to reply to one day, and the first half of a novel I can't get round to finishing. A Russian doll is jammed behind the computer, and a fairy's wand, half eaten by the dog, sticks out of the file I have laughingly marked "Life". I sit wedged between two large windows, which allows me to spy on the goings-on of my unusually dramatic street - crack dealers getting arrested and the family who come outdoors to solve their domestic problems - without (I hope) being seen. I have to admit that my ex-husband had a curtain structure, like something you might find in a hospital ward, built around my desk, so that when his friends came to visit he could hide the horror of my workspace, but it works all right for me.

If I analyse my attitude towards my workspace, it is that I am unwilling to make a fuss. My work just fits in with the life around it. Not for me the self-important demands of other friends who use rooms in other people's homes, have attic extensions built or move, slightly desperately, around the tables and desks in their own house in an attempt to discover somewhere really conducive to work. My mother-in-law has written quite a few novels sitting on the top stair. Of course, if you are going to write a masterpiece, you could do it on the loo.

And yet... I do dream of somewhere that might exist, in a place I have not yet moved into, that would suit the person I have unfortunately not yet become. It is creamy and spacious, with drawers and neat storage for all my talismanic bits of paper. There is no clutter, no overlap from domestic life. Such a room demands concentration: it would hold you prisoner to its potential, so that it would feel quite wrong to attempt an escape and lunge at the digestives in the kitchen drawer for the fourth time that morning. But a workspace such as this would be unrealistic for me. I would soon spill coffee over the creamy wood. Perhaps it would be better to have somewhere just as light and breezy. Unfortunately, I have a flibbertigibbet side, which sends too many emails and chats on the phone, and a workspace with any sign of frivolity would probably make me want to go shopping rather then write for long hours in front of the computer. No, I think the ideal workspace for me would be somewhere with the "clubby" feel of a study, where a gentleman might go to ponder, smoke a pipe and look at the naughty daguerreotypes of an evening. Somewhere full of shiny, dark wood, comfortable old chairs and the slight smell of beeswax, which would give me the gravitas I often seem to lack.

Not that I want somewhere full of books. While I agree that working in the productive atmosphere of, say, a library can be a change from the sometimes claustrophobic feeling of working from home, when the books are your own they can add an unwelcome weightiness. I not only feel guilty about those I have not yet read, but also about those I did once read, when my mind was eagerly studious. Looking towards the bookshelves near my desk I see a Carlos Fuentes that I have never got around to, and dozens of literary criticism, as well as Hegel's The Philosophy Of History, which I know I will probably never pick up again.
