fields.bodyText: When people who work from home meet for the first time, they always seem unusually interested not only in the seemingly dull details of each other's work routine - "What time do you start? When do you have lunch? Do you listen to music/the radio or take any exercise?" - but also in exactly where they work in their house or flat. Those who have their own room or study tucked away from the other functions of living are regarded with envy, whereas those who fit their workspace into the kitchen or sitting-room are probed about their desk, computer, drawing board, closeness to windows and colour of the room. Working from home supposedly means being in control of your own environment - and, because of that, it always holds the promise of being the perfect place to inspire original thought in an atmosphere of lively contemplation. I work in the messiest room in the house: the children's playroom. Toys are strewn on the floor - Lego models mix with unloved Pokémon figures, and Barbies lie in a horrible tangle of plastic flesh. Large, black hardware items such as TVs and long-obsolete games consoles nestle among the debris, so that getting to my desk can be something of an assault course. It could be used by a feng-shui expert as a perfect example of the worst kind of bad chi. A new book, Calm Working Spaces, by Lorrie Mack, aims to "help create a haven of peace and productivity". It advises that a tidy and ordered atmosphere will create a sense of purposeful calm. But in my case that would be a waste of precious work time, and a bit pointless considering it will all be messed up as soon as the children get home from school. My desk, too, echoes the general chaos - a pile of interesting bits of paper - letters from people I want to reply to one day, and the first half of a novel I can't get round to finishing. A Russian doll is jammed behind the computer, and a fairy's wand, half eaten by the dog, sticks out of the file I have laughingly marked "Life". I sit wedged between two large windows, which allows me to spy on the goings-on of my unusually dramatic street - crack dealers getting arrested and the family who come outdoors to solve their domestic problems - without (I hope) being seen. I have to admit that my ex-husband had a curtain structure, like something you might find in a hospital ward, built around my desk, so that when his friends came to visit he could hide the horror of my workspace, but it works all right for me. fields.headline: Superplonk
fields.trailText: Malcolm Gluck contemplates an amusing merger.
fields.body:
I am pleased to announce the merger of Morrisons and Waitrose. Alas, this is only for the purposes of this column, and not a hair-raising commercial reality. It is, however, amusing to imagine the lone wine-buying hero at Morrisons, Mr Stuart Purdie, contemplating the £50-quid bottles at Waitrose Direct, just as it is entertaining to contemplate Mr Julian Brind and his platoon of fellow Masters Of Wine in the Waitrose wine-buying department marching down the Morrison aisles and noting the plenitude of cheapies. However, the gulf between Morrison and Waitrose is not as large as this fanciful scenario might suggest.

We shall begin with those Morrisons aisles and these resident cheapies. La Chasse du Pape Réserve Côtes du Rhône 1998 is a country bumpkin with a city slicker's polish, thus it delivers decisively dry, rip-roaring, herby fruit with a suggestion of urban chic. It rates 16 points (out of 20) and costs £4.99. The 1998 vintage of Dom Ferraz Dao is also £4.99, and worth every escudo. It, too, exhibits a rich herbiness and even more dramatic tannins. The wine lingers, it loves food, and is a treat for the tastebuds. And it also rates 16 points.

Of all the ranges of wine at supermarkets, none was launched with more overall consistency or remarkable value-for-money fruit than Morrison's Falcon Ridge collection, made for the store by the enterprising Australian Michael Goundrey near Narbonne. Falcon Ridge Cabernet Sauvignon Vin de Pays d'Oc 1999 (16 points, £3.49) has hugely arresting blackcurrant richness and sufficient character and bite to make it versatile with food. Falcon Ridge Syrah Vin de Pays d'Oc 1999 (15.5 points, £3.49) offers lovely, tangy richness and plump ripeness, and parades a joyousness finish. Falcon Ridge Merlot Vin de Pays d'Oc 1999 (15 points, £3.49) is ripe, rich, and a touch raucous, but with a price so mellow that it is no problem to swallow. One is compelled to wonder just what Aussie techniques Mr Goundrey is employing to get such fruit from his farmers (and what Mr Purdie does to achieve such prices).

And last at Morrison's, a bargain from Spain. Conforrales Tinto Cencibel 1998 is a pert little performer, with excellent acids, and fairly lush tannins that yield a dry, charcoal edge of some charm. A solid quaffing companion and food wine, it rates 15 points and costs £3.49.

At Waitrose, let me open with an interesting Italian organic red. Terra Viva Merlot del Veneto 1999 is very dry, 14-point fruity, and reasonably well compacted, and it has been reduced to a special-offer price of £3.99 until September 3. The modesty of its fruit, when sipping, belies its excellence with food.

Houghton HWB 1998 (16 points, on offer at £4.99 until September 3) used to label itself Houghton White Burgundy, until the French chased that pretension away. However, though the grapes in HWB are not burgundian (ie, chardonnay) the wine does have an eerie echo of a smoothly vegetal burgundy - except, of course, it is Australian and so more gripping than anything Burgundy can remotely do for the same money. Waitrose has also reduced the price of Penfolds Koonunga Hill Chardonnay 1999 to £4.99 until September 3. Rating 16 points, this vintage is crisp, clean, classy.

The Australian Tatachilla Sauvignon/Semillon 1999 (15 points, £4.49, also until September 3) is also in fine fettle, very cool and collected, and most untypically subtle. Lugana Villa Flora 1999 (16 points, £3.99 until September 3), from Italy, has utterly lovely compressed gooseberries, pears and melon (under-ripe) with a hints of spice and a wonderful clean, crisp finish. This is an astounding bargain at this price, and I ll be shelling out my own money for some.

As I have done in the past for Warwick Estate Chardonnay 1999, from the Cape. Is this the best-value chardonnay in the world? It has lovely creamy woodiness, alert acids underpinning good melon/vegetal fruit and it'll get more like Montrachet as it ages over the next five years. It rates 17.5 points and costs £6.99 in assorted London stores or nationally via mail order, 0800 188881.

fields.headline: The knowledge
fields.standfirst: Flights of fancy: grouse
fields.trailText: Flights of fancy: grouse
fields.body:
The subject
Lagopus lagopus , member of the pheasant family. Unique to these isles. A one-sided sport for the unspeakably rich. But, in this case, the unspeakable are not pursuing the uneatable. The season (theoretically ending December 10, but see The details) began a week ago. Sorry we're late (but see Where to buy - and anyway, just about every grouse shot on the Glorious 12th last weekend was destined for restaurant kitchens, not the likes of you and me).

The basics
Grouse live in the moors of Yorkshire, Scotland and other parts north. The ones you want to know are small and young. Ideal weight: 300-350g. If you don't shoot them yourself, the sure path to grouse-heaven ends at the door of a reputable game merchant.

The details
The Knowledge got a grouse lesson from someone who has supervised the cooking of around 40,000 of them: Michel Bourdin, chef de cuisine at the Connaught. He speaks of grouse in the masculine gender. Lecture notes: 'We don't sophisticate grouse in any manner. We just treat him well. When you cook him on the bone, he keeps his best.' Cooking is the key: your hottest oven, 220-250C. Wrap a piece of pork fat or bacon around the breast, then brown on the legs only for a minute or two in oil and butter. Put the frying pan in the oven and time it for eight minutes (rare) or 10-12 minutes ( à point ). NB: timing starts from the beginning of browning, not of roasting. NB: turn once, and never let the breast touch the pan. Rest for two minutes, carve, serve. Garnish: 'In England, we have the right garniture.' Namely, game chips, bread sauce flavoured with brown butter and grouse jus, extra jus, tender Brussels sprouts. Plus celeriac purée, if you can manage it. Seasonal notes: Chris Gladman, of R Allen, which supplies M. Bourdin with grouse, says they start getting too old three to four weeks before the end of the season. Hanging notes: two to three days is ideal, one week the max.

Where to buy
Something to grouse about: the price, especially in the first week of the season. From here on in, the price will drop, but expect a £8-12 hit. Your best bet: a game-licensed butcher or fishmonger. R Allen is at 020-7499 5831.

The easy way out
Rob a bank and dine at the Connaught, 020-7499-7070.

fields.headline: A swift pint
fields.standfirst: Jenlain Blonde
fields.trailText: Jenlain Blonde
fields.body:
The Duyck brewery in Jenlain, French Flanders, is the best-known producer of the rustic bière de garde style (literally, 'keeping beer'), developed by French farmers to refresh labourers, not to mention themselves. Duyck is now a fully-fledged commercial company, best known for its russet-coloured Jenlain.

The 6% Jenlain Blonde represents something of a departure, being an exceptionally pale beer in a skittle-shaped green bottle. The UK distributors describe it as 'lager style', but bières de garde are traditionally warm-fermented ales. I suspect that, for the new beer, Duyck is using a lager yeast, which gives greater stability in bottle, but fermenting it at an ale temperature (its richness and roundness certainly indicates warm fermentation).

Jenlain Blonde has a spicy aroma with delightful pear-like fruit, is tart and quenching in the mouth, with juicy malt and peppery hops, while the long finish bursts with tart fruit and bitter hops. It costs £1.99 for 65cl, and is on sale at Safeway and Sainsbury's (further details from Erhmanns, 020-7418 1824).

fields.headline: The net addict
fields.trailText: Tanya has a bipolar bugbear
fields.body:
Hard as I tried, after two weeks I gave up and checked out www.bipolar.com, the site on Bipolar Disorder - which turned out to be just another name for manic depression. I was intrigued. The symptoms of mania are: euphoria, decreased sleep requirement, uncharacteristically poor judgment, increased sexual drive, denial that anything is wrong, over-spending and risk behaviour, all of which sounds like a perfect description of myself (and most people I know) on Friday and Saturday nights. On the other hand, symptoms of depression are: sad, anxious or empty mood, feelings of hopelesness, pessimism, and guilt, loss of interest in ordinary activities and sex, decreased energy and feelings of fatigue, and thoughts of suicide, all of which apply to most people I know every time their shares go down or they put on weight.

Could it be that we are all bipolars? A good site to cater for the maniac mood is www.clubnet-uk.com, which has the clubs' disc charts, and loads of information on clubs, DJs and sites useful for the club scene. Two of mum's really close girlfriends live in Glasgow, so she prefers www.webflyers.co.uk, which covers Glasgow and Edinburgh in detail.

Sadly, I haven't got an obvious suggestion for victims of the darker moods. When Migraine Alan used to fall into troughs of despair because of his yearning for Ann Widdecombe, his doctor put him on Lithium, but the dosage had to be carefully controlled and fine-tuned, which was difficult in his case. I always thought it was because Lithium is used for those sleek batteries we put in hand-held gadgets, but there was a brief period when poor Alan sounded like Terminator II. Fortunately, the medication and psychotherapy worked wonders in the end.

I wonder what he's doing now...

webTitle: They came, they saw, they drank

fields.headline: They came, they saw, they drank
fields.standfirst: Roger Protz looks back on the great British Beer Festival
fields.trailText: Roger Protz looks back on the great British Beer Festival
fields.body:
The Guardian-sponsored Camra Champion Bottled Beer of Britain competition broke new ground this year at the Great British Beer festival at London Olympia - the judges chose a beer from a brewery that had just closed down. Thankfully, the beer will live on: it is moving to a new brewery, ready for a relaunch this autumn.

The beer in question is that classic India pale ale, Worthington White Shield, one of the great 19th-century Burton-brewed beers that carved out a new market for British brewers in the colonies. First brewed by William Worthington, it became a Bass beer in the 20s when the two Burton companies merged. For years it was a small but much-loved brand in the Bass portfolio, but when Bass became a mass-market leisure group in the 80s and 90s, White Shield, which was painstakingly made with live yeast in the bottle and best drunk after a month or two of conditioning, became a nuisance. So it was kicked out of Burton, sent to subsidiaries in Sheffield and then Birmingham, before, in 1998, being handed over to independent brewer, King & Barnes.

Earlier this year, King & Barnes, a victim of the war of attrition in the brewing industry, was taken over by Hall & Woodhouse of Blandford, Dorset, which was keen to get its hands on the Horsham company's 57 pubs but had no interest in the brewery. So it was earmarked for closure, and Worthington White Shield was once again looking for a home. It found it, back in its hometown, Burton-on-Trent: Bass, which is now part of Belgian giant Interbrew, allows brewer Steve Wellington to make it in the small pilot brewery that is part of the Bass Museum. Wellington, using plant that can produce just 60 barrels a week, has already lovingly recreated such lost Bass beers as No 1 Barley Wine, and is now rubbing his yeasty hands at the thought of turning White Shield into a proper Burton pale ale once more.

So, the Guardian readers who volunteered to judge the championship have given a vital boost to a beer that has suffered more than its fair share of misfortune - and before you cry "fix", it must be stressed that they had no idea what they were drinking. White Shield was picked after a blind tasting of eight bottle-fermented beers, decanted into anonymous jugs and poured into half-pint glasses enigmatically labelled from K to R. The panel was made up of readers Wendy Conian, David Elworthy, Carl Flint, Simon Freytag, Rosanna Santagata and Alan Southgate, along with Guardian food and drink editor, Matthew Fort, Jeff Evans, the author of the Good Bottled Beer Guide, Kathy Hadfield from Camra's national executive, and myself.

Beer K had a luscious copper-red hue, and conjured up such conflicting descriptions as "wet hop sacks" (Kathy), "harsh finish" (Alan and Jeff), "cat-litter aroma" (Matthew), "subtle" (Rosanna), and "a good finish, yeasty and bitter" (Wendy). L was an attractive copper colour that delivered fruity aromas and flavours to several of the judges. Rosanna found lime, Kathy and Simon pears or pear drops, and David apples. Wendy found it too fruity: "It leaves the insides of my cheeks furry." All agreed it had a disappointing finish and was too sweet.

The straw-coloured M brought forth the most memorable comment of the championship from Wendy - she said that it smelled like "folk-festival farts", and we all bowed to her expertise in this area, seeing as she had spent the previous weekend at the Cambridge Folk Festival. Warming to the theme, Kathy found the aroma reminiscent of wet tents. Jeff found it to be chewy and wheaty, while several judges pondered whether it might be a wheat beer. David said it reminded him of "lime cordial with too much water".

Beer N was even paler than M. Kathy sniffed and said "Wow - peaches and pineapple!" After much deliberation, we agreed that, while it had a fine aroma, there was little finish. O was red-brown in colour and was praised by Wendy for its "mellow fruitfulness" - clearly an autumnal ale. Jeff detected Marmite on the nose, Kathy found digestive biscuits, Rosanna thought it salty, Matthew praised its "crisp and delicious drinkability", David said it reminded him of barley fields, Alan thought it rounded, and Carl brought us down to earth with the blunt, almost Orwellian comment that it was "like a Sunday afternoon when the smell of beer comes out of a pub and that's what you want".

We were bowled over by the delightful copper colour of beer P. Rosanna and I both cried "pear drops" as we sniffed, while Wendy found it "wonderfully bitter" and Jeff "very moreish". Kathy criticised it for being too strong, with too much alcohol, while Matthew thought it too well-behaved. Q was a more burnished copper colour and brought forth such superlatives as "fresh strawberries" (Kathy), "old smokestacks" (Simon) and "dark bitter chocolate" (Wendy). Matthew thought it so fruity that it needed to be drunk with food, which launched a short debate on just what dish it should accompany. Sea bass, said some , while I suggested the Czech tradition of drinking a darkish beer with carp. Then we were into the home straight with beer R, a pale, golden amber in colour. Rosanna and David were not impressed, saying it smelled like Domestos, but others were wild about the aroma that reminded them of grapefruit, passion fruit, mangoes, and lychees.

We marked each beer out of 10 for appearance, aroma, taste and finish. When the marks were totted up and the names of the beers revealed, the winner was P, the aforementioned Worthington White Shield, with Hampshire Brewery's Pride of Romsey IPA (R) second and another King & Barnes brew, Festive (O), in third place. fields.bodyText: The Guardian-sponsored Camra Champion Bottled Beer of Britain competition broke new ground this year at the Great British Beer festival at London Olympia - the judges chose a beer from a brewery that had just closed down. Thankfully, the beer will live on: it is moving to a new brewery, ready for a relaunch this autumn. The beer in question is that classic India pale ale, Worthington White Shield, one of the great 19th-century Burton-brewed beers that carved out a new market for British brewers in the colonies. First brewed by William Worthington, it became a Bass beer in the 20s when the two Burton companies merged. For years it was a small but much-loved brand in the Bass portfolio, but when Bass became a mass-market leisure group in the 80s and 90s, White Shield, which was painstakingly made with live yeast in the bottle and best drunk after a month or two of conditioning, became a nuisance. So it was kicked out of Burton, sent to subsidiaries in Sheffield and then Birmingham, before, in 1998, being handed over to independent brewer, King & Barnes. Earlier this year, King & Barnes, a victim of the war of attrition in the brewing industry, was taken over by Hall & Woodhouse of Blandford, Dorset, which was keen to get its hands on the Horsham company's 57 pubs but had no interest in the brewery. So it was earmarked for closure, and Worthington White Shield was once again looking for a home. It found it, back in its hometown, Burton-on-Trent: Bass, which is now part of Belgian giant Interbrew, allows brewer Steve Wellington to make it in the small pilot brewery that is part of the Bass Museum. Wellington, using plant that can produce just 60 barrels a week, has already lovingly recreated such lost Bass beers as No 1 Barley Wine, and is now rubbing his yeasty hands at the thought of turning White Shield into a proper Burton pale ale once more. So, the Guardian readers who volunteered to judge the championship have given a vital boost to a beer that has suffered more than its fair share of misfortune - and before you cry "fix", it must be stressed that they had no idea what they were drinking. White Shield was picked after a blind tasting of eight bottle-fermented beers, decanted into anonymous jugs and poured into half-pint glasses enigmatically labelled from K to R. The panel was made up of readers Wendy Conian, David Elworthy, Carl Flint, Simon Freytag, Rosanna Santagata and Alan Southgate, along with Guardian food and drink editor, Matthew Fort, Jeff Evans, the author of the Good Bottled Beer Guide, Kathy Hadfield from Camra's national executive, and myself. Beer K had a luscious copper-red hue, and conjured up such conflicting descriptions as "wet hop sacks" (Kathy), "harsh finish" (Alan and Jeff), "cat-litter aroma" (Matthew), "subtle" (Rosanna), and "a good finish, yeasty and bitter" (Wendy). L was an attractive copper colour that delivered fruity aromas and flavours to several of the judges. Rosanna found lime, Kathy and Simon pears or pear drops, and David apples. Wendy found it too fruity: "It leaves the insides of my cheeks furry." All agreed it had a disappointing finish and was too sweet. The straw-coloured M brought forth the most memorable comment of the championship from Wendy - she said that it smelled like "folk-festival farts", and we all bowed to her expertise in this area, seeing as she had spent the previous weekend at the Cambridge Folk Festival. Warming to the theme, Kathy found the aroma reminiscent of wet tents. Jeff found it to be chewy and wheaty, while several judges pondered whether it might be a wheat beer. David said it reminded him of "lime cordial with too much water". Beer N was even paler than M. Kathy sniffed and said "Wow - peaches and pineapple!" After much deliberation, we agreed that, while it had a fine aroma, there was little finish. O was red-brown in colour and was praised by Wendy for its "mellow fruitfulness" - clearly an autumnal ale. Jeff detected Marmite on the nose, Kathy found digestive biscuits, Rosanna thought it salty, Matthew praised its "crisp and delicious drinkability", David said it reminded him of barley fields, Alan thought it rounded, and Carl brought us down to earth with the blunt, almost Orwellian comment that it was "like a Sunday afternoon when the smell of beer comes out of a pub and that's what you want". We were bowled over by the delightful copper colour of beer P. Rosanna and I both cried "pear drops" as we sniffed, while Wendy found it "wonderfully bitter" and Jeff "very moreish". Kathy criticised it for being too strong, with too much alcohol, while Matthew thought it too well-behaved. Q was a more burnished copper colour and brought forth such superlatives as "fresh strawberries" (Kathy), "old smokestacks" (Simon) and "dark bitter chocolate" (Wendy). Matthew thought it so fruity that it needed to be drunk with food, which launched a short debate on just what dish it should accompany. Sea bass, said some , while I suggested the Czech tradition of drinking a darkish beer with carp. Then we were into the home straight with beer R, a pale, golden amber in colour. Rosanna and David were not impressed, saying it smelled like Domestos, but others were wild about the aroma that reminded them of grapefruit, passion fruit, mangoes, and lychees. We marked each beer out of 10 for appearance, aroma, taste and finish. fields.headline: The oracle of the ovary
fields.standfirst: After all the years of championing IVF, has Robert Winston, the country's most eminent baby-maker, gone cold on the practice? Dea Birkett, herself currently having fertility treatment, meets the proud peer behind a million embryos
fields.trailText: After all the years of championing IVF, has Robert Winston, the country's most eminent baby-maker, gone cold on the practice? Dea Birkett, herself currently having fertility treatment, meets the proud peer behind a million embryos.
fields.body:
Lord Winston is ebullient. His arms are waving around. His body leans over the table for emphasis, throws itself back in a moment of assumed thoughtfulness, then bends forward again. A wilted yellow rose bobs up and down in his lapel, as if even it agrees with him. Of course it would. He is talking about the one thing for which he is so very well known and in which he is so very well versed - IVF treatment.

But this afternoon's conversation has taken an unexpected turn. The professor of fertility studies is questioning his own creed: "We are obsessed with IVF," he says. "People are going through IVF who certainly don't need it." It's as if the Pope had declared that there was too much Catholicism about. Or, as Lord Winston is an orthodox Jew, the chief Rabbi had decided that an excess of young people were being barmitzvahed.

But the undermining of his own beliefs doesn't stop there. I had told this eminent babymaker that, just an hour before meeting him, I had an embryo transfer - two eight-cell embryos replaced in my womb. I was halfway through an IVF cycle myself.

"You don't need IVF," he states, and I note that even the wilted rose nods in agreement. "I don't want to personalise this, but I could argue that you're undergoing an experiment which is totally useless. We've become increasingly focused on this form of conception, so everyone thinks they really need IVF when the evidence for that need is not that good."

Well. Where can I start? Let me at first explain my predicament. I did not particularly intend to meet Lord Winston of Hammersmith, professor of fertility studies at Imperial College School of Medicine, consultant obstetrician and gynaecologist, and director of Europe's largest reproductive medicine department, on such an auspicious day. His schedule is so busy that he arranges meetings between meetings, presumably in the hope that one will finish early and another a little late. He obviously enjoys being courted, and finds it difficult to refuse an invitation. "I don't do anything very well these days," he says. "You laugh, but it's true. [I hadn't laughed.] I do too many things, all superficial. It's a big problem."

We met at the House of Lords, where he has been a Labour Life Peer since 1995, and where he chairs the Science and Technology Committee and gladly and charmingly hobnobs. As we walk to the bar, his arm appeared to be permanently half-extended, his hand open and ready to be shaken. He strolls easily past the great, good and ever-so conversationally interesting - Ruth Rendell, John Birt, Waheed Alli, David Puttnam. He clearly thinks he belongs here.

It just so happened that this sought-after man's only free moment all but clashed with my embryo transfer. So, instead of the recommended day of bed-rest, I disentangled myself from the stirrups, rose from my hospital bed and walked to my meeting with the Lord of Fertility. I must confess, I wasn't entirely reluctant to do so. It seemed a good omen. Childless couples turn to him as if to a saviour. Lord Winston won't only cure their condition, he will make their lives whole. He's believed to carry countless future families in his little Petri dishes. Just an appointment with him is seen as getting halfway to conception. "I'm nervous of him and I don't know why," said one woman as she entered his clinic in the 1996 documentary series, Making Babies. "It's because you think he's God," said her husband. "He is to me," she replied. If there were a Prayer for the Infertile, it would be, "Oh Lord Winston, please grant us a child". Just to be in his presence on the day of my transfer must surely be a blessing.

Although I had promised myself otherwise, within moments I'd told him where I'd just come from. He insisted I had a tumbler of red wine. "Not white," he said with authority. "But red. It will be good for your intrauterine conditions." In my bag, alongside the folic acid, I had leaflets warning of the dangers of alcohol and how it threatened fertility. And here, sitting opposite me, was the man with a reputation for conjuring up babies like a magician does rabbits. It was clear whom I should believe in. I began to sip my red wine.

The Lord had his usual, a malt whisky. I wondered what bit of the body that was good for. The brain, perhaps, judging by 60-year-old Robert Maurice Lipson Winston's impressive CV. There is hardly a country that has not honoured him - from visiting professor at the Catholic University of Leuven in Belgium to honorary member of a fertility society in Chile. Twenty years ago, he founded the first NHS IVF programme. Since then, he has used every means possible to promulgate support for the infertile, exploiting every media. His groundbreaking Making Babies documentary introduced us to the promise of IVF; before that, infertility was only some other poor and pitiable person's problem. It is his clinic at Hammersmith that has taken on women who have failed or been refused IVF everywhere else. Last summer, he was still calling it the "last port of call" for such desperate patients. He is the oracle on half a million women's ovaries.

So his unexpected words to me that afternoon in the House of Lords bar carried particular weight. "The trouble with in vitro fertilisation is that it's a wonderful money-spinner. It's a brilliant diversion from what's really the matter. It's jolly easy to do, because you can mechanise it. You can just thread people through a programme and you don't need to think. Most women going through IVF are actually effectively going through a mill." To bolster myself while listening to this tirade, I take another sip of red wine. It seems the Lord is losing his faith. "IVF isn't a treatment for infertility. It's a way of getting pregnant on a one-shot basis. It's quite different. It's what you're going through."

Oh no, I was waiting for that. I should have left myself out of it. My chromosomes, rather than my character, are of more than a little interest to most fertility experts. I have a chromosomal disorder called a translocation, and was having not your common-or-garden IVF but pre-implantation genetic diagnosis (PGD), to sort my good embryos from bad.

Winston pioneered PGD. But he uncharacteristically says he doesn't want to talk about that. "I can't talk to you honestly at this time, because you're vulnerable," he says. I insist I am not. The medicine man knows better. "I'm a doctor, I see people like you, I see a lot." Realising that this line of conversation may be good for the bedside but not the barside, he quickly retreats to the non-specific. "There is a need for a much more holistic approach. We're not treating infertile people any more. We're not actually treating the causes of their infertility. For example . . ." He's in full animated flow now, bending backwards and forwards. "We could do far more research into looking into why embryos don't implant. There's very, very little research going on. Chances are that doesn't need IVF at all. What that probably needs is better understanding of the genetic messages in the uterus and correcting those genetic messages by tailor-made drugs . . .

"I've not changed my views," he insists. "My research has changed."

Well. Shall I start again, at the beginning? A young Robert Winston, a graduate of London University, established his reputation as a fine and dextrous surgeon in the 70s. His breakthrough was in the field of tubal microsurgery. By improving techniques, he was able to unblock fallopian tubes and dramatically increase a woman's chance of getting pregnant. Half of his patients conceived within five months. In 1984, he delivered test-tube quads. His team developed tests to screen embryos for sex-linked diseases such as muscular dystrophy, gene defects such as cystic fibrosis and chromosome disorders. In 1995, they achieved the first ever pregnancy after testing embryos for a chromosome translocation like mine. Yet already he has changed his mind about that, too. He feels my hopes have been falsely raised. Now his clinic, once the only place you could go, rarely offers such screening.

It isn't the first time that Lord Winston has made an about turn. In 1993, he attacked the treatment of women aged over 50 as "misplaced use of technology", declaring 39 his upper age limit. A year later, that had shifted to 60. When Dolly the sheep was cloned, he wrote vociferously that the cloning of human tissue was never going to happen. Now it is the focus of his research. In a New Statesman interview this January, where he famously said that Britain's funding of its health service was "not as good as Poland's", he clearly attacked the Government's health record. "There is a lot wrong with the health service and no one is prepared to say so . . . we've been quite deceitful about it. We haven't told the truth and I'm afraid there will come a time when it will be impossible to disguise the inequality of the health service from the general population." Yet even before the interview was published, he was backtracking. "I believe that the basic direction of NHS policy is right under this Government . . . I did not mean, and I wish to stress this, that the Government are deceiving people over the NHS."

There is at least one thing he hasn't changed his mind on. He is a passionate believer in a national health service, if not ours. At present, around 10% of IVF is NHS-funded, "the worst in Europe", says Winston. "There's not nearly enough IVF on the NHS. It's grossly under-funded." This excludes patients who can't afford the treatment cost of around £2,000, and encourages sloppiness and bad practice. "The NHS is a way of ensuring decent, proper values. At the 80 or 90 private IVF clinics around the country, you'll have no idea what happens to your embryos after they weren't transferred. You'll have no access to detailed hormonal investigation when the thing goes wrong."

He believes that the government body responsible for regulating and licensing IVF and PGD, the Human Fertilisation and Embryology Authority (HFEA), is powerless to improve private practice. "The HFEA can't go to a private clinic and say you will have this kind of audit. All it can do is ensure that people have the absolute modicum of basic treatment, in clean laboratories, which are not contaminated, where there's reasonable record-keeping and so on. Basic things."

He is not a fan of the HFEA, with its strict licensing procedures for PGD and embryo research. He calls it "an irritation". "I'm not convinced that this is an area of medicine which should be regulated much more strictly than other areas, more than tubal or heart surgery. You inhibit research that needs to be done." Unsurprisingly, the HFEA has shunned him. "I wouldn't join them if I was asked," he responds petulantly, before adding, "but I don't want to talk about that. I don't want to talk about that," waving his hands about.

Winston has been caught out blabbering before. He indiscreetly gave away that Cherie Blair was apparently going for a Caesarean birth. Predictably, he denied ever having said it, leading to the playing of his fuzzy, taped confession on Radio 4's The World At One. He is well in with New Labour; Blair was a guest on his This Is Your Life. After the New Statesman attack on the NHS, he confidently announced that he expected to be "able to talk to people in Downing Street in the next week or two". He clearly believes that the recent £19 billion injection of cash is a good deal due to him. "The fact that I said the health service needed more money, I'd have to be pretty bloody stupid to believe that it was my doing that we got big money. But _ perhaps what that particular event did was to just highlight the problem."

He doesn't underestimate his influence. "Your Life In Their Hands was immensely successful. It was the second-most watched programme ever on BBC2," he reminds me about the 80s series he presented. "It may turn out that the Human Body is the most important thing I've ever done, more important than the 300 publications I've got in various journals, including the one in Nature. It may be more important than the invention of PGD."

And with such dexterity - the same dexterity for which he was once famed in the operating theatre - he has reminded me that, without Winston, I wouldn't even be there with my hour-old embryo transfer. I have him to thank. He would also like to remind me that last year the Royal Society awarded him the Faraday prize for "the furtherance of the public understanding of science". Any modesty is certainly mock. But there is a crack in his super confidence. He describes his forthcoming six-part BBC series, Superhuman, which predictably examines genetics, as "a disaster. I'd rather not talk about it."

His latest mission is transgenic, looking at how to transfer human genes to an animal that could be used as a source of organs. "Do you know what I do each month? You may not believe this. Do you know what I do? I fly 13,000 miles each month to do my research in California. It's easier to work on the mice in Caltech than it is in London."

It is the irritating HFEA that forces him to do this. "The government and the HFEA are both terrified of the Right To Life people, tales of all these little humans that are being frozen and destroyed." Red tape has killed good research. "The truth is that I have people in my unit who say, 'Let's stop working on these embryos, it's just not worth it'. I can't keep the records to the standards required of the HFEA. It's easier just to discard the embryos. That's a common view right across the country. There's no incentive to apply to do good research. There's so many loops to jump through, why do it? At Hammersmith, there's a feeling of great despondency."

I was feeling pretty despondent myself. I'd just shelled out £2,500 and subjected myself to a powerful drug regime for a treatment the most prominent fertility expert in Britain thought was futile. But then, there was always the chance he might change his mind. He has already done a flip-flop in his assessment of me. Apparently, an hour into our conversation, I am no longer vulnerable but "a particularly strong character. Otherwise, you wouldn't be sitting here right now, doing this interview on a day when a lot of people would find it really very stressful. It means that you'll go through the treatment again." Again? And I realise that, in his new-found lack of faith in IVF, he has already presumed that my treatment cycle has failed.

So what should replace IVF? If a woman came to him having failed to get pregnant, what would he do? "The first thing I would want to do would be to investigate them really thoroughly. Nearly every woman who comes to us who has failed IVF has not been properly investigated. And when you investigate, about half of them you find things that were missing. What we should do is focus much more on what's going wrong. Six-sevenths of those undergoing IVF won't get pregnant - of course they won't - but they'll have no idea why. And there'll be no real attempt to find out why. That's a shocking indictment."

And, of course, my follow-up question is what would he do with me? For the first time, he falters. "I don't know."

Well. Where shall I end? At the close of our interview, I asked Lord Winston if there was anything in particular on which he would like to put the record straight. I was thinking he might point to public misconceptions about GM foods, BSE, or possibly our fear of genetic engineering. But no. His concerns lie elsewhere. "What did I read in the Guardian this morning? I was really cross. There was Clare Brown [president of the National Infertility Awareness Campaign] being quoted, and the last column said it was in the 80s when we set up patients' support groups. Well - who was the person who first set them up? I bloody set them up! I was the first one, actually, with private income. My income. Clare Brown knows that, actually. She could have actually said so."

So now the Guardian has put that important record straight. All honour to the King.

He goes on to the full tale of setting up the first support group, presumably hoping that I will also include it in my piece. It's a story he tells with feeling. It was, he says, in response to one patient of tubal surgery. "She said she'd wished she'd never had the operation, because it changed her life: 'Before you operated on me, I knew my tubes were blocked and I knew I couldn't get pregnant. Now I've got open tubes, I live in constant doubt.' I thought, 'Bloody hell!' It had never struck me before. She was the stimulus. Interestingly, she never got pregnant. Never got pregnant. She ended up having IVF years later, and that didn't work either."

Lord Winston's promotion of the needs of the infertile, the funding of the NHS, better embryo research and himself continues unabated. In the few weeks between our interview and writing it, the indefatigable Lord had been in the papers at least half-a-dozen times, on issues ranging from Prime Minister's Question Time to the use of animal organs in human patients.

As for me, I had a positive pregnancy test. It must have been the red wine.

 Superhuman will be broadcast on the BBC in October. The book to the series will be published on October 5 by BBC Worldwide.

It's grossly under-funded." This excludes patients who can't afford the treatment cost of around £2,000, and encourages sloppiness and bad practice. "The NHS is a way of ensuring decent, proper values. At the 80 or 90 private IVF clinics around the country, you'll have no idea what happens to your embryos after they weren't transferred. You'll have no access to detailed hormonal investigation when the thing goes wrong." He believes that the government body responsible for regulating and licensing IVF and PGD, the Human Fertilisation and Embryology Authority (HFEA), is powerless to improve private practice. "The HFEA can't go to a private clinic and say you will have this kind of audit. All it can do is ensure that people have the absolute modicum of basic treatment, in clean laboratories, which are not contaminated, where there's reasonable record-keeping and so on. Basic things." He is not a fan of the HFEA, with its strict licensing procedures for PGD and embryo research. He calls it "an irritation". "I'm not convinced that this is an area of medicine which should be regulated much more strictly than other areas, more than tubal or heart surgery. You inhibit research that needs to be done." Unsurprisingly, the HFEA has shunned him. "I wouldn't join them if I was asked," he responds petulantly, before adding, "but I don't want to talk about that. I don't want to talk about that," waving his hands about. Winston has been caught out blabbering before. He indiscreetly gave away that Cherie Blair was apparently going for a Caesarean birth. Predictably, he denied ever having said it, leading to the playing of his fuzzy, taped confession on Radio 4's The World At One. He is well in with New Labour; Blair was a guest on his This Is Your Life. After the New Statesman attack on the NHS, he confidently announced that he expected to be "able to talk to people in Downing Street in the next week or two". He clearly believes that the recent £19 billion injection of cash is a good deal due to him. "The fact that I said the health service needed more money, I'd have to be pretty bloody stupid to believe that it was my doing that we got big money. But _ perhaps what that particular event did was to just highlight the problem." He doesn't underestimate his influence. "Your Life In Their Hands was immensely successful. It was the second-most watched programme ever on BBC2," he reminds me about the 80s series he presented. "It may turn out that the Human Body is the most important thing I've ever done, more important than the 300 publications I've got in various journals, including the one in Nature. It may be more important than the invention of PGD." And with such dexterity - the same dexterity for which he was once famed in the operating theatre - he has reminded me that, without Winston, I wouldn't even be there with my hour-old embryo transfer. I have him to thank. He would also like to remind me that last year the Royal Society awarded him the Faraday prize for "the furtherance of the public understanding of science". Any modesty is certainly mock. But there is a crack in his super confidence. He describes his forthcoming six-part BBC series, Superhuman, which predictably examines genetics, as "a disaster. I'd rather not talk about it." His latest mission is transgenic, looking at how to transfer human genes to an animal that could be used as a source of organs. "Do you know what I do each month? You may not believe this. Do you know what I do? I fly 13,000 miles each month to do my research in California. It's easier to work on the mice in Caltech than it is in London." It is the irritating HFEA that forces him to do this. "The government and the HFEA are both terrified of the Right To Life people, tales of all these little humans that are being frozen and destroyed." Red tape has killed good research. "The truth is that I have people in my unit who say, 'Let's stop working on these embryos, it's just not worth it'. I can't keep the records to the standards required of the HFEA. It's easier just to discard the embryos. That's a common view right across the country. There's no incentive to apply to do good research. There's so many loops to jump through, why do it? At Hammersmith, there's a feeling of great despondency." I was feeling pretty despondent myself. I'd just shelled out £2,500 and subjected myself to a powerful drug regime for a treatment the most prominent fertility expert in Britain thought was futile. But then, there was always the chance he might change his mind. He has already done a flip-flop in his assessment of me. Apparently, an hour into our conversation, I am no longer vulnerable but "a particularly strong character. Otherwise, you wouldn't be sitting here right now, doing this interview on a day when a lot of people would find it really very stressful. It means that you'll go through the treatment again." Again? And I realise that, in his new-found lack of faith in IVF, he has already presumed that my treatment cycle has failed. So what should replace IVF? If a woman came to him having failed to get pregnant, what would he do? "The first thing I would want to do would be to investigate them really thoroughly. Nearly every woman who comes to us who has failed IVF has not been properly investigated. And when you investigate, about half of them you find things that were missing. What we should do is focus much more on what's going wrong. Six-sevenths of those undergoing IVF won't get pregnant - of course they won't - but they'll have no idea why. And there'll be no real attempt to find out why. That's a shocking indictment." And, of course, my follow-up question is what would he do with me? For the first time, he falters. "I don't know." Well. Where shall I end? At the close of our interview, I asked Lord Winston if there was anything in particular on which he would like to put the record straight. I was thinking he might point to public misconceptions about GM foods, BSE, or possibly our fear of genetic engineering. But no. His concerns lie elsewhere. "What did I read in the Guardian this morning? I was really cross. There was Clare Brown [president of the National Infertility Awareness Campaign] being quoted, and the last column said it was in the 80s when we set up patients' support groups. Well - who was the person who first set them up? I bloody set them up! I was the first one, actually, with private income. My income. Clare Brown knows that, actually. She could have actually said so." So now the Guardian has put that important record straight. All honour to the King. He goes on to the full tale of setting up the first support group, presumably hoping that I will also include it in my piece. It's a story he tells with feeling. It was, he says, in response to one patient of tubal surgery. "She said she'd wished she'd never had the operation, because it changed her life: 'Before you operated on me, I knew my tubes were blocked and I knew I couldn't get pregnant. Now I've got open tubes, I live in constant doubt.' I thought, 'Bloody hell!' It had never struck me before. She was the stimulus. Interestingly, she never got pregnant. Never got pregnant. She ended up having IVF years later, and that didn't work either." Lord Winston's promotion of the needs of the infertile, the funding of the NHS, better embryo research and himself continues unabated. In the few weeks between our interview and writing it, the indefatigable Lord had been in the papers at least half-a-dozen times, on issues ranging from Prime Minister's Question Time to the use of animal organs in human patients. As for me, I had a positive pregnancy test. It must have been the red wine.  Superhuman will be broadcast on the BBC in October. The book to the series will be published on October 5 by BBC Worldwide.

fields.headline: Holding back the years
fields.standfirst: Cooking can be a pretty tiring affair, not least when you're no spring chicken any more. Rosie Sykes, Kitchen Doctor, helps out one couple desperate for meals that don't take an age to prepare. Bob Granleese looks on.
fields.trailText: Cooking can be a pretty tiring affair, not least when you're no spring chicken any more. Rosie Sykes, Kitchen Doctor, helps out one couple desperate for meals that don't take an age to prepare. Bob Granleese looks on.
fields.body:
It was the first single-word culinary dilemma that had been sent to Rosie Sykes, Kitchen Doctor, so it would have been churlish to pass it over. "Problem - age!" Norma Haemmerle had written with remarkable succinctness. "At 69, I get tired if I have to spend too much time on preparation. My partner, Richard, is older, and is on a low-cholesterol diet, but we both love to eat. And home-cooked food always tastes better than ready meals/frozen things, etc." How true, thought Rosie, and set her grey matter to devising a set of good-value, easy-to-prepare dishes (the words "one" and "pot" sprang immediately to mind) with which to alleviate Norma's burden, a task complicated just a little by Richard's unshakable aversion to tomato in all its manifestations.

And so it was that the KD arrived one wet summer's day at the Haemmerle's Arnos Grove home - as northern a part of north London as you could find without stumbling into the countryside - laden with enough comestibles to create five mouth-watering meals, each of which would take no longer than half-an-hour to prepare. "Not only will I not have to cook for a week," exclaimed Norma gleefully on seeing bag after bag unpacked in her kitchen, "but Richard - who is very good about saying, 'You look tired', and then going for a takeaway, so I don't have to cook - won't have to trek outside, either."

"Most of this can be cooked and then frozen," explained Rosie, before coming over all worried at the thought of leaving Norma and Richard with five dinners but nowhere to store them: "I hope you have enough room in your freezer."

She needn't have fretted - Norma had been busy: "Actually, I emptied it a bit this morning."

Rosie breathed easier, and set about preparing the first two dishes, pot-roast poussin with apple, parsnip, ginger and potato mash, and spiced lamb with spinach and bulgur. "Cooking would be much easier if I had you here to do the vegetables for me every day," said Norma. "You see, I like to read cookbooks, to drool over the recipes, but when it comes to lunchtime... don't you core the apples?" She seemed a little concerned all of a sudden.

"Oh yes," replied Rosie, " but I always quarter them first. That way, you can make sure you cut out all of those horrid hard white bits in the core - 'toenails', my mother used to call them."

"Ughh -that doesn't sound very appetising," grimaced Norma as she assumed a position next to Richard, giving them the perfect vantage point from which to watch Rosie go about her business, browning the meats, and peeling, chopping and dicing like a mad thing.

"Er, do you use spices much?" asked Rosie, her features again succumbing to that little expression of alarm as she surveyed the fresh and dried spices arrayed on the worktop.

"Oh yes," replied Norma, "in soups and the like, but I don't really know how to use them properly."

"You shouldn't worry about that ," said Rosie, who, it must be said seemed rather relieved at Norma's response. "It's all about trial and error; you work it out as you go along. That's how I learned to use them, anyway - do you cook at all, Richard?"

"Well, I would," he answered, a little sheepishly, "but Norma doesn't really trust my cooking."

"I trust you to open a tin of beans," laughed Norma. But Richard wasn't paying attention - his head was almost in the lamb pot.

"It doesn't need any accompaniment," said Rosie quickly, perhaps for fear that Richard was about to gobble up the pot's contents. "It's got spinach for roughage and bulgur wheat for bulk."

Richard raised his head, apparently drunk on the heady scent of cinnamon and cumin. "It smells magnificent," he said.

Then it was into the oven with the lamb and chicken, and on to the remaining dishes: a soup, a cod-and-bean combo and a clafoutis ("Just a posh word for a toad-in-the-hole type thingy," explained Rosie). But as she set about getting everything ready, Rosie's perturbed demeanour reappeared: "Um . . . I was meant to be doing things that didn't involve too much standing up and chopping, wasn't I, but I seem to have done little else since I got here."

"That's because you're making five meals at once," said Norma, "which is not something I'll be doing, is it?"

"I hadn't thought of that," said Rosie, as if for the first time realising that people in the real world, unlike professional cooks, tend to make only one meal at a time. "The soup will be ready soon, so you could have it for lunch. It's a minestrone sort of thing, only without tomatoes."

"That's in honour of you, Richard," said Norma.

"I expected you just to come here and cook," said Richard, "not to cater to our idiosyncrasies." Mind you, he didn't seem disappointed that she had.

"Well, the whole shebang is geared to you ," said Rosie. "That's why I rang beforehand, to check if there was anything either of you hated."

"Indeed," said Norma. "And I wish I'd been thinking more clearly when you called - I would have asked for nothing but Belgian chocolates!"

The soup was now ready, and the clafoutis and fish were well on their way. "There you go," said Rosie, popping a blob of pesto on top of each soup serving and handing them over to Richard and Norma.

"This is super," said Norma after the first spoonful. "Ahem, sorry, I didn't mean to say that," she said of the unintentional pun. "This is delicious, rather."

Rosie, meantime, was busy checking on her clafoutis. "It smells good," she said. "But then, I'm a sucker for cheese. It looks fantastic, too . . . Oh dear, I've done a lot of blowing my own trumpet today."

"Don't you worry," said Norma benevolently. "I'll second you. It's been a bit like going to a cookery school, except I'm the only pupil."

Richard, who had popped out of the kitchen for a moment, reappeared. "You've come back at the right moment," said Norma. "I don't know how you do it, but you always arrive the moment something comes out of the oven or off the stove."

Richard just grinned contentedly and dived into the clafoutis. "Lovely - but it's a bit hot," he said, puffing his cheeks as if it were burning their insides. He obviously wasn't that incapacitated, however, for he positively pounced on Rosie's next offering, the cod-and-bean stew. "Careful," warned Norma. "That, too, is still very hot."

"It's fabulous," said Richard, taking another forkful. "Never mind just a taste: I'm eating all of this"

All recipes serve two.

Spiced lamb with spinach and bulgur

I've used the bulgur a bit like pearl barley - whatever, it is an excellent way to get some starch into the meal.

1 small onion, chopped
1 clove garlic, crushed
450g diced lamb
2 tsp cinnamon
1 tsp ground cumin
1 tsp ground coriander
4 tbsp plain flour, seasoned
75ml white wine
150ml meat stock
125g frozen, chopped spinach
2 tbsp olive oil
100g bulgur wheat
200ml water
1 tbsp butter
2 tbsp pinenuts
2 tbsp raisins

Preheat the oven to 190C/375F/gas mark 5. Heat the oil in a casserole, toss the lamb in the flour, and add to the casserole, along with the spices (you may need to do this in batches). When all the meat is browned, push it to one side of the pan, add the garlic and onion, and sauté until the onion is soft. Mix everything in the pan together, pour in the wine and stock, bring to the boil, cover, and put into the oven. Leave it to do its thing for about an hour.

Meanwhile, melt the butter in a heavy pan and add the bulgur, stirring to coat all the grains with butter. Add the water, bring to the boil and simmer until the liquid is absorbed - about 15 minutes. Set the cooked wheat to one side.

Return the casserole to the top of the stove, add the spinach and bulgur, bring back to the boil and put back in the oven for around 15 minutes, until the wheat is fully puffed up. Stir in the raisins and pinenuts before serving.

Pot-roast poussin

A great one-pot dish, giving you a meal of crispy poussin with mash and gravy: the end result is fantastically moist.

1 decent-sized poussin
30g butter
1 tbsp oil
lemon, juiced
2 apples, peeled, cored and quartered
2 large baking potatoes, peeled and cut into chunks
2 parsnips, peeled and cut into chunks
1 tsp fresh ginger, peeled and grated
head garlic, peeled
1 splash brandy (optional)
60ml cider
1 bouquet garni

Heat half the butter and oil in a frying pan, pop in the poussin and brown all over. Remove the bird and, while the pan is still hot, add the cider and brandy, stirring to loosen all the bits and cooking flavours in the pan.

Grease a large casserole with the remaining butter. Toss the apple and ginger in lemon juice. Arrange the potatoes, parsnips and apples in the base of the casserole, followed by the garlic cloves. Stuff the juiced lemon and bouquet garni into the poussin's cavity and place the bird, breast-side down, on the apple-and-vegetable bed. Pour over the cider/brandy mix from the pan, cover, and cook in the oven for an hour, until the juices from the bird run clear.

Lift out the bird and leave to rest for a few minutes. Strain off any cooking liquor, to use as a sauce. Mash the solids, or put them in a blender for a smoother result. Cut the poussin in half and serve with the mashed veg, gravy and maybe some peas or broccoli.

Cod with white beans

Based on a delicious recipe from my friend, Sue Lewis, head chef at the Cow in west London. Hers has tomato in it; I have made it without, by request.

450g cod fillets, cut into chunks
1 tbsp oil
1 onion, finely chopped
1 red pepper, cut into strips
2 rashers smoked bacon, de-rinded and chopped into pieces
1 tsp paprika
60ml white wine
375ml fish stock
1 tin cannellini beans
1 clove garlic, crushed
1 handful parsley, chopped
1 lemon, rind grated

Heat the oil in a heavy-based pan, add the bacon and fry until it begins to brown. Add the onion, and sweat until soft. Add the red pepper and paprika, and sauté until soft. Pour in the wine and reduce by half. Chuck in the beans and stock, bring to the boil, and simmer for 15 minutes to let the flavours come together. If you run low on liquid, top up with water. Season the fish, add it to the pot, and simmer over a low heat for 10 minutes until the flesh is opaque, a sign that it is cooked.

Meanwhile, mix together the garlic, parsley and lemon zest (a mixture known as gremolata), stir into the casserole and serve immediately with some good bread and a green salad.

Savoury clafoutis

A nice, quick lunch dish, or a side dish to grilled meat or sausages. These quantities make more than enough for two, but you can freeze them.

55g plain flour, sifted and seasoned
1 egg
70ml milk mixed with 70ml water
45g pitted black olives
4 spring onions, finely chopped
55g taleggio (or mozzarella)
55g Parmesan, grated
4 anchovy fillets, chopped
Butter, for greasing

Preheat the oven to 190C/375F/gas mark 5. Tip the flour into a bowl. Beat the egg into the water/milk mix. Make a well in the centre of the flour, tip in the egg mixture, stir to dissolve the flour, and leave to stand. Grease a baking tin (or tins) and put it in the fridge. Roughly chop the olives, break the taleggio into chunks and tip into a bowl, along with the anchovies and spring onions. Mix together and check the seasoning.

Pour a little batter into the bottom of the tin, put a generous spoonful of the cheese, anchovy and onion mixture on top, and fill the baking tin with the remaining batter. Sprinkle with Parmesan and bake for 30-35 minutes, until the clafoutis is risen and golden. If you're making a big one, this may take up to 45 minutes. Serve immediately with a salad.

Big soup

My version of a minestrone-style soup. I use chickpeas instead of white beans, because I love their nutty, earthy taste. The stock and pesto can be homemade, of course, but we're going for speed and ease here. Also, a tin of tomatoes would not go amiss, but I have not used any because Richard really doesn't like them.

1 tin chickpeas (or 350g dried chickpeas, soaked, drained and cooked)
55g soup pasta, or even spaghetti broken into 4cm lengths
1 litre vegetable stock
2 leeks, trimmed and sliced
1 head broccoli, broken into florets, the stalks peeled and cut into slices
1 courgette, cut into rounds
1 head fennel, trimmed and sliced
1 large carrot, peeled and cubed
55g French beans, top and tailed
6 new potatoes, washed and halved
2 large tbsp pesto
2 slices white bread
1 clove garlic, peeled

Put the carrot, new potatoes, fennel and leeks in large pan with the stock, bring to the boil and simmer for 30 minutes. Add the chickpeas, courgettes, beans, broccoli and pasta, then simmer for 10 minutes. Taste and season.

Toast the bread, rub it with garlic (the toast will act like a grater), drizzle with olive oil and place in the bottom of two soup bowls. Ladle over the soup, top with a little pesto, and stir in the pesto before you take a mouthful

 Do you have a culinary problem that needs the Kitchen Doctor's expert treatment? Write, with brief details of your domestic set-up and daytime phone number, to Kitchen Doctor, Guardian Weekend, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER; email, weekend@theguardian.com.

Add the onion, and sweat until soft. Add the red pepper and paprika, and sauté until soft. Pour in the wine and reduce by half. Chuck in the beans and stock, bring to the boil, and simmer for 15 minutes to let the flavours come together. If you run low on liquid, top up with water. Season the fish, add it to the pot, and simmer over a low heat for 10 minutes until the flesh is opaque, a sign that it is cooked. Meanwhile, mix together the garlic, parsley and lemon zest (a mixture known as gremolata), stir into the casserole and serve immediately with some good bread and a green salad. Savoury clafoutis A nice, quick lunch dish, or a side dish to grilled meat or sausages. These quantities make more than enough for two, but you can freeze them. 55g plain flour, sifted and seasoned 1 egg 70ml milk mixed with 70ml water 45g pitted black olives 4 spring onions, finely chopped 55g taleggio (or mozzarella) 55g Parmesan, grated 4 anchovy fillets, chopped Butter, for greasing Preheat the oven to 190C/375F/gas mark 5. Tip the flour into a bowl. Beat the egg into the water/milk mix. Make a well in the centre of the flour, tip in the egg mixture, stir to dissolve the flour, and leave to stand. Grease a baking tin (or tins) and put it in the fridge. Roughly chop the olives, break the taleggio into chunks and tip into a bowl, along with the anchovies and spring onions. Mix together and check the seasoning. Pour a little batter into the bottom of the tin, put a generous spoonful of the cheese, anchovy and onion mixture on top, and fill the baking tin with the remaining batter. Sprinkle with Parmesan and bake for 30-35 minutes, until the clafoutis is risen and golden. If you're making a big one, this may take up to 45 minutes. Serve immediately with a salad. Big soup My version of a minestrone-style soup. I use chickpeas instead of white beans, because I love their nutty, earthy taste. The stock and pesto can be homemade, of course, but we're going for speed and ease here. Also, a tin of tomatoes would not go amiss, but I have not used any because Richard really doesn't like them. 1 tin chickpeas (or 350g dried chickpeas, soaked, drained and cooked) 55g soup pasta, or even spaghetti broken into 4cm lengths 1 litre vegetable stock 2 leeks, trimmed and sliced 1 head broccoli, broken into florets, the stalks peeled and cut into slices 1 courgette, cut into rounds 1 head fennel, trimmed and sliced 1 large carrot, peeled and cubed 55g French beans, top and tailed 6 new potatoes, washed and halved 2 large tbsp pesto 2 slices white bread 1 clove garlic, peeled Put the carrot, new potatoes, fennel and leeks in large pan with the stock, bring to the boil and simmer for 30 minutes. Add the chickpeas, courgettes, beans, broccoli and pasta, then simmer for 10 minutes. Taste and season. Toast the bread, rub it with garlic (the toast will act like a grater), drizzle with olive oil and place in the bottom of two soup bowls. Ladle over the soup, top with a little pesto, and stir in the pesto before you take a mouthful  Do you have a culinary problem that needs the Kitchen Doctor's expert treatment? Write, with brief details of your domestic set-up and daytime phone number, to Kitchen Doctor, Guardian Weekend, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER; email, weekend@theguardian.com.

fields.headline: A revolutionary eye
fields.standfirst: Tina Modotti, 20s film star, spy and famed beauty, will be remembered, above all, for her photographs. Lindsay Baker looks back on the short life of a woman who inspired passion on both sides of the lens
fields.trailText: Tina Modotti, 20s film star, spy and famed beauty, will be remembered, above all, for her photographs. Lindsay Baker looks back on the short life of a woman who inspired passion on both sides of the lens.
fields.body:
Tina Modotti was always rather dismissive of her beauty - as only the very beautiful tend to be. The photographer Edward Weston was famously smitten by her: his nude portraits of Modotti are among the most arresting images of the 20th century. Diego Rivera immortalised her in his public murals. Pablo Neruda penned her epitaph: "Perfect your gentle name, perfect your fragile life," he wrote. She inspired deep infatuation, great art, poignant poetry.

Modotti's looks served her well throughout her short life, and were instrumental in kick-starting her spell as a 20s Hollywood silent-screen star, the first of several varied careers. Soon after giving up film work, she became the model, lover and apprentice of Weston.

A kind of It girl of the avant-garde, Modotti was both celebrated and vilified in her lifetime. She was well known for her grand romances with illustrious men, and for her apparently effortless knack of inspiring others. "Drama goes with her, has been born with her and will die with her," read one particularly febrile newspaper editorial following the assassination of her communist Cuban lover, Julio Antonio Mella - and a charge against her of conspiracy in his murder.

Add to such high-octane intrigue her political activism in Mexico, Moscow and Europe - not to mention her early and sudden death in 1942, at the age of 46 - and it is easy to see why the Modotti myth has been revisited in recent years. Unsurprisingly, there has been talk of a feature film about her life - she is an immensely versatile icon, representing many things to many people: the dangerous femme fatale; the gentle, tragic spirit; the proto-feminist; the committed revolutionary.

Then, of course, there is the matter of her photography - ultimately, the only real certainty about her. Whatever the feverish speculation that surrounded the cult of her persona - and surrounds it still - Modotti was a great and visionary photographer. Her gifts and passion were unique, and her skill truly groundbreaking. In a photographic career of less than a decade, she produced work that was so startlingly innovative that she is now widely considered to be an important pioneer of modern photography. So much so, in fact, that a few years ago one of her flower studies (Roses, from 1924) commanded nearly $200,000 at auction in New York, an unprecedented amount for the sale of a photograph.

Still, such is the melodrama that surrounds her story - a mythology fuelled by the portraits of her as much as by her own images - that it has tended to colour the perception of her work. Recently shown in Arles, and moving next month to Helsinki, is a new exhibition, Tina Modotti And The Mexican Renaissance, which attempts to strip Modotti of the romanticism that surrounds her, and to present her work in a pure form within a strictly historical context.

"The story of her life has been presented as very Hollywood. Her reputation as a photographer must stand or fall by the intrinsic quality of her work," says the curator of the show, Sam Stourdzé, who describes the exhibition as "austere" in its conception. Excluding both Weston's portraits and Modotti's own famous flower studies, the show concentrates, instead, on her social documentary work in Mexico between 1923 and 1930.

The exhibition was made possible by a surprise discovery. In 1994, the American biographer Patricia Albers, while researching for a book on Modotti, went to Oregon to meet the family of her subject's first husband, Roubaix de L'Abrie Richéy, an American poet of French-Canadian origin known as Robo. The family directed Albers to their attic, where she found two crates packed with papers, letters, telegrams - and some original photographs and contact sheets that had never before been seen in public. They had been sent to Robo's mother, with whom Modotti had stayed in touch following her husband's death in 1923. The provenance was without doubt; many of the pictures even bore the photographer's distinctive handwriting on their reverse sides, "like postcards", says Stourdzé. The exhibition is the first showcase in Europe for these photographs, and they will be displayed alongside photographs from the private collection of New York dealer Truck Morton.

It is, perhaps, no surprise that Modotti was so drawn to Mexico. She said that it reminded her of her homeland. Born into a working-class family in Udine, northern Italy, in 1896, Modotti had followed her father and sister to California in 1913. She found work as a seamstress, but soon emerged from obscurity when she took to the stage in the theatres of the San Francisco Italian community and, following her marriage to Robo, the Hollywood studio world. She enjoyed some success on the silent-movie screen, although she was always typecast as a gypsy or harem girl. "The exotic allure of Tina Modotti," proclaimed a poster for The Tiger's Eye of 1920. "They could not picture an Italian girl except with a knife in her teeth and blood in her eye," Weston later wrote.

Modotti soon tired of the movie world, however, and - spurred on by her adulterous liaison with Weston - she became increasingly drawn to photography. There is no doubt that she benefited from the tutelage of the brilliant Weston: much can be seen of his influence in her work - she quickly assimilated his formal, rigorous skill in composition and meticulous approach to developing and printing. Photography became her passion, and even when the relationship with Weston foundered, she ensured that the apprenticeship thrived.

Despite her affair, it seems that Modotti's marriage to Robo was still functioning. It was Robo who first left for Mexico, in 1921, and his wife planned to join him later. A couple of months into his stay, however, he became ill with smallpox and, after a violent few days, died. Despite Robo's death, Modotti went to Mexico as planned, where she set up her own studio in Mexico City and began to earn her living through portrait photography while continuing to work on her increasingly politically-conscious photographs.

In 1910, the 34-year dictatorship of General Porfirio Diaz had collapsed into a brutal conflict that tore Mexico apart. It wasn't until a decade later that hostilities subsided, and when the left-wing leader General Alvaro Obregon came to power in 1920, the nation experienced a burst of creative energy and optimism. Modernisation was getting underway, and the arts were, for the first time in living memory, being treated with a new seriousness. An ambitious cultural policy was coming into play, combining social and educational initiatives. Little wonder that intellectuals, writers, poets and artists were drawn to Mexico City, which quickly established itself as the central axis of this cultural renewal and became home to an artistic revolution. It was not only painters such as Diego Rivera, Frida Kahlo and David Alfaro Siqueiros who were exponents of the new vision; photographers, too, played a major role.

Modotti quite easily found a place for herself in Mexico's artistic renaissance. She was especially struck by the work of the muralists, who encapsulated the mood of a country emerging from dictatorship and unrest: the desire to rediscover the country's pre-Hispanic traditions and renew its Indian roots was at the heart of the new movement, whatever the pictorial innovations it pioneered. "The Indian people of Mexico became like her family," says Stourdzé. So much so, in fact, that Modotti, shocked by what she had heard about her native Italy under fascist rule, joined the Mexican Communist party in 1927.

Weston taught her much, but the humanity and social engagement in Modotti's work are all her own. She photographed the life around her with such a revolutionary fervour that many of her pictures were published in the Mexican communist party's El Machete newspaper. She allied herself to the Estridentista, or Stridentist movement, a circle of writers and artists with internationalist aspirations for their country. It was a time when many photographers were clinging to a romantic ideal of Mexico, yet Modotti concentrated on the urban reality: she focused on Mexico as a nation in transition, and photographs such as those of telephone wires and telegraph poles became symbolic of the industrial modernisation that held such promise. Such images were rigorously constructed and, with their bold patterns and vertiginous angles, a million miles from the bucolic sensibility that was the norm at the time.

This is not to say that Modotti was immune to "exoticism"; on the contrary, she was equally drawn to the picturesque drama of Mexican life, and her subjects are ennobled in her images. Many of the pictures discovered by Patricia Albers present images of workers as valiant heroes: Indians Carrying Blocks Of Stone ... (1927), for example, and Indians Carrying Corn Husks ... (1927) depict Mexico's indigenous population as the backbone of the country. Her work also emphasised the shortcomings of government institutions, capturing the stark contrasts between the lives of the rich and the poor by juxtaposing urban squalor with bourgeois scenes.

Also among the new finds is an arresting image of a young girl writing. It's an image full of hopefulness: at that time, around 80% of the population were illiterate, and the government were introducing a literacy programme. Alongside this picture were found numerous street scenes of women and children going about their daily business in harsh conditions, some of them shot in soft focus. The photographs Making Tortillas and Women With Children Doing Laundry, along with the images of women carrying heavy loads on their heads, portray stoicism in adversity and a tenderness towards the subjects that stops just short of sentimentality. Modotti's emotional engagement, made almost abstract by the European modernism she had inherited from Weston, makes for some striking invention. In the shot of a political rally in 1928, before the murder of Obregon, the bold patterns made by the straw sombreros and draped white cotton clothing seem like symbols of quiet order amid tumult.

Hands Resting On A Tool, meanwhile, a now almost-iconic image, is shown in the exhibition alongside one of Albers's discoveries, a shot of the gnarled feet and battered toenails of a Mexican-Indian worker in hyper-real glory. They make an arresting sight, as does the 1929 portrait of Modotti wearing Tehuantepec Indian costume - a self- portrait, and not a particularly accomplished photo, but a telling moment in the life of a woman for whom Mexico had become a kind of spiritual home.

The photograph of the mother nursing her baby, in which the feeding infant's eyes are open, is also one of the newly discovered pictures. It is a particularly poignant shot, bearing in mind Modotti's own experiences. She was unable to have children - a string of grand passions transformed her life, but she died alone, with no family. All the more ironic, then, that Rivera miscasts Modotti as an earth mother in one of his murals high above the altar in a Mexican cathedral. Stourdzé is philosophical on the subject. "I think that it was because she had no family life that she was a great artist. She put everything into her photographs."

Modotti's relationship with Julio Antonio Mella, the leader of the Cuban communist party who was living in exile in Mexico, drew her more deeply into political life. But after just four months together, Mella was assassinated as the couple were walking along a street in Mexico City. In the aftermath of his death, Modotti was arrested and tried for conspiracy in the murder, and the Mexican newspapers made headlines out of the false allegations. At the same time, Modotti was viewed as the official "widow" of the martyred hero, and became a kind of mascot for the international revolutionary movement.

Modotti was eventually acquitted, but by 1930 all foreign communists were being expelled from Mexico. The authorities were watching Modotti closely, and became convinced - not without cause - that her house had become a base for insurgents. She was implicated, falsely, in a conspiracy to kill the Mexican president, and was deported. She spent the rest of the decade based in Moscow as a Soviet agent and apparatchik, and during the Spanish Civil War acted as an organiser with Red Aid. When the republican cause was dashed, she returned to Mexico, an exile with a false passport, and - together with her new lover, the Spanish Civil War hero Vittorio Vidali - became involved again in political work. She died there from a heart attack, although rumours suggested foul play or even suicide.

Modotti remained in the public eye - in Weston's nudes and Rivera's murals - even after her fashionableness as a photographer had faded, and the press remained intrigued by her starry presence. When she arrived in the US following her deportation from Mexico in 1930, press photographers scrabbled to take her picture. Trying to convince her to pose for them, they promised to make her look pretty. She later described the scene in a letter to Weston, adding, "I could not understand what prettiness had to do with the revolutionary movement."

 Tina Modotti And The Mexican Renaissance will show at Helsinki City Art Museum from September 12-November 15. A book of the exhibition, with 80 reproductions, is published by Jean Michel Place and is available from www.jmplace.com.
