webTitle: Ferguson warns Keane over uncharitable assault

fields.headline: Ferguson warns Keane over uncharitable assault
fields.trailText: Sir Alex Ferguson has warned Roy Keane he will not tolerate any more "unacceptable" ill discipline from his troubled Manchester United captain.
fields.body:
Sir Alex Ferguson has warned Roy Keane he will not tolerate any more "unacceptable" ill discipline from his troubled Manchester United captain.

Ferguson has instructed Keane to change his ways after his Charity Shield sending-off for a studs-up hack at Chelsea's Gustavo Poyet, the seventh red card of his United career.

"I've had a word with Roy to remind him of his responsibilities and duties as captain of our club," Ferguson disclosed yesterday. "He was upset because of a tackle by Jimmy Hasselbaink but he knows it was unacceptable to react that way.

"It was a matter of reminding him how far he has come as captain. He has done fantastically well and there has been a major all-round improvement in his game and maturity. We don't want that to be wasted; he has accepted that."

As Ferguson rarely criticises his players in public, it is clear Keane has been on the receiving end of the manager's infamous "hairdryer" treatment. But there is no suggestion that Ferguson would entertain the possibility of changing captains.

David O'Leary has agreed a new contract at Leeds, making him the best-paid manager in England at an estimated £10m over six years.

"Over a few bottles of champagne a couple of nights ago we shook hands and agreed a deal," said the Leeds chairman Peter Ridsdale. "It will be formally signed over the weekend."

Asked whether it made O'Leary the highest-earning manager in England, Ridsdale said: "I believe it will. I think David believes it will and I think that's why we reached such a swift conclusion."

The Leeds strikers Harry Kewell and Mark Viduka have been included in the Australia squad for the Olympics.

The Republic of Ireland will be without Leeds's Stephen McPhail and Wimbledon's Kenny Cunningham because of injury when they play Holland in their opening World Cup qualifier on September 2.

Brazil, beaten 3-0 by Chile in a World Cup qualifier on Tuesday, have recalled Romario for their next match against Bolivia. Romario has not played a full international since April 1998. The former Middlesbrough midfielder Juninho is also included.

webTitle: Chelsea well-placed to capitalise on charity

fields.headline: Chelsea well-placed to capitalise on charity
fields.trailText: I felt Manchester United had two or three gears to go up during the Charity Shield but I still reckon the outcome at Wembley was a pointer for the season. And that means Chelsea as Premiership champions with United runners-up.
fields.body:
I felt Manchester United had two or three gears to go up during the Charity Shield but I still reckon the outcome at Wembley was a pointer for the season. And that means Chelsea as Premiership champions with United runners-up.

I see Gianluca Vialli's team as a major force not so much because of Sunday's game but on the basis of the balance in the side. Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink and Mario Stanic will give more power and goals potential, and I like the look of Hasselbaink a lot.

He's quick, he plays against the last man and his link-up play is tidier than it was before he moved to Spain. So he not only gives Chelsea a new option but can also join in the possession football they enjoy. As for Stanic, he's technically sound and excellent in the air, and I expect him to get in at the far stick and score headers.

If there is one area where Chelsea might be short of top-drawer balance it's in the centre of midfield, although I see an obvious solution. To my mind Dennis Wise needs someone different alongside him, and I'm convinced Mario Melchiot would do a sensational job. He could do what Patrick Vieira does for Arsenal.

I've seen Melchiot play twice as a right-back at Wembley and he impressed me a lot. He's powerful, tidy and showed against United that he can score. With Christian Panucci and Albert Ferrer able to step into that full-back position I would move Melchiot into midfield. From what I understand he's not only played a lot there but prefers it.

Of the other factors that point towards Chelsea, their qualification for the Uefa Cup rather than the Champions League is significant. That means not only fewer games and potentially easier draws in Europe to start with, allowing Vialli to rest a few, but provides a different focus. It is the Premiership that really matters now.

Last season Marcel Desailly didn't always seem to be focused on the mundane league matches, and for me he is the barometer of this Chelsea side. If he desperately wants a championship medal he has got enough in his locker to pull the others towards it.

Of course writing off United is dangerous, and it is definitely best to take not the slightest notice of last Sunday. Don't forget they have lost the last three Charity Shields, and when I was in charge at Old Trafford in 1985 we were beaten by Everton in the Charity Shield, written off and won the first 10 league matches.

Sir Alex Ferguson has the best midfield quartet in the country and four great strikers, but I would have liked to have seen them take a top-class central defender. I think Michael Reiziger would have been a great signing from Barcelona. He's played with Jaap Stam for Holland and could fill in at full-back. As it is, I'm not sure United's back-line is as strong as it should be for a team of their standing. Denis Irwin is not getting any younger and it will be interesting to see how Gary Neville copes. Last season was not his best.

Liverpool, as it happens, are my tip for third spot. They have a massive array of talent but I'm not sure they yet have the blend to win the title. I can't see them gelling every week, although I think Gérard Houllier has made the signing of the summer in Gary McAllister. I would not be surprised if he emerged as their best player.

Arsenal will probably have to settle for fourth. They could regret selling Stephen Hughes now that Emmanuel Petit has gone, but I don't see the departures of Petit and Marc Overmars to Barcelona as the big problem.

Robert Pires has come almost unnoticed into the pot to fill the Overmars role and Vieira, one of my personal favourites, could thrive even more on his responsibility. fields.headline: Tykes haul 'Ingerland' home
fields.standfirst: Home-town heroes drive historic victory Headingley will not forget, says Frank Keating
fields.trailText: Home-town heroes drive historic victory Headingley will not forget, says Frank Keating.
fields.body:
"Ingerland! Ingerland!" they serenaded themselves and their cricket team - "Yorkshire is Ingerland" - all over Leeds well into the evening. And who is to say that the same discordant chorus did not ring out with a proud resonance in other parts of the land?

Certainly British sport needed cheering up and England's cricketers responded with one of the game's most historic victories. All over Leeds there was a buzz that ensured no one would ignore that it was three Yorkshiremen - Darren Gough, Chris White and Michael Vaughan (in addition to Somerset's Andy Caddick) - in the vanguard of an unbelievable win.

So frenetic has been recent Test cricket that unless the weather has prolonged affairs, the five-day Test has seemed increasingly an anachronism. But a two-day Test - 40 wickets in less than six sessions - is a different kettle of climax altogether. There have only been two two-dayers played in England before.

All of 88 summers ago, in 1912, an experimental triangular series was held between the home side and tourists from Australia and South Africa. At the Oval, England scored 176 then knocked off their second-innings target inside two days to win by 10 wickets.

Nine summers later Test cricket resumed after the war and at Trent Bridge in 1921 the Australian pace bowlers Gregory and Macdonald scattered the English batsmen for 112 and 147 for another 10-wicket victory. And that was that for England's two-dayers this century.

The last Test match to end inside two days was in March 1946 on a wretched pitch at Wellington, the first international match following another war. Australia declared at 199 for eight then bowled New Zealand twice out for 42 and 54 - and were so dismissively snooty about it that they refused to play their neighbours again till 1973.

So historians will log yesterday for ever in gold leaf. And how. As the excited throng from a full house leapt from the perimeter hoardings to pour itself all over the old northern paddock and the frantic hosts of broadcasters desperately thrust microphones under the noses of every participant in white as well as, it seemed, every one of their attendant sisters, mothers, cousins and aunts, one had to admit pangs of sadness at seeing the humiliated West Indians slinking away. So long have they been cocks of the walk, yesterday for them was a painful fall and a very heavy one.

But in their chivalrous captain Jimmy Adams they have an honourable man willing and ready to give best: "England were simply terrific. They got us on the run and then sustained it. The skids were under us. But no excuses really. The bottom line is that us West Indians have to show far more mettle and be much more consistent."

England's captain Nasser Hussain got high marks here for singling out the three Yorkshiremen, especially the contagiously ebullient Gough: "Darren is an inspiration. As a bowler he gets the key players out. You just put the ball in his hand and say 'wipe off the top order'. He does the business.

"In both innings it was Darren who simply put us ahead of the game. Then he inspires the others to keep the pressure on.

"Batting on Thursday the pitch was pretty poor and even worse when they took the new ball. But it wasn't the pitch that had anything to do with our bowling this afternoon - it was simply top quality swing bowling.

"I always thought Andy [Caddick] would react when I changed him to the southern end where Darren had been so wonderful. I couldn't put Andy on there in the first innings because Craig had been so terrific. So this afternoon it was just a case of waiting for Darren to need a little rest so I could make the switch."

But as well as England's cricketing credibility being marvellously perked up this summer - first the thriller at Lords, now yesterday - so of late has Yorkshire's. Once upon a time you - or they did anyway - took it for granted that at least a third of any England eleven would be Yorkshiremen.

Grand triumvirates come to mind like Sutcliffe, Hirst and Rhodes; Leyland, Bowes and Verity; Hutton, Yardley and Wardle; Trueman, Illingworth and Close. Yesterday Vaughan, White and Gough became the latest trio to seal their mark on posterity for the Tykes and for "Ingerland" in the most famous two-day Test match of them all.

webTitle: Had an accident? Not your fault? Watching the Test?

fields.headline: Had an accident? Not your fault? Watching the Test?
fields.standfirst: Jim White on the week's real television highlight, and it had nothing to do with Big Brother
fields.trailText: Jim White on the week's real television highlight, and it had nothing to do with Big Brother.
fields.body:
So where were you when Channel 4's historic television moment was aired on Thursday? No, not the insignificant thing with Nasty Nick being rumbled by his house-mates. The truly important transmission showing Cunning Curtly taking his 400th Test wicket.

The hydraulic arms, the smile that could have illuminated an indoor cricket match, the Headingley crowd generous in its appreciation: I was glad to be watching.

As it happens, it was no surprise I caught the moment. The sustained excitement of this Test series, enjoying two well matched but flawed teams slug it out, has been a nightmare for anyone attempting to work at home.

"Just another five minutes", "wait till the next wicket", "see how Hick gets on" have been the mental mantras accompanying the loss of hours of productive work.

Some have bemoaned the interruption of commercials as the only drawback of Channel 4's excellent coverage. Personally, I'm grateful for the intrusion of cheesy ads for ambulance-chasing lawyers and electric garage doors. Frankly, if it weren't for Christopher Timothy popping up every 20 minutes advising the over-50s to buy life insurance, this column would never have been written.

webTitle: One last chance to gain a little respect

fields.headline: One last chance to gain a little respect
fields.standfirst: Donna Symmonds on how the tourists need to find their fight again if the humiliation of Headingley is to be repaired
fields.trailText: Donna Symmonds on how the tourists need to find their fight again if the humiliation of Headingley is to be repaired.
fields.body:
It will take some masterly manoeuvrings to restore the West Indies' mental state and overall spirit and stop England winning the series now.

Their batting has looked fragile throughout and those failures have been compounded by the below-par efforts of the bowlers supporting Courtney Walsh and Curtly Ambrose. And now it has come to this - humiliation at Headingley.

There must be no attempt to blame the pitch. Both sides batted on it and England made 272 in their one and only innings with imaginative and clever tactics brilliantly executed. This game was won in England's heads and hearts.

At no stage of the second day could West Indies bring to bear the resolve to fight and counter-attack that they showed at Edgbaston, Old Trafford and even Lord's. And that is what the team management will be most worried about. The team had the look of the defeated throughout the day. They need deliverance - and fast.

It is not beyond them. What must be summoned up is the same attitude that has seen West Indies through when times looked darkest. In the dim and seemingly distant past, the West Indians were always at their most dangerous when down. That return to old ways must come from the class players and the experienced players in the side. They must show resilience and they must build on the few positives that came out of this Test.

They are: the batting of Ramnaresh Sarwan, who ended the match undefeated in both innings; the sustained high-class bowling of the opening pair; and the return to some semblance of form with the bat by Ridley Jacobs.

The knowledge that the Oval pitch is unlikely to resemble the Headingley strip must induce the West Indies to refine the balance of their bowling attack. It may involve brave decisions and a break from tradition.

Nothing can detract from the England performance. The batting attack and bowling of the seamers was exemplary and the win more than deserved.

But West Indies will know and must repeat the mantra that the series is not over. They have so much to play for, not least of which is pride. Some future places may also be in the balance. The ultimate Test is still to come.

fields.headline: Round-up
fields.trailText: When Michael Bevan dropped a sitter off South Africa's Mark Boucher in Melbourne yesterday, he did not merely cost Australia victory. By dislocating a knuckle, he may well have scuppered Sussex's prospects of promotion.
fields.body:
When Michael Bevan dropped a sitter off South Africa's Mark Boucher in Melbourne yesterday, he did not merely cost Australia victory. By dislocating a knuckle, he may well have scuppered Sussex's prospects of promotion.

The less than impeccable timing of Bevan's absence and injury - his championship average is 78 - was rammed home at Eastbourne yesterday. Resuming on 45 for seven with a further - not to say improbable - 183 required to deny the Second Division leaders Northamptonshire a fourth successive win, Chris Adams and Nick Wilton extended their alliance to 36 before Paul Taylor defeated the wicketkeeper and Jason Lewry with consecutive balls.

Mark Robinson resisted for 10 deliveries before Taylor earned the distinction of being the first bowler in this season's championship to dismiss the erstwhile duffer's duffer. The veteran left-armer finished with six for 27 as Sussex folded for 65 to complete a second thumping defeat by Northants in six days.

Adams did his manful best to fill the Bevan void. Unbowed on 24, his match haul was 108 runs off 221 balls; colleagues combined for 319 balls and 85 runs.

When Bobby Simpson took up the coaching reins at Lancashire last winter, the scent of a first outright pennant since the Depression became a heady whiff. All the more reason, then, to appreciate the extent of the angst that has accompanied the club's subsequent fitfulness.

Sourav Ganguly has proved a less than adequate replacement for Muttiah Muralitharan but, more pertinently, Simpson's charges have missed the experience and steadiness of Peter Martin.

Fortunately, after missing two months with a hand injury, the former England seamer is making a timely and fruitful comeback.

At Old Trafford, Matty Walker and Alan Wells helped hoist Kent from 14 for four to 127 for five but the last five men went for 28, Martin taking five for 42 for a lead of 80. The quicks, inevitably, continued to hold sway, Lancashire stumbling to 43 for six as David Masters affirmed his candidacy for an A tour.

Then up popped that faithful retainer Neil Fairbrother, doubling the score in harness with Chris Schofield and probably settling the outcome.

Yorkshire , meanwhile, could only watch the rain fall on Grace Road where their match against Leicestershire was a wash-out.

webTitle: Law takes it into his own hands

fields.headline: Law takes it into his own hands
fields.standfirst:
Gloucestershire 324 & 197
Essex 174 & 141-4
fields.trailText:
Gloucestershire 324 & 197
Essex 174 & 141-4
fields.body:
In this historic Roman town, Stuart Law, in full armour, seemed to be moving with the assertive stride of a centurion towards a win that he had refused to accept might be inaccessible.

As if mocking his side's daunting target of 348, he paraded a repertoire of bold attacking shots off a Gloucestershire range of bowlers that had rarely threatened Law's technical mastery and footwork. Then, just before the close, he was superbly held at slip by Martyn Ball off Ben Gannon.

Law, who passed 1,000 runs for the season during his innings, had belted seven fours off 90 balls, never remotely inhibited by the balance of this match. Essex still need 207, a tall order.

At his side was Paul Grayson, succeeding for the second time in this game. There was perhaps less flourish, less power and audacity. But his contribution to the stand had much merit, before he was out offering no stroke to Ball.

There may be something appropriate about military medium at this garrison town. Alleyne's controlled pace, in fact, demanded more attention from Law than the new-ball bowlers, who, striving for speed, too often erred in length and direction. The predictions of sustained spin have not materialised. The ball rarely turned all day.

If Gloucestershire had qualms about not enforcing the follow-on, their reservations may have increased when Tim Hancock was out to the fifth ball of the morning, parting company with his off-stump. In Ashley Cowan's next over, Alleyne was caught at slip. Cowan, dropped earlier this season, went on to take five wickets and also bowled Kim Barnett off a no-ball.

Gloucestershire had done their calculations but these had not taken into account the early dismissals that threatened to dissipate the first- innings lead of 150. Barnett and Chris Taylor, old and young, redressed the anxieties. They searched for runs: Barnett punched through the covers and Taylor prettily angled his bat with assertive strokes that obscured his greenhorn status.

But Taylor went immediately after lunch and Jack Russell soon followed. It had not been up to then a memorable match for batsmen - on the ground, after all, where Kent's Arthur Fagg once hit a double hundred in each innings. After Barnett spooned into the covers, it was left to Jeremy Snape, a batsman at his best when making crisp shots, and Ball, the off-spinner who fancies his batting.

In again, Essex appeared to be facing an ascent more marked than the steep climb up to Colchester's famous museum and clock tower. It did not help when Paul Prichard failed for a second time, caught by Ball's ever-reliable hands at first slip.

webTitle: Boucher cuts as Rhodes rides storm and South Africa salvage their pride

fields.headline: Boucher cuts as Rhodes rides storm and South Africa salvage their pride
fields.standfirst:
South Africa 226-8
Australia 226-9
Match tied
fields.trailText:
South Africa 226-8
Australia 226-9
Match tied
fields.body:
Australia and South Africa produced a repeat of their epic World Cup semi-final at Edgbaston last year when they tied the second of their three one-day internationals in Melbourne yesterday.

The hosts looked to have the upper hand at the indoor Docklands stadium after restricting the South Africans to 226 for eight from 50 overs and then cruising to 164 for three. But the Proteas struck back as the world champions lost their next five wickets for just 50 runs to collapse to 214 for eight.

With all their recognised batsmen departed, Australia needed 13 off the final over; they managed 12 and forced a tie when Shane Warne scrambled through for a single off the final ball. "It's a fair indication of the closeness of the two sides," the Australian captain Steve Waugh said. "We probably both thought we should have won the game so it was probably a fair result."

After winning Wednesday's opening match of the three-game series by 94 runs with an imposing total of 295, the Australians seemed to be on target to clinch the series after the South African innings.

Australia's fast bowler Jason Gillespie, in his second international following long-term injury, clean bowled Jacques Kallis for 22 in his first spell, then returned to pick up the wickets of the all-rounders Lance Klusener and Shaun Pollock to finish on three for 40.

The part-timer bowlers Andrew Symonds and Ian Harvey both collected two wickets apiece as the visitors slumped to 95 for four before Jonty Rhodes and Mark Boucher rescued them with a fifth-wicket stand of 87. Rhodes top-scored with 54 despite batting with a runner after injuring his groin midway through his innings. Mark Boucher contributed 51 after being dropped by Michael Bevan on five.

Bevan, who dislocated his finger dropping Boucher, was forced to pad-up after Australia's run chase went so badly awry. Klusener and the part-time medium-pacer Andrew Hall were the surprise heroes with Hall taking two for eight from three overs.

Mark Waugh (48), Gilchrist (37) and Ricky Ponting (39) gave the home side the perfect start but no one was able to go on and make a big score. Steve Waugh hit a quick 30, including 14 off one Pollock over, before being bowled in the penultimate over, leaving Warne to chase the remaining 13 off the final over.

Federal investigations in India into allegations of match-fixing are likely to end next month. "They will most probably wind up the investigations by September 15," said AC Muthiah, president of the Indian board of control. "That's what we want . . . otherwise the morale of the players is going down."

webTitle: Now is the time to bet on sport

fields.headline: Now is the time to bet on sport
fields.trailText: Now is the time to bet on sport. The conditions have never been more favourable for making big money from punting on pastimes.
fields.body:
Now is the time to bet on sport. The conditions have never been more favourable for making big money from punting on pastimes. At the track, you don't have to pay any tax. And if you bet with the spread betting firms the tax is included in the spread.

This prudent Chancellor is happy for sensible sports investors to keep their winnings. Compare and contrast with those fools who invest in What.com and the like. They have to pay dealing costs and when they pick a winner shell out 40 per cent in capital gains tax. A fair and reasonable levy to restrain such reckless gambling.

The differing treatment goes back to the courts being unwilling to sully their hands by dealing with filthy gambling disputes. 'Bets are legally unenforceable,' the judges decreed. And so it continued until the early Fifties when Churchill's government attempted to tax professional gamblers. Stupidly, they didn't ring-fence the provision to ensure that gambling losses could only be offset against gambling profits. Every butcher, baker and candlestick maker promptly claimed to be a pro gambler and set off their betting losses against the money they had made from meat, bread and wax. The government gave up.

Since then, betting shops were allowed to open so long as they resembled Hades. And everything was fine until Black Monday when some young speculators managed to do all their dough and then some. The Footsie fell hundreds and hundreds of points and the whippersnappers lost hundreds and hundreds of times their money. Decision time for Their Lordships. It is traditionally argued that hard cases make bad law, but in truth it is when the judges' prejudices come into play that duff judgments are spouted. They hummed and they hawed. It looked like gambling but it was done on the stock exchange. So it couldn't be gambling because if it was then... then... everything would be gambling. And then they'd be in a pickle.

To avoid such a fate they found that, despite all appearances to the contrary, the young guns hadn't been gambling, their debts were therefore enforceable and they should pay up promptly. They covered up this faulty logic by pointing out that the spread-betting firms were regulated by the Financial Services Act just like stockbrokers et al. Irrelevant, but sufficient.

You might have thought that it would follow from this that monies made from spread betting should be subject to capital gains tax just like monies made from other activities regulated by the FSA. Not a bit of it. 'A lot of people ask me that if it's [a spread bet] enforceable then why isn't it subject to Capital Gains Tax?' says Stuart Wheeler, head of IG Index, grandfather of spread betting, professional bridge player, and all-round shrewdie. 'But there is no connection between the two. Nor is it likely that the bets will be subject to tax in the future because the idea of making people pay tax on any betting profits is not a popular one and certainly not an election winner.'

The absence of CGT has saved Philip Peters, the star of Tuesday's edition of the much-improved Jackpot television series, a quarter of a million or so in tax because in the past five years he made £600,000 from spread betting. Peters' career has been picaresque. Here is his CV with, admittedly, somewhat sketchy dates:

1958-1963: Regular employment.

1963: Ceases regular employment.

1964: Having raised his stake money betting on photo-finishes at Reading dogs, realises that good money can be made backing second favourites each-way when there is a long odds-on favourite. 'You'd be getting 6-4 against when it should be 3-1 on,' says Peters.

1965-67: Works out way to make money on the Tote. 'When the bookies opened they would take any bet on anything and there was no minimum dividend. So if a dog was 8-1 on you'd get the same price for a place. There was nothing very clever about it.'

1967-72: Refines system and becomes heavily involved in Tote rigging. 'I was betting at Hastings dogs one afternoon and realised how little money was gambled on the place pool. It cost me very little to increase the minimum dividend and it worked very well.'

1972-77: Becomes very heavily involved in Tote rigging. 'I had 80 OAPs up and down the country working for me betting 12 of the straight forecast combinations off the track and we were betting the others at the track. We made a lot of money.'

1982: Wife nags him into getting a proper job on grounds of 'status'. He invests in a company making plastic containers for then new-in-the-kitchen microwave ovens. Dumb move. 'I'm the only person I know who got all his money from gambling and lost it all in straight business.'

1982-94: A bad dozen years.

1994: Introduced to spread betting. 'All I had was three years' worth of Racing Posts .'

1994-2000: Cleans up.

He has made his money primarily from betting on the spreads offered on horse-race distances, but has also trousered tidy sums from betting on the bookings index and the corners index. On all three markets he has sold. His reasoning is simple. Most punters find it psychologically soothing for their downside to be limited and their upside to be unlimited. They know exactly how much they can lose and can dream about how much they might win.

On the horse-race distances, about 19 out of 20 players would be buyers. Peters, a contrarian at heart, went the other way and turned nothing into £200,000. He has bad days - there have been a couple of £40,000 losses - but most days are good. He has used the same principles to win on corners and bookings. He has made healthy profits by taking the 'uncomfortable position' where you win a little often and lose a lot rarely and come out on top.

On the bookings index, in particular, he has been helped by the usual tabloid hype about card-crazy referees. The punters, whipped into a frenzy as effectively as Rebekah Wade inciting the unthinking majority, can't help themselves and buy away. The market is distorted. As Toby Brereton, chief market-maker at IG Index, says: 'Opposing hype is an extremely good tool for any bettor.' The latest market to attract the Peters Principle has been the time of Premiership goals. The spread makers have underestimated the number of goals in a match and therefore gone too high on the time of the opening goal. Once again, he has been selling and winning as the foolish crowd buy in the hope of that elusive big win.

The absence of CGT has saved Philip Peters, the star of Tuesday's edition of the much-improved Jackpot television series, a quarter of a million or so in tax because in the past five years he made £600,000 from spread betting. Peters' career has been picaresque. Here is his CV with, admittedly, somewhat sketchy dates: 1958-1963: Regular employment. 1963: Ceases regular employment. 1964: Having raised his stake money betting on photo-finishes at Reading dogs, realises that good money can be made backing second favourites each-way when there is a long odds-on favourite. 'You'd be getting 6-4 against when it should be 3-1 on,' says Peters. 1965-67: Works out way to make money on the Tote. 'When the bookies opened they would take any bet on anything and there was no minimum dividend. So if a dog was 8-1 on you'd get the same price for a place. There was nothing very clever about it.' 1967-72: Refines system and becomes heavily involved in Tote rigging. 'I was betting at Hastings dogs one afternoon and realised how little money was gambled on the place pool. It cost me very little to increase the minimum dividend and it worked very well.' 1972-77: Becomes very heavily involved in Tote rigging. 'I had 80 OAPs up and down the country working for me betting 12 of the straight forecast combinations off the track and we were betting the others at the track. We made a lot of money.' 1982: Wife nags him into getting a proper job on grounds of 'status'. He invests in a company making plastic containers for then new-in-the-kitchen microwave ovens. Dumb move. 'I'm the only person I know who got all his money from gambling and lost it all in straight business.' 1982-94: A bad dozen years. 1994: Introduced to spread betting. 'All I had was three years' worth of Racing Posts .' 1994-2000: Cleans up. He has made his money primarily from betting on the spreads offered on horse-race distances, but has also trousered tidy sums from betting on the bookings index and the corners index. On all three markets he has sold. His reasoning is simple. Most punters find it psychologically soothing for their downside to be limited and their upside to be unlimited. They know exactly how much they can lose and can dream about how much they might win. On the horse-race distances, about 19 out of 20 players would be buyers. Peters, a contrarian at heart, went the other way and turned nothing into £200,000. He has bad days - there have been a couple of £40,000 losses - but most days are good. He has used the same principles to win on corners and bookings. He has made healthy profits by taking the 'uncomfortable position' where you win a little often and lose a lot rarely and come out on top. On the bookings index, in particular, he has been helped by the usual tabloid hype about card-crazy referees. The punters, whipped into a frenzy as effectively as Rebekah Wade inciting the unthinking majority, can't help themselves and buy away. The market is distorted. As Toby Brereton, chief market-maker at IG Index, says: 'Opposing hype is an extremely good tool for any bettor.' The latest market to attract the Peters Principle has been the time of Premiership goals. The spread makers have underestimated the number of goals in a match and therefore gone too high on the time of the opening goal. Once again, he has been selling and winning as the foolish crowd buy in the hope of that elusive big win.
